Summary: Save This Seat exhibits spotlight relationship violence
Description: Save This Seat is a day-long installation in which a classroom seat is "saved," or left empty, for each young woman killed in Texas in the last four years by an intimate partner. Data for this project are collected and distributed by the Texas Council on Family Violence (http://www.tcfv.org/our-work/honoring-texas-victims). To volunteer, email voicesagainstviolence@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Landmarks Video presents work by Jesse Fleming
Description:
Landmarks Video presents "The Snail and the Razor" (2012) by videographer Jesse Fleming in which a trained snail climbs up and over a razor blade in a single frame. On view throughout October.



Over the past ten years, Fleming has taken his viewers on immersive, transcendent journeys by employing straightforward, uncomplicated methods. Whether focused on a solitary event or space, or on his own experimental voyages, he invites his audience to meditate on the extraordinary acts and behavior of ordinary beings.
Location: Art Building (ART), atrium, Landmarks Video Media Station

Summary: Resident assistant applications available now
Description: Resident assistant (RA) applications are now available and are due Wednesday, Oct. 24. Visit link below.

Summary: Razas de maíz & plant publics are anthropologist's topic
Description:
The Department of Anthropology 

2012-2013 Speaker Series presents a talk by UT anthropology professor John Hartigan titled "Life Forms:  Cultivating Razas de Maíz and Plant Publics." Based on ethnographic research in Mexico and Spain, this talk engages the challenges presented by nonhuman forms of race. 



Starting with a biodiversity genetics research institute and then using a series of botanical gardens as touchstones, Hartigan examines the varieties of parallelisms between plants and people that are developed to make sense of multispecies relations.

Summary: Latin America's new trade dependency is lecture topic
Description: In a talk titled "Deja Vu: Latin America and Its New Trade Dependency," Dr. Jaime Ortiz examines the sources of economic growth for a group of Latin American countries in relation to their export performance in China.

Summary: Edwidge Danticat's Vodou transnationalism is talk topic
Description: The CWGS Speaker Series Brown Bag Lunch presents a talk by Gwen Bergner, West Virginia University, "One and One Is Three: Edwidge Danticat's Vodou Transnationalism." Bergner explores how the Haitian author works to counter negative fantasies of voodoo that have perpetuated the illusion that Haiti remains isolated from modern civilization.

Summary: French anthropology in the 20th century is talk topic
Description:
As part of the EU Center for Excellence Lecture Series in Anthropology, Professor Vincent Debaene, French Department, Columbia University, examines 20th-century French anthropology in a comparative perspective, bringing into relief the cultural specificity of a French disciplinary practice so often considered untranslatable to anthropologists from the English-speaking world.



He will delineate the complex and contradictory identity of an intellectual tradition which, since the 1920s, has made claims to both scientific rigor and avant-garde literary experimentation.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: High-Tech borders in Palestine-Israel to be talk topic
Description: "Digital Occupation: Hi-Tech Borders in Palestine-Israel" is presented by Helga Tawil-Souri, associate professor of media, culture, and communication and Middle East and Islamic studies, New York University.

Summary: "The Hockey Stick & the Climate Wars" author talk presented
Description: Author Michael Mann discusses his book "The Hockey Stick and the Climate Wars: Dispatches from the Front Lines." Mann directs the Penn State Earth System Science Center. Recognized by Scientific American as one of the 50 leading visionaries in science, he shared the Nobel Peace Prize in 2007 with other members of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC).
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Hook 'em Arts hosts general meeting
Description: Hook 'em Arts is the official student voice of Texas Performing Arts. We find creative ways to promote shows around campus, host events in The Loft at Bass and attend performances together as a group. Attend a weekly meeting.
Location: Bass Concert Hall (PAC), The Loft, 6th floor

Summary: Study art in Italy
Description: Learn more about our Learning Tuscany study abroad program at this information session. ARH 374 is taught by Ann Johns, and ART 319T taught by Dan Sutherland, both of the College of Fine Arts.

Summary: Lars von Trier film series continues with "The Idiots"
Description: "The Idiots" (1998) is Lars von Trier's utterly shocking Dogme movie: A group of perfectly intelligent young people decides to react to society's aimlessness and lack of creativity by living together in a community of "idiots." Pretending to be mentally disabled, they attempt to create anarchy everywhere they go.

Summary: Harry Ransom Center presents Geoff Dyer, writer
Description: Novelist and essayist Geoff Dyer, author of "The Ongoing Moment" and "The Missing of the Somme," presents "Close Enough," a lecture about the changes in war writing and war photography over time. Doors open at 6:20 p.m. for members and at 6:30 p.m. for others.

Summary: Fallacies of the public goods theory is Mises Circle topic
Description:
This week's Mises Circle meeting focuses on Hans-Hermann Hoppe's classic "Fallacies of the Public Goods Theory and the Production of Security." Read the material here: https://mises.org/journals/jls/9_1/9_1_2.pdf.



Are roads, education, security or other such goods public goods? Are governments necessary to provide these goods? Or can the market not only provide them but provide them more efficiently and effectively?



Hoppe argues that public goods do not exist, and that the government has no business being involved in the production of any goods, even those seemingly "public."

Summary: UT Symphony Orchestra performs
Description: The UT Symphony Orchestra performs under the direction of Gerhardt Zimmermann, conductor. The program features Corigliano, Gazebo Dances, Martin Concerto for 7 Winds, Dvorak, Symphony No. 9 in E Minor, Op. 9.

Summary: Experts discuss the economy in 2013
Description: A panel of experts discusses the future of the economy, addressing such issues as budget deficits, double-dip recession, Europe's financial challenges, the Dow and the Texas economy. Distinguished panelists are Dean Tom Gilligan, Spencer Berthelsen, M.D. and Steve Felice. Register at http://msb.connect.utexas.edu/economy2013live.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 204

Summary: PCL bake sale to benefit Hearts of Texas
Description:
The Perry-Castañeda Library holds its annual bake sale as part of the Hearts of Texas employee charitable campaign.

Stop by and grab a delicious treat donated by the UT Libraries staff and support a charitable cause.

Summary: Participants needed for language study
Description: The Department of Linguistics seeks native speakers of English ages 18 and over to participate in a study of language processing. A session lasts approximately 1 hour and pays $10 per hour. Contact utlingpsych@gmail.com for more details.

Summary: Red Flag Project spotlights relationship violence awareness
Description: A dynamic art installation titled "Red Flag" highlights warning signs of an abusive relationship. Do you know the red flags of relationship violence? Learn more here:  http://www.cmhc.utexas.edu/dv_redflags.html. This exhibit is part of Relationship Violence Awareness Month.

Summary: Participants ages 55-65 sought for pedometer study
Description: Participants ages 55-65 are sought for a research study to examine the accuracy of pedometers. Participants must be able to walk without difficulty. Payment is $30 upon completion. Contact utcardiovascularrecruitment@gmail.com.

Summary: Texas American College of Sports Medicine lecture presented
Description: Claude Bouchard, Ph.D., professor at Pennington Biomedical Research Center, Louisiana State University, presents "Physical Activity Attenuates the Influence of a Genetic Predisposition to Obesity," the first fall lecture of the Texas American College of Sports Medicine series. Find Bouchard's bio here: http://www.pbrc.edu/research-and-faculty/faculty/?faculty=20.

Summary: Study Czech literature in Prague
Description: Attend an information session to learn about studying Czech literature in Prague.

Summary: UHS holds flu shot clinic at Student Activity Center
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: American power after the financial crisis is lecture topic
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "American Power After the Financial Crisis" with Jonathan Kirshner, professor of international relations and political economy, Cornell University. Refreshments provided.



Kirshner is the author of "Currency and Coercion: The Political Economy of International Monetary Power."

Summary: Natural Sciences Week presents Visualization Lab tours
Description: The College of Natural Sciences houses the highest resolution tiled display in the world. Spanning over 15 feet, the Stallion display is one among the many exciting visualization resources available at the College of Natural Sciences and at the pioneering edge of research and technology. Take an exclusive tour of the Visilab.

Summary: Computer Science hosts internal transfer info session
Description: Learn more about the computer science major. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Chemical Engineering Seminar presents Dr. Shaoyi Jiang
Description: Dr. Shaoyi Jiang, Boeing-Roundhill professor of chemical engineering and adjunct professor of bioengineering at the University of Washington, presents on "Molecular Understanding, Design and Development of Ultra Low Fouling Zwitterionic-based Functional Materials."

Summary: Social Work Maymester in London hosts information session
Description: Attend an information session about the social work Maymester course in London, England, Roots of Social and Economic Justice: An International Perspective.

Summary: Visiting Artists Program presents Sarah Oppenheimer
Description: Sarah Oppenheimer examines our perception of space through sculpture and installation. By creating new apertures in existing structures, she establishes new lines of sight with a play on architectural intervention.

Summary: DDCE pre-college alumni reunion announced
Description: UT students who were once part of a DDCE pre-college program such as UT Outreach, ChemBridge or SPURS are invited to reconnect with other alumni from those programs and, together, learn of resources on campus to ensure your success. Free food served. Email thais@austin.utexas.edu if you are interested in attending.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Asian Culture Room 4.224

Summary: Transferable skills is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Being a student employee at The University of Texas at Austin has implications for your future career. Learn to identify transferable skills you are currently gaining, and how to best market these experiences to future employers on a resume and in a job interview. Presented by the Center for Strategic Advising and Career Counseling.

Summary: Entrepreneurship Live features chairman & CEO of Barynoyx
Description: This week's Entrepreneurship Live features Ian Hatton, CEO and chairman of Barynoyx Corporation, which specializes in offshore wind energy and energy data centers. If you have an interest in clean technologies, don't miss this event. Meet and greet begins at 5:30 p.m. Networking event, with food and drinks, follows at 8 p.m.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Role of analytics is seminar topic
Description: The Austin Forum presents "More Than You Think You Know: Analyzing the Data That's Around Us," featuring John B. Gordon, IBM Watson Solutions. The role of analytics is coming into much clearer focus as organizations face an overwhelming volume of data from billions of new and diverse sources. This seminar addresses the resulting new complexities for leaders across industries.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Amphitheater 204

Summary: Science of addiction is Science Study Break topic
Description: Dr. Carlton Erickson of the School of Pharmacy's Addiction Science & Research Center discusses the science of addiction, using scenes from "House," "Nurse Jackie," "E.R." and other television shows.

Summary: Natural Sciences Week hosts Opportunities Abroad session
Description: Interested in the various study and research opportunities abroad? Attend this session to hear Dr. Mark Bierner's faculty perspective, listen to student testimonials and learn more about traveling abroad through the College of Natural Sciences.

Summary: Webinar addresses how to prepare for first job interview
Description: Interviewing is the last step toward employment that we must master. But how? Attend a special re-broadcast of featured speaker Dennis Guthrie, who gives tips on how to master your next interview, detailing how to prepare and interview for your first job out of school. Social hour, featuring snacks and refreshments, begins at 6:30 p.m.; webinar begins at 7.

Summary: Amazon.com tech talk and info session presented
Description: Attend a tech talk and information session on how scalability programming and machine learning are used at Amazon. Amazon is currently hiring full-time software engineers. Free food served and free Amazon t-shirts given away.

Summary: Fisher v. Texas is topic of civil rights forum
Description: A diverse panel of attorneys discusses "Fisher v. Texas and You: A Conversation with Civil Rights Leaders" at a town hall-style night of learning and dialogue. The panel represents Asian American, Mexican American and African American civil rights groups. Dr. Eric Tang (Center for Asian American Studies and African & African Diaspora Studies) moderates.

Summary: LGBTQ relationship violence is topic of performance
Description: Explore how relationship violence and LGBTQ issues relate in an interactive theater performance in honor of Relationship Violence Awareness month. In this presentation, Scott is coming out as transgender, but his girlfriend, Alex, wants to control his identity. What does this mean for their relationship and for Alex's identity? Who gets to decide?

Summary: "Why Bother?" Forum asks how to engage Texans in democracy
Description: Only 32 percent of eligible voters in Texas participated in the 2010 election. Many ask, "why bother?" "Why Bother? Engaging Texans in Democracy Today," a news and public dialogue series, investigates the range of causes for voter apathy in Texas, exploring new forms of engagement and what can be done to inspire more people to get involved in the democratic process.
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), Studio 6A, KLRU

Summary: Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority holds info session
Description: Theta Nu Xi Sorority is active in shaping the community through ethics, diversity, leadership and more. Attend this information session to learn more about the organization and meet the current members.

Summary: UT Micro Farm seeks student leaders
Description: The UT Micro Farm will be the first student-run sustainable farming initiative on UT's Forty Acres. This project is interdisciplinary and needs participants with many skill sets. Learn more, and sign up to become involved, at the link below, or visit our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/UTMicroFarm?ref=ts&fref=ts.

Summary: Poetry on the Plaza presents Actors from the London Stage
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center presents the Poetry on the Plaza event "The Poetry of Jacques Prevert" with actor Michael Palmer, who is on tour with Actors from the London Stage and plays Shylock in their current production of "The Merchant of Venice." Refreshments served.



Pick up a free poster and bookmark with the 2012-2013 Poetry on the Plaza schedule at the visitor desk in the Ransom Center lobby.

Summary: Climate change and migration in the Andes is talk topic
Description: Dr. Teofilo Altamirano presents "Environmental Refugees: Climate Change and Migration," a talk discussing the link between climate change and human displacement in the Andean countries.

Summary: Workshop focuses on emotional eating and losing weight
Description: Learn how to cope with your emotions and combat overeating from Holistic Health Coach Sarah Franklin. This presentation is a part of Bites of Wellness, a lunch-and-learn series all about wellness. Sign up on TxClass for PN288, or contact healthpoint.wellness@austin.utexas.edu to reserve your spot.
Location: AT&T Executive Education & Conference Center,The Carillon, dining room 1

Summary: CMAS plática explores career of local female boxer
Description: In 2005, San Angelo native Anissa Zamarron defeated San Antonio's Maribel Zurita to win her second women's boxing world title. She then retired due to injuries. This plática features "The Assassin" a short film by Amanda E. Gray, and questions and answers with Zamarron.

Summary: Ireland Maymester information session held
Description:
Attend an information session to learn about the university's Maymester in Ireland. Contact Professor Brad Love at lovebrad@austin.utexas.edu with questions. The next session will be held Oct. 11 from 3:30-5 p.m.



The 2013 May-June program at University College Dublin is a writing-intensive course organized by the College of Communication that offers a chance to study Dublin's history as well as the impact of modern media.

Summary: Rethinking Diplomacy panel topic is nuclear technology
Description: Join the Student Council for a Rethinking Diplomacy panel discussion on the impact of dual-use nuclear technology on diplomacy within and outside of the United States. Lunch provided.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Tufts professor speaks on cleaner energy technologies
Description: Tufts University Associate Professor of Energy and Environmental Policy Kelly Sims Gallagher presents a talk titled "The Diffusion of Cleaner Energy Technologies" at this week's UT Energy Symposium.

Summary: Panel discussion on Fisher v. Texas held
Description: The Public Affairs Alliance for Communities of Color (PAACC) hosts a brown bag panel discussion on the Supreme Court case Fisher v. University of Texas. The outcome of this case will have a definitive impact on affirmative action in the United States. Panelists include Dr. Edwin Dorn, Dr. Lino Graglia, Thomas L. Mariadason and Dr. Leonard N. Moore. Reeve Hamilton of the Texas Tribune moderates.

Summary: Suicide among young Latinas discussed in presentation
Description: Based on results from his NIMH-funded research, School of Social Work dean Dr. Luis Zayas describes the history of suicide attempts among teenage Latinas and how cultural and developmental factors converge to influence them.

Summary: UHS holds flu shot clinic
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: Center for Teaching & Learning presents Dr. David Yeager
Description: Dr. David Yeager leads a workshop titled "Productive Persistence: A Practical Theory of Developmental Student Success."

Summary: Visiting Artists Program presents Sarah Oppenheimer
Description: Attend a seminar with artist Sarah Oppenheimer, whose work examines our perception of space through sculpture and installation.

Summary: ECE Colloquium welcomes Dr. Ruchir Puri
Description: The Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering proudly presents Dr. Ruchir Puri of the IBM Thomas J. Watson Research Center, giving a talk titled "Opportunities and Challenges for High Performance Microprocessor Designs and Design Automation."

Summary: Google Books and Google Scholar class taught
Description: Learn how to use two specialized Google searches in conjunction with library resources for research and discovery.

Summary: Learn about Sport & English Society Maymester in England
Description: Hear about how you can take SOC 321K, KIN 350 or EUS 346 in Leeds, England, this June with Dr. Ben Carrington, Department of Sociology.

Summary: Study marine botany in Mexico Maymester
Description: Attend an information session to learn how you can take Marine Botany (MNS 352D) in Mexico. Pizza and drinks provided.

Summary: Natural Sciences Week hosts Quiz Bowl
Description: Test your mettle or watch others face College of Natural Sciences professors in Natural Science Council's Quiz Bowl trivia night. Free food served.

Summary: Inclusive Leadership & Social Identities workshop held
Description:
Leaders around the world must embrace diversity in order to bridge disciplines and enhance their global perspective. Learn about your own social identity and how diversity can strengthen you and/or your organization's identity, character and leadership. Offered as part of the Leadership Series.



The Leadership Series is a series of workshops designed to develop both individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations. Workshops are held twice a month in the fall and spring semesters.

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesday of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter.

Summary: Voices Against Violence (VAV) meeting announced
Description: Attend the third Voices Against Violence meeting to learn about more ways to support the work of VAV during Relationship Violence Awareness Month. No prior experience necessary. Visit VAV on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/VoicesAgainstViolenceUTAustin.

Summary: Computer Science hosts integrated BS/MS info session
Description: Learn about the five-year integrated BS/MS (bachelor of science / master of science) program in computer science. You must be a computer science student with a 3.00 GPA to pursue this program. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Stress management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: A workshop on stress management for students employed by UT Austin introduces stress coping skills. Using cognitive techniques and guided relaxation, this interactive workshop helps participants learn to recognize the effects of stress affects and new ways to relax. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: Student Leaders Pursuing Law group meets
Description: Student Leaders Pursuing Law holds its first meeting of the semester. The organization aims to increase awareness of the importance of diversity in the legal profession while maintaining a useful network of contacts within the profession to provide guidance and advice to aspiring undergraduate minority law students.

Summary: Indian Cultural Association holds dance clinic Jhoom
Description: Learn how to dance like a Bollywood pro at a clinic teaching two 45-second routines. Free food served to attendees.

Summary: Natural Sciences Week announces Star Party
Description: University professor and expert Dr. Karl Gebhardt delivers an engaging talk on black holes in RLM 4.202. Afterward, join the Natural Sciences Council on the rooftop of the RLM for stargazing, free dinner and liquid nitrogen ice cream.
Location: Robert Lee Moore Hall (RLM) 4.202 and rooftop

Summary: Undergraduate Forensics Organization meets
Description: Join the Undergraduate Forensics Organization for its first guest speaker of the semester, Officer Darrel Halstead of the UT Police Department. Light snacks provided.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays TCU
Description: Texas volleyball faces TCU for the first time as Big 12 Conference members. Volley for a Cure Special ticket offer: $4 general admission ticket. Enter promo code PINK at TexasSports.com or call 512-232-3865; advance sale only. Purchase by Wednesday, Oct. 3, at noon. Wear pink to support breast cancer awareness.

Summary: Maya astronomer's notes from Xultun discussed in talk
Description: Recent excavations at the large Maya city of Xultun have revealed a workspace dating to ca. 800 A.D., in which scribes and mathematicians wrote many of their astronomical calculations and notes on the painted walls around them. These faint hieroglyphs and numerical tables reveal many aspects of ancient mathematics and astronomical science.

Summary: Presidential debate watch party announced
Description: Join the Texas Freedom Network's student chapter for the hippest presidential debate watch party in Austin. Free pizza and free soda served. Stay after the debate for a 30-minute discussion about the importance of public education.

Summary: Hearts of Texas fall plant sale announced
Description: Plants grown and crafts made by UT Libraries staff are on sale, with all proceeds donated to the Capital Area Food Bank. Plants for the garden, home and office available.

Summary: McNair Scholars Program applications due Nov. 16
Description: The Ronald E. McNair Scholars Program is a federally funded program mandated by Congress whose goal is to increase the number of students in doctoral degree programs who are low-income and first-generation undergraduates or students who come from groups underrepresented in graduate education, particularly African American, Hispanic/Latino and American Indian/Alaska Natives. Deadline to apply is Nov. 16 by 5 p.m. Visit the link below for information, or contact 512-471-1205 or write to mcnairprogram@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Literature review class open to grad students, researchers
Description: Learn how a literature review is structured, how to use background information to shape your research question, how to find examples of literature reviews and how to get a brief overview of the tools and resources available to find, evaluate and cite sources. For graduate students and research staff. Session focuses on the social sciences, area studies and humanities.

Summary: CMCT presents NIEHS speaker
Description: Mike Waalkes, Ph.D., Chief of the National Toxicology Program Laboratory at the National Institute of Environmental Health Sciences, presents a seminar titled "Arsenic Carcinogenesis - Accumulating Insights."

Summary: Kinesiology & Health Education Job & Internship Fair held
Description: The Kinesiology & Health Education Job & Internship Fair is an excellent opportunity for students to learn about internships, network with various employers, familiarize themselves with the job market and search for employment opportunities.

Summary: Law School Fair announced
Description: Representatives from over 130 law schools from around the country will be on campus for our annual Law School Fair. Get all of your questions about law school answered. Business casual dress recommended.

Summary: UHS holds flu shot clinic at Student Services Building
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: See basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Computer Science hosts internal transfer info session
Description: Learn more about the computer science major. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: NEA and NIH host webinar on funding
Description: The National Endowment for the Arts (NEA) and the National Institutes of Health (NIH) co-host a live webinar titled New Funding Opportunity on Culture and Health.

Summary: Introduction to EndNote offered
Description: This introductory class covers tricks for using EndNote with library databases such as Web of Science and other library databases, indexes and the library catalog. This is an online class. At start time, go to link below. Select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." Headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher needed. To find out more, or request classes for your group/department, visit http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/index.html.

Summary: The Pagliacci Project comes to the Blanton Museum
Description: Enjoy a live performance of Act II from Leoncavallo's renowned opera, "Pagliacci," in the Blanton's Faulkner Plaza. The performance is the result of a new collaboration between Austin Lyric Opera and the Butler Opera Center at The University of Texas at Austin. The Pagliacci Project brings opera, performed in English, to new audiences in nontraditional, highly visible settings.

Summary: RTF Media Studies Colloquium welcomes Sahara Byrne
Description:
"The Boomerang Effect" is a talk presented by Sahara Byrne, assistant professor in the Department of Communication, Cornell University. Byrne's research examines the conditions under which communication messages with strategic intent are ineffective, met with resistance or even result in the opposite of the intended effect. She focuses primarily, but not exclusively, on youth and adolescent populations.



Imagine a media health campaign featuring a beautiful high school girl speaking about the negative consequences of her former addiction to heroin. No matter how strong her arguments about the consequences of her addiction, some members of the audience will be distracted by her beauty and thinness, which they may find attractive, and desire to be like her no matter what she argues about ill effects. If her attractiveness is selected as the processing priority, attention to this element will lead to unintended effects.

Summary: Bevonomics 101 topic is budgeting & building credit
Description: Acclimate your saving and spending style to the college lifestyle. Learn how to create and use a daily budget, save money, maintain and grow a savings account and build credit.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain. This meeting focuses on Salvador, Brazil.

Summary: Kinesiology & Health Education recruiter panel slated
Description: Learn from sports professionals from Austin AzTex, Austin Family & Sports Chiropractic, Austin ISD, Crull Fitness, Longhorn Network, San Antonio Alamodome and Train 4 the Game. Pizza provided and don't miss this networking opportunity.

Summary: BE Global Internship information session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for Business and Engineering majors beginning Summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.
Location: International Office Multi-Purpose Room, 715 W. 24th St.

Summary: Learn about the Transport Phenomena Maymester in England
Description: Attend an information session about the Transport Phenomena in Living Systems Maymester abroad in Cambridge, England.

Summary: Student Veteran Association hosts guest speakers
Description: Upcoming SVA meetings host guest speakers who will talk about veterans' issues and opportunities. This week, we welcome Brad Ward and Cameron McNeel of Orion International, one of the nation's largest military career placement firms.

Summary: Jester Block Party is National Night Out event
Description: Jester Block Party is held in collaboration with National Night Out and focuses on safety and security. Enjoy inflatable games, music, free food, t-shirt giveaways and photos Hook 'Em the mascot.

Summary: VAC presents "Two Ships Passing" with Barbara Perea
Description:
The Visual Arts Center, in collaboration with the art publication Pastelegram, presents the fall 2012 edition of "Two Ships Passing" on the topic of sound art with invitee Barbara Perea, a Mexico City-based curator, critic and lecturer with a concentration in emerging media, sound and video art.



Straddling the worlds of contemporary visual art and music, sound art includes diverse practices, from inventive machines, video and film, to performance and other possibilities. Sound art's boundaries are thus amorphous, posing particular complexities to those who wish to display such works or write about the field. These issues form the basis from which Barbara Perea, this edition's invitee, begins her conversation.

Summary: Natural Sciences Week holds dress-for-success workshop
Description: You have the brains, skill and talent for the job, but there is only one problem ... What to wear? Learn about appropriate attire in the business world for interviews and on-the-job wear. Free food and prizes included.

Summary: Nazar online South Asian magazine holds meeting
Description: Nazar is an online magazine that serves as an outlet for the South Asian perspective. We seek opinionated writers, photographers and editors of any level. Attend a meeting with Nazar members and learn how you can contribute. Desi refreshments served.

Summary: El Tejano Enamorado features music & art of Oscar Martinez
Description:
Celebrate the music and art of Corpus Christi legend Oscar Martinez, El Tejano Enamorado.

View Martinez's unique and colorful artwork and enjoy a performance by Martinez, backed by Larry Lange and His Lonely Knights, follows. RSVP to Margo Gutierrez at mgutierrez@austin.utexas.edu or 512-495-4589.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 1.108

Summary: Curators' tour of "I Have Seen the Future" held at HRC
Description:
Cathy Henderson, associate director for exhibitions, and Helen Baer, associate curator of performing arts, lead a tour of the exhibition "I Have Seen the Future: Norman Bel Geddes Designs America."



Bel Geddes (1893-1958) was an innovative stage and industrial designer, futurist and urban planner who, more than any designer of his era, created and promoted a dynamic vision of the future - streamlined, technocratic and optimistic. Bel Geddes popularized this vision through drawings, models and photographs of spectacular vehicles, buildings and products featured in his books "Horizons" and "Magic Motorways." His most notable effort was his Futurama display at the 1939-1940 New York World's Fair, which adopted the motto "I Have Seen the Future."

Summary: UT Scuba Club meets
Description: Join the Scuba Club at its general meeting to learn about upcoming dives/events, meet dive buddies and take advantage of dive courses and specials offered to UT students. Newcomers welcome.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Japanese Association 3rd General Meeting
Description: Join the Japanese Association for a general meeting, featuring a game and some important announcements.

Summary: Austin Speech Labs featured at Communication Council event
Description:
In the first lecture of its popular series, the Communication Council presents an evening with Shilpa Shamapant, co-founder and president of Austin Speech Labs. The organization provides intensive speech, language and cognitive therapy for stroke survivors. Lectures in the series bridge the gap between what is learned in the classroom and what awaits after college.



Learn more about Austin Speech Labs at www.austinspeechlabs.org.

Summary: Find out where Libertarians stand on key issues
Description:
Join Libertarian Longhorns for a meeting focused on hot-button issues such as foreign policy, health care and the drug war, and find out where Libertarians stand on these issues.



Other agenda items include

-Registration for the Dallas Students for Liberty Regional Conference (Oct. 13)

-Peaceful Streets Know Your Rights Training Session (Oct. 25)

-Antonio Buehler Speech (Oct. 31)

-Registration for the Austin Students for Liberty Conference (Nov. 17)

Summary: Author Bill McKibben discusses "The Climate Fight"
Description: Attend a talk by Bill McKibben, author of a dozen books about the environment, beginning with "The End of Nature" (1989), the first book for a general audience on climate change. His 2010 work, the provocative "Eaarth: Making Life on a Tough New Planet," argues we are living on a dramatically different planet than we have known, now defined by reduced energy resources and increased climate disruption.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium 2.106

Summary: Rethinking Power & Resistance conference slated
Description: Gender and human rights are topics at the two-day Rethinking Power & Resistance conference, bringing together organizers and activist scholars for a dialogue on arts as advocacy, pedagogies of alliance and resisting criminalization. To register, visit http://powerandresistance2012.wordpress.com/.
Location: Mexican American Cultural Center, 600 River Street

Summary: Third Central Texas Cervantes Symposium slated
Description:
The Department of Spanish and Portuguese hosts the Cervantes Society of America's Third Central Texas Cervantes Symposium. Friday's events are held on campus. Saturday's events take place at the Wizard Academy, just southwest of town.



The symposium brings together scholars from the United States and Canada who represent a diverse array of research agendas and areas of expertise. This year's program includes scholarly sessions devoted to Cervantes beyond Spain, print culture, religion and ethics, race and identity, and the emerging field of cognitive literary-cultural studies.

Summary: Texas Ballroom hosts Decades Dance
Description: Texas Ballroom announces its decades-themed social dance. Put on your crazy unique attire from your favorite decade and join us for a fun night of dancing, socializing and snacks. All genres of music featured.

Summary: Apply for Student Health Advisory Committee (SHAC)
Description: Applications for SHAC membership for spring 2013 are available. If you want to give a voice to student health follow the link below and download the application. Once completed, save the file to your desktop and send it attached in an e-mail to utaustinshac@gmail.com. Applications due by midnight Nov. 1.

Summary: Symposium on Gender, History & Sexuality slated
Description: The Symposium on Gender, History & Sexuality presents "The Politics of Identity in the Archives," a talk by Professor Christopher J. Lee, IHS fellow in UT Austin's History Department and professor of history at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill.

Summary: Population Research Center presents Dr. Kelley Crews
Description: Dr. Kelley Crews, associate professor of geography and the environment, delivers a talk titled "Scale, Pattern, and Process: Functional Implications of Pattern Metric Analysis for Demographic Research."

Summary: Maymester information session held
Description: Interested in studying abroad?  Attend a general information session to learn more about Maymester programs.

Summary: Cardiovascular/metabolic risk in children is talk topic
Description: Matthew Brothers, Ph.D., assistant professor in Kinesiology & Health Education presents a talk titled "Low-level Inflammation and Cardiovascular/Metabolic Risk in Children."

Summary: Others' prosocial behavior is topic of talk
Description:
Marlone Henderson, an assistant professor in the Department of Psychology, presents a talk titled "Others' Prosocial Behavior." Henderson's talk is part of the ongoing colloquia sponsored by the Department of Human Development and Family Sciences.



Henderson's research program examines the impact of distance, both spatial and psychological, on human interactions, negotiation, philanthropy and social judgement.

Summary: Tibet, travel & Buddhism in early 20th century is talk topic
Description:
Focusing on the image and influence of Tibet in the early 20th century, this scholarly symposium chaired by Associate Professor of Asian Art Janice Leoshko raises provocative questions about the intersections of travel, art and religion. 



Speakers include Claire Harris, a Tibetan art scholar from Oxford University; UT Professor of Art History Michael Charlesworth; and Donald Lopez, A.E. Link distinguished university professor of Buddhist studies at the University of Michigan.

Summary: Neurobiology for mental health practitioners is lecture topic
Description:
The School of Social Work hosts the 2012 Sue Fairbanks Lecture in Psychoanalytic Knowledge. Arlene Montgomery, Ph.D, LCSW, presents "Across the Social Synapse: A Neurobiological and Psychoanalytic Approach to Enactments." RSVP to the Office of Professional Development, School of Social Work: ssw-profdev@utlists.utexas.edu.



Montgomery has taught clinical courses at The University of Texas at Austin School of Social Work and Smith College School for Social Work since 1993. She is the author of "Neurobiology Essentials for Clinicians: What Every Therapist Needs to Know" (January 2013, in press). 



Montgomery has a successful private practice in Austin, Texas, with a focus on serving clients affected by trauma, in addition to providing LCSW supervision. Her professional interests include the clinical implications of the neurobiology of relationships between and among people as they relate to social service delivery and clinical practice, with particular interest in group work, supervision, attachment, adolescents and trauma. 



This lecture is sponsored by Sue Fairbanks, a 1981 graduate of the UT Austin School of Social Work master's degree program.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Albert J. Beveridge III speaks on Anthony Trollope
Description:
Albert Beveridge III gives a talk titled "Scriptor Renatus: Anthony Trollope." Why do some artists who are at the very top of their craft both in critical acclaim and popularity fall from their pinnacles - only to be restored in subsequent years? Writer Anthony Trollope is a case in point.



Trollope made slow progress during the course of his early career in the post office (but can claim credit for the familiar pillar-box for letters), and was unsuccessful in politics. It took over 20 years for him to establish his tradition of the novel-sequence in England, including, in the end, 47 novels. After his peak as a writer in the 1860s, his popularity began to decline, only to be substantially revived in the latter part of the twentieth century to the present.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Breaking through writer's block is workshop topic
Description: If you have been staring at a blank screen for hours and can't get your upcoming assignment going, bring your project (or blank sheets of paper) and find out how to jumpstart your writing at the Friday Afternoon Workshop. Find out more and reserve your spot at the link below.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC), Undergraduate Writing Center 211

Summary: SURGe announces Roads to Research event
Description: Distinguished researchers and UT alumni from the UNT Health Sciences Center give short research presentations on topics ranging from pharmacology to immunology. The panel will be followed by a networking session that connects undergraduates to representatives from research labs and other helpful resources on campus.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA) 4.338 and the Atrium (CBA third floor)

Summary: Callicarpa Gallery celebrates Tamara Johnson opening
Description: The Callicarpa Gallery hosts an opening reception and a live performance for its inaugural exhibition, "Immaterial Labor," by Tamara Johnson, running through Oct. 26. The exhibition includes a collection of Johnson's videos, objects and performance work.

Summary: Anna Mod presents "Building Modern Houston"
Description: Mid Tex Mod and the UT-Austin Graduate Program in Historic Preservation host a talk by Anna Mod titled "Building Modern Houston." A tour of the gorgeously brutalist First Baptist Church follows, led by one of its original designers, Jack Goodman, an alumnus of the UT engineering program.

Summary: Texas softball takes on St. Mary's
Description: Texas softball hosts the St. Mary's Rattlers.

Summary: Briscoe Center and KLRU screen "For the Sake of the Song"
Description:
The Briscoe Center for American History and KLRU host a screening of the award-winning documentary "For the Sake of the Song," which tells the story of Houston music venue Anderson Fair, which has cultivated some of America's most notable songwriters - including Lyle Lovett, Townes Van Zandt and Lucinda Williams. Screening followed by performances from musicians featured in the film.

 

Now in its sixth decade, Anderson Fair is one of the oldest folk and acoustic music venues still open in the United States. The film maps out how a devoted family of volunteers, patrons and artists transformed a subversive coffeehouse into a unique music institution.
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), KLRU Studio (2504-B Whitis Avenue)

Summary: Taiwanese American students host 10th annual Night Market
Description: TASA, the Taiwanese American Student Association, invites you to its 10th annual Night Market, showcasing Taiwanese culture.  Free food, prizes, games, t-shirts and performances make this an unforgettable night.

Summary: Access Christian Fellowship hosts gathering
Description: Join Access Christian Fellowship's Large Group Gathering for worship, fellowship and discipleship. We discuss topics relevant to students as they are living out their faith on campus.

Summary: Texas soccer plays Oklahoma State
Description: Longhorns soccer returns to the field to take on the Oklahoma State Cowboys. Look for Kick for a Cure Special ticket offer at TexasSports.com or call 512-232-3865. Enter promo code CURE. Wear pink to support breast cancer awareness. Teacher Appreciation Day and Government Employee Appreciation offers $4 tickets. Order by phone by Friday, Oct. 5, at noon.
Location: Mike A. Meyers Stadium & Soccer Field

Summary: Film screening features Q&A with director Aurora Guerrero
Description: Attend a screening of "Mosquita y Mari," a coming-of-age story about the tender friendship between two young Chicanas. In a fast-paced immigrant community where dreams are often lost to economic survival, the two protagonists contemplate life when they stir unexpected desires in each other.

Summary: UT Jazz Orchestra performs
Description: The UT Jazz Orchestra performs under the direction of Jeff Hellmer, premiering new compositions and arrangements by UT students and faculty.

Summary: Actors from the London Stage perform "Merchant of Venice"
Description: Actors from the London Stage returns to Austin for three performances of "The Merchant of Venice" as part of their week long-residency on campus. Come experience one of Shakespeare's famous "problem" comedies that dives into a world of love and hate, revenge and mercy amid the canals of Venice. The play will also be performed on Oct. 6 at the Winedale Theater Barn.

Summary: PAC presents an evening with David Byrne & St. Vincent
Description: David Byrne & St. Vincent (aka Annie Clark) perform music from their recently released album, "Love This Giant."
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Join the UT Language Creation Society
Description:
The Language Creation Society at the University of Texas at Austin is an organization specifically for student, staff and faculty conlangers at UT Austin. We offer a friendly and supportive, yet casual, environment to current and prospective students and faculty who have made a hobby of the secret vice. Sign up on Facebook (http://www.facebook.com/groups/155974534519874/) or visit our new website at the link below. 



The Language Creation Society at the University of Texas at Austin (officially affiliated with the Language Creation Society) aims to provide a home and a wealth of knowledge, linguistic resources and experience to beginners and experienced conlangers alike. You do not need to be an active conlanger or have any prior experience to join.

Summary: Spoken Sanskrit workshop offered
Description: Teachers from Samskrita Bharati Austin conduct a Spoken Sanskrit workshop for UT students. Learn the basics of the language in an interactive setting, through games, plays and conversation. Register online at http://www.samskritabharatiusa.org/index.php/en/component/dtregister/?eventId=27&controller=event&task=individualRegister, or visit www.samskritabharatiusa.org and click on UT Austin.

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts tree nursery seed planting
Description: Help the Campus Environmental Center/Green Fee tree nursery at the Wildflower Center put soil and seeds into 100,000 pots. The trees will help reforest the Bastrop Lost Pines after last September's fires. Sign up to volunteer at the link below. For carpool information or other questions, email Trees@UTEnvironment.org.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Daily Texan hosts kickoff countdown tailgate party
Description: Watch the game with Texas Student Media and enjoy free food and drinks provided by our sponsors. Event starts four hours prior to kickoff and continues through the UT game.

Summary: Texas football takes on West Virginia
Description: The Longhorns take on the West Virginia Mountaineers in their first matchup as Big 12 members in Game 5 of the 2012 season.
Location: Darrell K Royal Texas Memorial Stadium (DKR)

Summary: Actors from the London Stage perform at Winedale
Description: Actors from the London Stage returns for four performances of "The Merchant of Venice" as part of their week-long residency at UT, including this performance at the Winedale Theatre Barn. Experience one of Shakespeare's famous "problem" comedies that dives into a world of love and hate, revenge and mercy amidst the canals of Venice.
Location: Winedale Theatre Barn, Round Top, TX

Summary: "Mama Said Knock You Out II" celebrates conference
Description: The Center for Women's & Gender Studies announces A Benefit for Mamas of Color Rising, hosted by Mz Marlah, and featuring Invincible, Las Krudas, Lah Tere, Yoli, T-Fly, Tru Bloo, DJ Trinity, DJ T-Kay, Tiger Lily and live art by Toofly. This event is part of the conference Rethinking Power & Resistance: Gender & Human Rights from Texas to the Transnational Americas.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Sunday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Sunday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Faculty ensemble presents Afternoon of Opera at Blanton
Description: Talented faculty and students from the UT Butler Opera Center present favorite opera scenes and arias.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton Museum
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Sunday Best showcase features Alpha Lambda Omega co-founder
Description: Alpha Lambda Omega Christian Sorority announces its talent showcase, Sunday Best, featuring co-founder Terra O'Brien. Join us for an evening of worship, entertainment and good fellowship.

Summary: "The Rumble 2012" debate screening held
Description: Bill O'Reilly. Jon Stewart. Two podiums. One Air-Conditioned Auditorium. O'Reilly and Stewart take an entertaining and comedic approach to today's pressing political issues in an attempt to find the best direction for America. Join us for this must-see event.

Summary: Apply for University Co-op's Cohen New Works Festival
Description: The Cohen New Works Festival presented by the University Co-op is a week-long showcase of new work in the arts created by UT students held every other spring in various locations in and around the Winship Drama Building and The University of Texas campus. This spring's festival takes place March 25-29. Visit the link below to learn more about the application process.

Summary: Evidence of desert pastoralism in the Negev discussed
Description: Steve Rosen, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, presents "Shelter from the Storm: Preliminary Conclusions on Desert Pastoralism from the Analysis of Rock Shelters and Dung Layers in the Negev."

Summary: Gender and immigration are topic of panel discussion
Description: The Center for Women's and Gender Studies presents the second pre-election roundtable discussion on immigration (Pizza Party Politics). Enjoy free pizza and discuss issues related to women, gender and politics. The next Pizza Party Politics event is Women, Health and Politics, on Oct. 29.

Summary: Travel writings of Nasir al-Din Shah Qajar are talk topic
Description:
Naghmeh Sohrabi, Brandeis University, presents a lecture titled "Shah-Rah or the King's Road: Reinterpreting the European Travel Writings of Nasir al-Din Shah Qajar." Nasir al-Din Shah (r. 1848-1896), was the longest reigning Qajar monarch. He documented his travel to Europe extensively.



Until recently, these travelogues were dismissed by scholars for focusing on frivolous and repetitive information. This talk presents a new interpretation of Nasir al-Din Shah's extensive travel writing by placing them in their own cultural and political milieu, and by focusing on the question of why the king would choose to so meticulously record his travels.



Sohrabi is the Charles (Corky) Goodman Professor of Middle East History and the associate director for research at the Crown Center for Middle East Studies at Brandeis. Her book "Taken for Wonder: Nineteenth Century Travel Accounts from Iran to Europe" was recently published by Oxford University Press. Her new research focuses on the assassination of Nasir al-Din Shah in 1896 by a follower of Jamal al-Din al-Afghani. In addition to her scholarship on the nineteenth century, Professor Sohrabi writes and lectures on contemporary politics and culture of Iran.

Summary: Computer Science hosts internal transfer info session
Description: Learn more about the computer science major. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Dr. Clare Harris
Description: "In and Out of Place: Tibetan Artists' Travels in the Contemporary Art World" is a talk by art historian Clare Harris.

Summary: Study journalism in Beijing
Description: Learn more about the Reporting China Maymester program at an information session. Study abroad in Beijing and get journalism credit.

Summary: Club Outreach general meeting announced
Description: Club Outreach is a student organization whose mission is to form a link between University of Texas students and Austin Independent School District students. UT students volunteer and mentor at local schools through the club, providing assistance to at-risk students through fun, hands-on activities. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Learn about applying to graduate school at info session
Description: Get a head start on the process of applying to graduate school. Attend this information session to explore how to arrange your finances, prepare for the GRE, get letters of recommendation and create a timeline to stay organized. Space is limited. RSVP at link below.

Summary: New Student Orientation 2.0 presented
Description: Learn something new and connect with your #UT16 classmates on a deeper level. New Student Orientation 2.0 programs are designed specifically for first-year students to support your continued success in your transition. Attendees are entered to win a Kindle Fire HD. View the schedule at the link below.

Summary: Lars von Trier film series continues
Description: The Lars von Trier film festival continues with "Dancer in the Dark" (2000), winner of wthe Palme d'Or at the Cannes Film Festival, along with the Best Actress award for Bjork. The disturbing musical drama tells of Selma, a hard-working Czechoslovakian immigrant with a terrible secret and a passion for the music in classic Hollywood films.

Summary: Hazing workshop announced
Description: Learn how the University of Texas defines hazing and how you can help combat those activities that can potentially harm the university community and colleges around the country.

Summary: Art of Living UT offers free yoga classes
Description: Attend a free yoga session in the main mall, taught by a certified yoga instructor and hosted by the Art of Living UT. Bring a yoga mat and get ready for an amazing outdoor yoga experience. View the website below for more information.
Location: Main Mall (in front of UT Tower)

Summary: "Blue Like Jazz" screened, with director Steve Taylor
Description: Significance & Cinema hosts a screening of "Blue Like Jazz" with director Steve Taylor as part of the new Significance & Cinema Story Sessions Series. Taylor will discuss the making of the film and the elements of faith found in the story it tells. Join the Facebook event here: http://www.facebook.com/events/368796919867444/. Purchase tickets at link below.

Summary: UT Hispanic Journalists meeting held
Description: Attend the upcoming UTHJ meeting to learn about internship opportunities, networking skills and upcoming events. Open to all majors and ethnicities.

Summary: Mises Circle discusses utility and welfare economics
Description:
This week's Mises Circle be discusses Murray N. Rothbard's 1956 paper, "Toward a Reconstruction of Utility and Welfare Economics." Read the paper here: http://mises.org/rothbard/toward.pdf.



In this classic article, Rothbard proposes a formulation of welfare economics that is constrained by the Austrian concepts of subjectivity and action.

Summary: MadeInAustin Tech Fair announced
Description: MadeInAustin Tech Fair introduces students to the 100  fastest growing tech companies in Texas. Attend the fair to learn about internships and employment opportunities.
Location: Omni Downtown, 700 San Jacinto at 8th St.

Summary: CLUTCH New Music Series presents first fall concert
Description: The first CLUTCH (Collective Labors of the UT Composition Hub) concert of the 2012-13 season features fresh new compositions by University of Texas composers, including premieres for marimba sextet, saxophone quartet and more, plus the debut appearance of the new cross-genre ensemble "Blurred Divisions."

Summary: Texas Ballroom offers dance classes this week
Description: Learn ballroom dance from professional instructors through Texas Ballroom. No partner, shoes or experience necessary. Schedule is Monday: rumba and jive (8 p.m. and 9 p.m.); Tuesday: salsa and swing (8 and 9 p.m.); Wednesday: waltz and tango (8 and 9 p.m.); Thursday: two-step and West Coast swing (6 and 7 p.m.). Try our new technique class, Fridays from 6-8 p.m.

Summary: Volunteers sought for usability testing on Libraries website
Description: Volunteers are sought to test the UT Libraries website. Testing takes place on Wednesday, Oct. 17, or Thursday, Oct. 18, for approximately one hour. No experience required. UT student participants receive a $25 gift card to the University Co-op. Fill out questionnaire at the link by Oct. 10; selected participants notified by Oct. 12.

Summary: Trash to Treasure sale announced
Description: The Campus Environmental Center holds its annual Trash to Treasure sale, featuring used clothes, appliances and even furniture. Contact Emily Worthington at eeworthington@gmail.com for more information or to volunteer.

Summary: Black Faculty and Staff Association holds meeting
Description: The monthly BFSA meeting features highlights from the Successful Strategies for a New Year Faculty and Staff Panel Discussion as well as committee updates.

Summary: Online identity management course offered
Description:
Present yourself in the best light online and use social networks for your advantage. Class includes tips for sites like Facebook and Twitter, and advice for managing personal information on the Web. At class start time, go to the web link listed below, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." Headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher needed.



For additional information, including the form to request classes for your group/department, visit http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/index.html.

Summary: Enhance coursework with service in the arts
Description: A brown bag panel on service-learning addresses how faculty members and graduate students can incorporate service into curriculum. Muhsana Ali, Paula Gerstenblatt and Dr. Kara Hallmark discuss the role of the arts in their service-learning courses.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), ballroom north (2nd floor)

Summary: Hispanic Faculty/Staff Association October general meeting
Description: Join the Hispanic Faculty/Staff Association for its October general meeting featuring guest speaker Dr. Domino Perez, director of the Center for Mexican American Studies. The day's theme is "Culture/Cultura." Wear pink for Breast Cancer Awareness Month.

Summary: University Health Services holds flu shot clinic
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: Lessons from Woody Guthrie to Pussy Riot talk announced
Description: "How to Write a Protest Song: Lessons From Woody Guthrie to Pussy Riot" is a talk by Karl Hagstrom Miller, associate professor of History, The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Writing process is focus of library class
Description: Learn the basics of writing college-level papers in all academic genres and all disciplines. This class, taught by Undergraduate Writing Center staff, covers strategies for planning, creating, structuring and revising papers.

Summary: Academics weigh scholarly versus popular
Description: Can scholars reach a wider audience without sacrificing their academic reputations? What happens when they try? A panel of scholars discusses the question of scholarly versus popular in academia.

Summary: Chemical Engineering dept. hosts Dr. Rangaramanujam Kannan
Description:
Dr. Rangaramanujam Kannan of Johns Hopkins School of Medicine presents a seminar titled "Glial Engineering with Dendrimers Aimed Towards Targeted Nanotherapies for Neurodegenerative Diseases."



Kannan will discuss how engineering and reprogramming the microglial response, to achieve targeted attenuation of neuroinflammation, can be a potent therapeutic strategy for cerebral palsy, retinal degeneration and other debilitating neurodegenerative disorders.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Richard Hylton
Description: Art history guest lecturer Richard Hylton, a London-based independent curator and art criticism writer, presents "Keeping Up Appearances: Black Artists, State Patronage and the Politics of Visibility in Britain."

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese in Salvador, Brazil; Antigua, Guatemala; and Santander, Spain. This session features Dr. Niyi Afolabi, faculty representative for the Brazil program.

Summary: UT in Sydney info session held
Description: Kinesiology and Health Education majors are invited to learn about the new "UT in Sydney" exchange program from faculty, academic advisers and study abroad coordinators. In this unique two-part program, you will earn 16-20 hours of UT credit while exploring Australian sports culture.

Summary: Learn about working at the Undergraduate Writing Center
Description: Undergraduates are invited to attend an information session about working in the Undergraduate Writing Center. Hear about the required internship course (RHE368C), meet the course's teacher and hear from experienced undergrad consultants. Refreshments provided.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC), Undergraduate Writing Center 211

Summary: Texas Health Promotion Club meets
Description: Learn what the Texas Health Promotion Club has to offer and get involved. Upcoming events and volunteer opportunities are announced at each meeting. All majors welcome. Join us on Facebook at "Texas Health Promotion Club."

Summary: Employment basics is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop is offered for students employed by UT Austin, and geared toward student employees without prior employment experience in the university environment, as well as experienced student employees who want pointers on good job performance. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: ACE workshop topic is International Travel 101
Description: Are you interested in study abroad but have never traveled internationally? Attend a workshop sponsored by Achieving College Excellence (ACE) and get information and tips on how to prepare to be a first-time international traveler.

Summary: Urban Institute president discusses why housing matters
Description: Sarah Rosen Wartell, president of the Urban Institute, presents a talk titled "Why Housing Matters: Growth, Equity & the Future of the U.S. Housing Market for the Next Presidential Administration."

Summary: Stress Management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: A workshop on stress management for students employed by UT Austin introduces stress coping skills. Using cognitive techniques and guided relaxation, this interactive workshop helps participants learn to recognize the effects of stress affects and new ways to relax. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: Stanley Lombardo reads Virgil's "Fall of Troy"
Description: University of Kansas classics professor Stanley Lombardo presents a dramatic reading of "The Fall of Troy" from Book II of Virgil's Aeneid. Lombardo is known for his translations of the Iliad, the Odyssey and the Aeneid. He has been giving dramatic readings of his translations on campuses throughout the country, as well as at the Smithsonian Institution, the Chicago Poetry Center, on National Public Radio and national television.

Summary: Living with Pride: Out at Work is panel about coming out
Description: Join the Gender & Sexuality Center, the UT Sanger Learning Center and UT Residential Life for an informative panel about coming out during the application process, at work, or not at all. Ask panelists questions and hear them talk about their decisions to come out or not while on the job.
Location: San Jacinto Multipurpose Room, 309 E 21st Street Austin, TX 78705

Summary: Daniel Hope & Friends present Forbidden Music
Description: Daniel Hope & Friends present Forbidden Music, part one of a two-evening series, featuring Daniel Hope, violin; Jeffrey Kahane, piano; Benny Kim, violin; Eric Kim, cello; and David Small, baritone, and featuring the Miro Quartet.

Summary: Plan II Honors student seeks participants for Disney study
Description: As part of a thesis study of character development in Disney films, Plan II student Hilary Walker invites participants to view a Disney movie and fill out a short survey about the main character. Filling out the survey is voluntary and not required to view the films. "Sleeping Beauty" screened tonight; "Mulan" screened Monday, Oct. 15, at 8:30 p.m. Contact Walker at hilary_walker@austin.rr.com with questions.

Summary: Apply to be an orientation adviser
Description: New Student Services at The University of Texas at Austin seeks a diverse group of talented students to develop, plan and execute the 2013 summer orientation program. Attend this meeting to learn more, or visit the link below.

Summary: Photo exhibit shows work by Dennis Darling & Loli Kantor
Description: Photographers Dennis Darling (professor, School of Journalism) and Loli Kantor display their photos of modern-day Terezin and its survivors. A reception with light refreshments celebrates the opening of the exhibit, following a performance from Daniel Hope & Friends at Bass Concert Hall. This event is part of the interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death."
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall lobby, levels 1 & 2

Summary: Texas State Employees Union tables on campus
Description:
Visit the Texas State Employees Union information and sign-up table to learn more about the union that seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions for all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at The University of Texas at Austin. 



The union advocates across-the-board flat-amount pay raises and opposes all attempts to remove long-standing protections against arbitrary cuts in benefits.

Summary: Terezin concentration camp is topic of arts panel
Description:
World-class violinist Daniel Hope, renowned pianist Jeffrey Kahane and choreographer Donald Byrd of Spectrum Dance Theater speak about the legacy of the Terezin concentration camp Terezin in an artists' panel moderated by Professors Robert Abzug and Rebecca Rossen. 



This event is part of the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies' and Texas Performing Arts' interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death," which explores the impact of the music and art created by prisoners of the camp.

Summary: Diaspora Talk Series presents "Cuban Compromises"
Description: "Cuban Compromises: Race and Revolution as Lived Experiences" is a talk by Dr. Devyn Spence Benson, assistant professor of Africana studies and history, Williams College.

Summary: University Health Services holds flu shot clinic
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: Computer Science hosts internal transfer info session
Description: Learn more about the computer science major. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: "Last Dance": Award-winning documentary screened
Description:
Powerhouse creative forces unite and sparks fly in Mirra Bank's award-winning documentary "Last Dance." Banks follows the dazzling Pilobolus Dance Theater and legendary author-illustrator Maurice Sendak ("Where the Wild Things Are") as they collaborate on the dance-theater work that honors a haunting Holocaust legacy. 



This event is part of the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies' and Texas Performing Arts' interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death," which explores the impact of the music and art created by prisoners of the camp.

Summary: Learn to find census data in this library course
Description: This class covers methods for  searching 2010 Census and American Community Survey data, as well as historical census data. Learn how to construct effective searches, and use data to create tables and maps.

Summary: BE Global Internship Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.

Summary: Computer Science hosts game development info session
Description: Learn more about the game development track in computer science. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: UT in Guatemala information session held
Description: All majors are invited to learn about the new faculty-led UT in Guatemala Spring Semester Abroad Program. Earn 15 hours of UT credit while exploring Antigua, Guatemala life and culture. Four UT credit classes are taught in English at Casa Herrera in addition to one language-component class (Spanish or Mayan language).

Summary: Terezin/Theresienstadt in history is lecture topic
Description: Professor Tatjana Lichtenstein delivers a lecture on Terezin and Theresienstadt in history. This event is part of the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies' and Texas Performing Arts' interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death," which explores the impact of the music and art created by prisoners of the camp.

Summary: Discrimination basics to be topic of S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop provides a guide to policies, rights and resources that empower the employee in the workplace. Review policies in the areas of nondiscrimination, sex discrimination and sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, consensual relationships and disability accommodations. Presented by the Office of Institutional Equity.

Summary: Strengthening Your Personal Statement workshop offered
Description: Write a great personal statement for your graduate school application. A strong essay will help you stand out from the crowd. Come learn strategies on how to effectively show your true potential. Space is limited. RSVP at link below.

Summary: Archaeology Field School announces summer 2013 program
Description:
Attend an information session about the faculty-led 2013 summer archaeological field school in the north of Portugal. 

Information about the course, living arrangements, trips and financial aid will be discussed.

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: Workplace safety is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In this workshop, participants become familiar with basic worker safety concepts, learn situational awareness strategies and learn about the important legal protections afforded to employees and what to do in the event of a work injury. Presented by Human Resource Services - HealthPoint.

Summary: Apply to be an orientation adviser
Description: New Student Services at The University of Texas at Austin seeks a diverse group of talented students to develop, plan and execute the 2013 summer orientation program. Attend this meeting for more information, or visit link below.

Summary: Association of Black Psychologists meets
Description: Attend a graduate school-oriented meeting of the Association of Black Psychologists to discuss how to properly create written documents such as CVs, emails with potential advisers and personal statements.

Summary: Master of Science in Finance program hosts info session
Description: Learn about the master of science in finance offered by the Department of Finance in the McCombs School of Business, designed for students from a wide variety of backgrounds, including liberal arts, natural sciences, engineering and business. No previous work experience is required. Meeting features snacks and prizes.

Summary: Texas MSTC information session announced
Description: Learn about the Master's of Science in Technology Commercialization (MSTC) at this information session. Session begins with a presentation by Program Director Dr. Gary Cadenhead, followed by alumni comments and an open forum for questions.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 107

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents conversation on abstraction
Description: Center Space Project presents "A Conversation on Abstraction," a discussion session with Nick Griffin, Phillip Harrell and Anne Riley, artists whose work is featured in the exhibition "Now What It Never Was," on view at the Visual Arts Center through Oct. 13.

Summary: Texas softball plays Alvin Community College
Description: Texas softball hosts the Alvin Community College Dolphins.

Summary: Collegiate Muslim Professionals hold info session
Description: Are you active in seeking opportunities for personal and professional growth? Ambitious in pursuing an impactful and engaging career? Collegiate Muslim Professionals helps students discern and actualize their goals. Attend this information session to meet the CMP executive board and members. Visit the Facebook link below for updates.

Summary: Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority holds info session
Description: Theta Nu Xi Sorority is active in shaping the community through ethics, diversity, leadership and more. Attend this information session to learn about the organization and meet the current members.

Summary: Daniel Hope & Friends present Music from Terezin
Description: Daniel Hope and Friends present Music from Terezin, part two of the Remarkable Power of Music series, featuring the Miro Quartet. Presented as part of the "Creativity in the Face of Death: The Contemporary Resonance of Terezin" symposium.

Summary: Participate in "The Void" performance art piece
Description: Participate in a performance art piece titled "The Void." Participation takes approximately four minutes.

Summary: University Health Services holds flu shot clinic
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. For students, most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."
