Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Hall of Honors

Summary: Prints in Blanton's collection are topic of gallery talk
Description: Blanton staff members Francesca Consagra, Colette Crossman and Catherine Zinser discuss prints by William Hogarth (1697-1764), an English artist, satirist and social reformer, in this Perspectives gallery talk.

Summary: Book repair workshop offered
Description: Dropped your favorite book in the bathtub? New puppy grabbed your precious edition? Learn how to preserve and/or repair your personal book collection using readily available materials. Use library samples or bring a book of your own.

Summary: Play about Terezin is topic of community discussion
Description: Students from Bastrop High School who participated in an award-winning production of Celeste Raspanti's play "I Never Saw Another Butterfly" read poetry from Terezin and talk about the experience of portraying the doomed children of the camp. This event is part of the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies' and Texas Performing Arts' interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death," which explores the impact of the music and art created by prisoners of the camp.

Summary: Bevonomics 102 topic is the scholarship search
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships and learn writing tips to improve your application in this short Bevonomics course.

Summary: Ireland Maymester information session held
Description:
Attend an information session about the university's Maymester in Ireland, at University College, Dublin. Contact Professor Brad Love at lovebrad@austin.utexas.edu with questions.



The 2013 May-June program at University College is a writing-intensive course organized by the College of Communication that offers a chance to study Dublin's history as well as the impact of modern media.

Summary: Historical & artistic memory of Terezin camp is talk topic
Description: Professors Veronika Tuckerova and Robert Abzug present a lecture on Terezin in historical and artistic consciousness. This event is part of the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies' and Texas Performing Arts' interdisciplinary symposium "Terezin: Creativity in the Face of Death," which explores the impact of the music and art created by prisoners of the camp.

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Learn more about the program and application process at this session. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Learn about study abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua
Description: Attend a general information session for students interested in the "Afro-Caribbean Politics and Culture in Central America" summer abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua.

Summary: Return of the PRI in Mexico is talk topic
Description: Professor Sergio Aguayo discusses the return of Mexico's Partido Revolucionario Institucional (PRI). Aguayo is professor of international studies at El Colegio de México.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Study textiles and apparel in China
Description: Attend an information session to learn how you can take TXA 365 (Advanced Topics in Textiles and Apparel) in China. Pizza and drinks provided.

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: Questionnaire design seminar offered for undergrads
Description: The Office of Survey Research offers a two-hour Survey Basics & Questionnaire Design Seminar for UT undergrads. Learn to create a quality questionnaire that leads to the best results for your research project. Open to all current UT undergrad students. Contact beth.vanriper@austin.utexas.edu to pre-register.

Summary: Professionalism is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides inside tips on creating and maintaining your professionalism, including a discussion of communication with staff, faculty and peers, along with important tips on interview protocol. Presented by the College of Natural Sciences - Peer Leader Academy.

Summary: NRG Energy president of Electric Vehicles speaks at program
Description: Arun Banskota, president of Electric Vehicle Services at NRG Energy, presents "Electric Vehicles and the EVGo Program" at this week's Energy Symposium. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: McCombs VIP Speaker Series presents Don Knauss
Description: The McCombs VIP Distinguished Speaker this month is Donald R. "Don" Knauss, CEO of the Clorox Company. In addition to a distinguished history in the field of business, Knauss received the Jackie Robinson Foundation's ROBIE Award for industry achievement in 2006, the foundation's highest tribute to an individual who has promoted and expanded opportunities for minorities in the corporate world.

Summary: Latino filmmaking is panel topic
Description:
Emerging filmmakers Miguel Alvarez, Sergio Carvajal, Maru Buendia-Senties and Alex Avila introduce their work and join a discussion about the state of Latino filmmaking.



Co-moderators are Dr. Joseph D. Straubhaar (Amon G. Carter Professor of Communication, Department of Radio-TV-Film) and Jean Anne Lauer, Cine Las Americas.



Co-sponsored by the UT Latino Media Studies program, Center for Mexican American Studies, Teresa Lozano Long Institute of Latin American Studies and the Department of Radio-Television-Film.

Summary: Acts of Sharing holds bowling party
Description: Meet the UT alumnus who founded Acts of Sharing, a collaborative consumption start-up in Austin whose mission is "to create a cultural shift toward deeper and more sustainable communities through the sharing of possessions."

Summary: Doubles nights held at Penick-Allison Tennis Center
Description: Are you looking for a great way to get some exercise and have some fun?  The Penick-Allison Tennis Center offers Longhorns Doubles Nights, Thursdays from Oct. 11-Nov. 15. Registrants receive a free t-shirt. Women rated 4.0 and above and men rated 3.5 and above are eligible to participate. Email Granger Huntress at Granger@utexas.edu to reserve your spot.

Summary: Award-winning novelist Antoine Wilson reads at BookPeople
Description: The New Writers Project presents an evening with award-winning novelist Antoine Wilson, appearing as part of the New Writers Tour, a reading series that introduces emerging authors that people are already talking about. Wilson will speak about and sign his new, critically acclaimed novel, "Panorama City."

Summary: Guns, arms and rights are Libertarian Longhorns topic
Description: Tired of watching presidential debates filled with shallow rhetoric and empty promises? Join Libertarian Longhorns this Thursday to listen to a substantive discussion on the 2nd Amendment led by Payton Mogford.

Summary: Science Under the Stars topic is the urban lives of animals
Description: UT Austin graduate student Patrick Stinson discusses the the myriad ways in which animals and humans interact in urban ecosystems. Science Under the Stars is a free, monthly public outreach lecture series founded and organized by graduate students in the Section of Integrative Biology at University of Texas at Austin. Arrive early for refreshments and activities for kids of all ages.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Summary: Spectrum Dance Theater performs work about Terezin camp
Description:
Spectrum Dance Theater presents "The Theater of Needless Talents," choreographed and directed by Donald Byrd. Performed as part of Creativity in the Face of Death: The Contemporary Resonance of Terezin. Visit http://www.texasperformingarts.org/terezin to learn more.



Presented in partnership with the Department of Theatre and Dance and the Jewish Community Association of Austin. Creativity in the Face of Death is a three-day symposium featuring music and dance performances, photo exhibitions and panel discussions exploring the enduring influence of music and art created by prisoners at Terezin, the "model ghetto" created by the Nazis near Prauge in late 1941.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Marco Bellocchio's "Vincere" screened
Description:
I Film del Circolo presents Marco Bellocchio's award-winning "Vincere" (2009), a gripping presentation of the little-known story of Benito Mussolini's first wife, Ida Dalser, and their son Albino.

Set against the backdrop of   Italy in the 1910s, 1920s and 1930s, "Vincere" says as much about fascist Italy and its ruler as it does about its central character. In Italian with English subtitles.

Summary: Learn tips & tricks of research in the Information Age
Description: Learn how to research using the best Internet sources and other sources. Learn tricks of key words and ways to match your research to your assignment.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC), Undergraduate Writing Center 211

Summary: International Affairs Society holds book drive
Description: Help the International Affairs Society (IAS) fill five Kenyan libraries with your favorite children's books. Donate books to the IAS book drive, held in partnership with the Nobelity Project (for more info: http://nobelity.org/).
Location: Gebauer Building (GEB) 2.306 and Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18

Summary: UT RecSports hosts Tailgate by the Pool
Description: RecSports alumni and friends of RecSports are invited to a Tailgate by the Pool event, three hours prior to kickoff of the UT vs. BU game on Saturday, Oct. 20. Be our guest and enjoy food, drinks and live music in one of the most unique settings on campus. RSVP by Oct. 16 to rsvp@utrecsports.org. Groups welcome but reservations are suggested.

Summary: SSC Seminar presents math professor Andrew Blumberg
Description:
The SSC Seminar Series presents UT math professor Andrew Blumberg, giving a talk titled "The Interaction Between Computational Algebraic Topology and Statistics." 



This talk provides an overview of the techniques of computational algebraic topology and then discusses recent work aimed at integrating this methodology with standard statistical practice to perform "topological hypothesis testing."

Summary: Population Research Center hosts Dr. Arlene Rosen
Description: Dr. Arlene Rosen of the Department of Anthropology delivers a talk titled "Adapting to Climate Change, Food Shortages and Drought: Lessons from the Ancient Near East."

Summary: Study abroad financial aid & scholarships reviewed
Description: Financial aid information for students interested in Study Abroad Office faculty-led Maymester and summer programs is discussed at this information session.

Summary: Social work Maymester in London info session held
Description: Attend an information session about the "Roots of Social and Economic Justice: An International Perspective" Maymester abroad in London, England.

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: José Esteban Muñoz speaks at CMAS symposium
Description:
José Esteban Muñoz, professor of performance studies at New York University, presents the kickoff lecture for the fall 2012 CMAS symposium, Sexing the Borderlands: From the Midwest Corridor and Beyond. Muñoz's lecture is titled "The Brown Commons: The Sense of Wildness." A reception follows.



Sponsored by the Center for Mexican American Studies; the LGBTQ/Sexualities research cluster in the Center for Women's and Gender Studies; the Teresa Lozano Long Institute for Latin American Studies; the Performance as Public Practice program in the Department of Theatre and Dance; the Latino Media Studies program in the College of Communication; the Department of English; and allgo.

Summary: Philip Stern discusses "evolution of the city of Bombay"
Description: Philip Stern discusses the entangled political and intellectual history of the British Empire in India, which can be traced to the Anglo-Portuguese conflict over the late-seventeenth-century transfer of the colony of Bombay. Stern is assistant professor of history at Duke University.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: UT women's swimming & diving team hosts Orange-White Meet
Description: The UT women's swimming and diving team starts its season with the Orange-White Meet. Come see the team in action as they compete against each other for squad bragging rights.
Location: Lee & Joe Jamail Texas Swim Center

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Eusebius of Emesa's Commentary on Genesis is talk topic
Description: Attend a lecture Lucas van Romapy, Duke University, on Eusebius of Emesa (4th century) and his Commentary on Genesis, titled "Between Greek and Syriac; Between Judaism and Christianity."
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governor's Room 3.116

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.
Location: McCombs School of Business Atrium (CBA third floor)

Summary: Texas soccer plays Texas Tech
Description: The Longhorn soccer team takes on the Texas Tech Red Raiders. Teacher and Government Employee Appreciation Day ticket price is $4 (general admission). Call 512-232-3865 to purchase by noon, Friday, Oct. 12; advance sale only. Canned food donations accepted (donate five for prizes, while supplies last).
Location: Mike A. Meyers Stadium & Soccer Field

Summary: Praise Night presented by Innervisions Gospel Choir
Description: Innervisions Gospel Choir hosts its first concert of this school year, featuring a program of worship through song, dance and poetry. Join us for worship and fellowship.

Summary: Access Christian Fellowship hosts gathering
Description: Join Access Christian Fellowship's Large Group Gathering for worship, fellowship and discipleship. We discuss topics relevant to students as they are living out their faith on campus.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays Kansas
Description: Texas volleyball faces the Kansas Jayhawks in a Big 12 Conference matchup. Medical Community Night: $4 general admission ticket for all employees in the medical community and guests. Purchase by Friday, Oct. 12 at noon at 512-232-3865; advance sale only.

Summary: CMAS hosts fall 2012 symposium
Description:
The Center for Mexican American Studies is proud to sponsor annual public symposia, beginning this fall with Sexing the Borderlands: From the Midwest Corridor and Beyond. This gathering of leading scholars from diverse disciplines is designed to facilitate and further conversations central to the changing field of Mexican American studies.



Sponsored by the Center for Mexican American Studies; the LGBTQ/Sexualities research cluster in the Center for Women's and Gender Studies; the Teresa Lozano Long Institute for Latin American Studies; the Performance as Public Practice program in the Department of Theatre and Dance; the Latino Media Studies program in the College of Communication; the Department of English; and allgo.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts Plant Sale & Gardening Festival
Description: The Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center's Fall Plant Sale & Gardening Festival provides the best selection of hardy Central Texas plants, shrubs and trees, including hard-to-find options. Nearly 300 different native plant species will be available. Enjoy guided hikes at 11 a.m., 1 and 2 p.m., expert advice, storytime at 1 p.m., book signings and more.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts tree nursery seed planting
Description: Help the Campus Environmental Center/Green Fee tree nursery at the Wildflower Center put soil and seeds into 100,000 pots. The trees will help reforest the Bastrop Lost Pines after last September's fires. Sign up to volunteer at the link below. For carpool information or other questions, email Trees@UTEnvironment.org.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Texas Ballroom offers Viennese Workshop
Description: A two-hour Viennese workshop will be taught by an instructor from GoDance studio. This is a great way to learn for the upcoming Great Waltz.

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: See basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Sunday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Sunday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Texas soccer takes on Kansas
Description:
Longhorns Soccer plays the Kansas Jayhawks. Sunday web coupon is $8. Coupons must be printed and redeemed at any Myers Stadium box office on day of the match. Gates open one hour prior to the start of each match. Longhorns Kids Club Party is a pre-match party for club members. Visit LonghornsKidsClub.com for details. 



Post-match Youth Clinic is free to kids 8th grade and under. Players should come dressed with their soccer cleats and bring their own ball. Please make sure child's name is on their soccer ball.
Location: Mike A. Meyers Stadium & Soccer Field

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton Museum
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Great Organ Series features David Heller
Description: Organist David Heller performs.

Summary: Apply to be an orientation adviser
Description: New Student Services at The University of Texas at Austin seeks a diverse group of talented students to develop, plan and execute the 2013 summer orientation program. Attend this meeting for more information or visit the link below.

Summary: Construction Industry Institute course offered
Description: The Construction Industry Institute offers a five-day Planning and Design course. Online registration is now closed. Contact Erin Warner at erin.muire@austin.utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Learn about Intellectual Entrepreneurship internship
Description: Visit the link below to learn about the Intellectual Entrepreneurship Pre-Graduate School Internship, which gives undergrads the opportunity to work closely with a graduate student mentor and/or faculty member.

Summary: Women sought for research on weight & dissatisfaction
Description: Researchers in the Department of Kinesiology and Health Education have designed a short survey to better understand how women deal with day-to-day experiences that make them think about their weight. Your participation in this research will provide valuable information to help women better cope with their body weight and related dissatisfaction. Click on the link below to complete the survey.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Karl Miller
Description: "Sound Investments: Amateur Musicians Making American Pop" is a talk by Dr. Karl Miller, Institute for Historical Studies fellow and associate professor of history at The University of Texas at Austin. He is the author of the award-winning book "Segregating Sound: Inventing Folk and Pop Music in the Age of Jim Crow."

Summary: Study Abroad Office hosts internship info session
Description: New Freeman Asia stipends are available for internships in Asia. Attend an information session with Adam Jones, CET senior manager for Asia Programs, to learn about internship programs in Beijing and Shanghai. Can't make it to the session? Call 512-471-6490, email studyabroadoffice@austin.utexas.edu or stop by the office at 2222 Rio Grande Suite 2.201C.

Summary: Eric McKee discusses Mozart's ballroom dances
Description: Guest lecturer Eric McKee presents a talk titled "Hearing the Body in Motion: Mozart's Ballroom Dances." McKee is author of "Decorum of the Minuet, Delirium of the Waltz: A Study of Dance-Music Relations in 3/4 Time."

Summary: Warfield Center holds roundtable on Fisher case
Description: What are the larger implications of the Fisher v. University of Texas case? How does the struggle for affirmative action in the United States compare with struggles for racial justice in other parts of the Americas? A panel of Warfield Center for African and African American Studies staff discusses these questions and more.
Location: Jester Center (JES), John L. Warfield Center A232A

Summary: Bevonomics 302A covers stocks, bonds and mutual funds
Description: Find out what stocks, bonds and mutual funds are, and how they work.

Summary: Lars von Trier film series continues with "Dogville"
Description: "Dogville" (2003) is the wonderful first film in Lars von Trier's "USA - Land of Opportunities" trilogy. Nicole Kidman plays a young fugitive in one of her best roles ever.

Summary: Free ESL class offered for advanced students
Description: A four-week class for advanced ESL students is offered from Oct. 15-Nov. 9, 6-8 p.m. Topics include daily writing (GRE, SAT, TOEFL, IELTS, or other as you choose) and workshops on special topics. Sign up at Facebook link below.

Summary: Rational Middle Energy Project presents films & discussion
Description: The Rational Middle Energy Project presents short films on shale gas followed by a panel discussion about energy. Filmmaker Gregory Kallenberg and expert panelists discuss whether natural gas can help achieve a cleaner energy future and address the realities of drilling. Reception at 6 p.m.; hors d'oeuvres follow event at 7:30.

Summary: Master of Science in Business Analytics info session held
Description: Learn about the new Master of Science in Business Analytics offered by the IROM Department in the McCombs School of Business. This is a one-year degree with no work experience required. Students from engineering, math, economics, statistics, MIS and other quantitative fields are encouraged to attend.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: Mises Circle discusses work of economist Oliver Williamson
Description:
In a session titled "Austrians, Neoclassicals and the Firm," the Mises Circle looks at Peter Klein's Mises Daily article on the work of Nobel Prize-winning neo-institutionalist economist Oliver Williamson, whose work provides intriguing perspectives on the nature of the firm. A short presentation from the neoclassical perspective precedes the discussion. Read the paper here: http://mises.org/daily/3784.



For extra credit, you can read Williamson's classic paper, "Transaction Cost Economics: The Natural Progression", which was also the topic of his Nobel Prize lecture.

Summary: 24-hour service kicks off at PCL
Description: Join the libraries and your Student Government (SG) representatives for the kickoff of 24-hour service at the Perry-Castañeda Library, just in time for midterms. SG president and vice president Thor Lund and Wills Brown will be on hand to officially launch the service expansion and hand out pizza (while it lasts) and prizes.
Location: Perry-Castaneda Library (PCL), UFCU Student Learning Commons

Summary: Plan II student seeks participants for Disney study
Description: As part of a thesis study of character development in Disney films, Plan II student Hilary Walker hosts a screening of Disney's "Mulan" and invites viewers to fill out a short survey about the main character. Filling out the survey is voluntary and not required to view the films. Contact Walker at hilary_walker@austin.rr.com with questions.

Summary: Liberal Arts grad students: Sign up for grant workshop
Description:
Interested in applying for grants but don't know where to start? Sign up for a workshop to be held Friday, Oct. 26, at 12:30 p.m. Learn the basics: what kinds of funding graduate students are eligible for, where to find opportunities and how to organize your application process. RSVP by Monday, Oct. 22, to Melanie Morgan at mmorgan@austin.utexas.edu to reserve your place. 



Open to graduate students in the College of Liberal Arts only.

Summary: Health Week 2012 focus is mental, physical, emotional
Description: The ladies of Delta Xi announce Health Week, a chance to boost your mental, physical and emotional health with three days of events. View the Facebook list below for a complete list of events.

Summary: Texas State Employees Union table at Gregory Gym
Description:
Visit the Texas State Employees Union information and sign-up table to learn more about how the union seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions for all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at The University of Texas at Austin. 



The union advocates across-the-board flat-amount pay raises, opposes all attempts to remove long-standing protections against arbitrary cuts in benefits, and opposes

efforts to privatize part or whole sections of our workforce.

Summary: Study Czech literature in Prague
Description: Learn about studying Czech literature in Prague through UT Maymester programs.

Summary: Colloquium examines traditional college financial aid
Description: Join the LBJ School Center for Health and Social Policy (CHASP) for a lunchtime colloquium featuring a presentation by Dr. Douglas Harris of Tulane University titled "Is Traditional College Financial Aid Too Little, Too Late? Early Results from a Randomized Trial of a 'Promise' Scholarship for Low-Income Students." Register at link below.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Landmarks public art tour announced
Description: Join Landmarks docents for an insightful and conversational tour of Landmarks public art projects located throughout the main campus. Meets in the Bass Concert Hall lobby. For more information, contact Landmarks Education Coordinator Taylor Browning at taylor.browning@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall lobby

Summary: Study documentary photography in Prague
Description: Attend an information session to learn about studying documentary photography in Prague, Czech Republic.

Summary: Geopolitics and political clans in Russia are topic of talk
Description: International energy lawyer Robert Amsterdam gives a talk titled "Geopolitics and Political Clans in Russia." Amsterdam, whose clients include the jailed Russian dissident Mikahil Khodorkovsky, provides an insider's view of the internecine battles among the Russian elite. This talk should be of particular interest to students and teachers of the social sciences, law, history, public policy and energy related studies.

Summary: Learn about the Transport Phenomena Maymester in England
Description: Attend an information session about the Transport Phenomena in Living Systems Maymester abroad in Cambridge, England.

Summary: Politics of inclusion is topic of talk
Description: Professor Mala Htun of the University of New Mexico presents a talk titled "Politics of Inclusion: Women, Afrodescendants, and Indigenous Peoples in Latin America." Light refreshments served.

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Learn more about the program and application process at this session. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Customer service is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This hands-on workshop provides you with strategies for delivering quality customer service by incorporating key improvisation principles. You will learn how to put these techniques into practice through group activities and discussion. Presented by the Texas Interdisciplinary Plan.

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: Goal setting is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: A workshop on goal setting is offered for students employed by UT Austin. This workshop includes an interactive PowerPoint followed by group exercises. Learn how to create, plan and follow up on SMART (specific, manageable, achievable, realistic and timely) goals. Presented by the College of Natural Sciences - Peer Leader Academy.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Certificate Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in commercial real estate. Register to attend at link below.

Summary: Texas Native Plant Week butterfly gardening workshop held
Description: The Wildflower Center celebrates Texas Native Plant Week and the state's indigenous plants, which typically need less water and maintenance than non-natives. Attend an evening butterfly gardening workshop through Go Native(http://www.wildflower.org/gonativeu/). For more details, visit the link below or call 512-232-0100.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: UT Lions Club holds general meeting
Description: Looking for community service and social opportunities? Stop by the Lions Club's general meeting to learn how you can get involved in meaningful community service projects and exciting socials with other members.

Summary: University Flying Club meets
Description: Students who are interested in aviation, becoming a pilot or simply enjoy travel are invited to join the University Flying Club at this meeting. All are welcome. Guest speakers from Textron/Bell Helicopters will attend. Free pizza served after the meeting.

Summary: Latin America Network presents discussion on Cuba
Description: Join the Latin America Network for its first meeting of the year, featuring an open discussion on Cuba in the historical and modern context, including cultural topics. Food and drink provided.

Summary: Student Events Center presents Dive-in Movie: "Jaws"
Description: Need a mid-week study break?  Enjoy a screening of "Jaws" while swimming in the Gregory Gym Event Pool. When a gigantic great white shark begins to menace the small island community of Amity, a police chief, a marine scientist and grizzled fisherman set out to stop it. Runs 124 minutes.

Summary: Hindu Students Association meets
Description: The Hindu Students Association meets every Tuesday to discuss various topics in Hinduism. Meetings are discussion oriented and designed to be a group-learning experience.

Summary: Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority holds info session
Description: Theta Nu Xi Sorority is active in shaping the community through ethics, diversity, leadership and more. Attend this information session to learn about the organization and meet the current members.

Summary: African American undergrads sought for research study
Description: Undergraduate African American students ages 18 and over are sought for a psychology research study examining how a range of attitudes and experiences impact African American students' academic achievement. Participants' names to be entered in a drawing for a $50 gift card. For more information, email mcclainse@utexas.edu or click the link below.

Summary: Launch Leadership Conference registration open
Description: Register by Oct. 18 to network with other students from across Texas at the Launch Leadership Conference, Friday, Nov. 2, where students with an interest General Electric, ConocoPhillips and KPMG forge professional and social relationships and take part in case studies and workshops with representatives from large corporations. Transportation provided.

Summary: Find articles on Latin America/Latinos in the U.S.
Description: Learn the best methods for locating articles, and the best databases for finding research and news articles about and from Latin America, and about Latinos in the United States.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 1.115

Summary: Participants sought for health information search study
Description:
Participate in a 90-minute study on information searching behavior using search engines. Participants are eligible if they do not major or minor in medical related fields, such as nursing, medicine, pharmacy, biology or public health. Sign up by contacting Ramona Broussard (ramona@ischool.utexas.edu).



IRB approval number: 2012-03-0096. Approving body: The University of Texas at Austin IRB.

Summary: Texas THON holds Why We Stand Wednesday
Description: Texas THON is a philanthropic organization that raises money for Dell Children's Hospital, which provides treatment to all children, regardless of their ability to pay. Attend this event to sign a wall for children and stand for those who can't.

Summary: ECE Distinguished Lecture presented by Takeo Kanade
Description: The UT Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering is proud to present a talk by distinguished lecturer Professor Takeo Kanade titled "First-Person Vision."
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: RecSports Job Fair announced
Description: Students in search of a part-time job for the spring semester are invited to apply and interview for a variety of positions at the RecSports Job Fair. Be ready for an interview by bringing a completed application, available at Gregory Gym and the RecSports Center or http://bit.ly/1j3tQT.

Summary: Research + Pizza presents "Beauty Pays"
Description: Dr. Daniel Hamermesh of the Department of Economics discusses the research underpinning his 2011 book, "Beauty Pays: Why Attractive People Are More Successful." Free pizza served while it lasts.

Summary: Raise your stock with iForty
Description: iForty invites you to "Raise Your Space with Microsoft OneNote." Vanessa Moore demonstrates Microsoft OneNote, a digital notebook that lets you collect everything you need for any project you are working on, and capture your ideas and information in electronic form. RSVP to jstonerice@austin.utexas.edu by Oct. 16.

Summary: Violent history of Mexican-U.S. borderlands is talk topic
Description: The LLILAS Faculty Book Series welcomes author Nicole Guidotti-Hernandez, Department of American Studies, who discusses her book "Unspeakable Violence: Remapping U.S. & Mexican National Imaginaries." Frank Guridy, Department of History, serves as discussant.

Summary: International development NGOs & diplomacy are panel topic
Description: Attend a panel discussion on the past and future role of international development NGOs in shaping U.S. foreign policy. Panelists include Dr. Stephen Porter (University of Cincinnati), Stephanie Majerowicz (Center for Global Development) and Todd G. Smith (LBJ School). Hosted by the Student Council on Rethinking Diplomacy.

Summary: Copyright, academic work and fair use are talk topic
Description: Curious about what exactly fair use is? Have you ever wondered if you can use an image in your academic work? Not sure about the restrictions on performing a piece of music? Copyright attorney Georgia Harper discusses these and other issues and answers questions.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 4.106

Summary: Celebrate National Fossil Day
Description: Join paleontologists at Texas Memorial Museum for National Fossil Day, an event promoting awareness and stewardship of fossils as well as a greater appreciation of their scientific and educational value.

Summary: The Daily Texan & Texas Travesty hold open house
Description: Tour the newly renovated newsroom of The Daily Texan and Texas Travesty, where walls have come down to promote collaboration and the transition to a digital future. Snacks and cake provided. RSVP to rsvp@texasstudentmedia.com.

Summary: Language Matters Series presents Dr. Azza Ahmad
Description: The Language Matters Series presents a talk by Dr. Azza Ahmad, lecturer, Department of Middle Eastern Studies, who presents the results of her research on the language-learning experiences of college students.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Lone Star Room 3.208

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Learn more about the program and application process at this session. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: The Department of Spanish and Portuguese hosts an information session on summer 2013 faculty-led study abroad programs in Santander, Spain, Salvador da Bahia, Brazil and Antigua, Guatemala. Learn basic information about the programs and discuss the application process.

Summary: Careers in student affairs information session held
Description: Students interested in the field of Student Affairs are invited to attend an information session on the topic, featuring a Q&A session with campus professionals. Find out if a career in student affairs is an option for you.
Location: San Jacinto Residence Hall (SJH), multipurpose room

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: Study organic chemistry in Spain
Description: Attend an information session to learn about taking organic chemistry II (CH 320N) in Spain. Pizza and drinks provided.

Summary: FIMRC, children's medical relief group, meets
Description: Attend the second meeting of UT's chapter of the Foundation for International Children's Medical Relief, a national organization dedicated to providing access to medical care for children in developing countries around the world. Food is provided and all students are welcome.

Summary: Leadership Series presents ethical decision making workshop
Description: The Leadership Series presents Ethical Decision Making, a workshop. The series is designed to develop individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations. Workshops are held twice a month in the fall and spring semesters.

Summary: Texas Native Plant Week celebrated at Wildflower Center
Description: Enjoy a garden tour and a talk about native plants by the Wildflower Center's horticulture director. Meet in the Center's courtyard that Wednesday at 5:30 p.m. to walk the gardens with Andrea DeLong-Amaya, who also talks about the benefits and variety of native plants in Central Texas at 6:30 p.m. in the auditorium.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter.

Summary: Student Leaders Pursuing Law present law student meet-up
Description:
Student Leaders Pursuing Law (SLPL) hosts an event with students from UT Law School, who talk about their experiences in law school and to answer questions from undergraduate students interested in pursuing a career in law.



SLPL is a student organization at The University of Texas at Austin that aims to increase the awareness of the importance of diversity in the legal profession while maintaining a useful network of contacts within the profession to provide guidance and advice to aspiring undergraduate law students.

Summary: Author Michael Chabon appears on campus
Description:
L.A. Times book critic David Ulin speaks with Pulitzer Prize-winning writer Michael Chabon about Chabon's life, work and new novel, "Telegraph Avenue." Seating is limited. Line forms upon arrival of the first patron, and doors open 30 minutes in advance. A book signing follows, with books available for sale from BookPeople.



Michael Chabon is the bestselling author of "The Mysteries of Pittsburgh," "A Model World," "Wonder Boys," "Werewolves in Their Youth," "The Final Solution," "The Yiddish Policemen's Union," "Maps and Legends," "Gentlemen of the Road" and "Summerland." His novel "The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier and Clay" won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 2001.

Summary: Comparative Americanists screen Cuban "Ciudad en Rojo"
Description: The Comparative Americanists host a screening of Rebeca Chavez's "Ciudad en Rojo" (Cuba, 2009). Discussion following the film led by Ph.D. candidate Enrique Gonzalez-Conty of the Spanish and Portuguese Department.

Summary: Humanities Institute present "Public & Private" lecture
Description:
As part of its lecture series on the theme of "Public & Private," the Humanities Institute welcomes anthropologist Kathleen Stewart, presenting a lecture titled "Worldings: Scenes of Life in the U.S. Now."



Stewart, professor and chair of Anthropology at The University of Texas at Austin, will speak about the forms and sensibilities of contemporary life. The talk draws on Stewart's many years of ethnographic research in Appalachia, Las Vegas and Texas. The lecture engages the fields of cultural studies, geography and American Studies as well as anthropology. A recipient of fellowships from the Rockefeller Foundation and The National Endowment for the Humanities, Stewart has given numerous lectures throughout North America and Europe.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: YES Prep public charter school holds recruiting session
Description:
YES Prep is a high-performing, open-enrollment public charter school that serves 7,000 students across 11 Houston campuses. The school is recruiting new teachers. Learn more at this session. RSVP to Lindsey Windham at Lindsey.Windham@yesprep.org or

online at http://events.r20.constantcontact.com/register/event?oeidk=a07e6hgip2t5e6e7914&llr=j6lefwcab.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays Iowa State
Description:
Texas Volleyball faces the Iowa State Cyclones in a pivotal Big 12 match-up. Medical Community Night: $4 general admission ticket for all employees in the medical community and guests. Call 512-232-3865; advance sale only, by noon Wednesday, Oct. 17. 



Web Coupon Wednesday: Print out a web coupon and receive a general admission ticket and small popcorn for only $5. Coupons must be printed and redeemed at the Gregory Gym ticket windows on the day of the match. Gates open one hour prior to the start of each match.

Summary: Hearts of Texas bake sale held at Benson Collection
Description: The Benson Latin American Collection holds its annual bake sale as part of the Hearts of Texas employee charitable campaign. Stop by and grab a delicious treat donated by the UT Libraries staff and support a charitable cause.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection plaza

Summary: Zotero Manage Citations class offered
Description:
Learn how to use this free, web-based tool to collect, manage and cite your sources. The session introduces the basics of Zotero and moves into more advanced concepts to be selected by attendees. 

Special sessions of this class can be arranged for UT groups or departments. To learn more, visit the link below.

Summary: College of Fine Arts hosts Study Abroad Fair
Description: Learn about programs specifically designed for fine arts majors at the annual College of Fine Arts Study Abroad Fair. Information on a variety of programs available, including a Maymester Abroad 2013 course, a whole summer, a semester or a full year.
Location: Co-op Fine Arts Student Center and Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA) FAB Gallery 1.101

Summary: CMCT presents Dr. Taiping Chen, MD Anderson Cancer Center
Description: Taiping Chen, Ph.D., associate professor of molecular carcinogenesis at the MD Anderson Cancer Center (Science Park Research Division), presents a seminar titled "Epigenetic Modifiers in Mammalian Development and Human Diseases."

Summary: Learn about study abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua
Description: Attend a general information session for students interested in the "Afro-Caribbean Politics and Culture in Central America" summer abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua.

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: See basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Staff Council monthly meeting held
Description: The monthly meeting of the Staff Council is open to all staff and all are encouraged to attend.

Summary: Bevonomics 102 topic is the scholarship search
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships and get writing tips to improve your application in this short Bevonomics course.

Summary: Brazilian musician/scholar José Miguel Wisnik gives talk
Description: Brazilian musician, essayist and professor José Miguel Wisnik presents a talk titled "Machado maxixe: O caso Pestana." Wisnik is visiting Austin as a musician, accompanying the internationally celebrated dance company, Grupo Corpo, performing on Oct. 18-19 at Bass Concert Hall.

Summary: BE Global Internship Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.
Location: International Office, 715 W. 23rd St., Multi-Purpose Room

Summary: Bevonomics 103 topic is student loans
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Social Work Maymester in London hosts information session
Description: Attend an information session about the social work Maymester course in London, England, Roots of Social and Economic Justice: An International Perspective.

Summary: Blanton's Third Thursday is evening of art & activities
Description: Attend the Blanton's free evening of art and activities. Enjoy special prices at the Blanton Cafe. Activities include Yoga in the Galleries (6:30 p.m., passes distributed starting at 5:30); Blanton Book Club (7 p.m.); tour (7:30 p.m.).

Summary: "Einstein, Relativity & Myths" is talk by Alberto Martinez
Description:
Alberto A. Martinez, associate professor in the department of history, presents a lecture titled "Einstein, Relativity and Myth," about Einstein's groundbreaking 1905 paper on relativity and the myths it spawned.



In 1905, Albert Einstein, an unknown, third-class clerk at the Swiss Federal Office for Intellectual Property, solved outstanding problems in physics by proposing a theory about the relativity of time. Einstein's original paper became immensely influential in physics and other fields. Martinez discusses how his relativity paper of 1905 changed physics and how it also led to misinterpretations and myths.

Summary: 2012 City Safety Coalition meets
Description: Join forces with The University of Texas Police Department at this City Safety Coalition meeting, promoting education on safety topics pertinent to the West Campus and Riverside areas. Topics to be discussed are fire safety, code enforcement, graffiti, alcohol, thefts and how to report crimes. Other related questions will be answered.
Location: University Police Building (UPB), 2201 Robert Dedman Drive

Summary: Information session held for F-1 international students
Description:
An information session is offered for international students in F-1 status who want information about how to obtain off-campus work authorization for a position directly related to their field of study. The International Office will give an overview of Curricular Practical Training (CPT) eligibility, application materials and immigration requirements.



Co-sponsored by the Center for Strategic Advising & Career Counseling.

Summary: Energy VP to speak on gas-power nexus
Description: Eric Bradley, vice president for strategy at IPR-GDF Suez North America, gives a talk titled "Gas-Power Nexus: A Closer Look at the Gas Value-Chain in Power Production" at this week's UT Energy Symposium. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Third Thursday at COFA topic is study abroad
Description:
Learn how your study abroad experience could help you get the job you want. This Third Thursday @ COFA session focuses on the transferable skills from your abroad experience and how you can use them to your professional advantage. Free pizza served. 



Whether you've already studied abroad, or are simply considering it for the future, don't miss this opportunity.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: Epidemiologist Walter Willett presents talk
Description: The Department of Nutritional Sciences is honored to present an evening with Dr. Walter Willett, Fredrick John Stare professor of epidemiology and nutrition, Harvard School of Public Health. Willett presents "An Overview of Current Evidence on Diet and Health." A reception follows the talk.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Relationship violence & disabilities are performance topic
Description: Theatre for Dialogue hosts a performance with a focus on students with disabilities as part of Relationship Violence Awareness Month. Milk and cookies provided for participants.

Summary: Noche de Baile - Night of Dance hosted by MACC
Description: The Mexican American Culture Committee invites you to dance the night way at Noche de Baile, featuring Grammy Award-winning Austin band Grupo Fantasma, followed by DJ Vladimir. Come enjoy norteñas, cumbias, bachata, huapangos and much more. Light refreshments served throughout the evening.
Location: Gregory Gym Plaza (GRE); rain location: SAC ballroom 2.41NS

Summary: "It's a Girl" documentary screened
Description: The documentary film "It's a Girl" calls attention to the estimated 200 million girls who are "missing" every year due to gendercide, the deliberate and systematic destruction of a specific gender.

Summary: National Defense Authorization Act is talk topic
Description: The Libertarian Longhorns' Daniel Krawisz provides an informative presentation on the military detention and trial provisions in the National Defense Authorization Act, the biggest election issue no one's talking about.

Summary: Congressman Mickey Edwards discusses partisanship
Description: Former U.S. congressman Mickey Edwards discusses the current election and his new book, "The Parties Versus The People: How to Turn Republicans and Democrats into Americans." Edwards represented Oklahoma's 5th District in the U.S. House of Representatives for 16 years, and served on the Budget and Appropriations Committees.

Summary: The Magic of Reality is talk by Richard Dawkins
Description: "The Magic of Reality" is an evening with author Dr. Richard Dawkins. Doors open at 6:15 p.m. and seating is on a first come, first served basis. The talk will be followed by a book signing.

Summary: Political polarization is Strauss Institute panel topic
Description: "Political Polarization: A Conversation Across the Divide" addresses the widening and deepening gulf between Americans who identify as either Republican or Democrat. Presented in partnership with Harvard's Institute of Politics, we welcome Trey Grayson, Mark McKinnon and Linda Moore Forbes to partake in a frank conversation that bridges this partisan divide.

Summary: Gender & Sexuality Center Speaker Series hosts Kye Allums
Description:
The Gender & Sexuality Center Speaker Series is proud to present to Kye Allums: The Transition Tour. Allums is a 22-year-old African American male from Saint Paul, Minn. While in college, Allums made history by coming out as the first transgender basketball player to play openly on a Division 1 women's basketball team. This event can be found on Facebook here.



Allums' story was featured in this Sports Illustrated article.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton Museum
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Brazil's Grupo Corpo performs
Description: By popular demand, Texas Performing Arts presents the two-evening return of Brazil's world-renowned dance company, Grupo Corpo. Performance supported by ArtesAméricas.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: The Romans at Dinner: Lecture covers archaeology & art
Description: Dinner for the Romans was the central function of social life, and a formal dinner party was governed by numerous rules and conventions, many alien to modern ways. Written evidence about Roman dining habits can be expanded, enriched and sometimes challenged by that of archaeology and art. Presented by Katherine Dunbabin, emerita, Department of Classics, McMaster University.

Summary: Work Pressures Conference slated
Description: The College of Communication at The University of Texas at Austin and The Effective Edge announce the Work Pressures Conference - two days of lectures, featuring the research of scholars from around the world, on the latest advances related to work and organizational effectiveness. Register at goo.gl/TLriA.

Summary: Salsa Fest comes to Texas Union
Description: Join Longhorn Salsa for two nights of the best salsa and Latin dance instruction Austin has to offer, plus fun competitions and all your favorite music in salsa, bachata, merengue and more.

Summary: UT RecSports Bob Childress Classic announced
Description: Enjoy an afternoon of golf at an 18-hole course designed by the PGA Tour Design Center. Proceeds from this four-person scramble benefit the Division of Recreational Sports' Excellence Fund, which provides critical funding to enhance its programs and facilities. Check-in begins at 11 a.m., followed by lunch and shot gun start at 1 p.m.
Location: Falconhead Golf Club, 15201 Falcon Head Boulevard, Austin

Summary: Population Research Center hosts Dr. Giovanna Merli
Description: Dr. Giovanna Merli of the Department of Sociology at Duke University delivers a talk titled "China's Demographic Dynamics, Sexual Networks and the Spread of HIV."

Summary: Gender & Sexuality in History speaker is Faegheh Shirazi
Description: The Symposium on Gender and Sexuality in History presents "Death the Great Equalizer: Memorializing Martyred (Shahid) Women in the Republic of Iran," a talk by Professor Faegheh Shirazi, Middle Eastern studies.

Summary: Study Abroad financial aid & scholarship info session held
Description: Attend an information session on financial aid  and scholarships for students interested in Study Abroad Office faculty-led Maymester and summer programs.

Summary: Sustainable Architecture summer abroad info session held
Description: Learn about the "Sustainable Architecture and Design" summer abroad program in Munich, Germany, with courses led by Professor Vincent Snyder.

Summary: Nutritional Sciences speaker examines impact of dairy intake
Description: Dr. Walter Willett, Fredrick John Stare professor of epidemiology and nutrition, Department of Nutrition, Harvard School of Public Health, presents a talk titled "Three Servings of Dairy per Day: Essential Nutrition or Udderly Ridiculous?" as part of the ongoing speaker series sponsored by the Department of Nutritional Sciences.

Summary: Spanish heritage language learners are topic of talk
Description: The University of Texas at Austin has implemented a bilingual/bicultural track to the lower-division Spanish-language courses starting at the introductory level and continuing up through advanced grammar. As current participants in the development and instruction of these courses, we are eager to share insights gleaned from our experiences and research to assist others in better serving this population of language learners.
Location: Austin Community College (ACC), Rio Grande Campus, Main Building 125

Summary: Betty Smocovitis presents "Rhapsody on a Darwinian Theme"
Description: The Faculty Seminar on British Studies presents a talk by Betty Smocovitis, University of Florida, who is currently working on a project that explores Darwinism in song, theater and musical production.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Friday Afternoon Workshop focuses on essay exams
Description: How do you write under pressure? What strategies can help you make the most out of the time you have? Can you revise in an essay exam? Bring sample questions and find out how to strengthen your writing at the Friday Afternoon Workshop.

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Sixth annual William J. Battle Public Lecture presented
Description: Dr. Ralph Rosen of the University of Pennsylvania presents a lecture titled "Efficacy and Temporality in Greek Poetry of Invective and Satire." A reception follows the talk. The Battle Lecture is hosted annually by the graduate students of the UT Classics Department honoring former UT president and classics professor William J. Battle.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents "A Nation of Fear" panel
Description: Hosted during the opening reception for the exhibition "A Nation of Fear," Center Space Project presents a panel discussion examining the current wave of violence in Mexico, its causes and the widespread social and political effects, both in Mexico and the United States. Moderated by Dr. George Flaherty, assistant professor in art history.

Summary: Fest Africa 2012 announced
Description: Fest Africa is a showcase put on by the African Students Association every year celebrating the diversity and accomplishments of the African continent and its peoples. Music, dancing, food and fun make for an unforgettable night.

Summary: Men's club soccer plays Texas A&M in Conference Championship
Description: Support the UT Men's Club Soccer Team in the Conference Championship match against rivals Texas A&M. The Intramural Fields, set up with bleachers, restrooms and free parking, are able to accommodate all who wish to attend.

Summary: "The Cataract": D'Amour drama staged on campus
Description: Set in Minneapolis in 1883, this poetic drama explores one week in the lives of Cyrus and Lottie Finch, a stalwart couple who take in two vagabond lovers from the South. Written by Pulitzer Prize-nominated playwright Lisa D'Amour and directed by Daria Davis. Learn about Subscription Series savings at link below. Runs through Oct. 28, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Brazil's Grupo Corpo performs
Description: By popular demand, Texas Performing Arts presents the two-evening return of Brazil's world-renowned dance company, Grupo Corpo. Performance supported by ArtesAméricas.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Pharmacy Month celebrated with education, health screenings
Description: In celebration of October being pharmacy month, the UT College of Pharmacy's Project Collaborate provides free health education and health screenings. Get checked out and learn something new about the diverse pharmaceutical professions.

Summary: Work Pressures Conference concludes
Description: The Work Pressures Conference concludes. The conference features the research of scholars from around the world on the latest advances related to work and organizational effectiveness. Register at goo.gl/TLriA.

Summary: Daily Texan hosts kickoff countdown tailgate party
Description: Watch the game with Texas Student Media and enjoy free food and drinks provided by our sponsors. Event starts four hours prior to kickoff and continues through the UT game.

Summary: Registration open for faculty & staff wellness screening
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Screenings test levels of cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. For more information and to register now, use the link below, or call 866-935-5462.

Summary: Salsa Fest continues
Description: Longhorn Salsa hosts night two of Salsa Fest, featuring Latin dance instruction, competitions and the best of salsa, bachata, merengue and more.

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts tree nursery seed planting
Description: Help the Campus Environmental Center/Green Fee tree nursery at the Wildflower Center put soil and seeds into 100,000 pots. The trees will help reforest the Bastrop Lost Pines after last September's fires. Sign up to volunteer at the link below. For carpool information or other questions, email Trees@UTEnvironment.org.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Caribbean Fun Day announced
Description: Join the Caribbean Students Association for a fun day of Caribbean sports, featuring  cricket, soccer and great food. Attendees are welcome to bring a dish of their own to share.
Location: Adams Hemphill Park, 201 W 30th Street, Austin, TX 78705

Summary: Texas football takes on Baylor
Description: The Longhorns take on the Baylor Bears in Game 7 of the 2012 season.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Sunday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Sunday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Sam Houston State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Sam Houston State Bearkats. Tickets will only be sold at UFCU Disch-Falk on game day. Gates open two hours prior to the game.

Summary: "The Cataract": D'Amour drama staged on campus
Description: Set in Minneapolis in 1883, this poetic drama explores one week in the lives of Cyrus and Lottie Finch, a stalwart couple who take in two vagabond lovers from the South. Written by Pulitzer Prize-nominated playwright Lisa D'Amour and directed by Daria Davis. Learn about Subscription Series savings at link below. Runs Oct. 19, 24-27 at 8 p.m. and Oct. 27, 28 at 2 p.m.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: SoundSpace presented at Blanton Museum
Description:
SoundSpace is a concert series that brings together musicians, dancers and performance artists from all corners of Austin's artistic community for simultaneous performances throughout the Blanton Museum of Art. The October concert explores spatial music - music that surrounds and travels around the audience in all directions. 



The program will feature Orbits, a mesmerizing work for 80 trombones, soprano and organ; a theatrical work by Karlheinz Stockhausen that incorporates physical movement; interactive works for guitar and theremin; and solo works for voice and percussion.

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: See basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: "The Planets: An HD Odyssey" comes to PAC
Description: Experience a powerful performance of composer Gustav Holst's "The Planets" performed by the UT Wind Ensemble and Women of the UT Chamber Singers and Concert Chorale, paired with a high-definition film from NASA's latest exploration of the solar system.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Water Forum focus is Texas Drought 2012
Description: In a two-day forum on water and the Texas drought, experts from UT Austin and other state universities, state and federal agencies, and local water authorities discuss the wide-ranging impact of droughts on water resources, agriculture, power, property and economy, as well as assess progress and share new findings in drought science.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Learning from Anton Chekhov is anthropologist's talk topic
Description:
The Department of Anthropology 

2012-2013 Speaker Series presents Kirin Narayan, "Ethnography and Imagination: Learning from Anton Chekhov."

Summary: Resume review offered for College of Fine Arts students
Description: Get your resume in shape for the Arts Internship & Networking Fair. Fine Arts Career Services offers two resume review sessions, from 12-1 p.m. and 5-6 p.m. Sessions are for current College of Fine Arts students only.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: Study architectural engineering in London
Description: Attend this information session to learn about the Emerging Technologies in London Maymester. Courses taught by engineering professor Gregory Brooks.

Summary: Hip hop, mass media & racial storytelling is talk topic
Description: Hip hop has been considered the most influential and socially conscious American youth music since the emergence of rock 'n' roll.  But the commercial state of hip hop today offers very little social critique. In this talk, Tricia Rose, professor of Africana Studies at Brown University, addresses a number of questions at the heart of hip hop's retreat from politics.

Summary: Enhance reading instruction for kids with Down Syndrome
Description: Dr. Chris Lemons of the University of Pittsburgh delivers a lecture titled "Enhancing Reading Instruction for Children with Down Syndrome: Phonics, Behavioral Phenotype, and Individualization." RSVP with the subject heading "Lemons" to rsvp@meadowscenter.org.
Location: Sanchez Building (SZB), Cissy McDaniel Parker Deans Conference Room 238

Summary: Learn about summer abroad study in Guatemala
Description: Attend an information session about the "Culture, Diversity, and Education in Casa Herrera" summer abroad program in Antigua, Guatemala.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description: Dr. Mike Raney, University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.

Summary: Bevonomics 302B topic is investing for life
Description: Learn how to use investments to satisfy your financial goals.

Summary: MS in business analytics info session held
Description: Learn about the new master of science in business analytics offered at the McCombs School of Business. This is a one-year degree with no work experience required. Students from engineering, math, economics, statistics, MIS and other quantitative fields are encouraged to attend.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Visiting artist Matthew Monteith presents lecture
Description:
Matthew Monteith uses photography to investigate the enclosures, both literal and figurative, in which we live, work and play. By closely looking at these spaces -  museums, hospitals, classrooms and even automobiles - Monteith reveals both the isolation and fantasy of their inhabitants. 



Monteith is a visiting assistant professor of photography at the Massachusetts College of Art and Design.

Summary: Moving Through Conflict is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: Conflict seems to be a fact of life but does not have to cause anxiety. Explore your personal approach to handling conflict and get a better understanding of how conflict, when moved through effectively, can lead to personal and professional growth. Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Lars von Trier film series continues
Description: "Manderlay" (2005) is the second movie in Lars von Trier's USA - Land of Opportunities trilogy. The frightening tale stars Bryce Dallas Howard, Danny Glover and Willem Dafoe, who, after leaving Dogville, wander into a gated Alabama community still operating under the tenets of slavery.

Summary: Slow Food UT meets
Description: Slow Food UT meets every other Monday to talk about the cultural relevance of food today. Meetings feature guest speakers and the opportunity to work with other food groups on campus.

Summary: LabVIEW Core I and Core II certification program offered
Description:
Offered Mondays and Thursdays beginning on Oct. 22, this specially designed evening edition of the LabVIEW Academy program provides classroom curriculum and hands-on exercises to anyone seeking LabVIEW education and knowledge through an academic institution. No class meeting on Thanksgiving.



The LabVIEW Academy curriculum gives students the opportunity to validate their knowledge and skills at a professional level with certification.



This program will allow you to take the Certified LabVIEW Associate Developer (CLAD) certification exam as part of the course and at no extra cost. The exam will be administered in the class and on the last day of instruction. Experience and certification in LabVIEW could improve participants' career opportunities - providing graduates and potential employers with benefits.
Location: Ernest Cockrell Jr. Hall (ECJ), SC2 lab 3.402

Summary: Archives Week presents talk by fashion archivist
Description: Karen Trivette Cannell presents "Impressions: A Fashion Archives Experience," a public lecture about her work as assistant professor and head of Special Collections at the Fashion Institute of Technology Archives. Presented as part of the UT Society of American Archivists' annual Archives Week celebration.

Summary: "My Father Evgeni" is Andrey Zagdansky documentary
Description: Attend a screening of the documentary "My Father Evgeni," directed by Andrey Zagdansky. The film explores the relationship and transcontinental correspondence between a father and son whose lives are steeped in the cinema. It includes beguiling footage from Soviet archives to create an intimate portrait of a family living through dramatic changes. In Russian with English subtitles.

Summary: UT Hispanic Journalists meet for workshop
Description: UTHJ meets for a writers workshop and to discuss the upcoming Halloween event. Bring some writing samples and ideas; we are here to help.

Summary: Business cycle is topic of Mises Circle meeting
Description: Austrian economists argue that business cycles would not exist if it were not for credit expansion. Join the Mises Circle to discuss "Bank Credit Expansion and Its Effects on the Economic System," chapter 5 of Jesus Huerta de Soto's treatise "Money, Bank Credit, and Economic Cycles." Find the article here.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together under one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: 7,000 Pencil Pass Out is anti-dropout campaign
Description: Longhorn TFA will pass out 7,000 pencils in one day to represent the 7,000 students that drop out of school every day in the United States. The goal of this event is to raise awareness on campus about educational inequality and what students can do to reverse the dropout culture in our public schools.

Summary: disABILITY Advocate Foundation training held
Description:
The disABILITY Advocate Foundation Program is designed to help faculty, staff and students at The University of Texas at Austin develop knowledge and advocacy skills to promote inclusion and access for people with disability. 



The engaging two-hour training provides a foundation in disability awareness and allows for interaction and discussion among participants. Topics include disability-related language, how to recognize and reduce barriers for people with disabilities, the perspective of disability as an aspect of diversity and how to make a positive difference on campus for people with disabilities.

Summary: Apply for LeaderShape-Texas; learn more at info session
Description: Attend an information session on LeaderShape - Texas, a six-day leadership retreat open to undergraduates. Apply by Nov. 1 at 11:59 p.m. Thirty-minute information sessions take place Oct. 24 (6 p.m., UTC 1.144), Oct. 25 (3 p.m., ETC 2.102), Oct. 26 (11 a.m., WEL 4.224) and Oct. 29 (5 p.m., JCB 2.202).
Location: Various locations on campus; apply online

Summary: NSF doctoral dissertation research workshop held
Description: Doctoral students and faculty advisers in the College of Liberal Arts are invited to attend a session on the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) for the 2012-2013 academic year.

Summary: Religion in American war and diplomacy is lecture topic
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Religion in American War and Diplomacy: A History," with Andrew Preston, senior lecturer in American history at Cambridge University. Refreshments provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Christian Faculty Network meets
Description: The Christian Faculty Network is a community committed to enhancing the diversity of the university with the biblical Christian worldview. Weekly meetings involve lunch fellowship, discussions, relevant presentations and prayer.

Summary: Visiting artist Matthew Monteith leads seminar
Description: Attend a Visiting Artist Seminar led by photographer Matthew Monteith. Monteith uses photography to investigate the enclosures, both literal and figurative, in which we live, work and play. Closely looking at spaces such as museums, hospitals, classrooms and even automobiles, Monteith reveals both the isolation and fantasy of their inhabitants.

Summary: Lance Armstrong's legal team holds forum
Description: Members of Lance Armstrong's legal team hold a forum open to all law and business students.

Summary: Introduction to EndNote offered
Description: This introductory class covers tricks for using EndNote with library databases such as Web of Science and other library databases, indexes and the library catalog. It also covers other databases, indexes and the Library Catalog. Special sessions of this class can be arranged for UT groups or departments. Visit the link below for more information.

Summary: Compliance with international courts is topic of talk
Description: The Rapoport Center's Human Rights Happy Hour Speaker Series welcomes Professor Clifford Carrubba of Emory University and Professor Matthew Gabel of Washington University in St. Louis, who present a talk titled "The Politics of Compliance with International Courts: A General Theory with Evidence from the European Court of Justice." Light refreshments served.

Summary: Bevonomics 104 topic is living off-campus
Description: Prepare yourself to live off-campus. Familiarize yourself with popular student areas around Austin, expenses, safety and your rights and responsibilities as a tenant. Co-presented by Legal Services for Students.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description: Dr. Mike Raney, University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.

Summary: UT in Sydney info session held
Description: Kinesiology and Health Education majors are invited to learn about the new "UT in Sydney" exchange program from faculty, academic advisers and study abroad coordinators. In this unique two-part program, you will earn 16-20 hours of UT credit while exploring Australian sports culture.

Summary: Info session looks at Reporting China Maymester
Description: Learn about the study abroad Maymester, Reporting China: A Foreign Correspondent's Workshop, with guest speaker Tracy Dahlby, an award-winning journalist with 13 years experience living in Asia.

Summary: Archaeology Field School announces summer 2013 program
Description:
Attend an information session about the faculty-led 2013 summer archaeological field school in the north of Portugal. 

Information about the course, living arrangements, trips and financial aid to be discussed.

Summary: Careers in student affairs information session held
Description: Students interested in the field of Student Affairs are invited to attend an information session on the topic, featuring a Q&A session with campus professionals. Find out if a career in student affairs is an option for you.
Location: San Jacinto Residence Hall (SJH), multipurpose room

Summary: Texas Health Promotion Club meets
Description: Learn what the Texas Health Promotion Club has to offer and get involved. Upcoming events and volunteer opportunities are announced at each meeting. All majors welcome. Join us on Facebook at "Texas Health Promotion Club."

Summary: Emergency preparedness is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides participants with the tools necessary to be a leader in campus emergency preparedness in cases of natural and man-made incidents. This is a multi-media workshop; discussion will be encouraged. Presented by the Office of Emergency Preparedness.

Summary: Longhorn Networking hosted by UT PRSSA
Description: The UT chapter of the Public Relations Student Society of America hosts a Longhorn Networking social. Make new contacts and enjoy the conversation at our third bi-annual networking event.
Location: Whole Foods Market, 525 N. Lamar Blvd., rooftop patio

Summary: Suicide prevention is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: The "Be That One" Suicide Prevention Program helps student employees support peers and friends who may be thinking about suicide. Research shows that students who take this interactive workshop feel better prepared to intervene with friends who are in distress. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: Entrepreneurship Live presents Brett Hurt of Bazaarvoice
Description: Entrepreneurship Live presents Brett Hurt, founder and CEO of Bazaarvoice. A seasoned CEO, Hurt has been pioneering eCommerce innovations since 1998 and online communities since 1982.
