He was named RISE's Serial Entrepreneur of the Year for 2012 and received Austin Entrepreneurs Foundation's Community Leadership Award. Coffee and dessert reception follows the talk.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 204

Summary: Turkish film series screens Ahmet Uluçay film
Description:
Attend a screening of "Karpuz kabugundan gemiler yapmak" (Boats out of watermelon rinds), directed by Ahmet Uluçay (2008, 97 minutes). Two adolescents who live in a small village, work in temporary summer jobs and have a passion for cinema. Made in the director's own village, the film's actors are all locals. In Turkish with English subtitles.



The Turkish Film Series is co-sponsored by the Department of Middle Eastern Studies and Austin-Antalya Sister Cities Committee.

Summary: Holocaust survivor tells his story
Description: Special guest Irving Roth speaks at the second annual Standing with Israel event. Roth tells his story of survival through the death camps of Auschwitz and Buchenwald.

Summary: Zeta Sigma Chi information session held
Description: Zeta Sigma Chi Multicultural Sorority hosts upcoming events where potential pledges get the opportunity to meet sisters and decide if Z-Chi is the right for them.

Summary: Amnesty International general meeting announced
Description: Amnesty International looks at the right to housing and the evictions of Roma in Europe, followed by an Urgent Action at the end of the meeting. More information about Amnesty's position on the right to housing and the Demand Dignity campaign can be found here: http://www.amnestyusa.org/our-work/campaigns/demand-dignity/housing-is-a-human-right.

Summary: PCL bake sale to benefit Hearts of Texas
Description:
The Perry-Castañeda Library holds its annual bake sale as part of the Hearts of Texas employee charitable campaign.

Stop by and grab a delicious treat donated by the UT Libraries staff and support a charitable cause.

Summary: Physical Education Teacher Education holds student round-up
Description: The Physical Education Teacher Education (PETE) program announces the 7th annual PETE student round-up, bringing PETE faculty and students together to reach out to those interested in a career in physical education. Drop by for advising at AHG 105 or 125 from 8 a.m.-noon and 1-3 p.m. The Round-Up social begins at 4 in AHG 136, featuring food and fun.

Summary: Learn about conducting a science literature review
Description: Learn how to conduct a thorough literature review and get a brief overview of the types of tools and resources available to find and cite sources. This session focuses on the sciences and is geared toward advanced undergraduates, graduate students and research staff. Learn more about library class offerings at the link below.

Summary: Arts Internship & Networking Fair held
Description: Start your internship search and connect with future employers in person at the Fine Arts Career Services Internship and Networking Fair. Dress is business casual. Representatives from local arts organizations and businesses offer internships for both spring and summer.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall, 4th floor lobby

Summary: Rally spotlights Relationship Violence Awareness Month
Description: Attend a rally to spread awareness of relationship violence as part of Relationship Violence Awareness Month. Free t-shirts available while supplies last.

Summary: Food Day celebrates affordable, local & sustainable food
Description:
Food Day is a nationwide celebration and part of the movement to promote healthy local and sustainable foods. Learn what really goes into our bodies and where it comes from, and learn how you can find access to healthy, affordable food in Austin and on campus. Event features free food samples, prizes, a massive food tracking map and much more.



Co-sponsored by The Food Studies Project, Nourish International, Art Above Ground and the Campus Environmental Center.

Summary: Retirement Lunch and Learn series announced
Description:
Are you saving enough for retirement? Do you have the right investment mix? Will your retirement savings allow you maintain your current quality of life? Join Lunch and Learn for "Asset Allocation: Strategies for a Well Balanced Investor," an informative seminar led by a licensed representative from ING.



Learn how to diversify your savings and invest across the different asset classes, manage your investment's performance and reassess your savings plan every year.

Summary: "Bonus" UHS flu shot clinic held
Description: University Health Services provides a "bonus" flu shot clinic to UT students, faculty and staff. Bring UT ID and insurance card, if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (payable by cash or check only) is accepted for faculty/staff. For students most health insurance accepted, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or asking the posting charge to be posted to "WhatOwe."

Summary: disABILITY Advocate faculty program announced
Description: The faculty disABILITY Advocate training program provides an opportunity for education and discussion about how to interact with and accommodate students with disabilities in order to create an understanding and inclusive environment at UT while also balancing the integrity and rigor of academic courses and requirements.

Summary: Ethics and leadership flag event announced
Description: The Center for the Core Curriculum announces an ethics and leadership flag event featuring Dr. Mary Gentile, an internationally recognized expert in ethics pedagogy, who introduces her new approach to ethics education, the Giving Voice to Values (GVV) curriculum. GVV trains students to voice and act on their values despite opposing pressures.

Summary: Bevonomics 305 topic is employee benefits
Description: Learn about 401(k) plans and other benefits your future employer may offer.

Summary: BE Global Internship Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.

Summary: Learn about the CS Elements of Computing certificate
Description: Learn more about the elements of computing certificate. This certificate is for non-Computer Science majors. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu

Summary: Moving Through Conflict is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: Conflict seems to be a fact of life but does not have to cause anxiety. Explore your personal approach to handling conflict and get a better understanding of how conflict, when moved through effectively, can lead to personal and professional growth. Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Study social work in London
Description: Attend this meeting to learn more about social work study abroad through our faculty-led Maymester.

Summary: Study abroad in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Description: Attend an information session to learn more about study abroad in Brazil on the topic of the theory, history and politics of the African Diaspora in the Americas.

Summary: Economics internal transfer session held
Description: The Department of Economics hosts internal transfer information sessions for prospective economics majors who want to declare an economics major before registration starts. RSVP required via the link below by 5 p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 23. Students who are unable to attend a session must wait until after registration declare. An additional session is offered on Oct. 25.

Summary: George Royer presents Designing Games That Matter
Description:
"Designing Games That Matter: Deconstruction, Design Interventions, and Virtual World-building" is a talk by George Royer, doctoral student in the School of Information. Royer is co-founder of the game studio White Whale Games, whose first title, "God of Blades," was released in 2012 to wide critical acclaim.



Royer's areas of interest include archives, digital media and the history of information.

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: FIMRC, children's medical relief group, meets
Description: Attend the third meeting of UT's chapter of the Foundation for International Children's Medical Relief, a national organization dedicated to providing access to medical care for children in developing countries around the world. Food is provided and all students are welcome.

Summary: Activist Sylvia Méndez & author Winifred Conkling speak
Description:
Attend an evening with civil rights activist Sylvia Méndez (Méndez v. Westminster School District) and author Winifred Conkling. Conkling's book, "Sylvia and Aki," was awarded the 2012 Tomas Rivera Children's Book Award for chronicling the lives of Sylvia Mendez and Aki Munemitsu. 



Méndez's family leased the asparagus farm of the Munemitsu family when they were relocated to a Japanese internment camp. As the family tried to enroll their children in the local Westminster school they were denied enrollment and sent to the Mexican school. Méndez's parents led a lawsuit against four Orange County, Calif., school districts in the landmark civil rights case, Mendez v. Westminster School District.

 

At this talk, Méndez provides firsthand testimony of the family's experiences in winning the appellate decision in the Mendez v. Westminster School District case, which preceded Brown v. Board of Education.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection Conference Room

Summary: Art of Living holds weekly "Stress-Buster" breathing sessions
Description: Art of Living UT offers weekly "Stress-Buster" sessions to teach stress management through simple breathing techniques and meditation. This session is led by an experienced Art of Living guest speaker.

Summary: Art talk with Nick Cave presented
Description:
In conjunction with his exhibition Nick Cave: Hiding in Plain Sight, on view at the AMOA-Arthouse Jones Center through Dec. 30, artist Cave discusses his artistic practice and process with Dr. Moyo Okediji, director of the Center for Art of Africa and its Diaspora, University of Texas at Austin.



Artist Nick Cave's highly imaginative work bridges sculpture, fashion, dance and performance art. He compiles found materials into fantastical "Soundsuits" inspired by a variety of global costume traditions.

Summary: Amon Carter Lecture celebrates Tom Lea Month
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center commemorates Tom Lea Month with a lecture on West Texas artists presented by Kenneth Grant and J.P. Bryan.



Grant, head of exhibition services at the Ransom Center, 

shares behind-the-scenes insights on the conservation of artist and writer Tom Lea's drawing in "Saving Sarah: The Conservation of Tom Lea's drawing for 'Sarah in the Summertime.'" Then, historian and collector Bryan discusses collaborations between El Paso artists Lea and Jose Cisneros and publisher Carl Hertzog in "Iron Sharpens Iron: The Unique Collaborations of Early El Paso Artists."



The Ransom Center holds the largest single collection of Lea's work.

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship holds New Covenant Passover
Description: Attend a Bible study session and discussion on the New Covenant Passover.

Summary: Breaking the Silence forum discusses relationship violence
Description: Survivors and allies speak out about experiences of relationship violence at this forum.

Summary: Texas volleyball team plays Baylor
Description: Texas volleyball faces the Baylor Bears in a Big 12 match-up. Web Coupon Wednesday: Print out a web coupon and receive a general admission ticket and small popcorn for only $5. Coupons must be printed and redeemed at a Gregory Gym ticket window on the day of the match. Gates open one hour prior to the start of each match.

Summary: Learn about spring EMT class at Longhorn EMS info session
Description: Become a certified emergency medical technician at the spring EMT class. Learn more at an information session hosted by Longhorn EMS. Email szadoo@longhornems.org with questions.

Summary: "The Cataract": D'Amour drama staged on campus
Description: Set in Minneapolis in 1883, this poetic drama explores one week in the lives of Cyrus and Lottie Finch, a stalwart couple who take in two vagabond lovers from the South. Written by Pulitzer Prize-nominated playwright Lisa D'Amour and directed by Daria Davis. Learn about Subscription Series savings at link below. Runs Oct. 19, 24-27 at 8 p.m. and Oct. 21, 27, 28 at 2 p.m.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Desserts for Leaders event announced
Description: At Desserts for Leaders, student leaders across campus come together to discuss upcoming events and current issues throughout campus. Desserts served. RSVP to sedinternal@gmail.com to reserve your seat.

Summary: Themes of "The Cataract" discussed
Description: Audiences of "The Cataract" are invited to "I think they're talking about us": Engaging the Themes of 'The Cataract'." Join us as we investigate a variety of themes and directorial approaches - from Noh theatre to Victorians' obsession with flowers and futurism.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Is philanthropy in Latin America seeing dawn of a new era?
Description: Philanthropy in Latin America is examined in a two-part workshop examining both scholarly research and reflections from practical experience. In a brief concluding plenary, speakers and participants work together to review a preliminary report on key research questions related to philanthropy in Latin America.

Summary: CLAVIS hosts 2012 research forum
Description: The Center for Latin American Visual Studies (CLAVIS) hosts the 2012 International Research Forum, "Synchronicity, Contacts, and Divergences in Latin American and U.S. Latino Art, 19th Century to the Present." Click on link below for information on events and their location.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Bldg (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302 & Texas Union (UNB)

Summary: RSVP for Liberal Arts Graduate Student Council meeting
Description: Liberal Arts graduate students are asked to RSVP for the meeting on Monday, Oct. 29, at 4 p.m. This meeting will cover recent departmental reports to the dean on the status of graduate programs, time to degree and the current job market for PhDs. All are welcome. RSVP to Lauren Apter Barinsfather at apter@austin.utexas.edu by Thursday, Oct. 25.

Summary: Madrigal Dinner 2012 tickets on sale
Description: Tickets are on sale now for Madrigal Dinner 2012, a grand, Renaissance-themed dinner theatre experience featuring an original comedic play, choir concert and a four-course meal, held Thursday, Friday and Saturday, Nov. 29-Dec. 1 (6:30-10 p.m.). Tickets available at TexasBoxOffice.com or the Erwin Center box office through Nov. 27. Visit link below for menu options and more.

Summary: Males ages 18-24 wanted for paid study on language and memory
Description: Males 18-24 who have been diagnosed with a learning disability (including but not limited to ADD, ADHD and dyslexia) are sought for a study on language and memory. Two 90-minute sessions required. Contact Megan Blau (mjblau@utexas.edu) to schedule an appointment, providing age, gender, LD diagnosis and scheduling availability. Must be a native English speaker.
Location: Jones Communication Building A (CMA), UT Speech and Hearing Center

Summary: Learn about the CS Elements of Computing certificate
Description: Learn more about the Elements of Computing certificate for non-computer science majors. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: AAAFSA holds membership meeting featuring talk on Roma
Description: Join the Asian/Asian-American Faculty and Staff Association for its October membership meeting, featuring a talk titled "The Roma: From India to Austin in a Thousand Years" by Professor Ian Hancock, Nowlin regents professor of Liberal Arts. Lunch provided (with vegetarian/vegan options). RSVP to sona.shah@austin.utexas.edu. Friends are welcome.

Summary: Perspectives talk topic is art and meditation
Description: Director Billy Boyar of the Austin Shambhala Meditation Center discusses meditation and its relation to the sacred art of Tibetan Buddhism in this Perspectives gallery talk.

Summary: Become an advanced Google searcher in online course
Description: How does the Google search engine work? How does one focus searches to get more relevant results? Learn the mechanics behind Google searches, along with advanced search tricks, to become a savvier searcher. This is an online class. At start time, go to the web address for the class. Select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher.

Summary: ECE Distinguished Lecture presents Dr. Stanley Williams
Description: UT ECE is proud to present Dr. Stanley Williams of HP Labs, giving a seminar titled "Mott Memristors, Spiking Neuristors and Turing Complete Computing."
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Sasha Issenberg, "Victory Lab" author, to be interviewed
Description:
Author Sasha Issenberg talks with James Henson, director of the Texas Politics Project, about the 2012 election and about his new book, "The Victory Lab," which looks at how social and behavioral science research has changed the practices of modern political campaigns in recent years.



Issenberg is the "Victory Lab" columnist for Slate and the Washington correspondent for Monocle, where he covers politics, business, diplomacy and culture.

Summary: Economics internal transfer session held
Description: The Department of Economics hosts internal transfer information sessions for prospective economics majors who want to declare an economics major before registration starts. RSVP required via the link below by 5 p.m. Tuesday, Oct. 23. Students who are unable to attend a session must wait until after registration declare.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: The Department of Spanish and Portuguese hosts an information session for our summer 2013 faculty-led study abroad programs in Santander, Spain, Salvador da Bahia, Brazil and Antigua, Guatemala. Get basic information about the programs and discuss the application process.

Summary: Investment treaty arbitration & the WTO are lecture topic
Description: Dan Sarooshi, professor of public international law, The Queen's College, Oxford University, speaks on investment treaty arbitration, the World Trade Organization (WTO) and what can they learn from each other. For more information or to RSVP, email G. Dawson, gdawson@law.utexas.edu, or phone 512-475-9328.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: Learn about summer study abroad in Lyon, France
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the UT intensive language and culture program in Lyon, France, which runs from May 20-July 5. Earn six credit hours for two UT courses. Live with a French family. Discover Paris, Beaujolais, the Alps and the Mediterranean. Participants must have completed at least one year of college French to apply.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Certificate Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in commercial real estate. Register to attend at link below.

Summary: Panel discusses carbon capture and storage
Description: This week, the UT Energy Symposium presents a panel discussion on carbon capture and storage. Participants will be Senior Research Scientist Dr. Susan Hovorka (UT), Professor of Chemical Engineering Gary Rochelle (UT) and Douglas Heguy, Commercial Leader of Gasification at GE. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Cyber Scare and Gigglepants talk Internet safety
Description:
Learn how to browse the Internet safely while trying not to fall off your seat from laughing. UT Student Organization Safety Board

presents Cyber Scare alongside Gigglepants, who perform their improvisation comedy act on the theme of Internet safety. Free food and education.

Summary: Newt Gingrich discusses leadership challenges post-election
Description:
The Honorable Newt Gingrich, former Speaker of the U.S. House of Representatives, presents a lecture titled "Leadership Challenges Beyond the Election." 



Gingrich will address the crisis in strategic thinking for national security, American exceptionalism, the challenge of economic growth in a world market, rethinking government in the information age and effective leadership in a complex constitutional system. The lecture will be followed by an open Q&A session with the audience.

Summary: Texas Collaborative Consumption hosts Co-op Cook founder
Description: Texas Collaborative Consumption hosts special guest Matt Miller, the founder of Co-op Cook, a potluck cooking organization in Austin. Hear how Miller came up with the idea and how you can get involved.

Summary: Archives Week features Levi Strauss & Co. historian
Description: Lynn Downey, the historian of Levi Strauss & Co., presents a public lecture titled "Unbuttoned: Adventures in the Archives of an American Icon" in which she discusses her work archiving the world's oldest blue jeans and other treasures of the Levi archives. Presented as part of the UT Society of American Archivists' annual Archives Week celebration.

Summary: The Broccoli Project presents Don Nigro's "Paganini"
Description:
The Broccoli Project presents Don Nigro's "Paganini," a dark comedy in two acts about the infamous virtuoso violinist Nicolo Paganini, whose skill with the violin was so great that many believed he was a marionette of the devil. Contact director David Skaggs at skeegz@gmail.com with questions. Runs through Nov. 3.



Using Paganini's 24 Caprices for Violin as a haunting soundtrack, the play traces the grotesque and satirical adventures of Paganini as he plays throughout Europe, his century's equivalent of a rock star.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: TILTS presents Fate of the Book preservers panel
Description: The first TILTS 2012-13 public panel presentation brings together Nicolas Barker, editor of "The Book Collector"; Kathleen Rooney, poet, writer and founding editor of Rose Metal Press; and Michael Witmore, director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, to discuss the ways books are preserved by such radically diverse forces as private collectors, changing technologies, The Oprah Book Club and major libraries. A reception follows.

Summary: State Comptroller Susan Combs discusses the Texas budget
Description: College Republicans at Texas welcome guest speaker Susan Combs, State Comptroller of Public Accounts. The comptroller's duties include tax collection, accounting and the enforcement of the Texas constitution's balanced budget requirement. Students who are interested in state politics, public finance, accounting and economics are encouraged to attend.

Summary: Know Your Rights training held by Libertarian Longhorns
Description:
Libertarian Longhorns is proud to welcome Antonio Buehler, Harold Gray and Joshua "Comrade" Pineda from the Peaceful Streets Project, who present a Know Your Rights Training Session to inform UT students of their constitutional rights when dealing with police, conflict deescalation skills and tips, as well as using audio/video technology to hold police accountable.



This Know Your Rights Training Session will be followed up by a West Campus cop-watch with members of the Peaceful Streets Project. All students are welcome.



More information on the Peaceful Streets Project can be found here.

Summary: Learn about spring EMT class at Longhorn EMS info session
Description: Become a certified emergency medical technician at the spring EMT class. Learn more at an information session hosted by Longhorn EMS. Email szadoo@longhornems.org with questions.

Summary: Author Denis Johnson reads from his work
Description: Legendary author Denis Johnson presents a literary reading. Johnson's work includes the 2007 National Book Award Winner "Tree of Smoke," last year's Pulitzer short-listed "Train Dreams" and his now-classic story collection "Jesus' Son."

Summary: Italian thriller-horror "Almost Blue" screened
Description: I Film del Circolo celebrates Halloween with the screening of "Almost Blue," an award winning thriller-horror by Alex Infascelli (2000). A serial killer called the Iguana is terrorizing Bologna in this classic cat and mouse thriller exploring the links between rookie policewoman Grazia, a protean psychokiller and young blind man Simone, part online busybody, part oracle. In Italian with English subtitles.

Summary: Volunteer for Soles4Souls event; learn more at meeting
Description: Soles4Souls seeks volunteers to help out at an all-day pledge drive (featuring free Round Rock Donuts) taking place Tuesday, Oct. 30, from 10 a.m.-4 p.m. at Gregory Plaza. To volunteer, attend this brief meeting.

Summary: College of Fine Arts hosts Family Weekend 2012 events
Description: The College of Fine Arts offers special activities as part of the campus-wide Family Weekend 2012. Family and friends of current students are invited to experience sample classes, performances and more. The Butler School of Music, the Art & Art History Department and the Theatre & Dance Department host a variety of events throughout the weekend including plays, concerts and a production of Puccini's "Madame Butterfly."
Location: Various locations throughout the College of Fine Arts

Summary: Sociological Insight research journal invites submissions
Description: Sociological Insight, a fully refereed national undergraduate research journal aimed at promoting undergraduate research in the social sciences, seeks submissions for volume 5. Application deadline is Nov. 15. Visit the link below for more information.

Summary: Sir Nicholas de Mimsy-Porpington's Death Day Feast held
Description: Join the Austin Harry Potter Alliance for a Halloween celebration worthy of Hogwarts. Enjoy a magical evening filled with delicious food, fantastic music and your fellow Harry Potter fanatics. Come in your best costumes and be ready to dance. Buy tickets at any AHPA meeting or email us at austinhpalliance@gmail.com to order online.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Austin Translational Neuroscience Symposium slated
Description:
The NeuroTexas Institute Research Foundation, along with The University of Texas at Austin's Institute for Neuroscience, hosts the second annual Austin Translational Neuroscience Symposium, featuring a keynote address by Dr. Terrence Sejnowski of UC-San Diego / Salk Institute.



Designed for academic and medical researchers and  graduate students, this symposium series in intended to highlight the latest in neuroscience research, as well as provide a venue for clinicians and researchers to meet and discuss collaborative opportunities. In addition to the keynote address, the conference features presentations by an additional six invited speakers.
Location: St. David's Medical Office Building, 3000 N IH 35

Summary: STAAR Carnival celebrates academic achievement
Description: The Iota Delta Chapter of Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity Inc. hosts the 13th annual STAAR Carnival, which rewards low-income elementary students who have scored well on the state-mandated test. Campus student organizations volunteer to entertain the 300 students expected to attend.

Summary: Shakespeare library director gives Fate of the Book talk
Description: Michael Witmore, director of the Folger Shakespeare Library, speaks about the digitization of literary works and Shakespeare's late period. The event part of the Texas Institute for Literary and Textual Studies' 2012-13 events series, "The Fate of the Book."

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Marc Suchard
Description: The SSC Seminar Series welcomes Professor Marc Suchard, UCLA, who presents a talk titled "Learning from Big Data in Biology."

Summary: West Mall plant sale announced
Description: The Science Undergraduate Research Group (SURGe) hosts its monthly plant sale. Friday's sale features lotus bamboo, lithops (living stones), assorted cacti, assorted foliage, aloe vera, succulents and more. The organization raises money to promote undergraduate research and award fellowships to student researchers.

Summary: Population Research Center hosts Dr. Sahotra Sarkar
Description: Dr. Sahotra Sarkar of the Department of Integrative Biology and Philosophy delivers a talk titled "Methodological Individualism."

Summary: Central Health Prop 1 press conference announced
Description: Kappa Rho Pre-Medical Honor Society hosts a press conference to rally for Central Health Proposition 1, featuring prominent community leaders.

Summary: McCraw Lecture presents Michael Cramer on sports & media
Description: Michael Cramer, executive director of the Texas Program in Sports and Media in the College of Communication at The University of Texas Austin, presents a talk titled "Sports, Media, and American Culture."

Summary: Gentrification and protecting tenants is forum topic
Description:
Attend a lunchtime Opportunity Forum panel discussion on policies to protect tenants who are displaced by redevelopment projects. The panel features a recent report by UT Law students examining the demolition of an apartment complex on East Riverside Drive last year that displaced more than 500 low-income tenants and the City of Austin's ad hoc policy for dealing with displacement issues. Register at link below. 



Co-sponsored by William Wayne Justice Center for Public Interest Law; Center for Politics and Governance; Center for Health and Social Policy; Cityforum, School of Architecture.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Learn about Nutrition in Italy study abroad opportunity
Description: Attend an information session on the "Nutrition in Italy" summer abroad program in Sicily, Italy.

Summary: "Tony Benn: The Making of a British Radical" talk presented
Description: Tony Benn is one of the most popular and most controversial figures in British politics. A leading figure in public life for more than sixty years, he is now the undisputed godfather of the Left. Yet he was once the best hope of the right-of-center Social Democrats. Jad Adams analyzes Benn's political trajectory in terms of the Christian nonconformist roots of British socialism.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Join the discussion about campus safety alerts
Description: We want your response to UT's response. Join an interactive, energetic discussion about your experience and recommendations for university procedures and communications during campus-wide threats. The UT Society of Professional Mediators facilitate the discussion. Snacks and refreshments provided. RSVP here: http://www.eventbrite.com/event/4582815324.

Summary: Students for Clean Water hold Water Walk
Description: Water Walk brings attention to the importance of clean water access for people around the globe. Every day, millions of people walk miles to collect water that may not even be safe. Meet at the Tower to receive provided water jugs, then walk around two miles with us to Town Lake to collect water, and return to campus with water in hand. Experience firsthand the difference clean water can make.

Summary: Texas polo team offers lessons
Description: The Texas polo team announces polo lessons on Friday and Sunday afternoons at 3:30 p.m. No riding experience necessary. Carpool available. Find us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/groups/2201557398 or email Alison Baylis for more information at abaylis@utexas.edu.
Location: 4884 Bell Springs Road, Dripping Springs, TX

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Do you speak Québécois? is FISGO presentation
Description: The French & Italian Graduate Student Organization presents "Do You Speak Québécois?: A Historical Approach to the Never-ending Linguistic Insecurity in Québec." Andréanne Clouthier of McGill University gives an English-language overview of the linguistic question in Quebec for undergraduates interested in la francophonie hors de France. French conversation hour follows.

Summary: Texas swimming & diving teams host Indiana, Michigan
Description: The Texas men's and women's swimming and diving teams host Michigan and Indiana in Day 1 of a two-day meet.
Location: Lee & Joe Jamail Texas Swimming Center

Summary: Poetika: New poetry app presented
Description: Jacobo Benareche presents the new poetry app, Poetika, produced with the collaboration of invited poet Jenaro Talens. Users of Poetika, which includes the "poem of the hour" feature, can search for poetry linked to emotional states, locations, weather and time.

Summary: Summer research info session and resume workshop held
Description: Learn about coveted summer research opportunities in the sciences at the university and around the country, and how to apply, including how to draft your resume. Speakers include Dr. Sarah Simmons, assistant dean (OHRIS), and Christiana Cough, career coach (Career Design Center).

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club for its weekly meeting. Play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Texas softball plays St. Edward's
Description: Texas softball hosts the St. Edward's Hilltoppers.

Summary: Hot Science - Cool Talks topic is water resources
Description:
Hot Science - Cool Talks presents "Last Call at the Oasis: Will There Be Enough Water for the 21st Century?" with Dr. Jay Famiglietti. Famiglietti explores how climate change and population growth affect the way our water is replenished. Pre-lecture fair and teacher workshop begin at 5:45 p.m.



Without water, life cannot exist. Yet our most precious resource faces major threats which are pushing it to the brink of depletion in many regions. Famiglietti explores the question of replenishment for both Texas and California using innovative satellite technology.

Summary: Learn about spring EMT class at Longhorn EMS info session
Description: Become a certified emergency medical technician at the spring EMT class. Learn more at an information session hosted by Longhorn EMS. Email szadoo@longhornems.org with questions.

Summary: Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly"
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly." Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Visit the link below to listen.

Summary: "How to Avoid Falling in Love with a Jerk" discussed
Description:
Alpha Omega Campus Ministry presents a discussion of practical lessons from the bestselling book "How to Avoid Falling in Love with A Jerk: A Foolproof Way to Follow Your Heart Without Loosing Your Mind," by John Van Epp. Men and women welcome.



Learn to break destructive dating patterns and mentalities with a few simple techniques. Based on years of research in marital and premarital happiness, Van Epp provides foolproof tools for spotting the gem among the jerks (or jerkettes) so you can find the love you deserve.

Summary: Texas soccer takes on West Virginia
Description: Longhorns soccer takes on the West Virginia Mountaineers for the first time as Big 12 members. Features Hook 'Ems Halloween (wear a costume for a parade and trick-or-treating) and Scout Day: $4 general admission ticket for all Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts and guests.
Location: Mike A. Meyers Stadium & Soccer Field

Summary: Les Violons du Roy perform with Emmanuel Pahud, flute
Description: Celebrated flutist Emmanuel Pahud joins Les Violons du Roy for an extraordinary evening of chamber music.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Queer Texas Conference announced
Description: The Queer Texas Conference - Embracing Identities brings together college, community and high school LGBTQA activists across the state to network, learn and discuss how to embrace each and every identity. The event includes workshops, skill sessions, forums, panels and speakers in a flexible format.

Summary: Poetics for the 21st Century conference slated
Description: "Poéticas para el Siglo XXI / Poetics for the 21st Century" is a day-long conference that is part of the graduate seminar titled "Extrañeza, Extranjería, Migración." The central theme is the ways in which poetic language confronts and incorporates a variety of differences provoked by cultural contact. Visit link for full schedule.

Summary: Saturday Morning Math Group looks at game theory and more
Description:
The Saturday Morning Math Group presents "Game Theory and Knowing about Knowledge," a talk led by Dr. Thomas Wiseman of the UT Austin Department of Economics. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. 



Snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: Texas swimming & diving teams host Indiana, Michigan
Description: The Texas men's and women's swimming and diving teams host Michigan and Indiana in Day 2 of a two-day meet.
Location: Lee & Joe Jamail Texas Swimming Center

Summary: Big 12 Cross Country Championship held
Description: The University of Texas hosts the 2012 Big 12 Cross Country Championship. The women's 6K starts and 10 a.m. and the men's 8K starts at 11 a.m.
Location: Jimmy Clay Golf Course, 5400 Jimmy Clay Drive, Austin, 78744

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents Work Party in Hecho Farm
Description:
Hecho Farm is a stage for the continued growth of artist Cruz Ortiz's lovesick alter ego Spaztek, as well as an exploration of the material, social and political possibilities of collaboration within an art education context. Join Ortiz for a free collaborative workshop on his "farm" followed by a BBQ lunch.

Contact Xochi Solis at xochisolis@utvac.org to reserve your spot.

Summary: "The Cataract": Matinee performance held
Description: Set in Minneapolis in 1883, this poetic drama explores one week in the lives of Cyrus and Lottie Finch, a stalwart couple who take in two vagabond lovers from the South. Written by Pulitzer Prize-nominated playwright Lisa D'Amour and directed by Daria Davis. Learn about Subscription Series savings at link below. Runs Oct. 19, 24-27 at 8 p.m. and Oct. 21, 27, 28 at 2 p.m.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton Museum
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Texas Ballroom offers Viennese workshop
Description: Attend a two-hour workshop Viennese workshop taught by Kelvin Pho, a ballroom instructor for Texas Ballroom. A great way to learn for the upcoming Great Waltz.

Summary: Dance Action presents SEED (two shows)
Description: Attend Dance Action's fall production of SEED (Students Exhibiting Experimental Dance), featuring student choreographers and dancers showcasing a wonderful range of dance. A second show takes place on Sunday, Oct. 28, at 3 p.m.

Summary: Rahim Alhaj performs with UT's Bereket ensemble
Description: Rahim AlHaj, oud, and Issa Malluf, percussion, join Bereket UT Middle Eastern Ensemble under the direction of Sonia Seeman for an evening of new and traditional Middle Eastern music.

Summary: The Great Waltz presented by Texas Ballroom
Description:
Texas Ballroom presents the 31st annual Great Waltz with music by the Austin Civic Orchestra. Join us for an exciting night of social dancing and performances. Formal attire required. Reserve tickets online at link below.



Two Viennese Waltz workshops will be offered in the weeks prior to the Great Waltz. Check website for details.

Summary: Umoja Week kicks off with "Open Up My Heart"
Description: Join the ladies of Umoja as we celebrate our week of unity, beginning with a "Open Our Hearts" service at Greater Mt. Zion Baptist Church. Meet in front of Jester Smoothie at 9:15 a.m. for rides.
Location: Greater Mt. Zion Baptist Church, 1801 Pennsylvania Avenue; carpool available

Summary: Fright at the Museum comes to Texas Memorial Museum
Description: Dress up your little goblins and celebrate Halloween at Austin's very own dinosaur graveyard. Spooky scientists explore the mysterious side of Texas' natural history. Feel frightful fish from the ocean depths; be rattled by slithery snakes of Central Texas; and feast your eyes on our bizarre bugs while we serve up creepy, crawly critters for your culinary delight.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Texas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Texas State Bobcats. Tickets to be sold only at UFCU Disch-Falk Field on game day. Gates open at 11 a.m.

Summary: Special event offers Halloween fun for UT families
Description:
Longhorn Halloween is a fun and safe Halloween program for the children of The University of Texas at Austin's staff, faculty and students. 



This special event will feature student performances, carnival events, a haunted house, face painting, a chemistry circus, a University Police vehicle, a real fire truck and much more!

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: See basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Unearthing "The Cataract" is post-performance talk
Description: Audience members are invited to an intimate post-performance talk with playwright Lisa D'Amour and director Will Davis. "The Cataract" runs Oct. 19-28 in the B. Iden Payne Theatre.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts Goblins in the Garden
Description:
It's time to dress in your Halloween finest for the annual Goblins in the Garden family festival. Children dressed as insects parade at 6 p.m. to commemorate our Butterfly Garden's 10th anniversary. Also featuring Punkin' Patch, trick-or-treat, Haunted Tower, owl prowl and scavenger hunt.



Enjoy Halloween arts and crafts and goodies from local vendors or the cafe. Kids 12 and under get a treat at The Store.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Bill Cosby returns to Bass Concert Hall
Description: One of America's most beloved entertainers makes a return to the Bass Concert Hall stage for an evening of classic stand-up.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "Nefarious" documents world sex-trafficking crisis
Description: Attend a screening of the documentary "Nefarious: Merchant of Souls," which details the world sex-trafficking crisis. Cash donations welcome; all proceeds benefit Exodus Cry's sex-trafficking prevention campaign.

Summary: Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly"
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly." Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Visit the link below to listen.

Summary: Spooktacular Sunday Social Dance features lesson, costumes
Description: Spooktacular Sunday Swirl Dance is a unique, eclectic dance open to everyone who loves partner dancing. Costumes welcome for this special Halloween edition. Instruction in various styles provided. All ages welcome. No partner needed.

Summary: Register for fall 2012 Poster Design Class
Description: The Poster Design Class covers poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and poster presentation know-how. All undergraduates at any stage in their research are welcome. We will hold two classes this semester starting Friday, Nov. 9, at 9 a.m. in FAC 332. RSVP by Nov. 7 to ugresearcher@utlists.utexas.edu.

Summary: Contribute to Hearts of Texas Charitable Campaign
Description: The Hearts of Texas Charitable Campaign is part of the State Employee Charitable Campaign. The goal of this year's campaign is to raise $615,000. University employees are encouraged to visit the Hearts of Texas website to make a pledge.
Location: The University of Texas at Austin

Summary: Capture the Forty Acres benefit event held
Description:
Texas Orange Jackets hosts its annual Capture the 40 Acres event, a university-wide capture-the-flag tournament benefiting the Settlement Home for Children, an Austin facility for children and teens with whom Orange Jackets volunteers bi-monthly. The tournament takes place Sunday, Nov. 4, from 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Teams of six compete. Register by Nov. 2 at the link below. Contact Fernanda Alvarez at feralvarez91@gmail.com with questions.



There are three game times from which to choose. Entry fee includes one hour of play time, snacks, lunch, prizes for tournament winners and superlative awards. Payments in cash or check accepted, with checks made out to "Orange Jackets."

Summary: Transit survey seeks feedback on buses & UT shuttles
Description: The School of Information's Interaction Design program seeks information on user attitudes toward current bus and shuttle services around campus. Users of the services are invited to fill out a short survey (5-10 minutes) with the main goal of improving your transit experience. All answers are anonymous. Visit link below.

Summary: Tor and the censorship arms race discussed
Description: Tor is a free-software anonymizing network that helps people around the world use the Internet in safety. In this talk, Roger Dingledine gives a brief overview of the Tor design and its diverse users before delving into the technical and social problems it presents. Dingledine is project leader, director and head of research for The Tor Project.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Christopher Lee
Description: "The Indian Ocean as a 'Zone of Peace,' 1955-1979" is a talk by Dr. Christopher Lee, Institute for Historical Studies fellow and assistant professor of History at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill. Dr. Itty Abraham, director, South Asia Institute, and associate professor in the Department of Asian Studies and the Department of Government, responds.

Summary: OpenLanguage co-founders discuss media in language learning
Description: Guest speakers Hank Horkoff and Jenny Zhu, co-founders of OpenLanguage, offer a look at the pioneering use of media for learning and education. Horkoff develops cutting-edge implementation of web and mobile technologies to improve traditional learning. Zhu is the main host of the successful and popular podcast series "ChinesePod," where she has hosted over 2,000 lesson podcasts.

Summary: Linguistics colloquium presents Michael Erard
Description:
Writer and journalist Michael Erard presents "Myths and Realities of High Intensity Language Learners."



A University of Texas at Austin alumnus (M.A. in linguistics, Ph.D. in English) Erard is the author of two books that bring linguistic research to a popular audience. They are: "Um???: Slips, Stumbles, and Verbal Blunders, and What They Mean"  and "Babel No More: The Search for the World's Most Extraordinary Language Learners."

Summary: Niche News & Campaign 2012 examines public's media choices
Description: "Niche News and Campaign 2012" is a talk by Talia Stroud, associate professor of communication studies, University of Texas at Austin. In this talk, Stroud analyzes where people turn for political news and whether our own views influence our choice of news outlet.

Summary: Attachment and dyadic regulation are topic of talk
Description: Nickola Overall presents a talk titled "Attachment and Dyadic Regulation: Buffering Insecurity Within Conflict Interactions" as part of the Department of Human Development and Family Sciences' ongoing speaker series.

Summary: Umoja Week presents "Get Me Bodied"
Description: The Ladies of Umoja, and the resident advisers of Jester East host Get Me Bodied, a field day featuring tug-of-war, sack racing and an obstacle course. Join the fun while getting some exercise and socializing.

Summary: An evening of Maya cinema presented by Rosa Chávez
Description: A session on Maya films is presented by K'iche'/Kaqchikel poet and filmmaker Rosa Chávez, who screens and discusses four short films by Maya men and women filmmakers.

Summary: Lars von Trier film series continues
Description: In "The Boss of It All" (2006) groundbreaking Danish director Lars von Trier shows his comedic side. The funny, thought-provoking movie tells of a business owner who has to make up lies to cover up for having invented a nonexistent company president to run his business.

Summary: Rally to support diversity, speak to support UT
Description: Show your support for diversity at UT by joining the Rally to Support Diversity. Speakers to include UT students, high school students and community leaders, who share their personal stories about the importance of diversity and why we still need it. Follow us on Twitter @WeSupportUT #WSUT. Like us on Facebook. Contact us at wsutexas@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Healthcare policy in America is Plan II Pre-Med talk topic
Description: Plan II Pre-Medical Society and Liberal Arts Honors Pre-Medical Society co-host a panel discussion about the current state of healthcare policies and coverage in the United States and how the Affordable Care Act will affect you, the field of medicine and the country. Pizza, desserts and drinks provided. Email questions or topics you would like discussed to plan2premed@gmail.com.

Summary: Mises Circle holds Austrian Banking Showdown
Description: If you put a handful of praxeologists in a room together for long enough, sooner or later they are going to start yelling at each other about banking. This coming Monday, the Mises Circle holds an Austrian Banking Showdown between free bankers and full reserve bankers, backed 100 percent by raw economic theory. Visit the link below for information on pertinent articles.

Summary: Kappa Delta Pi holds fall initiation ceremony
Description: Delta chapter initiates new members at this ceremony.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Soles4Souls holds pledge event, with donuts
Description: Soles4Souls aims to raise awareness for the 1.5 billion people around the world without shoes. Make a footprint and sign your name as a pledge to donate during our annual post-Thanksgiving shoe drive. Free Round Rock Donuts served. Follow us at #BAREFOOTBANNER. To volunteer, attend a brief meeting on Oct. 25, at 8 p.m in CBA 4.348.

Summary: Communication Job & Internship Fair announced
Description: The fall 2012 Communication Job & Internship Fair is a communication-specific career fair that provides excellent opportunities to meet job and internship recruiters. Students can also research companies and industries and network with industry representatives. Open to all majors.
Location: DKR Texas Memorial Stadium, North End Zone - The Club (Enter at Gates 14 & 16)

Summary: National Young Women's Day of Action hosts speaker
Description: Celebrate the seventh annual National Young Women's Day of Action at a luncheon with speaker Cristina Tzintzun, executive director of the Worker's Defense Project, featuring opening remarks by Jordan Metoyer, chief of staff for Student Government. Lunch provided for those who RSVP. Email gsc@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-232-1831.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Disparities in mental health is webinar topic
Description:
The Center for Elimination of Disproportionality & Disparities (CEDD), Texas State Office of Minority Health and the Texas Health & Human Services Commission present a webinar on disparities in mental health led by Vicky Coffee-Fletcher, MEd, LPC, program officer for the university's Hogg Foundation for Mental Health. For information on continuing education contact hours, email CEDD@hhsc.state.tx.us.



Viewing site hosted by St. David's Center for Health Promotion & Disease Prevention Research in Underserved Populations, The University of Texas at Austin School of Nursing. Attendees are offered 1.0 contact hour of continuing education for multiple disciplines or a certificate of attendance.

Summary: Music at the Blanton features Bach Cantata performance
Description: Musicians from the Butler School of Music perform "Gelobet sei der Herr, mein Gott," BWV 129 in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: The War Within the War for Afghanistan is Strauss Ctr talk
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law invites you to Little America: The War Within the War for Afghanistan, a talk and book signing with Rajiv Chandrasekaran, national editor of the Washington Post. Refreshments provided and books available for purchase after the event.

Summary: Physics Department hosts open house
Description: The Physics Department hosts an open house with 21 labs open to the public for guided tours, followed by a watermelon drop at 5 p.m.

Summary: Trick-or-Treat sponsored by Delta Sigma Pi
Description: Celebrate Halloween and support Delta Sigma Pi. Choose between a trick or a treat. Trick: Pie a friend or test your luck at the Mystery Bag Challenge. Treat: We'll have cake pops, brownies, cookies and more baked goods to indulge in. Proceeds fund Delta Sigma Pi's professional, community and other events.

Summary: "Latir sin descanso" presented by Rosa Chávez
Description: K'iche' / Kaqchikel poet Rosa Chávez, of San Andrés Itzapa, Chimaltenango, Guatemala, presents a lecture on poetry.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: The Department of Spanish and Portuguese hosts an information session for the summer 2013 faculty-led study abroad programs in Santander, Spain, Salvador da Bahia, Brazil and Antigua, Guatemala. Get basic information about the programs and discuss the application process.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: Public forum focuses on Black and Latino voters
Description: Black Studies and Mexican American Studies faculty and students discuss Black and Latina/o participation in the 2012 presidential election and what this means for the university, Texas and the United States.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Time management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Academic achievement begins with the basics: plenty of sleep, nutritious meals, a balance of work and play, and useful stress-reducing strategies. Having a hard time with any of those? Come learn how to practice time management skills, prioritization and other techniques for fitting it all in. Presented by the Sanger Learning Center.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Certificate Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in commercial real estate. Register at link below to attend.

Summary: Money Talks presents Clint Bybee, ARCH Venture Partners
Description:
Money Talks presents Clinton Bybee, co-founder and managing director of ARCH Venture Partners, one of the largest seed venture capital firms operating nationally. Presentation followed by reception with snacks and beverages.



Bybee has helped organize, finance and build numerous companies out of university and national laboratory research. He leads ARCH's initiative with the Department of Energy at Sandia National Laboratories and ARCH's LabStart initiative at Los Alamos National Laboratory.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Human Rights Student Advisory Council meets
Description: The Human Rights Student Advisory Council meets, bringing together human rights organizations across campus.

Summary: Free daily ESL classes offered by ESL Services
Description: Free ESL class are offered daily at both beginning and intermediate levels.

Summary: Debate on the presidential election & foreign policy held
Description:
The UT Alexander Hamilton Society hosts a debate on foreign policy in the 2012 presidential campaign. "The Presidential Election and Foreign Policy: A Debate on Who Should Lead America in the Next Four Years" features Dr. Kori Schake of the Hoover Institution and the U.S. Military Academy at West Point speaking in support of the Romney campaign and Dr. Jeremi Suri of The University of Texas at Austin and the LBJ School of Public Affairs speaking in support of the Obama campaign.



For more information on the Hamilton Society, visit www.hamsoc.org and be sure to "like" the UT chapter on Facebook.

Summary: BINGO Night sponsored by by Kappa Phi Lambda
Description: Play BINGO for prizes and gift cards. All proceeds go toward philanthropy projects of Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority, Inc., for their Philanthropy Week, "Fight the Fright."

Summary: Abolish the Death Penalty event hosted by Amnesty Int'l
Description: Learn about the death penalty with Amnesty International's UT chapter. This event features speakers and artwork. Art exhibit and refreshments are followed by a Q&A at 7 p.m.

Summary: Learn about spring EMT class at Longhorn EMS info session
Description: Become a certified emergency medical technician at the spring EMT class. Learn more at an information session hosted by Longhorn EMS. Email szadoo@longhornems.org with questions.

Summary: VAC screening explores phenomenon of public-access TV
Description: A decade before Wayne and Garth premiered their public access show "Wayne's World" on Saturday Night Live in 1988, the TV party had already begun. Join the VAC for a special screening exploring the central themes of community, public space and performance in the weird world of public-access television.

Summary: School-to-Prison Pipeline panel slated
Description:
Education inequality has taken an enormous toll on poor communities across this nation. A by-product is the school-to-prison pipeline. Longhorn Teach for America presents a panel discussion  addressing one of the root causes of injustice in the United States. 



Panelists include the College of Education's Dr. Richard Reddick, AISD Police Chief Eric Mendez and Higher Education Administration Ph.D. candidate Manuel Gonzalez.

Summary: Umoja Week holds "Act Like a Lady Think Like A Man" forum
Description: The Ladies of Umoja present an all-male panel as part of a forum with the topic "Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man."

Summary: Dr. Toughlove answers questions about relationships
Description:
"Dr. Toughlove of The Horn Tackles Men's Questions About Love and Lust" is an event hosted by Voices Against Violence and co-sponsored by Tejas Club and the Mu Rho chapter of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc. Read sample sage advice from Dr. Toughlove here: http://www.readthehorn.com/users/dr_toughlove. Free food served.



Many have compared Dr. Toughlove to an ice pick. He's cold, tough and pointed. Pulling from years of escapades, rejection and his own brutal honesty, Dr. Toughlove engages relational problems as few do. He advocates for relationships based on honesty and consent. He refuses to add even the thinnest of sugar coatings to his responses. In other words, he levels with his readers in way they may find comfortable or uncomfortable, but always darkly funny.

Summary: Invisible Children presents screening of "Move"
Description: "Move," the first film released by Invisible Children since the return of founder and chief creative officer Jason Russell, is a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the most viral video ever, which made an African warlord famous. Screening to be followed by a Q&A with a Ugandan advocate and Invisible Children representatives.

Summary: Women's basketball takes on Incarnate Word
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Incarnate Word Cardinals in an exhibition game.

Summary: KUT presents Leonard Cohen: A Life in Art
Description: In anticipation of two Austin performances by Cohen, his collaborator, producer and bassist, Roscoe Beck, joins Cohen biographer Sylvie Simmons ("I'm Your Man: The Life of Leonard Cohen") and members of Cohen's band to explore the life and art of a living legend. Limited seating available; line forms early.

Summary: Gilberto Gil presents "For All"
Description:
Multi-Grammy-winning Brazilian superstar and social activist Gilberto Gil returns to Texas Performing Arts with a program that pays homage to music pioneer and father of the baião, Luiz Gonzaga. An ArtesAméricas performance.



Baião fuses classic styles of European folk music with indigenous and African sounds. Acclaimed composer, accordionist and singer Luiz Gonzaga, known as the "King of Baião," was responsible for taking this music from rural Northeast Brazil to the rest of the country. Driven by the accordion, triangle and a bass drum, baião forms the soundtrack for the Catholic June Festival and the popular dance music known as forró.

Summary: Longhorn Board Gamerzzz meet
Description: Longhorn Board Gamerzzz gather in a relaxed and informal setting to play board games. Drop in during this session; games welcome. For more information, call 281-384-8263 or email nishantjayant@gmail.com.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Hearts of Texas Halloween event announced
Description:
Enjoy spooky treats

and make a donation to the Hearts of Texas Charitable Campaign. All donations benefit the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

Summary: Health Policy Workshop sponsored by School of Nursing
Description: The School of Nursing hosts the Health Policy Workshop, an opportunity to examine recent changes in health-related policies with some of Texas's most experienced legislators and analysts.
Location: Frank Erwin Center, Lone Star Ballroom

Summary: Student presents CMAS graduate portfolio plática
Description: Karla González, doctoral candidate in Spanish and Portuguese with a graduate portfolio in Mexican American studies, presents her graduate portfolio plática, titled "'¿A qué le tiras cuando sueñas mexicano?: The Intellectuals in Exile and the Disillusionment of the Mexican Revolution in Early Mexican-American Novels."
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Panel discusses Syria and humanitarian intervention
Description: Attend a panel titled "Humanitarian Intervention vs. State Sovereignty? Competing Norms in Syria and Beyond," with participation by Senator Robert C. Krueger, Ambassador Tom Schieffer, Professor Robert M. Chesney and Dr. Alan J. Kuperman.

Summary: John McKiernan-González presents faculty book talk
Description: The LLILAS Faculty Book Series welcomes John McKiernan-González, Department of History, presenting "Fevered Measures," an examination of public health campaigns along the Texas-Mexico border between 1848 and 1942.

Summary: Ellen Wartella discusses food marketing & childhood obesity
Description: Ellen Wartella, professor of communication, human development/sociology and psychology at Northwestern University, presents the 2012 Wayne Danielson Lecture, "Food Marketing and the Childhood Obesity Crisis." Wartella, former dean of the College of Communication, discusses the extent of the childhood obesity crisis and the food environment in American society.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium 2.106

Summary: Halloween potluck held at Concho Community Garden
Description:
Celebrate Halloween with a potluck at the UT Concho Community Garden. Carpool leaves from WEL 2.312 at 5 p.m. sharp. Duo-team pumpkin carving contest begins at 5:30 p.m. followed by a screening of the classic zombie thriller "Night of the Living Dead." Bring a dish to share. Sign up for a dish, or the pumpkin carving contest, at gardening@utenvironment.org.



This event takes the place of the CEC's general meeting.
Location: UT Concho Community Garden, 2108 Concho Street

Summary: Halloween Carillon Concert announced
Description: Music theory sophomore Austin Ferguson performs a fun-filled concert of Halloween favorites on the UT Tower. Selections include works by Bach, Van den Gheyn and some Hollywood favorites. For more information on the carillon and student guild, visit www.texascarillon.com.

Summary: Leadership Series Workshop announced
Description: The Leadership Series presents workshops designed to develop both individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations. Workshops are held twice a month in the fall and spring semesters.

Summary: Association of Black Psychologists meets
Description: At this meeting, the Association of Black Psychologists discusses how to choose the best academic program with financial aid in mind.

Summary: Film screening and talk spotlight human trafficking
Description: Watch clips from the hit blockbuster "Taken," starring Liam Neeson, and learn about the difference between how the media portrays human trafficking and how it actually exists in our world today. Popcorn served. This is part of a series of events hosted by Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority, Inc., for their Philanthropy Week, "Fight the Fright."

Summary: Shades of Mahogany annual scholarship banquet held
Description: Shades of Mahogany is a scholarship banquet ceremony  honoring deserving men on campus. All are invited to attend and show their support for the academic achievements of males on UT's campus.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Symphony Orchestra performs
Description: The UT Symphony Orchestra performs. Online tickets are available until 9 a.m. of the day of performance. Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance, here: http://www.music.utexas.edu/calendar/details.aspx?id=23252.

Summary: Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority holds info session
Description: Theta Nu Xi Sorority is active in shaping the community through ethics, diversity, leadership and more. Attend this information session to learn more about the organization and meet the current members.

Summary: Leonard Cohen performs at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Legendary singer, songwriter and poet Leonard Cohen graces the Bass Concert Hall stage during the North American leg of his "Old Ideas World Tour 2012." VIP packages available at http://ev9.evenue.net/cgi-bin/ncommerce3/SEGetPackageInfo?packageCode=GS:PAC::LCVIP:&linkID=tex-pac&shopperContext=&caller=&appCode=&RSRC=tex-pac&RDAT=cohen-tpaevt.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Landmarks Video presents "Vault," by Yonemoto brothers
Description: Landmarks Video presents "Vault" (1984) by artists Bruce and Norman Yonemoto. Referencing the conventions of soap operas, Hollywood films and advertising, the Yonemoto brothers challenge viewers to recognize the role of mass media in our perceptions of identity and reality. On view throughout November.

Summary: Practica Plática holds breakfast taco fund-raiser
Description: Support Practica Plática at a breakfast taco fund-raiser. Breakfast tacos are $1.00 each. Vegetarian options also available.

Summary: Visions of the Future symposium held
Description:
The tenth biennial Fleur Cowles Flair Symposium, "Visions of the Future" is held in conjunction with the exhibition "I Have Seen the Future: Norman Bel Geddes Designs America." Registration (http://flair2012.eventbrite.com/) and schedule (http://www.hrc.utexas.edu/flair/schedule/) are online.



A panel of historians, architects, industrial designers and visionaries in the fields of science fiction, film, theater and future studies comes together to explore the ways the future has been imagined over time.



Panelists will discuss the guiding principles of designers of the twentieth century and today, creative works that have inspired their visions of the future, efforts to market these visions to the public, and developments in transportation design.

Summary: Lemonade stand by Kappa Phi Lambda helps charity
Description: Grab a cool, refreshing drink from the Kappa Phi Lambda lemonade stand and submit your name for a chance to win prizes. Proceeds benefit the Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority's Philanthropy Week, "Fight the Fright."

Summary: Learn to use Google Docs in online course
Description:
Learn how to use Google Docs to share and collaboratively create documents, spreadsheets, and slide presentations online. At class start time, go to the web address for the class, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher. 



For a complete schedule of classes go to http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/index.html.

Summary: Interfraternity Council kicks off "Movember"
Description:
Participate in "Movember" to raise vital funds and awareness of men's health issues, specifically prostate and other cancers that affect men. Register at the Interfraternity Council table. During November each year, Movember is responsible for the sprouting of moustaches on thousands of men's faces in the United States and around the world. 



On Nov. 1, guys register at Movember.com with a clean-shaven face. For the rest of the month, these selfless and generous men, known as Mo Bros, groom, trim and wax their way into the annals of fine moustachery while raising funds.

Summary: Autism, genetics and the environment are topic of talk
Description: The Center for Molecular & Cellular Toxicology presents Genevieve Konopka, Ph.D., assistant professor of neuroscience at UT Southwestern Medical Medical Center, delivering a lecture titled "Genetic and Environmental Interactions in Autism."

Summary: Researcher says yes, it is possible to be smart and happy
Description: The Texas Enterprise Speaker Series welcomes Dr. Raj Raghunathan, who discusses his research on happiness and intelligence in a talk titled "If You're So Smart, Why Aren't You Happy?"

Summary: Learn about study abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua
Description: Attend a general information session for students interested in the "Afro-Caribbean Politics and Culture in Central America" summer abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua.

Summary: Perspectives gallery talk presented by Coach Rick Barnes
Description: Rick Barnes, head coach of the Longhorns men's basketball team, delivers a Perspectives gallery talk on "The Rules of Basketball," an exhibition of works by contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer presented in conjunction with a special display of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball," the 1891 document outlining the 13 original rules of the game.

Summary: Belo Center for New Media tours offered
Description: Building tours of the new Belo Center for New Media meet near the building's first-floor elevators. Named in recognition of the seminal role played by Col. A.H. Belo in the early days of Texas journalism, the Belo Center provides much-needed space for more than 4,600 students.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), 300 W. Dean Keeton Street

Summary: BE Global Internship Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for Business and Engineering majors beginning Summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.
Location: Cockrell Hall (ECJ), 10th floor, Large Conference Room

Summary: Belo Center for New Media holds dedication ceremony
Description: Attend the dedication ceremony of the Belo Center for New Media, featuring presentations by university officials. Named in recognition of the seminal role played by Col. A.H. Belo in the early days of Texas journalism, the Belo Center for New Media provides much-needed space for more than 4,600 students.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), 300 W. Dean Keeton Street, 2nd-floor auditorium

Summary: Emergency preparedness is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides participants with the tools necessary to be a leader in campus emergency preparedness in cases of natural and man-made incidents. This is a multi-media workshop; discussion will be encouraged. Presented by the Office of Emergency Preparedness.

Summary: UT Energy Symposium presents panel on climate change
Description: This week, the UT Energy Symposium presents a panel discussion on climate change with Professor J. Eric Bickel of the Cockrell School of Engineering and Lee Lane, visiting fellow at the Hudson Institute. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Teacher certification information session held
Description: Learn about the many different paths to becoming a certified educator at a presentation that includes traditional and alternative routes. Visit the link below and click on the RSVP button to say you'll attend.

Summary: Student Health Advisory Committee holds annual Town Hall
Description:
The Student Health Advisory Committee cordially invites you to our annual Town Hall, an open discussion with University Health Services administrators and health leaders. Free food and prize drawings included.



Discussion topics include: (1) How to use insurance at UHS and how the new Affordable Care Act affects you, (2) Does better health mean better grades? (3) How you can become a health advocate and leader on campus?
Location: San Jacinto Residence Hall (SJH), Multipurpose Room

Summary: VIP Distinguished Speaker Series presents Kenneth Chenault
Description: The McCombs VIP Distinguished Speaker Series welcomes Kenneth Chenault, CEO and chairman of American Express. Chenault also serves on the boards of IBM, the Arthur Ashe Institute for Urban Health, the National Center on Addiction & Substance Abuse at Columbia University, the Smithsonian Institution's Advisory Council for the National Museum of African American History & Culture and the Phoenix House Foundation.

Summary: Author and scholar Theresa Runstedler presents book
Description: The Warfield Center hosts a presentation by Dr. Theresa Runstedler, author of "Jack Johnson, Rebel Sojourner: Boxing in the Shadow of the Global Color Line." Runstedler is assistant professor of transnational American studies, SUNY-Buffalo. Dr. Ben Carrington, associate professor of sociology, serves as discussant.

Summary: Umoja Week promotes breast cancer awareness
Description: Wear pink and join the Ladies of Umoja and the Ladies of Delta Sigma Theta to discuss breast cancer awareness.

Summary: The Broccoli Project presents Don Nigro's "Paganini"
Description:
The Broccoli Project presents Don Nigro's "Paganini," a dark comedy in two acts about the infamous virtuoso violinist Nicolo Paganini, whose skill with the violin was so great that many believed he was a marionette of the devil. Contact director David Skaggs at skeegz@gmail.com with questions.



Using Paganini's 24 Caprices for Violin as a haunting soundtrack, the play traces the grotesque and satirical adventures of Paganini as he plays throughout Europe, his century's equivalent of a rock star.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: UT Scuba Club meets
Description: Join University Scuba Club at its general meeting to learn about upcoming dives/events, meet dive buddies and take advantage of dive courses and specials offered to UT students. Newcomers welcome.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Defense Distributed's wiki weapon discussed in talk
Description: Law student Cody Wilson discusses Defense Distributed, an open-source group attempting to design a firearm, a wiki weapon, that can be downloaded from the Internet and "printed" on a 3D printer. The group's goal is to develop design schematics that would allow for the production of a working plastic gun.

Summary: Miró Quartet performs faculty artist concert
Description: The Faculty Artist Series presents the Miró Quartet in concert. Online tickets available until 9 a.m. of the concert date. Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Click Visit the Butler School of Music website to listen.

Summary: Bruce Sterling launches 2012 Flair Symposium
Description:
Author and futurist Bruce Sterling delivers the keynote lecture of the Harry Ransom Center's Flair Symposium "Visions of the Future." Sterling is an American science fiction author best known for his novels and his work on the Mirrorshades anthology, which helped define the cyberpunk genre. Seating is limited. Line forms upon arrival of the first patron, and doors open 30 minutes in advance. Paid registrants for Flair Symposium given priority.



The 2012 Flair Symposium "Visions of the Future" continues Friday, Nov. 2, and Saturday, Nov. 3, bringing together historians, architects, industrial designers and visionaries in the fields of science fiction, film, theater and future studies to explore the ways the future has been imagined over time. Payment and pre-registration for the symposium is required.

Summary: Leonard Cohen performs at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Legendary singer, songwriter and poet Leonard Cohen graces the Bass Concert Hall stage during the North American leg of his "Old Ideas World Tour 2012." VIP packages available at http://ev9.evenue.net/cgi-bin/ncommerce3/SEGetPackageInfo?packageCode=GS:PAC::LCVIP:&linkID=tex-pac&shopperContext=&caller=&appCode=&RSRC=tex-pac&RDAT=cohen-tpaevt.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall
