Summary: Talk looks at history of eugenics in the 20th century
Description: Professor Philippa Levine presents a talk titled "The Curious History of Eugenics in the Twentieth Century." Levine is a specialist in the history of the British Empire with a particular interest in science, medicine and society at the intersections of race and gender. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: AT&T Education and Conference Center (ATT), Carillon Mezzanine

Summary: Day of the Dead ILASSA Conference Fund-raiser held
Description: Institute of Latin American Studies Student Association (ILASSA) presents its 2012 Day of the Dead ILASSA Conference Fund-raiser, a great night of music and dancing. Entry fee includes a raffle ticket for great prizes from Austin businesses. All proceeds go toward the 2013 ILASSA Conference, the oldest and largest student-run Latin American studies conference in the country.
Location: Copa Bar and Grill, 217 Congress Avenue

Summary: Carnegie Endowment Junior Fellows deadline is Nov. 15
Description:
Nominations are now being accepted for The University of Texas at Austin selection of candidates for the 2012-2013 Carnegie Endowment Junior Fellows Program. Eligible students are in their senior year or are alumni who have graduated within the past academic year and have not yet started graduate studies. Junior Fellows provide research assistance to scholars working on the Carnegie Endowment's projects. 



Project areas include nuclear policy, democracy building, energy and climate issues, international economics, international security, Middle East studies, South Asian politics, Southeast Asian politics, Asia and China-related issues and Russian and Eurasian affairs.

Summary: CIBER presents Teaching Business Language symposium
Description: This symposium, designed for current and prospective language faculty, discusses the benefits of introducing or adding business language courses to your curriculum and identifies tools, resources and methods to help you make the transition.

Summary: Apply for NAE Grand Challenges Scholars Program by Nov. 6
Description:
Students of all majors and all years are invited to apply for the Grand Challenges Scholars Program (GCSP) sponsored by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE). Learn more at http://www.engineeringchallenges.org/. Submit application via email to Dr. Christina White, director, at gcsp@engr.utexas.edu by Nov. 6.



The scholarship provides an interdisciplinary curriculum emphasizing research, entrepreneurship, global dimensions and service learning.

Summary: Texas men's tennis hosts UT Invitational
Description: The Texas men's tennis team hosts the UT Invitational. Come see what the racquet is all about.

Summary: Microsoft's chief research & strategy officer gives talk
Description: Microsoft's Craig Mundie presents a talk titled "How Tomorrow's Technologies Will Shape Your World."

Summary: Argentine fin de siglo documented in sisters' diaries
Description: The Gender Symposium presents "Writing Sisterhood in the Argentine Fin de Siglo," a look at the diaries kept by sisters Julia and Delfina Bunge, whose turn-of-the-century diaries (1880-1910) represent an unparalleled record of the transformation of Buenos Aires from village to cosmopolitan metropolis.

Summary: Grant-writing workshop for grad students offered
Description: This workshop is offered to Liberal Arts graduate students. Get guidance on preparing fellowship or grant proposals, with special focus on the different components of a standard proposal and on writing project descriptions. Participants are encouraged to bring samples of their work for peer review. RSVP to Melanie Morgan at mmorgan@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Population Research Ctr & Dept of Sociology host speaker
Description: Dr. Denise Park, co-director of the Center for Vital Longevity at the University of Texas at Dallas, delivers a talk titled "Fragile Minds: Neural Scaffolding and Cognitive Aging." Reception to follow in the ACE lobby.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Higher Education Leadership Program info session held
Description:
Students interested in obtaining a master's or doctoral degree in educational administration at The University of Texas at Austin are encouraged to attend the Higher Education Leadership information session. RSVP at http://uthighered.eventbrite.com/.



Hear from the Higher Education Administration Program (HEAP) and the Community College Leadership Program (CCLP) faculty, administrators and students. Gain useful tips and hints about crafting a strong application.



Ask questions about courses, assistantships and ways to finance your education.



Learn more about getting a M.Ed., Ph.D. or Ed.D. in educational administration with a concentration in one of various areas.
Location: Sanchez Building (SZB), Cissy McDaniel Parker Deans Conference Room 238

Summary: Senator John Kerry discusses rule of law in world affairs
Description: The Honorable John F. Kerry, United States Senator from Massachusetts, presents a talk titled "The Rule of Law in World Affairs." Kerry discusses promoting the rule of law in the Middle East at a time of transition; Iran and the utility of multilateral sanctions; and the role of treaties in keeping Americans safe and our country secure.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Auditorium, 2315 Red River Street

Summary: Philippa Levine discusses "colonial prostitution"
Description: History Professor Philippa Levine gives a talk titled "Colonial Prostitution: Brothel Clubs in British South East Asia."
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Grammar-o-Ramma sponsored by Undergraduate Writing Center
Description: Learn about the most common grammatical errors and how to fix them. Bring your questions about grammar and punctuation to this informative workshop. Refreshments provided.

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: "Scarlet Letter" is topic of afternoon salon
Description:
When was the last time you read Nathaniel Hawthorne's "Scarlet Letter"? High school? College? What do you remember? What questions did/do you have about the novel? Attend a special afternoon salon with the theme Everything You Ever Wanted to Know About the Scarlet Letter, in anticipation of the UT Department of Theatre and Dance's world premiere of "The Scarlet Letter" by Sarah Saltwick. 



Salon features Dr. Martin Kevorkian (UT associate professor of English) and the cast and crew of the play.

Summary: BGSA and BSA hold members' mixer
Description: The Black Graduate Students Association and the Black Students Alliance invite all members to an informal mixer. This event is important for creating and maintaining connections between the BGSA and the BSA.

Summary: Siemens Competition hosts reception
Description: Attend a reception for regional finalists in the 14th annual Siemens Mathematics, Science and Technology Competition. Projects will be on display and students will be on hand to share their research findings. Refreshments provided.

Summary: Architect and MacArthur fellow Jeanne Gang presents talk
Description: Architect and MacArthur fellow Jeanne Gang is founder and principal of Studio Gang Architects, a Chicago-based collective of architects, designers and thinkers whose projects confront pressing contemporary issues.

Summary: Yoruba African art lecture focuses on master carvers
Description:
Dr. Roslyn A. Walker, acclaimed author and leading authority on African 

art, presents a lecture titled "Anonymous Has a Name: Olowe of Ise, A Yoruba Sculptor to Kings," offering insight into the fascinating world of the Yoruba master carvers.



This lecture is held in conjunction with the dual exhibition ERE and Reflections, an exceptional fusion of traditional and contemporary art that celebrates the Yoruba culture past and present. On view through January 5.
Location: The Carver Art Museum and Cultural Center, Boyd Vance Theater, 1165 Angelina Street

Summary: Baal Dan holds banquet and cultural showcase
Description: Enjoy a full Indian dinner while being entertained by live performers at the Baal Danquet charity fund-raiser. Baal Dan helps street children, slum children and orphans in India with direct aid and investment in ways to provide these children with an education. Tickets can be purchased at West Mall, Jester or from Baal Dan members. All proceeds benefit Baal Dan Charities.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays Kansas State
Description: Texas volleyball faces the Kansas State Wildcats in a Big 12 matchup. Canned Food Drive: Donate five nonperishable canned food items and receive a free Texas Sports DVD and Whataburger coupon (while supplies last).

Summary: Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly"
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly." Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Visit the link below to listen.

Summary: Cameron Carpenter, organ, performs
Description: Texas Performing Arts presents Cameron Carpenter, organ, called "the most controversial organist alive" by the Dallas Morning News. Carpenter's flamboyant style, dazzling performances and profound musical intelligence have completely changed the game of his instrument.

Summary: Texas Ballroom hosts Halloween Dance
Description: Texas Ballroom announces its Halloween social dance. Put on your costume and join us for a fun night of dancing, socializing and snacks. All genres of music featured.

Summary: Siemens Competition in Math, Science & Technology held
Description: High school students compete for scholarships and a chance to advance to the national competition in December, where the top award is $100,000. Student projects will be on display during competition hours in Room 103.

Summary: UT Micro Farm holds first workday
Description: Help start UT's first student-run sustainable farm by volunteering at the UT Micro Farm's very first workday. Tools and supplies provided. All skill levels welcome. Bring construction tools if you have them. Free breakfast served. Bring water and wear closed-toe shoes. Visit us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/UTMicroFarm.

Summary: Participants needed for psychoacoustics study
Description: The UT Psychophysics Lab seeks native speakers of American English, ages 18-35, to participate in a tone perception study. Subjects must have no experience with tone languages and less than three years' experience playing a musical instrument. Study consists of two sessions of about two hours each. If interested, email utsoundlab@gmail.com with "tone study" in the subject heading.

Summary: "Wake Up Everbody" is Umoja Week community service event
Description: Join the Ladies of Umoja as we end Umoja Week with community service. Meet in front of Jester Smoothie at 9 a.m. for a ride.

Summary: Asian American parents sought for focus group
Description: Asian American parents who were either born in the United States or came to the United States before the age of 10, with children between the ages of 3-10 years old, are sought a focus group or interview on Asian American parenting. Contact the researchers at aa.parenting@gmail.com]aa.parenting@gmail.com or 512-666-8580 for an appointment.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Channel creativity at Blanton's Girl Scout Day
Description: Join other Girl Scouts, Brownies and Juniors to explore art and the creative process at Girl Scout Day at the Blanton. Activities are designed for Girl Scouts to work on earning badges. For program details and registration, visit the Girl Scouts of Central Texas website at www.gsctx.org.

Summary: Blanton hosts tour of The Rules of Basketball
Description: Basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures featuring the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Turkish Film Series presents "Fetih  1453"
Description: The Turkish Film Series screens "Fetih 1453" (Conquest 1453, dir. Faruk Aksoy, 2012, 160 min.). "Conquest 1453" is the new spear-and-molten-pitch swashbuckler movie that had Turkish viewers storming their local cinemas in record-breaking numbers. In Turkish with English subtitles.

Summary: LIGHT | NIGHT: Bike Light Dance Project presented
Description:
LIGHT | NIGHT, the culminating event of the 16-month UT Safe Cycling Campaign, is a cross-disciplinary effort among a School of Architecture graduate student, design students in the Department of Art and Art History and performers and costume designers from the Department of Theatre and Dance. 



LIGHT | NIGHT aims raises awareness about nighttime bike safety with an exciting choreographed dance performance. During the performance, lights will illuminate the movement of dancers, and as day turns to night, those dancers will only be visible by the lights on their bodies - a poetic reminder to the campus community of the importance of being lit at night.



As part of the event, the UT Safe Cycling Campaign will distribute 270 free bike lights to university students, faculty and staff with a valid ID.

Summary: Hold 'Em for Hunger benefits Nourish International
Description:
Nourish International presents a casino night featuring live performances, great food, and a chance to win a pair of Lupe Fiasco tickets. All proceeds benefit Nourish International, a nonprofit organization that sends students abroad over the summer to work on projects in impoverished communities. 



View our project video from summer 2012 here.

Summary: Choral Arts Society performs
Description:
The Choral Arts Society performs. Online tickets available until 9 a.m., Friday, Nov. 2. Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance.



Visit the Butler School of Music website to listen.

Summary: GSA 5K Run/Walk announced
Description: Join the Graduate Student Assembly for a rousing 5K run/walk through campus, starting and finishing at the Gregory Gym plaza. After the race, there will be entertainment and refreshments for everyone. All proceeds from the 5K are dedicated to graduate student education, travel and resources. To volunteer, visit the link below.

Summary: ULI Deferred Action Clinic held
Description:
The University Leadership Initiative hosts its second clinic for the DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) application. Subsequent clinics will be held Nov. 10 and Nov. 17 for those who cannot attend this one. High school graduates are eligible. Reserve a spot at tinyurl.com/ULIDACAreserveNOV4. Or call 512-655-DACA (512-655-3222) from 8 a.m.-8 p.m. on weekdays and 8 a.m.-8 p.m. on weekends, or email uli.daca@gmail.com. To volunteer, visit tinyurl.com/ULIDACAvolunteerNOV4.



Visit the University Leadership Initiative on Facebook at tinyurl.com/facebookULI.



Follow us on Twitter at twitter.com/ULIDACA.
Location: El Centro de Familia, 6002 Jain Lane, 78721

Summary: Tour Blanton exhibit: Into the Sacred City
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Wind Ensemble performs
Description:
The UT Wind Ensemble performs. Online tickets available until 9 a.m. Friday, Nov. 2. Webcast will begin streaming a few minutes before the performance. 



Visit the Butler School of Music website to listen.

Summary: Archaeology Field School announces summer 2013 program
Description:
Attend an information session about the faculty-led 2013 summer archaeological field school in the north of Portugal. 

Information about the course, living arrangements, trips and financial aid to be discussed.

Summary: Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly"
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents "Madame Butterfly." Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Visit the link below to listen.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Voting open for Study Abroad Office photo contest
Description: Photos submitted by UT students who studied abroad fall 2011, spring 2012 and summer 2012 can be viewed and voted for online. The photo with the most amount of "likes" in each category wins a $50 gift card. Voting is open until Nov. 9 at 5 p.m., with winners announced on Monday, Nov. 12 at the launch of International Education Week.

Summary: Construction Industry Institute class offered
Description: Project Construction and Startup includes the following modules: Planning Startup, Managing the Small Project, Project Delivery and Contract Strategies, Materials Management, Safety: Zero Accidents and International Project Risk Assessment.

Summary: Callicarpa presents Bantam: How Big Is Small?
Description: Can an artwork that is small in size have large implications? This exhibition explores ways in which small works can operate in big ways, negating our assumptions that a work's strength comes through its size. The exhibition features work by Victoria Batey, Ryan Chen, Laura Doughtie, Hilary Fagadau, Iva Kinnaird, Phil LaDeau, Phillip Scarpone, Taylor Swan and Trey Wright; juried by Peter Abrami.

Summary: Learn about faculty-led semester in Antigua, Guatemala
Description: The spring 2013 University of Texas at Austin study abroad program at Casa Herrera offers courses in Mesoamerican art, archeology, anthropology and Spanish or indigenous languages. Students live and study in breathtaking Antigua, Guatemala. Learn more at this information session.

Summary: Introduction to EndNote offered
Description: This introductory class covers tricks for using EndNote with library databases, such as Web of Science, and with indexes and the library catalog. Special sessions of this class can be arranged for UT groups or departments. Learn more at link below.

Summary: Taiwanese temple style & immigrant identity are talk topic
Description: "Temple Style and Immigrant Identity: Yinshan Temple in Early 19th-Century Tamsui" is a talk presented by Dr. Fang-Mei Chen, professor, Graduate Institute of Art History, National Taiwan University.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 2.204

Summary: Moroccan translator of El Quijote is topic of talk
Description: Poet and scholar Abderrahman El Fathi presents a talk in Spanish on Thami Ouazzani, Moroccan translator of El Quijote, titled "Por la senda del traductor aljamiado del Quijote en Marruecos: Thami Ouazzani."

Summary: Inspiration for the Arch of Constantine is lecture topic
Description: The Workshop on Late Antiquity presents "The Senate and the Sun: Inspiration for the Arch of Constantine," a lecture by Noel E. Lenski, University of Colorado at Boulder.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 2.204

Summary: Club Outreach general meeting announced
Description: Club Outreach is a student organization whose mission is to form a link between University of Texas students and Austin Independent School District students. UT students volunteer and mentor at local schools through the club, providing assistance to at-risk students through fun, hands-on activities. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Bevonomics 302A topic is stocks, bonds & mutual funds
Description: Find out what stocks, bonds and mutual funds are, and how they work.

Summary: Texas Nutrition Career Panel held
Description: Join Texas Nutrition for its annual Career Panel. Hear from speakers who work in the nutrition field and learn what a career in this field looks like. Food served.

Summary: Focus on East Asia presents talk on Taiwan's future
Description: The Center for East Asian Studies welcomes Director General Daniel T.C. Liao of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston. Liao will outline the current position of Taiwan with an eye to the future, focusing on many relevant cultural, political and economic considerations.

Summary: The Lars von Trier film series continues
Description: "Antichrist" (2009) is Lars von Trier's most brutal, disturbing movie. Combining themes of loss and eroticism, it is a rare and controversial piece of art, not for everyone. With Willem Dafoe and Charlotte Gainsbourg.

Summary: Discrimination on campus is topic of meeting, panel
Description:
The Black Graduate Student Association and the Black Homecoming Planning Committee host a meeting and panel to address discrimination and recent injustices on campus. All UT students, including organization leaders, are encouraged to stand together to oppose discrimination.



Panelists include Robert Dahlstrom, University of Texas at Austin Chief of Police; Mary Beth Mercatoris, associate director of the Dean of Students; Nelson Linder, NAACP Austin Chapter president; Ana Ixchel Rosal, director, Multicultural Engagement Center; Rudolph Metayer, Austin Black Lawyers Association President.

Summary: Difficult Dialogues topic is surveillance & the public
Description:
The Humanities Institute presents a panel titled Surveillance, Space and the Public, with Dr. Simone Browne (UT Sociology); Micha Cárdenas (scholar, artist, activist); and Ernesto Yerena (artist, activist). Together, they examine historical and contemporary modes of surveillance, art as a form of critical engagement and the use of creative engagement with surveillance tactics to form community.



The panel will be followed by small group discussion of these and other issues raised during the presentations.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Mises Circle discusses Ron Paul's "Origins of the Fed"
Description:
Rounding off our series on the economic consequences of fractional reserve banking, the Mises Circle reads Ron Paul's "The Origins of the Fed." Read the article at http://mises.org/daily/5742/.



For a more in-depth analysis of the history and economics of the Federal Reserve, read Murray Rothbard's "The Origins of the Federal Reserve" here or here.

Summary: Regina Spektor performs at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Regina Spektor performs on the Bass Concert Hall stage. Spektor's extraordinary voice has guided the way through a prolific catalogue filled with songs of satire, heartache, and novelty, manifested in six critically acclaimed studio albums.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas Ballroom offers lessons; new dances featured
Description: Attend a new series of classes with Texas Ballroom this week. No partner, shoes or experience necessary. Monday: cha-cha at 8 p.m. and samba at 9, Tuesday: salsa at 8 p.m. and swing at 9, Wednesday: fox-trot at 8 p.m. and quickstep at 9 p.m, Thursday: triple two-step at 6 p.m. and west coast swing at 7.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Faculty workshop on teaching critical thinking offered
Description: In higher education, our mission extends beyond simply teaching content - it includes teaching students how to think critically across a wide range of circumstances, topics, and problems. Spanish and Portuguese Professor Luis Cárcamo-Huechante leads this workshop. Register at https://utdirect.utexas.edu/txclass/index.WBX; course ID: DI 507.

Summary: Learn about faculty-led semester in Antigua, Guatemala
Description: The spring 2013 University of Texas at Austin study abroad program at Casa Herrera offers courses in Mesoamerican art, archeology, anthropology and Spanish or indigenous languages. Students live and study in breathtaking Antigua, Guatemala. Learn more at this information session.

Summary: Crunch Time 2012 held at campus libraries
Description: Get research help, time-saving handouts, giveaways and mini Crunch bars just in time for the end-of-semester deadline crunch. Find help at the Benson Latin American Collection (SRH 1.108), Fine Arts Library (DFA 3.200), Geology Library (JGB 4.202), Life Science Library (MAI 220), Perry-Castañeda Library (PCL) and Physics Mathematics Astronomy Library (RLM 4.200).

Summary: Zotero Manage Citations class offered online
Description:
Learn how to use this free, web-based tool to collect, manage and cite your sources.  At start time, go to the web address for the class, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher. 



Special sessions of this class may also be arranged for UT groups or departments. For more information, including the form to request classes for your group/department, visit the link below.

Summary: Bevonomics 101 topic is budgeting and building credit
Description: Acclimate your saving and spending style to the college lifestyle. Learn how to create and use a daily budget, save money, maintain and grow a savings account and build credit.

Summary: ChE Graduate Seminar Series presents Dr. Karen Winey
Description: Nanoparticles, particularly carbon nanotubes and metal nanowires, provide new routes for engineering the electrical properties of polymers. This lecture will focus on two aspects of this expanding field, namely electrical conductivity and resistive switching.

Summary: The U.S. Constitution in Argentina is topic of talk
Description:
The Rapoport Center's fall Human Rights Happy Hour Speaker Series welcomes Professor Jonathan Miller of Southwestern Law School, presenting a talk titled "Borrowing a Constitution: The U.S. Constitution in Argentina and the Heyday of the Argentine Supreme Court (1853-1930)." Light refreshments served.



Respondents are William Forbath, associate dean for research and Lloyd M. Bentsen chair in law, University of Texas School of Law; Tom Ginsburg, Leo Spitz professor of International Law, Ludwig and Hilde Wolf research scholar and professor of political science, University of Chicago Law School; and Ran Hirschl, professor of political science and law and Canada research chair in Constitutionalism, Democracy, and Development, University of Toronto Faculty of Law.

Summary: Visiting Artists Program presents Deborah Stratman
Description: Visiting artist Deborah Stratman presents a talk. She is a Chicago-based artist and filmmaker interested in landscapes and systems. Her films, rather than telling stories, pose a series of problems - and through their at-times ambiguous nature, allow for a complicated reading of the questions being asked.

Summary: Texas Health Promotion Club meets
Description: Learn what the Texas Health Promotion Club has to offer and get involved. Upcoming events and volunteer opportunities are announced at each meeting. All majors welcome. Join us on Facebook at "Texas Health Promotion Club."

Summary: Transferable skills to be S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Being a student employee at The University of Texas at Austin has implications for your future career. Learn to identify transferable skills you are currently gaining, and how to best market these experiences to future employers on a resume and in a job interview. Presented by the Center for Strategic Advising and Career Counseling.

Summary: Learn how to respond to an active shooter
Description: University Future First Responders hosts the UTPD chief of police for a lecture on what to do in an active shooter situation.

Summary: Business Healthcare Association meeting hosts speaker
Description: The Business Healthcare Association welcomes special guest speaker Leslie Carruth, health analysis specialist at The University of Texas System. Free pizza served.

Summary: Suicide prevention is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
The "Be That One" Suicide Prevention Program gives you the tools to support your fellow student employees and friends who may be thinking about suicide, the second leading cause of death for college students. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.



Research shows that students who take this interactive workshop feel less stressed and better prepared to intervene with their friends when they're in distress.

Summary: "The Man Nobody Knew": Film looks at life of CIA spy
Description: Attend a screening of "The Man Nobody Knew: In Search of My Father, CIA Spymaster William Colby." Screening to be followed by a Q&A with filmmaker Carl Colby.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Operation Smile Meeting
Description: Operation Smile is a nonprofit organization that transforms lives across the globe by funding surgeries for children and young adults who are born with facial deformities (specifically cleft lip or cleft palate). Join us in our efforts to spread smiles. All new members welcome.

Summary: Decision 2012: Watch it happen at SAC ballroom
Description: Decision 2012 is a presidential election watch party intended to unify the many cultures on UT's campus. Multiple organizations have joined forces to provide students with a safe space to watch history happen. Watch party features free food, a live DJ and more fun than one description can contain.

Summary: Harp Ensemble performs
Description:
Join the UT Harp Ensemble for a fun-filled evening of dance music by J.S. Bach, Michael Jackson and everything in between. Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. 



Visit the Butler School of Music website to listen.

Summary: Tibetan Buddhist "Ten Million Multiplier" day celebrated
Description: Lhabab Duchen is one of the four special days in the Tibetan Buddhist tradition, celebrated as a "ten million multiplier" day, said to multiply the effects of all positive and negative actions 10 million times. Join Diamond Way Buddhism to celebrate with meditation and a talk.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Register now for Women's Undergraduate Career Launch
Description: Are you a female undergrad who wants to work in business or run your own company some day? Getting your MBA from The University of Texas at Austin can help you get there. Learn how at the Women's Undergraduate Career Launch, held Thursday, Nov. 15, from 5-7 p.m. at the AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center. Register by Friday, Nov. 9, at link below.

Summary: Indian Cultural Association presents Jhalak pre-show
Description: Jhalak is the largest national Bollywood dance competition in Texas. Join members of the UT Indian Cultural Association as they kick off their silent rally for Jhalak, where you can buy a ticket and enjoy authentic Indian food.

Summary: Thanks Day is opportunity to express gratitude
Description:
Take a moment to thank those who contribute to your UT education, whether it be family, professors, scholarship benefactors or others. Students Hooked on Texas provide card-making and video recording materials for your messages at this event. 



Cookies and other giveaways provided to students who participate. Visit us on Facebook.

Summary: Christian Faculty Network hosts Women's Prayer Group
Description: Join fellow women faculty and staff to pray for the campus and each other. All are welcome.

Summary: Free Retirement Guidance Series, Fall 2012, offered
Description:
Attend a seminar titled "Your Retirement Plan at Work," with a representative from VALIC, a UT System authorized retirement program provider.



In this informative seminar, learn about the importance of saving for retirement, the benefits of participating in a workplace retirement plan and the most common types of retirement plans offered by employers.

Summary: CMAS workshop features UT Press editor-in-chief
Description: The Center for Mexican American Studies presents "In Between the Covers: A Publishing Workshop with Theresa May, Editor-in-Chief, UT Press." May has over 35 years of editorial experience and will address the history of UT Press, its field specialties, prominent book series and overall approach to academic publishing. A Q&A follows.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Research on cultural bias & depressive symptoms presented
Description: In a talk titled "Cultural Influences on Responses to Depressive Symptom Measures," Dr. Yuri Jang, associate professor in the UT School of Social Work, presents her findings on cultural bias in responses to CES-D, a commonly used tool for measuring depressive symptoms, and discusses implications for research and practices.

Summary: Say it with Infographics: Library class offered
Description: Pictures are worth 1,000 words. This class surveys ideas, tools and resources for creating charts, graphs and visualizations to display information in a meaningful and less textual way. For a complete schedule of classes, visit the link below.

Summary: NSF faculty submissions workshop held
Description: This presentation and workshop is open to faculty in the College of Liberal Arts who are planning to submit a grant application to National Science Foundation (NSF) in 2012-2013. Session covers how to search for NSF grant solicitations, NSF proposal guidelines for the specific documents required to complete your application, the NSF review process and timeline, and overview of a FastLane application.

Summary: Visiting artist Deborah Stratman gives seminar
Description: Attend a seminar given by visiting artist Deborah Stratman, a Chicago-based artist and filmmaker interested in landscapes and systems. Rather than telling stories, her films pose a series of problems - and through their at-times ambiguous nature, allow for a complicated reading of the questions being asked.

Summary: BE Global Internship Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for Business and Engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1.

Summary: Bevonomics 102 topic is scholarship searches
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships and learn writing tips to improve your application in this short Bevonomics course.

Summary: AGA holds networking social
Description: The Association for Government Accountants (AGA) hosts a networking event with special guest AGA president Evelyn Brown for students seeking mentorship or post-graduation professional development. Mingle with financial managers, as well as executive directors and department heads of many state agencies. RSVP at link below.

Summary: Mobilization & participation in a digital age is talk topic
Description: The College of Communication is pleased to host a public lecture by Dr. Dhavan Shah, titled "Mobilization, Participation and Socialization in a Digital Age." Shah is Maier-Bascom professor of journalism and mass communication at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and a leading authority on mass communication and political psychology.

Summary: FIMRC children's medical relief group meets
Description: Attend the third meeting of UT's chapter of the Foundation for International Children's Medical Relief, a student organization dedicated to providing access to medical care for children in developing countries around the world. Learn about local and international volunteering opportunities as well as leadership opportunities. Food provided.

Summary: Social identities is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
Attend a workshop on social identity, offered for students employed by UT Austin. As a student employee, you often will work with individuals from various social identities and backgrounds. This session provides some fundamental insight into the various social identities in our society and how we navigate working across these identities and cultures.



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter.

Summary: "The Matsugane Potshot Affair": Japanese film screened
Description:
Attend a screening of the popular contemporary Japanese 35 mm film "The Matsugane Potshot Affair" (dir. Yamashita Nobuhiro, 2006), a deliciously absurd dark comedy about two brothers who find themselves catapulted onto different sides of the law after a woman's body is discovered on the outskirts of their dead-end hometown of Matsugane. 



Generously sponsored by The Japan Foundation, as well as the Departments of Asian Studies and Radio-Television-Film.

Summary: Latin Economics Business Assoc. presents Roy Terracina
Description:
A financial wizard with more than three decades of executive experience, Roy 

Terracina shares his business acumen and his inspirational story on campus.



Nominated for Entrepreneur of the Year by Venture North America, Roy Terracina was listed in Who's Who in Finance and Business and Who's Who in America.Roy will be speaking and sharing his motivational story. Open for all majors.

Summary: Science Study Break presents Superheroes & Superstrength
Description: Drs. Jan Todd and Terry Todd of the Stark Center for Physical Culture & Sports look at the strength of superheroes like Batman and the Avengers, and discuss the realities of human strength.

Summary: Author and yogic monk discusses social transformation
Description: Dada Maheshvarananda is a yogic monk, social activist and director of the Prout Research Institute of Venezuela. He is the author most recently of "After Capitalism: Economic Democracy in Action." He will read from the book and discuss the importance of inner peace in social transformation.

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents Moving While Waking
Description: Experimental Response Cinema and the VAC present a diverse group of screen works, all exploring a fundamental characteristic of cinema: movement. The screening presents both rare and acclaimed works of film and video, followed by a brief presentation by and Q&A with curator Ekrem Serdar.

Summary: Women's Health Day sponsored by Zeta Sigma Chi
Description: Zeta Sigma Chi Multicultural Sorority holds its annual Women's Health Day, focusing this year on the prevention and treatment of ovarian, uterine and cervical cancer, all of which affect young women. Free reading material provided, as well as light refreshments and the opportunity to discuss how young women at UT can take steps to maintain good health.

Summary: Primus in 3D comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description: Primus presents the first-ever traveling 3D-enhanced live musical performance, featuring Quad Surround Sound. For the past 27 years, Primus have followed in the footsteps of boundary-pushing artists like Frank Zappa and Pink Floyd to create original and inventive music.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: CMAS pláticarte explores the craft of writing
Description: In a CMAS pláticarte, "Innocent Writing: Writing From a Fear-Free, Fun, Daring, and Caring Place," Elva Treviño Hart, author of "Simpáticas: San Miguel Stories" and "Barefoot Heart: Stories of a Migrant Child," discusses her personal approach to writing and reflects on her writing career.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Into the Sacred City discussed in Perspectives gallery talk
Description: Traveling teacher Sergio Ayala, of Diamond Way Buddhist Center, discusses the Into the Sacred City exhibition as part of the Blanton's Perspectives speaker series.

Summary: Venture Expo: Sixteen startups pitch on Nov. 8
Description:
Sixteen investor-ready startups from The University of Texas at Austin and Central Texas pitch their business ideas to a packed house. Come see what UT Entrepreneurship is all about while rubbing elbows with entrepreneurs and investors. Join us for appetizers and drinks from 5-7 p.m. plus one-on-one time with the day's presenters.



Companies include current members of the Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs, as well as ATI companies and Texas Venture Labs alumni.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Black performativity in São Paulo is symposium topic
Description: "Spaces of Black Performativity in São Paulo" presents four case studies of black communities in São Paulo that have created unique urban experiences of their own through performances. Presentations followed by reception for the accompanying photo exhibition "Spaces of Black Performativity: The Samba Rock Culture in São Paulo," running Nov. 8-Dec. 7.

Summary: School of Human Ecology presents 3 outstanding Longhorns
Description: The School of Human Ecology presents three astounding Texas Longhorns who share their personal stories in a panel on how to approach to life's challenges with making healthy choices as a priority. Panelists are track and field coach Beverly Kearney, Olympic swimming medalist Garrett Weber-Gale and Marissa Duswalt, Associate Director of Policy and Events for First Lady Michelle Obama's Let's Move! initiative.

Summary: Dr. Richard B. Silverman speaks about drug discovery
Description: Dr. Richard B. Silverman, professor of chemistry at Northwestern University, presents a talk titled "Drug Discovery: Ingenuity or Serendipity?" Silverman is the inventor of Lyrica, a drug used to treat epilepsy, neuropathic pain and fibromyalgia. He holds 45 patents, has written four books and has published close to 300 research articles.

Summary: Bevonomics 103 topic is managing your student loans
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Nonverbal communication scholar discusses research
Description: Join the Department of Communication Studies in welcoming Dr. Judith Hall, a prestigious scholar of nonverbal communication, who discusses some of her work in a talk titled "ThingsHave Learned (So Far) About Accurate Interpersonal Perception."

Summary: Office of Survey Research offers seminar for grad students
Description: Back by popular demand, the Office of Survey Research offers a three-hour seminar on the basics of survey research and how to create a quality questionnaire that leads to the best results for your research project. Open to all current University of Texas at Austin graduate students. Contact Beth Van Riper at beth.vanriper@austin.utexas.edu to register.
Location: Lake Austin Center (LAC), 3001 Lake Austin Boulevard, 4th floor

Summary: Texas Newswatch to be broadcast
Description: Texas Newswatch is produced by the broadcast students in the UT College of Communication, School of Journalism. Tune in or log on to the live web stream to watch Texas Newswatch, Thursdays at 4:15 and 9 p.m. View live stream at http://journalism.utexas.edu/texasnewswatch. Rebroadcast shown at 9 p.m. on KVR-TV (channel 15, dorm; channel 16, UT Cable; channel 29, antenna).

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Learn more about the program and application process at this session. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Customer service is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This hands-on workshop provides strategies for delivering quality customer service by incorporating key improvisation principles. Participants learn how to put these techniques into practice through group activities and discussion. Presented by the Texas Interdisciplinary Plan.

Summary: CFO panel discussion held
Description: Chief financial officers Thomas P. Chambers of Apache, Niloy Shah of BP and Steven M. Sterin of Celanese participate in a panel discussion.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Texas Tribune reporter speaks on energy and the media
Description: Kate Galbraith, energy and environment reporter for the Texas Tribune, presents a talk titled "Energy in Media: A Journalist's Perspective on Covering Energy" at this week's UT Energy Symposium. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Entrepreneurship & Leadership in Real Estate panel slated
Description: The Real Estate Finance and Investment Center hosts a panel of industry experts on the topic of entrepreneurship and leadership in real estate. Register to attend at the link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Green Room 4.350

Summary: Solutions for heart disease look to science of the future
Description: Dr. Doris A. Taylor presents "Solutions for Heart Disease: The Science of the Future Today," a lecture on the discovery and application of new knowledge to improve patient care and prevent cardiovascular disease. She will share how building new cell- and organ-based solutions for severe diseases could impact millions of patients who are suffering or are at risk for these diseases.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Amphitheater 204

Summary: "Get Sexy, Get Consent" workshop held
Description: This workshop for new members of sororities and fraternities is a highly interactive one-hour program that examines how we negotiate sex and consent, boundaries and safety. Trained student facilitators act out scenes and monologues and improvise conversations with audience members about negotiating sex. Get Sexy. Get Consent. is inclusive of all romantic and sexual relationships from long-term to one-night-stand and is relevant for all genders and sexualities.

Summary: New Covenant Passover is topic of Bible study
Description: Attend a Bible study session to learn more about the New Covenant Passover.

Summary: National Stuttering Association holds open house, panel
Description:
Attend a panel discussion on the positive role of self-help/mutual aid in the stuttering community at the second annual open house event of the National Stuttering Association Austin Chapter. RSVP to Ryan McDermott at RyanMcDermott86@gmail.com.



This is an opportunity to learn about stuttering and become inspired by the stories of people who stutter. Since 2009, the National Stuttering Association (NSA) Austin Chapter has advanced the NSA's three-decade-long mission of bringing hope and empowerment to children and adults who stutter. By collaborating with the UT Speech and Hearing Clinic, we help to serve the needs of the stuttering community in Austin.

Summary: Panel discusses "What happened in election 2012?"
Description: Evan Smith, Sherri Greenberg, Vicky DeFrancesco Soto and Wayne Slater discuss questions that follow on the heels of Election Day 2012.

Summary: Israel advocate Neil Lazarus speaks
Description: Texans for Israel, Stand with Us, The David Project and CUFI present renowned British lecturer Neil Lazarus, who discusses how to advocate for Israel and why it is so important. Snacks and refreshments served.

Summary: Texas MSTC information session held
Description: Learn about the Master's of Science in Technology Commercialization (MSTC) at this information session. Session begins with a presentation by Program Director Dr. Gary Cadenhead, followed by alumni comments and an open forum for questions.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Coonference Center (ATT) 107

Summary: Paint. Play. Plié. is Classical Reinvention performance
Description: Classical Reinvention presents a thrilling collaboration among musicians, dancers and visual artists. Audience members are free to chat and walk around the FAB Gallery and are even encouraged to participate in the production by depicting it through visual media. Free food served.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), FAB Gallery 1.103

Summary: Award-winning memoirist Elva Treviño Hart lectures
Description: Elva Treviño Hart reads from her work. Hart's award-winning memoir, "Barefoot Heart," has been widely praised for its unflinching portrayal of childhood in a migrant family. Her latest book, "Simpáticas: San Miguel Stories," is a collection of short fiction that observes the lives of wealthy American tourists through the eyes of their Mexican maids.

Summary: Post-Election Autopsy hosted by Libertarian Longhorns
Description: Now that the election is over and everyone knows who the president will be in 2013, it's time to inspect the entrails and divine the future. Join Libertarian Longhorns for a discussion on the implications for the future.

Summary: Longhorn Wellness Club presents Nutrition 101 seminar
Description: Join the Wellness Club for Nutrition 101, featuring grocery shopping tips, facts about on-campus eating, healthy smoothie recipes and free smoothies and more.

Summary: Theta Nu Xi Multicultural Sorority holds info session
Description: Theta Nu Xi Sorority is active in shaping the community through ethics, diversity, leadership and more. Attend this information session to learn more about the organization and meet the current members.

Summary: Science Under the Stars topic is fluorescence in biology
Description: Science Under the Stars hosts "Light Bright: Fluorescence Lighting New Paths in Biology," a talk by Chintan Modi, who explores how scientists continue to find novel uses for biofluorescent and biochemiluminescent molecules to gain insight into the inner workings of biology and chemistry. Arrive early for refreshments and fun activities for kids of all ages.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Summary: Jackson Browne performs
Description: Jackson Browne performs, with special guest Sara Watkins. Browne has written and performed some of the most literate and moving songs in popular music and has defined a genre of songwriting charged with honesty, emotion and personal politics.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Department of French & Italian screens Molaioli's "The Jewel"
Description: Based on the true story of the bankruptcy of Italian company Parmalat, Andrea Molaioli's "Il gioiellino" ("The Jewel," 2011) is a dark morality tale about the deceptive gloss of high finance with thriller and dark comedic undertones. In Italian with English subtitles.

Summary: Higher Education Student Veteran Symposium slated
Description: The Office of the Dean of Students announces the first annual Higher Education Student Veteran Symposium, with topics geared toward faculty, staff and administrators. The goal is to promote a keen sense of awareness regarding student veteran experiences in higher education and thus foster responsiveness to the needs of this population. Outstanding student veteran Starr Corbin presents the keynote address.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: WRA seeks director for "Vagina Monologues"
Description: The Women's Resource Agency seeks applicants to direct this year's production of Eve Ensler's "Vagina Monologues." The student-run performance takes place March 21-23, this year featuring simultaneous performance in American Sign Language. Visit the link below or email danielle.corley@utexas.edu for an application. Deadline is Nov. 9, with interviews held Nov. 12.

Summary: Fall 2012 Poster Design Class announced
Description: The Poster Design Class covers poster content, design guidelines and timelines, as well as poster presentation know-how. All undergraduates at any stage in their research are welcome. RSVP by Nov. 7 to ugresearcher@utlists.utexas.edu.

Summary: Data in health promotion research is colloquium topic
Description: Attend a School of Nursing colloquium titled "Omaha System: A Tool for High Stakes Health Promotion Research," presented by Karen A. Monsen, PhD, RN, FAAN, assistant professor, University of Minnesota School of Nursing, and director, Omaha System Partnership for Knowledge Discovery and Health Care Quality.

Summary: Population Research Center hosts Claire Margerison Zilko
Description: Dr. Claire Margerison Zilko delivers a talk titled "Impacts of Economic Downturns on Maternal and Infant Health."

Summary: Climate Forum speaker discusses CO2 and weather data
Description:
Dr. Inez Fung, UC-Berkeley, presents a talk titled "CO2: Weather Data Assimilation." Fung studies the interactions between climate change and biogeochemical cycles. A question driving her research is how will atmospheric CO2 and climate co-evolve, and what can be done about it? 



She continues to analyze atmospheric, land and ocean observations pertinent to the carbon cycle, and to synthesize them in atmospheric transport models to infer how CO2 sources and sinks have been changing.
Location: Jackson Geological Sciences Building (JGB), Barrow Conference Room 4.102

Summary: The State of Black UT panel slated
Description:
The experiences of Black/African American students on The University of Texas at Austin campus have recently been in the spotlight following incidents of racism in the wake of the Fisher v. Texas Supreme Court hearing on affirmative action. The case, along with the glass ceiling of 5% for admission of African American students, invites a thoughtful conversation about the past, present and future state of Blacks at UT. 

 

Forum topics include:

- Campus Climate for African American students

- Fisher v. Texas case

- UT admissions and enrollment of African American students

- Black faculty/staff achievements & issues

- Black alumni past and present

- Why aren't there more Black graduate students at UT?

 

Moderated by Jonathan Sprinkles, CEO; Panelists include Marlen Whitley, JD; Dr. Choquette Hamilton; Dr. Edmund T. Gordon; Mr. Philemon Brown; Mr. Lonnie Fogle; Ms. Cortney Sanders; Mr. Michael Williams, Ms. Amber Chenevert.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Community organizers offer initial post-election briefing
Description: Attend a post-election briefing with community organizers and political professionals from Texas, who assess the 2012 election results, with a focus on participation among traditionally disenfranchised communities such as youth, Hispanics and African Americans. National political professionals and pollsters will teleconference in to provide an overview of how Texas fits into the national landscape.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), Fifth Floor Presentation Room 5.102

Summary: Crisis bargaining & domestic opposition discussed in talk
Description:
Why do democracies sometimes fight long, politically divisive wars that end poorly? Professor Philip Arena argues that electoral accountability, induced by party competition, sometimes promote this and other tragic outcomes. Electronic copies of Arena's paper are available from Scott Wolford, swolford@austin.utexas.edu.



Arena analyzes a bargaining model in which one state is conceived of as a unitary actor while the other consists of a government and an opposition that is motivated both by electoral ambition and concern for the national interest.

Summary: "Bloomsbury Reassessed" is a talk by Paul Levy
Description: Paul Levy discusses the Bloomsbury group. As recently as the 1960s, it was a rare week that went by without a media reference to this intellectual magic circle. Now, few educated people in Britain under 40 have heard of it and, apart from Virginia Woolf, hardly anyone can name any of its members. The Bloomsbury group seems uninteresting precisely because we have accepted their values as our own.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Prove it: Thesis statement workshop offered by UWC
Description: How do you go from evidence to argument? What parts make up a strong thesis statement? How does the thesis statement relate to the rest of the paper? Find out at this free workshop offered by the Undergraduate Writing Center.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC), Undergraduate Writing Center 211

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: QPOCA holds panel on trans & queer people of color
Description: Join Queer People of Color and Allies (QPOCA) for a discussion panel on issues affecting the TPOC (trans people of color) and QPOC (queer people of color) communities. The panel includes UT faculty and staff who are willing to speak out about these issues and seeking to "POC up" queer spaces and queer up POC spaces.

Summary: Annette Strauss Institute hosts 2012 election debriefing
Description: After the ballots have been cast and our political leaders have been named, the Annette Strauss Institute for Civic Life's New Politics Forum hosts a nonpartisan 2012 election debriefing, offering an insider's perspective on the election from campaign professionals, communication experts, scholars and members of the press.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), 300 W. Dean Keeton Street, 2nd-floor auditorium

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), third floor atrium

Summary: Art & Art History faculty exhibition opens with reception
Description: An opening reception is held for Part Two of the Faculty Exhibition Series, the second installment in a three-part exhibition occurring over three years that features a selection of work by faculty artists in the Studio Art, Art History, Art Education and Design divisions of the university's Department of Art & Art History.

Summary: Tower lights & other events mark Human Ecology centennial
Description: The School of Human Ecology celebrates its centennial with campus-wide events. On Friday, Nov. 9, the Tower at The University of Texas at Austin will be lit orange with the number "100." View the link below for details on all centennial celebrations and events.

Summary: Texas men's basketball plays Fresno State
Description: Texas men's basketball hosts the Fresno State Bulldogs in the first game of the season.

Summary: Eddie Vedder performs with guest Glen Hansard
Description: Eddie Vedder performs at Bass Concert Hall with guest Glen Hansard. Vedder's solo album "Ukulele Songs" was nominated for the Best Folk Album Grammy.

Summary: KVRX student radio presents Fall Show
Description: KVRX 91.7 FM, Austin's student-run radio, hosts its Fall Show, a night of games, prizes, a fall-themed photo booth and live music by Bobby Jealousy, Rayon Beach, The Bad Lovers and Unknown Relatives. Learn more at the link below. This is an all ages event.

Summary: Daily Texan hosts kickoff countdown tailgate party
Description: Watch the game with Texas Student Media and enjoy free food and drinks provided by our sponsors. Event starts four hours prior to kickoff and continues through the UT game.

Summary: Academic Service Learning Day announced
Description: Join the Senate of College Councils in its first Academic Service Learning Day. Student volunteer opportunities include helping at an art lesson for seniors at the Maggie Johnson Nursing Home or volunteering with Keep Austin Beautiful. Sign up below. Contact lauren_mills@utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: School of Nursing tailgate announced
Description: The School of Nursing hosts its first-ever tailgate party prior to the Texas vs. Iowa State game. Kickoff is at 11 a.m. Come for fun, food and prizes.

Summary: Lone Star Clash 2 held
Description: Lone Star Clash 1 revolutionized the e-sports landscape and shocked the community with its impressive production quality, superior professionalism and unparalleled fan interaction. Join us for the incredible sequel: Lone Star Clash 2.
Location: The Marchesa Hall & Theater, 6406 I-35 Service Rd. #3100

Summary: UT Micro Farm holds workday
Description: Help start UT's first student-run sustainable farm by volunteering at the UT Micro Farm's second workday. Tools and supplies provided but additional construction tools welcome. All skill levels. Free breakfast served. Bring water and wear closed-toe shoes. Visit us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/UTMicroFarm.

Summary: Southwestern Marxism Conference announced
Description: The International Socialist Organization hosts the Southwestern Marxism Conference. Register now at: http://isoaustin.blogspot.com/p/texas-socialist-conference.html. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: ULI Deferred Action Clinic held
Description:
The University Leadership Initiative hosts its third clinic for the DACA (Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals) application. A subsequent clinic will be held on Nov. 17 for those who cannot attend this one. High school graduates are eligible. Reserve a spot at tinyurl.com/ULIDACAreserve. Or call 512-655-DACA (512-655-3222) from 8 a.m.-8 p.m. on weekdays and 8 a.m.-8 p.m. on weekends, or email uli.daca@gmail.com. To volunteer, visit tinyurl.com/ULIDACAvolunteer. 



Visit the University Leadership Initiative on Facebook at tinyurl.com/facebookULI. 



Follow us on Twitter at twitter.com/ULIDACA.
Location: 5800 E. Martin Luther King Jr. Blvd., 78721

Summary: Texas football takes on Iowa State
Description: The Longhorns take on the Iowa State Cyclones in Game 10 of the 2012 season.

Summary: Jhalak Bollywood dance competition comes to campus
Description: Hosted by the Indian Cultural Association at The University of Texas at Austin and DesiDanceTeams.com (DDT), Jhalak is the largest national Bollywood dance competition in the State of Texas, featuring collegiate teams from across the country. This year, Jhalak focuses on pure dance skill, without the frills.

Summary: Front & Center presents "We Are Yours" showcase
Description: Front & Center, a new performing and visual arts organizations, presents its first showcase, "We Are Yours." Doors open at 5:30 p.m. Free food served.

Summary: Eid banquet sponsored by Pakistani Students Association
Description: The Texas Pakistani Students Association hosts an Eid banquet to celebrate the cultural significance of Eid in the lives of Muslims worldwide. Alumni, professionals and families from all over Austin are welcome to join the UT student body for great food and a wonderful evening.

Summary: Veterans' Day parade volunteers sought
Description: Join WarriorWorks to honor veterans in the Veterans' Day parade, beginning at 8 a.m. RSVP to Robin Sikes at sikes.robin@gmail.com. All are welcome. Hot-off-the-presses WarriorWorks t-shirts will be for sale that morning at $10 each and WarriorWorks will have a table at the Long Center in the afternoon.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Sunday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club for a Sunday sail on Lake Travis.  UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring a swimsuit, towel, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Blanton hosts public tour of "The Rules of Basketball"
Description: Basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures that feature the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Inclusive Leadership workshop announced
Description: Sorority and Fraternity Life's continuing series for new members of sororities and fraternities holds an Inclusive Leadership workshop. This training is designed to help participants develop inclusive leadership skills and equip them to work with a diverse group of people.

Summary: Eddie Vedder performs with guest Glen Hansard
Description: Eddie Vedder performs at Bass Concert Hall with guest Glen Hansard. Vedder's solo album "Ukulele Songs" was nominated for the Best Folk Album Grammy.

Summary: Rick Ross, Meek Mill and Wale perform at Erwin Center
Description: Maybach Music Group brings Rick Ross, Meek Mill and Wale to perform a headline set with special guest Machine Gun Kelly and host DJ Scream at the Frank Erwin Center.

Summary: UT Conjunto Ensemble performs for World Music Week
Description: The UT Conjunto Ensemble performs as part of World Music Week at the Butler School of Music (Nov. 11-14).
Location: Butler School of Music (MRH), Recital Studio 2.608

Summary: Texas Student Media's "Local Live" presents Levi Weaver
Description: KVRX and TSTV proudly present "Local Live." Be part of a live taping and TV/radio broadcast for solo artist Levi Weaver. The free concert with live audience taping includes food and refreshments. Wristbands are available from Thursday, Nov. 8, at 1 p.m. and all day Friday at HSM.

Summary: International Education Week announced
Description: UT Austin hosts its fourth annual International Education Week (IEW) through Nov. 16, promoting cross-cultural exchange and global understanding. Events include foreign and documentary film nights, country and culture workshops, music and dance performances, international trivia competitions and more.  Visit IEW's website below for the full schedule.

Summary: Coats of Love holiday coat drive announced
Description: Students for Equity and Diversity (SED) hosts Coats of Love, a holiday coat drive. Faculty, staff and students are encouraged to donate lightly used or new jackets, sweaters, blankets, coats, socks and scarves. Drop items at the location listed below for donation to the Multicultural Refugee Coalition.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 2.102

Summary: Veteran appreciation tabling event announced
Description: In recognition of Veterans Day, Student Veteran Services, a division of The Office of The Dean of Students, and the Student Veteran Association host a tabling event on the Six Pack for grassroots outreach including health-care benefit enrollment services and free goodies.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Huaiyin Lee
Description:
"Geopolitics, Fiscal Constitution, and Statecraft: The Qing Empire Revisited" is a talk by Dr. Huaiyin Li, Institute for Historical Studies fellow and professor of modern Chinese history at The University of Texas at Austin. Dr. Mark Metzler, associate professor of history and Asian studies at the University of Texas at Austin, responds.



Most recently, Li is the author of "Reinventing Modern China: Imagination and Authenticity in Chinese Historical Writing." His current project is tentatively titled "China Before the Rise: Maoist Economy and Politics Revisited."

Summary: Anthropologist discusses technology & traditional intimacy
Description: The Department of Anthropology welcomes Melissa Gregg, Gender and Cultural Studies, University of Sydney, presenting a talk titled "Ambient Companions." Gregg explores how online media platforms have transformed traditional avenues for intimacy.

Summary: Speaker Richard Nunan discusses the transgender gaze
Description: The Center for Women's & Gender Studies Speaker Series presents "What Is the Transgender Gaze? Identity Politics and Transgender Ambivalence at the Movies," a talk by Richard Nunan, College of Charleston.

Summary: Moscow-Texas Connections Program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session for the Moscow-Texas Connections Program, a Fulbright-Hays Group Project Abroad, offering a 10-week Russian language and culture summer program at the Higher School of Economics in Moscow, June 10-August 16. Open to students at a level of 2nd year and above. Cost to participants is only $200.  Application due Dec. 15.

Summary: Former U.S. Attorney General Ramsey Clark speaks
Description:
William Ramsey Clark, the 66th U.S. attorney general, delivers a lecture titled "From Civil Rights to Human Rights." Clark played an important role in the Johnson administration's civil rights agenda, including supervising the drafting of the 1968 Civil Rights Act, and later became a noted international human rights activist.  



The talk is co-presented the Bernard and Audre Rapoport Center for Human Rights and Justice and the William Wayne Justice Center for Public Interest Law. Cosponsors include the Public Interest Law Association, the Texas Journal for Civil Liberties & Civil Rights and the Thurgood Marshall Legal Society.

Summary: Rembrandt and the Jews is art history lecture topic
Description: Professor Shelley Perlove, University of Michigan, Dearborn, gives a talk on Rembrandt and the Jews as part of the Art History Lecture Series.

Summary: Study abroad in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Description: Attend an information session to learn more about study abroad in Brazil on the topic of the theory, history and politics of the African Diaspora in the Americas.

Summary: Bevonomics 302B presents Investing for Life
Description: Learn how to use investments to satisfy your financial goals.

Summary: Study Organic Chemistry II (CH 320N) in Spain
Description: Attend this information session to learn how you can take Organic Chemistry II (CH 320N) in Spain. Pizza and drinks provided.

Summary: Emergency preparedness is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides participants with the tools necessary to be a leader in campus emergency preparedness in cases of natural and man-made incidents. This is a multi-media workshop; discussion will be encouraged. Presented by the Office of Emergency Preparedness.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.



University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Final movie in Lars von Trier film series screened
Description: "Melancholia" (2011) is the most recent Lars von Trier movie and the last in the film series. In this beautiful picture poem and meditation on depression and the end of the world, Justine is an emotionally troubled newlywed whose sister Claire throws her a lavish wedding party as an impending apocalypse nears.

Summary: Callicarpa hosts opening for Bantam: How Big Is Small?
Description: Attend an opening reception for Bantam: How Big Is Small? This exhibition by Callicarpa Galleries explores ways in which small works can operate in big ways, negating our assumptions that a work's strength comes through its size.

Summary: Learn about Human Dimensions of Organizations master's
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is now open for enrollment in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences, and behavioral sciences.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Lone Star Room 3.208

Summary: "Switch": Documentary looks at our energy future
Description: In 2009, documentary filmmaker Harry Lynch and geologist Dr. Scott Tinker set out to make a film on our transition from the current fossil fuel-dominated energy system to a more diversified system. The goal was not to advocate for one technology over another, nor to suggest how the transition should happen. The result is "Switch."

Summary: Mises Circle reads "How an Economy Grows & Why It Doesn't"
Description: This week the Mises Circle dives into capital theory with Irwin Schiff's classic comic book, "How an Economy Grows and Why it Doesn't." This simple comic book provides key insights onto the importance of savings and capital in an economy and the troubles of distorting these factors. View the pdf here: http://freedom-school.com/money/how-an-economy-grows.pdf.

Summary: Mariachi Ensemble performs for World Music Week
Description: The Mariachi Ensemble performs as part of World Music Week at the Butler School of Music (Nov. 11-14).
Location: Butler School of Music (MRH), Recital Studio 2.608

Summary: Award-winning poet Matt Hart reads on campus
Description: The New Writers Project presents a reading and talk by 2012 visiting writer Matt Hart. Author of four acclaimed books of poetry, Hart is the poet-in-residence at the Art Academy of Cincinnati.

Summary: "Vagina Monologues" director application deadline extended
Description: The Women's Resource Agency seeks applicants to direct this year's production of Eve Ensler's "Vagina Monologues." The student-run performance takes place March 21-23, this year featuring simultaneous performance in American Sign Language. Visit the link below or email danielle.corley@utexas.edu for an application.

Summary: Orange Santa accepts donations during annual toy drive
Description:
Orange Santa seeks donations for its annual drive. Donated toys or gifts should be new, unwrapped and in original packing. Donations can be dropped at UT guard stations and parking garages on the main campus and at Pickle Research Campus. Wrapping paper, gift bags, ribbons and gift cards also accepted. Make monetary donations online the link below.  



Cash or checks can be received at the Office of University Events (MAI 22; phone Jill Rice at 512-471-7753).

Summary: Researchers seek users of online diabetes communities
Description: A group of researchers in the School of Information seeks participants for an interview study about how online diabetes communities are being used. Contact us at danresearch@utexas.edu. Your time will be compensated with a $20 Amazon gift card. This study has been approved by the IRB at UT-Austin and the IRB number is 2011-12-0036.
Location: UT Administration Building (UTA) 5.510 and 5.516, School of Information

Summary: One Million Bones: Art installation promotes social justice
Description: One Million Bones (OMB) is a national hands-on art project that was initiated by artist Naomi Natale in New Mexico to create awareness about the atrocities emerging from military conflict and humanitarian crises around the globe. The Academic Service-Learning program is proud to sponsor an art installation developed by Dr. Kara Hallmark's Visual Art Studies service-learning students in partnership with the One Million Bones project and Students Rebuild.

Summary: Liberal Arts Council presents "Oh the Places You'll Go!"
Description: Learn about study and work abroad from guests from major language departments at the university, the Study Abroad Office, Liberal Arts Career Services, international exchange students, as well as representatives from nonprofit organizations and recruiters looking to send people abroad. Free food served.

Summary: Hispanic Faculty/Staff Association hosts potluck meeting
Description:
Join the Hispanic Faculty/Staff Association for its November general meeting. The theme is "Giving Thanks / Dando Gracias." HFSA will provide the main dishes (turkey and ham) and asks members to provide side dishes, desserts and drinks to share in this family-style potluck.



Membership in the Hispanic Faculty/Staff Association (HFSA) is open to all faculty members and staff employed at least 20 hours per week at the University of Texas at Austin, regardless of religion, age, race or color, marital status, national origin, disability or sexual orientation.

Summary: Research plus Pizza presents Art Markman on Smart Thinking
Description: Dr. Art Markman, Department of Psychology, discusses the cognitive science research that led to his book "Smart Thinking," an action plan for thinking more effectively.

Summary: Fall 2012 Poster Design Class announced
Description: The Poster Design Class covers poster content, design guidelines and timelines, as well as poster presentation know-how. All undergraduates at any stage in their research are welcome. RSVP to ugresearcher@utlists.utexas.edu.

Summary: Durability of Yiddish in Argentina is topic of talk
Description: Professor Alan Astro, Trinity University, delivers a talk titled "The Durability of Yiddish in Argentina." Lunch provided.

Summary: Food Lab hosts official taste testing
Description: Come and taste the products of three enterprising food companies all for the wonderful price of nothing. Sign up at the link below and come be a food critic.

Summary: UT in Sydney info session held
Description: Kinesiology and Health Education majors are invited to learn about the new "UT in Sydney" exchange program from faculty, academic advisers and study abroad coordinators. In this unique two-part program, you will earn 16-20 hours of UT credit while exploring Australian sports culture.

Summary: Future of U.S. presence in the Persian Gulf assessed
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents a talk assessing the tuture of U.S. presence in the Persian Gulf by Caitlin Talmadge, assistant professor of political science and international affairs at George Washington University. Refreshments served.

Summary: International health & social policy research talk held
Description: Get an eye-opening look into the international side of the LBJ School's Center for Health and Social Policy as LBJ School professors Carolyn Heinrich, David Warner, Jane Lincove and Sam Richardson discuss their research on South Africa, the U.S.-Mexico border, sub-Saharan Africa and the UK, respectively. Bring a lunch; coffee, dessert and conversation provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Bob Dylan's "Last Thoughts on Woody Guthrie" is talk topic
Description: "Second Last Thoughts on Bob Dylan's 'Last Thoughts on Woody Guthrie'" is a talk by Tom Palaima, professor of Classics, The University of Texas at Austin. Palaima ponders two Dylan tributes to Guthrie and discusses the nature of a meeting between the two in 1961.

Summary: Strengthening innovative learning is theme of workshop
Description: Innovation can be learned. Critical to improving creativity is appreciating how to overcome habitual ways of thinking. Dr. Roberta Ness, MD, MPH, dean of the university's School of Public Health, provides a toolbox of techniques described in her book "Innovation Generation."

Summary: Avoiding Plagiarism class offered online
Description: This online session defines plagiarism and covers mistakes that can lead to plagiarism, strategies for avoiding these mistakes and practical techniques for using sources correctly. At class start time, click the link below. Select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." Special sessions of this class may also be arranged for UT groups or departments.
