Visit http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/index.html for information.

Summary: Peace Corps info session held
Description: Attend a Peace Corps informational session with the UT representative and guest returned volunteer. Learn about the mission of the Peace Corps, the volunteer experience and how to become a Peace Corps volunteer.

Summary: Cult of personality explored in sociologist's talk
Description: "Cult of Personality: Social Actors behind the Stage" is a talk by Adrian Popan, Department of Sociology. Popan identifies the causes and structural conditions that permit the development of cults of personality around state leaders in totalitarian societies.

Summary: Personality in workplace is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In a workshop offered to student employees of UT Austin, unravel the mysteries behind your coworkers' - and classmates' - quirky behavior by exploring personality types, Carl Jung and the theories behind the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. Become aware of your own personality type and the types of others, and explore how personality is expressed in the workplace.

Summary: TX Distinguished Faculty Lecture presents Ignacio Grossmann
Description: Dr. Ignacio Grossman of Carnegie-Mellon University presents a seminar titled "Discrete and Continuous Optimization Models for the Design and Operation of Sustainable and Robust Process Systems." He will provide an overview of recent applications in process systems engineering of new discrete and continuous optimization techniques.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.



University Extension (UEX) provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Compliance and ethics are S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Compliance and ethics are the topics of a workshop offered for students employed by UT Austin. Compliance and ethics programs are a standard practice in business. Learn the importance of these programs in the public and private sectors and how they got started. Presented by University Compliance Services.

Summary: International Travel 101 session held
Description:
This session, part of International Education Week, is open to anyone who is thinking of traveling abroad for the first time or needs a refresher on the ABCs of international travel. Contact Ellen Aoki at eaoki@austin.utexas.edu or Sejal Mehta at smehta@austin.utexas.edu.

 

Topics include:

- How to get a passport and/or visa

- How to buy a plane ticket, get through customs, deal with jet lag

- Ideas on how to save money for a future trip abroad

- Accessing money abroad and exchange rates

- What to pack, and more

Summary: Career Trends panel hosts reps from various fields
Description:
Have questions about supply chain management? The medical profession? Business analytics? Do you want to know what recruiters really want? Texas PSA hosts a panel of professionals from multiple fields (Dell, BP, BroadCom, Houston Methodist Hospital, Volt), who discuss their industries and answer your questions.



Panelists are:

Shahid Javed, chief procurement officer, North America Gas, BP



Aizaz Manzar, director of Worldwide Demand Planning, Dell



Asher Syed, Business Strategy & Analytics manager, Dell



Zafar Choudhury, technical and professional recruiter, Volt Technical Resources



Faisal Masud, M.D., critical care cardiology, associate professor, Cornell, Houston Methodist Hospital



Imran Baqai, principal engineer, BroadCom

Summary: Money Talks presents Bril Flint, angel investor
Description: Attend a presentation by Bril Flint, an active angel investor and the incoming chairman of the Central Texas Angel Network (CTAN). Prior to his investing, he was a successful corporate executive at highly entrepreneurial companies such as Apple, Dell, EMI-Capitol Music and Bain.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Human Rights Student Advisory Council meets
Description: The Human Rights Student Advisory Council meets, bringing together human rights organizations across campus.

Summary: KUT presents talk on Voyager spacecraft's Golden Record
Description: KUT presents "Defining Intelligence: The Golden Record Revisited," a talk with poet Tomas Morin and essayist/performer Elena Passarello, who are editing an anthology on the Voyager mission and assembling poetry, fiction, nonfiction and plays that respond to the content of this record and illustrate the intelligence and diversity of life on Earth. Limited seating.

Summary: Worldwide perceptions of Islam is IAS Round Table topic
Description: Mark your calendars for the International Affairs Society's 5th Round Table discussion, an official event of International Education Week. This biannual panel discussion features scholarly presentations, a Q&A and refreshments.

Summary: VAC presents screening of "Méliès"
Description: In conjunction with the Part Two: Department of Art and Art History Faculty Exhibition, Professor Teresa Hubbard presents the single-screen version of a recent video work, "Méliès," created in collaboration with Alexander Birchler. The video is the second installment in their trilogy exploring the social and physical sites of cinema.

Summary: "Texas Furniture" volume 2 book signing & reception held
Description:
Celebrate the release of the updated and expanded "Texas Furniture, Volume Two:

The Cabinetmakers and Their Work, 1840-1880" with a program, book signing and reception featuring authors Lonn Taylor and David B. Warren. A reception follows the lecture. RSVP to cah.rsvp@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-495-4369.

Summary: Diwali 2012 celebrated on Main Mall
Description: The Hindu Student's Association presents Diwali 2012, a fun-filled night of games and prizes, live entertainment and a fireworks show. Food available at reasonable prices.

Summary: "Out on the Front Lines" is talk by veteran & LGBT activist
Description: "Out on the Front Lines" is a speech by Lt. Dan Choi, Iraq War veteran and LGBT activist. Choi discusses his personal struggle for truth and acceptance in the military, as well as his continuing fight for LGBT rights and veterans' health. A Q&A session follows the lecture. Email              dsc@utlists.utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Amnesty International meeting held
Description: Human rights in Syria is the topic of this Amnesty International meeting.

Summary: Ayn Rand's Free Market Revolution is talk topic
Description: Don Watkins discusses Ayn Rand's Free Market Revolution. Traditionally, moral idealism has been on the side of those who want to expand government in the name of "the common good." Rand turned that on its head, placing moral idealism on the side of individualism and capitalism. Q&A follows the talk.

Summary: The Early Music Ensemble presents "Bach and Friends"
Description: The Early Music Ensemble presents "Bach & Friends." Travel through Germany's courts and chapels with the music of D. Buxtehude, G. Muffat and G.F. Handel. Experience two generations of the talented Bach family with works by Johann Sebastian and his son, Carl Philipp Emanuel.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Join the College of Education Tuition & Advisory Committee
Description:
Join the College of Education's College Tuition and Budget Advisory Committee (CTBAC). Applications are available at locations listed below and due by 5 p.m., Friday, Nov. 30. Applicants must be pursuing an undergraduate degree within the College of Education and committed to serving through May 2013. Email completed application to coed2013@gmail.com. Contact Michael

Ugeo Williams (mjw2455@austin.utexas.edu) with questions.



Late or incomplete applications will not be accepted. Include a one-page resume with your application. Applications should not exceed five pages in length.

Summary: Share the Warmth clothing drive announced
Description: As the cold weather is fast approaching, Austin families are bracing for another winter without warm clothes. Sigma Lambda Beta, Sigma Delta Lambda and UMOJA come together to help families in need. Drop off new or gently used shirts, shoes, belts, pants, sweaters and other warm items at our drop box.

Summary: Learn to use libraries' alerting services
Description: Stay current with newly published research in your area. Set up alerting services to notify you of new articles, and get journal tables of contents and search results delivered to your email inbox or RSS reader. This class is particularly useful to graduate students and faculty.

Summary: Women veterans' luncheon held
Description: In celebration of Veterans' Day, Student Veteran Services hosts a luncheon for women veterans at UT. Faculty, staff and students are all welcome. Networking lunch and reception opens at 11:30 a.m., followed by guest presentations. For more information, and to RSVP, contact Student Veteran Services at 512-471-5017 or via email.

Summary: Develop your design skills with iForty
Description: Campus administrative professionals are often asked to create newsletters, presentations, posters, flyers and event emails. This meeting focuses on developing design skills for a variety of media programs. RSVP to jstonerice@austin.utexas.edu by Tuesday, Nov. 13.

Summary: Public forum to address future of CMAS
Description: The Center for Mexican American Studies hosts a public forum addressing the future role of the center in the College of Liberal Arts and the university. Dean Randy Diehl of the College of Liberal Arts is scheduled to attend and participate. A Q&A session will follow.

Summary: Celebrate plans to bring ethical apparel to UT
Description: The University Co-op will soon be offering UT apparel from Alta Gracia, the only collegiate clothing factory that provides its workers with a living wage and protects their human and legal rights. Come out to show your support and enjoy free cookies and cake.
Location: In front of the UT Co-op (2246 Guadalupe)

Summary: Learn to use maps with your research
Description: Learn how to incorporate maps into your research without having to learn GIS.

Summary: ClicaBrasil uses technology to teach language and culture
Description: Vivian Flanzer discusses the ClicaBrasil website, developed for intermediate-level learners of Portuguese. Its lessons integrate reading, writing, listening and reading comprehension, grammar, vocabulary, oral communication and cultural activities. Visit http://www.laits.utexas.edu/clicabrasil/.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Lone Star Room 3.208

Summary: Connected history of Safavid Iran & Mughal India discussed
Description: "The Monarch as Saint: A Connected History of Safavid Iran and Mughal India" is a lecture by A. Azfar Moin, assistant professor of history, Southern Methodist University.

Summary: Bevonomics 305 topic is employee benefits
Description: Learn about 401(k) plans and other benefits your future employer may offer.

Summary: Roundtable reflects on Brazil's Estado Novo (1937-1945)
Description: November 2012 marks the 75th anniversary of the advent of the Vargas dictatorship, the Estado Novo, widely seen as a formative moment in the history of twentieth-century Brazil. This roundtable discussion and lecture bring together political scientists and historians to assess the impact of the Vargas dictatorship on Brazilian politics and society and its historical legacy.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: Funding study abroad is meeting topic
Description: In celebration of International Education Week, attend this meeting to learn about how to fund a summer, semester or year abroad.

Summary: Peace Corps information session held
Description: Attend an informational session about the Peace Corps with the UT representative and a guest returned volunteer. Learn about the Peace Corps mission, the volunteer experience and how you can land the toughest job you'll ever love.

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Learn more about the program and application process at this session. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Workplace safety is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In this workshop, participants become familiar with basic worker safety concepts, learn situational awareness strategies and learn about the important legal protections afforded to employees and what to do in the event of a work injury. Presented by Human Resource Services - HealthPoint.

Summary: Learn about study abroad in Latin America
Description: Attend an information session to learn about study abroad programs in Latin America, from semester-long exchange programs that promote holistic language immersion in Chile, Argentina and Peru, to more specialized programs of study of indigenous history.

Summary: Archaeology Field School announces summer 2013 program
Description:
Attend an information session about the faculty-led 2013 summer archaeological field school in the north of Portugal. 

Information about the course, living arrangements, trips and financial aid to be discussed.

Summary: Discrimination basics to be topic of S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop provides a guide to policies, rights and resources that empower the employee in the workplace. Review policies in the areas of nondiscrimination, sex discrimination and sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, consensual relationships and disability accommodations. Presented by the Office of Institutional Equity.

Summary: Leadership Series Workshop held
Description: The Leadership Series is a series of workshops designed to develop individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations. Workshops are held twice a month in the fall and spring semesters.

Summary: WTS hosts Preparing for the Job Market event
Description: The Women's Transport Service (WTS) presents tips for finding a job, interviewing and resumes from professional panelists. Attendees can bring a resume to be reviewed by one of our professional members. WTS is an international organization dedicated to the advancement of women in the transportation industry.

Summary: Intel gaming system, WBB autographs featured at pre-game event
Description:
The women's basketball team signs autographs and Intel showcases its new gaming product at the pre-game event for Texas volleyball vs. Texas Tech. 



The showcase includes gaming kiosks, a cat walk and Ultrabooks for fans to try out, as well as free giveaways and the raffling of one Ultrabook and one XBOX.

Summary: "A Stranger of Mine": Japanese film screened
Description: Attend a screening of the popular contemporary Japanese 35 mm film "A Stranger of Mine" (dir. Uchida Kenji, 2004), the interlocking story of one night in the lives of five lost souls in Tokyo - two lovers, an ex-wife, a private eye and a mob boss - that includes extortion plots, a stack of missing money and a gang of angry yakuza.

Summary: Psychology graduate student panel held
Description: Women in Psychology and Psi Chi present their annual graduate student panel, featuring students from clinical, counseling, developmental, social and neuroscience, followed by an open Q&A session. All undergrads welcome. Food and drinks provided.

Summary: Gateway to Mexico presents study abroad opportunities
Description: Learn about two new and exciting study abroad opportunities in Mexico. Presentation includes health and safety information, courses for various majors, financial aid information and much more.

Summary: "Art from the Streets: The Movie" to be screened
Description: "Art from the Streets: The Movie" is a documentary by Layton Blaylock about an Austin program that helps homeless people create art and then sell it in a once-a-year exhibition. The film is funny, sad, shocking and emotional, a home-run that puts a human face on homelessness.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theater

Summary: Center for Students in Recovery presents New Member Series
Description: As part of Sorority and Fraternity Life's New Member Series, students and staff from the Center for Students in Recovery (CSR) talk about the various programs, resources and activities offered by CSR. If you have a friend who you suspect is struggling with substance abuse, this is a great opportunity for you to learn more about how you can get them the help they might need.

Summary: World Trivia Night tournament announced
Description: At World Trivia Night, teams of five compete for prizes. Bonus points awarded to teams dressed in costume. Visit our website to register your team. This event is part of International Week.

Summary: Ancestral Encounter celebrates indigenous roots
Description: Ancestral Encounter / Encuentro Ancestral: Recognizing, Remembering and Reclaiming Our Indigenous Roots is a cultural evening celebrating Indigenous Heritage and Native Heritage Month. Performers from Danza Mexica/Azteca featured.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays Texas Tech
Description: Texas volleyball faces the Texas Tech Red Raiders in a Big 12 matchup. Check out the Hoodie Bundle Pack: $15 bundle pack that includes one general admission ticket and one Longhorns hooded sweatshirt (to be picked up at the match, size and quantity based on availability).

Summary: Hispanic Caribbean Ensemble performs for World Music Week
Description: The UT Caribbean Ensemble, featuring music of the Hispanic Caribbean, performs as part of World Music Week at the Butler School of Music (Nov. 11-14).

Summary: Confessions of a Recovering Skinhead presented by ADL
Description: "Confessions of a Recovering Skinhead" is presented at a special live-stream viewing of the ADL National Event from Chicago, welcoming reformed skinhead Frank Meeink, who became a skinhead at the age of 13. Meeink discusses his work with domestic hate groups and his eventual redemption and continued work with the ADL nationwide. A discussion follows with free pizza served. RVSP to Jordan at JWeber@ADL.org.
Location: Texas Hillel, 2105 San Antonio Street, corner of 21st and San Antonio

Summary: From UT to Evin Prison: Case of Omid Kokabee discussed
Description: Omid Kokabee, a UT physics Ph.D. student, was arrested during a family visit to Iran and sentenced to 10 years in prison without due process. Drs. Arash & Kamiar Alaei, recently released from the same prison, discuss the details of their shared experiences with Kokabee. The Alaei brothers are internationally recognized champions of health and human rights. View a petition for Kokabee here below.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Evening with Frank Rich and Fran Lebowitz announced
Description: Just a week after the 2012 presidential election, Texas Performing Arts presents a compelling "State of the Union" conversation with two of America's most respected writers and social commentators, Frank Rich and Fran Lebowitz.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" comes to UT stage
Description: Neil LaBute's play takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Finding Funding class offered
Description: Learn how to find grants, scholarships and other funding sources. This class focuses on using online sources, including funding databases, and government agency, foundation and society websites. Students also learn how to set up a personalized alerting service to learn of new opportunities as they arise. This class is especially useful for graduate students and faculty.

Summary: America Recycles Day announced
Description:
The Campus Environmental Center celebrates America Recycles Day with a recycling drive for electronics,

plastic bags and glass, along with free prizes and games. Learn how to reduce your waste and pledge to increase your recycling.

Summary: Policy center director discusses immigration system
Description:
Mary Giovagnoli, director of the Immigration Policy Center at the American Immigration Council in Washington, D.C., delivers the School of Social Work Dean Jack Otis Social Problem and Social Policy Lecture, titled "Beyond Immigration: Why a Dysfunctional Immigration System Hurts All Americans; Why All Americans Must Contribute to a Solution."



In her presentation, Giovagnoli provides an overview of current immigration politics (including a postelection analysis of what's next for immigration) and discusses the role of the social sciences in shaping the debate. She will engage the audience in a discussion of how the work we do in our everyday lives translates into important data that can drive policy discussions and change the hearts and minds of Congress and other policymakers.



Prior to joining the Immigration Policy Center in 2009, Giovagnoli was the senior director of policy for the National Immigration Forum. 



The late Dr. Jack Otis (1923-2010) established the Dean Jack Otis Social Problem and Social Policy Endowed Lecture series to inspire more academic attention to current social problems. Otis was a dean (1965-1977) and a professor (1978-1993) at the School of Social Work, The University of Texas at Austin.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Enforced determinism is topic of Computer Science lecture
Description: UTCS Colloquia presents a talk by Bryan Ford of Yale University, "Enforced Determinism: What Is It, How Practical Is It, and What's It Good For?"

Summary: Black Faculty and Staff Association meets
Description: The monthly BFSA meeting features current campus topics, a guest presentation and committee updates.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Free Retirement Guidance Series offered
Description: Attend a seminar entitled "Building Your Retirement Roadmap," with a representative from Fidelity, a UT System authorized retirement program provider. In this informative seminar, learn how to plan for your retirement, begin saving, reduce your debt while saving and maximize tax advantaged saving opportunities.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: UT Libraries class covers Advanced EndNote software
Description: This class covers Advanced EndNote features such as modifying output styles, creating subject bibliographies, using connection files and more. Attendees should have taken "Introduction to EndNote" or be familiar with the basics of EndNote.

Summary: Landmarks public art tour held
Description: Join Landmarks docents for an insightful and conversational walking tour of Landmarks public art projects located throughout the main campus. The tour features the current Landmarks Video project, Bruce and Norman Yonemoto's "Vault." Contact Landmarks Education Coordinator Taylor Browning at taylor.browning@austin.utexas.edu for more information.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall lobby

Summary: BE Global information session held
Description: This International Education Week, attend an information session to learn about the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Application deadline is Dec. 1. Prizes will be given out at this event.

Summary: Blanton's Third Thursday is evening of art & activities
Description:
Join the Blanton for Third Thursday. Enjoy a slice of pizza and beverage at the Blanton Cafe. Evening includes Yoga in the Galleries (6:30 p.m., space limited), 

Blanton Book Club (7 p.m.) and Public Tour (7:30 p.m.).



Free Thursdays and Third Thursdays are supported in part by the Austin Community Foundation.

Summary: New York Seminar arts administration info session held
Description:
Looking for a career in arts administration for the performing or visual arts? Attend this information session on the New York Seminar trip to New York City from March 11-13. The NY Seminar connects students with key professionals and alumni in arts administration. Visit our Facebook event here: 

http://www.facebook.com/events/110005175828155/.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: Study and work with an NGO in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil
Description: Attend an information session on courses in Rio de Janeiro taught by Professor João Costa Vargas, Department of Anthropology. Students in this program also volunteer with CRIOLA, a Brazilian nongovernmental organization (NGO) focusing on the support of Afro-Brazilian women. Volunteer positions vary but give students the opportunity to interact with the CRIOLA community.

Summary: Master of science in finance program hosts info session
Description: Learn about the master of science in finance offered by the Department of Finance in the McCombs School of Business, designed for students from a wide variety of backgrounds, including liberal arts, natural sciences, engineering and business. No previous work experience is required. Meeting features snacks and prizes.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.

Summary: Curators' tour of "I Have Seen the Future" held at HRC
Description:
Cathy Henderson, associate director for exhibitions, and Helen Baer, associate curator of performing arts, lead a tour of the exhibition "I Have Seen the Future: Norman Bel Geddes Designs America."



Bel Geddes (1893-1958) was an innovative stage and industrial designer, futurist and urban planner who, more than any designer of his era, created and promoted a dynamic vision of the future - streamlined, technocratic and optimistic. Bel Geddes popularized this vision through drawings, models and photographs of spectacular vehicles, buildings and products featured in his books "Horizons" and "Magic Motorways." His most notable effort was his Futurama display at the 1939-1940 New York World's Fair, which adopted the motto "I Have Seen the Future."

Summary: Liberal Arts Council presents study abroad panel
Description: Interested in studying abroad? Hear about the travel and study adventures of former study abroad students at this Liberal Arts Council event.

Summary: Local imam shares insights on the Prophet Muhammad (PBUH)
Description: Attend an introductory talk exploring the life, character and legacy of one of the most influential yet poorly understood personalities in history - Muhammad - with guest speaker Islam Mossaad, a UT alumnus and an imam at Austin's largest mosque. A Q&A, plus cookies, follows the talk.

Summary: HIV/AIDS Awareness Film Series presents "Call Me Kuchu"
Description: GlobeMed, Face AIDS and the Queer Student Alliance present the never before released award-winning film "Call Me Kuchu." Proceeds are to be donated to local and international organizations that are fighting HIV/AIDS. Baked goods sold.

Summary: Hurricane Sandy & voluntary charity is libertarians' topic
Description: Caitlyn Bates gives an informative presentation on the charitable response to Hurricane Sandy, highlighting how voluntary charity in general is more effective in providing a social safety net than government transfer programs. Register at this meeting for the Austin Students for Liberty Regional Conference taking place Saturday, Nov. 17.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Chucho Valdés Quintet performs
Description: The Chucho Valdés Quintet performs at Bass Concert Hall, featuring "the dean of Latin jazz," Valdés, piano; Yaroldy Abreu Robles, percussion; Dreiser Durruthy Bombalé, bata drums and vocals' Rodney Yllarza Barreto, drums; and Angel Gaston Joya Perellada, bass. An ArtesAméricas performance.

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" comes to UT stage
Description: This play by Neil LaBute takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: HealthPoint offers wellness screening for faculty, staff
Description: The HealthPoint Wellness Program has partnered with Wellness Inc., to offer the Wellness Screening Program for faculty and staff. Check cholesterol, glucose, triglycerides, blood pressure and body mass index. Learn more and register at the link below, or call  866-935-5462.
Location: Facilities Complex Building 1 (FC1), Training Room B&C

Summary: VSLC nonprofit volunteer nominations open now
Description: Each month, the Volunteer and Service Learning Center encourages local nonprofits to nominate an outstanding UT Austin student volunteer or student organization who has demonstrated exemplary community service. Visit the link below to submit your nomination.

Summary: Forum in the Business of Sports, Entertainment & Media held
Description: The MBA Sports, Entertainment & Media Association hosts the fourth annual Forum on Innovation & Entrepreneurship in Sports, Entertainment & Media, with featured speaker five-time Olympic gold medalist and UT alum Sanya Richards Ross. Breakfast and coffee provided. RSVP at link below. Send questions to Dan Amodio (daniel.amodio@mba13.mccombs.utexas.edu).

Summary: UTCS Colloquia presents Bryan Ford, Yale University
Description: Bryan Ford of Yale University gives a talk titled "Scalable Traffic Analysis Resistant Anonymity in Dissent," sponsored by UTCS Colloquia.

Summary: "Shadow of Greatness" Veterans' Week book signing held
Description: Graduates from the class of the 2003 Naval Academy hold a signing for their their book of short stories, "A Shadow of Greatness," which Tom Brokaw called a "must read for all Americans."

Summary: Gender Symposium talk examines secluded Indian poet
Description: "'I Am a Ruby Wrapped in a Rag': The Poetry of a Secluded Woman in Early 20th-Century India" is a talk by Professor Gail Minault on poet Zay Khay Sheen, or Zahida Khatun Sherwani (1894-1922), an accomplished poet who observed complete purdah, to the point of never leaving her family home in Aligarh district in northern India.

Summary: Ransom Center fellows' brown bag lunch held
Description:
Members of the university community are invited to learn about the work of Ransom Center research fellows during an informal lunchtime discussion. No RSVP is required, but seating is limited and will be provided on a first come, first served basis. Drinks and dessert provided. Learn more about the Ransom Center's research fellowships in the humanities, at the link below.



Fellows include Iryna Kuksa, Nottingham Trent University, 

Project: Modernist Scenography Reborn in 3D: A Study of Norman Bel Geddes; Randall McLeod, University of Toronto, Project: Bearing Type in Aldines; Printing the Aldine Aristotle, 1495-98; Pierre A. Walker, Salem State University, Project: The Complete Letters of Henry James.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Obesity, metabolism and cancer to be topic of talk
Description:
Stephen Hursting presents a talk titled "Obesity, Metabolism and Cancer: The Year in Review" as part of the ongoing speaker series in the Department of Nutritional Sciences.



Hursting is a professor and chair of the Department of Nutritional Sciences at The University of Texas at Austin. His research focuses on diet-gene interactions relevant to cancer prevention, particularly the molecular and hormonal mechanisms underlying energy balance-cancer associations.

Summary: UT Save a Life hosts bone marrow swabbing drive
Description: The university's first-ever campus-wide drive is meant to save lives affected by leukemia and other fatal illnesses. Participants can enter their DNA in the national bone marrow registry with a simple cheek swab. Donation is free and easy, so please come do your part in ending the fight against certain cancers and blood diseases.

Summary: NSF doctoral dissertation research workshop held
Description: Doctoral students and faculty advisers in the College of Liberal Arts are invited to attend a session on the National Science Foundation's (NSF) Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement Grant (DDRIG) for the 2012-2013 academic year.

Summary: William Janeway discusses legacy of John Maynard Keynes
Description: In assessing John Maynard Keynes' failure to drive economic policy in the 1930s, how relevant are his ideas today? How would Keynes himself have addressed government paralysis and the widespread fear that economic initiatives will undermine business confidence? To what extent do his economic policies remain relevant? Venture capital investor William Janeway addresses these questions and more.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Introductions and Conclusions writing workshop offered
Description: How do you start or end an essay? How do you avoid being repetitive in a conclusion? Attend the Introductions and Conclusions workshop at the Undergraduate Writing Center to find out more and work on your writing.

Summary: Summer abroad in Guatemala info session held
Description: Attend an information session for the "Culture, Diversity, and Education at Casa Herrera" summer abroad program in Antigua, Guatemala.

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Learn about study abroad in Bluefields, Nicaragua
Description: Attend an information session about the "Afro-Caribbean Politcs and Culture in Central America" summer abroad program in Bluefields, Nicaragua.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), third floor atrium

Summary: Caribbean Night 2012 comes to South Mall
Description: Join the Caribbean Students Association for a night of Caribbean culture that is both entertaining and educational. Enjoy performances and sample foods from throughout the region.

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents evening of arias
Description: Farid Chada, Chaz Nailor and students from the Butler School of Music perform popular arias from Italian and French operas.

Summary: VAC presents "Yet, By No Means": A night of projections
Description:
Center Space Project presents a night of projections with Sandy Carson and Emma Whelan, featuring found slides and Super 8 films from the 1950s, 60s and 70s. Collected from locations around the globe by Carson, these slides appear with selections from abandoned home movies reminiscent of the American Dream. 



Presented in conjunction with the exhibition "Yet, By No Means," on view at the VAC Nov. 16-Dec. 8.

Summary: Autism Speaks holds Zumbathon fund-raiser
Description: Ditch the workout and join the party at the Autism Speaks Zumbathon. This is a great way to try out Zumba, a combination of aerobic exercise and dance moves. Proceeds go to Autism Speaks science and advocacy organization. To RSVP for tickets, email autismspeaksulonghorn@yahoo.com.

Summary: UTG presents "Dead Man's Cell Phone"
Description: The University Theatre Guild presents "Dead Man's Cell Phone," written by Sarah Ruhl, directed by Chris Stevens. When a stranger answers a recently deceased man's cell phone, she launches herself into a journey exploring morality, redemption and the need to connect in a world obsessed with technology. Runs through Nov. 18; doors open at 6:30 p.m.

Summary: Japanese Association hosts Fall Festival
Description: Fall Festival is an annual event hosted by the Japanese Association, featuring performances, food, games and more.

Summary: Texas Sweethearts present Dream Date 2012
Description:
Texas Sweethearts is proud to present the 7th annual Dream Date live auction, benefiting our philanthropy, the BeHive Austin, an after-school program dedicated to providing a safe haven and academic support to underprivileged elementary-aged children. Dress is semi-formal.



Prizes to be auctioned include items from:

Oakley 

Lily Pulitzer

Crossfit

Plato's Closet

Camp Gladiator

Mama Fu's

Snap Kitchen

Footlocker

Bath & Body Works

Alamo Draft House

Bass Concert Hall Tickets

Doc's Backyard 

El Mercado

Kendra Scott

Ashley D Photography

Arbor Car Wash

Langford Market

Impeccable Pig

Mellow Mushroom

Staybridge Suites

Embassy Suites



All guests receive a FREE Dream Date 2012 t-shirt as well as free, unlimited appetizers and beverages.

Summary: The Longhorn Singers present "Shades of Broadway"
Description: Take a journey with the Longhorn Singers that explores the range of human emotion expressed in word, song and dance.

Summary: "The Scarlet Letter" comes to UT stage
Description:
Sin. Guilt. Judgment. Love. Protagonist Hester Prynne comes to the stage in a reimagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic tale, adapted by Sarah Saltwick

and directed by Steven Wilson. Runs through Dec. 7, including matinees.



Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Aerosmith performs with special guest Cheap Trick
Description: Iconic American rock band Aerosmith headlines an evening at the Frank Erwin Center with a guest appearance by quintessential eighties rockers Cheap Trick. The concert is held in conjunction with fan festivals planned around the Formula 1 United States Grand Prix.

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" comes to UT stage
Description: This play by Neil LaBute takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: Students for Liberty Austin Regional Conference announced
Description:
Join Students For Liberty for the 2012 Students For Liberty Austin Regional Conference. The day-long event features speakers in the libertarian movement, networking with other pro-liberty students, opportunities for jobs, internships, conferences and seminars. Register here: http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/2012AustinRC.



Visit the Facebook event here.

Summary: UT Micro Farm holds workday
Description: Help start UT's first student-run sustainable farm by volunteering at the UT Micro Farm's third workday. All skill levels. Tools and supplies provided but additional construction tools welcome. Free breakfast served. Bring water and wear closed-toe shoes. Visit us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/UTMicroFarm.

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents Work Party in Hecho Farm
Description:
Hecho Farm is a stage for the continued growth of artist Cruz Ortiz's lovesick alter ego Spaztek, as well as an exploration of the material, social and political possibilities of collaboration within an art education context. Join Ortiz for a free collaborative workshop on his "farm" followed by a BBQ lunch.

Contact Xochi Solis at xochisolis@utvac.org by Nov. 9 to reserve your spot.

Summary: Texas volleyball plays West Virginia
Description:
Texas volleyball faces the West Virginia Mountaineers. Donate to Orange Santa: bring a new, unwrapped toy to the match and receive a voucher for one free general admission ticket. Donations accepted on Gregory Gym plaza prior to the match.



Teacher Appreciation and Government Employee Appreciation offers $4 general admission, including guests. Call 512-232-3865; advance sale only, by Friday, Nov. 16, at noon.

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" matinee performed
Description: This play by Neil LaBute takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: Shape-note singing group meets
Description: Shape-note singing is one of America's oldest musical traditions, made unique by its striking, rough-hewn harmonies and participatory, amateur-oriented nature. Join UT's Shape-Note Singing student organization for an afternoon of communal singing from "The Sacred Harp." Beginners welcome; no musical experience necessary. Tunebooks provided.

Summary: Color for a Cause raises money for hurricane victims
Description: Help support Hurricane Sandy victims by participating in a color and water balloon war. Dry paint provided. All proceeds go to the American Red Cross.

Summary: Blanton Museum offers Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" comes to UT stage
Description: This play by Neil LaBute takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents Fall for Dance
Description:
The award-winning Dance Repertory Theatre ensemble returns to the stage in Fall for Dance, under the artistic direction of David Justin and Charles O. Anderson. The 

highlight of the concert features "Promenade," by Robert Battle, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, set to a discordant score by John Mackey. Runs through Dec. 1.

Summary: ISACO presents annual performing arts show
Description:
The Iranian Student Academic and Cultural Organization (ISACO) presents "Farhange Finglisi," a showcase celebrating Persian culture that includes dances, skits, poetry and a fashion show. 

Refreshments and Persian sweets served at intermission. 

Half of proceeds donated to Children of Persia, a charity helping those affected by the recent earthquake in East Azerbaijan.

Summary: Health Care Research Symposium posts call for proposals
Description: The McCombs School of Business is currently accepting extended abstracts for the fourth annual Health Care Research Symposium, Innovation in Health Care Delivery Systems: Focus on Social Issues, to be held April 11-12 at the AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center. Visit the link below for details. Deadline is Jan. 18. Contact Dr. Reuben McDaniel with questions at 512-471-9451 or reuben.mcdaniel@mccombs.utexas.edu.

Summary: "The Scarlet Letter" matinee performed
Description:
Sin. Guilt. Judgment. Love.

Protagonist Hester Prynne comes to the stage in a reimagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic tale, adapted by Sarah Saltwick

and directed by Steven Wilson. 

Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Dec. 7, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents Fall for Dance matinee
Description:
The award-winning Dance Repertory Theatre ensemble returns to the stage in Fall for Dance, under the artistic direction of David Justin and Charles O. Anderson. The 

highlight of the concert features "Promenade," by Robert Battle, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, set to a discordant score by John Mackey. Runs through Dec. 1.

Summary: "Some Girl(s)" matinee performed
Description: This play by Neil LaBute takes an unflinching look at the wake of destruction we leave behind us when we think we are "following our heart." "Some Girl(s)," directed by Jeremy Lee Cudd, includes adult language, sexual themes and situations. Seating is limited. Tell us you're coming and join the conversation at https://www.facebook.com/events/382630035148654/permalink/387840447960946/.

Summary: Post-performance discussion of "Scarlet Letter" held
Description: Audience members are invited to a post-performance discussion on the Department of Theatre and Dance's production of "The Scarlet Letter" with the playwright, director and members of the cast. "The Scarlet Letter" runs Nov. 16-Dec. 7 in the B. Iden Payne Theatre.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Great Organ Series presents Alan Morrison
Description: Alan Morrison performs on organ as part of the Great Organ Series at the Butler School of Music.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents Fall for Dance
Description:
The award-winning Dance Repertory Theatre ensemble returns to the stage in Fall for Dance, under the artistic direction of David Justin and Charles O. Anderson. The 

highlight of the concert features "Promenade," by Robert Battle, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, set to a discordant score by John Mackey. Runs through Dec. 1.

Summary: Apply for NAE Grand Challenges Scholars Program
Description: Students of all majors and all years are invited to apply for the Grand Challenges Scholars Program (GCSP), sponsored by the National Academy of Engineering (NAE). Learn more at http://www.engineeringchallenges.org/. Submit application via email to gcsp@engr.utexas.edu by Jan. 6.

Summary: Male cyclists needed for research study
Description: Male cyclists or regular spin class participants ages 30-39 needed for cycling study. Contact utexercisestudy@gmail.com for more information. Must be available for 3 two-hour sessions through Dec. 19.

Summary: Females sought for study on body image, eating
Description: Females with significant body image and/or eating concerns are sought to participate in a research study designed to help women feel better about their bodies. Some participants will attend 8 weekly meetings on campus. Must be in Austin and available for meetings over winter break. Contact TexasBodyProject@utexas.edu or 512-232-2334.

Summary: Scholar discusses Latin American feminisms & decoloniality
Description: Professor Claudia de Lima Costa challenges the notion put forth by academics and activists who claim the need to decolonize feminist knowledges.

Summary: Design Lecture Series presents Paul Elliman
Description: Paul Elliman presents a lecture titled "Of Laws and Songs and Behavior." Ellliman is a London-based designer/artist. Known for his work with a found typography of objects and industrial debris, he also follows the human voice through many of its social and technological guises, often imitating other languages and sounds of the city.

Summary: Texas Nutrition holds general meeting
Description: Join Texas Nutrition for its sixth meeting of the fall semester. UT Professor Lydia Steinman discusses container gardening. Food provided.

Summary: AID presents Affirmative Action in the Indian context
Description: The Association for India's Development (AID) presents a Let's Talk India forum, titled Affirmative Action in the Indian context. A series of short videos and documents will expose the audience to the issue of reservations in India and prompt discussion. Refreshments served.

Summary: Austrian capital theory is Mises Circle topic
Description: In a time of rampant Keynesianism and monetarism, perhaps one of the most illuminating contributions of the Austrian school is Austrian capital theory. Join the Mises Circle to discuss Pater Tenebrarum's article "The Production Structure." View the article here: http://www.acting-man.com/?p=10053.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together with one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: ChE Graduate Seminar Series presents Dr. Cato Laurencin
Description: Dr. Cato Laurencin discussed the unprecedented strides predicted for the next decade in regenerating musculoskeletal tissues, a move from an era of advanced prosthetics to what Laurencin terms regenerative engineering.

Summary: Study in Denmark information session held
Description: Learn about study abroad in Denmark. Find out why the Danes are considered the happiest people on Earth and what makes some of Denmark's greatest cities like Copenhagen and Aarhus so exciting.

Summary: Art historian discusses Brazilian art under dictatorship
Description:
The Art History Lecture Series presents a talk by author Claudia Calirman titled "Brazilian Art Under Dictatorship: Antonio Manuel, Artur Barrio and Cildo Meireles," based on her book of the same title. Calirman explores Brazilian visual arts during the critical period between 1968 and 1975, the most repressive years of the military dictatorship that ruled Brazil for two decades. 



Calirman is assistant professor of art history, John Jay College of Criminal Justice, City University of New York.

Summary: Learn how to respond to an active shooter
Description:
University Future First Responders host UTPD Chief Robert Dahlstrom, who presents a short lecture on how to react in an active shooter situation.



University Future First Responders (UFFR) is a student organization open to any UT student with an interest in the first responder field or wishing to support first responders. For more information, contact John Horton, president, at john.horton@universityffr.com; Ryan Monsevalles, vice president, at ryan.monsevalles@universityffr.com; Lauren Jackson, secretary, at lauren.jackson@universityffr.com; Roberto Gonzalez, UTPD, roberto.gonzalez@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Global Feast presented by International Affairs Society
Description: Travel the world with the International Affairs Society at this international feast, featuring food, people and music. Global Feast was voted the Number 1 Campus Event last year. Includes all-you-can-eat international dinner and performances by some of the most talented student and cultural organizations on campus.

Summary: Flamenco for absolute beginners offered by Grupo Flor y Canto
Description: Grupo Flor y Canto offers a workshop on the sevillanas, an Andalusian folk dance from Sevilla, Spain. Danced in pairs at festivals and fairs throughout southern Spain, it is often taught as an introduction to flamenco. Contact grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com to pre-register. This is not a ballroom dance style. Required: Dress shoes for men, heels for ladies. Recommended: Shoes with nails, flamenco skirt for ladies.

Summary: Brazilian poet Salgado Maranhão gives reading
Description: Salgado Maranhão, one of Brazil's leading poets, gives a reading, accompanied by his American translator Alexis Levitin. Maranhão's collected poems, "The Color of the Word," won Brazil's highest poetry award in 2011. For more information, call 512-471-5787.

Summary: Women's basketball plays Jackson State
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Jackson State Tigers. Get the Duffle Bag Bundle Pack for $15: includes one reserved ticket and one Texas Athletics duffle bag. To purchase, call 512-232-3865; advance sale only by Monday, Nov. 19 at 4 p.m.

Summary: Students sought for survey including gift card raffle
Description:
Business, engineering, nursing and social work students are sought for a brief online survey on motivation and learning conducted by a Ph.D. candidate in social work. Participants are eligible to win a $50 Amazon gift card, to be awarded to six randomly chosen people. Contact Miki Tesh at tesh.miki@gmail.com for more information. Survey is at link below.



Survey consists of questions such as: "The most important thing for me in a course is to understand the content as thoroughly as possible." "I just want to avoid doing poorly in a class." "I feel likeam free to decide for myself how to learn in classes."

Summary: Daily Texan hosts kickoff countdown tailgate party
Description: Watch the game with Texas Student Media and enjoy free food and drinks provided by our sponsors. Event starts four hours prior to kickoff and continues through the UT game.

Summary: Texas football takes on TCU
Description: The Longhorns take on the TCU Horned Frogs in Game 11 of the 2012 season.

Summary: Bill O'Reilly and Dennis Miller appear at PAC
Description: Bill O'Reilly and Dennis Miller bring their "Bolder and Fresher Tour to Austin. O'Reilly is known as the godfather of "no spin" and in-your-face television, and Miller the king of references and rants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas women's basketball plays Central Connecticut State
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Central Connecticut State Blue Devils. Visit promo code page of TexasSports.com and enter ERWIN35 for general admission. Orange Santa offers free general admission ticket with donation of a new, unwrapped toy; game day only.

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" at Blanton Museum
Description: Basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures that feature the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Texas Energy Research Challenge seeks student abstracts
Description:
The third annual UT Energy Forum, a student-led conference exploring today's pressing energy challenges, seeks abstracts from students performing energy-related research to compete in our first annual research competition. First-place winner receives $3,000. Abstracts are due on a rolling basis by Monday, Dec. 31. Contact research@utenergyforum.com.



The UT Energy Forum takes place Feb. 21-22 in the Texas Union at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Mobile app usability testers needed
Description:
Researchers at the School of Information seek people who are currently in a long-distance relationship to test a mobile application. Subjects will answer questions about demographics, interactions while using the app and perceptions of the app. All participation is anonymous. Visit link below to fill out survey.

 

No identifying information will be collected. No questions will be asked about your name, location or workplaces, and all participants will be assured of privacy. Data will be used to report group trends only and the confidentiality of the data will also be ensured.

Summary: David Wayne Hammers, Kinesiology, presents doctoral work
Description: David Wayne Hammers, Ph.D. candidate with in the Department of Kinesiology and Health Education, presents his dissertation defense: "Influence of Insulin-like Growth Factor-I on Skeletal Muscle Regeneration."

Summary: UT Southwestern med school dean discusses admissions
Description: Kappa Rho Pre-Med Honor Society and Plan II Pre-Med Society present Dr. Angela Mihalic, associate dean  of UT Southwestern Medical School, as part of the Medical School Speaker Series. Mihalic addresses the application process, interviews and other information about the school.

Summary: Theatre for Dialogue performs Get Sexy, Get Consent
Description: Get Sexy. Get Consent. is a highly interactive one-hour program that examines how we negotiate sex and consent, boundaries and safety. Trained student facilitators act out scenes and monologues and improvise conversations with audience members about negotiating sex. The performance is inclusive of all romantic and sexual relationships, from long-term to one-night-stand, and relevant for all genders and sexualities.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne lobby

Summary: Hyperinflation and money demand are Mises Circle topics
Description:
Is our economy on the verge of hyperinflation? Join the Mises Circle to discuss Thorsten Polleit's "Hyperinflation, Money Demand, and the Crack-up Boom" for a look at how money can be destroyed overnight. Find the article here: http://mises.org/daily/4016.



Mises and Rothbard saw that government-controlled fiat money can endure inflation without destroying the money. That is, unless people believe the central bank will expand the money supply at ever-greater rates. At this point, the crack-up boom will unfold, and the fiat money is doomed to be worthless scraps.

Summary: Senate of College Councils offers Study Abroad Scholarship
Description: The Senate of College Councils Study Abroad Scholarship offers $1,000 to a qualified student. Deadline to apply is Friday, Nov. 30. Open to all students studying abroad beginning in spring 2013. Maymester study abroad students are not eligible. Applications can be found on the Global A$$ist website at the link below.

Summary: Apply for Texas Venture Labs Investment Competition
Description: Applications are being accepted through Dec. 17 for the 2013 Texas Venture Labs Investment Competition (TVLIC). Current UT graduate students who are considering starting a business are eligible to compete for $10,000 in cash prizes and automatic acceptance into the Global VLIC, held in May. Visit the link below to learn more, or attend an info session on Dec. 6, 6:30 p.m., in CBA 3.202.

Summary: Study on scholarly use of primary sources seeks subjects
Description: Researchers in the School of Information are looking for 5-10 participants to help us understand scholarly needs for keeping track of primary source materials. Participants must have experience with conducting research in the reading room of an archive. Contact the research team at star@ischool.utexas.edu.

Summary: Take part in #GivingTuesday on Nov. 27
Description: The Division of Continuing and Innovative Education has teamed with a national movement to create a day of giving back during the holiday season. #GivingTuesday aims to make the Tuesday after Thanksgiving a national day of giving. Take a moment on that day to donate to your favorite charity. Visit  - read more about this event....

Summary: Give a Spit Campaign supports national marrow registry
Description: Take five minutes to swab your cheeks so that you can be added to the national bone marrow registry. If you are a match for a cancer patient or someone with another life-threatening illness, you have the chance to save a life. Mark your calendar, bring friends and get swabbed.

Summary: Soles 4 Souls announces inaugural shoe drive
Description: Donate your unwanted shoes and ask friends and family to donate as well. All sizes, types and conditions accepted; bind shoes in pairs with laces or rubber bands. Soles 4 Souls will keep a tally of how many shoes you donate. The individual who donates the most will receive a $25 Amazon gift card. Find drop-off dates, times and locations at link below. Contact Josh at josh.shen@utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: Music at the Blanton presents Bach Cantata
Description: Musicians from UT's Butler School of Music perform Ach wie flüchtig, ach wie nichtig, BMV 26 in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: History of the War for Peace in Vietnam presented
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Hanoi's War: An International History of the War for Peace in Vietnam" with Lien-Hang T. Nguyen, associate professor at the University of Kentucky. Refreshments provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Political internships are info session topic
Description: Attend this information session and discussion to learn how to land your first political internship. Katie Romano, director for the Archer Center, and Julia Michaels, legislative research director for Project Vote Smart, discuss how you can become involved in policy and public service as a UT undergraduate.

Summary: Panel discusses Asian Americans and Fisher v. Texas
Description:
Asian Americans and Fisher v. Texas is to be discussed by mixed faculty and student panel moderated by featuring Dr. Edmund T. Gordon, chair, African and African Diaspora Studies. 



Panelists include Tu-Uyen Nguyen, classics and Asian American studies senior; Dr. Sharmila Rudrappa, sociology, Dr. Eric Tang, African & African Diaspora Studies, Center for Asian American Studies; and Dr. Kamala Visweswaran, anthropology, Center for Asian American Studies; Tony Vo, alumnus, Multicultural Engagement Center. Moderated by Dr. Edmund T. Gordon, chair, African and African Diaspora Studies.



RSVP on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/109916449174562/.

Summary: Texas Health Promotion Club meets
Description: Learn what the Texas Health Promotion Club has to offer. Upcoming events and volunteer opportunities are announced at each meeting. All majors welcome. Join us on Facebook at "Texas Health Promotion Club."

Summary: Human Rights Student Advisory Council meets
Description: Human Rights Student Advisory Council meetings bring together human rights organizations from across campus.

Summary: Practica Plática holds last meeting of the semester
Description: Join Practica Plática for its last meeting of the semester, an informal two-hour Spanish conversation session. Food and music provided. Participants with all levels of fluency welcome.

Summary: Shades of Skin: Guest speaker discusses discrimination
Description: The Oh So Fly Xi Chapter of Sigma Lambda Gamma and the Señoritas of the Eta Chapter of Sigma Lambda Alpha present distinguished speaker Dr. Nestor Rodriguez, who addresses discrimination with a focus on minorities, followed by a group discussion.

Summary: Faculty artists from "Part Two" lead discussion
Description: Join a discussion with faculty artists for fresh insight into their individual studio practices and their most recent bodies of work. Jack Risley, newly appointed chair of the Department of Art and Art History, moderates. Presented in conjunction with the "Part Two": Department of Art and Art History Faculty Exhibition.

Summary: Digital media director for the Obama campaign speaks
Description: Join Digital Media Director Teddy Goff fresh off the campaign trail to discuss the latest trends in social media and campaigns.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Bass Lecture Hall, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Grupo Flor y Canto teaches beginners' flamenco class
Description: Grupo Flor y Canto offers a beginners' workshop on the sevillanas, an Andalusian folk dance from Sevilla, Spain, often taught as an introduction to flamenco. Contact grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com to register. This is not a ballroom dance style. Required: dress shoes for men, heels for ladies. Recommended: shoes with nails, flamenco skirt for ladies.

Summary: Study hours hosted by sisters of Zeta Sigma Chi
Description: Come study with the sisters of Zeta Sigma Chi Multicultural Sorority. Food and drinks provided.

Summary: Texas men's basketball takes on Sam Houston State
Description: Texas men's basketball faces the Sam Houston State Bearkats.

Summary: Food Studies hosts final Educated Eater event of semester
Description: At this Educated Eater event, learn more about the Food Studies Project and get involved with mapping the UT food scene. Dessert provided.

Summary: Christian Faculty Network hosts Women's Prayer Group
Description: Join fellow women faculty and staff at a prayer group. All are welcome.

Summary: Free Retirement Guidance Series hosts seminar
Description:
Attend a seminar titled "Realize Your Retirement Dreams in Four Simple Steps," with a representative from Lincoln, a UT System authorized retirement program provider.



In this informative seminar, learn the four key behaviors associated with successful investing and get the information needed for you to set retirement income goals and strategies, make sure your savings last through retirement and more.

Summary: Panel examines NATO, the media & international intervention
Description: Three panelists discuss their perspectives on NATO, the media and international intervention. Participants are Ambassador Robert Hutchings, dean of the LBJ School; Steve Randolph, Ph.D., director of the Office of the Historian, U.S. State Department; and Dr. Mary C. Neuburger, associate professor and Chair, Department of Slavic and Eurasian Studies.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Mark K. Shriver chronicles father's success, Alzheimer's
Description: Mark K. Shriver, senior vice president of Save the Children's U.S. Programs, discusses his best-selling memoir, "A Good Man: Rediscovering My Father, Sargent Shriver," which chronicles the true successes of Sargent Shriver's life, as well as his struggles with Alzheimer's disease. Approved for social workers, LPC and LMFT for one CEU; contact ssw-profdev@utlists.utexas.edu.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Young women graduates and the workforce is talk topic
Description: Amanda Pouchot, founder of Levo League, speaks to young women about successfully entering the workforce upon graduating. Her talk will cover how to sell yourself through your elevator pitch, your resume and how to excel once you have a job. Contact madelinekeulen@gmail.com for more information, or visit http://content.levoleague.com/.

Summary: Ethical decision making is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: The workshop on ethical decision making is offered for students employed by UT Austin. Learn the definition of ethics and where ethics come from as we examine common ethical lapses and how to identify ethical temptations and compromises. Presented by University Compliance Services.

Summary: Bevonomics 103 topic is managing your student loans
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Scholar discusses co-existence and segregation in Haifa
Description:
Professor Kenneth Brown discusses social change over a century from Mandate Palestine to the present state of Israel, examining the social, economic and political consequences of the wars since 1948 for the changing urban population.



Originally from Los Angeles, Brown lives in Paris, where he is director and founding editor since 1991 of the biannual review Mediterraneans/Méditerranéennes. His book "The People of Salé: The Social History of a Moroccan City" is a classic in urban history.

Summary: FIMRC children's medical relief group meets
Description: Attend the fourth meeting of UT's chapter of the Foundation for International Children's Medical Relief, a student organization dedicated to providing access to medical care for children in developing countries around the world. This week, we welcome a speaker from Princeton Review and hold officer elections. Food provided.

Summary: Leadership Series Workshop held
Description:
Dr. Gage Paine, vice president for student affairs, University of Texas, speaks on leadership, which, as she reminds students, "is all about relationships." As an administrator who manages numerous offices on campus, Paine knows the importance relationships play in working with others. She introduces "The Leadership Dance" at this workshop.



The Leadership Series is a series of workshops designed to develop both individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations. Workshops are held twice a month in the fall and spring semesters.

Summary: "Dog in a Sidecar": Popular Japanese film screened
Description: Attend a screening of the popular contemporary Japanese 35 mm film "Dog in a Sidecar" (dir. Negishi Kichitaro, 2008), the heartwarming story of an unexpected friendship that grows between the subdued 10-year old Kaoru and her father's unconventional and irrepressible mistress.

Summary: New Member Series presents "How to Ace Your Finals"
Description: As part of Sorority and Fraternity Life's New Member Series, students and staff from the Sanger Learning Center talk about the various programs, resources and activities offered by the Center. They will also cover tried-and-true methods for making sure you do well on your final exams.

Summary: Interracial couples sought for discussion
Description: Kinsolving resident assistants are looking for interracial couples willing to discuss various aspects of their interracial relationship in a forum sponsored by the Division of Food and Housing Diversity program. Free food reception provided. Contact Chelsea Bryant (cmbryant@utexas.edu) or Dakota Batch (dylan.batch@utexas.edu).

Summary: Naadasudha hosts Indian classical music session, meeting
Description: Naadasudha, UT's Indian classical music student organization, holds weekly meetings and music sessions where students can improve their musical knowledge and skills though practice, lessons and lectures. Listeners also welcome.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Asian Culture Room 4.224

Summary: Novelist Paul La Farge discusses and reads from his work
Description: Paul La Farge is author of several acclaimed books, including his most recent novel, "Luminous Airplanes," which exists as a physical text as well as a companion online text that continues to evolve. Reviewers have compared his work to that of Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Jorge Luis Borges, categorizing him among "literary wizards" and "fantasists."

Summary: "On Beauty & Social Justice" is Humanities Institute talk
Description: The Humanities Institute at The University of Texas at Austin continues its lecture series on the theme of Public & Private with a talk by illustrious scholar Elaine Scarry. Dr. Scarry's talk, "On Beauty and Social Justice," focuses on how beauty presses individuals to be concerned with social justice. A discussion follows.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Jazz on the Patio hosted at Texas Union
Description: The Student Events Center's Music and Entertainment Committee hosts Jazz on the Patio, featuring local jazz band The East Side Dandies. Enjoy your pre-finals break with a free show and free coffee. Check us out on Facebook and Twitter for updates about the show and our committee: facebook.com/UTexasMEC and @UTexasMEC.

Summary: Take a break and play checkers at West Mall fountain
Description: Notice that giant crater as you're walking through campus to the Strip? Here is your chance to make use of it. Take a break from studying and play a game of checkers at the West Mall fountain. Learn more about the crater at #UTWestMall on Twitter, or tweet at @ashharre.

Summary: SoundBrain Lab seeks participants for paid study
Description: The SoundBrain Lab seeks participants for an experiment involving auditory learning. You may be eligible if you are a native English speaker with normal hearing. Contact the experimenter, Han-Gyol Yi, at gyol@utexas.edu for details.

Summary: Texas swimming & diving hosts national championship
Description: Texas men's and women's swimming and diving teams host the AT&T Short Course National Championships.
Location: Lee & Joe Jamail Texas Swimming Center

Summary: Texas Memorial Museum hosts Holiday Shopping Days
Description:
The Museum Store offers a diverse selection of fine jewelry, hand-crafted gifts, books, toys, shirts and other educational products. Extended shopping hours on Thursday, Nov. 29, are from 9 a.m.-7 p.m. Bring your own bag for a 25% discount; 20% if we provide bag.



Located in Texas Memorial Museum, we're open during regular Museum hours. Hours on Friday are 9 a.m.-4:45 p.m., Saturday, 10 a.m.-4:45 p.m. and Sunday, 1-4:45 p.m.

Summary: Former CEO, American Heart Association, discusses marketing
Description: Cass Wheeler, retired CEO of the American Heart Association (AHA), discusses AHA's marketing communication, including the "Go Red for Women Campaign."

Summary: Study Abroad financial aid & scholarship info session held
Description: Attend an information session on financial aid  and scholarships for students interested in Study Abroad Office faculty-led Maymester and summer programs.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Texas Photography Club holds free portrait day
Description: Celebrate the holidays with a free portrait from the Texas Photography Club. We are taking free portraits of UT students, faculty and staff in front of the Union Building on the West Mall. Check the Facebook event for updates and details.
Location: In front of the Texas Union Building (UNB), West Mall

Summary: Sen. Bill Bradley gives keynote on basketball & culture
Description: As part of the campus-wide celebration of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basketball," the Stark Center hosts a special symposium, "Basketball and American Culture," featuring a keynote address by Rhodes Scholar, Hall of Fame NBA player and former U.S. senator Bill Bradley. For maps and parking information for the Etta Harbin Alumni Center, visit http://texasexes.org/about/location.aspx.

Summary: Moscow Plus Program info session held
Description: Study first- and second-year Russian as well as a bridge course through the Moscow Plus study abroad program. Attend this information session to learn more. This program is open to students from all colleges and schools.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about study abroad programs in Spanish and Portuguese: Language and Culture in Salvador, Brazil; Spanish Literature in Antigua, Guatemala; and Spanish, Genetics & Engineering in Santander, Spain.

Summary: 1 Semester Startup Demo Day announced
Description: 1 Semester Startup invites you to Demo Day, showcasing the 10 undergraduate startups from our fall 2012 class. Learn more about 1 Semester Startup at http://1semesterstartup.com/.

Summary: Future of nuclear power is Energy Institute talk topic
Description: Professor Dale Klein, associate director of the Energy Institute, associate vice president for research at UT Austin and former chair of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, presents a talk titled "The Road Forward for Nuclear in the U.S. and Internationally." Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: American Studies Film Series screens "American Splendor"
Description: The American Studies Film Series hosts a free screening of Shari Springer Berman and Robert Pulcini's 2003 film "American Splendor," a humorous look at everyday life and the ever-illusory American Dream. American Studies doctoral student Andrew Friedenthal introduces the film with a brief talk on the place of comic books in our culture.

Summary: Study Abroad financial aid & scholarship info session held
Description: Attend an information session on financial aid  and scholarships for students interested in Study Abroad Office faculty-led Maymester and summer programs.

Summary: Turkish Film Series presents "Vavien"
Description: "Vavien" is a noir comedy that delicately tells the story of a small-town family in which the unhappy father is in financial crisis and hopelessly in love with a nightclub singer. Directed by Yagmu and Durul Taylan, 2010, 100 minutes. In Turkish with English subtitles.

Summary: Free market environmentalism is Libertarian Longhorns topic
Description: Libertarian Longhorns welcome Kelly Hackmann, who gives a presentation on free market environmentalism, arguing that property rights and markets are the best ways to protect our natural resources.

Summary: "The Scarlet Letter" comes to UT stage
Description:
Sin. Guilt. Judgment. Love. Protagonist Hester Prynne comes to the stage in a reimagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic tale, adapted by Sarah Saltwick

and directed by Steven Wilson. 

Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Dec. 7, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: ILIMAQ, a drum kit opera, premieres
Description: Texas Performing Arts presents the world premiere of ILIMAQ, a drum kit opera by John Luther Adams, featuring Glenn Kotche, percussion, and featuring On Fillmore with Darin Gray, bass.

Summary: Last Italian film of the semester screened
Description:
I Film del Circolo concludes its fall screenings with Rocco Papaleo's "Basilicata Coast to Coast" (2010), a musical road movie filmed against the backdrop of some of southern Italy's most beautiful countryside. In Italian with ITALIAN subtitles.



When accepted into a music festival, Nicola and his band decide that a 10-day cross-country journey on foot will act as a publicity-seeking, chemistry-building exercise from which the band can only emerge better off. Predictably, the end of the characters' odd journey from one sea to another turns out to be not as important as the journey itself, through which they will evolve and learn much about themselves and the meaning of their lives.

Summary: Theatre for Dialogue performs Get Sexy, Get Content
Description: Get Sexy. Get Consent. is a highly interactive one-hour program that examines how we negotiate sex and consent, boundaries and safety. Trained student facilitators act out scenes and monologues and improvise conversations with audience members about negotiating sex.
