The performance is inclusive of all romantic and sexual relationships, from long-term to one-night-stand, and relevant for all genders and sexualities.

Summary: Engineering mentors needed for Beyond Blackboards program
Description: Engineering student mentors are needed immediately to provide guidance and serve as role models to elementary and middle school students engaged in after-school innovation clubs and robotics experiences locally. Additional opportunities are available for spring and summer. Contact joules.webb@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-475-6845 for more information.

Summary: Upperclassmen: Apply to be a spring 2013 LEAP mentor
Description:
LEAP (Leadership, Education and Progress) is a leadership development program for aspiring student leaders, offered through the university's Leadership and

Ethics Institute, in the Office of the Dean of Students. Applications are due Friday, Nov. 30 at 5 p.m., and are submitted online. Visit the link below for information.

Summary: STATA/Texas Empirical Micro Conference 2012 held
Description: The Department of Economics hosts the STATA/Texas Empirical Micro Conference 2012, sponsored by STATA Corporation.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Wild Ideas shopping event comes to Wildflower Center
Description:
Find the perfect holiday gifts at the Wildflower Center's annual Wild Ideas shopping event. Get 20 percent off all merchandise, featuring handcrafted jewelry, paintings and glassware by a dozen local artists and artisans. Pottery and woven trunk shows take place Friday and Saturday, respectively, as well as book signings. Open Friday and Saturday, 9 a.m.-5 p.m., and Sunday, noon-5 p.m.



Co-sponsored by H-E-B and Classically Austin 89.5/KMFA.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: West Mall plant sale announced
Description: The Science Undergraduate Research Group (SURGe) hosts its monthly plant sale. This month's specials include pointsettias and Christmas cacti, along with grafted cacti, lotus bamboo, fire crotons, pink splash and more. SURGe raises money to promote undergraduate research and award fellowships to student researchers.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents James Berger
Description: Professor James Berger, Duke University, Department of Statistical Science, presents "The Reproducibility of Science: P-values and Multiplicity," a look at how Bayesian approaches to testing and multiplicity can solve the problems of replication.

Summary: Texas women's basketball plays Texas A&M Corpus Christi
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Texas A&M Corpus Christi Islanders. Learn about the Forty Acres Field Trip at www.40AcresFieldTrip.com.

Summary: Artist Kara Lynch presents visiting scholar talk
Description: Kara Lynch presents a talk titled "Miss Otis Regrets ... or, What We Can Learn from Laura Nelson." Lynch is a video, sound and performance artist.

Summary: Nutrition and tuberculosis are topics of talk
Description: Dave McMurray presents a talk titled "Nutrition and Tuberculosis" as part of the ongoing speaker series in the Department of Nutritional Sciences. McMurray is Regents professor in the Department of Microbial and Molecular Pathogenesis at the Texas A&M Health Science Center. His research examines the intersection of malnutrition and tuberculosis in the developing world.

Summary: McCraw Lecture presents Rosa Schnyer on acupuncture & pain
Description: Rosa Schnyer, D.A.O.M., clinical assistant professor in the School of Nursing at The University of Texas at Austin, gives a talk titled "Acupuncture in the Management of Chronic Pain."

Summary: Higher Education Leadership information session held
Description: Students and others interested in a master's or doctoral degree in Educational Administration at The University of Texas at Austin are invited to the Higher Education Leadership information session, featuring the Higher Education Administration Program (HEAP) and the Community College Leadership Program (CCLP) faculty, administrators and students. RSVP at link below.
Location: Sanchez Building (SZB), Cissy McDaniel Parker Deans Conference Room 238

Summary: Dan Raff discusses Oxford and Cambridge university presses
Description:
The Cambridge and Oxford university presses underwent

extensive restructuring in the late 1960s and 1970s with enduring consequences. Professor Daniel Raff discusses the radical reorganization of the two presses and their ramifications for the present.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Creating oral presentations with flair is workshop topic
Description: What makes an effective presentation? How do you incorporate visual elements? What kind of audience participation is appropriate? And how do you stop the butterflies in your stomach? Attend this UWC workshop to find out how to give engaging, terror-free presentations.

Summary: Lecture looks at the rise and fall of human running
Description: Daniel E. Lieberman, Ph.D., professor of human evolutionary biology at Harvard University, presents "The Rise and Fall of Human Running." Lieberman's interest in how and why the human body looks and functions as it does has led to groundbreaking research on various questions with implications for runners today.

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club's weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Works of Taylor Smith on display at reception
Description: FAB Gallery celebrates the end of the fall season with a solo exhibition of the works of BFA studio art student Taylor Smith. Enjoy free snacks, drinks and art at this opening reception.

Summary: B Scene Art Party hosted at Blanton Museum
Description:
If Gatsby had lived in Texas, he would have had his parties at the Blanton. Start your holidays Jazz Age-style, dancing the Lindy to Austin's ragtime band, White Ghost Shivers and enjoying beverages, snacks and exclusive after-hours access to the galleries. Blanton members have access to the private Member Lounge overlooking the atrium.



Media sponsor is CultureMap Austin.

Summary: Sigma Lambda Beta holds new member presentation
Description: The Eta Alpha chapter of Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity presents the newest additions to its brotherhood with an evening of entertainment, dances, a DJ and many more surprises.

Summary: "And Then Came Tango" is play for young audiences
Description: "And Then Came Tango," an interactive play for young audiences, runs through Dec. 2, including matinees. "And Then Came Tango" tells the heartwarming story of two male penguins, Roy and Silo, who are eager to become parents. Recommended for ages 6 and older. For more information, call 512-471-5793.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Hot Science - Cool Talks topic is the War on Cancer
Description:
Hot Science - Cool Talks presents: "The War on Cancer: 41 Years After Nixon's Declaration," with Dr. Mark Clanton, who discusses how our understanding, awareness and treatment of cancer has progressed over the years. Pre-lecture fair and teacher workshop begin at 5:45 p.m.



In 1971, U.S. President Richard Nixon declared war on cancer by signing the National Cancer Act. Have we identified new causes? What new breakthroughs lie just around the corner? Clanton, chief medical officer for the American Cancer Society High Plains Division provides insights on this war that most people never hear about.

Summary: Landmarks Video presents "Animal" by David Ellis
Description: Landmarks Video presents David Ellis's motion painting, "Animal" (2010). The nine-and-a-half-minute video features a kaleidoscope of spectacular creatures, landscapes and abstractions in varying colors and shapes interspersed with dramatic splashes of paint. On view throughout December.
Location: Art Building (ART), atrium, adjacent to Visual Arts Center galleries 23rd St. and San Jacinto

Summary: Asian American parents sought for focus group
Description: Researchers at the Department of Human Development, led by faculty member Su Yeong Kim, Ph.D., seek Asian American families for participation in a focus group on their parenting experiences. Contact aa.parenting@gmail.com or 512-666-8580 to set up an interview or to participate in the group. Study approved by The University of Texas at Austin Institutional Review Board.

Summary: Texas Quidditch hosts final round of house matches
Description: Texas Quidditch hosts the final round of house matches. Come support your favorite house and participate in a the Thunderstick sword fight hosted by Universal Pictures. Prizes and entertainment included.

Summary: Daniel Marcos Gomez, saxophone, presents doctoral recital
Description: Doctoral candidate Daniel Marcos Gomez, saxophone, performs his doctoral recital, featuring works by Alex Heppelmann, Juan Carlos Cobain, Kendra Kestner and Terry Riley, with participation by a consortium of other musicians.

Summary: "And Then Came Tango" is play for young audiences
Description: "And Then Came Tango," an interactive play for young audiences, runs through Dec. 2, including matinees. "And Then Came Tango" tells the heartwarming story of two male penguins, Roy and Silo, who are eager to become parents. Recommended for ages 6 and older. For more information, call 512-471-5793.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents Fall for Dance matinee
Description:
The award-winning Dance Repertory Theatre ensemble returns to the stage in Fall for Dance, under the artistic direction of David Justin and Charles O. Anderson. The 

highlight of the concert features "Promenade," by Robert Battle, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, set to a discordant score by John Mackey.

Summary: Blanton offers tour of "Into the Sacred City"
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to see a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: "And Then Came Tango" evening show presented
Description: "And Then Came Tango," an interactive play for young audiences, runs through Dec. 2, including matinees. "And Then Came Tango" tells the heartwarming story of two male penguins, Roy and Silo, who are eager to become parents. Recommended for ages 6 and older. For more information, call 512-471-5793.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents Fall for Dance
Description:
The award-winning Dance Repertory Theatre ensemble returns to the stage in Fall for Dance, under the artistic direction of David Justin and Charles O. Anderson. The 

highlight of the concert features "Promenade," by Robert Battle, artistic director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, set to a discordant score by John Mackey.

Summary: Cristina Pato and the Migrations Band perform
Description: After a show-stealing performance as the green-haired member of Yo-Yo Ma's Silk Road Ensemble, Cristina Pato returns to the Bass Concert Hall stage with her Migrations Band. Hailed by the BBC as "the Galician bagpipe diva," Pato fuses influences of Sephardic, Latin, jazz, pop and contemporary music to create a sound and vision that is energetic, flamboyant and virtuosic.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "The Scarlet Letter" matinee performed
Description:
Sin. Guilt. Judgment. Love.

Protagonist Hester Prynne comes to the stage in a reimagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic tale, adapted by Sarah Saltwick

and directed by Steven Wilson. 

Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Dec. 7, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "And Then Came Tango" early show performed
Description: "And Then Came Tango," an interactive play for young audiences, runs through Dec. 2, including matinees. "And Then Came Tango" tells the heartwarming story of two male penguins, Roy and Silo, who are eager to become parents. Recommended for ages 6 and older. For more information, call 512-471-5793.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures that feature the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: "Scarlet Letter" post-performance discussion held
Description: Audience members are invited to a post-performance discussion on the Department of Theatre and Dance's production of "The Scarlet Letter" with the playwright, director and members of the cast. "The Scarlet Letter" runs through Dec. 7.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "And Then Came Tango" is play for young audiences
Description: "And Then Came Tango," an interactive play for young audiences, runs through Dec. 2, including matinees. "And Then Came Tango" tells the heartwarming story of two male penguins, Roy and Silo, who are eager to become parents. Recommended for ages 6 and older. For more information, call 512-471-5793.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Attend broadcast taping with Megz Kelli & Dougie Do
Description: Be part the studio audience for Local Live's weekly on-air taping, this week featuring with Megz Kelli & Dougie Do. Local Live broadcasts feature interviews and performances with up-and-coming or national touring artists. Sample a video of our first taping with Eric and Olivia from "America's Got Talent" here and here.

Summary: Study Abroad Planning scholarship applications due Dec. 11
Description: Freshmen and sophomores, apply today for the chance to win $2,000-$3,000 to study abroad between fall 2013 and summer 2015. You select your program after you win the award. Awards reserved for first-generation students, UGS majors or students with a 2.0-2.5 GPA. The deadline to apply is Tuesday, Dec. 11.

Summary: Bhopal Die-In marks 28th anniversary of gas tragedy
Description: On the night of December 2, 1984, 27 tons of toxic gas escaped from the Union Carbide pesticide factory in Bhopal, India, killing 8,000 people within the next 72 hours. Some 25,000 have died to date, and at least 150,000 others suffer from debilitating exposure-related illnesses; 347 tons of hazardous waste still lie exposed at the site. Join AID India at a die-in to mark this tragic anniversary.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Stephen Porter
Description: "A New Benevolent Empire: Immigration and War Relief at the American Century's Dawn" is a talk by by Dr. Stephen Porter, author, Institute for Historical Studies fellow and assistant professor of history at the University of Cincinnati. Porter's primary interests revolve around international human rights.

Summary: "Keynes, the Man," is topic of Mises Circle
Description: Murray Rothbard called John Maynard Keynes an "arrogant, sadistic, power besotted bully" as well as a "deliberate and systemic liar." The Mises Circle gathers one last time this semester to discuss Rothbard's classic essay "Keynes, the Man." Read it here: http://mises.org/etexts/keynestheman.pdf or here: http://www.lewrockwell.com/rothbard/rothbard208.html.

Summary: Free Holiday Choral Concert held at Bass Concert Hall
Description: The Butler School of Music partners with Texas Performing Arts to host its annual Holiday Choral Concert, featuring the combined choirs of UT, Butler School instrumentalists and new faculty member baritone Donnie Ray Albert. Director of Choral Activities James Morrow leads the ensembles.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together under one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: Korean-born participants sought for perception study
Description: Native Korean speakers are sought for a perception study.  Qualified subjects were born in Korea, did not learn English from birth (meaning it was not spoken at home) but did learn English before the age of 12.  Study consists of one session of approximately one hour. Email utsoundbrain@gmail.com for details.

Summary: ChE Graduate Seminar presents Dr. Christopher Roberts
Description: Dr. Christopher Roberts, University of Delaware, presents a seminar titled "Biomolecular Engineering for Controlling Aggregation and Phase Behavior of Therapeutic Proteins."

Summary: Study abroad scholarships discussed at info session
Description: Representatives from the UT Study Abroad Office discuss scholarships available for first- and second-year students who wish to study abroad. Recipients have up to two academic years to select and participate in a UT-approved study abroad program. Deadline to apply is Dec. 11.

Summary: Business Healthcare Association meets with Sen. Kirk Watson
Description:
State Senator Kirk Watson discusses Proposition 1, UT Medical School, and what it means for future medical school applicants. Watson is a Texas attorney and politician from Austin. He served as Austin mayor from 1997 to 2001. 

Free pizza will be served.

Summary: HDO executive master's degree info session held
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP to http://sites.la.utexas.edu/hdo/rsvp-information-session/.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18, Liberal Arts Career Services Suite

Summary: Study hours hosted by sisters of Zeta Sigma Chi
Description: Come study with the sisters of Zeta Sigma Chi Multicultural Sorority. Food and drinks provided.

Summary: University Orchestra performs with Jun Seo, cello
Description: Join the UT University Orchestra for their second concert, featuring Jun Seo performing the beautiful and vibrant Haydn Cello Concerto No. 2. Liszt's "Les Preludes" and Copland's "Rodeo" will also be played.

Summary: Muscle & Grace photos celebrate physical culture & sport
Description:
Muscle & Grace highlights the Stark Collection's rich photography collections in an exhibition of more than 650 photographs, thematically arranged in 10 galleries, each highlighting a different aspect of sport and physical culture. Open Monday-Thursday 10 a.m.-6 p.m., Friday 10 a.m.-5 p.m. Call 512-471-0995 to schedule group visits or write jan@starkcenter.org.



Themes include Tom Landry and the Dallas Cowboys; bodybuilding; strongmen and strongwomen; Joe and Betty Weider; Arnold Schwarzenegger; Muscle Beach; Ben Crenshaw, Tom Kite and Harvey Penick from the world of golf. Of special note are the more than 150 photographs of New York photographer Stephen Green-Armytage who worked for Life and Sports Illustrated for many years.  



Visitors are also welcome to view the fine art in the Teresa Long Gallery at the Center.
Location: H.J. Lutcher Stark Center for Physical Culture and Sports

Summary: Annual Friends Of Orange Santa Sausage Sale announced
Description: Friends of Orange Santa hold a Sausage Wrap Sale to raise money for children's bicycles to be given as Orange Santa gifts.

Summary: Christian Faculty Network hosts Women's Prayer Group
Description: Join fellow women faculty and staff at a prayer meeting, the last of the fall semester. The group resumes in January. All are welcome.

Summary: Free Retirement Guidance Series seminar held
Description:
Attend a seminar titled "How AmDoing? Understanding and Achieving Your Long-Term Financial Goals," with a representative from TIAA-CREF, a UT System authorized retirement program provider.



In this informative seminar, learn how to take stock of where you are in preparing for a comfortable retirement, consider how you will fund the costs associated with retirement (healthcare, children's education, assisting aging parents, etc.) and how to create a strategy and plan of action to achieve your financial goals.

Summary: "Hanging Garden": Contemporary Japanese film screened
Description: Attend a screening of "Hanging Garden" (dir. Toyoda Toshiaki, 2005, 35 mm, subtitled), a drama about an unusual family that practices a fanatical brand of honesty with no taboo subjects, from sex to childbirth. Yet each of the family's members has a secret that gnaws away at them and finally explodes at a drunken birthday celebration.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: Islamophobia is topic of panel discussion
Description:
Islamophobia is the topic of a panel discussion with Dr. Snehal Shingavi, assistant professor of English and core faculty in Asian American Studies; Sheikh Umer, Nueces Mosque; and Lesley Varghese, executive director, Asian American Resource Center. Food served. RSVP on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/events/539160002779084/.



Additional sponsors are Network of Asian American Organizations, Indian American Coalition of Texas, Asian Desi Pacific Islander American Collective, Nueces Mosque - Student Chapter, Muslims Without Borders - Texas, Sikh Students Association, and Students for Equity and Diversity.

Summary: Secular Student Alliance speaker discusses Nativity scene
Description: The Secular Student Alliance hosts a talk by James H. Dee about the biblical accounts of the Nativity scene and their overall accuracy. A Q&A follows the talk.

Summary: "The Scarlet Letter" comes to UT stage
Description:
Sin. Guilt. Judgment. Love. Protagonist Hester Prynne comes to the stage in a reimagining of Nathaniel Hawthorne's classic tale, adapted by Sarah Saltwick

and directed by Steven Wilson. 

Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Dec. 7, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Spitshine Poetry CUPSI qualifier poetry slam
Description: UT Spitshine Poetry presents a poetry slam (i.e., competition), complete with rules, scores and judges. The top four poets at the end of the night win a spot on the Spitshine team that will represent UT Austin at the College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational (CUPSI) in New York this April. Follow the link below to learn more.

Summary: UT Libraries hold Food-for-Fines Amnesty Days
Description: Bring in nonperishable food items to some campus libraries and the library will waive $5 off of your outstanding library fines for each item you contribute. Some charges, like bills for lost items, are not eligible. Check with billing library for questions about a particular charge. For more information and a full list of libraries, visit the link below.

Summary: Global Holiday Bazaar held in Blanton Museum Shop
Description: Join the Blanton Museum Shop for a holiday celebration of ethical Fair Trade gifts and jewelry from around the globe.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), Museum Shop

Summary: Toxicology Seminar addresses endocrine disruption
Description: Scott Belcher, Ph.D., professor of pharmacology and cell biophysics at the University of Cincinnati College of Medicine, presents a seminar titled "Endocrine Disruption by Bisphenol A: Getting to the Heart of the Matter."

Summary: UT Harp Ensemble presents Eight Harps a-Playing
Description: Join the eight members of the UT Harp Ensemble for a noon-hour concert of holiday music.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 2.204

Summary: Restoration & Revelation exhibit is Perspectives talk topic
Description: Francesca Consagra, the new senior curator of prints and drawings and European paintings at the Blanton Museum, discusses the Restoration and Revelation exhibition as part of the Perspectives speaker series.

Summary: Applied Statistical Modeling fall colloquium held
Description: The Division of Statistics & Scientific Computation holds its Fall Research Colloquium for the Graduate Portfolio in Applied Statistical Modeling program, with doctoral students Kathryn Faulk (health education) and Neveen Shafeek Amin (sociology) presenting their research.

Summary: Students present "Energy Vignettes" video series
Description: At this week's UT Energy Symposium, students present "Energy Vignettes," a video-clip series on cutting-edge energy issues. Coffee and cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: China Care holds benefit night auditions
Description: China Care holds auditions for Benefit Night, a talent show that raises funds to sponsor surgeries for orphans in China. Performances range from singing to dancing to slam poetry. This year's event takes place Feb. 22. Sign up to audition at texaschinacare@gmail.com]texaschinacare@gmail.com. All talents welcome. For more information about China Care, visit http://www.txchinacare.org.

Summary: Gaza in the Public Eye faculty panel held
Description: A faculty panel addresses the latest bombardment of Gaza in a talk on the history and context of the occupation, the biases in media coverage of Operation Pillar of Cloud and an analysis of the geopolitical ramifications of this latest devastating incursion into Gaza. Panelists are Dr. Kamran Ali, anthropology; Dr. Snehal Shingavi, English/Asian American studies; and Dr. Robert Jensen, journalism.

Summary: Madrigal Broadway Revue auditions announced
Description: Do you like to act? Sing? Dance? Come audition for the Madrigal Broadway Revue, scheduled for Feb. 14 and 15 in the SAC Black Box. All auditioners should arrive by 9 p.m. and be prepared to sing one to three songs of their choice from the list on the Facebook event page linked below (at least 30 seconds from any song).

Summary: Stateless Order is Libertarian Longhorns meeting topic
Description:
Can law and security be provided in a stateless society? Join Libertarian Longhorns for the last meeting of the semester to learn more about the implications of law and order in the absence of the violent monopoly known as the State, drawing from great thinkers such as Gustave de Molinari, Murray Rothbard, Hans-Hermann Hoppe and David Friedman.



Discussion will be preceded by a presentation on Robert Murphy's classic essays from "Chaos Theory."

Summary: Authors Jim Crace & Anthony Giardina present reading
Description: Fall visiting professors at the Michener Center for Writers Jim Crace and Anthony Giardina read from their fiction.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Collaborative Artists meets
Description: Collaborative Artists meets on Fridays to relax, draw and collaborate on fun art projects and events. Email utcollabartists@gmail.com to receive our newsletter.

Summary: NCAA Volleyball Championship Austin Regional held
Description: The University of Texas will be one of four regional sites for the 2012 NCAA Volleyball tournament. Experience the excitement at Gregory Gym.  Tickets available now on TexasSports.com.

Summary: Global Holiday Bazaar held in Blanton Museum Shop
Description: Join the Blanton Museum Shop for a holiday celebration of ethical Fair Trade gifts and jewelry from around the globe.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), Museum Shop

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Brad Carlin
Description: The SSC Seminar Series presents Brad Carlin, University of Minnesota, Department of Biostatistics, giving a talk about using Bayesian adaptive methods for clinical trials.

Summary: Emergent hot topics in demography discussed at brown bag
Description: The fall 2012 Population Research Center brown bag speaker series concludes with Dr. Mark Hayward, Dr. Joseph Potter, Dr. Kelly Raley and Dr. Alex Weinreb - all faculty at UT Austin - discussing emergent hot topics in demography. (Please note the location has changed to Burdine Hall, Room 214)

Summary: University hosts "Songs of the Season" sing-along
Description: Songs of the Season is a holiday sing-along and a university tradition presented by the combined choir of the Butler School of Music. Enjoy a cup of hot chocolate and be part of the music. Orange Santa makes a rare appearance.

Summary: CMAS plática explores TV's "Ugly Betty"
Description:
Dr. Tanya González (Kansas State University) and Dr. Eliza Rodríguez y Gibson (Loyola Marymount University) explore the ways in which the television show "Ugly Betty" moved the audience beyond patriarchal modes of familia toward affective kinship networks through an analysis of Justin's coming out narrative and the networks of support that are available to this young gay character.



González and Rodríguez y Gibson are collaborating on a book-length project titled "The Word on Ugly Betty: Latina/o Cultural Politics on Television."
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Dr. Paul Dimeo discusses research on doping and sports
Description: Fulbright scholar Paul Dimeo of Stitling University in Scotland discusses his research on doping and sports and his experiences as a Fulbright faculty scholar in the Fall of 2012. Lecture attendees are invited to a reception for Dimeo and other members of the Fulbright community following the presentation.
Location: H.J. Lutcher Stark Center for Physical Culture and Sports

Summary: David Leal presents "Sherlock Holmes versus James Bond"
Description:
Two iconic British fictional characters have experienced recent rejuvenations at the box office - Sherlock Holmes as portrayed by Robert Downey Jr. and James Bond as interpreted by Daniel Craig. David Leal asks, "What does it mean that these characters may be the best-known British subjects - living, dead, or fictional - across the globe?"

 

Leal is associate professor of government and director of the Irma Rangel Public Policy Institute at the University of Texas at Austin.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Good Writing is Rewriting: Workshop offered at UWC
Description: Writing your paper is only the first step. Learn effective revision strategies, both for big-picture revision and editing at this Undergraduate Writing Center workshop.

Summary: Tavola Italiana meets
Description: The Italian Club holds the last Tavola of the semester, featuring a guest performance by Italian songwriter and singer Giulia Millanta.

Summary: Sociologist discusses research on Breitenau prison
Description:
In a talk titled "The Remains of a Prison: Fugitive Knowledge on the Wings of Red Arrows," Professor Avery Gordon discusses her archival research of historical traces left by those who were imprisoned in Breitenau, a correctional facility in Guxhagen, Germany, where poor or disobedient people were sent to be reformed into "good" workers and obedient citizens.



Gordon is a professor of sociology at the University of California, Santa Barbara and Visiting Faculty Fellow at the Centre for Research Architecture, Department of Visual Cultures, Goldsmiths

College, University of London.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: VAC presents Sound + Vision with Lesley Flanigan
Description: In collaboration with Church of the Friendly Ghost, an Austin collective dedicated to cultivating new media art and sound, the VAC presents an evening of music with New York-based artist Lesley Flanigan, who builds electroacoustic instruments that bridge the disciplines of object making, musical composition and performance.

Summary: 'Tis the Season holiday benefit concert announced
Description: 'Tis the Season is a holiday benefit concert performed by students, faculty and alumni of the Butler School of Music to raise money for Austin Kent, a 24-year-old diagnosed with testicular cancer. Kent will receive 100 percent of the proceeds raised. Join us for an uplifting program of classical and popular holiday tunes, from "Santa Baby" to "Carol of the Bells."

Summary: UT Symphony Orchestra performs
Description: UTSO presents its final concert of the semester, with  Blair Francis, graduate student and winner of the 2012 Butler School of Music Wind Concerto Competition, performing Carl Nielsen's Flute Concerto. Maestro Zimmermann leads the orchestra in a French program featuring Saint-Saens, Debussy and Ravel.

Summary: World Music Night features UT ensembles
Description: Celebrate the end of the semester at World Music Night, a night of music by the UT ethnomusicology ensembles, with performances by the Middle Eastern Ensemble Bereket, Mariachi Paredes, Tex-Mex Conjunto and Hispanic Caribbean Ensemble. Door donations will benefit the UT ensembles.
Location: "Pedro's Place," upstairs at the Clay Pit, 1601 Guadalupe

Summary: Queer Chorus at UT presents Fall 2012 Concert
Description: The Queer Chorus at UT presents its fall concert. A student-run organization, the group is in its second year of providing a safe community for LGBTQ and ally folk and creating change through music. Everyone is welcome. Email questions to queerchorus@gmail.com.

Summary: UT Micro Farm holds workday
Description: Help start UT's first student-run sustainable farm by volunteering at the UT Micro Farm. All skill levels needed. Tools and supplies provided but additional construction tools welcome. It's a potluck, so bring food to share. Bring water and wear closed-toe shoes. Visit us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/UTMicroFarm.

Summary: Saturday Morning Math Group explores counting techniques
Description: The Saturday Morning Math Group presents "Counting Techniques of a Soda Jerk," a talk led by Dr. Mark Maxwell of the UT Mathematics Department. This is the last meeting of the year, with special prize give-aways. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Snacks, beverages and ice-cream provided.

Summary: Christmas at Winedale Folklife Event announced
Description: The Winedale Folklife Christmas welcomes visitors of all ages to tour decorated historic homes, a stagecoach ride, and enjoy demonstrations of blacksmithing, quilting, weaving, spinning, lace making, pioneer encampment and more. Additional children's activities offered. Food and drinks available for sale. Contact 979-278-3530 or winedale@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: Winedale Theatre Barn, Round Top, TX

Summary: Tour "The Rules of Basketball" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Basketball's history and future come together in this juxtaposition of James Naismith's "Original Rules of Basket Ball" and the cutting-edge originality of contemporary artist Paul Pfeiffer's video sculptures that feature the spectacle of basketball.

Summary: Wildflower Center presents Luminations
Description: The Wildflower Center dresses up its gardens for the holidays with thousands of luminarias and lights. Attend this magical event featuring local performers, hands-on crafts indoors, a puppet show, Frosty the Snowman and much more. Also enjoy food and drinks from the cafe and specials and book signings in the gift shop. All canned goods donated to the Capital Area Food Bank.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: O' Holy Night presented by Innervisions Gospel Choir
Description: Innervisions Gospel Choir hosts its annual O' Holy Night Christmas concert and play, featuring a program of worship through song, dance and poetry. This year's theme is "Searching for Your Savior." Join us for worship and fellowship.

Summary: A Very Blanton Christmas features festive chamber music
Description: Butler School of Music string professors Brian Lewis and Roger Myers join their colleagues and students to present a program of Chamber Orchestra music chosen to celebrate the joy of the season.

Summary: Blanton Museum holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Textbook drive held for local AISD elementary school
Description: Donate your used textbooks and novels to HelpingHornz, a student service organization. Drop boxes located at PCL, GRE and SAC. Proceeds from resale of books will be used to purchase children's books and other educational items for children at Ridgetop Elementary School. Contact helpinghornz@gmail.com if have a large volume of items for pickup.
Location: Perry-Castaneda Library (PCL); Gregory Gym (GRE); and Student Activity Center (SAC), SG office suite

Summary: Participants needed for language study
Description: The Department of Linguistics seeks native speakers of English ages 18 and over to participate in a study of language processing. A session lasts approximately one hour and pays $10 per hour. Contact utlingpsych@gmail.com for more details.

Summary: Therapy dog study break held
Description: Visit the UFCU Student Learning Commons for a relaxing study break with two therapy dogs from Austin Dog Alliance. Ozzy and Buddy will be on hand to help you de-stress as you prepare for your finals. There will also be button-making, cute animal videos and snacks.

Summary: Yoga and Yogurt event reduces stress before tests
Description: Feeling a little worked up? Come to Yoga and Yogurt and reap the benefits. Bring a towel or exercise mat, a water bottle and wear comfortable clothes. Friends welcome. Email carmenfinch@utexas.edu for more information. Free food served.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description: Dr. Mike Raney, University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mraney@mail.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: "Why Bother? Engaging Our Changing City" takes place Dec. 10
Description:
The Annette Strauss Institute for Civic Life, KLRU-TV, Austin PBS and KUT 90.5 FM host a community conversation exploring the effects of changing demographics on civic participation in Central Texas. "Why Bother? Engaging Our Changing City" is the second event in a yearlong news and public dialogue series. 



KUT News reporter Joy Diaz hosts the event. Juan Castillo, senior reporter for the Austin American-Statesman, will share recent demographic trends in Austin from the 2010 census. Chantel Bottoms, senior research analyst at Community Action Network, will present voter turnout data for Travis County. Participants will then join small roundtable discussions to explore how to expand community engagement as the city continues to grow and change.



This community event is organized in partnership with Austin Community College's Center for Public Policy and Political Studies.

Summary: Feed Your Mind during finals
Description: Feed Your Mind is the largest food giveaway on campus. Get a good meal during finals and try something new.

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Fine Arts Career Services announces workshop for seniors
Description: Fine arts students graduating this year: Improve your networking, business-etiquette and resume-writing skills at a workshop with a local professional. Includes a resume review to help you maximize your document's potential. Lunch provided. Register at link below. Questions? Contact FACS at 512-232-7333 or facs@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: University Extension conducts webinar on entrepreneurship
Description: University Extension (UEX) presents a webinar titled "Characteristics of Successful Entrepreneurs: Separating Fact from Fiction," with instructor Eli Mercer of The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: "Revenge of the Electric Car" screened at study break
Description: Attend a free screening of "Revenge of the Electric Car," followed by a panel discussion on the next generation of electric vehicles featuring the latest from industry reps and faculty experts. A reception follows the panel.
Location: Blanton Museum, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the University of Louisiana at Monroe Warhawks.

Summary: Billy Elliot the Musical comes to PAC stage
Description: Billy Elliot the Musical is the joyous celebration of a boy's journey to make his dreams come true. The story follows Billy as he stumbles out of the boxing ring and into a ballet class, discovering a surprising passion that inspires his family and his whole community. Contains some adult language. Parental discretion advised.

Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Description: Students are invited to enjoy free coffee while studying at Victory @ Gregory Gym, the retail outlet on the first floor of the gym. There's plenty of quiet space and even four iPads available for use by students. No purchase is necessary and space is available on a first-come, first-served basis.

Description:
This session covers features such as adding, modifying and removing Grade Center items, weighing grades by item or by category, dropping the lowest grade(s) and exempting graded items and providing feedback on assignments and tests. Register at  - read more about this event....



The session also includes creating smart views of Grade Center content and customizing the letter grade scheme.

This is a participatory workshop, so come prepared to share your experiences, be creative and explore how your co-worker (or supervisor) thinks. Register via TXClass by Dec. 6, PN 628.

Summary: Sci-fi film "Things to Come" (1936) screened at HRC
Description:
In conjunction with the exhibition "I Have Seen the Future: Norman Bel Geddes Design America," the Harry Ransom Center screens the Bel Geddes-influenced film "Things to Come" (1936). Written by H.G. Wells and directed by William Cameron Menzies, the British science-fiction film is a loose adaptation of Wells' 1933 novel "The Shape of Things to Come" and his 1931 nonfiction work "The Work, Wealth and Happiness of Mankind."



Seating is limited. Line forms upon arrival of the first patron, and doors open 30 minutes in advance.

Summary: Science Under the Stars topic is new stars and sub-stars
Description: Do you ever think about how big space is? Michael Gully-Santiago explains how he is discovering new stars and sub-stars with some of the largest telescopes in the world. Science Under the Stars takes place outdoors. Arrive early for refreshments, star gazing through telescopes and fun activities for kids of all ages.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Description: Landmarks Video presents "Theme Song" (1973) by Vito Acconci. In a 30-minute stream-of-consciousness monologue, Acconci attempts to seduce the viewer while music from the Doors, Bob Dylan and Van Morrison plays. On view throughout January. The video media station is adjacent to Visual Arts Center galleries at 23rd St. and San Jacinto Blvd.

Summary: Wildflower Center offers free admission in January
Description: If you need a break from the hustle and bustle, the Wildflower Center's free admission January is a lovely way to enjoy nature's beauty up close. Indoor attractions include the Colorado River art exhibit by Margie Crisp, a winter clearance special in The Store (Jan. 5-6) and healthy Center Cafe meals. Closed on Mondays until mid-March; open noon to 5 p.m. on Sundays.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Udall Scholarship deadline is February 7
Description: Nominations are now being accepted for The University of Texas at Austin selection of candidates for the Udall Scholarship. Eligible students are current UT Austin students with sophomore or junior standing for 2012-2103 academic year, minimum GPA of 3.0/4.0, studying the environment or related fields, or a Native American or Native Alaskan and studying Native health care or tribal policy.

Texas Exes members receive special access and pricing. Use your Texas Exes member's login to access the current offers at TexasExes.org.

Summary: Blanton Museum screens "The Rake's Progress"
Description: This visually striking adaptation of Stravinsky's opera "The Rake's Progress" is based on the series of prints by William Hogarth currently on display at the Blanton. The film sets the opera in the modern American West, with oil derricks and swimming pools in the backdrop, and singers bathed in neon light.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Funding available for undergraduate research fellowships
Description:
Funding will soon be available for spring 2013 Undergraduate Research Fellowships (URF). Apply by 5 p.m., Tuesday, Jan. 22. No late applications will be accepted. For complete instructions and application form, visit the link below.



URFs in amounts up to $1,000 will be awarded through an upcoming spring competition. Faculty, lecturers and full-time research scientists/engineers may supervise undergraduate students in independent research projects.

Summary: DemTex Classes offered in spring 2013
Description: The DemTex program offers three student-created and -facilitated courses for the spring 2013 semester: "College Athletics and Society," "Leading a Social Enterprise" and "Euro Crisis: Europe's Response." Register with the School of Undergraduate Studies. Learn more at link below, or contact Joey Dominguez and Kevin Boening at utdemtex@gmail.com.

Summary: Get course credit for volunteering
Description: Get course credit for volunteering and enhance your resume with a leadership role in the community. Teach actual lessons in fourth to sixth grade classrooms in Austin through UTeach. Open to all majors. Register for CH207K (UN# 51950) today.

Summary: Bridging Disciplines Programs hosts information sessions
Description:
Learn about the Bridging Disciplines Programs (BDP) undergraduate interdisciplinary certificate opportunities at an information session with BDP advisers. Can't make it to a session? Call 512-232-7564 or stop by FAC 338 to set up an alternate time. Spring 2013 application deadline is March 7, 2013.



Topics to be covered are (1) How you can benefit from the BDPs, (2) How to choose the right BDP for you, (3) How a BDP can complement your degree plan, (4) The application process involve and writing a successful essay.



We offer certificates in the following interdisciplinary areas: 

-Children & Society

-Conflict Resolution & Peace Studies

-Cultural Studies

-Digital Arts & Media

-Environment

-Ethics & Leadership

-Global Studies

-Human Rights & Social Justice

-Innovation, Creativity and Entrepreneurship

-Social Entrepreneurship and Non-Profits

-Social Inequality, Health and Policy

Summary: World-renowned climatologist discusses Texas hurricanes
Description: Hot Science - Cool Talks presents Dr. Kerry Emanuel of MIT, who provides insights into Texas' stormy past and future in a highly anticipated lecture titled "Hurricanes in the Gulf of Mexico: The History and Future of the Texas Coast." A pre-lecture fair, beginning at 5:45 p.m., features engaging displays and activities.

Summary: Daily Living Project seeks families for research study
Description:
The Daily Living Project seeks families to participate in a study of family problem solving at The University of Texas at Austin. Participation entails visiting campus and completing a series of activities a few short questionnaires for a total of an hour or less. Contact 

Patrick Tennant at DailyLiving@Austin.UTexas.edu for details and eligibility.



Each family will be compensated with $40 in gift certificates and t-shirts. 



To be eligible to participate in the study, your family must:

- Have a child or children between the ages of 3 and 12 years old (all children in the family must be in this age range).

- All members of the family must be present (evening and weekend sessions are available).

- All children need to be the biological or adopted children of both participating adult partners. 

- All participants must be fluent in English.

Summary: Sand Mandala Project opening ceremony held
Description: Tibetan Buddhist monks from the Drepung Loseling Monastery visit the Blanton to construct a magnificent tantric Buddhist mandala sand painting. Experience the beauty of this ancient ritual and blessing of the space as monks prepare for the creation of the mandala. Find details at the link below.

Summary: Odyssey Free Lectures topic is integrated health care
Description: Dr. Octavio Martinez, executive director of the Hogg Foundation for Mental Health and an associate vice president in the Division of Diversity and Community Engagement, presents a lecture on integrated health care, highlighting approaches to integration currently in place in Texas and the nation.

Summary: Texas men's basketball plays West Virginia
Description: Texas men's basketball faces the West Virginia Mountaineers. Web coupon for $6 is good for one End Court Mezzanine ticket. Redeem at the Frank Erwin Center Box Office on game day. Doors open at 7 p.m. UT Faculty and Staff Appreciation Night features discounts for faculty and staff. Call 512-232-3865 for more information and order by noon, Wednesday, Jan. 9.

Summary: Participants sought for study on diet & blood pressure
Description:
Participants ages 30-80 with blood pressure higher than 120/80 are sought for a study on the effects of diet on blood pressure. Visits consist of four long appointments (1-2 hours) as well as additional brief visits to pick up supplies. Contact dairyintakestudy@gmail.com, or call 512-471-8594, for information. Payment is $200 for completing the study.  



Participants will be asked to add nonfat dairy products to their normal diet for four weeks and replace dairy products with fruit products for an additional four weeks. All food products provided free of charge.



To be eligible for participation, you must have high blood pressure. People currently on blood pressure medications are also eligible to participate in this study. 



Admission into this study is ongoing and new participants are accepted on a rolling basis.

Summary: First-year student LEAP mentee applications available
Description: First-year students in the Leadership, Education and Progress (LEAP) program have the opportunity to meet influential leaders in the UT community and develop personal leadership skills, all while creating a large network among fellow student leaders. Apply at the link below.

Summary: Sand Mandala Project welcomes visitors
Description: Tibetan Buddhist monks from the Drepung Loseling Monastery visit the Blanton to construct a magnificent sand mandala. During museum hours, watch as millions of grains of sand are laid into place in this ancient spiritual art form.
