Description: The Blackboard Advanced Training workshop is an open-format workshop that targets specific topics that workshop attendees wish to cover. Topics can range from using communication or interactive tools to creating user groups or incorporating YouTube video. Register at link below.

Summary: Library offers help with grants, scholarships and more
Description: The Regional Foundation Library is a cooperating collection of the Foundation Center of New York and has an array of resources for finding grants, scholarships and awards. The library is a program of the Division of Diversity and Community Engagement at The University of Texas at Austin.
Location: Regional Foundation Library, 1009 E. 11th St., 2nd floor

Summary: Volunteers needed at Texas Natural History Collections for Spring 2013
Description: Texas Natural History Collections (TNHC) seeks volunteers for the spring semester in its fish and herpetology collections. Volunteers must work at least one four-hour shift per week (Monday-Friday only). TNHC is located on the Pickle Research Campus in North Austin. Contact Jess at rosales@austin.utexas.edu explaining interest and specific times available. Serious, dedicated applicants sought.

Summary: Sand Mandala Project welcomes visitors
Description: Tibetan Buddhist monks from the Drepung Loseling Monastery visit the Blanton to construct a magnificent sand mandala. During museum hours, watch as millions of grains of sand are laid into place in this ancient spiritual art form.

Summary: WWE presents RAW World Tour at Erwin Center
Description: Don't miss this action-packed evening featuring WWE Superstars, including "The Leader of the Cenation" - John Cena, live. Event features a WWE championship match: "Unstoppable" Ryback vs. WWE Champion CM Punk, and more. Card is subject to change.

Summary: Sand Mandala Project welcomes visitors
Description: Tibetan Buddhist monks from the Drepung Loseling Monastery visit the Blanton to construct a magnificent sand mandala. During museum hours, watch as millions of grains of sand are laid into place in this ancient spiritual art form.

Summary: Symbolism of the Sand Mandala discussed in talk
Description: Join monks of the Drepung Loseling Monastery for a talk on the meaning of the Sand Mandala. Learn how, by creating a sand mandala, we bring creative energy into our lives and attune ourselves to natural perfection.

Summary: Tour "Into the Sacred City" exhibit at Blanton
Description: Be among the first museum visitors to experience a selection of newly conserved Tibetan Buddhist thangkas and mandalas from the Theos Bernard Collection at the University of California, Berkeley Art Museum and Pacific Film Archive.

Summary: Women's basketball takes on Oklahoma State
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Oklahoma State Cowboys. T-shirt Bundle Pack ($10) includes one reserved ticket and one Texas Athletics t-shirt; purchase by 4 p.m. Thursday, Jan. 10. Discount available for all city, state, county and federal employees. Call 512-232-3865 for information. Longhorns Kids host a postgame party for members. Visit longhornskidsclub.com to learn more.

Summary: The Balloon Project presents show for young audience
Description: "The Balloon Project" is a theatrical collaboration between the Department of Theatre and Dance and Patch Theatre Company exploring theatre-making using the artistic model of Patch Theatre to create a highly sophisticated visual theatre piece for children 3-8 years old.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Sand Mandala Project closing ceremony held
Description: In a ceremony representing the impermanence of all that exists, Buddhist monks from the Drepung Loseling Monastery will dismantle the sand mandala displayed in conjunction with the exhibit "Into the Sacred City." Half of the colored sand will be distributed to ceremony attendees and the other half will be dispersed in Waller Creek following a procession that starts at 3:30 p.m.

Summary: Apply for Academic Campus Engagement & Support (FACES)
Description: Student organizations are encouraged to apply for a FACES award to help fund your organization's academically based events. Help bring knowledge and learning to the UT campus as a whole. Events receive up to $500.
Location: Office of the Dean of Students

Summary: Texas Zephyrs recruitment activities held
Description: Texas Zephyrs is a service-oriented sorority excited to meet potential new members. Visit our table in the West Mall from 10 a.m.-3 p.m. More tabling takes place Jan. 21-25. Information sessions held on Tuesday, Jan. 22, and Wednesday, Jan. 23, both at 6:30 p.m. in Parlin Hall (PAR) 1.

Summary: RecSports presents Try Before You Buy
Description: During Try Before You Buy, all currently enrolled students and RecSports members can enjoy a free trial of all group exercise classes. These include TeXercise, Group Cycling, Aqua and PRC. Participants must present their UT ID for access.

Summary: Perry-Castañeda Library tour announced
Description: This walking tour provides an overview of the service points of the PCL, introducting the key areas in the building, including the periodicals collection, map collection, general stacks, microfilm and group study rooms. Meet at the PCL information counter.

Summary: Introduction to the UT libraries offered for new users
Description: Learn about the libraries on campus and the services and research resources available to you. Designed for new users of the UT libraries, this class includes a brief introduction to the library catalog and article databases. The class is preceded by a tour from 10-11 a.m. that meets at the PCL reference desk.

Summary: Claudia Rueda presents Inst. of Historical Studies talk
Description: Claudia Rueda presents "Untamable Elements: Protest and Repression During Nicaragua's 'Democratic Effervescence.'" Rueda is a PhD candidate in the Department of History.  Arturo Arias, professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese, responds. RSVP to christinedbaker@gmail.com.

Summary: Blackboard "Getting Started" training announced
Description:
In this training session, participants learn how to build a Blackboard course site by uploading course documents, organizing material and applying course designs. Register at the link below.



This course also covers adding files to a course site, managing material using folders, adding Web resources to a course site, customizing a course menu, applying unique design to a course site, managing students and teaching assistants.

Summary: Undergraduate research science info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research science information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.

 

University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Argentine tango class and practice held
Description: Join the University of Texas Argentine Tango Club for its spring class series. Class is from 6-7 p.m., followed by guided practice from 7-8 p.m. Beginners always welcome: no previous experience necessary; no partner required; join anytime during the semester.

Summary: Japan Karate practice held
Description: Japan Karate is the Austin branch of the Japan Karate Association as well as a member dojo of the American Amateur Karate Federation Southwestern Region. We teach Shotokan Karate to members of the university community. No prior experience is necessary. Classes held three times a week.

Summary: Texas State Employees Union visits campus
Description: The Texas State Employees Union visits campus with an information and sign-up table. The union seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions of all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at UT Austin.

Summary: Natural Sciences Council application due Feb. 1
Description: The Natural Sciences Council application is due by Friday, Feb. 1, at 5 p.m. Information sessions are scheduled for Tuesday, Jan. 22, from 5-6 p.m. in WEL 3.502 and Monday, Jan. 28, from 5-6 p.m. in WEL 2.308 after the general body meeting. Find the application at the link below.

Summary: Audition for "The Vagina Monologues"
Description: Calling all female-identified students, hearing and deaf, to audition for this year's production of Eve Ensler's "Vagina Monologues." Auditions are in 10-minute slots, on Jan. 23 and Jan. 24 from 7-10 p.m. in CBA 4.348. They include a cold reading of a monologue and a few short questions. Sign-up sheets to be posted outside the room at 6 p.m. Performance dates are March 21-23.

Summary: 2013 Maya Meetings present The Art of Maya Culture
Description: The 2013 Maya Meetings explore new ideas about the art and meaning of ancient Maya architectural decoration and design. Inspiring presenters, including rising scholars, will discuss archaeology, iconography, epigraphy and the study of architectural forms to focus on the built environment as an expression of ritual, cosmological and political space.
Location: University of Texas at Austin campus

Summary: Females sought for paid study on body image, eating issues
Description: Females with significant body image and/or eating concerns are sought to participate in a research study designed to help women feel better about their bodies. Participants can receive up to $90 compensation over two months. Some participants will attend eight weekly meetings on campus. Contact TexasBodyProject@utexas.edu or 512-232-2334.

Summary: Help evaluate a program for University Health Services
Description: The Health Promotion Resource Center (HPRC), part of University Health Services, seeks current students to help evaluate an online health program in a confidential, small-group setting. Sessions are Jan. 15 and Jan. 24 from 3-5 p.m. Food and swag provided. Contact Traci Toone at t.toone@uhs.utexas.edu with your name, EID, gender, age and date(s) available.

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: IROM Department and Statistics seminar held
Description: IROM Department and the Division of Statistics & Scientific Computation present Jared Murray of Duke University, giving a talk titled "Semiparametric Bayesian Gaussian Copula Factor Models."
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: Perry-Castañeda Library tour announced
Description: This walking tour provides an overview of the service points of the PCL, introducting the key areas in the building, including the periodicals collection, map collection, general stacks, microfilm and group study rooms. Meet at the PCL information counter.

Summary: Learn to find books and media in Libraries course
Description:
This course covers how to use the Library Catalog, e-books, Google Books and WorldCat, and how to find books, e-books, DVDs, CDs, journals and more. 

Class is preceded by a tour from 2-3 p.m. that meets at the PCL reference desk.

Summary: Enabling Advanced Biofuel Production: Seminar held
Description: "Enabling Advanced Biofuel Production Through Materials-Inspired Energy Efficient Separations" is a seminar presented by Dr. Ryan Lively, Algenol Biofuels. Read the abstract on this talk at the link below.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. 



University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Lions Club at UT holds first general meeting of 2013
Description: Looking for community service and social opportunities? Stop by this Lions Club meetings to learn how you can get involved in meaningful community service projects and exciting socials with other members.

Summary: HDO executive master's degree info session held
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP at link below.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.

Summary: Folklorico dance series offered by Grupo Flor y Canto
Description: Grupo Flor y Canto hosts a folklorico dance series. To register, email grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com.

Summary: Madrigal Theatre Committee holds play & musical auditions
Description: The Madrigal Theatre Committee announces open auditions for two student-written productions, a play and a musical. Musical auditions (SAC 1.118) and play auditions (SAC 1.106) all run from 7-10 p.m. except musical audition on Thursday, Jan. 17, at 8-11 p.m. Arrive at 7 p.m. for both. For musical, sing 32 bars (30 seconds) of a song that showcases your voice. Play auditions involve a cold read. Contact Reid O'Conor (reidoconor@utexas.edu) or Matt Hill (mattbhill@live.com) for more information.

Summary: Diamond Way Buddhist Meditation Group meets
Description: Diamond Way Buddhism provides a practical Western approach to Tibetan Buddhism that can be used in daily life. We host ten-minute talks about Buddhism and the history of this lineage, followed by a guided meditation. Meetings take place every Tuesday.

Summary: Apply for the 2013 Student Enrichment Awards
Description:
Texas Parents is pleased to offer the 2013 Student Enrichment Awards to registered student organizations in good standing with the Student Activities and Leadership Development (SALD) office. Visit our website for more information and to download application.



Grants are awarded to successful applicants who are working to enhance and enrich The University of Texas at Austin student experience.

Summary: Researchers seek individuals actively managing their weight
Description:
Participate in a UT research study about your weight management experiences, including communication with a romantic partner about your weight management. Involves daily surveys and a brief interview. Contact 

Dr. Rene Dailey, associate professor, Department of Communication Studies, at rdailey@utexas.edu with questions.



You are eligible to participate in this study if:

- You are at least 18 years of age,

- You are currently in a romantic relationship and are cohabiting/living with your partner,

- Your body mass index (based on height and weight) is 25 or greater - the classification of overweight,

- You are actively managing your weight through either diet, exercise or both.

Summary: Improving productivity in public education is forum topic
Description: Will K-12 education become more productive in 2013? Policymakers, researchers and civic leaders discuss this question from national and state perspectives in a day of presentations and panel discussions. RSVP to news@ipsi.utexas.edu.

Summary: Christian Faculty Network hosts Women's Prayer Group
Description: Join fellow women faculty and staff for a prayer group meeting. All are welcome.

Summary: Undergraduate Studies Council information session held
Description: The Undergraduate Studies Council (UGSC) is the official representative student organization for the School of Undergraduate Studies, providing a platform for UGS students to explore leadership while planning and executing beneficial events and activities for fellow students. Join us for an information session and free refreshments. Email us at ugscouncil@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI) holds info session
Description: The University of Texas Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI) is a centralized, comprehensive leadership-training program for enrolled undergraduate and graduate students in any academic college, school or unit. Attend this meeting to learn of opportunities for theoretical and practical ethical leadership development.

Summary: Join Texas women's rugby
Description: Are you interested in playing a new sport, meeting great people and getting in shape? Try Texas women's rugby. No experience necessary. Practices are Mondays and Wednesdays, 6-8 p.m. Email texasrugbyinfo@gmail.com with questions or for a ride.

Summary: Capoeira Club meets
Description: Developed by captive African slaves in 16th-century colonial Brazil, capoeira was used by its Afro-Brazilian practitioners to fight their oppressors and earn their freedom. Today, capoeira incorporates martial arts, dance and music with acrobatics for a great workout, no matter your fitness level. Taught by native Brazilian Professor Vagner.

Summary: Japan Karate practice held
Description: Japan Karate is the Austin branch of the Japan Karate Association as well as a member dojo of the American Amateur Karate Federation Southwestern Region. We teach Shotokan Karate to members of the university community. No prior experience is necessary. Classes held three times a week.

Summary: Longhorn Salsa holds open house
Description: Kick off the semester with Longhorn Salsa. Join us for a free beginner salsa lesson from 7-8 p.m. followed by social dancing with DJ Brad, spinning a mix of salsa, bachata and merengue.

Summary: International Socialist Organization meets
Description: The campus branch of the International Socialist Organization meets weekly to discuss news and politics from a far left perspective. Those turned on to radical thought because of the Arab Spring, Occupy Wall Street and growing union struggles are encouraged to attend.

Summary: Women's basketball plays Texas Tech
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Texas Tech Raiders. The $5 web coupon is good for one general admission ticket plus a Longhorns Team Shop coupon for 25 percent off. Redeem at the Frank Erwin Center Box Office on game day. Discount available for all city, state, county or federal employees. Call 512-232-3865 for information. Order by Friday, Jan. 15, at 4 p.m.

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: National Theatre of Scotland returns to Austin
Description: The National Theatre of Scotland presents "The Strange Undoing of Prudencia Hart." An evening of anarchic theater, live music and strange goings-on unfolds as Prudencia Hart, an uptight academic, sets off to attend a conference in the Scottish Borders, where the folk-studies community has gathered for a symposium. Recommended for ages 14 and up.

Summary: Apply to work at The Daily Texan
Description: The Daily Texan, Texas' award-winning student newspaper, is accepting applications for news reporters, sports reporters, life & arts writers, photographers, videographers, designers with any level of experience in InDesign, comics artists, copy staff and web staff. Applications available in the basement of the HSM building through Jan. 31. All students welcome.
Location: William Randolph Hearst Building (HSM, formerly CMC)

Summary: Community march, festival honor legacy of Dr. King
Description: The 20th annual Community March celebrating Dr. Martin Luther King's legacy kicks off at the MLK statue on The University of Texas at Austin campus. The event features speeches and a performance by Innervisions Gospel Choir. The march culminates with music and festivities at the Huston-Tillostson University campus.
Location: MLK Statue, East Mall, 23rd St. & Speedway

Summary: Study Abroad hosts international internships info session
Description: Students can work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting internship programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Blood Drive held in remembrance of Shia and Ahmadi victims
Description: The Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Organization holds a two-day blood drive in remembrance of Shia, Ahmadi and other oppressed minorities in Pakistan. Ahmadiyya hopes that this peaceful response to persecution sends a message of promoting life. Walk-ins welcome, or sign up online at our Facebook link.
Location: Speedway in front of Welch Hall (WEL)

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" matinee performed
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Monthly Staff Council meeting is canceled
Description: The monthly meeting of the UT Staff Council is canceled for the month of January. The next monthly meeting takes place Thursday, Feb. 21.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: History of computers, political change in Chile presented
Description: Eden Medina, Indiana University, presents a talk titled "The Cybernetic Revolution: A History of Computers and Political Change in Chile." Medina details the history of a computer network known as Project Cybersyn, built during the 1970s as part of Chile's peaceful road to socialism during the government of Salvador Allende.
Location: UT Administration Building (UTA) 5.522, Large Conference Room

Summary: Viewpoint Series presents Cary Levine & Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The annual Viewpoint Series, taking place each spring, features visits by a pair of invited guests, each lasting several days and spread throughout the semester. Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck present this lecture.

Summary: Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI) holds info session
Description: The University of Texas Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI) is a centralized, comprehensive leadership-training program for enrolled undergraduate and graduate students in any academic college, school or unit. Attend this meeting to learn of opportunities for theoretical and practical ethical leadership development.

Summary: BE Global Internship info session held
Description: Attend an information session on the BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Rolling admissions until Feb. 1.
Location: Cockrell Hall (ECJ), 10th floor, Large Conference Room

Summary: Master's in economics information session held
Description: Attend an information session and Q&A on the economics master's program. For seating priority, register at the program website, listed below.

Summary: Free yoga class offered weekly
Description: University Yoga Club offers a free weekly yoga and meditation class every Thursday.

Summary: Mitigating the natural resources curse is talk topic
Description: The UT Energy Symposium kicks off the spring semester with a talk by Scott Gaille, adjunct professor of management at Rice University and chief compliance officer for ZaZa Energy Corporation. Gaille's talk is titled "Alternatives for Mitigating the Natural Resources Curse." Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Blanton Lecture presents Stephen Gritt on conservation
Description: Stephen Gritt, director of Conservation and Technical Research at the National Gallery of Canada, illustrates the importance of conservation and discusses past and future conservation work in the context of the Blanton exhibition Restoration and Revelation.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Hide and Seek Club sponsors game
Description: Break in the new semester with a fun game of hide and seek. Prizes will be given for the first three games.

Summary: Tryouts held for Texas men's volleyball
Description: Try out for the Texas men's volleyball team. The club has two teams that compete both regionally in the SIVA Conference and nationally in the NCVF Conference. For more information visit the website below, or like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/texasmensvolleyball. Contact us with questions at utmensclubvb@gmail.com.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Zeta Sigma Chi Multicultural Sorority hosts info session
Description: Ever thought about joining a sorority truly devoted to multiculturalism? Zeta Sigma Chi is devoted to education, success, culture, service and sisterhood. Attend this meeting to find out more. Visit us on Facebook at facebook.com/UT.ZSC.

Summary: Collaborative Artists meets
Description: Collaborative Artists meets weekly to relax, draw and collaborate on fun art projects and events. Email utcollabartists@gmail.com to receive our newsletter.

Summary: Talk explores intersection of queer and undocumented
Description:
In "Narrativas UndocuQueer: Usando la Jotería para Cuestionar el American Dream," Óscar Salvador Torres shares findings from his ethnographic research about the intersection of the Queer and Undocumented movements in Central Texas.



The UndocuQueer movement includes Queer Latino DREAMers who are struggling to legalize their citizenship status as they face racisim and homophobia.

Summary: Undergraduate research general information sessions held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Mexican immigrant response to border violence is talk topic
Description: In "Experiencias de Resistencia ante la Pérdida," May-ek Querales Mendoza discusses the preliminary findings of her ethnographic project examining the complex everyday life experiences of women and men from the Valle de Juarez, Chihuahua, who migrated during the 2008-2012 period to El Paso, Texas, as a way to cope with multiple forms of violence in the border region.

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Michael Hout
Description: Dr. Michael Hout, of the Department of Sociology at The University of California at Berkeley, gives a talk titled "The Social Recession: The Immediate and Lasting Effects of the Lagging Economy, 2006-2010."

Summary: Undergraduate science research info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research science information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: IROM Department and Statistics seminar held
Description: The IROM Department and the Division of Statistics & Scientific Computation present "Advances in Bayesian Nonparametrics," a talk by Sinead Williamson of Carnegie Mellon University.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: Kariann Yokata discusses post-colonial Americans
Description: Kariann Akemi Yokota presents a seminar titled "Unbecoming British? The Place of Post-Colonial Americans in the British Empire."
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Viewpoint seminar given by Cary Levine & Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The annual Viewpoint Series presents a seminar by Cary Levine, University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, and Judith Rodenbeck, Sarah Lawrence College.

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Texas Polo Team holds open practices for prospective members
Description: The Texas Polo Team invites all prospective members to an official practice, held Fridays and Sundays at 4 p.m. No riding experience necessary. Wear long pants and closed-toed shoes. Transportation available if needed. Email Sam Maher at sammaher2@comcast.net with questions.
Location: Longhorn Polo and Equestrian Center, 4884 Bell Springs Road, Dripping Springs, TX

Summary: Flop Flick Friday is a night of bad movies
Description: Enjoy a night of bad movies. Featuring "Attack of the Killer Tomatoes" (5 p.m.), "Troll 2" (7 p.m.) and "Leprechaun" (9 p.m.). Come for all three or choose between them. A limited supply of popcorn and prizes provided.

Summary: Terry Allen performs at Cactus Cafe
Description: Texas songwriting legend Terry Allen returns to the Cactus for one night.

Summary: BFSA volunteers for Dr. King Day of Service
Description: Join the UT Black Faculty and Staff Association (BFSA) for the annual Dr. King Day of Service. We will participate in the MLK Boulevard Clean-Up sponsored by the Office of State Representative Dawnna Dukes, Hands On Central Texas and Keep Austin Beautiful. Long pants, jeans or other comfortable covered clothing recommended. When registering, make sure to select BFSA as your team.

Summary: Texas legislative intern seminar held
Description: The Texas Politics Project and the Annette Strauss Institute for Civic Life host a day of nonpartisan training sessions for interns working in the 83rd Texas Legislature. From professional office behavior to the ins and outs of the legislative process, interns have the opportunity to hear from professionals from many different walks of Capitol life.

Summary: Men's basketball hosts Kansas
Description: The Texas men's basketball team hosts the Kansas Jayhawks at the Frank Erwin Center. Tickets available at TexasSports.com.

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" matinee performed
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Description: The National Theatre of Scotland presents "The Strange Undoing of Prudencia Hart." An evening of anarchic theater, live music and strange goings-on unfolds as Prudencia Hart, an uptight academic, sets off to attend a conference in the Scottish Borders, where the folk-studies community has gathered for a symposium. Recommended for ages 14 and up.

Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Write poetry about art at Blanton Museum workshop
Description: The Blanton is proud to have inspired great poems by Texas writers. This spring, find your creativity in a workshop taught by poet Vive Griffith. Participants will learn forms and techniques for creating new poems about artworks in the museum. Email publicintern@blantonmuseum.org for registration and information about these free classes.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), Dell Classroom

Summary: Texas Juggling Society holds campus meeting
Description: Attend the weekly auxiliary meeting of the Texas Juggling Society held specifically for the UT community (with invited special guests from the juggling community at large). This is an open session for learning and practicing a variety of juggling and related activities (hoops, diabolo, devil stick). Beginners and spectators welcome.

Summary: Live band auditions held for new musical
Description: The Madrigal Theatre Committee announces auditions for the live band to accompany a new musical scheduled for this spring. Piano, guitar and bass guitar sought. Auditions held on a drop-in basis, with no specific repertoire required.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas Zephyr recruitment activities held
Description: Texas Zephyrs is a service-oriented sorority excited to meet potential new members. Visit our table in the West Mall from 10 a.m.-3 p.m. More tabling takes place Jan. 21-25. Information sessions held on Tuesday, Jan. 22, and Wednesday, Jan. 23, both at 6:30 p.m. in Parlin Hall (PAR) 1.

Summary: Apply for the Multicultural Leadership Institute
Description: The Multicultural Leadership Institute offers UT undergraduate students a unique opportunity to engage in hands-on leadership learning while improving organizational, writing and planning skills. Application is available on the Facebook page below and due by Wednesday, Jan. 30, at 5 p.m.

Summary: Hazlitt novel "Time Will Run Back" is Mises Circle topic
Description:
The Mises Circle is back for a new year, beginning with a discussion of Henry Hazlitt's novel "Time Will Run Back." The book is available in PDF and ePub formats at 

http://mises.org/document/3060/. A synopsis of the story and its social and economic lessons will precede the discussion.

Summary: Become a peer educator in safety education
Description: Apply to become a peer educator. Help facilitate the peer-led Safety Education Program that is required of specifically identified registered student organizations at The University of Texas at Austin. Application deadline is Thursday, Feb. 14.
Location: Office of the Dean of Students

Summary: UT Organizations: Apply for 2012-2013 Swing Out Awards
Description: Campus organizations that wish to spotlight a significant accomplishment during the past year and raise awareness of the organization on campus are invited to apply for a 2012 Swing Out Award. Applications accepted through Feb. 22. Winners are represented at the annual Evening of the Stars, with cash awards for winners in each category. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: Brain study volunteers sought
Description:
Fill out a short online survey to determine if you qualify for studies in the Poldrack Lab. The lab has multiple studies at various dates and times and seeks healthy participants for research on thinking, brain function and genetics. Visit link for survey. Contact subject.pools@gmail.com with questions.



Lab visits could include playing simple computer games, brain MRI or small blood samples. Study pays $10-$25 per hour. For most studies, participants must be at least 18 years old, have at least an eighth grade education, speak English fluently and not be using any medicine for psychiatric reasons.



Studies are directed by Dr. Russell Poldrack at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Get Fit registration is open for Jan. 28 start
Description:
Get Fit is a 12-week exercise and weight-loss program administered by the Fitness Institute staff at The University of Texas at Austin. Four class times offered for each day of course. Register online at 

the link below, and call 512-471-0081 to schedule an initial meeting.



The program involves three workouts and one luncheon seminar each week led by accredited fitness staff and a registered dietitian. The workouts consist of a balanced mix between cardiovascular and resistance training, the goal being to maximize weight loss from fat and improve daily functioning for each participant.

Summary: Learn to manage grades with Blackboard's Grade Center
Description: This session covers features such as adding, modifying and removing Grade Center items; weighing grades by item or by category; dropping the lowest grade(s) and exempting graded items and providing feedback on assignments and tests. Session also includes creating smart views of Grade Center content and customizing the letter grade scheme. Register at link below.

Summary: Religiosity and substance use in El Salvador is talk topic
Description: "The Protective Effect of Religiosity and Spirituality for Substance Use and Abuse: El Salvador and Beyond" is a lecture by Christopher Salas-Wright, Center for Alcohol and Addiction Studies, Brown University.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theater

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Texas APO rush announced
Description: Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO) is a unique, co-ed organization that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university through campus involvement and running the world's largest Texas flag at sports events. Visit our tables at the West Mall and Gregory Plaza and meet active members of Texas APO.
Location: West Mall and Gregory Gym Plaza (GRE)

Summary: Mining in "Post"-war Guatemala is topic of talk
Description: "Half a Miillion or $1000 an Ounce: Mining, Metrics, and Dubious Equivalencies in 'Post' War Guatemala" is a lecture by Diane Nelson, professor of cultural anthropology, Duke University.

Summary: Zeta Sigma Chi hosts Interest Week
Description: Ever thought about joining a sorority truly devoted to multiculturalism? Zeta Sigma Chi is devoted to education, success, culture, service and sisterhood. Zeta Sigma Chi hosts a week of exciting events for prospective members. Follow the link below or visit us at facebook.com/UT.ZSC for more information.

Summary: The value and values of diplomacy is talk topic
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law announces "The Value and Values of Diplomacy: Moral Psychology and the Search for Security in 1920's Europe" with Brian Rathbun, associate professor at the University of Southern California. Refreshments provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: IROM and Statistics seminar presented
Description: The IROM Department and the Division of Statistics and Scientific Computation seminar series proudly present a talk by Bailey Fosdick, University of Washington, about modeling heterogeneity within multiway array data.

Summary: ChE Graduate Seminar presents Dr. Qing Hua Wang (MIT)
Description: Dr. Qing Hua Wang of MIT describes her work on the chemical functionalization of graphene via two different approaches in a seminar titled "Chemical Functionalization and Patterning of Graphene."

Summary: Objectivism Society hosts regular meeting
Description: The UT Objectivism Society meets every Tuesday to discuss aspects of Ayn Rand's philosophy, which she called Objectivism - "a philosophy for living on Earth." Check the link below for meeting topics.

Summary: Lions Club meets
Description: Looking for community service and social opportunities? Stop by the Lions Club's meetings to learn how you can get involved in meaningful community service projects and exciting socials with other members.

Summary: Voices Against Violence (VAV) holds weekly meeting
Description: VAV hosts a weekly student meeting to discuss how to make the campus community safer against intimate partner violence. Join us.

Summary: AIESEC Austin holds information session
Description: Learn about interning abroad or becoming a member of AIESEC at an information session featuring free food. AIESEC is the world's largest student-run nonprofit organization. It provides a platform for students to develop professional skills, establish a global network of friends and colleagues and intern abroad.

Summary: Project SEEE holds information session
Description: Participate in community service by doing science experiments with children in elementary schools in Austin. Attend this meeting to learn how to get involved with Project SEEE, or email projectseee@hotmail.com with your questions.

Summary: Aikido self-defense practice for beginners held
Description: Seidokan Aikido classes teach self-defense based on a relaxed, coordinated mind and body rather than strength. Train with instructors who have decades of experience in the oldest aikido dojo in Austin. No prior experience or uniform needed to begin - just clothing to move easily in.

Summary: Alpha Phi Omega info session announced
Description: Alpha Phi Omega invites prospective members to attend an information session to learn more about joining our co-ed service organization. Food provided.

Summary: Texas APO information session held
Description: Attend an information session with members of Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO), a unique organization that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university. Learn about the opportunities our co-ed service fraternity offers and how you can become a part of this community-impacting organization.

Summary: Amnesty International holds meeting
Description: Attend the spring informational meeting of Amnesty International.

Summary: Texas Taekwondo meets
Description: Learn Olympic style taekwondo.  All skill levels welcome, from absolute beginners to advanced belts. Wear comfortable workout clothes and be ready to learn.  Interested students are requested to come to class on Jan. 22, 24 or 29 to pick up a membership packet.

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas Ballroom announces Free Week
Description: Join Texas Ballroom for Free Week. No partner or experience necessary. Times vary: Tuesday, Jan. 22, 8-10 p.m., salsa/jitterbug; Wednesday, Jan. 23, 8-10 p.m., waltz/tango; Thursday, Jan. 24, 6-8 p.m., two-step/West Coast swing; Friday, Jan. 25, 8:30-midnight, social dance; Monday, Jan. 28, 8-10 p.m., rumba/jive. Visit texasballroom.org or our Facebook link.

Summary: Texas Crew Rent-A-Rower program announced
Description: Texas Crew announces its Rent-A-Rower program. Crew team members work to pay off their dues by doing manual labor, yard work, babysitting, tutoring, moving, technical support and more. Visit our website or email rowfortexas@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: UHS holds flu shot clinic
Description: University Health Services provides flu shots to UT students, faculty and staff (while supplies last). Bring UT ID and insurance card if you have insurance. UT Select Insurance or $10 (cash or check only) accepted for faculty/staff. Most health insurance accepted for students, except HMO plans, non-U.S. plans or government health insurance. Uninsured students or students with excluded insurance pay $10 by cash, check or posting charge to "WhatOwe."

Summary: Learn about study abroad options at campus fair
Description: Attend the Study Abroad Fair to learn about study abroad options from faculty and staff, partner universities, program providers, program alumni and current exchange students.

Summary: IRB intro course offered
Description: This educational session addresses general IRB processes, background information, levels of review and how to submit. Each IRB educational session targets investigators across all disciplines. Register on TXClass.

Summary: FACS New York seminar info session held
Description:
Looking for a career in arts administration? Fine Arts Career Services (FACS) leads a trip to New York City focused on two areas: arts administration for visual arts and for performing arts. Register and learn more at the link below. Apply for the FACS Travel Grant by 4 p.m. Jan. 25. See http://ow.ly/ggPm0. Contact FACS at 512-232-7333 or facs@austin.utexas.edu with questions.



This trip includes the opportunity to meet industry leaders from top-tier companies and attend networking events with Texas alums working in your field.

Summary: Perry-Castañeda Library tour announced
Description: This walking tour provides an overview of the service points of the PCL, introducting the key areas in the building, including the periodicals collection, map collection, general stacks, microfilm and group study rooms. Meet at the PCL information counter.

Summary: Engineering master's degree info session held online
Description: Attend a live-online information session about the engineering master's degree program geared toward the working professional and offered through the Cockrell School of Engineering at The University of Texas at Austin. Programs include Engineering Management and Software Engineering, and meet one weekend (Friday and Saturday) a month for two years.

Summary: Introduction to the UT libraries offered
Description: Learn about the libraries on campus and the services and research resources available to you. This class, designed for new users of the UT libraries, includes a brief introduction to the library catalog and article databases. Class is preceded by a tour from noon-1 p.m. that meets at the PCL reference desk.

Summary: Blackboard "Getting Started" training announced
Description:
In this training session, participants learn how to build a Blackboard course site by uploading course documents, organizing material and applying course designs. Register at the link below.



This course also covers adding files to a course site, managing material using folders, adding Web resources to a course site, customizing a course menu, applying unique design to a course site, managing students and teaching assistants.

Summary: Hindi and Urdu learning is topic of professor's talk
Description: Dr. Rupert Snell, professor in the Department of Asian Studies and director of the Hindi Urdu Flagship, discusses how students who learn Hindi and Urdu in parallel encounter two complementary sets of culturally marked social conventions. Snell examines this diversity in the context of the close but often vexed relationship between Hindi and Urdu.

Summary: BE Global Internship info session held
Description: Attend an information session on the new BE Global Internship Program, offering international internships in Barcelona and Shanghai for business and engineering majors beginning summer 2013. Rolling admissions run until Feb. 1.

Summary: RecSports invites you to Gregory Gym
Description: Discover three great resources available at Gregory Gym: the retail outlet, massage services and the pilates studio/exercise studio. Join us for a tour, light refreshments, door prizes and a special drawing. Find details at the link below.

Summary: Electronic Dance Music (EDM) Club Meeting
Description: The EDM Club aims to build a community for electronic music listeners, producers and DJs. Join us to share information about all things EDM related - from parties to projects, and more.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Balcony Room A 3.106

Summary: Quest for balance in the professor's life is talk topic
Description:
The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence introduces the 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series with Dr. Richard Reddick, presenting "The Secret Lives of Professors: The Eternal Quest for Balance." Reddick was the 2010-2011 Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation Career Enhancement Fellow. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions. 



Reddick is an assistant professor in the College of Education's Department of Educational Administration at The University of Texas at Austin, and is also the coordinator of the M.Ed. program in College and University Student Personnel Administration. An award-winning teacher and scholar, Reddick received the Spring 2009 Eyes of Texas Excellence Award, 2012 Outstanding Young Texas Ex Award, the John L. Warfield Center for African and African American Studies Faculty Teaching Award and the Black Faculty and Staff Association (BFSA) Faculty Member of the Year Award.

Summary: Intro to Clinical Medicine lecture series held
Description: The College of Natural Science announces a distinguished lecture series led by Associate Dean of Health Professions and cardiothoracic surgeon Dr. Reginald Baptiste. Noted health professionals give their first-hand insight into the world of clinical medicine every other Wednesday through May 1.

Summary: Project SEEE holds information session
Description: Participate in community service by doing science experiments with children in elementary schools in Austin. Attend this meeting to learn how to get involved with Project SEEE, or email projectseee@hotmail.com with your questions.

Summary: Kappa Delta Chi rush week info session held
Description: Kappa Delta Chi Sorority, Inc. (KDChi) is a sisterhood serving the Latina/o community. Since 1987, the award-winning sisterhood has motivated women to achieve the dream of a higher education and nurtured them to become successful leaders. Chapters share the common premise of the scholastic, philanthropic and ethical standards. Meet sisters and learn ore at this event.

Summary: Texas MSTC information session held
Description: Learn about the Master's of Science in Technology Commercialization (MSTC) at this information session. The session begins with a presentation by Program Director Dr. Gary Cadenhead, followed by alumni comments and an open forum for questions.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 101

Summary: Taiwanese American Students hold general meeting
Description: Join the Taiwanese American Students for free pizza at their first general meeting this semester. All are welcome.

Summary: Student Action for Refugees holds first meeting
Description: Attend the first meeting of STAR, Student Action for Refugees, to learn about student projects supporting refugees in the Austin area. We work in conjunction with Refugee Services of Texas to help Iraqi, Bhutanese, Burmese, Cuban, Eritrean, Somali and other refugees acclimate to life in the United States. All are welcome.

Summary: Faculty Learning Community looks at student learning outcomes
Description: This Faculty Learning Community focuses on how to identify student learning outcomes for a unit and design assessments and tasks that align with these desired outcomes. Class meets for five sessions, every other week, throughout semester.

Summary: Longhorn Club hosts women's basketball coach Karen Aston
Description: Join Texas women's basketball head coach Karen Aston for an update on the Texas women's team and the Longhorns' march through the Big 12 Conference. Includes a buffet lunch. Save $21 with a full spring membership. RSVP today by calling 512-471-4439.
Location: Frank Erwin Center, Lone Star Room

Summary: Undergraduate research general info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers, and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Asian/Asian American Faculty & Staff Association meets
Description: Join AAAFSA for its January membership meeting. We will learn about the Campus Climate Response Team and the reporting of bias incidents on campus. Lunch provided (including vegetarian/vegan options). RSVP to sona.shah@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Blackboard Advanced Training workshop offered
Description: The Blackboard Advanced Training workshop is an open-format workshop that targets specific topics that workshop attendees wish to cover. Topics can range from using communication or interactive tools to creating user groups or incorporating YouTube video. Register at link below.

Summary: Peace Corps information session held
Description: Attend an informational session about the Peace Corps with the UT representative. Learn about the Peace Corps mission, the volunteer experience and how you can become a competitive applicant for the toughest job you'll ever love.

Summary: UT in Sydney information session held
Description: UT in Sydney for Kinesiology and Health Education majors is a unique opportunity to go abroad with a UT faculty member and spend fall semester 2013 on exchange with the University of Technology, Sydney (UTS), as part of the same program.

Summary: UT Energy Symposium hosts open house
Description: Join the UT Energy Symposium for pizza and a casual conversation about how to improve energy education and research on campus.

Summary: AIESEC Austin holds information session
Description: Learn about interning abroad or becoming a member of AIESEC at an information session featuring free food. AIESEC is the world's largest student-run nonprofit organization. It provides a platform for students to develop professional skills, establish a global network of friends and colleagues and intern abroad.

Summary: Texas APO information session held
Description: Attend an information session with members of Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO), a unique organization that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university. Learn about the opportunities our co-ed service fraternity offers and how you can become a part of this community-impacting organization.

Summary: CAN presents advance screening of "NO"
Description:
Students of the World at UT kicks off its first semester of the Creative Activist Network (CAN) with a screening of the new Chilean documentary "NO," about the overthrow of Augusto Pinochet in Chile during the late 1980s. Seating is limited. Find a synopsis and trailer of the film here at http://www.participantmedia.com/pm-films/no-film/.



Students of the World's UT Chapter gives special thanks to Participant Media for this presentation.

Summary: TFN Student Chapter holds first meeting; pizza served
Description:
Join the Texas Freedom Network (TFN) student chapter at its first meeting. We are Longhorns who advocate for religious freedoms, civil liberties and strong public schools in Texas. We offer a mainstream, progressive voice to counter the radical right. Free pizza served.



We support:

* Strong public schools

* Medically accurate sex education

* Teaching of evolution

* Religious freedoms

* LGBTQ rights

* Stem cell research

Summary: Libertarian Longhorns meet
Description: Libertarian Longhorns hold their first meeting of the semester. Join a discussion of what libertarianism is and why it is especially important in today's political climate. Planning for upcoming events is also on the agenda.

Summary: College Republicans at Texas holds first spring meeting
Description: College Republicans at Texas believes in limited government, liberty, a free-market economy and fiscal conservatism. Attend our very first meeting of the semester to enjoy free pizza and soft drinks, meet current officers and other members, and learn more about the party and conservatism as a governing philosophy. Members of the class of 2016 and transfer students are especially welcome.

Summary: Students for Clean Water holds Pancake Party
Description: Help Students for Clean Water bring access to clean, safe water in Tigray, Ethiopia, at our 6th biannual Pancake Party, where $5 buys all the pancakes you can eat and all proceeds go directly to fund well projects. For a ride to the event, contact sfcwaustin@gmail.com.

Summary: UT Press fellowships available for alumni
Description:
The University of Texas Press offers two publishing fellowships for the 2013-2014 year, beginning Sept. 1, 2013, and ending Aug. 31, 2014. Fellowships are open to alumni of the University of Texas at Austin only. Applications available at 

http://www.utexas.edu/utpress/about/fellow.html. Deadline is

Friday, March 29.



The fellowship program is designed to give one year of experience in book publishing to the most qualified applicants. The 2013-2014 fellowships are offered in two areas of concentration, Design and Production, and Editorial. Applicants must indicate on their application which area they are applying for.

Summary: Global Game Jam sponsored by EGaDS
Description: Join a team and make a video game in a weekend. No experience required. Play the role of designer, artist, programmer, sound guy at this event sponsored by the Electronic Game Developers Society. Check-in is Friday, Jan. 25, from 5-7 p.m. More details available at link below.

Summary: "Preparing to Flip": Create an active learning classroom
Description: The "Preparing to Flip" workshop helps faculty design learning experiences that teach students how to acquire basic content outside of classroom and how to apply these ideas and concepts inside of class.

Summary: Soles 4 Souls announces last chance to donate shoes
Description: This is the final chance to donate your unwanted shoes and to ask friends and family to donate as well. All sizes, types and conditions accepted; bind shoes in pairs with laces or rubber bands. The individual who donates the most shoes receives a $25 Amazon gift card. Find drop-off dates, times and locations at link below. Contact Josh at josh.shen@utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: Spring Student Organization Fair held
Description: Attend the spring Student Organization Fair to learn how you can get more involved with campus groups.

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Becky Pettit
Description: Becky Pettit, from the Department of Sociology, University of Washington, gives a talk titled "Invisible Men: Mass Incarceration and the Myth of Black Progress."

Summary: Jr. Faculty Book Club reads Ken Bain book
Description: This semester, the Jr. Faculty Book Club reads and discusses Ken Bain's book, "What the Best College Teachers Do." Sessions take place every other Friday.

Summary: UT Solar Design/Build Workshop Series info session held
Description:
Attend this session to learn about a spring workshop offering the unique opportunity to design and fabricate a functional solar charging station for the UT campus. This project is sponsored by the UT Green Fee program and the Office of Sustainability.



Students will design and assist in constructing a charging station accessible to all UT students, faculty staff, and the public at sporting events and other large campus events. The workshop will teach practical skills in solar design, electrical engineering, prototyping and fabrication. A committed group of students will attend five Design/Build workshops on weekends throughout February and March 2013.
Location: Student Services Building (SSB), Glenn Maloney Room South (basement)

Summary: 2012-13 McCraw Lecture Series presents Rick Neptune
Description: Rick Neptune, Ph.D., professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering at The University of Texas at Austin, presents a talk titled "Improving Human Performance through Design Optimization."

Summary: Community-based behavioral intervention is CHPR talk topic
Description: Dr. Jane Champion, professor, The University of Texas at Austin School of Nursing, presents "Ethical Frameworks for Translation of Community-based Behavioral Interventions Within Diverse Healthcare Settings."

Summary: Asian Americans in a Majority-Minority Nation is talk title
Description: Deepa Iyer, executive director of South Asian Americans Leading Together (SAALT) and chair, National Council of Asian Pacific Americans, presents a talk titled "Asian Americans in a Majority-Minority Nation." Free lunch provided.

Summary: Type 2 diabetes in African American women is talk topic
Description:
John W. Newman presents a talk titled "Type 2 Diabetes Associated Changes in the Plasma Non-Esterified Fatty Acids, Oxylipins and Endocannabinoids in BMI-matched African American Women" as part of the Department of Nutritional Sciences' ongoing speaker series.



Newman is an associate adjunct professor in the Department of Nutrition at the University of California, Davis. His research program explores the interactions of dietary lipids, lipid transport and metabolism as they pertain to obesity and complications of obesity, including chronic inflammation and cardiovascular disease.

Summary: IROM & SSC Seminar presents Mingyuan Zhou, Duke University
Description: The IROM Department and the Division of Statistics & Scientific Computation present Mingyuan Zhou of Duke University, with a talk titled "Nonparametric Bayesian Count and Mixture Modeling."
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: British imperial state in the 18th century is talk topic
Description: Historian Brian Levack presents a seminar titled "The British Imperial State in the Eighteenth Century."
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, the Italian Club of the Department of French and Italian that meets at the Cactus Cafe for informal conversation in Italian.

Summary: Undergraduate Research Forum info session held
Description: Why present at the Undergraduate Research Forum? Faculty members share their perspective on the importance of scientific communication, including posters, and students who have presented posters share their experience, advice and perspectives. Food provided. RSVP at www.surveymonkey.com/s/whypresent.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Inclusive leadership skills to be S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This training is designed to help participants develop inclusive leadership skills and equip them to work with a diverse group of people. Concepts such as social  identities and inclusion will be introduced. Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Texas Graduate Christian Fellowship hosts talk on faith
Description: The Texas Graduate Christian Fellowship hosts a talk on faith and academics by Dr. John Goodenough, Department of Mechanical Engineering. Free dinner provided at 6; talk begins at 7. All students are welcome.

Summary: Texas APO holds meet and greet
Description: Attend an information session with members of Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO), a unique organization that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university. Learn about the opportunities our co-ed service fraternity offers and how you can become a part of this community-impacting organization.

Summary: International Affairs Society holds info sessions
Description: Interested in international issues, cultures, careers or food? Learn about the International Affairs Society, a multifaceted campus organization, at this meeting. All majors welcome.

Summary: Rick Rowley gives faculty artist recital
Description: Rick Rowley, pianist, gives a faculty recital featuring solo sonatas of Cimarosa and the Schumann C Major Fantasie, Op. 17. He will be joined by pianist Anne Epperson for Percy Grainger's "Fantasy on Themes from George Gershwin's Porgy and Bess." Online tickets available until 9 a.m., Friday, Jan. 25.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis.  The morning will consist of sailing instruction and the afternoon will be a choice of cruising or racing. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Tree Celebration and Sale held at Wildflower Center
Description: Winter is planting time for woody species in Central Texas. Attend a free walk and tree-planting tutorial in the Mollie Steves Zachry Texas Arboretum (accessed through  central courtyard past the cafe, using Hill Country Trails entry). Native trees and shrubs and Yan Lee's tree drawings are on sale. Kids' activities provided. Learn more below, or call 512-232-0100.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: Texas women's tennis plays Wichita State in ITA kick-off
Description: UT women's tennis hosts ITA Kick-Off Weekend at the Penick-Allison Tennis Center. The team takes on Wichita State at 10 a.m. For more information on the Tennis Center, visit PlayPenickTennis.com.

Summary: Orange Bike Project holds shop hours
Description: Volunteer at Orange Bike Project's cage, or learn to work on your own bike. Tools, bike stands and more available.
Location: Guadalupe Garage (GUG), San Antonio at 16th St.

Summary: Women's basketball takes on Kansas State
Description: Texas Women's Basketball hosts the Kansas State Wildcats. At this game, "UT & Me" features tabling by university and community organizations around the concourse, beginning at 11 a.m. A $5 general admission ticket is available for fans wanting to attend both the game and expo. Purchase with the promo code UTANDME on the promo code page of TexasSports.com.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Men's basketball plays Texas Tech
Description: Texas men's basketball hosts the Texas Tech Red Raiders. Canned Food Drive: Bring five canned goods and receive a free Texas Athletics DVD and a coupon for a free Whataburger; game day only. Teacher Appreciation Night discount available for teachers and staff. Call 512-232-3865 for more information before noon Sunday.

Summary: ITA Kick-Off Weekend features UT women's tennis match
Description: ITA Kick-Off Weekend concludes as Texas women's tennis hosts either Utah or Stephen F. Austin. Visit TexasSports.com for match time and other information.

Summary: Identification Day held at Texas Memorial Museum
Description: Have you ever wondered about a fossil you've found? Then bring it with you to Identification Day. Scientists and experts from all over Central Texas are on hand to look at and identify natural objects (fossils, bones, rocks, etc.) and archaeological materials (arrowheads, points, scrapers, etc.).

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Get involved in the UT Micro Farm project
Description: The UT Micro Farm is our campus' first student-run, sustainable farm, where food is grown for the local community. Volunteers are needed, whatever your skill set or interests. Visit the website below to learn how to get involved.

Summary: Chi Beta Delta service sorority announces rush week
Description: Chi Beta Delta is a community service sorority. Our rush week involves activities that allow young women to get to know our current members, as well as learn more about our sorority. Check the Facebook link below for event details and times.

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau recruitment held
Description: Meet the women of Sigma Delta Tau as we kick off our spring recruitment. For more information, look for us on Facebook at the link below.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies fellow presents talk
Description: Jorge Cañizares-Esguerra presents "Mary, Empire, and the Trinitarian Structure of Time." He is an IHS fellow and the Alice Drysdale Sheffield professor of history at The University of Texas at Austin. Dr. Alison Frazier, associate professor of history, responds. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Genomic articulations of indigeneity to be talk topic
Description: Anthropologist Kim TallBear presents a talk titled "Genomic Articulations of Indigeneity." TallBear is assistant professor in the Department of Environmental Science, Policy, and Management at the University of California, Berkeley. The talk addresses the definitions of "indigeneity" among indigenous peoples and genome scientists, which illustrate their competing notions of identity, origins and futures.

Summary: Racial formations in the 21st century is roundtable topic
Description:
The Center for Asian American Studies presents Racial Formations in the 21st Century: A Roundtable Discussion with Dr. Michael Omi. Omi is associate professor of ethnic studies and associate director of the Haas Institute for a Fair and Equitable Society at the University of California, Berkeley. Download Omi's article on the topic at http://www.utexas.edu/cola/centers/aas/_files/pdf/RFinthe21stCentury.pdf.



Hosted by the Center for Asian American Studies with generous support from the Division of Diversity and Community Engagement, Humanities Institute, Multicultural Engagement Center, Native American and Indigenous Studies Program, Social Justice Institute, John L. Warfield Center for African and African American Studies and the Center for Women and Gender Studies.

Summary: Undergraduate science research info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research science information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers, and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: "The Unbearable Whiteness of Being" is ethnic studies talk
Description:
"The Unbearable Whiteness of Being: Situating Asian Americans" is talk by Dr. Michael Omi, associate professor of ethnic studies and associate director of the Haas Institute for a Fair and Equitable Society at the University of California, Berkeley. RSVP at facebook.com/events/400266440057622/.

 

Omi serves as associate director of the University of California Center for New Racial Studies, a multi-campus research program. He is the co-author of "Racial Formation in the United States."



Hosted by the Center for Asian American Studies with generous support from the Division of Diversity and Community Engagement, Humanities Institute, Multicultural Engagement Center, Native American and Indigenous Studies Program, Social Justice Institute, John L. Warfield Center for African and African American Studies and the Center for Women and Gender Studies.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Panel discusses solutions to Texas water crisis
Description: "The Texas Water Crisis: Finding and Funding a Solution" is a panel discussion examining water issues in the state and some of the solutions the legislature is considering. The panel features members of the state legislature, including State Representative Lyle Larson. The panel runs for one hour and includes an audience Q&A.

Summary: Synapse Neuroscience Club meets
Description: Synapse Neuroscience Club is an undergraduate student organization interested in promoting neuroscience research. The club meets weekly to host discussions, listen to talks by researchers in the field and read and review journal articles. Meetings alternate between journal club and standard meetings every other week.

Summary: Join Texas women's rugby
Description: Are you interested in playing a new sport, meeting great people and getting in shape? Come play with the team ranked fourth in the nation, Texas women's rugby. No experience necessary. Practices take place Mondays and Wednesdays, 6-8 p.m. Email texasrugbyinfo@gmail.com with questions or for a ride.

Summary: Engineers Without Borders holds general meeting
Description: Attend the Engineers Without Borders Greater Austin Chapter's first general meeting to learn more about our projects in Panama and Peru. The organization focuses on partnering with communities to find sustainable solutions to meet their needs. The Greater Austin Chapter is made up of students and professionals of all disciplines.

Summary: Caribbean Students Association holds general meeting
Description: The Caribbean Students Association holds general meetings every other Monday. Join us in celebrating all aspects of Caribbean culture. Meetings feature free Caribbean food, and a chance to meet other Caribbean students and become involved in our vibrant organization.

Summary: Texas APO information session held
Description: Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO) is a unique co-ed service fraternity that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university through campus involvement and running the world's largest Texas flag at sports events. Come and meet active members at this session.

Summary: International Affairs Society holds spring kickoff meeting
Description: Interested in international issues, cultures, careers or food? Learn about the International Affairs Society, a multifaceted campus organization, at this meeting. All majors welcome; food and refreshments served.

Summary: Bitcoin, Austrian theory of money are Mises Circle topics
Description:
The Mises Circle tackles the topic of Bitcoin, a decentralized and open-source digital currency. Discussion will center on Peter Surda's paper "Economics of Bitcoin: Is Bitcoin an Alternative to Fiat Currencies and Gold?" Read the paper here: http://dev.economicsofbitcoin.com/mastersthesis/mastersthesis-surda-2012-11-19b.pdf. Can't make it in person? Join us online via Google  Hangouts.



The discussion will be preceded by a brief talk by Peter Surda.

Summary: Texas Do Something holds first general meeting
Description: Attend the first meeting of the University of Texas chapter of Do Something. Learn about new service opportunities, eat free pizza, and make Valentine's Day cards for children at the Austin Children's Hospital.

Summary: Longhorn Salsa lessons offered
Description: No experience? No partner? No problem. Join Longhorn Salsa to learn how to salsa dance, meet new people and attend occasional outings around Austin.

Summary: New music ensemble eighth blackbird performs
Description: Texas Performing Arts presents eighth blackbird, with Tim Munro, flutes; Michael J. Maccaferri, clarinets; Yvonne Lam, violin and viola; Nicholas Photinos, cello; Matthew Duvall, percussion; and Lisa Kaplan, piano, combining the finesse of a string quartet with the energy of a rock band to deliver provocative and mind-changing performances.

Summary: Men of Excellence applications available
Description: Men of Excellence is the premier honor organization focused on building relationships with first- and second-year students to help them become successful in their college career. The organization values leadership, mentorship, wisdom, friendship, service, and knowledge. Apply by 11:59 p.m. on Thursday, Jan. 31.

Summary: Introduction to EndNote offered
Description: This introductory class covers tricks for using EndNote with library databases, such as Web of Science, and with indexes and the library catalog. Instructors: special sessions of this class can be arranged for UT groups or departments. Learn more at http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/request.html.

Summary: Spain summer study abroad info session held
