Description: Learn about opportunities to work on your lower-division Spanish requirements while living Spain, and how you can earn International Business credit for the Business Foundations Program. Summer internship opportunities will also be discussed.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Academic writing in the classroom is workshop topic
Description: Learn to teach and assign writing tasks more effectively in your course in this Collaborative Consultation Series workshop. The series engages faculty participants interested in applying new strategies for teaching academic writing.

Summary: Music at the Blanton features Bach Cantata performance
Description: Students and faculty from the Butler School of Music perform Bach's "Ach Gott, wie manches Herzeleid," BWV 3, in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: UT Summer Camps info session held
Description: Join UTeach Outreach for a brown bag "lunch & learn" session on summer camps that are offered for fourth to eighth grade students on campus. Light refreshments served. Email summercamps@uteach.utexas.edu to RSVP or get directions.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: IROM & SSC Seminar Series presents Corey Zigler, Harvard
Description: The IROM Department and the Division of Statistics and Scientific Computation present Corey Zigler of the Harvard School of Public Health with a talk titled "Uncertainty in Propensity Score Estimation: Bayesian Methods for Variable Selection and Model Averaged Causal Effects."

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Moscow Plus summer program holds information session
Description: Enjoy a slice of pizza while learning about this exciting summer program in Moscow. Earn credit for a full year of Russian language in 10 weeks with beginner and intermediate classes. Students with more advanced language skills can earn 6 credits in bridge courses.

Summary: Instructor collaborative learning group meets
Description: The Collaborative Learning Faculty Learning Community provides a place to get, give, share, improve, discuss, support, test and report on the good ideas you have tried - or would like to try - in an effort to make your classes more collaborative and students more engaged.

Summary: Employment basics is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop on how to be a top performer is offered for students employed by UT Austin, and geared toward student employees without prior employment experience in the university environment, as well as experienced student employees who want pointers on good job performance. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: Study Organic Chemistry II in San Sebastian, Spain
Description: Attend an information session about studying Organic Chemistry II in San Sebastian, Spain. A second session is scheduled for Monday, Feb. 4, from 5-6:30 p.m. in PAI 3.14.

Summary: Intro to Photography workshop offered
Description: The Texas Photography Club is hosting a diverse and interactive Intro to Photography workshop. Come ready to click.

Summary: Men of Excellence holds recruitment social
Description: Men of Excellence can help you create a more successful college experience. Join members at this information and social meeting to learn more. Applications due before midnight, Jan. 31.

Summary: Barbara Jordan Statue rededication announced
Description: Members of Afrikan American Affairs and the Epsilon Beta Chapter of Delta Sigma Theta Sorority commemorate the fifth anniversary of the planning of the Barbara Jordan statue on The University of Texas at Austin campus. The groups host a rededication at the statue followed by a reception.

Summary: Business Healthcare Association meets
Description:
Business? Medicine? Not sure? 

Come to BHA's first meeting of the spring semester, featuring guest speaker Leann Gutierrez, associate director for business from University Health Services. Gutierrez will discuss her financial and administrative role in UT's student healthcare system. Free pizza provided.

Summary: Special screening of Acconci's "Theme Song" presented
Description:
Landmarks Video hosts a special screening of its January video, "Theme Song" (1973) by Vito Acconci. Kate Green gives an introduction to Acconci and the video, and the screening is to be followed with a Q&A. Green is writing an art history dissertation about Acconci's performative videos from the 1970s.



Acconci has recently been commission by Austin Art in Public Places to create a new work at the Austin-Bergstrom International Airport.

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents Lead Pencil Studio talk
Description: Lead Pencil Studio, comprised of Annie Han and Daniel Mihalyo, are the spring 2013 Vaulted Gallery Artists-in-Residence at the Visual Arts Center. This artist talk concerns their past projects, as well as their exhibition on view at the VAC, "Diffuse Reflection Lab." Seattle-based Han and Mihalyo have been working together as Lead Pencil Studio since 1997.

Summary: Texas APO information session held
Description: Alpha Phi Omega (Texas APO) is a unique co-ed service fraternity that promotes friendship, leadership and service as well as pride for our university through campus involvement and running the world's largest Texas flag at sports events. Come and meet active members at this session.

Summary: Longhorn Honeys info session held
Description: The Longhorn Honeys is a spirit, social and service organization. They are a close group of young women who work to support athletic teams and create enthusiasm among fans, and strive to help the community through volunteering for several local organizations. Attend this session to learn more.

Summary: Operation Smile meets
Description: Attend the first Operation Smile meeting of the semester. Operation Smile is a nonprofit organization that transforms lives across the globe by funding surgery for children and young adults who are born with facial deformities (specifically cleft lip or cleft palate). New members welcome. Food served.

Summary: Amnesty International holds general meeting
Description: Join Amnesty International this Tuesday to discuss national and international human rights issues and write Urgent Actions to governments requesting change. Visit our website to find out upcoming discussion topics.

Summary: Learn about Engineers Without Borders Panama Project
Description: The Engineers Without Borders (EWB) Greater Austin Chapter is working with the Naso People, an indigenous group in Panama, to improve their access to potable water. Learn more at an EWB meeting or at our website. Contact project leads at panama@ewbgreateraustin.org.

Summary: Your legislature, your voice is civic summit topic
Description:
Many voters assume their job is done on Election Day, but citizens need to stay engaged to hold elected leaders accountable. What does it take to get your voice heard in the Texas Legislature? Join us for "Why Bother? Your Legislature, Your Voice" - a discussion with state legislators, community advocates and the public about how to engage your representatives on issues you care about. Doors open at 7 p.m.



Panelists include Representative Larry Gonzales, Texas District 52; Senator Wendy Davis, Texas District 10; and community advocates.
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), Studio 6A, KLRU

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas Ballroom announces Paid Week
Description: Join Texas Ballroom for Paid Week. No partner or experience necessary. Times vary: Tuesday, Jan. 29, 8-10 p.m., salsa/jitterbug; Wednesday, Jan. 30, 8-10 p.m., waltz/tango; Thursday, Jan. 31, 6-8 p.m., two-step/West Coast swing; Monday, Feb. 4, 8-10 p.m., rumba/jive. Visit texasballroom.org or our Facebook link.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together for one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: Get Fit with GlobeMed offers classes for a good cause
Description: Check out Get Fit with GlobeMed, a three-day series of affordable fitness classes including Nike Training Camp, Zumba and yoga. Proceeds will help Clinica Ana Manganaro in Guarjila, El Salvador, toward the construction of a brand-new community health library. RSVP here: https://www.facebook.com/events/468248429908120/?ref=ts&fref=ts]Facebook Event.

Summary: Texas State Employees Union visits Gregory Gym
Description: The Texas State Employees Union visits campus with an information and sign-up table. The union seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions of all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at UT Austin.

Summary: Paid study seeks students 17-23 with weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend six weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau recruitment held
Description: Meet the women of Sigma Delta Tau as we kick off our spring recruitment. For more information, look for us on Facebook at the link below.

Summary: Christian Faculty Network hosts Women's Prayer Group
Description: Join fellow women faculty and staff for our weekly prayer group meeting. All are welcome.

Summary: Critical thinking is topic of Faculty Learning Community
Description: The critical thinking Faculty Learning Community seeks to help faculty move beyond teaching content and into teaching students to apply complex cognitive skills across a range of topics and problems. Faculty participating in this community learn strategies for teaching students how to think critically and solve problems creatively.

Summary: NISOD hosts webinar on college completion
Description: "Finish What You Start: How One College Doubled Completions" is a webinar featuring Dr. Jason Watts, chief academic officer, Snead State Community College (Alabama). In this talk, Watts outlines a series of simple, high-impact changes Snead State made over the past three years that doubled the number of graduating students. Register below.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese summer info session held
Description: Learn about faculty-led summer programs Salvador, Brazil, and Santander, Spain.

Summary: Swing Out Awards info session announced
Description:
The Leadership and Ethics Institute's Swing Out Awards honor outstanding campus organizations. If you are interested in recognizing a significant accomplishment of your organization during the past year and raising awareness of it on campus, apply for a 2012 Swing Out Award. Apply by Feb. 22. Learn more at this information session. 



If selected as a finalist for a particular category, your organization could be represented at the annual Evening of the Stars in April. Each category winner receives $300, with the most outstanding organization receiving an additional $1,000.

Summary: Solar Design/Build Workshop Series info session held
Description: Attend this session to learn about a spring weekend workshop series offering the unique opportunity to design and fabricate a functional solar charging station for the UT campus. Email soldesignlab@gmail.com for an application or more information.

Summary: UT Solar Design/Build Workshop Series info session held
Description: Attend this session to learn about a spring weekend workshop series offering the unique opportunity to design and fabricate a functional solar charging station for the UT campus. Email soldesignlab@gmail.com for an application or more information.

Summary: Title IX and the future of women's athletics is talk topic
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence introduces the 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series. This week, Chris Plonsky presents "Title IX and the Future of Women's Athletics." Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Campus Environmental Center meetings announced
Description: Campus Environmental Center meetings are back for the spring semester. Join us every Wednesday for food and news of exciting projects that can help change the face of our campus.

Summary: AIESEC Austin holds information session
Description: Learn about interning abroad or becoming a member of AIESEC at an information session featuring free food. AIESEC is the world's largest student-run nonprofit organization. It provides a platform for students to develop professional skills, establish a global network of friends and colleagues and intern abroad.

Summary: Queer artists and their archives to be scholar's topic
Description: The Humanities Institute's lecture series on the theme of Public & Private presents a talk by cultural studies scholar Ann Cvetkovich titled "The Secret Life of Counterarchive: Queer Artists and their Archives." Cvetkovich focuses on the current state of LGBTQ archives and their use by artists to create counterarchives and interventions in public history. A discussion follows.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Longhorn Honeys info session held
Description: The Longhorn Honeys is a spirit, social and service organization. They are a close group of young women who work to support athletic teams and create enthusiasm among fans, and strive to help the community through volunteering for several local organizations. Attend this session to learn more.

Summary: Food Studies Project presents Educated Eater
Description: What is food? What is the Food Studies Project? Attend this information session to find out. Free food served.

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau hosts open house
Description:
Join the women of Sigma Delta Tau for their open house. Come and go as you please or stay and watch the Longhorn basketball team take on Kansas State. For more information, visit us on Facebook at 

https://www.facebook.com/groups/211038925697587/.
Location: Sigma Delta Tau house, 405 W. 22nd St.

Summary: Undergraduate Forensics welcomes guest lecturer
Description: Travis County deputy chief medical examiner Dr. Satish Chundru speaks on forensic science.

Summary: Engineers Without Borders holds Peru meeting
Description: The Engineers Without Borders (EWB) Greater Austin Chapter is working with the Huasta community in the Peruvian Andes to mitigate the effects of climate change on water availability. Learn more at an EWB meeting or at our website. Contact project leads at peru@ewbgreateraustin.org.

Summary: FIMRC, a medical aid group, holds first general meeting
Description: FIMRC is the Foundation for the International Medical Relief of Children. Our Texas chapter helps raise money for FIMRC's cause. This year, funding goes to buy iron supplements and other multi-vitamins for mothers in India. Attend this meeting to learn more. Free pizza served.

Summary: Las Calacas: Exhibit of Oaxacan textiles presented
Description: Las Calacas is a temporary exhibit featuring textiles from a diversity of indigenous groups and regions found in the Mexican state of Oaxaca, among them Coastal Mixtec, Amuzgo, Trique and Tacute. For more information, email grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 1.108

Summary: Apply to mentor at-risk youth with Real Role Models
Description: Apply by 8 p.m., Monday, Feb. 4 to mentor elementary school children through the Real Role Models service organization. No late applications accepted. Application available at link below.

Summary: Lee Chesney's "Interim Whimsey" on display at the Courtyard
Description: The Courtyard Gallery presents an exhibition of work by Associate Professor Lee Chesney titled "Interim Whimsey," on view through April 19. Chesney's work has been exhibited nationally and internationally in competitive and invitational exhibitions throughout the world.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Courtyard Gallery

Summary: Participants needed for language study
Description: The Department of Linguistics seeks native speakers of English ages 18 and over to participate in a study of language processing. A session lasts approximately one hour and pays $10 per hour. Contact utlingpsych@gmail.com for more details.

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Program staff and former fellows host open hours (10 a.m.-3 p.m.) to assist with the application. Students are also encouraged to attend the information session (4-5:30 p.m.). Apply by Feb. 22 at 5 p.m. For accommodations, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Green Fee application workshop held
Description: Get a resume boost and use dollars of your tuition to make UT more sustainable. The easiest way to enact sustainable, lasting environmental change on campus is through the Green Fee Program. Attend this workshop to learn about the application process and possible green projects that you or a team can get funding for and enact.

Summary: Webinar discusses most relevant tech industry legislation
Description: "A Tech Industry View of the Newly Elected: 2013's Most Relevant State & Federal Legislation" is a timely discussion about the new Texas Legislature and U.S. congressional activities and opportunities posing the greatest likelihood of affecting startup and emerging growth businesses.

Summary: Austin Longhorn Club hosts Coach Augie Garrido
Description: Join Texas baseball head coach Augie Garrido for a preview of the 2013 Texas baseball team. Cost of attendance includes a buffet lunch. RSVP today at 512-471-4439.
Location: Frank Erwin Center, Lone Star Room

Summary: Undergraduate research general info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers, and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Natural Sciences holds 2013 Spring Career Fair
Description: The Natural Sciences Spring Career Fair features over 100 employers who hire students from various natural sciences backgrounds.

Summary: "Real Students of SDI" open house announced
Description: Meet the students involved in Student Diversity Initiatives (SDI) and tour the Multicultural Engagement Center and the Gender and Sexuality Center. The afternoon features a scavenger hunt and performances by Queer Chorus, Melody Chang and The Manifest Electric. Free food served. Visit https://www.facebook.com/events/496343653743329/.

Summary: Copyrights and fair use addressed in library workshop
Description: Curious about what exactly fair use is? Have you ever wondered if you can use an image in your academic work? Not sure about the restrictions on performing a piece of music? Copyright attorney Georgia Harper discusses these issues and answers questions.

Summary: LLILAS Faculty Book Series hosts Luis Cárcamo-Huechante
Description: "Ta iñ fijke xipa rakizuameluwün: Historia, colonialismo y resistencia desde el país Mapuche" brings together 14 Mapuche authors who examine many dimensions of Mapuche history, relying on the concept of colonialism as the axis of debate and reflection on historical, political, cultural, and territorial issues. Shannon Speed, Dept. of Anthropology and Jossianna Arroyo, Dept. of Spanish & Portuguese, serve as discussants.

Summary: CMAS hosts art reception
Description: The Center for Mexican American Studies (CMAS) announces the official unveiling of the winning submissions for the Fourth Annual CMAS Student Poster Art Scholarship Competition, highlighting the role of language in Mexican American and Latina/o communities, the power of bilingualism and/or Spanglish. Refreshments provided.

Summary: Museum of the History of Polish Jews is topic of talk
Description: Moshe Rosman, an eminent scholar of Eastern European Jewish history, delivers the lecture "Categorically Jewish, Distinctly Polish: The New Museum of the History of Polish Jews in Warsaw." Rosman is a professor at Bar Ilan University. This is the second of three lectures he will present as a visiting scholar at the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies.

Summary: Deconstructing Django roundtable discussion held
Description:
Attend a roundtable panel discussion with Black Studies faculty on the implications of Quentin Tarantino's recent film, "Django Unchained."



Deconstructing Django features panelists Dr. Daina Berry, associate professor, Department of History and African and African Diaspora Studies Department; Dr. Minkah Makalani, assistant professor, African & African Diaspora Studies Department; Dr. Shirley Thompson, associate professor, American Studies and African & African Diaspora Studies Department and Dr. Kevin Thomas, assistant professor, Department of Advertising.

Summary: Reception for "Interim Whimsey" held at Courtyard Gallery
Description: Join Associate Professor Lee Chesney at the opening reception for his exhibition "Interim Whimsey," on view through April 19.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Courtyard Gallery

Summary: Master of Science in Finance program hosts info session
Description: Learn about the Master of Science in Finance offered by the Department of Finance in the McCombs School of Business, designed for students from a wide variety of backgrounds, including liberal arts, natural sciences, engineering and business. No previous work experience is required. Meeting features snacks and prizes.

Summary: UT Energy Symposium topic is behavior & energy conservation
Description: Thomas Dietz, professor of sociology and environmental science and policy at Michigan State University, presents this week's UT Energy Symposium lecture, "Energy Conservation Behavior and the Behavioral Wedge." Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Women in Transportation holds afternoon get-together
Description: Join the Women in Transportation Seminar (WTS) student chapter for a relaxed evening at São Paulo's Brazilian Restaurant. WTS is an international organization that promotes the advancement of women in the transportation industry through networking opportunities and professional development events. Both women and men are welcome at this event.

Summary: First University Investors Association meets
Description:
The University Investors Association is a holistic finance organization that aims to educate the university community about various investment vehicles and the companies that utilize them. Investment banking, commercial banking, private equity, wealth management and trading form the core of our focus. All majors welcome; tacos served.



Our guest speaker at this meeting will be Charles Murphy, CFA, the portfolio manager at Liberty Park Capital Management, a long/short hedge fund located in Austin.

Summary: Biblical explanation of the Trinity is meeting topic
Description: University Elohim Fellowship meets to discuss the meaning of the Trinity according to the Bible. Contact UEFellowship2012@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: AIESEC Austin holds information session
Description: Learn about interning abroad or becoming a member of AIESEC at an information session featuring free food. AIESEC is the world's largest student-run nonprofit organization. It provides a platform for students to develop professional skills, establish a global network of friends and colleagues and intern abroad.

Summary: Turkish Film Series screens "My Grandfather's People"
Description: Attend a screening of "Dedemin Insanlari" (My Grandfather's People, 2011, dir. Cagan Irmak). Inspired by Irmak's own childhood and family history, this warm family drama takes place among the  challenging socio-political period of the late 1970s and early 1980s in Turkey while relating memories of the 1924 population exchange agreement between Turkey and Greece. Runs 123 min. In Turkish with English subtitles.

Summary: Ice Cream and Info hosted by Sigma Delta Tau
Description: The women of Sigma Delta Tau continue their spring recruitment with Ice Cream and Info. Enjoy an ice cream social and learn more about us. Look for us on Facebook at Sigma Delta Tau Spring 2013 Recruitment.
Location: Sigma Delta Tau house, 405 W. 22nd Street

Summary: The future of ethnic and identity studies is forum topic
Description: The International Socialist Organization hosts a panel and public forum on the future of ethnic and identity studies at The University of Texas at Austin and what we can do to save our centers.

Summary: College Republicans meet
Description: The College Republicans host State Representative James White as a speaker. Enjoy the discussion in a laid-back and friendly environment.

Summary: ONE holds Advocacy in Action letter and call party
Description: The mission of ONE is to raise awareness of extreme poverty on a domestic and global scale through service and advocacy. Participate in a letter and call party as part of our Advocacy in Action Campaign. Learn what you can do, right here in Austin, to make a substantial impact on behalf of those living in extreme poverty.

Summary: Poet Jonathan Galassi reads from his work
Description: Jonathan Galassi presents a poetry reading. Galassi is a poet, translator and long-time publisher at Farrar, Straus & Giroux. His books of poetry include "Morning Run," "North Street" and "Left Handed."
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: CLUTCH Wind Ensemble and Austin Soundwaves perform
Description:
UT's highly successful "CLUTCH" (Compositional Labors of the UT Composer's Hub) Music Series, in conjunction with Austin Soundwaves, presents their second annual special event concert, featuring premieres of seven new works for large wind symphony. Proceeds benefit Austin Soundwaves, an El Sistema-based youth music program in East Austin. 



One of only thirty programs like it in the country (and three in Texas), Austin Soundwaves was founded by the Hispanic Alliance for the Performing Arts in 2011, based on the Venezuelan system of musical education created by José Antonio Abreu in 1975. Austin Soundwaves provides high-quality musical training to students in grades 5-9 through group and private lessons, sectionals, orchestra and wind ensemble rehearsals and performance, and music theory.

Summary: Ethan Azarian performs at the Cactus
Description: Artist, musician and all around nice guy Ethan Azarian returns to the Cactus to bring his unique songs to our stage.

Summary: Landmarks Video screens "Buster," by Kate Gilmore
Description: Landmarks Video presents "Buster" (2011) by Kate Gilmore. Gilmore examines gender roles in as she descends stairs neatly arranged with 150 ceramic pots filled with paint. Though in a fashionable black dress and ballet flats, she kicks and throws the pots, seemingly fighting against the male-dominated art world she inhabits. On view throughout February.

Summary: Sign up to audition for Texas Revue 2013
Description:
Showcase your talent at the Texas Revue, one of UT's best traditions. Contestants are eligible to win $1,500. Sign up at UNB 4.312 by Wednesday, Feb. 13, for the Saturday, Feb. 16 audition. All are welcome; only UT students are eligible for prize money.



Texas Revue is the largest and most diverse student-run talent show held on campus. This annual tradition showcases a variety of acts, including dancing, music and skits performed by student organizations and individual performers. Texas Revue prides itself in choosing diverse and talented acts to produce the most entertaining show possible. With over 55 acts auditioning each year and averaging over 1,000 attendees, Texas Revue has truly made a name for itself.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Student Events Center office 4.312

Summary: Paid study seeks students 17-23 with weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend six weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: ACA 2013 Student Development Scholarship applications due
Description: Are you an undergraduate student working in academic student support services? An orientation adviser, peer adviser or mentor, resident adviser, or in some other position on campus in which you help your fellow students? If so, apply for a $200 Student Development Scholarship offered to UT students who support the vision and values of the academic advising community. Visit link below. Due March 5.

Summary: Researchers seek children 3-7 who do and do not stutter
Description: Researchers seek children between the ages of 3 and 7 who do and do not stutter to investigate the awareness and perceptions of stuttering. If you know anyone that might be interested in having their child participate in the study, contact nicole.bishop@utexas.edu.
Location: Jones Communication Building (CMA) 2.222, UT Speech and Hearing Center

Summary: Food, the City, and Innovation roundtable conference held
Description: The Food Lab at UT presents the Food, the City, and Innovation roundtable conference, a two-day event designed to expand our understanding of the food system, help us think about the relationship of food to global urbanization and explore the potential for entrepreneurship and innovation to improve our food system in the future.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS)

Summary: Undergraduate research science info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research science information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau holds spring recruitment
Description: Meet the women of Sigma Delta Tau as we kick off our spring recruitment. For more information, look for us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/groups/211038925697587/.

Summary: Undergraduates: Live, learn and intern in D.C.
Description: Spend a semester in Washington, D.C., learning firsthand about public policy while interning and taking in-residence courses through the Archer Fellowship Program. Program staff and former fellows host open hours for students seeking assistance with the application. Applications for 2013-2014 are due Feb. 22 at 5 p.m. If you need accommodations for this event, contact Rose Mastrangelo at r.mastrangelo@austin.utexas.edu in advance.

Summary: Psychosocial mechanisms of smoking abstinence discussed
Description: "Psychosocial Mechanisms of Smoking Abstinence" is a talk by Yessenia Castro, PhD, assistant professor at the UT School of Social Work.

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Jen'nan Read
Description: Jen'nan Read, from the Department of Sociology at Duke University, gives a talk titled "What You Don't Know Can Hurt You: Gender and Health Care Utilization Among U.S. Immigrants."

Summary: Undergraduate research general info session held
Description: Attend an undergraduate research information session. Learn about how to contact faculty members, the qualities faculty members look for in undergraduate researchers, and course credit for undergraduate research.

Summary: Public service loan forgiveness explained in 5 easy steps
Description: National student loan expert Heather Jarvis presents "Public Service Loan Forgiveness in Five Easy Steps" in a lecture for public service professionals and students from the university's School of Law and other Texas law schools. Jarvis also covers the details of President Obama's new Pay As You Earn Repayment Plan. RSVP at link below.

Summary: Author of "American Heathens" presents lecture
Description:
Guest speaker Joshua Paddison presents a lecture titled "Chinese Immigrants, Native Americans, and the Religio-Racial Politics of Reconstruction" as part of the 

spring 2013 speaker series sponsored by the Center for Asian American Studies and the Native American and Indigenous Studies Program.

Summary: IROM & SSC seminar series presents Chong Wang
Description:
The IROM Department and the Division of Statistics & Scientific Computation present a talk by Chong Wang, Carnegie Mellon University, titled "New Probabilistic Models for Document Recommendation and Exploration."



The talk describes a new document recommender system that is both predictive and interpretable. It enjoys the advantages of probabilistic topic models and matrix factorization, but outperforms each of them in term of predictive performance.

Summary: Dora Carrington & the Bloomsbury Circle is seminar topic
Description: Biographer and critic Anne Chisolm discusses Dora Carrington and the Bloomsbury Circle. Our understanding of the group of friends and lovers known as Bloomsbury has developed from decade to decade, and Carrington has emerged from the shadow of Lytton Strachey as an artist of underrated talent and a woman of compelling originality.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana, its weekly meeting at the Cactus Cafe for informal conversation in Italian. This Friday, at the beginning of the Tavola, the Italian Club's officers talk about their experiences in Italy.

Summary: Learn about summer study abroad in the UK and Ireland
Description: Attend this information session to learn about affiliated summer programs in the UK and Ireland.

Summary: Linguistics scholar discusses second-language acquisition
Description: Join the French and Italian Department for a talk on second-language acquisition by guest speaker Professor Julia Herschensohn of the University of Washington. Herschensohn will discuss the transfer effects between first and second language as well as processing of grammatical gender of French and Spanish learners.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Texas Judo meets
Description: Learn and practice judo with Texas Judo. People of all skill levels welcome.
Location: Recreation Sports Center (RSC), Martial Arts Room

Summary: Texas swimming & diving hosts Arizona and SMU
Description: The Texas men's and women's swimming and diving teams host Arizona and SMU for two days of competition.
Location: Lee and Joe Jamail Texas Swimming Center

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meet
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Visual Arts Center spring 2013 season opening
Description: Join the Visual Arts Center at the opening reception for the first five exhibitions of the spring 2013 season, including Lead Pencil Studio's "Diffuse Reflection Lab," Diego Bianchi's "Into the Wild Meaning," "New Prints 2012," "Overlapping Impressions: A Study in Contrasting Cognition" and Zoe Berg's "Til sjos (At Sea)." Berg performs at 6 p.m. sharp as part of her show. Skye Ashbrook's Fade In screening begins at 8 p.m.
Location: Visual Arts Center (VAC), Kayem Arbor Entrance on Trinity Street

Summary: Baal Dan Charities holds Date Auction
Description:
Support Baal Dan Charities at the second annual Baal Dan Date Auction. Contestants showcase their talents and personalities through a series of interviews and performances. Prizes are awarded to the top bidders. Tickets available through Baal Dan members and at West Mall and Jester. Doors open at 6:30 p.m.



Baal Dan Charities helps children in need in India by purchasing necessary items for them (food, clothing, etc).

Summary: "The Edge of Peace" is play about war for all ages
Description: A play for all ages, Suzan Zeder's "The Edge of Peace" tells the touching story of a young boy struggling to make sense of a world at war. Produced in partnership with Seattle Children's Theatre. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Feb. 10, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: The Abrams Brothers perform at the Cactus
Description: The Abrams Brothers are a combination of bluegrass, country and folk-rock that has had the Canadian festival circuit up in arms over their potential. Austin audiences are sure to catch on.

Summary: Men's volleyball hosts Purgason Memorial Valentine Classic
Description: Texas men's volleyball honors the beautiful life of brother, friend and teammate Michael "Purgy" Purgason. The Michael Purgason Memorial Valentine Classic features adult and collegiate club teams from all over Texas who compete for ultimate bragging rights. Visit the link below or like us at https://www.facebook.com/texasmensvolleyball. Contact us with questions at utmensclubvb@gmail.com.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. The morning consists of sailing instruction and the afternoon offers a choice of cruising or racing. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Texas Swimming & Diving hosts Arizona and SMU
Description: Attend the final day of competition as the Texas men's and women's swimming and diving teams host Arizona and SMU.
Location: Lee and Joe Jamail Texas Swimming Center

Summary: Minds Without Binds holds general meeting
Description: Attend an engaging group discussion and potluck with members of Minds Without Binds, whose purpose is to to develop social capital to ignite the genius within the individuals and the collective genius of the group.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), African American Culture Room 4.110

Summary: Texas baseball takes on UT baseball alumni
Description: Texas baseball hosts UT baseball alumni for an exciting game.

Summary: Shape-note singing school held
Description: Shape-note singing is one of America's oldest musical traditions, made unique by its participatory, amateur-driven nature and striking, rough-hewn harmonies. This singing school consists of an hour on the practice and history of the shape-note tradition and Sacred Harp singing, followed by an hour of singing from "The Sacred Harp" (Cooper revision). Tunebooks provided.

Summary: Tour Blanton's "Changing American Landscape" exhibit
Description: The wide-open spaces of the American West have beckoned artists since the 19th century. Trace the development of landscape painting from its roots in Europe to its culmination in the 21st century during this tour that features the C.R. Smith Collection of Western Art.

Summary: Men's basketball takes on TCU
Description: Texas men's basketball faces the Texas Christian University (TCU) Horned Frogs. Scout Night and Teacher Appreciation: Discount available for all Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts and guests, as well as teachers and staff. Call 512-232-3865 by noon, Friday, Feb. 1.

Summary: B. Sterling album release show presented at the Cactus
Description: B. Sterling, a 2011 Kerrville New Folk Finalist, is an emerging singer/songwriter always on the hunt for the perfect turn of phrase. This show marks the release of the artist's new CD.

Summary: A Night in the Caribbean brings dance, food, fun
Description: Join the Latin America Network for a night of dance, food and fun as we celebrate the cultures of the Latin American nations of the Caribbean. Free food and drink, raffles and other fun activities provided.

Summary: "The Edge of Peace" is play about war for all ages
Description: A play for all ages, Suzan Zeder's "The Edge of Peace" tells the touching story of a young boy struggling to make sense of a world at war. Produced in partnership with Seattle Children's Theatre. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Feb. 10, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Great Organ Series features James David Christie
Description: James David Christie performs pieces for organ.

Summary: Texas Judo meets
Description: Learn and practice judo with Texas Judo. Newcomers welcome. Additional meetings take place throughout the week. See website for details.
Location: Recreation Sports Center (RSC), Martial Arts Room

Summary: Calling science undergraduate presenters
Description: The Science Undergraduate Research Group (SURGe) seeks science undergraduates to present their poster research at its poster session at the Science Undergraduate Research Fair, on Friday, March 1 at 3-5 p.m. Contact Leslie Ynalvez at surge.events.ut@gmail.com with your name, contact information and poster topic.

Summary: Attend a Research Poster Design class
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by emailing uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or calling 512-471-5949.

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15th.

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau recruitment held
Description: Meet the Women of Sigma Delta Tau as we kick off our spring recruitment. Look for our table on the West Mall or, for more information, look for us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/groups/211038925697587/.

Summary: "The Story of Por Por": A Film by Nii Yemo Nunu and Steven Feld
Description:
Attend a screening of "The Story of Por Por," a film by Nii Yemo Nunu and Steven Feld

(60 minutes, 2012). Drawing on their work with Accra's La Township Drivers Union from 2005-2010, Nunu and Feld chronicle Ghana's intertwined histories of colonial lorry driving and the invention of Por Por, a music for squeeze-bulb truck horns played uniquely for union driver funerals. A Q&A with follows with Steven Feld, distinguished professor of anthropology and music, University of New Mexico.

Summary: CMAS presents postdoctoral fellowship candidate
Description: Eddy Francisco Alvarez, Jr., presents "Cartographies of Hope, Methodologies for Survival: Mapping Memory, Sequins, Love and Other Hallucinations in the Queer Chicana/o, Latina/o Metropolis." Alvarez is a doctoral candidate in the Dept. of Chicana and Chicano Studies at the University of California, Santa Barbara, and a finalist for a CMAS Carlos E. Castañeda Postdoctoral Fellowship in Mexican American Studies for 2013-2014.

Summary: Global Professional Training hosts Middle East session
Description: Are you interested in living, studying or working in the Middle East? Gaining cross-cultural communication and leadership skills? Are you an international student from the Middle East who wants to connect to other students from or studying the Middle East?  If so, consider applying to Global Professional Training: Communicating, Working & Leading in the Middle East. Learn more at this session.

Summary: Asian Studies undergrad Honors info session held
Description: Faculty Honors adviser Dr. Heather Hindman holds an information session to answer questions about applying for departmental honors this April. The Asian Studies Honors program gives students an opportunity to work closely with faculty and to write an independent research paper.

Summary: Former Sec'y of Education William Bennett to speak
Description: Former Secretary of Education William Bennett delivers a public lecture titled "Education Policy and the American Future." A graduate of the university's PhD program in philosophy, Bennett is a respected scholar and academic who has authored 20 books, including two New York Times best-sellers.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA), Julius Glickman Conference Center 1.302B

Summary: Goal Setting is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
A workshop on goal setting is offered for students employed by UT Austin. Learn to create long-term and short-term goals utilizing the SMART goal philosophy and methodology, become familiar with backward planning techniques for effective goal achievement and to develop SMART (Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, Time-bound) goals.



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Free Krav Maga self-defense class offered
Description: University Krav Maga hosts a free seminar to newcomers and veterans alike. Krav Maga is a battle-proven self-defense and combative system used by military, police and special forces across the world, as well as a great workout. Wear athletic clothes; neighboring locker room available for changing.

Summary: Study Organic Chemistry II in San Sebastian, Spain
Description: Attend an information session about the Organic Chemistry II class in San Sebastian, Spain.

Summary: Suicide Prevention is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: The "Be That One" Suicide Prevention Program helps student employees support peers and friends who may be thinking about suicide. Research shows that students who take this interactive workshop feel better prepared to intervene with friends who are in distress. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: UT Undergraduate French Club hosts meet and greet
Description: Join the UT French Club upstairs at Caffe Medici to learn about the club, meet others and play games. This is a relaxed club that welcomes all levels of French speakers.

Summary: Lost and Nameless Orchestra performs at Cactus
Description: Every Monday in February, the "Cactus Artist in Residence" continues with the Lost and Nameless Orchestra - a foot-stomping, fiddle-driven folk-rock quartet.

Summary: Mises Circle discusses socialism & entrepreneurship
Description:
Can rational economic decisions be made in a socialist economy? Join the Mises Circle for a discussion on chapters 2 and 3 ("Entrepreneurship" and "Socialism") of Jesús Huerta de Soto's "Socialism, Economic Calculation and Entrepreneurship." Find the pdf here: http://www.jesushuertadesoto.com/books_english/socialism/socialism.pdf.



Can't join us in person? Tune in to the Google-plus Hangout from anywhere in the world. A link will be posted when we go live.

Summary: Phi Beta Sigma holds informational meeting
Description: The brothers of Phi Beta Sigma Fraternity, Inc., announce their spring 2013 informational meeting. Phi Beta Sigma is an international organization of college and professional men, founded in 1914 at Howard University. It has exemplified its principles - Brotherhood, Scholarship and Service - ever since. Meeting starts promptly at 7:14 p.m.

Summary: New music ensemble eighth blackbird performs
Description: Texas Performing Arts presents eighth blackbird, with Tim Munro, flutes; Michael J. Maccaferri, clarinets; Yvonne Lam, violin and viola; Nicholas Photinos, cello; Matthew Duvall, percussion; and Lisa Kaplan, piano, combining the finesse of a string quartet with the energy of a rock band to deliver provocative and mind-changing performances.

Summary: Students with language disorder sought for study
Description: Participants ages 18-24 with a language disorder are wanted for paid study on language and memory. Native English speakers only. Disorders include diagnosis with a learning disability (including but not limited to ADD, ADHD, auditory processing and dyslexia). Two 90-minute sessions required. Contact Kadee Bludau at kd_bludau@utexas.edu with age, gender, LD diagnosis, availability.
Location: Jones Communication Building A (CMA), UT Speech and Hearing Center

Summary: College of Fine Arts holds diversity focus groups
Description:
Calling all College of Fine Arts students, faculty and staff: The Fine Arts Diversity Committee wants to hear your perspectives, experiences and opinions on diversity and equity in COFA. The committee is conducting focus groups in the college from Feb. 18-28. Sign up at the link below. Food and refreshments provided.

Contact the committee at fadc@austin.utexas.edu with questions.
Location: College of Fine Arts, various locations

Summary: UT Libraries hosts class on finding articles
Description: Learn how to find articles on any research topic using the databases and electronic journals available to the campus community.

Summary: Learn to find books and media in Libraries course
Description: Learn how to find books, e-books, DVDs, CDs, journals and more. Course covers how to use the library catalog, e-books, GoogleBooks and WorldCat. Class is preceded by a tour from 2-3 p.m. that meets at the PCL reference desk.

Summary: UT in Sydney information session held
Description: UT in Sydney for Kinesiology and Health Education majors is a unique opportunity to go abroad with a UT faculty member and spend fall semester 2013 on exchange with the University of Technology, Sydney (UTS), as part of the same program.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese summer info session held
Description: Learn about faculty-led summer programs Salvador, Brazil, and Santander, Spain.

Summary: Perry-Castañeda Library tour announced
Description: This walking tour provides an overview of the service points of the PCL, introducing the key areas in the building, including the periodicals collection, map collection, general stacks, microfilm and group study rooms. Meet at the PCL information counter.

Summary: Global Professional Training hosts Middle East session
Description: Are you interested in living, studying or working in the Middle East? Gaining cross-cultural communication and leadership skills? Are you an international student from the Middle East who wants to connect to other students from or studying the Middle East?  If so, consider applying to Global Professional Training: Communicating, Working & Leading in the Middle East. Learn more at this session.

Summary: Study in Denmark information session held
Description: Learn about study abroad in Denmark. Find out why the Danes are considered the happiest people on Earth and what makes some of Denmark's greatest cities like Copenhagen and Aarhus so exciting.

Summary: "Creating Safe Work Environments" is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: In this workshop, participants become familiar with basic worker safety concepts, learn situational awareness strategies and learn about the important legal protections afforded to employees and what to do in the event of a work injury. Presented by Human Resource Services - HealthPoint.

Summary: Using text data in finance is faculty research talk topic
Description: Dr. Shimon Kogan, assistant professor of finance, presents his research on the utilization of text data in finance. Kogan bridges the fields of finance and computer science to effectively utilize massive amounts of data. Food and drinks provided.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Certificate Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in commercial real estate. Register to attend at link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202 (Center for Business Administration)

Summary: Entrepreneurship Live presents Hemi Thaker, Anue Systems
Description: Entrepreneurship Live presents Hemi Thaker of Anue Systems. Thaker was named Ernst and Young Enterpreneur of the Year 2011 in Central Texas for his passion for solving complex customer problems using leading-edge technology. Food and drink reception follows the talk.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 205

Summary: HDO executive master's degree info session held
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP at link below.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18, Liberal Arts Career Services Suite

Summary: Longhorn Circus practice announced
Description: Longhorn Circus is a student organization geared to the sharing and practicing of circus arts. We practice hula-hooping, acrobatic-yoga, juggling, poi and staff. Supplies are usually provided by the club. Practicing these "flow arts" is an alternative form of exercise. All skill levels welcome.

Summary: Advocacy for nurses is lecture topic
Description: The Texas Nurses' Association District 5 and the UT Association of Nurses in Graduate School co-host a lecture by distinguished UT professor John Daly, titled "Advocacy - Strategies for Nurses: Championing Ideas and Influencing Others." Refreshments provided. Open TNA members and nonmembers. No reservations required.

Summary: Picture yourself in Sigma Delta Tau
Description: The women of Sigma Delta Tau host a night of crafts. Join us for a chance to meet members of Sigma Delta Tau and decorate a picture frame. For more information look for us on Facebook at the link below.
Location: Sigma Delta Tau house, 405 W. 22nd St.

Summary: "180 South" screening hosted with star Jeff Johnson
Description: Attend a screening of "180 South" with special guest Jeff Johnson, star of the film, who discusses the film during a Q&A after the screening. Adventurers, environmentalists and anyone who needs a break from studies are all welcome.

Summary: SFER-Texas holds general meeting
Description: Students for Education Reform (SFER) hosts its first general meeting of the semester. SFER is a nonprofit student organization that aims to spread awareness about educational issues nationally and in the Austin community.

Summary: Longhorn Singers presents spring concert
Description: The UT Longhorn Singers present a choral concert highlighting love in all its forms.

Summary: Hayes Carll performs at the Cactus
Description: Tuesdays in February, Hayes Carll takes the stage to play new songs, old favorites and more. Tuesday performances are solo acoustic shows with occasional guest appearances by friends and fellow musicians.

Summary: Disney's "The Lion King" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description:
Experience the phenomenon of Disney's "The Lion King," with breathtaking animals brought to life by award-winning director Julie Taymor and the pulsating rhythms of an unforgettable score. Runs through Feb. 10; includes matinees. Purchase a Broadway Across America subscription at http://www.broadwayacrossamerica.com/austin or call 800-731-SHOW.



Everyone entering the hall must have a ticket, including children and infants.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "Unlearning Racism" workshop held for faculty and staff
Description: Nationally acclaimed diversity and inclusion trainer and speaker Lee Mun Wah facilitates a workshop for UT faculty and staff titled "Unlearning Racism in Schools." This workshop provides a forum to discover the conscious and unconscious ways in which racism permeates our attitudes and behaviors in our schools and affects our relationships with each other.

Summary: Paid study seeks students with body image/weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: U.S. Business Council on Sustainable Development meets
Description:
The U.S. Business Council on Sustainable Development (US BCSD) and the Environmental Science Institute (ESI) at The University of Texas at Austin co-sponsor the US BCSD Winter Meeting 2013. Learn more at the link below.



US BCSD is a nonprofit business association based in Austin whose members work on authentic sustainability projects with industry, governmental and other key stakeholders. ESI's mission is to foster environmental science research, education and outreach across disciplines.

Summary: Poetry on the Plaza commemorates Harlem Renaissance
Description:
In commemoration of African American History Month, the Harry Ransom Center presents the Poetry on the Plaza event Harlem Renaissance. Invited speakers will read poetry from the Harlem Renaissance, a flourishing of African American arts and culture between the two world wars.



Mark your calendar for the remaining Poetry on the Plaza events this season: Portraits on March 6, Poetry of Sport on April 3 and Singers & Songwriters on May 1.

Summary: Research + Pizza hosts talk on women's health funding
Description: Dr. Joseph Potter of the Texas Policy Evaluation Project discusses funding for women's health programs in Texas. Free pizza provided.

Summary: Knowledge & Noms hosts Be a Good Girl/Act Like a Real Man
Description: Attend this community workshop event to discuss and deconstruct the gender binary. Light snacks provided.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Australia and New Zealand information session held
Description: Attend an information session about the UT-affiliated program in Australia or New Zealand. Arcadia campus representative Todd Karr will give details and answer questions.

Summary: Become an advanced Google super searcher
Description: Learn the mechanics behind Google searches, discover advanced search tricks and use this knowledge to become a superior searcher. This is an online class. For more information, visit link below.

Summary: UK/Ireland summer information session held
Description: Attend an information session on the UT-affiliated summer program in the UK or Ireland. Arcadia campus representative Todd Karr will attend to give details and answer questions.

Summary: Cross-cultural dialogue workshop held for students
Description: Acclaimed diversity trainer and speaker Lee Mun Wah leads a workshop for UT students titled "How to Have a Dialogue Across Cultures." This seminar addresses often awkward issues of cultural differences, and helps participants practice talking to someone who is different from themselves in a compassionate and honest way.

Summary: Course Transformation Program holds academic showcase
Description: Faculty participants from the departments of economics, English and psychology showcase projects from the second cycle of the university's Course Transformation Program. First-cycle participants biological sciences, chemistry and biochemistry and statistics and scientific computation provide highlights of a maturing course redesign and address the challenges of sustainability.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Get money for research, travel and fun in Europe
Description: Attend an enlightening workshop with Drs. Michael Kimmage (Harvard University), Jeremi Suri (LBJ School of Public Affairs) and Mary Neuburger (CREEES, UT) on ways to find funding for travel, study, research and fun in Europe. This workshop will be of significant value to undergraduate and graduate students.

Summary: Cairo, urbanism and political space to be lecture topic
Description: The History Lecture Series Global Lessons, Local Opportunities? presents "Cairo, Urbanism, and Political Space in Transition," a lecture by Diane Singerman, associate professor and comparativist whose research interests focus on political change from below, particularly in the Middle East, and more specifically Egypt.

Summary: Improvisation in customer service is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This hands-on workshop provides you with strategies for delivering quality customer service by incorporating key improvisation principles. You will learn how to put these techniques into practice through group activities and discussion. Presented by the Texas Interdisciplinary Plan.

Summary: Peace Corps info session held
Description: Attend a Peace Corps informational session with the UT representative and guest returned volunteer. Learn about the mission of the Peace Corps, the real volunteer experience, and how you can land the toughest job you'll ever love.
Location: Sanchez Building (SZB), Al Kiva Auditorium 104 (lower level)

Summary: Study abroad information session held
Description: Get more information on the programs offered by the Study Abroad Office and the process of applying to the program.

Summary: Decline of the West is topic of historian's talk
Description:
Dr. Michael Kimmage presents "The Decline of the West," a lecture addressing the rise and fall in affiliation with the West among educated Americans, starting with the early years of the Cold War, when the West was a concept robustly embraced by many Americans, and concluding with the 1980s and 1990s, when this same concept grew less salient and more politicized.



Kimmage is associate professor of history at the Catholic University of America.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Esteban Buch
Description: "Scandal at The Rite: Games of Distinction and Dreams of Barbarism" is a talk by Esteban Buch of the Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales (EHESS) in Paris, France. He is a specialist on the relationship between music and politics in the twentieth century.

Summary: Leadership Series presents Janelle Green
Description: Pathways to Leadership features Janelle Green, assistant director of the University of Texas Leadership and Ethics Institute. Green will lead an exercise to help participants create and customize their own unique pathway to leadership. Visit utlei.com for more information and follow LEI on Facebook at facebook.com/utlei and on Twitter at twitter.com/utlei.

Summary: Dissecting Your First Semester workshop offered
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence introduces the 2013 ACE workshops, beginning this week with a seminar titled "Dissecting Your First Semester: What DidDo Right (and Wrong)?" All events are open to all students, staff and the larger community. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter.

Summary: Texas Athletic Council meets
Description: Support UT Athletics by being a part of the Texas Athletic Council. At this meeting, help make Big Head signs for the student sections at the basketball game on Feb. 9.

Summary: 2013 Lunar New Year Festival celebrated
Description: Join the Asian-American community at UT in celebrating the Year of the Snake. Live entertainment, free games, food and prizes make this an unforgettable evening, so take a study break to experience and explore Asian culture. Attendees encouraged to dress in traditional Asian clothing to bring in the New Year.

Summary: International Gastronomy Society meets
Description: Love to cook? Love to eat good food? Attend the first meeting of the International Gastronomy Society. Contact gastronomyinternational@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Muslims Without Borders holds body meeting
Description: Muslims without Borders Texas holds its first general body meeting of the spring 2013 semester. Meet members and hear about upcoming events. Free food served. You are invited to like our Facebook page, where we will be making announcements about our meetings and events in the future: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Muslims-Without-Borders-UT-Austin/327954723960431.

Summary: Texas Judo meets
Description: Learn and practice judo with Texas Judo. Newcomers welcome.
Location: Recreation Sports Center (RSC), Martial Arts Room

Summary: Open mic held at Cactus Cafe
Description: The Cactus Cafe's Open Stage returns for 2013. Join us once a month to take your turn at singing on our stage. Sign up at 6:30 p.m. for a 7 p.m. start.

Summary: View "Last Chance for Eden" with director Lee Min Wah
Description: Acclaimed diversity trainer and speaker Lee Mun Wah presents a screening of his film "Last Chance for Eden," a documentary in which nine men and women discuss the issues of racism and sexism, examining the impact of society's stereotypes on their lives in the workplace, their personal relationships and their families and communities.

Summary: Dumpling Night hosted by Taiwanese American Students
Description: Celebrate the Lunar New Year with delicious dumplings and tāngyuán (rice balls in soup). Guests can enjoy preparing dumplings or get to know association members as we make them for you.

Summary: Women's basketball takes on Iowa State
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Iowa State Cyclones. The $5 web coupon buys one general admission ticket and a coupon for 25% off your purchase at the Team Shop. Redeemable at Frank Erwin Center Box Office on game day. Medical Community Night features discount for all employees in the medical community and their guests. Call 512-232-3865.

Summary: "The Edge of Peace" is play about war for all ages
Description: A play for all ages, Suzan Zeder's "The Edge of Peace" tells the touching story of a young boy struggling to make sense of a world at war. Produced in partnership with Seattle Children's Theatre. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats. Runs through Feb. 10, including matinees.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Stalin film series begins with "Stalin"
Description: The Center for Russian, East European and Eurasian Studies presents the Stalin Film Series, a collection of movies depicting the lives and struggles of Russians under the rule of Joseph Stalin. Tonight's film, "Stalin" (1992), starring Robert Duval, documents Stalin's rise from obscure revolutionary to feared leader of Russia. In English. Runs 2 hrs, 57 min.

Summary: Paid study seeks students with body image/weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend six weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Investment Competition
Description: The Texas Venture Labs Investment Competition is an annual business plan competition open to all graduate students at The University of Texas at Austin. Judged by local entrepreneurs and investors, 25 student teams will compete this year for a total $10,000 in cash and $135,000 in prizes. Register and learn details at the link below.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Global Environmental Brigade holds bake sale
Description: Support the Global Environmental Brigade by purchasing delicious baked goods and find out how to get involved in a project in Panama. Global Environmental Brigade works to empower rural communities in Panama to reverse degradation and preserve their environment through reforestation, sustainable agriculture, waste management and education programs. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: Phi Kappa Theta holds chili dog sale
Description: The brothers of Phi Kappa Theta invite hungry students to enjoy delicious, cheap hot dogs grilled to perfection. Toppings include chili, cheese and other condiments. All proceeds go to TexasTHON 2013, benefiting the Dell Children's Medical Center.

Summary: Paul Woodruff discusses the power of ancient tales
Description: "Myth as Mirror: The Abiding Power of Ancient Tales" is a talk by Paul Woodruff, a distinguished and beloved professor of philosophy and classics. His latest book, "The Ajax Dilemma: Justice, Fairness, and Rewards," explores the Greek myth of Ajax as a parable of modern dilemmas of fairness and leadership.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Toxicology Seminar hosts UT Health Science Center speaker
Description: Dae Joon Kim, PhD, assistant professor of pharmacology at the UT Health Science Center at San Antonio, delivers a talk titled "Protein Tyrosine Phosphatases in Skin."

Summary: Instructor Learning Community focuses on student outcomes
Description: This Learning Community facilitates the process in which instructors identify student learning outcomes for a unit and design assessments and tasks that align with the desired learning outcomes. We meet for five sessions, every other week. By the end of the semester, you should have a well-designed unit to use in your next class.

Summary: Austin Longhorn Club hosts Football Coach Mack Brown
Description: Join Texas football head coach Mack Brown for the 2013 Recruiting Roundup and get a preview of future Longhorn stars. Admission cost includes a buffet lunch. RSVP today by calling 512-471-4439.
Location: Frank Erwin Center, Lone Star Room

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Indigenous language revitalization is talk topic
Description: John Sullivan, Universidad Autónoma de Zacatecas, discusses indigenous language revitalization in higher education, particularly related to his work as Director of the Zacatecas Institute for Teaching and Research in Ethnology (IDIEZ), a Mexican nonprofit research institute.

Summary: Budget and build credit as a college student
Description: Acclimate your saving and spending style to the college lifestyle. Learn how to create and use a daily budget, save money, maintain and grow a savings account and build credit.

Summary: Emergency preparedness is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides participants with the tools necessary to be a leader in campus emergency preparedness in cases of natural and man-made incidents. This is a multi-media workshop; discussion will be encouraged. Presented by the Office of Emergency Preparedness.

Summary: Impunity, justice & the human rights agenda conference held
Description: The Bernard and Audre Rapoport Center for Human Rights and Justice announces its ninth annual conference, titled "Impunity, Justice and the Human Rights Agenda." Scholars, human rights advocates and policymakers from around the world come together to assess critically the human rights movement's focus on anti-impunity. Conference continues Feb. 8. For details, visit the link below.

Summary: Free Krav Maga self-defense class offered
Description: University Krav Maga hosts a free seminar to newcomers and veterans alike. Krav Maga is a battle-proven self-defense and combative system used by military, police and special forces across the world, and a great workout as well. Wear athletic clothes; neighboring locker room available for changing.

Summary: Changing technology and regulation is lecture topic
Description: Sherman Elliott, consultant and former commissioner at the Illinois Commerce Commission, speaks at this week's UT Energy Symposium. His talk is titled "Emerging Supply- and Demand-Side Technologies Are Pressuring Regulators to Change Course - But Do They Have the Political Will?" Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Alexander Nemerov
Description:
In a talk titled "Kissing in August 1945: Two Visions of the Moment," author Alexander 

Nemerov discusses his book, "Wartime Kiss." A scholar of American art, Nemerov writes about the presence of art, the recollection of the past and the importance of the humanities in our lives today.

Summary: SEC leadership info session announced
Description: Interested in a leadership position within the Student Events Center? Attend this SEC leadership information session to gain insight on what it is to be an SEC committee chair and a leader on campus. Attendance is strongly encouraged. Contact Jennifer Zamora at jzamora@universityunions.utexas.edu if you are unable to attend.

Summary: Marine Science Club holds first general meeting
Description: The Marine Science Club is dedicated to exposing students to different aspects of the marine sciences and fostering exploration of the field among like-minded students through seminars and community activities. Join us for our first general meeting. Pizza served.

Summary: Engineering masters degree info session held
Description: The Engineering Masters Degree Program hosts an information session about the Engineering Management and Software Engineering programs at The University of Texas at Austin. Alumni and current students will be present to answer your questions, following a brief program overview.
Location: J. J. Pickle Research Campus (PRC), Stadium Room 1.130

Summary: Thomas Jefferson, Islam & civil rights to be talk topic
Description:
The Texas Muslim Students' Association presents the first installment of its Inside Islam series. Dr. Denise Spellberg, author and professor in the departments of History and Middle Eastern Studies, discusses the largely unknown but deep-seated origins of Islam in America. For more information, contact Sarah Abdelhadi at utmsa.outreach@gmail.com or Haya Husain at utmsa.admin@gmail.com.

 

Inside Islam is an educational series by the Texas Muslim Students' Association that aims to dispel commonly-held stereotypes by promoting new perspectives of Islam & Muslims.

Summary: Magicians & Charlatans: Author Jed Perl speaks at HRC
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center hosts Jed Perl, art critic for The New Republic, for a discussion about the state of the art world and the future of fine publishing with Peter Kayafas, director of the Eakins Press Foundation. A book signing follows. View a live webcast of this program at www.hrc.utexas.edu/webcast.



Seating is limited. Line forms upon arrival of the first patron, and doors open 30 minutes in advance.

Summary: "The Duchess of Malfi" is topic of special lecture
Description: A special lecture on John Webster's "The Duchess of Malfi" kicks off the American Shakespeare Center's residency at the university. English professor Frank Whigham presents "Sexual and Social Mobility in 'The Duchess of Malfi'." The play is considered by many to be the greatest Renaissance tragedy not written by Shakespeare.

Summary: LGBTQ graduate & professional student mixer announced
Description: The Gender and Sexuality Center (GSC) hosts a mixer for LGBTQ graduate and professional students to meet each other and get more acquainted with the GSC and our resources. Light snacks provided.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Sigma Delta Tau holds craft night
Description: Join the women of Sigma Delta Tau for an evening of crafting.  We would love to get to know you. Learn more at the link below.
Location: Sigma Delta Tau house, 405 W. 22nd Street

Summary: College Republicans meet
Description: The College Republicans is a center-right coalition representing conservatives, libertarians and independents. At this week's meeting, members discuss important and relevant issues of the day. This is a great forum for politically oriented students to voice their opinions and exchange ideas. All students welcome.
