Summary: University Scuba Club meets
Description: The University Scuba Club holds its first meeting of the spring semester to plan dives for experienced divers and discuss classes and training for beginners. Contact us at info@utscuba.com with questions.

Summary: Texas softball plays Texas A&M Corpus Christi
Description: Texas softball hosts the Texas A&M Corpus Christi Islanders in the Texas Classic.

Summary: Longhorn Startup Seminar features Jason Cohen
Description: Entrepreneur Jason Cohen presents "HowMade More Money Through Honesty Than Through Typical Business Behavior." Cohen is the founder of Smart Bear Software and author of "Best Kept Secrets of Peer Code Review." He blogs weekly on startups and marketing from a geek's point of view at http://blog.asmartbear.com/jason-cohen.

Summary: The Trishas perform at the Cactus Cafe
Description: The Trishas present their Bundle Up the Babies Winter Tour, with special guest Courtney Patton.

Summary: Paid study seeks students with body image/weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend six weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Eighth annual McCombs Alumni Business Conference slated
Description: The eighth annual McCombs Alumni Business Conference, "Innovation & Opportunity in a Challenging Economy," features the latest knowledge on today's most pressing business issues and includes presentations and facilitation by distinguished university and McCombs School professors.

Summary: Impunity, justice & the human rights agenda conference held
Description: The Bernard and Audre Rapoport Center for Human Rights and Justice announces day two of its ninth annual conference, titled "Impunity, Justice and the Human Rights Agenda." Scholars, human rights advocates and policymakers from around the world come together to assess critically the human rights movement's focus on anti-impunity. For details, visit the link below.

Summary: Valentine's Day-themed plant sale announced
Description: Get ready for Valentine's Day by picking up flowers in reds, pinks and purples at the Science Undergraduate Research Group (SURGe) plant sale. SURGe raises money to promote undergraduate research and award fellowships to student researchers.

Summary: Teen fatherhood Population Research Center talk topic
Description: Elizabeth Peters, director of the Center on Labor, Human Services and Population at the Urban Institute, gives a talk titled "Economic and Social Consequences of Teen Fatherhood."

Summary: Second Gloria Anzaldúa Luncheon honors Kim Katrin Crosby
Description: QPOCA presents the second annual Gloria Anzaldúa Luncheon: Honoring Feminists of Color. Join us to welcome our guest of honor, Kim Katrin Crosby. Lunch will be served. RSVP to: qpocatexas@gmail.com. Learn more about Kim Katrin Crosby here.

Summary: Positive emotions and physical health are topic of talk
Description: Sarah Pressman, PhD, presents a talk titled "Understanding the Connections Between Positive Emotions and Physical Health" as part of the Department of Human Development and Family Sciences' ongoing speaker series. Pressman's research examines the role that positive emotions and social relationships play in influencing health outcomes.

Summary: John Charles Sisson Memorial Lecture announced
Description: The second annual John Charles Sisson Memorial Lecture welcomes Dr. Bruce Alberts, editor-in-chief of Science Magazine, former U.S. science envoy, professor emeritus, University of California at San Francisco and former president, National Academy of Sciences. His lecture is titled "Biology Past and Biology Future: Where Have We Been, and Where Are We Going?"

Summary: UK/Ireland summer information session held
Description: Attend an information session on the UT-affiliated summer program in the UK or Ireland that includes details on class and location offerings.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Africa Conference Room

Summary: James Banner on 'Academics, Intellectuals, and Popular History'
Description:
No topic is of more intense interest among historians and intellectuals in general than the question of historical scholarship and public discourse--of the application of deeply researched and informed history to public affairs, as well as its interest to members of the public.  Many elements of this question have not been adequately addressed.  Nor has responsibility for the rupture between academic and popular history been fairly apportioned.  What is the situation, and what can be done to address shortcomings on both sides?  



James M. Banner, Jr., is a historian of the United States and the discipline of history.  Formerly a member of the Princeton faculty, he is the author of books and articles on history, teaching, and public affairs, most recently Being a Historian: An Introduction to the Professional World of History (Cambridge).  He was the co-founder, with Joyce Appleby, of the History News Service and has been a moving force behind the National History Center.
Location: Tom Lea Rooms, Harry Ransom Humanities ResearchCenter 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture. This Friday, at the beginning of the Tavola, guest students discuss their experiences living in Italy.

Summary: Learn about summer study in Spain
Description: Study Abroad offers an affiliated summer program in Spain. Stop by our office for information on your choices of location and classes.
Location: International Office, 2222 Rio Grande, Asia Conference Room

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Authority//Rigor exhibits work of design students
Description:
Authority//Rigor is an exhibition of work by design juniors, under the instruction of Jett Butler, creative director of Foda Studio. Refreshments provided.



AUTHORITY: Document a single image, then combine with unrelated typography and phrases chosen by the instructor to create a cohesive series of posters



RIGOR: Choose and define a single act that you can repeat each day, for seventy days. Document each time it is performed.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), lower level

Summary: Texas softball takes on North Texas
Description: Texas softball hosts the North Texas Mean Green in the Texas Classic.

Summary: Dinesh D'Souza debates Andrew Bernstein on Christianity
Description: Is Christianity the source of important truths, moral law and man's rights, and thus profoundly good for mankind? Or is it antithetical to all such values and thus profoundly bad? For the first time ever, a top Objectivist intellectual - atheist Andrew Bernstein - debates a top Christian conservative, Dinesh D'Souza. Unlike others who have debated D'Souza, Bernstein will offer a rational alternative to religion in this debate.

Summary: Mr. McCombs pageant announced
Description: Mr. McCombs is a male beauty pageant that raises money and canned goods for charity. Contestants from various McCombs student organizations come together to compete for the title of "Mr. McCombs" based on talent, personality, and audience support. Winners choose the charity of their choice to give to upon winning. All canned goods donated to the Capital Area Food Bank.

Summary: Wood & Wire album release show announced
Description: Wood & Wire, a four-piece band, honors the purity of acoustic instruments and the gorgeous music a skilled artist can coax out of simple wood and wire. The band celebrates the release of a new CD at the Cactus Cafe.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. The morning consists of sailing instruction and the afternoon offers a choice of cruising or racing. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Scholarship Competition announced
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs, in conjunction with the McCombs School of Business, sponsors the Texas Venture Labs Scholarship. A group of 12 prospective MBA students compete for scholarship packages valued at $175,000. The public is invited to enjoy the inaugural competition. Event details and registration instructions are available at the link below.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday for a variety of tasks for all ages and skill levels. We are UT's first student-run sustainable farm. Tools and supplies provided. Food available but potluck encouraged. Bring work gloves and construction tools if available, as well as water. Closed toe shoes required. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Texas Leadership Summit announced
Description: The second annual Texas Leadership Summit is a campus-wide conference that offers a unique opportunity to interact with a diverse community of student leaders and to develop and refine leadership skills through participation in breakout sessions, group activities and special workshops. Register and learn more at the link below.

Summary: "New Prints 2012" presented by Printmaking Convergence
Description: The UT Printmaking Convergence program holds a showcase designed to elevate knowledge and appreciation of printmaking. Event includes open studios with demonstrations of printmaking processes, a gallery tour and a public reception.

Summary: Texas men's basketball plays Oklahoma State
Description: Texas men's basketball hosts the Oklahoma State Cowboys. Scout Day discount available for all Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts and their guests. Government employee and military appreciation discounts available as well. Call 512-232-3865 for more information. Order by noon, Friday, Feb. 8.

Summary: Twenty-first Great Lecture in Astronomy announced
Description: How and when did the cosmic dark ages end? Dr. Volker Bromm presents the remarkable story of how the first stars and galaxies formed, a few hundred million years after the Big Bang.
Location: Applied Computational and Engineering Sciences Building (ACE) 2.302

Summary: Texas softball takes on Memphis
Description: Texas softball hosts the Memphis Tigers in the Texas Classic.

Summary: Staged readings from Suzan Zeder's work announced
Description:
Audience members are invited to abridged readings of "Mother Hicks" and "The Taste of Sunrise," the first two plays in Suzan Zeder's cherished Ware trilogy. The readings feature dramaturgical commentary from Zeder and photos of the locations that inspired both plays.



Set against the stark backdrop of the Great Depression in Ware, Illinois, "Mother Hicks" introduces the audience to three outsiders: a deaf young man, Tuc; a foundling child, known only as Girl; and a mysterious recluse, Mother Hicks, whom the townspeople suspect of being a witch.



Set in the roaring twenties, "The Taste of Sunrise" tells of the night Tuc, the beloved leading character from Mother Hicks, loses his hearing. Follow him through his experiences at the School for the Deaf and his return to his hometown of Ware, Illinois.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Blanton's "Persuasion" tour explores messages in art
Description: From the church-sponsored art of the 17th century to contemporary artists reflecting on war, poverty and politics, artists have long sought to persuade the masses. Tour the Blanton Museum of Art's permanent collection and examine how artists have communicated messages and meaning from the beginning of time.

Summary: Texas Classic semifinals held
Description: Attend the first and second semifinal games of the Texas Classic softball tournament. Game 2 begins at 6:30 p.m.

Summary: Women's basketball faces Baylor
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Baylor Bears. Wear pink to support breast cancer awareness. For $5 ticket, enter promo code CURE on the promo code page of TexasSports.com or call 512-232-3865; advance sale only by Friday, Feb. 8 at noon. Other discounts available for all Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts, employees in the medical community and Texas Exes members (visit TexasExes.org).

Summary: The Coffee Sergeants perform at the Cactus
Description: Hear the Coffee Sergeants at one of the premier listening environments in Austin.

Summary: Texas Classic softball seeded game announced
Description: Attend the seeded game in the Texas Classic softball tournament.

Summary: Texas Classic Championship and third place game held
Description: Attend the championship and third place games in the Texas Classic softball tournament.

Summary: Celebrate Darwin Day at the Texas Memorial Museum
Description:
Join the Texas Natural Science Center for Darwin Day, a family-friendly event celebrating the 204th anniversary of Charles Darwin's birth and the 154th anniversary of the publication of "On the Origin of Species." Teachers receive four hours of CPE credit but must register here. Contact Christina Cid by Feb. 5 for accommodations if needed.



Travel on your own voyage of discovery as you explore specimens from the TNSC collections similar to those that Darwin saw during his journey while aboard the HMS Beagle. Investigate how Darwin's observations led him to develop fundamental theories of evolution, and learn more about Darwin's influence on modern-day science.

Summary: Sunday Math Circle explores encryption
Description: The Sunday Math Circle presents "Telling Secrets Loudly: Modular Arithmetic and Public Key Encryption" a talk led by Gil Moss of the UT Mathematics Department. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: "The Edge of Peace" is play about war for all ages
Description: A play for all ages, Suzan Zeder's "The Edge of Peace" tells the touching story of a young boy struggling to make sense of a world at war. Produced in partnership with Seattle Children's Theatre. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Green Fee application workshop held
Description: Get a resume boost and use dollars of your tuition to make UT more sustainable. The easiest way to enact sustainable, lasting environmental change on campus is through the Green Fee Program. Attend this workshop to learn about the application process and possible green projects that you or a team can get funding for and enact.

Summary: Cale McDowell Award for Innovation nominations accepted
Description:
Nominations are being accepted for the Cale McDowell Award for Innovation in Undergraduate Studies. The award was established to encourage research or innovation that improves the core curriculum at The University of Texas at Austin. Deadline for nominations is March 29.



Students, faculty and staff members who demonstrate extraordinary effort or strong individual commitment to improving the undergraduate experience through the core curriculum are eligible.

Summary: Valentine's Day contest held by UT Libraries
Description: What do you love about the Libraries? Visit http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/utliblove and tell us for a chance to win sweets and other goodies to keep or share with your Valentine. Enter by the end of the day Thursday, Feb. 14.

Summary: Letter artists sought for research on mobile app design
Description: Participate in a design research study of a mobile app that aims to help artistic people capture their experience and footprints in the form of letter arts. Involves daily surveys and a brief interview. Contact Haoyang Li, master's student in the School of Information, at haoyang.li@foxmail.com with questions.

Summary: Fashion Design Workshop & Conference Series sign-up open
Description:
Learn sewing and pattern-making techniques from a Textiles and Apparel faculty member. The Workshop and Conference Series runs June 10-14 and June 17-21. Choose one week or both; fees and topics covered vary by week. Open to age 16 and up. Space is limited.



Make your own creation as you learn how to take individual body measurements, how to draft patterns and how designers construct garments and patterns. No prior sewing experience necessary. Supplies and snacks provided.

Summary: Lions Club holds Valentine's Day bake sale
Description: The Lions Club holds a Valentine's Day bake sale to raise money for organizations that fight human trafficking. Cookies, cupcakes and cake pops sold.
Location: Jester (JES), West Mall, Gregory Gym Plaza (GRE)

Summary: Stress and sleep deprivation study seeks participants
Description:
The UT-Psychology Human Memory & Decision Making Lab seeks participants for a study of stress and chronic sleep deprivation. Participation involves two separate sessions and the continuous wearing of a small wristwatch device that measures your sleep/wake activity for 21 days. You must be 18 or older with normal or corrected-to-normal vision. Contact Logan at trujillo@psy.utexas.edu.



This study has been approved by The University of Texas at Austin Institutional Review Board.

Summary: Valentine massage special offered by RecSports
Description: Indulge in a 60, 90 or 120-minute table massage during RecSports' Valentine's promotional dates (Feb. 11-17) and RecSports will treat you to two complimentary upgrades (choose from aromatherapy, hot towel, deep tissue, lemon verbena hand treatment or peppermint foot treatment) and a free flower at the time of your appointment. Nonmember pricing is available.

Summary: Paid study seeks students with body image/weight concerns
Description: Male and female students ages 17-23 are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy lifestyle choices. Participants can receive up to $225 compensation over two years. Some participants will attend six weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or email sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Valentine's Day Goodie Bag Special benefits sorority
Description: The sisters of Sigma Delta Lambda sell Valentine's Day goodie bags containing brownies and candy. Special message included. Complimentary photo upon pick up. Proceeds help fund a women's empowering event in April.

Summary: Spanish and Portuguese summer info session held
Description: Learn about faculty-led summer programs Salvador, Brazil, and Santander, Spain.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Capitalizing on employee benefits is Bevonomics topic
Description: Learn about 401(k) plans and other benefits your future employer may offer. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Moving Through Conflict is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: Conflict seems to be a fact of life but does not have to cause anxiety. Explore your personal approach to handling conflict and get a better understanding of how conflict, when moved through effectively, can lead to personal and professional growth. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: GSC Book Club discusses "Will Grayson, Will Grayson"
Description: Attend a discussion of the novel "Will Grayson, Will Grayson," by John Green and David Levithan.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender & Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Global Environmental Brigade holds info session
Description: The mission of the Global Environmental Brigades is to empower rural communities in Panama to reverse degradation and preserve their environment. Attend this meeting to learn more. Food provided. Visit http://www.globalbrigades.org/environmental-brigades-overview, or keep up with our events on Facebook at the link below.

Summary: African American cooperative thought & practice talk held
Description:
Scholar/activist Jessica Gordon Nembhard speaks on the "long, strong, but hidden history" of African Americans in the cooperative movement. 



A political economist and professor of community justice and social economic development in the Department of African American Studies at John Jay College of the City University of New York, Nembhard is the author of the forthcoming book "Cooperative Ownership and the Struggle for African American Economic Empowerment: Alternative Strategies on the Economic Front."

Summary: Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man forum part II held
Description: This forum for men and women features a diverse all-mall panel, from football players to men from the Greek community, and even the gentlemen that Mama says you should "always bring home." The panel will speak about relationships from a male point of view. Friends welcome; two gift cards given to the person with the most guests. Doors at 7 p.m.; event begins 7:30.

Summary: Caribbean Students Association holds general meeting
Description: The Caribbean Students Association holds general meetings every other Monday. Join us in celebrating all aspects of Caribbean culture. Meetings feature free Caribbean food, and a chance to meet other Caribbean students and become involved in our vibrant organization.

Summary: Global Human Rights Brigade holds info session
Description: The mission of Human Rights Brigades is to empower rural communities in Panama who have limited or no access to legal resources to resolve their civil and property disputes. Attend this meeting to learn more.

Summary: The Myth of Sweden is Mises Circle topic
Description: Is Sweden an example of how socialism can work? Join the Mises Circle as we cut through the economic fallacies and discover the true state of the Swedish economy and what we can learn from it. Visit the link below for links to readings. Can't join us in person? Tune in to the Google  Hangout from anywhere in the world. A link will be posted when we go live.

Summary: Secular Student Alliance at UT holds weekly meeting
Description: The Secular Student Alliance aims to foster a community of nontheist students who are committed to reason, critical inquiry, secular humanism-based ethics and the separation of church and state. All are welcome.

Summary: Sustainability lecture asks "Why do my actions matter?"
Description:
"Sustainability: 7 Billion and Counting. Why Do My Actions Matter?" is the second annual sustainability-focused lecture fulfilling the spring 2013 Signature Course University Lecture Series requirement. Dr. John B. Callicott and Dr. Sahotra Sarkar discuss sustainability and the ethics of our personal actions in this lecture.



Callicott is university distinguished research professor and formerly regents professor of philosophy at the University of North Texas. Sarkar is professor of philosophy and integrative biology at The University of Texas at Austin.
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), Studio 6A, KLRU

Summary: Longhorn Salsa offers bachata workshop
Description: Longhorn Salsa hosts a one-time bachata class with local Austin dance instructor Daniel Guzman. Learn this sensual dance from the Dominican Republic just in time for Valentine's Day.

Summary: Real Role Models holds Valentine's Day bake sale
Description: Real Role Models hosts a Valentine's Day bake sale and card-writing event. All proceeds benefit the annual Mentor & Mentee Field Day for at-risk youth in Austin. Cards can be written to sick children at a local Austin hospital to be distributed on Feb. 14.

Summary: Get compensated for your feedback on campus health issues
Description: Campus agency seeks UT students to participate in a confidential, two-hour small-group discussion about health issues and health care. Food, a t-shirt and a $10 gift card to the UT Co-op are provided to all who complete a group. Sessions take place late afternoons/early evenings from Monday, Feb. 25-Thursday, Feb. 28. Visit the link below to sign up.

Summary: Apply to Global Professional Training: Middle East
Description: Apply now for Global Professional Training: Communicating, Working and Leading in the Middle East, a two-day conference for undergraduate students. Students from the Middle East are encouraged to apply for the Cultural Ambassador program. The free conference takes place April 6-7; apply by March 1. Contact international.initiatives@austin.utexas.edu for details or apply online at link below.

Summary: UT Summer Statistics Institute registration is open
Description: Register now to take statistics short courses from May 20-23. Courses taught primarily by UT faculty and offered at all levels in morning or afternoon sessions. Registration closes May 3. Visit the website below for more information and to register. Early registration recommended due to high demand.

Summary: "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" is on display at Ransom Center
Description:
Photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006) created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century. A bold modernist with a superb sense of compositional geometry, Newman is known for a crisp, spare style that situates his subjects in their personal surroundings rather than a studio. Closed Mondays. Visit link for museum hours.



Newman's archive resides at the Ransom Center. Marlene Dietrich, Harry Truman, John F. Kennedy, Arthur Miller, Salvador Dali and Pablo Picasso are only a few of his celebrated sitters. Featuring more than 200 of these well-known masterworks, "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" also includes rarely seen work prints and contact sheets. 

 

The first major exhibition of the photographer's work since his death, the exhibit showcases the entire range of Newman's photography, featuring many prints for the first time.

Summary: UT Red Cross Club hosts blood drive
Description: The UT Red Cross Club and Red Cross of Central Texas co-host a blood drive. Donors are encouraged to set up appointments online at the link below using the sponsor code: longhorn. For specific instructions, visit our Facebook event at  - read more about this event....
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Hall of Honors

Summary: Ransom Center offers free tours of Arnold Newman exhibit
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center offers free, docent-led tours of the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" every Tuesday. The exhibition explores the career of photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006), who created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century. All docent tours begin with a brief introduction to the Ransom Center and the Gutenberg Bible.



A bold modernist with a superb sense of compositional geometry, Newman is known for a crisp, spare style that situates his subjects in their personal surroundings rather than in a photographer's studio. Marlene Dietrich, Harry Truman, John F. Kennedy, Arthur Miller, Salvador Dali and Pablo Picasso are only a few of his celebrated sitters. Newman's archive resides at the Ransom Center. Featuring more than 200 of these well-known masterworks, the exhibit also includes rarely seen work prints and contact sheets.



The first major exhibition of the photographer's work since his death, "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" showcases the entire range of Newman's photography, featuring many prints for the first time.

Summary: Zotero Manage Citations course offered
Description: Learn how to use Zotero, a free, web-based tool, to collect, manage and cite your sources Each session introduces the basics of Zotero and moves on to more advanced concepts to be selected by attendees.

Summary: Study Abroad info session for history majors offered
Description: History majors with an interest in studying abroad are invited to an information session on program and class offerings specifically geared toward the history major.

Summary: Study Abroad in Asia Information Session
Description: Choosing a study abroad program in Asia can be overwhelming. Attend this information session to learn about your choices.

Summary: Make the most of your scholarship search
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships and learn writing tips to improve your application.

Summary: ChE Seminar hosts Tina Ng on flexible printed electronics
Description: "Flexible Printed Electronics: From Materials Characterization to Device Integration" is a paper presented by Dr. Tse Nga Ng, Palo Alto Research Center.

Summary: Collaborative Learning faculty group meets
Description: The Collaborative Learning Faculty Learning Community is a place to get, give, share, improve, discuss, support, test and report on the good ideas we have tried - or would like to try - in order to make our classes more collaborative and our students more engaged.

Summary: Discrimination basics to be topic of S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop provides a guide to policies, rights and resources that empower the employee in the workplace. Review policies in the areas of nondiscrimination, sex discrimination and sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, consensual relationships and disability accommodations. Presented by the Office of Institutional Equity.

Summary: CAAD presents lecture by Nigerian artist Wura Ogunji
Description: The the Center for the Arts of Africa and Its Diasporas (CAAD) presents a lecture by Wura Ogunji on the burgeoning performance art scene in Lagos, Nigeria. Ogunji also discusses her most recent work, "Radio Kaduna," a video performance that premieres at the Menil Collection in Houston on Saturday, Feb. 16.

Summary: Trans training offered by Gender & Sexuality Center
Description: The Gender and Sexuality Center offers an open training session on how to be considerate toward and educated about transgender individuals and the issues they face.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.120

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program. Future sessions also offered Feb. 18 and 21, at 5-6 p.m.

Summary: Time Management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Academic achievement begins with the basics: plenty of sleep, nutritious meals, a balance of work and play, and useful stress-reducing strategies. Having a hard time with any of those? Learn how to practice time management skills, prioritization and other techniques for fitting it all in. Presented by the Sanger Learning Center.

Summary: Views and Brews presents talk on Arnold Newman
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center and KUT 90.5 present a conversation exploring the work of photographer Arnold Newman in conjunction with the Ransom Center's current exhibition, "Arnold Newman: Masterclass." KUT's Rebecca McInroy and Roy Flukinger, Ransom Center senior research curator of photography, delve into the career of Newman, one of the finest portrait photographers of the twentieth century.



Newman's archive resides at the Ransom Center. The exhibition runs through May 12.

Summary: Human cost of India's race for development discussed
Description:
The Association for India's Development, in association with the School of Journalism, presents "The Human Cost of India's Race for Development," a talk and photo exhibit by journalist Priyanka Borpujari.

And independent journalist based in Mumbai, Borpujari speaks about the dark territories of mineral-rich India, which are rife with violence and disease that are kept out of sight. Photo exhibit opens at 4:30 p.m.

Summary: Entrepreneurship Live hosts Satin Mirchandani, MD Buyline
Description: Entrepreneurship Live presents an evening with Satin Mirchandani, a serial entrepreneur and technology executive who currently serves as CEO of MD Buyline, a health-care information services company headquartered in Dallas. Food and drinks served following the program.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator seeks graduate students
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. To be part of the program, students must complete an application process. If selected, students register for three hours of graduate coursework during the fall semester. Learn more at this session.

Summary: Science Study Break topic is science of relationships
Description: Science Study Break presents a talk by Dr. Timothy Loving on the science of relationships. Loving is an associate professor in Human Development and Family Sciences in the College of Liberal Arts.

Summary: Texas MSTC information session held
Description: Learn about the Master's of Science in Technology Commercialization (MSTC) at this information session. The session begins with a presentation by Program Director Dr. Gary Cadenhead, followed by alumni comments and an open forum for questions.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 107

Summary: Flamenco for beginners offered by Grupo Flor y Canto
Description: Grupo Flor y Canto offers a flamenco series focused on the sevillanas, an Andalusian folk dance from Sevilla, Spain. Danced in pairs at festivals and fairs throughout southern Spain, it is often taught as an introduction to flamenco. Contact grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com to preregister. Note: This is not a ballroom dance style.

Summary: American Shakespeare Center presents "Twelfth Night"
Description: The American Shakespeare Center (ASC) returns to campus for two exciting performances. In "Twelfth Night," Shakespeare provides a feast of language and songs in a play that is sublime and subversive, breaking rules and bending gender to show love in all its guises and disguises. ASC follows with John Webster's "The Duchess of Malfi" on Feb. 13 at 7 p.m.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together under one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: Operation Smile meets
Description: Operation Smile is a nonprofit organization that transforms lives across the globe by funding surgeries for children and young adults who are born with facial deformities (specifically cleft lip or cleft palate). Join us in our efforts to spread smiles. New members welcome. Food provided.

Summary: University Flying Club meets
Description: Students who are interested in aviation, becoming a pilot or simply enjoy travel are invited to join the University Flying Club at this meeting. All are welcome. Free pizza served.

Summary: "American Meat" screened on campus
Description: The Campus Environmental Center presents "American Meat," a feature documentary about a grass-roots revolution in sustainable farming and the meat industry in America. A panel discussion with the film's director and other food world experts follows. A free after-party takes place at Chipotle on Guadalupe (food included).
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: Submit your work to the Undergraduate Research Journal
Description: The Undergraduate Research Journal (URJ) is a work of multi-disciplinary research produced and edited by University of Texas at Austin undergraduate students. The URJ seeks interesting and lucid research papers written by past or current undergraduate students. Submit your research online by Feb. 22 at 11:59 p.m. for a chance to be published and eligibility to win a $200 or $100 cash award.

Summary: Register for hands-on science & technology summer camps
Description:
Registration is now open for STEM (science, technology, engineering, mathematics) summer camps hosted by UTeach Outreach. All university faculty and staff get a discount of $50. Camps are open to students entering 4th through 8th grade. Topics also include aerodynamics, research in life science and

geology. Learn more at the link below.
Location: University of Texas at Austin campus

Summary: Passport Day held at McCombs School
Description: Apply for a new passport or renew your old one at the McCombs Business School on Passport Day. Contact bbainternationalprograms@mccombs.utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: CMAS presents postdoctoral fellowship candidate
Description: Marisa Elena Duarte, doctoral candidate in the Information School at the University of Washington, presents "HB 2281: Suppressing Intellectual Freedom in the U.S.-Mexico Borderlands." Duarte is a finalist for a CMAS Carlos E. Castañeda Postdoctoral Fellowship in Mexican American Studies for the 2013-2014 academic year.

Summary: Immigrant detention and incarceration are panel topics
Description: A panel on immigrant detention and incarceration discusses reports of human rights violations at two immigrant detention centers in Texas, as well as the Hutto Visitation Program and the impact of Operation Streamline, a program that shifts immigration into the federal criminal justice system.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 2nd floor conference room

Summary: Critical Thinking Through Creativity FLC announced
Description: The critical thinking faculty learning community helps faculty move beyond teaching content and into teaching students to apply complex cognitive skills across a range of topics and problems. Faculty participating in this workshop learn strategies for teaching students how to think critically and solve problems creatively.

Summary: EndNote for Mac users offered
Description: This introductory class covers some of the tricks for using EndNote on a Mac. Users should bring their Mac laptops with a fully charged battery and a copy of EndNote installed.

Summary: Sustainable Business and Social Enterprise Summit held
Description: The Sustainable Business and Social Enterprise Summit is an inspiring evening of mini-lectures and panels presented by professionals from a wide variety of backgrounds. Issues pertaining to social enterprise, impact investing and sustainability featured. Networking and dinner reception follow. RSVP to https://mccombs.qualtrics.com/SE/?SID=SV_8c9kHKwOr94zhxb or contact Cara Offterdinger at cara.offterdinger@mba13.mccombs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Texas softball plays Stephen F. Austin
Description: Texas softball hosts the Stephen F. Austin Lumberjacks. Purchase 25 or more group tickets to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade and under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offer based on availability. Call 512-232-3865 for details. For $5 Happy Hour ticket offer, enter HAPPY13 on the promo code page of TexasSports.com. Order by noon, Feb. 13.

Summary: Green Fee application workshop held
Description: Get a resume boost and use dollars of your tuition to make UT more sustainable. The easiest way to enact sustainable, lasting environmental change on campus is through the Green Fee Program. Attend this workshop to learn about the application process and possible green projects that you or a team can get funding for and enact.

Summary: Personality in workplace is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In a workshop offered to student employees of UT Austin, unravel the mysteries behind your coworkers' - and classmates' - quirky behavior by exploring personality types, Carl Jung and the theories behind the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. Become aware of your own personality type and the types of others, and explore how personality is expressed in the workplace.

Summary: Sec. of Agriculture Tom Vilsack discusses renewable energy
Description:
U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Tom Vilsack presents a talk titled "Unlimited Opportunity for Homegrown Energy," touching on the current state of the biofuel and renewable energy industries, the promise of advanced biofuels, ongoing research in renewable energy technology and the unlimited opportunity of the bio-based economy for rural communities.

To register for this event, visit the link below.
Location: LBJ School of Public Affairs, first floor, 2315 Red River Street

Summary: Entrepreneurship 101 looks at starting a business
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence's 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series presents Tony Aguilar, "Entrepreneurship 101: What It Takes to Start a Business." A former professional poker player turned social entrepreneur, Aguilar's passion is building organizations and businesses that address social and economic issues. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Heterosexism is seminar topic
Description: The Association of Black Psychologists and the Social Justice Coalition hosts a program on heterosexism. This discussion will provide a definition of heterosexism and describe the cycle that leads to homophobia. Join us to share your opinion or learn more.

Summary: Mind/Body + Healthy Sexuality seminar offered
Description: Feeling stressed? Unbalanced? Attend a seminar on how to balance the mind, body and something most people don't focus on - sexuality.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator info session held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. Attend this session to learn about the organization and the role you, as a graduate student, can play within it. Interested students must enroll in the course next fall.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202 (Center for Business Administration)

Summary: Delta Kappa Delta Sorority presents Service from the Heart
Description: Each year, Delta Kappa Delta Sorority invites students across campus to make Valentine's Day cards for seniors living in Austin-area nursing homes as well as Hospice Austin's Christopher House. We will deliver your handmade cards to the seniors that Saturday. Bring love into someone's heart with a few minutes of your time.

Summary: American Shakespeare Center performs "The Duchess of Malfi"
Description:
The American Shakespeare Center (ASC) returns to campus for two exciting performances. John Webster's brutal and astonishing play "The Duchess of Malfi" tells the story of one of the stage's greatest women and two of its greatest villains. ASC performs Shakespeare's "Twelfth Night" on Tuesday, Feb. 12.



The widowed Duchess of Malfi tragically defies her two powerful brothers by secretly marrying her household steward. When they uncover her deception, the brothers plot a series of horrific events that leads them all to destruction in this dark tapestry of sibling rivalry, forbidden love, unquenchable ambition, and ensuing madness.

Summary: VAC presents "Screening Room" episode with Ed Emshwiller
Description:
"Screening Room," a 1970s television series that aired in Boston, invited independent filmmakers to screen and discuss their work on a commercial affliate station. Attend an episode of "Screening Room" featuring Ed Emshwiller, a major figure in avant-garde cinema and the experimental film movement of the 1960s and 1970s. He was later a pioneer of computer-generated video, combining technology and art.



Presented as part of the Visual Arts Center's Focus Group series, which centers on experimental film in its various formats, including but not limited to 16mm, 8mm and digital video.

Summary: Blackademics live taping held at KLRU
Description:
KLRU hosts a live recording of nationally and internationally renowned black studies scholars as they offer dynamic talks on education, performance and youth empowerment. The event includes talks hosted by Kevin Michael Foster and the Institute for Community, University and School Partnerships (ICUSP). RSVP at link below.



*
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), Studio 6A, KLRU

Summary: Difficult Dialogues looks at "Future of Global Education"
Description:
The forum explores the cultural and political issues surrounding the growth of global university exchange programs. Small group discussion follows panel.



Join scholars Nancy Abelmann, associate vice chancellor for research and professor of anthropology at the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, and Richard Handler, director of global development studies and professor of anthropology at the University of Virgina for this panel presentation.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Undergrad Forensics Organization hosts homicide detective
Description: The Undergraduate Forensics Organization hosts guest speaker Robert Driscoll, a homicide detective. Light snacks provided.

Summary: Men's basketball takes on Iowa State
Description: Texas men's basketball hosts the Iowa State Cyclones. Government employees and guests receive discount. Call 512-232-3865 by noon of game day. A $6 Web coupon is good for one End Court Mezzanine ticket and 25% off your purchase at the Texas Longhorns Official Team Shop at the game. Redeem at the Erwin Center box office on game day.

Summary: David Halley performs with Rich Brotherton
Description:
Singer/songwriter David Halley takes the Cactus stage with guitarist Rich Brotherton.



Halley came to Austin from Lubbock in 1983 and was subsequently featured in "A West Texas Songwriter's Special" (1983) on PBS's Austin City Limits along with Townes Van Zandt, Jimmie Dale Gilmore and Butch Hancock. He is presently working on a recording of unreleased material and beginning to play out again after taking a long leave of absence to care for his young daughter.

Summary: Stalin Film Series presents "Burnt by the Sun"
Description: The Stalin Film Series presents "Burnt by the Sun" (1995, 152 min.), with an introduction by Professor of History Charters Wynn. The film tells the story of a war hero from the Russian Revolution who is targeted by his wife's ex-lover, a member of Stalin's secret police. Directed by and starring Nikita Mikhalkov. Oscar winner for Best Foreign Film, 1994. Russian with English subtitles.

Summary: Club for Environmental Outreach meets
Description: The Club for Environmental Outreach works with partner groups to plan and carry out environmental projects, focusing on education and environmental accountability. Join us at a meeting to learn more about our current projects.

Summary: University Democrats host Houston mayor in Twitter Town Hall
Description: Join University Democrats welcome Houston mayor Annise Parker in a Twitter town hall where students will be able to ask questions via the hash tag #UDems.

Summary: Longhorn Music Camp registration open
Description:
Sign your high school or middle school student up today for a summer Longhorn Music Camp hosted by the Butler School of Music. Middle school students can register for MS Band or String Orchestra camps. High school students can take HS Band, Harp Solo & Ensemble Workshop, Choir, Jazz Improvisation or the Marimba Intensive Workshop. Learn more at the link below.



Instruction provided by outstanding musicians from around the state, with rehearsals, sectionals, master classes and supervised practice. Camps culminate with a required student performance.

Accommodations and all meals may be purchased for an additional residential fee.
Location: Butler School of Music (MRH); forms available online

Summary: Abriendo Brecha Conference on Activist Scholarship slated
Description: The 10th annual Abriendo Brecha Conference brings together artists, community activists and scholars whose work is directed toward social justice. Nearly 50 alumni of our programs have been invited to discuss their distinctive approaches to activist scholarship, and to reflect on their experiences carrying on these efforts throughout the hemisphere, both inside and outside the academy.

Summary: Sesame Street Live presents "Can't Stop Singing"
Description: When Elmo gets his furry fingers on Abby Cadabby's magic wand, there's something in the air - and Sesame Street becomes a nonstop, all-singing, all-dancing musical montage. Multiple daily performances. Check schedule at link below.
Location: The Theatre at the Frank Erwin Center

Summary: Mandarin- & Spanish-speaking children sought for study
Description: Mandarin-English and Spanish-English bilingual children ages 4-7 are sought for a study on vocabulary and grammar development. Testing takes up to four hours and consists of fun word-learning assessment tests. Children receive a prize when finished. Weekend and after-school hours available. Email utchildlanguage@gmail.com or fill out the form at the link.
Location: Visits can be scheduled at location of convenience

Summary: Researchers seek users of online diabetes communities
Description:
Researchers in the School of Information at The University of Texas at Austin seek participants in online diabetes communities for an interview study on how these communities are used for health purposes. To participate, contact danresearch@utexas.edu. Subjects compensated with a $20 Amazon gift card.



Study has been approved by the IRB at UT-Austin, IRB number 2011-12-0036.
Location: UT Administration Building (UTA) 5.510 and 5.516, School of Information

Summary: Business Foundations Summer Institute applications open
Description: Halliburton Business Foundations Summer Institute offers certification in business for nonbusiness majors. Learn more at the link below

Summary: KDCHI & ODPHI V-Day bake sale held
Description: The ladies of Kappa Delta Chi along with the gentlemen of Omega Delta Phi are making life a little sweeter this Valentine's Day. Stop by our bake sale for a homemade treat.

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15th.

Summary: Study Abroad hosts info session on internships in Asia
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Austin Longhorn Club hosts basketball coach Rick Barnes
Description: Join Texas basketball head coach Rick Barnes for an update on the Texas men's basketball team as the Longhorns prepare for postseason play. Admission price includes a buffet lunch. RSVP today by calling 512-471-4439.
Location: Frank Erwin Center, Lone Star Room

Summary: Attend a research poster design class
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by emailing uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or calling 512-471-5949.

Summary: Japan's 3.11 catastrophe is talk topic
Description: Guest speaker Richard Samuels presents "Japan's 3.11 Catastrophe: The Rhetoric of Crisis and Political Change," a talk on how Japanese political entrepreneurs have used the March 2011 catastrophe in Tohoku (3.11) to nudge national policy in the direction of their own choosing. Samuels is Ford International professor of political science at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Refreshments provided.

Summary: Perspectives gallery talk topic is Images of Love
Description: Blanton curatorial associate Catherine Zinser gives a gallery talk on images of love in the Blanton collection.

Summary: Say it with Infographics: Library class offered
Description: Pictures are worth a thousand words. This class surveys ideas, tools and resources for creating charts, graphs and visualizations to display information in a meaningful and less textual way.

Summary: Practica Plática holds Valentine's Day cake pop sale
Description: Practica Plática Spanish conversation group hosts a Valentine's Day cake pop sale. Both cash and cards accepted.
Location: Sidewalk next to Speedway by Gregory Gym Plaza (GRE)

Summary: Ulysses at 90 revisits James Joyce's masterpiece
Description: Ninety years after the original publication of James Joyce's "Ulysses," Dr. Alan Friedman revisits the work often acclaimed as the greatest novel of the twentieth century.

Summary: Early modern Jewish women to be talk topic
Description: Moshe Rosman, an eminent scholar of Eastern European Jewish history, delivers the lecture "Early Modern Jewish Women and the Accumulation of Cultural Capital." Rosman is a professor at Bar Ilan University. This is his final lecture as a visiting scholar at the Schusterman Center for Jewish Studies.

Summary: Transferable skills are S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Being a student employee at The University of Texas at Austin has implications for your future career. Learn to identify transferable skills you are currently gaining, and how to best market these experiences to future employers on a resume and in a job interview. Presented by the Center for Strategic Advising and Career Counseling.

Summary: Regulation of unconventional gas to be talk topic
Description: John Hays presents a talk titled "Recent Developments in Unconventional Gas Law and Regulation" at this week's UT Energy Symposium. Hays is an adjunct professor of energy law at The University of Texas at Austin School of Law and a partner at Hays & Owens LLP. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: University Investors Association hosts guest from KPMG
Description: The University Investors Association hosts guest speakers from KPMG Corporate Finance. University Investors is a holistic finance organization that aims to educate the university community about investment vehicles and the companies that utilize them. Investment banking, commercial banking, private equity, wealth management and trading form the core of our focus. Pizza served.

Summary: Ransom Center offers free tours of Arnold Newman exhibit
Description:
The Harry Ransom Center offers free, docent-led tours of the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass." This exhibition explores the career of photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006), who created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century. Newman's archive resides at the Ransom Center.



All docent tours begin with a brief introduction to the Ransom Center and the Gutenberg Bible.

Summary: New Innervisions Gospel Choir members welcome
Description: In preparation for its biggest concert of the year, College Day, held April 13, Innervisions Gospel Choir welcomes new members to join the family. We rehearse every Thursday at 7 p.m., preceded by 6 p.m. Bible study. Join us for a fun time filled with praise and worship.
Location: University Presbyterian Church,	 2203 San Antonio Street

Summary: Madrigal Theatre Committee presents LOVE
Description: The Madrigal Theatre Committee presents LOVE: A Broadway-inspired musical revue. Enjoy our two performances of three magical stories that intertwine classic and modern Broadway songs, and showcase many types of love: new love, old love, failed love and blossoming love. Performances take place Thursday and Friday.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: Libertarian Longhorns examine marriage equality
Description:
Should everyone have the right to marry the person he or she chooses without the consent of a higher authority? What role should the government play in marital relations? Share your views at this Libertarian Longhorns meeting. 



Libertarian Longhorns is a diverse, issue-oriented, nonpartisan organization dedicated to exposing students to the libertarian philosophies of non-aggression and individual freedom. Learn more at our weekly general meeting.



Ask us about our sister group, the Mises Circle, which focuses on Austrian economics, the school of thought that predicted the housing bubble 10 years before it popped.

Summary: College Republicans hold Game Night with University Dems
Description: Join the College Republicans for a night of fun games on campus with our friends from University Democrats. This is a great way to meet members from both organizations.

Summary: Tom Echols & Leah Nelson with Kithara Duo perform at Cactus
Description: Classical Cactus does Valentine's Day like never before with a show featuring the Kithara Duo - Denton-based guitarists Olga Amelkina-Vera and Fernand Vera - followed by Austin guitarist Tom Echols and Austin Symphony Orchestra violist Leah Nelson, presenting a special duo program just for this occasion.

Summary: Sex in the Animal Kingdom is Science Under the Stars topic
Description:
You may know about the birds and the bees, but do you know about the snails and the sea horses? Courtship and mating behaviors are as diverse as  the species in our world. This Valentine's Day, grad student Victoria Huang talks about how the environment influences an animal's reproduction, and how each individual finds The One (or One Hundred). Arrive early for refreshments and fun activities for kids of all ages.



Science Under the Stars is a free, monthly public outreach lecture series founded and organized by graduate students in the Section of Integrative Biology at University of Texas at Austin. Our goals are to host fun, informal science outreach events for Austin citizens of all ages, and give scientists a venue to share their work with the general public. Events are held at outdoors at Brackenridge Field Laboratory during the fall and spring academic semesters. In the case of inclement weather, lectures are held indoors.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Summary: The Tournées Festival screens new French films
Description:
The Tournées Festival: New French Films on Campus presents two weekends of French films (Feb 15-17 and 22-24) with screenings on 

Friday and Saturday evenings at 7:30 p.m. and Saturday and Sunday afternoons at 4 p.m. 

All films are in French with English subtitles. Learn more at the link below.



The Tournées Festival was made possible with the support of the Cultural Services of the French Embassy in the U.S. and the Centre national de la cinématographie et de l'image animée.

Summary: Volunteers over age 50 sought for website research
Description: Volunteers over age 50 with basic computer skills are sought for research about usability testing of health-related websites. Fill out the questionnaire at the link below. Contact Cara (cara.schlegel@utexas.edu) with questions.
Location: UT Administration Building (UTA), IX Lab 5.510 and 5.516

Summary: SSC Seminar present Chris Hans
Description: The SSC Seminar Series presents Chris Hans, associate professor of statistics at Ohio State University, with a seminar titled, "Structuring Dependence in Regression: Radius Mixtures of Spherically Uniform Priors."

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Adam Gamoran
Description: Adam Gamoran of the Department of Sociology at the University of Wisconsin at Madison, gives a talk titled "Causal Effects of Social Capital on Child Outcomes."

Summary: Author Selina Hastings speaks on "The Red Earl"
Description: John, Viscount Hastings (1901-1990), heir to an ancient earldom, was brought up as a hard-riding philistine, an unquestioning Tory expected to restore the family fortunes by marrying an heiress. Instead, he ran off with a glamorous Italian Communist. In 1931, he met Diego Rivera and became his assistant, accompanying him to Mexico, Chicago and Detroit. This talk is presented by the Red Earl's daughter, Selina Hastings, a writer and journalist.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture. This Friday, at the beginning of the Tavola, guest students discuss their experiences living in Italy.

Summary: Information age research is topic of Libraries course
Description: Learn how to find and evaluate information in the UT libraries and on the Web, and manage your citations. Bring your own research project and questions, and get help from librarians during this workshop. Taught in conjunction with Undergraduate Writing Center staff.

Summary: LabVIEW workshop offered for students and faculty
Description: Learn National Instruments LabVIEW and become a certified LabVIEW associate developer (CLAD) at a weekly workshop that provides an opportunity to take the certification exam free of charge. Bring a laptop computer to the event with LabVIEW installed (visit link below to install). Contact danyhaddad@utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: Get to Know Your ABC's 2013 celebrates Black History Month
Description: The Caribbean Students Association, Black Student Alliance and African Students Association celebrate Black History Month with Get to Know Your ABC's 2013. Join us for an evening of free ethnic food and performances that promises to be a cultural highlight of the year.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Sacramento State
Description: Texas Longhorns baseball hosts the Sacramento State Hornets.

Summary: "Face to Face" celebrates opening of Arnold Newman exhibit
Description:
"Face to Face" is the opening celebration for the photography exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass." Get a first look at the exhibition, enter a drawing for a Newman-inspired prize package and enjoy refreshments. Become a member now to receive complimentary admission and valet parking. Join or order tickets the link below or at 512-232-3669.



Guests will also have the opportunity to pose in one of Newman's iconic portraits in an analog photo booth and to view screenings of Arnold Newman interviews and film clips in the theater.

Summary: Dave Douglas and Joe Lovano present Sound Prints
Description: Grammy-winning saxophonist and composer Joe Lovano and two-time Grammy-nominated trumpeter Dave Douglas bring their all-star ensemble Sound Prints to the Bass Concert Hall stage for an evening of powerhouse jazz. The ensemble features Lawrence Fields, piano, James Genus, bass, and Joey Barron, drums.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Terri Hendrix performs at the Cactus
Description:
Singer/songwriter Terri Hendrix takes the stage at the Cactus Cafe with her eclectic brand of Americana, encompassing folk, pop, country, blues and jazz.



Hendrix is a multi-instrumentalist who has been entertaining audiences for for more than two decades. Her charismatic stage presence and reputation for always delivering an energetic and spiritually uplifting live show explain why the Terri Hendrix "experience" has been embraced by three generations of loyal fans across the country and around the globe.

Summary: Plant trees in the Bastrop Lost Pines
Description: Join the Campus Environmental Center in planting 2,500 trees in the charred forest of the Bastrop Lost Pines. Carpools leave from Littlefield Fountain on the south end of the South Mall at 7:30 a.m. Food provided. RSVP to Trees@UTEnvironment.org to help us plan transportation.
Location: Meet at Littlefield Fountain to carpool

Summary: FE refresher course offered spring 2013
Description: The Fundamentals of Engineering (FE) Refresher Course helps senior engineering students and professional nonstudents prepare for the Engineering-In-Training FE exam. Course meets over four Saturdays: Feb. 16, 23, March 23, April 6. Course is not required to take exam. Each class session presents a brief review of theory and fundamentals, with selected questions answered and problems worked. Register below.

Summary: Gold a-Go-Go Gala After Party held at Blanton
Description: This Valentine's Day weekend, bask in the golden glow of art, lively music and your fellow glamorous guests while toasting the Blanton's 50th anniversary at the museum's first-ever gala after party. Ample refreshments - including custom 50th anniversary cupcakes - will be provided to keep everyone dancing.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. The morning consists of sailing instruction and the afternoon offers a choice of cruising or racing. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday for a variety of tasks for all ages and skill levels. We are UT's first student-run sustainable farm. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Bring food for potluck. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Black Male Summit announced
Description: The Black Male Summit brings distinguished speakers to give their insight and advice on many aspects of life. This year's themes include social entrepreneurship and diversity in the workplace. Dean of Students Dr. Soncia Reagins-Lilly and Student Affairs Administrator Kyle Clark are featured speakers. Free food served.

Summary: Minds Without Binds holds general meeting
Description: Attend an engaging group discussion and potluck with members of Minds Without Binds, whose purpose is to to develop social capital to ignite the genius within the individuals and the collective genius of the group.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), African American Culture Room 4.110

Summary: Texas baseball plays Sacramento State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Sacramento State Hornets.

Summary: 2013 Blanton Museum Gala announced
Description: The Blanton Museum of Art marks its 50th anniversary with an evening in celebration of the art and the people who have made possible this cultural gem for Texas. Join us for a glimpse of the Blanton's dazzling future.

Summary: Turkish Film Series presents "Shadows and Faces"
Description: The Turkish Film Series presents a screening of "Gölgeler ve Suretler" (Shadows and Faces, 2010, 116 minutes), by director Dervis Zaim. In "Shadows and Faces," Turkish Cypriot filmmaker Zaim tackles the tragic intercommunal violence faced by Turkish Cypriots in the 1960s through the story of a father and daughter. Turkish with English subtitles.

Summary: Emily Wolfe performs at the Cactus for live recording
Description: Be a part of the live recording of Emily Wolfe's debut record. "Director's Notes" is rooted in folky-pop melodies featuring Wolfe's unique, soothing vocal quality and inspired lyrics about the ups and downs of young love.

Summary: Apply now for DemTex apprenticeship
Description: Interested in helping to run UT Austin's student-led courses program? Apply to be a 2013-2014 DemTex apprentice. Application available at link below. Contact utdemtex@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Sacramento State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Sacramento State Hornets. Kids ages 14 and under can run the bases and play catch in the outfield following the conclusion of the game.

Summary: Ransom Center offers free Sunday tours
Description: The Harry Ransom Center offers free, docent-led tours of the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass." The exhibit explores the career of photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006), who created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century. Docent tours begin with a brief introduction to the HRC and the Gutenberg Bible.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Office supply swap & recycling event held
Description:
Swap unwanted office supplies for ones you need or clear out clutter. Used writing instruments recycled. Drop off items from 9 a.m.-noon; return to shop from 1:30-4 p.m. Snacks and coffee served for morning contributors. Special recycling also available for keys, e-waste, books, batteries, paper & cardboard, vinyl banners and ink & toner. Drop off anytime during the day.



A second swap takes place Tuesday, Feb. 19, at Anna Hiss Gym (AHG) 135.
Location: San Jacinto Residence Hall (SJH), multipurpose room

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Vicki L. Ruiz
Description: "Las Dos Luisas: Latina Feminist Traditions, 1900-1930" is a talk by Dr. Vicki L. Ruiz, professor of history and Chicano/Latino studies and former dean, School of Humanities, at the University of California at Irvine. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Talk explores relationship between poetry & ethnography
Description: Anthropologist and poet Renato Rosaldo explores the relations between poetry and ethnography in his poetry collection, "The Day of Shelly's Death." What would it mean to write poetry with an ethnographic sensibility - what the author calls antropoesía? Rosaldo, an internationally known cultural anthropologist, will read a set of poems to accompany the talk.

Summary: Political scientist discusses field's "peculiar blindspot"
Description:
"A Peculiar Blind Spot: Why Did 'Radical' Political Theory Ignore the Rampant Rise in Inequality over the Past Thirty Years?" is a talk by Dr. Joseph M. Schwartz, Department of Political Science, Temple University. Schwartz explores why most political theorists have failed to address the debilitating effects of growing inequality on people's lives and on democratic society.



Power, History, and Society (PHS) is faculty-student network dedicated to advancing discussion and collaboration in political, historical and comparative sociology.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program. Another information session is offered on Feb. 21.

Summary: Global Human Rights Brigade holds general meeting
Description: The mission of Human Rights Brigades is to empower rural communities in Panama, with limited or no access to legal resources, to resolve their civil and property disputes. Attend this meeting to learn more.

Summary: UT French Club holds conversation hour
Description: Join the UT Undergraduate French Club upstairs at Caffe Medici for an hour of French conversation. All speaking levels welcome.

Summary: Role of the entrepreneur is Mises Circle topic
Description: Within Austrian economics, there are varying interpretations of the role and nature of the entrepreneur in the marketplace. This week, the Mises Circle examines contrasting viewpoints on the entrepreneur, focusing on Kirzner and Sautet contra Foss and Klein. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: New Music Ensemble performs
Description: The New Music Ensemble commemorates the 60th anniversary of the death of poet Dylan Thomas with two seminal 20th-century pieces based on his writing featuring guest tenor Richard Fracker. Program includes music by Stravinsky, Corigliano, Ives, Gurekis and UT student composer Brandon Rumsey.

Summary: Volunteer for brain imaging research; earn $25/hour
Description:
The Preston Lab at The University of Texas at Austin seeks healthy volunteers ages 18-35 to participate in a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) study of human cognition. Fill out a quick survey at the link below to see if you are eligible.



You may be eligible if you

1. Are right-handed

2. Are not claustrophobic

3. Are a native English speaker

4. Have no history of psychiatric illness or learning disorders

5. Have no recent history of drug or alcohol abuse

Summary: Office supply swap & recycling event held
Description: Swap unwanted office supplies for ones you need or clear out clutter. Used writing instruments recycled. Drop off items from 9 a.m.-noon; return to shop from 1:30-4 p.m. Snacks and coffee served for morning contributors. Special recycling also available for keys, e-waste, books, batteries, paper & cardboard, vinyl banners and ink & toner. Drop off anytime during the day.

Summary: TASA Milk Tea Fund-raiser announced
Description: The Taiwanese American Student Association sells Boba milk tea with funds going to support Culture Night in March.

Summary: Internships in Asia information session held
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Engineering master's degree info session held online
Description: Attend a live online information session discussing the master's degree program geared toward the working professional offered through the Cockrell School of Engineering at The University of Texas at Austin. Programs are offered in Engineering Management and Software Engineering and meet one weekend (Friday/Saturday) a month for two years.

Summary: Shirley Franklin delivers keynote at Barbara Jordan Forum
Description: Former two-term Atlanta mayor Shirley Franklin delivers the opening keynote address at the 17th annual Barbara Jordan Forum luncheon, the kickoff to a week of student-led activities honoring former congresswoman and LBJ School professor Barbara Jordan. The theme for the week, chosen by students, is "See the Change: Pressing Towards Equality of Outcomes." Register at http://barbarajordanforum2013.eventbrite.com/.
Location: LBJ School of Public Affairs, first floor lobby, 2315 Red River Street

Summary: Online identity management is class topic
Description: Have you Googled yourself lately? Learn tips and tricks to present yourself in the best light online and use online social networks to your advantage. At class start time, go to the web address listed below, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher.

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in amounts up to $2,000. Learn more at an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu or visit us online.

Summary: Middle East study abroad info session held
Description: Learn how you could study abroad in Jordan, Egypt, Turkey or Morocco. UT offers exciting study abroad programs in the Middle East as well as scholarship resources.

Summary: Learn to manage your student loans
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Dynamic tailorability of the stem cell niche is talk topic
Description: "Directed Cell Fate in a Couple of Clicks: Dynamic Tailorability of the Stem Cell Niche" is a talk by Dr. Cole DeForest, California institute of Technology. Visit the link below for full abstract.

Summary: The fight for elder justice in the U.S. is talk topic
Description:
Marie-Therese Connolly presents an address titled "How Change Happens: The Fight for Elder Justice in the U.S," as the Law School's second G. Rollie White Public Interest Scholar in Residence, Feb. 18-21. Connolly recently received a MacArthur Foundation "genius" fellowship for her work to prevent elderly abuse. A reception follows.



Connolly is a senior scholar at the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars and former director of the U.S. Department of Justice's Elder Justice and Nursing Home Initiative.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description: Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator info session held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. Attend this session to learn about the organization and the role you, as a graduate student, can play within it. Interested students must enroll in the course next fall.

Summary: Money Talks! presents talk by Beto Pallares
Description: Money Talks! welcomes Beto Pallares, co-founder in 2009 of Cottonwood Capital Partners, the general partner of Cottonwood Technology Fund, a seed and early-stage venture fund with headquarters in El Paso, TX. Food and drinks served following the program.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Learn about HDO executive master's degree
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP at link below.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18, Liberal Arts Career Services Suite

Summary: Texas baseball hosts UT Arlington
Description: Texas baseball hosts the UT Arlington Mavericks. A $10 web coupon is good for one general admission ticket, one free hot dog and a small drink.

Summary: American Studies Film Series screens "Good Hair"
Description:
