In celebration of Black History Month, the American Studies Film Series hosts a free screening of Jeff Stilson's 2009 docu-comedy "Good Hair." The film follows comedian Chris Rock on an international journey to better understand the African American hair industry, prompted by his young daughter's question, "Daddy, how comedon't have good hair?" American studies PhD student Jackie Smith gives a brief introduction to the film.



Watch the trailer here.

Summary: Students for Education Reform general meeting held
Description: Students for Education Reform holds its second general meeting of the semester to discuss issues affecting the education community in Austin. Meetings take place every Tuesday.

Summary: Issues & solutions in Texas Public Education discussed
Description: LULAC and Lambda Theta Alpha host Dr. Deborah Palmer of the College of Education, who speaks about how current legislation and court decisions are affecting the Texas public education system and how citizens can take action against budget cuts. We will also make posters for the upcoming Save Texas Schools Rally on Feb. 23. Visit http://www.facebook.com/LonghornsForSaveTexasSchools?fref=ts.

Summary: Women in Foreign Affairs holds first general meeting
Description: Women in Foreign Affairs is an organization that works to promote the role of women in international fields such as diplomacy, international business and defense/military. To learn more and to get involved, attend our first general meeting of the semester.

Summary: The Knights perform with pipa virtuoso Wu Man
Description: Renowned pipa virtuoso Wu Man performs in concert with progressive New York classical ensemble The Knights, under conductor Eric Jacobsen, for an elegant evening of classic and contemporary chamber orchestra works.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "Refashioning Blackness" is 2013 Lozano Long Conference
Description: The "Refashioning Blackness" conference encourages a cutting-edge conversation about the current political and cultural moment in the Afro-Americas. It asks how scholars and activists can engage in antiracist politics in systems where racial democracy/post-racial ideologies prevail, stifling the impact of black social movements? Embracing blackness, which is often seen as the desirable and logical tactic to counter racism, is an insufficient response.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 2nd floor conference room

Summary: Complete a short survey about your online reading habits
Description: Participate in a short survey on online reading habits. Your input will help researchers design better ways for people to find, organize and share information on the web in ways similar to a physical newspaper.

Summary: Register for St. David's CHPR mental health conference
Description: St. David's Center for Health Promotion and Disease Prevention Research in Underserved Populations (CHPR) presents its 2013 conference, Meeting the Mental Health Needs of Texans. Register by March 22. Early-bird registration (save 20 percent) ends Feb. 28. Continuing education hours available. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: Learn about avoiding plagiarism in Libraries session
Description: Are you confused about what is and isn't plagiarism? Do you wonder how to avoid it as a writer and researcher? This session covers mistakes that can lead to plagiarism, strategies for avoiding these mistakes and practical techniques for using sources correctly. For more information, and to request special sessions of this class, visit link below.

Summary: Launch of Social Justice Library celebrated
Description: The Multicultural Engagement Center (MEC) is proud to announce the launch of its Social Justice Lending Library, a growing collection of books that encourage critical thinking, dialogue and reflection. Mandy Skinner from the Beehive Design Collective, a nonprofit political arts organization, shares the recently completed work, "Mesoamérica Resiste."
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: CMAS presents postdoctoral fellowship candidate
Description:
Lorena Alvarado, finalist for a CMAS Carlos E. Castañeda Postdoctoral Fellowship in Mexican American Studies for the 2013-2014 academic year, presents "Transnational Laments and the Queering of the Ranchera."



Alvarado holds a Doctor of Philosophy in Culture and Performance from the University of California, Los Angeles. She is research scholar at the Center for the Study of Women, UCLA, and a lecturer in Chicano-Latino studies at the University of California, Irvine.

Summary: "Protecting the Elderly in Texas" panel discussion slated
Description: Marie-Therese Connolly, the second G. Rollie White Public Interest Scholar in Residence, facilitates a lunchtime panel on protecting the elderly in Texas. Connolly is the recent recipient of a MacArthur Foundation "genius" fellowship for her work to prevent elderly abuse. She is joined by Bruce P. Bower, Texas Legal Services Center; Dr. Catherine Hawes, Texas A&M School of Rural Public Health; and the Hon. Susan D. Reed, Bexar County Criminal District Attorney. RSVP to RSidopulos@law.utexas.edu.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator info session held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. Attend this session to learn about the organization and the role you, as a graduate student, can play within it. Interested students must enroll in the course next fall.

Summary: iForty Orange Bag holds talk on Smart Thinking
Description: February's iForty Orange Bag features Dr. Art Markman, Department of Psychology and director of Human Dimensions of Organization, discussing smart thinking. Get important tips about how to use the information you already have to be a better, more innovative thinker. No food allowed at this event. RSVP to jstonerice@austin.utexas.edu by Feb. 19.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Attend a research poster design class
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP via email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15.

Summary: Africa's Legacy: Latin American photo exhibit opens
Description: Photographer Tony Gleaton speaks about his exhibition, "Tengo Casi 500 Años: Africa's Legacy in Mexico, Central and South America," on view at the Benson Latin American Collection, Feb. 20-April 1. The exhibit and talk are part of the 2013 Lozano Long Conference Refashioning Blackness: Contesting Racism in the Afro-Americas.

Summary: Stocks, bonds and mutual funds are Bevonomics topic
Description: Find out what these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are, and how they work. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Texas softball plays Houston Baptist
Description: Texas softball hosts the Houston Baptist Huskies. Happy Hour special ticket price is $5 (general admission) before 5 p.m. Enter HAPPY13 on promo code page of TexasSports.com by noon, Wednesday, Feb. 20. Buy 25 group tickets or more to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade & under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offer based on availability.

Summary: Advise TX College Advising Corps info session held
Description: Advise TX seeks recent UT graduates (Dec. 2012, May 2013) to serve as college advisers in low-income high schools in Austin, San Antonio, Corpus Christi, El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley. Advisers help high school students realize their dream of attending college by assisting with college admissions, financial aid and scholarship applications. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Sahaj Marg meditation taught in introductory seminar
Description: Establish a center of peace and balance within yourself through a simple meditation practice. Learn more at this seminar.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator info session held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. Attend this session to learn about the organization and the role you, as a graduate student, can play within it. Interested students must enroll in the course next fall.

Summary: Ethical leadership is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
This training is designed to provide a comprehensive and interactive perspective on ethics and integrity-based leadership. Participants will reflect on personal values and how they influence ethical leadership and decision making. Participants will also be introduced to an approach for evaluating and making ethical decisions. 



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Business Honors Program holds sophomore transfer session
Description: The Business Honors Program (BHP) of the McCombs School of Business provides a world-class education, countless opportunities and a tight-knit student community. Learn more about the application process, meet the recruiting team and ask questions about BHP student life.

Summary: Longhorn Startups presents Bob Metcalfe
Description: Professor of Innovation Bob Metcalfe, Murchison Fellow of Free Enterprise, presents a lecture titled "Longhorn Startups: Learn to Operate the Machinery of Free Enterprise." Find the Leadership and Ethics Institute (UTLEI) on Facebook at www.facebook.com/utlei and on Twitter at www.twitter.com/utlei.

Summary: Health promotion career panel and networking event held
Description: The Texas Health Promotion Club hosts a career panel and networking session. Meet health promotion professionals and learn more about the many careers made possible by a health promotion degree. Learn about internships and volunteer opportunities during the networking portion. Light snacks provided.

Summary: Texas head diving coach presents "Olympic Lessons"
Description: The 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series of the Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence welcomes speaker Matthew Scoggin, presenting the talk "Olympic Lessons." Now in his 19th season as Texas head diving coach, Scoggin has clearly established Texas as one of the nation's premier diving programs. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: International Gastronomy Society meets
Description: Love to cook? Love to eat good food? Attend the second general meeting of the International Gastronomy Society, where the topic is Spanish gastronomy. Contact gastronomyinternational@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Nilsson Lecture memorializes Dylan Thomas
Description:
The 8th annual David O. Nilsson Lecture in Contemporary Drama and Literature presents a Dylan Thomas musical redux memorializing the 60th anniversary of the Welsh poet's death. The event features a performance by The University of Texas New Music Ensemble under the direction of Dan Welcher, featuring guest tenor Richard Fracker.



Fracker performs Igor Stravinsky's "In Memoriam Dylan Thomas," David Diamond's "I Have Longed to Move Away" and John Corigliano's "Poem in October" as well as original works by UT composers Chris Prosser and Brian Heim, inspired by the Welshman's work.



The New Music Ensemble is widely regarded as one of the best student ensembles of its kind nationwide.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 3.200

Summary: "The Invisible War" screened
Description: Attend a screening of "The Invisible War," Academy Award nominee for Best Documentary Feature. The documentary was made in the hope of exposing the epidemic of sexual assault in the military. This screening is a 60-minute version of the film, followed by a panel discussion and a reception with light refreshments. Doors open at 6 p.m. Arrive early.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Elisha Marshall Pease is focus of Odyssey lecture
Description: Dr. Fred McGhee,a historical archaeologist, green builder and author of the recently published "Two Texas Race Riots," contextualizes the story of Elisha Marshall Pease within broader Texas and U.S. history. Pease came to Texas from the north in search of a better life and played a pivotal role in the social, political and economic development of the Lone Star State.

Summary: Hindu YUVA hosts weekly activities
Description: Hindu YUVA hosts weekly activities include yoga, games, discussions and exercise.

Summary: Indian Cultural Association holds dance clinic Jhoom
Description: Learn how to dance like a Bollywood pro at a clinic teaching two 45-second routines. Free food served to attendees.

Summary: Women's basketball plays Kansas
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the Kansas Jayhawks.

Summary: Stalin film series presents "Burnt by the Sun 2"
Description:
The Stalin Film Series screens "Burnt by the Sun 2," the 2010 sequel to Nikita Mikhalkov's "Burnt by the Sun." In Russian with English subtitles; 181 minutes. The ongoing Stalin Film Series presents a collection of movies depicting the lives and struggles of Russians under the rule of Joseph Stalin.



Director Mikhalkov's sequel, in which he also stars, is set on the Eastern Front of World War II. It had a production budget of $55 million, the largest ever in Russian cinema.

Summary: The Hillbenders perform at the Cactus
Description: The Hillbenders take the stage at the Cactus Cafe with special guest Silas Lowe. The dynamic bluegrass quintet from Springfield, Missouri, performs high-octane shows, with tight harmonies and stunning instrumental prowess.

Summary: National Residence Hall Honorary holds recruitment mixer
Description: The National Residence Hall Honorary is the premier organizational branch of the National Association of College and University Residence Halls. Its members are composed of the top 1 percent of leaders, servers, recognizers and students living in on-campus residence halls. Learn more at this gathering.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: March 1 is Architecture internal transfer deadline
Description: Current UT Austin students may apply to transfer to the School of Architecture by March 1. Eligibility requirements and FAQs are available at the link below.

Summary: AIESEC Austin Global Village seeks participants
Description:
Are you a globally minded student or part of an organization that looks to promote cultural awareness? 

Partner with AIESEC Austin to help spread global awareness and celebrate cultures from all around the world at our Global Village on March 20.

Email globalvillageaustin@gmail.com or contact us on Facebook: http://facebook.com/aiesecaustin.

Summary: UT Energy Forum announced
Description: The UT Energy Forum is an event where diverse communities engage each other on the latest developments in energy policy, energy markets and energy technology research. Keynote speakers include Ben Brigham of Anthem Ventures and Trevor Houser of Rhodium Group.

Summary: Wildflower Center hosts tree nursery seedling extraction
Description: Help the Campus Environmental Center/Green Fee tree nursery at the Wildflower Center extract pine tree seedlings for reforesting the Bastrop Lost Pines and for planting during the The Project 2013, UT's largest volunteering event. More information available at the link below. For carpool or other questions, email Trees@UTEnvironment.org.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: International Mother Language Day remembrance held
Description: The Bengali Students Association hands out flyers on the West Mall to mark International Mother Language Day. This day commemorates those who lost their lives on Feb. 21, 1952, in Bangladesh fighting for their language. Visit our table to learn more about the language movement and Friday's memorial event.

Summary: Mayo Clinic professor to speak on multiple myeloma
Description: Leif Bergsagel, M.D., professor of medicine, Mayo Clinic College of Medicine, presents a toxicology seminar titled "Lessons from a Genetically Engineered Mouse Model of Multiple Myeloma (GEMMMM)."

Summary: BFSA Black History Month Summit announced
Description: The Black Faculty and Staff Association Black History Summit focuses on strategies to address mentorship and campus climate challenges.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Asian/Asian American Faculty & Staff Association meets
Description: Join AAAFSA for its February membership meeting and a talk titled "Between the Past and the Present: Understanding the Rise of China," by Dr. Huaiyin Li, professor of history and Asian studies; Lunch provided (includes vegetarian/vegan options). RSVP to sona.shah@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration & Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in "Restoration and Revelation: Conserving the Suida-Manning Collection," an in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect  centuries-old works of art.

Summary: One Thing Clothing Drive held by Texas Do Something
Description: Donate that one thing you never wear to homeless teens at this event, sponsored by Texas Do Something.

Summary: Internships in Asia information session held
Description: Students, work with premier organizations in China, Hong Kong, South Korea or Thailand in an exciting and meaningful internship that will help set you apart from the crowd. Attend this information session to learn about these exciting programs. The meeting also covers the new Freeman Stipend for Internships in Asia.

Summary: Texas men's tennis hosts doubleheader
Description: The Texas men's tennis team hosts a doubleheader. At 1:30 p.m., the team takes on UT Arlington; at 6 p.m. they face Texas A&M - Corpus Christi.

Summary: Staff Council holds monthly meeting
Description: The monthly meeting of the Staff Council is open to all staff and all are encouraged to attend.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. 



University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Living off-campus is Bevonomics workshop topic
Description: Prepare yourself for the move to live off-campus. Familiarize yourself with popular student areas around Austin, expenses, safety and your rights and responsibilities as a tenant. Co-presented by  Legal Services for Students.

Summary: Blanton's Third Thursday is evening of art, activities
Description: Attend the Blanton's free evening of art and activities. Enjoy an extended happy hour in the Blanton Cafe, featuring gourmet pizza. Evening includes Beat the Rush concert (5:30 p.m.), Art Gazes with Ray Williams (6 p.m.), Yoga in the Galleries (6:30 p.m., passes distributed from 5:30) and docent-led tour (7:30 p.m.).

Summary: Field of Childhood Studies is topic of presentation
Description: Professor Lynne Vallone of Rutgers University presents a talk on Childhood Studies in the academy, examining how it engages with other multi-disciplinary fields such as American studies, gender studies and media studies. She will also discuss the birth and development of the Department of Childhood Studies at Rutgers - the first such department in the U.S. granting doctoral degrees.

Summary: "Shut Up & Shoot Me" screened with Q&A
Description: Attend a screening of the black comedy "Shut Up and Shoot Me"(UK & Czech Republic), introduced by producer Jeffrey Brown, who  discusses his experiences making films in the Czech Republic, Africa and elsewhere. Q&A to follow the screening.

Summary: Rebecca McGinnis & Amanda Allison give Art Education talk
Description: The Art Education Lecture Series presents "Accessibility for Art Education" with Rebecca McGinnis and Amanda Allison. McGinnis is the museum educator overseeing Access and Community Programs at The Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York. Allison is coordinator of the Art Education Program at Texas Christian University.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program.

Summary: Texas Venture Labs Accelerator info session held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator connects local startup companies with talented and entrepreneurial graduate students from the MBA, Law, Engineering, and Natural Sciences programs. Attend this session to learn about the organization and the role you, as a graduate student, can play within it. Interested students must enroll in the course next fall.

Summary: Learn to be a top performer at S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop on how to be a top performer is offered for students employed by UT Austin, and geared toward student employees without prior employment experience in the university environment, as well as experienced student employees who want pointers on good job performance. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: Art therapy is topic of Third Thursday at COFA
Description: Interested in a career in art therapy? Meet Deanna Miesch, founder of Art Therapy Austin, who discusses her work and how to succeed as an art therapist. Each month, the College of Fine Arts Career Services' Third Thursday events introduce a different presenter covering topics specific to fine arts.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: VAC presents performance and screening with Zoe Berg
Description: The Visual Arts Center presents "Like a Desert Mirage: Once a Mountain, Now a Hole," a performance by Zoe Berg as part of her exhibition "Til sjøs (At sea)." The work will be staged in Berg's whimsical set, installed in the Center Space gallery, followed by a screening of selected videos with transmedia professor Michael Smith and a brief Q&A.

Summary: UT undergrad French Club holds social
Description: The French Club holds its first social. Join us for delicious food and French conversation practice in a relaxed setting.
Location: Rancho Rio Food Trailers, 26th and Rio Grande

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship discusses the Water of Life
Description: The University Elohim Fellowship meets to explore, according to the Bible, who gives us the Water of Life in this age. Just as our bodies need water to live, our spirits need the water of life to live eternally, and we gather to seek the answer to this important question through the Bible. Email us at UEFellowship2012@gmail.com.

Summary: Survey Research & Questionnaire Design seminar offered
Description: The Office of Survey Research (OSR) conducts a seminar on basic survey research and questionnaire design concepts for current students. This seminar is perfect for students who are or will be engaged in a survey research project and have limited or no experience designing surveys or drafting questionnaires. Register at link below; click on the "OSR Seminar Series" link.

Summary: RTF community screenings series presents "High Noon"
Description:
The Radio-Television-Film (RTF) Department kicks off a four-part series of free community screenings with Charles Ramirez Berg (Joe M. Dealey Sr. professor in Media studies) presenting the classic Hollywood Western "High Noon" (1952), starring Gary Cooper, Grace Kelly and Katy Jurado. A Q&A and brief discussion of cinematic techniques follows the screening.



A former National Endowment for the Humanities Fellow, Ramirez Berg was recently appointed to the National Film Preservation Board of The Library of Congress. He is a member of the Academy of Distinguished Teachers and has won every major teaching award at The University of Texas.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium

Summary: National Association of Black Journalists meets
Description: At this meeting, learn about study abroad opportunities specifically designed for communication students.

Summary: Anna's Yoga Workshop hosted by Longhorn Wellness Club
Description: Stressed? Yoga can help you reach a new level of harmony and fitness. Anna's Yoga Workshop is open to participants of all skill levels.

Summary: Black women's panel asks "What is good hair?"
Description: Attend a panel discussion among Black women faculty, staff and students on the subject of hair. Panelists will attempt to answer questions and dispel myths while discussing hair textures and styles, interactions with other races about their hair and why the issue of hair is important to many Black women. There will be an anonymous Q&A during the panel.

Summary: Religion, spirituality & LGBTQ identities are talk topic
Description: Living with Pride presents an informal discussion about LGBTQ identities and religion and spirituality. Snacks provided.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Libertarian Longhorns movie night presents "Beer Wars"
Description:
If you're in college, you've probably had at least some contact with beer. But have you ever stopped to consider how the beer industry operates, and how the government has played a role in keeping smaller, subjectively better beer companies from garnering a larger share of the market?  Join Libertarian Longhorns for a screening of "Beer Wars." Pizza served.



Do you generally identify with Republicans on fiscal matters but tend to agree with Democrats on issues of social equality? You might be a libertarian. Libertarian Longhorns is a diverse, issue-oriented, nonpartisan organization dedicated to exposing students to the libertarian philosophies of nonaggression and individual freedom. Learn more at our weekly general meeting. 



Libertarian Longhorns promotes idea transparency, free markets, free people and sound money. 



Ask us about our sister group, the Mises Circle, which focuses on Austrian economics, the school of thought that predicted the housing bubble 10 years before it popped.

Summary: Poet, critic & translator Susan Stewart gives reading, talk
Description: Prize-winning poet, literary critic and translator Susan Stewart presents a reading and talk. A chancellor of the Academy of American Poets, she has been honored with numerous fellowships from the NEA, the Pew, Guggenheim and MacArthur Foundations, and the 2003 National Book Critics Circle award for "Columbarium," a poetry collection.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: CLUTCH presents new music by UT composers
Description: CLUTCH celebrates the early arrival of spring with a concert of fresh new music by UT composers. Hear works by Egemen Kesikli, Joelle Zigman, Brandon Scott Rumsey, Michael Mikulka, Brian Heim and Matthew Jackfert. Webcast begins streaming a few minutes before the performance. Visit link below to listen.

Summary: College Republicans host endorsement meeting
Description: College Republicans invite all students to attend our endorsement meeting for candidates for Student Government, Texas Media, Student Union and other posts in the 2013 Campus-Wide Election. This is an opportunity to meet some of the candidates directly and ask questions. Endorsement decisions will be reserved for dues-paying club members only.

Summary: Black Watch & Band of the Scots Guards play Erwin Center
Description: Embark on a historical and musical journey with "British Isles of Wonder," featuring the Band of the Scots Guards and the pipes, drums, highland dancers of the Black Watch, 3rd Battalion, Royal Regiments of Scotland perform. Together, the bands will celebrate the music of Scotland, England, Ireland and Wales with traditional marches, drums, bagpipes, pageantry, dancing and more.

Summary: Between Someonesons is world-class juggling act
Description: Scandinavian jugglers Patrik Elmnert and Wes Peden present their new flamboyant juggling show, "Between Someonesons."  Through their use of space, time, bodies and objects, these dynamic young jugglers build a personal and vibrant atmosphere full of giant movements and bizarre twisted tricks. Presented in conjunction with the 20th annual Austin Jugglefest.

Summary: "The Stonewater Rapture" presented by Round About Players
Description: Round About Players presents "The Stonewater Rapture," a play by Doug Wright. Whitney and Carlyle, two West Texas teenagers, struggle to practice what they believe is right while reaching the peak of their sexual awakening. The play portrays the complex and painful relationship between the constraints of religious faith and our inner desires.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: Will T Massey plays the Cactus
Description: Will T Massey plays the Cactus Cafe with special guest Jon Grossman. Rolling Stone magazine calls Will T "an original voice from Texas," and Time magazine opines that in his music, "the restless soul of Hank Williams matches up effortlessly with a rock 'n' roll heart."

Summary: Help designers create mobile app to track daily expenses
Description: Participants are sought for a survey by the developers of a mobile app that keeps track of daily expenses and income. Visit link below to participate

Summary: The Tournées Festival screens new French films
Description:
The Tournées Festival: New French Films on Campus presents its second weekend of French films, with screenings on Friday and Saturday evening at 7:30 p.m. and Saturday and Sunday afternoon at 4 p.m. All films are in French with English subtitles. Learn more at the link below.



The Tournées Festival was made possible with the support of the Cultural Services of the French Embassy in the U.S. and the Centre national de la cinématographie et de l'image animée.

Summary: Students sought to fill out roommate survey
Description: Living with roommates can be challenging. Graduate students in the School of Information are creating a website to make it easier. We want to hear from you so that we can make the website as useful as possible. Visit the link below to fill out this 10-minute survey.

Summary: Celebrate National Recreational Sports & Fitness Day
Description: Celebrate National Recreational Sports & Fitness Day by enjoying free access to all facilities and group exercise classes at RecSports (classes only for currently enrolled students and RecSports members). Free five-minute chair massages will be offered at Gregory Gym from 2-5 p.m. as well. A detailed schedule is available below.

Summary: West Mall plant sale announced
Description: The Science Undergraduate Research Group (SURGe) hosts its monthly plant sale. This month's specials include bromeliads, jade, grafted cacti, ivys, foliage and succulents. SURGe raises money to promote undergraduate research and award fellowships to student researchers.

Summary: Indigenous presence is topic of anthropologist's talk
Description: James Clifford, professor, History of Consciousness at UC Santa Cruz, presents a talk titled "Indigenous Presence and the Shapes of History" as part of the 2012-2013 UT Department of Anthropology Speaker Series, "The Long Hand: Anthropology, Writing, and Inscription."

Summary: Language practices of Japanese diaspora examined by panel
Description: Language practices of the Japanese diaspora in the U.S. and Brazil are the focus of a panel. Chiho Sunakawa, Ph.D., anthropology, speaks about the reconstruction of Japanese families via webcam. Tomoko Sakuma, Ph.D., linguistics, lecturer in Japanese Language, discusses language ideologies in a Japanese Brazilian cultural association in São Paulo, Brazil. Attendees welcome to bring their lunch.

Summary: Population Research Center series presents David Yeager
Description: David Yeager, Department of Psychology, gives a talk titled "Social Psychology Outside the Lab: Do Experiments Conducted with College Students Generalize to the U.S. Population?"

Summary: Texas Foreign Language Education Conference (TexFLEC) held
Description: Blending the Boundaries in the Age of Globalization: Trends, Challenges, and Innovations in Language Education is the TexFLEC 2013 conference. TexFLEC is an annual graduate-student-run conference that brings together researchers and educators in the fields of foreign language education, TEFL/TESL, bilingual education, linguistics and applied linguistics. Learn more below.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA) 1.302A Glickman Conference Center

Summary: Is there feminism in the Hebrew Bible?
Description: Attend a fun, critical exploration of the story of Purim and the Book of Esther with Rabbi David Komerofsky.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Peers for Pride presents Acting for Change
Description: Support the fifth cohort of Peers for Pride in their first public performance, an interactive event in which audience members participate in conversations with the monologue characters. Attendees are welcome to arrive late or leave early.

Summary: 2012-13 McCraw Lecture Series presents Tim Lightfoot
Description: Tim Lightfoot, Ph.D., professor in the Department of Health and Kinesiology at Texas A&M University, presents a talk titled "Is Voluntary Physical Activity Really Voluntary?"

Summary: Health equity beyond Affordable Care Act is lecture topic
Description:
Attend a live webcast of the 15th annual William T. Small, Jr., keynote lecture at the 34th annual Minority Health Conference. The address, by Brian D. Smedley, VP and director, Health Policy Institute, Joint Center for Political & Economic Studies is titled "Taking Action to Achieve Health Equity: Beyond the Affordable Care Act." St. David's Center for Health Promotion Research is a viewing site for this interactive Internet broadcast, which includes a live telephone and email Q&A session. Learn more about the conference at 

http://studentorgs.unc.edu/msc.

Summary: John Spurling discusses Sir Edmund Gibson & British Raj
Description: Playwright, critic and novelist John Spurling discusses the life of his great-uncle, Sir Edmund Gibson, who joined the Indian Civil Service in 1910. Extracts from Sir Edmund's diaries and letters convey what it was like to be part of the "machine" that ran this part of Britain's vast imperial territory in the period leading toward its independence.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: From Evidence to Argument is undergrad writing workshop
Description: Trying to write an argument? Come to this class with your own project, and learn to identify your claims and assumptions; then find and interpret evidence to support those claims. Taught in conjunction with Undergraduate Writing Center staff. For undergraduates.

Summary: Renowned Chinese writer Kenneth Pai to speak
Description: Professor Bai Xianyong, aka Kenneth Pai, presents "Literature and History: From Taipei People to My Father and the Republican China," a talk connecting his best known story collection, "Taipei People," and "My Father and the Republican China," a photo-biography of Bai Chongxi, the famous Nationalist general. Talk delivered in Mandarin Chinese.

Summary: Undergraduate Writing Center writers present reading
Description: Published writers who work, or previously worked, at the Undergraduate Writing Center present a reading. Listen to the work of Alyssa Harad, Owen Egerton, Michael Erard, Susan Schorn, Vince Lozano and Mary Hedengren.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC), Student Reading Lounge, first floor

Summary: Texas softball plays Lamar
Description: Texas softball hosts the Lamar Cardinals.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Robert Bullard discusses environmental justice movement
Description:
Dr. Robert Bullard, known as "the father of environmental justice," presents an insightful account of events, individuals and organizations that have shaped the environmental justice movement over the past two decades, and describes a framework for how advances in environmental justice can and should be achieved. Pre-lecture fair starts at 5:45 p.m. Lecture starts at 7:p.m., with Q&A at 8:15 p.m.



Hurricane Katrina provided a startling reminder that environmental health threats such as pollution and climate change disproportionately affect historically disadvantaged communities in our society. Some progress has been made in environmental law and governance, policy and planning in the United States, yet major work lies ahead in order to eliminate disparities and achieve the goal of global health and sustainability.

Summary: Texas softball faces Tulsa
Description: Texas softball hosts the Tulsa Hurricane. Purchase a minimum of 25 group tickets to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade and under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offed based on availability. Call 512-232-3865 for details.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Nebraska
Description: Texas baseball hosts old Big 12 rival, the Nebraska Huskers.

Summary: China Care holds fourth annual Benefit Night
Description: China Care hosts its fourth annual Benefit Night with the theme of Time Travel. Get ready to rock to the 50s, sing the 60s, dance with the 80s and jam to the 90s and 2000s at a night you won't want to miss. Learn more at the link below. Tickets sold Feb. 18-22 in Jester. Ticket purchasers automatically entered into raffle.

Summary: Butler Opera Center presents "Les Enfants Terribles"
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents "Les Enfants Terribles," a Philip Glass opera inspired by Jean Cocteau's 1929 novel of the same title.

Summary: International Mother Language Day memorial event held
Description: The Bengali Students Association commemorates International Mother Language Day, celebrating the beauty of cultural and linguistic diversity and in remembrance of those who lost their lives fighting for their language on February 21, 1952, in Bangladesh. The program includes performances and other acts illustrating that historic day.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Brian Regan brings his comedy to PAC stage
Description: Brian Regan has distinguished himself as one of the premier comedians in the country.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Bruce Robison & Kelly Willis perform at the Cactus
Description: When is the sum of the parts of a musical quantity far greater than the whole? When Kelly Willis and Bruce Robison unite as an ongoing musical act. Hear the pair live at the Cactus Cafe.

Summary: Undergraduate Writing Center holds celebration & symposium
Description: To commemorate its 20th year serving student writers, the Undergraduate Writing Center hosts The Future of Writing Centers, a symposium featuring writers, teachers and tutors from the U.S. and Canada.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Project 2013 is day of volunteer service
Description: Volunteer with 2,000 of your fellow Longhorns at UT's largest day of service. The Project brings UT students and staff out for a full day of work in one of Austin's most underserved neighborhoods. Visit utproject.org to sign up, read more about Project 2013, the Dove Springs neighborhood and the impact you can make with a single day of service.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Saturday Morning Math Group presents statistics talk
Description: The Saturday Morning Math Group presents "Statistics in Clinical Trial Design," a talk led by Dr. Peter Mueller of the UT Mathematics Department. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: Texas softball plays Utah State
Description: Texas softball hosts the Utah State Aggies. Purchase a minimum of 25 group tickets to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade and under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offer based on availability. Call 512-232-3865 for details.

Summary: Connoisseurship workshop held at Blanton
Description: Blanton Curator of Prints and Drawings and European Paintings Francesca Consagra teaches the basics of evaluating Old Master print impressions in this special workshop. Email publicintern@blantonmuseum.org to register and learn more. Enrollment is limited.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Prints & Drawings Gallery, first floor

Summary: Texas baseball plays Nebraska
Description: Texas baseball hosts old Big 12 rival, the Nebraska Huskers.

Summary: Ransom Center offers free Saturday tours
Description: The Harry Ransom Center offers free, docent-led tours of the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass." The exhibit explores the career of photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006), who created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century. Docent tours begin with a brief introduction to the HRC and the Gutenberg Bible.

Summary: Texas softball semifinals game 1 announced
Description: Texas softball hosts first game of semifinals.

Summary: Second annual Dr. Ramshorn Competition announced
Description: Engineering men and women show off their beauty, talents and skills in the Cockrell School's Dr. Ramshorn Competition. The festivities feature special guest, Gigglepants comedy group. Enter the Ramshorn Raffle by donating unused school supplies to support the next generation of engineers. Learn more at the link below or visit our Facebook here.

Summary: Texas softball semifinals game 2 announced
Description: Texas softball hosts second game of the semifinals.

Summary: Men's basketball plays Kansas State
Description: Texas men's basketball hosts the Kansas State Wildcats. Family fun packs include one end court mezzanine ticket, hot dog and 16 oz. drink for only $10. To purchase, call 512-232-3865; advance sale only. Minimum purchase is three packs.

Summary: Gaby Moreno plays the Cactus
Description: Singer/songwriter Gaby Moreno performs a range of music, from blues and jazz to soul and R&B.

Summary: Texas Softball Championship third-place game held
Description: Attend the Texas Softball Championship's third-place game.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Nebraska
Description: Texas baseball hosts old Big12 rival the Nebraska Huskers. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals.

Summary: Write poetry about art at Blanton Museum workshop
Description: The Blanton is proud to have inspired great poems by Texas writers. This spring, find your creativity in a workshop taught by poet Vive Griffith. Participants will learn forms and techniques for creating new poems about artworks in the museum. Email publicintern@blantonmuseum.org for registration and information about these free classes.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), Dell Classroom

Summary: Voices for Reproductive Justice (VRJ) holds meeting
Description: Voices for Reproductive Justice holds a general meeting that includes a presentation on Texas's 83rd Legislative Session titled "What Is Ahead for Women's Health." In support of the reproductive justice movement, VRJ educates and advocates for the human right to make personal reproductive decisions.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), LBJ School of Public Affairs, 3.124 (use south entrance)

Summary: Nominate faculty and/or staff for AAAFSA RAISE award
Description: The Asian/Asian American Faculty & Staff Association's RAISE awards recognize outstanding faculty and staff members at the university who demonstrate a strong commitment to our campus or manage student concerns with positive, constructive support. Nominees must be full-time faculty or staff. Find the form at the link below. Submit by March 22 to raise.award@gmail.com or campus mail to Alex Pong at GIAC N5580.

Summary: UGS Week highlights School of Undergraduate Studies
Description: Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Week presents events for UGS and undeclared students, as well as a few events open to all. Visit the Facebook page at the link below to learn more.

Summary: Stuttering research seeks adults who stutter
Description: The Dr. Jennifer and Emanuel Bodner Developmental Stuttering Lab seeks stuttering adults for a study on how adults who stutter process speech and language in the absence of speech production. Participants receive $30 monetary compensation and parking reimbursement for two 90-minute sessions. Contact austin.stuttering.project@gmail.com or visit link below.
Location: Jones Communication Building (CMA) 2.222, UT Speech and Hearing Center

Summary: Healthy older adults, 65-80, sought for research study
Description: Researchers seek healthy older adults to study the role of dietary flavanols on the maintenance of vascular health. Contact Michelle Harrison (michelle.harrison@utexas.edu) if interested in participating.

Summary: National Instruments LabView Campus Tour announced
Description: See the latest technologies for measurement, control, embedded and communication applications at the National Instruments LabView Campus Tour.

Summary: Official class ring promotion week held
Description: Be a part of the class ring tradition. The official UT ring can be ordered through March 1. Balfour representatives will be on hand to answer questions and help you order. Payment plans are available. Eligible students who order their rings by Friday, March 1, receive a personal invitation to ring ceremonies, held in April.
Location: Etter-Harbin Alumni Center (UTX), 2110 San Jacinto Boulevard

Summary: Research participants sought for variety of experiments
Description: The Maddox Lab seeks volunteers to participate in a wide variety of categorization and decision-making experiments. Contact the lab at maddoxlab@psy.utexas.edu to set up an appointment. Each session lasts 1-2 hours and pays $8 per hour.

Summary: "Zero Dark Thirty" & torture in American discourse discussed
Description: Dr. Ramzi Kassem, associate professor of law and director of the Immigrant and Non-Citizen Rights Clinic, CUNY Law School, focuses on how the Oscar-nominated film "Zero Dark Thirty" has reignited the controversy about the place of torture in American policy. Kassem explores what the ongoing debate reveals - and obscures - about American counterterrorism efforts and the United States' current legal and moral standing.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Jeremy Friedman
Description: "La Via Pacifica versus Class Warfare: Allende's Chile and the Sino-Soviet Split," is a talk by Dr. Jeremy Friedman, who is currently a postdoctoral fellow in grand strategy in the International Security Studies program at Yale University. Jonathan C. Brown, professor of history at UT Austin, responds. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: AIESEC international internship info session held
Description:
Interested in interning abroad? 

Attend an AIESEC info session to learn how you can work paid or unpaid, in a business-type setting or community development. Internships range from 6 weeks to 18 months. AIESEC is affiliated with 113 countries worldwide.

Summary: Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley speaks at CWGS FDP Colloquium
Description: Dr. Omise'eke Natasha Tinsley presents "To Transcender Transgender: Haitian American Choreographies of Gender Fluidity in the Performances of Mildred Gerestant," a talk on Haitian American performance artist MilDred Gerestant, who shot to fame in the 1990s drag king scene as a smooth mackdaddy who played with and subverted stereotypes of African American masculinity.

Summary: Golda Meir is topic of scholar's talk
Description: Professor Pnina Lahav presents a lecture titled "Golda: Fifty Shades of Gold." Lahav teaches constitutional law, political and civil liberties, and comparative law at Boston University. She served as a fellow at the Center for Advanced Studies at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem in 2008.

Summary: Inclusive Leadership is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In this workshop, participants develop inclusive leadership skills and better equip themselves to work with a diverse group of people. Concepts such as social  identities and inclusion will be introduced. Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Impact of globalization on India's environment discussed
Description: Kanchi Kohli, a researcher, writer and campaigner working on environment, forest and biodiversity governance in India, presents a talk titled "Post-Globalization Challenges to Environmental Governance in India."

Summary: Radcliffe Bailey discusses work with Michael Ray Charles
Description:
Join Atlanta-based artist Radcliffe Bailey and UT professor of art Michael Ray Charles for a conversation about Bailey's recent work, his exploration of personal and historical narratives, and the transmission and interpretation of African and African American history within contemporary art.



Additional funding for this event is provided by the Carolyn Harris Hynson Centennial Endowment at the Blanton Museum of Art.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Longhorn Circus practice announced
Description: Longhorn Circus is a student organization geared to the sharing and practicing of circus arts. We practice hula-hooping, acrobatic yoga, juggling, poi and staff. Supplies are usually provided by the club. Practicing these "flow arts" is an alternative form of exercise. All skill levels welcome.

Summary: Eating Disorders Anonymous meets
Description: Eating Disorders Anonymous welcomes members who struggle with food and healthy eating, the only requirement being a desire to recover. Meetings take place weekly. Please note time change. Contact Hilary at hjmkoo@utexas.edu for more information.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Center for Students in Recovery (basement)

Summary: Nigerian writer E.C. Osondu reads at BookPeople
Description: The New Writers Project presents an evening with E.C. Osondu, visiting writer in fiction, appearing as part of the New Writers Tour, a reading series that introduces emerging authors that people are already talking about. Osondu is the author of the story collection "Voice of America" and was awarded the 2009 Cain Prize for African Writing.

Summary: Longhorn Lockpicking Club meets
Description: Join us for an eye-opening introduction to responsible hobbyist lockpicking that will change the way you think about physical security. The club meets every other Monday. Visit www.longhornlockpicking.com for the exact schedule.

Summary: Caribbean Students Association holds general meeting
Description: The Caribbean Students Association holds general meetings every other Monday. Join us in celebrating all aspects of Caribbean culture. Meetings feature free Caribbean food, and a chance to meet other Caribbean students and become involved in our vibrant organization.

Summary: Housing crisis is this week's Mises Circle topic
Description:
Join the Mises Circle for a discussion on the housing boom and bust, focusing on Mark Thornton's 2006 paper "The Economics of Housing Bubbles." In the midst of the bubble popping, Thornton offered a substantial "I told you so." View the paper here: http://mises.org/journals/scholar/Thornton13.pdf.



Can't join us in person? Tune in to the Google  Hangout. A link will be sent out when we go live.

Summary: Texas Do Something hosts general meeting
Description: Attend the third general meeting of the University of Texas chapter of Do Something. Vote for our next service opportunities and help sort clothes donated in One Thing drive.

Summary: Women with body image concerns sought for research study
Description: Women ages 17 and older with body-image concerns are sought for a research study designed to promote healthy body image. Participants can receive up to $165 compensation over three years. Some participants will attend four weekly meetings on campus. Call 512-232-2334 or e-mail sticelab1@utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in any amount up to $2,000. To learn more, attend an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu, or visit us online.

Summary: Information Security Certificate info session held
Description: The Computer Science Undergraduate Advising Center holds an information session for computer science students on the Information Security Certificate. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Music at the Blanton features Bach Cantata
Description: Students and faculty from UT's Butler School of Music perform Bach's "Sei Lob und Ehr dem hochsten Gut," BWV 117, in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: Heart health is topic of brown bag lunch talk
Description: At this brown bag luncheon on heart health, Marciela Wilson, RN, from Seton Healthcare Network, explains the causes of heart disease and stroke, lifestyle changes you can make to protect yourself and how to recognize the signs and symptoms of a heart attack and stroke. Sign up on TXClass PN 277 or email healthpoint.wellness@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Rebels' use of terrorism in civil wars is talk topic
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law announces "Do Terrorists Win? Rebels' Use of Terrorism and Civil War Outcomes" with Page Fortna, Columbia University. Refreshments provided. Fortna is professor of political science and a member of the Saltzman Institute of War and Peace Studies.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Author discusses how to build an active, happy retirement
Description: Informal Classes presents Peter Spiers, author of "Master Class: Living Longer, Stronger, and Happier," speaking on how to build a vibrant and happy retirement. Through inspirational stories from active seniors, supported by research in psychology and neuroscience, Spiers shares his book's findings on how to break out of a daily routine and build an enriching and active lifestyle.

Summary: Sanger Center hosts job information session
Description: The Sanger Center is among the largest student employers on campus. Attend this information session to learn more about the variety of positions available for fall 2013. For hiring information, search for Sanger Learning Center at the link below.

Summary: Advise TX College Advising Corps holds info session
Description: Advise TX seeks recent UT graduates (Dec. 2012, May 2013) to serve as college advisers in low-income high schools in Austin, San Antonio, Corpus Christi, El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley. Advisers help high school students realize their dream of attending college by assisting with college admissions, financial aid and scholarship applications. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Gender-inclusive clothing and book swap announced
Description: Swap your clothes and your books at this event. All genders welcome.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Green Fee application workshop held
Description: Get a resume boost and use dollars of your tuition to make UT more sustainable. The easiest way to enact sustainable, lasting environmental change on campus is through the Green Fee Program. Attend this workshop to learn about the application process and possible green projects that you or a team can get funding for and enact.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Sam Houston State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Sam Houston State Bearkats. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Quality customer service is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This hands-on workshop provides you with strategies for delivering quality customer service by incorporating key improvisation principles. You will learn how to put these techniques into practice through group activities and discussion. Presented by the Texas Interdisciplinary Plan.

Summary: Business Honors Program holds sophomore transfer info session
Description: The Business Honors Program (BHP), part of the McCombs School of Business, provides a world-class education, countless opportunities and a tight-knit student community. Learn more about the application process, meet the recruiting team and ask questions about BHP student life.

Summary: Forty Acres Fest first mandatory info session held
Description: Forty Acres Fest takes place Saturday, April 6. This information session is the first of two mandatory meetings for all organizations that will be participating. Participating organizations must attend one of two mandatory meetings. The alternate meeting takes place at 6 p.m. on Feb. 27, in the SAC auditorium. Applications are at link below. Priority deadline to apply is Friday, March 8. Regular deadline is Friday, March 22.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governor's Room 3.116

Summary: Texas MSTC information session held
Description: Learn about the Master's of Science in Technology Commercialization (MSTC) at this information session. The session begins with a presentation by Program Director Dr. Gary Cadenhead, followed by alumni comments and an open forum for questions.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 107

Summary: VAC presents Art in Practice with George Scheer
Description:
Art in Practice welcomes George Scheer, co-founder and executive director of Elsewhere, a living museum, international residency program and educational laboratory in Greensboro, North Carolina. 



Art in Practice is a program series that provides guidance and insight into the professional world for students preparing for careers in the arts. Topics of conversation range from a nuts-and-bolts approach to gaining valuable job skills, to broad issues relevant to creative culture as a whole.

Summary: Forum discusses fracking boom and the Texas legislature
Description: KUT's StateImpact Texas reporter Mose Buchele moderates a panel of Texas legislators - including State Senators Rodney Ellis (Houston) and Carlos Uresti (San Antonio), and Texas state representative Tryon Lewis (Odessa) - discussing the prospects for new laws about fracking during this legislative session. Doors open at 6 p.m.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), second-floor auditorium 2.106

Summary: American Romance program presented by University Orchestra
Description: Bassist Elizabeth Lehr joins the UT University Orchestra in a performance of composer and UT alumnus Peter Askim's "Islands: Concerto for Double Bass and String Orchestra." Leonard Bernstein's effervescent and witty "Overture from Candide" and Howard Hanson's lush and sensuous "Symphony No. 2, 'Romantic'" round out the program.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds general meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together under one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: Operation Smile meets
Description: Operation Smile is a nonprofit organization that transforms lives across the globe by funding surgeries for children and young adults who are born with facial deformities, specifically cleft lip or cleft palate. Join us in our efforts to spread smiles. New members welcome. Food provided.

Summary: "A Night in Vegas" is casino night for students
Description: The Student Events Center's Tournaments & Games Committee transforms the Texas Union Ballroom into A Night in Vegas, featuring all of the classic table and card games found in casinos. The best part is that there is no money involved. Big prizes available for those who win big at the tables.

Summary: Women's basketball plays TCU
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the TCU Horned Frogs. Join the team for a post-game wrap-up on the Frank Erwin Center court.  Open to all fans. For more access to the Texas Women's Basketball program, join the Fast Break Club, the team's official fan club, by emailing FastBreakClub@athletics.utexas.edu.

Summary: Is America ready for comprehensive immigration reform?
Description:
Professionals in a diverse set of fields share their perspectives on the policy and politics of immigration reform in a panel. Discussion will focus on the upcoming bipartisan proposal from the "Gang of Eight," its implications for immigrant families and the nation. Lunch served.



Panelists include Bill Beardall (Transnational Workers Law Clinic), Joshua Trevino (Texas Public Policy Foundation) and Dr. Martha Menchaca (UT School of Anthropology), among other invited guests. Moderated by Dr. Victor Saenz (UT School of Education).

Summary: Learn to be a top performer at S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop on how to be a top performer is offered for students employed by UT Austin, and geared toward student employees without prior employment experience in the university environment, as well as experienced student employees who want pointers on good job performance. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Learn to conduct a science research literature review
Description: Learn how to conduct a thorough literature review and get a brief overview of the tools and resources available to find and cite sources. This session focuses on the sciences and is geared toward advanced undergraduates, graduate students and research staff.

Summary: Literature review class open to grad students, researchers
Description: Learn how to structure a literature review focused on social sciences, area studies and humanities. Learn to use background information to shape your research question, how to find examples of literature reviews and how to find the tools and resources to evaluate and cite sources. For graduate students and research staff.

Summary: Natalie Byfield discusses race and the news media
Description: Professor Natalie Byfield of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at St. John's University, New York, discusses negative media representations of black males, with a focus on the racialized portrayals in press coverage of the sexual assault of the Central Park jogger that led to the subsequent wrongful conviction of five black and Latino teens.

Summary: Jewish humor is topic of talk
Description: Jews don't have a monopoly on humor, but how does one account for the incontrovertible cultural phenomenon of "Old Jews Telling Jokes"? Humor played an important role in Yiddish-speaking Jewish life, and the joke was a central vehicle of that humor. Dr. Jordan Finkin addresses these issues, examining what's so Jewish about Jewish humor through the lens of the joke.

Summary: AIESEC international internship info session held
Description:
Interested in interning abroad? 

Attend an AIESEC information session to learn how you can work paid or unpaid, in a business-type setting or community development. Internships range from 6 weeks to 18 months. AIESEC is affiliated with 113 countries worldwide.

Summary: Cupcake Showdown comes to Jester dining hall
Description: In Cupcake Showdown, competitors create completely original cupcakes using secret ingredients. A taste test decides whose cupcake reigns supreme. Contestants need you to cheer them on to victory in their quest to become cupcake champions. All are invited to join the fun by decorating an individual cupcake at the event.
Location: J2 Dining Hall in Jester Center (201 E. 21st Street, Austin, TX, 78705)

Summary: Investing for Life is Bevonomics workshop
Description: Learn how to use investments to satisfy your financial goals. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Workshop looks at gender and advertising
Description: The Gender and Sexuality Center presents an open training titled "What Goods Are We Really Being Sold?" This is an interactive workshop on which ideas of gender are reinforced through commercial advertising, and how this is done.

Summary: Childhood obesity prevention is topic of talk
Description: Mary Story, PhD, RD, presents a talk titled "Childhood Obesity Prevention: Where Do We Go from Here?" as part of the Department of Nutritional Sciences' ongoing speaker series. Story is the program director of Healthy Eating Eating Research with the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation, and co-director, Obesity Prevention Center at the University of Minnesota.

Summary: Improve your resume and cover letters
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence holds a seminar titled "Improving Your Resume and Cover Letters" as part of the 2013 ACE workshops. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Forty Acres Fest second mandatory info session held
Description: Forty Acres Fest takes place Saturday, April 6. This information session is mandatory for all participating organizations. An alternate meeting takes place on Feb. 26, 6 p.m., in UNB 3.116. Application is located at link below. Priority deadline to apply is Friday, March 8. Regular deadline is Friday, March 22.

Summary: "Make a Difference" dogdeball tournament held
Description: The For Us From Us Scholarship Committee invites student organizations to participate in our Make a Difference Dodgeball Tournament. This charitable competition raises funds to support the For Us From Us Scholarship Award, granted to four outstanding Black or African-American students who exemplify academic excellence and community involvement. Visit the link below for more information.

Summary: Slow Food UT outing announced
Description: Join Slow Food UT and Slow Food Austin for a chocolate-making slow session. Carpool available; email hbabich@utexas.edu to join carpool and visit the link below for more event information.
Location: Carpool from Starbucks, 24th & Guadalupe; event at Clear Point Wellness, 2001 S. 1st St.

Summary: Muslims Without Borders Texas Members Social!
Description: Muslims Without Borders Texas hosts its first members' social of the semester, featuring fun icebreaker activities, board games and fun. Food served.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: Central Texas Model United Nations meets
Description: Central Texas Model United Nations meets to introduce new officers and discuss preliminary plans for next semester's conference, CTMUN 2013. Model United Nations organizations simulate the structure of the United Nations as way to immerse students in world affairs and international diplomacy.

Summary: FIMRC, a medical aid group, holds general meeting
Description: FIMRC is the Foundation for the International Medical Relief of Children. Our Texas chapter helps raise money for FIMRC's cause. This year, funding goes to buy iron supplements and other multivitamins for mothers in India. Attend this meeting to learn more about upcoming volunteering events. A speaker from Princeton Review is this week's guest.

Summary: Summer EMT class information session held
Description: Get your questions answered about the summer EMT class offered on campus, and learn more about how you can join Longhorn EMS.

Summary: Ray Sasaki and the Tone Road Ramblers perform
Description: Ray Sasaki and the Tone Road Ramblers perform. The group describes their musical materials as involving extended techniques, the use of toys and unusual sound sources, micro tunings, diverse traditions of jazz, world music and the Western avant-garde.

Summary: Stalin film series presents "The Inner Circle"
Description: The Stalin Film Series presents "The Inner Circle" (1991), a film by Russian director Andrei Konchalovsky that tells the story of Stalin's private projectionist and KGB officer Ivan Sanchin. The film will be introduced by History Professor Joan Neuberger. In English, 137 minutes.

Summary: Jeremy Denk, piano, performs at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Hailed as one of the great pianists of this generation, Jeremy Denk has steadily built a reputation with an unusually broad repertoire. This program includes works by Liszt and Brahms, and marks the concert debut of The Cornelia, Texas Performing Arts' new Steinway concert grand, a gift from the Mary Potishman Lard Trust and the Friedman children in honor of their mother Cornelia C. Friedman.

Summary: Archaeologist spies are topic of scholar's talk
Description:
Dr. Susan Allen gives a lecture titled "Archaeologist Spies: The Truth Behind the Myth." Allen offers a unique perspective on an untold story, the first insiders' account of the U.S. intelligence service in World War II Greece and the eastern Mediterranean who drew on their personal contacts and knowledge of languages and terrain to set up spy networks in Nazi-occupied Greece. 



Co-sponsored by the Archaeological Institute of America.

Summary: Men's basketball hosts Oklahoma
Description: Texas men's basketball faces conference rival Oklahoma Sooners. The $6 web coupon buys one End Court Mezzanine ticket and a coupon for 35 percent off purchase at the Texas Longhorns Official Team Shop at the game. Coupon must be redeemed at the Erwin Center Box Office on game day. Doors open one hour prior to the start of the game.

Summary: Forensics Engineering Conference slated
Description: This CEU conference brings together the best of academia and industry for an exciting exchange on forensics engineering. Conference topics are lessons learned from hurricanes, building envelopes, structural failures, foundation and other case studies. Case studies and best practices from a full spectrum of industries, organizations and reference points will be showcased.
Location: Pickle Research Campus (PRC), West Pickle Research Building, auditorium 1.118

Summary: Report a bias incident to the Campus Climate Response Team
Description:
Do you know of a student organization hosting a party with a racist theme? Have you seen derogatory graffiti on campus regarding sexual orientation or gender identity? Have you overheard malicious threats intended to intimidate a person because of their religion? If so, contact the Campus Climate Response Team at the link below. Reporters may remain anonymous.



In an emergency, contact the University of Texas Police Department at 512-471-4441 or 911.

Summary: Trash to Treasure sale on March 5 seeks volunteers
Description: The Campus Environmental Center's Trash to Treasure sale takes place on March 5 from 10 a.m.-2 p.m. at the FAC Patio. Volunteers are needed from 8 a.m.-4 p.m. It's a fun job, and all the proceeds support the center's vision transforming UT into a more sustainable campus. Contact Emily Worthington at trashtotreasure@utenvironment.org for information.

Summary: Creative Leadership course open for registration
Description: Registration is open for a Creative Leadership course from the university's Professional Development Center (PDC): "Innovation and Creativity for Project Managers" is offered May 9. PDC is a department of the Division of Continuing and Innovative Education.

Summary: Register for Strategic Communication courses from PDC
Description: Register for a Strategic Communication courses from the university's Professional Development Center (PDC): "Delivering the Strategic Message: Make the Manner and the Message Count" takes place April 9. PDC is a department of the Division of Continuing and Innovative Education.

Summary: Scientific teaching improves classroom instruction
Description:
Dr. Eric Mazur of Harvard University gives a presentation on scientific teaching and how he uses classroom data to improve teaching and learning. Mazur is an internationally recognized scientist, researcher and founder of the Peer Instruction teaching model. 



The event will also unveil a free online resource, "Making Decisions with Data," developed by the School of Undergraduate Studies and the Center for Teaching & Learning, with support from the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board.

Summary: Spanish-language forum joins journalists & academics
Description: Journalists and academics come together in "La Nueva Crónica: Diálogo entre Académicos y Periodistas" to exchange ideas about the challenges of representing the new formations of violence in Latin America. Presented in Spanish. No translation available.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 2nd floor conference room

Summary: Black History Month program features Mr. Clifton VanDyke
Description:
Share in a conversation with native Austinite Mr. Clifton VanDyke, the first Black man to work in the Office of Admissions. VanDyke was on campus with Mama Duren and Dr. John Warfield. He will discuss his campus experiences and the progress that has been made. 



VanDyke graduated from the original L.C. Anderson High School and attended Southern University in Baton Rouge, Louisiana, serving as drum major for the "Marching 100" band. His early professional positions included deputy district clerk for Travis County and director of the Neighborhood Youth Corp. His interest in education led him to positions with the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board, followed by recruitment to the position of assistant director of Admissions at The University of Texas at Austin. His deep interest in community college education prompted VanDyke to accept the position of director of Admissions and Records at Austin Community College.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15.

Summary: Michael & Susan Dell Lectureship in Child Health announced
Description:
The seventh annual Michael & Susan Dell Lectureship in Child Health focuses on the next steps that researchers, practitioners and the community can take to solve child and teen health issues such as obesity, substance abuse and tobacco use. For more information about this year's speakers, visit the link below.



While the annual Dell lectureship is focused on research and academics, the program aims to reach the community at large to share knowledge, raise awareness and inspire new actions to promote healthy children in a healthy world.
Location: J.J. Pickle Research Campus (PRC), Commons Learning Center, Bldg. 137

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Google Docs online course offered
Description:
Learn how to use Google Docs to share and collaboratively create documents, spreadsheets and slide presentations online.

This is an online class. At class start time, go to the web address for the class, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher.

Summary: Climbing wall re-opens with open house event
Description: An open house event celebrates the re-opening of the newly renovated and expanded climbing wall at Gregory Gym. Stop by for bouldering games, top rope climbing and giveaways. Climbing wall passes are on sale now, but UT students and RecSports members can enjoy open climbing (no pass required) through Feb. 28.

Summary: Ninth annual Rare Book Lecture announced
Description:
The Tarlton Law Library at The University of Texas School of Law presents its ninth annual rare book lecture, "Evidence from the Fifteenth Century: Tarlton Law Library's Earliest Printed Books." The talk features Dr. Eric White, curator of Special Collections, Bridwell Library, Southern Methodist University.



In this talk, White uses examples from the Tarlton Law Library's Rare Book Collection to discuss the early history of printing and the many ways in which fifteenth-century books preserve evidence about reading and their readers.

Summary: Littlefield Lecture presents historian Jacquelyn Dowd Hall
Description:
