The Department of History's Littlefield Lecture Series proudly presents Dr. Jacquelyn Dowd Hall, with a lecture titled "Left of the New Deal: Radical Women and the Struggle to Put Race and the South at the Center of Reform." Hall presents a subsequent lecture on Friday, March 1, 4-6 p.m., in CLA 0.126.



Hall is the Julia Cherry Spruill professor of history at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Mexican perspective on migration reform discussed
Description: Agustin Escobar, CIESAS del Occidente, presents a talk on the Mexican perspective on U.S.-Mexico migration reform. CIESAS is the abbreviation of Centro de Investigaciones y Estudios Superiores en Antropología Social.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Susanna McFadden
Description: "Roman Wall Painting and the Megalographic Experience in Late Antiquity" is a lecture presented by Susanna McFadden, Fordham University. McFadden examines the art, politics and culture of the late Roman world via an investigation of a particular genre of wall painting, the megalographia (a large-scale figural composition).

Summary: Smart grids are topic of Energy Symposium
Description: John McDonald, director of Technical Strategy & Policy Development at GE Energy Management-Digital Energy, presents a talk titled "All You Ever Wanted to Know About Smart Grids" at this week's Energy Symposium. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship discusses the Passover
Description: Join University Elohim Fellowship for Bible study about the Passover and its link to eternal life. Contact UEFellowship2012@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Graduate Christian Fellowship presents Udo Middelmann
Description: Join the Texas Graduate Christian Fellowship for dinner followed by a lecture by Udo Middelmann, international scholar-in-residence at Nyack College, titled "The Necessary Foundations for the Survival of Democracy in the 21st Century."

Summary: AIESEC international internship info session held
Description:
Interested in interning abroad? 

Attend an AIESEC information session to learn how you can work paid or unpaid, in a business-type setting or community development. Internships range from 6 weeks to 18 months. AIESEC is affiliated with 113 countries worldwide.

Summary: Professionalism in the workplace is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: This workshop provides inside tips on creating and maintaining your professionalism, including a discussion of communication with staff, faculty and peers, along with important tips on interview protocol. Presented by University Unions.

Summary: Careers in federal government to be talk topic
Description: An executive from the Department of Energy discusses how to use your degree in careers in the federal government, including communications, outreach, research operations and policy.

Summary: VAV presents evening of original theater
Description: Voices Against Violence presents an evening of original theater produced by UT students and Austin youth. The Changing Lives Youth Ensemble shares their original piece "Above the Noise," followed by VAV Theatre for Dialogue Ensemble's "Checking In, Checking Up - Everybody Facebook Stalks, Right?"

Summary: Muhammad (PBUH): Messenger of Peace presented
Description: The University of Texas at Austin Ahmadiyya Muslim Students Organization is proud to host Muhammad (PBUH): Messenger of Peace, in conjunction with the Ahmadiyya Muslim Community of Austin. This event is among the first of a national campaign to refute misconceptions about the Prophet Muhammad and distinguish fact from fiction about his life and teachings. Food and drinks served.

Summary: A Date with Science looks at dinner & dessert chemistry
Description: Creative Chemistry presents "A Date with Science: Dinner and Dessert Chemistry." Learn about the chemical reactions that release robust flavors and how to alter the boost the flavor of food by altering its preparation.

Summary: UT Law's Assault & Flattery performs Harry Potter spoof
Description: Assault & Flattery (A&F) presents "Harry Potter and the Order of the Peregrinus," in which Harry and his motley crew of nerdy magic law students fight against the Slythegreens to secure the most desirable jobs that School of Magic Law can offer. Runs through Sunday, March 3, a matinee (see separate listing). Buy your ticket at link below. Showtime is 7 p.m.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theater

Summary: Images of black men in mainstream media is scholar's topic
Description:
Professor Natalie Byfield of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at St. John's University, New York, presents a talk titled "Savage Portrayals: Images of Black Men in the Mainstream Media." 



Byfield discusses negative media representations that have been a growing problem in the lives of black males, with a focus on the racialized portrayals in press coverage of the sexual assault of the Central Park jogger and that led to the subsequent wrongful conviction of five black and Latino teens.
Location: St. James Episcopal Church, 1941 Webberville Road

Summary: "Pariah" screened at GSC Movie Night
Description: The Gender and Sexuality Center screens the award-winning feature film "Pariah," a coming-of-age tale about a Brooklyn teenager coming to terms with her sexuality. Light snacks provided.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Summer EMT class information session held
Description: Get your questions answered about the summer EMT class offered on campus, and learn more about how you can join Longhorn EMS.

Summary: Voices Against Violence presents "Checking In, Checking On"
Description: "When does checking in or checking on become stalking?  When is it just annoying? Who decides?" The Voices Against Violence Theatre for Dialogue program presents a realistic scenario demonstrating situations of relationship violence and stalking. The group creates dialogue by exploring options, choices and consequences, and examining different perspectives.

Summary: Masters of Tradition is evening of Irish music
Description: Masters of Tradition features seven of the most compelling artists in Irish music today exploring the heart of their country's traditional music. The program includes solo performances, duets, trios and full group collaborations, performed by musicians who bring an unparalleled level of mastery to the spellbinding music they play.

Summary: The Carper Family plays at the Cactus
Description: The Carper Family brings together three of Austin's most talented young country and bluegrass singers and pickers, with special guest Jonathan Terrell.

Summary: ACE seeks full-time AmeriCorps members
Description: ACE: A Community for Education seeks over 100 full-time AmeriCorps members to serve as literacy tutors from Sept. 2013 to June 2014. Teach young children to read and give back to the community in and around Austin. For more information or to apply, visit the website below. Questions? Email ace.info@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-6764.

Summary: Secession Redux conference examines lessons for the EU
Description: Several EU states and potential EU candidates face secessionist movements, violent or otherwise. This conference assesses the lessons learned from recent U.S. and EU policy regarding unilateral secession in two countries: the former Yugoslavia and Georgia.

Summary: Sign up for Global Brigades variety show
Description: Global Brigades at UT seeks talented students and others to perform at a fund-raising event on April 27. Dancers, singers, instrumentalists, jugglers and others are encouraged to email us for more information at shell_vuong@yahoo.com.

Summary: Recruiting open for 2013 Student Cluster Challenge
Description:
The Texas Advanced Computing Center (TACC) seeks talented undergraduate students to compete in the Student Cluster Competition (SCC) at the Supercomputing Conference '13 (SC13), held next November in Denver, Colo. TACC selects, coaches and sponsors the UT team. All majors are welcome. Women and underrepresented students strongly encouraged to participate. Contact Carlos Rosales-Fernandez at 512-232-5189 or 

carlos@tacc.utexas.edu before March 8.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE) 2.404, TACC/ACE Vislab

Summary: Green Fee application workshop held
Description: Get a resume boost and use dollars of your tuition to make UT more sustainable. The easiest way to enact sustainable, lasting environmental change on campus is through the Green Fee Program. Attend this workshop to learn about the application process and possible green projects that you or a team can get funding for and enact.

Summary: Native American/Indigenous Studies series presents speaker
Description: Manu Vimalassery, assistant professor of history, Texas Tech University, presents "Guests in the Land: Asian American Through American Indian Studies." His manuscript, "Skew Tracks: Imperialism, Racial Capitalism, and the Transcontinental Railroad," rethinks capitalism through Plains Indian and Chinese migrant histories.

Summary: Impromptu Speech Club meets
Description: The Impromptu Speech Club helps hone language skills of non-native English speakers to promote more effective and confident communication.

Summary: Hilary Spurling lectures on Pearl Buck and China
Description: Biographer Hilary Spurling, author of "Pearl Buck in China," asserts that writer Pearl Buck was the first person to make China accessible to the British as well as the American public, recreating the lives of ordinary Chinese people in "The Good Earth," which became an overnight worldwide bestseller after its 1932 release.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: Science Undergraduate Research Fair (SURF) announced
Description: The Science Undergraduate Research Fair (SURF) exposes undergraduates to the opportunities and challenges of research. The event features a talk by Dr. Sacha Kopp, associate dean for Curriculum and Programs for the College of Natural Sciences, followed by a research poster session by undergraduates in aerospace engineering, astronomy, computer science, biology and biomedical engineering.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Room

Summary: Jacquelyn Dowd Hall presents second Littlefield lecture
Description:
The Department of History's Littlefield Lecture Series proudly presents Dr. Jacquelyn Dowd Hall, with a lecture titled "Misread and Betrayed: Left Feminism in the Shadow of the Long Cold War." This is the second of Hall's two lectures in the series.



Hall is the Julia Cherry Spruill professor of history at the University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill.

Summary: Texas Rootstrikers hold first meeting
Description: Texas Rootstrikers is a nonpartisan network of online and grassroots activists fighting corruption in national politics. Our goal is to reform the campaign financing system to make it dependent upon the people alone, and to overturn Citizens United so that super PACs will be unconstitutional. Attend our first meeting to learn more.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Desi Culture Night presents showcase
Description: Desi Culture Night promotes awareness of South Asian religions and cultures to bring more diversity and knowledge to the university campus. The showcase features music, dance, educational games, fashion, food, magic, art and a bouncy house.

Summary: Mike Doughty plays the Cactus
Description: Former Soul Coughing frontman and current alternative singer/songwriter Mike Doughty visits Austin for an intimate show at the Cactus Cafe.

Summary: Summer EMT class information session held
Description: Get your questions answered about the summer EMT class offered on campus, and learn more about how you can join Longhorn EMS.

Summary: "Intimate Apparel" is tale of romance and ambition
Description: Esther, a gifted seamstress in 1950s Manhattan, crafts lingerie for a variety of clientele, including Fifth Avenue socialites and Tenderloin district prostitutes while looking for love. Don't miss Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage's tale of romance, ambition and self-discovery. Runs through March 9.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Submissions sought for annual art show, "Untitled"
Description:
The Undergraduate Art History Association seeks submissions for its annual show and sale, "Untitled," held April 19. Submit work by March 22. All media accepted; up to five works priced between $25-250 may be submitted (UAHA takes 20 percent). Send submissions to untitled.uaha@gmail.com. 

Include title of work, date of work, dimensions, price (remember to factor in the 20% commission) and medium.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Explore UT at the Blanton
Description: On Explore UT day, the Blanton Museum of Art invites visitors to discover the exciting role of art in university life. Join us for a fun-filled afternoon of free, educational art activities, including the creation of a giant collage with contemporary artist Barbara Kruger, a Create-Your-Own Art Collection activity inspired by the exhibition Through the Eyes of Texas, gilded frame photos and soap sculpting.

Summary: Palestine Solidarity Committee holds BDS Day conference
Description: The Palestine Solidarity Committee holds an activist conference to promote BDS - Boycott, Divestment and Sanctions - as well as an academic boycott of Israel. Visit the conference website at the link below, or the Facebook event at https://www.facebook.com/events/381851751911037/?ref=ts&fref=ts.

Summary: VAC hosts guided exhibition tours during Explore UT
Description: During Explore UT, Texans of all ages are invited to experience the intellectual life, technological advances and rich resources of a world-class university. The Visual Arts Center invites visitors to explore four dynamic exhibitions with guided tours beginning each hour, on the hour, from 12-3 p.m. Don't miss the Biggest Open House in Texas.

Summary: Social Justice Symposium announced
Description: Nourish International and A.C.T. (Against Cruel Trafficking) host a social justice panel and discussion involving experts from local Austin nonprofits and the School of Social Work. Themes of the symposium are human trafficking, sustainable development and fostering student activism. Food and drinks served.

Summary: Phoebe Hunt plays the Cactus
Description: Singer/songwriter, instrumentalist and UT graduate Phoebe Hunt takes the stage at the Cactus Cafe for an intimate performance.

Summary: Landmarks Video presents "Orient" by Marcus Schinwald
Description: Landmarks Video presents the two-part film "Orient" by Austrian-born Marcus Schinwald. Eccentric scenes place men and women in disjointed locations and situations, alternating between humorous and macabre, as Schinwald explores our position in time and space. Each film lasts nine minutes. On view throughout March.
Location: Art Building (ART), atrium, adjacent to Visual Arts Center galleries 23rd St. and San Jacinto

Summary: UT Entrepreneurship Week announced
Description: The 40 Acres has a diverse array of entrepreneurial resource. UT Entrepreneurship Week (UT EWeek) is meant to introduce the university community to these resources and allow attendees to connect with organizations, programs and people that can help them achieve their goals as an entrepreneur. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: UT Law's Assault & Flattery performs Harry Potter spoof
Description: Assault & Flattery (A&F) presents a matinee performance of "Harry Potter and the Order of the Peregrinus," in which Harry and his motley crew of nerdy magic law students fight against the Slythegreens to secure the most desirable jobs that School of Magic Law can offer. Buy your ticket at link below. Show starts at 2 p.m.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theater

Summary: "Intimate Apparel" is tale of romance and ambition
Description: Esther, a gifted seamstress in 1950s Manhattan, crafts lingerie for a variety of clientele, including Fifth Avenue socialites and Tenderloin district prostitutes while looking for love. Don't miss Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage's tale of romance, ambition and self-discovery. Runs through March 9.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Music at the Blanton presents Renaissance brass ensemble
Description: Scott Hanna conducts a brass ensemble from the UT Butler School of Music performing compositions from the Renaissance era.

Summary: Through the Eyes of Texas tour celebrates Blanton's 50th
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Tom Russell performs at the Cactus
Description: Spend an evening with Tom Russell, a master storyteller whose songs have been recorded by such icons as Johnny Cash, Dave Van Ronk, Jerry Jeff Walker, Doug Sahm, Joe Ely, Nanci Griffith, Iris Dement and Ramblin' Jack Elliott, among others.

Summary: Assessment Showcase call for posters announced
French native speakers sought for linguistic experiment
Description: French native speakers are sought to participate in linguistic experiment involving audio recording and listening. Contact monique.murphy@utexas.edu for details.

Summary: Basic Wood Structural Design course offered in Houston
Description: This course consists of a practical approach to both ASD (Allowable Stress Design) and LRFD (Load and Resistance Factor) design of wood members and connections. It is intended especially for engineers who are new to wood design, but also for those who have experience in wood design and desire a greater insight. The National Design Specification (NDS) and selected supplements will be used.
Location: 4702 North Sam Houston Parkway West, Suite 800, Houston

Summary: Engineering Leadership Institute Certificate offered
Description:
The Engineering Leadership Institute (ELI) at The University of Texas at Austin announces the launch of its newly redesigned Engineering Leadership Certificate program, for engineers who have become first-time managers of projects or people. 



Making the transition from individual technical contributor to strategic manager requires the development of a different skill set. The Engineering Leadership Institute is designed to help you do exactly that, with just the right mix of lecture and interactive sessions to give you exceptional tools for success.
Location: 2815 San Gabriel Street, or live online

Summary: SoundBrain Lab seeks English-Spanish bilinguals for study
Description: The UT SoundBrain Lab seeks fluent bilingual speakers of English and Spanish ages 18-40 with normal hearing for a one-hour auditory study. Participants must have been exposed to both languages from birth. Email utsoundbrain@gmail.com if you are interested in participating.

Summary: Cactus Yearbook Photo Studio is in its final week
Description: This is the last week of Cactus Yearbook's annual free photo studio. The studio accepts underclassmen for walk-ins between 9 a.m.-5 p.m. Seniors must make a cap-and-gown appointment at www.takeourpicture.com/cactus.

Summary: Residence hall students sought for study on relationships
Description: Current undergraduate students living in residence halls are sought for participation in a confidential 15-30 minute online study about romantic relationships and conflict. If you complete this study for extra credit, confirmation will be forwarded to the faculty member of your choice. Contact Robert Carroll (carrollrw@utexas.edu), doctoral student in Communication Studies, with questions.

Summary: Support literacy in Austin on Amplify Austin Day
Description: Nearly half of Austin's kindergartners lack a strong foundation in the language and literacy experiences that are critical for success in learning to read. ACE: A Community for Education provides low-income schools with highly trained tutors to ensure that children advance to grade level in reading before third grade. Participate in Amplify Austin, ACE's first annual 24-hour online giving festival. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: International Student & Scholar Services launches blog
Description: International Student and Scholar Services (ISSS) in the International Office have officially launched a blog for all international students, visiting scholars and university departments. The blog will highlight the programs and services offered by ISSS, as well as current news and fun events.

Summary: Latin American Forum on Energy and the Environment slated
Description: This two-day forum features energy and environment ministers from Latin America and leaders from business, academia and government in a collaborative effort to strengthen ties between the U.S. and Latin America, and between UT Austin and the region. For a list of speakers and more, visit the link below.

Summary: SoundBrain Lab seeks individuals with dyslexia for study
Description: The SoundBrain Lab seeks healthy participants ages 18-65 with normal hearing and a diagnosis of dyslexia for a behavioral study of auditory training optimization.

Summary: Liz Ogbu, designer and social innovator, gives lunch talk
Description:
The Center for Sustainable Development presents a lunch talk by designer and social innovator Liz Ogbu, titled "Repositioning Design: New Ways for Creating Impact."



Ogbu is a designer, urban strategist, social innovator, academic and expert on sustainable design and spatial innovation in challenged urban environments globally. From designing shelters for immigrant day laborers in the U.S. to a water and health social enterprise for low-income Kenyans, Ogbu has built an extensive career in social impact design. Currently, she has her own multidisciplinary consulting practice and serves as the first-ever scholar-in-residence at the Center for Art & Public Life at California College of the Arts. She is also on the faculty at the d.school at Stanford University.

Summary: CMAS plática explores Native American identity
Description: Mark Rifkin, associate professor in the Department of English at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro, discusses his current work on sexuality, kinship systems and Native American governance in a talk titled "The Erotics of Sovereignty." Rifkin holds a Doctor of Philosophy degree in English from the University of Pennsylvania.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Brent O. Peterson
Description: Dr. Brent Peterson presents a paper titled "Moses Mendelssohn: Germany's First Migrant." Peterson is professor of German and chair of the German Department at Lawrence University, Appleton, WI. He is interested in questions of ethnic and national identity. To RSVP and receive a copy of the pre-circulated paper, email Courtney Meador (cmeador@austin.utexas.edu) by 9 a.m., Friday, March 1.

Summary: Goal Setting is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
A workshop on goal setting is offered for students employed by UT Austin. Learn to create long-term and short-term goals utilizing the SMART goal philosophy and methodology, become familiar with backward planning techniques for effective goal achievement and to develop SMART (Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, Time-bound) goals.



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: CWGS faculty colloquium presents Roxanne Schroeder-Arce
Description:
"Toward Culturally Responsive Artistry: Mapping Engagement With Latino/a Stories on Stage" is a talk presented by Assistant Professor Roxanne Schroeder-Arce for the Center for Women's and Gender Studies Faculty Development Program colloquium. Schroeder-Arce examines "Mariachi Girl," a theatrical production produced with the goal of engaging Austin's Latino/a audiences.



Schroeder-Arce is an assistant professor of theatre in the Theatre Studies Program, Department of Theatre and Dance.

Summary: Transferable skills is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Being a student employee at The University of Texas at Austin has implications for your future career. Learn to identify transferable skills you are currently gaining, and how to best market these experiences to future employers on a resume and in a job interview. Presented by the Center for Strategic Advising and Career Counseling.

Summary: Capitalizing on employee benefits is Bevonomics topic
Description: Learn about 401(k) plans and other benefits your future employer may offer. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: GSC book club discusses "Bossypants"
Description: The Gender and Sexuality Center book club discusses Tina Fey's classic book "Bossypants."

Summary: Student Action for Refugees (STAR) meets
Description: Attend a meeting of Student Action for Refugees to learn about projects supporting refugees in the Austin area. We work in conjunction with Refugee Services of Texas to help Iraqi, Bhutanese, Burmese, Cuban, Eritrean, Somali and other immigrants acclimate to life in the United States. Opportunities available to speak Spanish, Arabic and more (we are in particular need of Spanish speakers). All are welcome.

Summary: Longhorn Circus practice announced
Description: Longhorn Circus is a student organization geared to the sharing and practicing of circus arts. We practice hula-hooping, acrobatic-yoga, juggling, poi and staff. Supplies are usually provided by the club. Practicing these "flow arts" is an alternative form of exercise. All skill levels welcome.

Summary: Learn To Be founders host dinner talk
Description: Stephen Chen and Neeraj Kapoor, co-founders of Learn To Be, a nationally acclaimed nonprofit organization, host a dinner talk about technological advances in the education sector and how to start a nonprofit organization in college.

Summary: Food Recovery Network meeting held
Description: Food Recovery Network is a national nonprofit that fights food waste and hunger by donating surplus food from campus facilities and nearby restaurants to local agencies fighting hunger and poverty.  Attend our first-ever general meeting to learn more about the process, who we are and how to get involved.

Summary: Higher education mania is Mises Circle topic
Description:
More Americans are receiving a college education than ever before, and student loan debt has reached astronomical levels, eclipsing credit card debt. Join the Mises Circle and guest speaker Doug French, senior editor of Laissez-Faire Club and past president of the Ludwig von Mises Institute, to explore the looming student loan bubble, the economic implications of its bursting and what students can do to hedge against the economic calamity.



For an overview of the student debt problem, see French's "The Higher-Education Bubble Has Popped." For further readings on the topic, see the Mises Circle's higher education reader.



Can't join us in person? Tune in to the Google  Hangout. A link will be sent out when we go live.

Summary: Men's lacrosse hosts Boston College
Description: Undefeated and ranked 15 in the nation in polls from the Men's Collegiate Lacrosse Association, the UT men's lacrosse team hosts number 16 Boston College for an exciting game. Come cheer the Horns on to victory.
Location: Caven Lacrosse & Sports Center at Clark Field (CCF)

Summary: Men's basketball plays Baylor
Description: Texas men's basketball takes on the Baylor Bears.

Summary: Support literacy in Austin on Amplify Austin Day
Description: Nearly half of Austin's kindergartners lack a strong foundation in the language and literacy experiences that are critical for success in learning to read. ACE: A Community for Education provides low-income schools with highly trained tutors to ensure that children advance to grade level in reading before third grade. Participate in Amplify Austin, ACE's first annual 24-hour online giving festival. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: Register: Innovation in Healthcare Delivery Systems Symposium
Description: The McCombs School of Business hosts the fourth annual healthcare research symposium, Innovation in Healthcare Delivery Systems: Focus on Social Issues, from Thursday, April 11-Friday, April 12. Registration is open through April 10 at the link below (click the link for 2013 Healthcare Symposium). Meals sold separately.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: RTF offers camps for teens
Description: Register your teen for creative fun this summer at day camps where they can make a film, write a screenplay and learn to use animation and game development software. Taught by lecturers, alumni and graduate students from UT's nationally ranked Department of Radio-Television-Film. Evening workshops offered for adults and mature teens. Learn about workshops here: http//rtf.utexas.edu/workshops.

Summary: 27-Hour Stand for Freedom raises awareness of trafficking
Description: The 27-Hour Stand for Freedom event draws awareness and funds to end human trafficking. Currently there are 27 million people enslaved in our world - more than at any time in history. They need a voice. Join Ignite to make a statement of solidarity and commitment to the cause of their freedom.

Summary: Depression treatment study seeks participants
Description: The Mood Disorders Laboratory at The University of Texas at Austin seeks adults who are currently experiencing symptoms of depression to participate in the trial of an experimental computerized treatment program. Contact us at MDL@psy.utexas.edu or 512-475-6817.

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in any amount up to $2,000. To learn more, attend an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu, or visit us online.

Summary: Trash to Treasure sale benefits Campus Environmental Center
Description: The Campus Environmental Center (CEC) presents the Trash to Treasure sale. All proceeds support the CEC's vision of transforming UT into a more sustainable campus. To volunteer, contact Emily Worthington at trashtotreasure@utenvironment.org.

Summary: Engineering Ethics course offered
Description: This course provides an overview of the basic tenets of engineering ethics and the ethical obligations of engineers. It offers an approach to resolving ethical problems in which it is not at all clear what the solution is, what the choices are or even what standards apply. It assumes that an engineer's most important asset in resolving an ethical problem is the ability to think creatively about the problem and to generate options.

Summary: The Art of Storytelling is lecture by Gioia Timpanelli
Description:
Often called the "Dean of American Storytelling," Gioia Timpanelli is both master and scholar of the ancient art of telling stories. In this talk, she discusses the nature and importance of the improvisational telling of ancient and modern stories. 



Timpanelli won two Emmy Awards for her PBS series on storytelling, "Stories from My House." She has also received the prestigious Women's National Book Association Award for bringing the oral tradition to the American public and recently the Maharishi Award for "promoting world harmony wherever she goes by enlivening within the listener that field of pure consciousness that is the source of all stories." Her radio series "Told and Retold" is currently on both PRX and NPR's ContentDepot.

Summary: Lecture & book signing with author John Tutino announced
Description: Join author and professor John Tutino as he discusses his new book, "Mexico and Mexicans in the Making of the United States." Tracing economic, social and cultural connections from colonial times until today, Tutino highlights the foundational contributions of Mexico and Mexicans to the United States - Hispanic capitalism, patriarchy and mestizaje, or ethnic blending. A book signing follows.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 1.115

Summary: Moving Through Conflict is S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: Conflict seems to be a fact of life but does not have to cause anxiety. Explore your personal approach to handling conflict and get a better understanding of how conflict, when moved through effectively, can lead to personal and professional growth. Presented by Human Resource Services.

Summary: Kinesiology Networking Panel announced
Description: Meet professionals who work in Kinesiology and Health related fields. Panel members talk about their current jobs, career paths and training.  After the panel, network with Austin Family & Sports, Austin Simply Fit, Cadence Sports, Longhorn Network, Round Rock Express, UT Athletics, UIL, Well at Dell and University of St. Augustine panelists.   Email Rita@austin.utexas.edu for more information.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on UT Pan-American
Description: Texas baseball hosts UT Pan-American. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Loving v. Virginia roundtable discussion slated
Description: In 1967, the U.S. Supreme Court invalidated laws preventing interracial marriage in the landmark Loving v. Virginia ruling. Join the Warfield Center for a discussion on the significance of the ruling and its implications for broader questions of multi-raciality today.

Summary: Design Lecture Series presents Paul Elliman
Description: In a talk titled "Sirens Taken for Wonders," London-based designer/artist Paul Elliman expounds on the emergency evacuation procedure for a UT lecture hall and a brief history of sirens. Elliman is known for his work with a found typography of objects and industrial debris. He also follows the human voice through many of its social and technological guises.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program. Other information sessions scheduled for Tuesday, March 19, and Tuesday, March 26.

Summary: Time Management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Academic achievement begins with the basics: plenty of sleep, nutritious meals, a balance of work and play, and useful stress-reducing strategies. Having a hard time with any of those? Come learn how to practice time management skills, prioritization and other techniques for fitting it all in. Presented by the Sanger Learning Center.

Summary: The Stampede supercomputing system is topic of presentation
Description: Jay Boisseau, director of the Texas Advanced Computing Center, presents a lecture and forum on the center's Stampede supercomputing system. Named with typical Texas bravado, Stampede, when completed, will contain more than 500,000 processing cores and will fill a machine room about one-quarter the size of a football field, making it one of the most powerful systems on the planet. RSVP to Rosalia Arellano: info@austinforum.org.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), amphitheater 204

Summary: Learn about HDO executive master's degree
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP at link below.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18, Liberal Arts Career Services Suite

Summary: Zumba Gold class offered by Grupo Flor y Canto
Description: Zumba Gold is a low-impact, Latin-music-based fitness class. To register, email grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com. Students, faculty and staff of all ages and ability levels are welcome. We cannot accept individuals who have had injuries within the last two months.

Summary: Immigration is topic of bipartisan policy forum
Description: College Republicans and University Democrats co-host a policy forum on immigration with a panel of distinguished UT faculty. This forum is geared toward learning, not partisan rhetoric. Light refreshments and sodas provided. Follow us on #UTimmigration for updates. All students welcome.

Summary: Raja Bhattar presents "I am Desi and Queer"
Description: Raja Bhattar, director of UCLA's LGBT Campus Resource Center, discusses his experiences as a queer Desi man in the gay communities in the United States, as well as Hinduism and its positions on homosexuality.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: Women's basketball plays West Virginia
Description: Texas women's basketball hosts the West Virginia Mountaineers. A $5 web coupon is good for one general admission ticket and a coupon for 25% off your purchase at the Longhorns Team Shop at the game. Redeemed at the Frank Erwin Center Box Office on game day. Youth 18 and under can enjoy inflatables, face painting, basketball goals and more for free at the Denton Cooley Pavilion, 90 minutes before tip.

Summary: Joffrey Ballet presents "The Rite of Spring"
Description:
The University of Texas Symphony Orchestra joins the world-famous Joffrey Ballet for a spectacular evening of classical dance and music, highlighted by a performance of "Le Sacre du Printemps" (The Rite of Spring), celebrating the centennial of the work's world premiere in Paris in 1913. 



The Joffrey Ballet's "Rite of Spring" explores Stravinsky's revolutionary score and Nijinsky's radical choreography with a remarkable reconstruction of the 1913 production with original costumes, choreography and design.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Game of Thrones trivia tournament held
Description: Join the Student Events Center Tournaments & Games Committee to celebrate the imminent return of "Game of Thrones" season 3 with a spirited night of pub trivia. Test your knowledge of the show (and the books) with your friends for a shot a great prizes. Maximum of six people per team allowed; sign up at the event. Doors open at 7:30 p.m.

Summary: Faculty iPad Initiative blog seeks contributors
Description: The Faculty iPad Initiative blog chronicles the experiences of faculty experimenting with iPads for instruction, research and productivity. It includes daily news and how-to videos for getting started. Anyone can subscribe or comment. Guest posts from faculty or graduate students using iPads or tablets are welcome. Submit your story at the link below.

Summary: Environmental Science program accepting applicants
Description: The Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science degree program at the College of Natural Sciences, the College of Liberal Arts and the Jackson School of Geosciences is accepting internal transfer applications from students currently enrolled at UT Austin. Visit the link below for more information, or contact Deborah Salzberg at evs@esi.utexas.edu. Applications due April 1.

Summary: Health Professions Fair 2013 announced
Description: Attend the 2013 Health Professions Fair to meet and talk with admissions representatives from health profession programs from schools state-wide and across the country. Contact Shannon Gutheil at sgutheil@austin.utexas.edu or 512-232-2672 for more information. To volunteer, contact Jonathan Canava at jcanava@austin.utexas.edu or 512-471-3172.

Summary: disABILITY 101 training session held
Description: The disABILITY 101 Program provides a snapshot of disability awareness and sensitivity. The program is conducted in a lecture format with three engaging interactive activities.

Summary: Knowledge and Noms topic is Bystander Behavior
Description: Attend a workshop on helpful bystander behavior. How should you react when you see something offensive occurring? Light snacks provided.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Research + Pizza topic is innovative product design
Description: Carolyn Seepersad, associate professor in mechanical engineering, speaks on innovative product design at this edition of Research   Pizza.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Computer Science Complex celebrates grand opening
Description: Join the Department of Computer Science at >goto_GDC - the grand opening celebration of the Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex and Dell Computer Science Hall - for an open house, tours, BBQ, live music and live streaming of the Bill Gates Student Address. Space is limited and on a first-come, first-seated basis.
Location: Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex & Dell Computer Science Hall (GDC) and SAC ballroom

Summary: "Find Images" course offered online
Description: Learn how to find images on any research topic, with a focus on specialized image databases available to the campus community. At class start time, go to: https://meeting.austin.utexas.edu/findimages/ and select "Enter as a Guest." Type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9. For more information, visit the link below.

Summary: Living off-campus is Bevonomics workshop topic
Description: Prepare yourself for the move to live off-campus. Familiarize yourself with popular student areas around Austin, expenses, safety and your rights and responsibilities as a tenant. Co-presented by  Legal Services for Students.

Summary: Discrimination Basics to be topic of S.E.E.D. workshop
Description: This workshop provides a guide to policies, rights and resources that empower the employee in the workplace. Review policies in the areas of nondiscrimination, sex discrimination and sexual harassment, sexual misconduct, consensual relationships and disability accommodations. Presented by the Office of Institutional Equity.

Summary: Maxwell's Demon is physics colloquium topic
Description:
In 1870, James Clerk Maxwell proposed a thought experiment that became known as Maxwell's Demon. In a talk titled "Breaking Barriers with Maxwell's Demon," Professor Mark Raizen describes how we have realized Maxwell's Demon in the laboratory, and how it is being used to control

matter with light and to break the existing barriers of laser cooling, nanoscience and isotopes.

Summary: Advise TX College Advising Corps info session held
Description: Advise TX seeks recent UT graduates (Dec. 2012, May 2013) to serve as college advisers in low-income high schools in Austin, San Antonio, Corpus Christi, El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley. Advisers help high school students realize their dream of attending college by assisting with college admissions, financial aid and scholarship applications. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Reading of Lisa Thompson's "Single Black Female" presented
Description: Join the Warfield Center for a staged reading of Professor Lisa Thompson's play "Single Black Female," a humorous look at the lives of single, middle-class black women. The reading is followed by a talk-back with the playwright.

Summary: Texas softball plays Louisiana-Lafayette
Description:
Texas softball hosts the Louisiana-Lafayette Ragin' Cajuns in game one of a double-header. Get $5 Happy Hour general admission ticket before 5 p.m. by entering HAPPY13 on the promo code page of TexasSports.com or calling 512-232-3865; advance sale only, by March 6 at noon. 



Buy 25 group tickets or more to a 2013 game and your children (8th grade & under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offer based on availability.

Summary: The American achievement gap is talk topic
Description: The 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series of the Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence presents a talk by Audrey Hooks titled "Causes and Resolutions for the American Achievement Gap." Hooks is chief human assets officer for IDEA Public Schools. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Certificate Program info session held
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major with an interest in pursuing a career in commercial real estate. Register to attend at link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: International Gastronomy Society meets
Description: Love to cook? Love to eat good food? Attend the upcoming meeting of the International Gastronomy Society. Contact gastronomyinternational@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Intro to Clinical Medicine lecture series presented
Description: Intro to Clinical Medicine is a weekly distinguished lecture series led by Associate Dean of Health Professions and cardiothoracic surgeon Dr. Reginald Baptiste. In these talks, Baptiste, along with an array of noted health professionals, share their first-hand insight into the world of clinical medicine. Open to the University of Texas community.

Summary: Money Talks presents Rudy Garza of G51 Capital in keynote
Description:
Rudy Garza gives the UT Enterpreneurship Week (UTEWeek) keynote address, who discusses the importance about creating entrepreneurial opportunities on campus. Garza is the founder and general managing partner of G-51 Capital, where he works with some of Central Texas' premier technology startups. RSVP at link below; learn more about UTEWeek at UTEWeek.com



The startup seed was planted in Rudy's career by UT technology commercialization pioneer George Kozmetsky during Rudy's time as an MBA student at UT. In 2011 he served as the chairman of the board of the Texas Exes Association, and is a lifetime honorary trustee of the Dell's Children's Medical Center in Austin.

Summary: Turkish Film Series screens Pelin Esmer film
Description: In "11'e 10 kala" (10 to 11), a 2009 film by director Pelin Esmer, elderly collector Mithat (Mithat Esmer) and newly arrived concierge Ali (Nejat Isler) find their lonely lives increasingly intertwined both with each other and with the city Istanbul itself as they become the last two inhabitants of a condemned apartment block. In Turkish with English subtitles; 110 minutes.

Summary: Engineering master's degree info session held
Description: The Engineering Masters Degree Program hosts an information session on the Engineering Management and Software Engineering programs at The University of Texas at Austin. Alumni and current students will be present to answer questions following a brief program overview.
Location: J. J. Pickle Research Campus (PRC), Stadium Room 1.130

Summary: Muslims Without Borders Texas holds general body meeting
Description: Muslims without Borders Texas holds its second general body meeting of the spring semester, featuring introductions, icebreakers and a general introduction to the club at both the local and national level. Learn about upcoming events and volunteer opportunities, including the upcoming Project Downtown, in April, which feeds the homeless.

Summary: International Women's Day zine release party announced
Description: Attend a zine release party for Feminist Action Project's "Musings of a #lonelyfeminist." Event features spoken word performances and other feminist art.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Open stage night held at Cactus Cafe
Description: The Cactus Cafe's open stage takes place once a month. Sign up at 7 p.m. to take your turn performing on this legendary stage.

Summary: Taiwanese American Student Association holds meeting
Description: Enjoy the last TASA meeting before spring break with a fun game of spider. Representatives from KUSA will attend and we will provide information on the upcoming TACL (Taiwanese American Citizen's League) leadership conference.

Summary: Astrophysicist presents "Telescopes as Time Machines"
Description: Hot Science - Cool Talks presents a special edition lecture, "Telescopes as Time Machines: The Legacy of Hubble & the Future Through the James Webb Space Telescope," by Dr. Jason Kalirai, astrophysicist at the Space Science Institute in Baltimore. No pre-lecture fair for this occasion. Can't attend in person? View the webcast via link below.

Summary: Texas softball plays Louisiana-Lafayette
Description: Texas softball hosts the Louisiana-Lafayette Ragin' Cajuns in game two of a double-header. Join the Longhorns on the field for starting lineup introductions: buy a minimum of 25 group tickets to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade & under) can take the field with the Longhorns. Offer based on availability. Call 512-232-3865 for details.

Summary: Stalin film series presents "Within the Whirlwind"
Description: The Stalin Film Series presents "Within the Whirlwind" (2010), which tells the true story of literature professor Evgenia Ginzburg, who was sent to 10 years' hard labor in a Siberian gulag in Siberia. After losing everything and no longer wishing to live, she meets the camp doctor and begins to come back to life. Dialogue in English; 90 minutes.

Summary: "Intimate Apparel" is tale of romance and ambition
Description: Esther, a gifted seamstress in 1950s Manhattan, crafts lingerie for a variety of clientele, including Fifth Avenue socialites and Tenderloin district prostitutes while looking for love. Don't miss Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage's tale of romance, ambition and self-discovery.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Joffrey Ballet presents "The Rite of Spring"
Description:
The University of Texas Symphony Orchestra joins the world-famous Joffrey Ballet for a spectacular evening of classical dance and music, highlighted by a performance of "Le Sacre du Printemps (The Rite of Spring), celebrating the centennial of the work's world premiere in Paris in 1913. 



The Joffrey Ballet's "Rite of Spring" explores Stravinsky's revolutionary score and Nijinsky's radical choreography with a remarkable reconstruction of the 1913 production with original costumes, choreography and design.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Experimental documentary "The Great Northwest" screened
Description:
The Mad Stork Cinema premieres Matt McCormick's newest film, "The Great Northwest," along with other short experimental documentaries. "The Great Northwest" re-creates a 3,200 mile road-trip made in 1958 by four Seattle women. Work by local filmmakers screened as well.



Mad Stork Cinema is a student group committed to the advancement of the experimental film and video arts.

Summary: Apply for EUCE Brussels program
Description: The European Union Center of Excellence (EUCE) offers grants to three UT Austin undergraduate students to travel to Brussels in the summer of 2013 through the EUCE Brussels Program. UT undergraduate students of any major can apply. Applications are due by 5 p.m. on Friday, March 29. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: UIL boys' high school basketball State Championships held
Description: Witness some of the most exciting moments in Texas high school basketball history when 24 of the best teams from across the state compete for coveted championship trophies. The six-game-a-day tournament format offers fans the chance to see 18 contests during one weekend.

Summary: Texas A&M Health Science professor discusses strokes
Description: Farida Sohrabji, professor and associate department chair, Neuroscience and Experimental Therapeutics, Texas A&M Health Science Center, presents a seminar titled "Stroke Neuroprotection in the Aging Brain: Interactions of Estrogen/IGF-1/microRNA."

Summary: Earn cash for filling out 20-minute survey
Description: The McCombs School of Business seeks participants to fill out a 20-minute survey to gather data for research projects. Participants receive $5 cash and a free snack. You must be a current student, not on a diet, not a student in Foundations of Marketing or Principles of Marketing this year or last and not a previous participant in a paid McCombs study this semester.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA) Behavioral Lab 6.402 (6th floor)

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: "Through the Eyes of Texas" is Perspectives talk topic
Description: The Blanton presents a gallery talk on the exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections," led by exhibition curator and Blanton curator-at-large Annette DiMeo Carlozzi.

Summary: John Tutino discusses fall of the first global economy
Description: Author and historian John Tutino presents "The Fall of the First Global Economy: Hairi and the Bajío, 1790-1820." Tutino, of Georgetown University, has received two prestigious awards for his most recent book, "Making a New World: Founding Capitalism in the Bajío and Spanish North America."
Location: Garrison Hall (GAR), Institute for Historical Studies, 4th floor

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Contemporary Czech Cinema screens film with producer Q&A
Description: The Department of Slavic and Eurasian Studies presents "Kuky Returns" (2010), a film by renowned Czech director Jan Sverak. This charming family film combines puppet animation, slow motion and live action. A Q&A with producer Jeffrey Brown follows.

Summary: Low-carbon technology transfers discussed in energy talk
Description: Varun Rai, assistant professor of public affairs and mechanical engineering at UT Austin, speaks at this week's UT Energy Symposium. His talk is titled "International Low-Carbon Technology Transfers: Do Intellectual Property Regimes Matter?" Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: ScienceOnline2013 watch party held
Description: Attend a free viewing of two sessions from the ScienceOnline2013 Conference, an annual gathering of scientists, students, educators, physicians, journalists, librarians, bloggers, programmers and others interested in the way the World Wide Web is changing the way science is communicated, taught and done. Includes pizza and post-viewing discussion. Visit link to learn more.

Summary: Speakers share insights about communications careers
Description: Two guest speakers share their insights on how to build a successful career in communications. Jacqi Moore Richardson (B.S. Public Relations, 2003) is senior manager at Chicago-based public relations firm  GolinHarris. Fred Cook is chief executive officer of GolinHarris.

Summary: Photojournalists Diana Walker and Lucian Perkins give talk
Description: Attend An Evening with Diana Walker and Lucian Perkins, internationally acclaimed photojournalists who have spent much of their professional careers covering the White House. Both have work featured in the current Briscoe Center exhibit, "News to History: Photojournalism and the Presidency." (See http://bit.ly/14pnhuL.) Former television news anchor Neal Spelce moderates the conversation.

Summary: South Asia Institute screens "Jai Bhim Comrade"
Description: Anand Patwardhan's film "Jai Bhim Comrade" took 14 years to complete. Beginning with an incident at Ramabai Colony in Mumbai where 10 Dalits were shot dead by the police in 1997, the film goes on to explore the music of protest of those who were treated as "untouchables" by a caste hierarchy that has ruled the Indian sub-continent for thousands of years.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: GSC Movie Night screens "(A)sexual"
Description: Studies show that 1 percent of the population is asexual. The documentary "(A)sexual" follows four individuals in an exploration of this largely unknown territory.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center conference room, 2.112G

Summary: Texas Royals spirit group holds info session
Description: Meet the newest spirit group on campus, the Texas Royals. Founded in remembrance of Coach Darrell Royal (DKR), Texas Royals are rooted in spirit and sisterhood. Email texasroyalsrecruitment@gmail.com for more information, or attend this information session.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), lobby

Summary: Texas men's tennis plays Penn State
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on Penn State. Support your Longhorns as they face the Nitty Lions.

Summary: Curator's tour of "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" offered
Description:
Roy Flukinger, senior research curator of photography, leads a tour of "Arnold Newman: Masterclass," which explores the career of photographer Arnold Newman (1918-2006), who created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century.



The first major exhibition of the photographer's work since his death, "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" showcases the entire range of Newman's photography, featuring many prints for the first time. Newman's archive resides at the Ransom Center.

Summary: Diversity Talent Show auditions held
Description: The Black Student Alliance's Freshman Action Team holds auditions for its March 22 talent show. Winner receives $100. Contact utfatinfo@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Anna's Yoga Workshop open to all levels
Description: Stressed or feeling down? Need a relaxer? Reach a new level of harmony and fitness yourself through yoga. Workshops are open to participants of any skill level.

Summary: Human Rights Student Advisory Council holds first meeting
Description: Attend the first meeting of the Human Rights Student Advisory Council (HRSAC), an organization targeted toward building cohesion among human rights student organizations on campus. Contact Saif and Lalini at uthrsac@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Violinist Giora Schmidt performs in Starling series
Description:
Giora Schmidt, violin, and Victor Asuncion, piano, perform a program of Beethoven, Schumann, Faure and Ysaye as part of the Starling Distinguished Violinist Series.



Program includes Beethoven Sonata No. 1 in D Major, Schumann Sonata No. 1 in A Minor, Faure Sonata No. 1 in A Major, Ysaye "Caprice d'apres l'etude en forme de Valse de Saint-Saens" (Valse-Caprice).

Summary: Healthyhorns Peer Educators application now available
Description: Earn class credit while being a health leader on campus and empowering fellow UT students to make well-informed decisions about their health and well-being. Healthyhorns Peer Educators receive training in the foundations of public health and provide interactive and educational outreach activities to fellow students. Apply online.

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15.

Summary: Immigration & entrepreneurship to be USCIS panel topic
Description:
Students and local entrepreneurs are invited to a panel discussion with representatives from the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS), the government agency responsible for administering immigration benefits. Issues at the nexus of immigration law, entrepreneurship and innovation to be discussed. 



USCIS will discuss ongoing efforts to streamline existing immigration pathways through its Entrepreneurs in Residence (EIR) initiative. In addition, USCIS wishes to hear from students and the local entrepreneurial community about their experiences with the current immigration process, as well as ideas to enhance current policies and programs for innovation-driven entrepreneurs.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Acting Under Secretary of State Rose Gottemoeller speaks
Description:
Acting Under Secretary of State Rose Gottemoeller, the government's chief arms control negotiator and senior adviser to the president and secretary of state on arms control, nonproliferation and disarmament policy, leads a roundtable on nuclear policy for the 21st century. 



For more information, contact Dr. Kate Weaver at ceweaver@austin.utexas.edu or Dr. Steve Biegalski at biegalski@mail.utexas.edu. Snacks provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.384, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: Steven Isenberg discusses father-and-son memoirs
Description: Edmund Gosse's "Father and Son" (1907) and J.R. Ackerley's "My Father and Myself" (1968) are compelling memoirs in the father-and-son genre by two accomplished men of letters. Author and teacher Steven Isenberg explores the burden of the secrets and mysteries that are unspoken between father and son.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Texas Rootstrikers hold meeting
Description:
Texas Rootstrikers is a nonpartisan network of online and grassroots activists fighting corruption in national and local politics. Our goal is to reform the campaign financing system to make it dependent upon the people alone, demand transparency from UT about its funders and ask that the study of institutional corruption be included in the curriculum.



Learn more about our organization and its current projects at this meeting.

Summary: Texas softball plays Texas State
Description: Texas softball hosts the Texas State Bobcats. Teacher Appreciation Day discount available for all school employees. Purchase a 25 or more group tickets to a 2013 softball game and your children (8th grade and under) can take the field with the Longhorns, based on availability. Call 512-232-3865 for details on offers.

Summary: Mahjong Club meets
Description: Join the Mahjong Club and play mahjong with fellow university students. No experience or prior knowledge required. For more information, visit our website.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on UC Santa Barbara
Description: Texas baseball host the UC Santa Barbara Gauchos in the first game of a series.

Summary: Texas men's tennis takes on Michigan
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on Michigan. Support your Longhorns as they face the Wolverines.

Summary: Texas baseball hosts UC Santa Barbara
Description: Texas baseball plays second game against the UC Santa Barbara Gauchos.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Alejandro Escovedo plays the Cactus
Description: Austin legend Alejandro Escovedo takes the stage at the Cactus Cafe for one night only. Don't miss this chance to see such an icon at this intimate, storied venue.

Summary: Texas baseball plays UC Santa Barbara
Description: Texas baseball hosts the UC Santa Barbara Gauchos. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: SoundSpace: Music performed in Blanton galleries
Description: SoundSpace creates exciting visual and sonic experiences in multiple simultaneous performances throughout the Blanton's galleries. This concert, with performances by Graham Reynolds and Mother Falcon, features the music of young composers who transcend distinctions between classical and rock music.

Summary: Texas softball plays Texas State
Description:
Texas softball hosts the Texas State Bobcats. The $8 web coupon includes one general admission ticket, hot dog and drink. Coupons must be printed and redeemed at the McCombs Field Box Office on game day. Teachers and other school employees get appreciation discount. Call 512-232-3865 for details. 



Fan Appreciation Day: Join Texas softball for a fun-filled day to celebrate the best college softball fans in the nation. A variety of team Texas softball memorabilia will be given away during the game. Afterward, join the team for an autograph session on the field.

Summary: Apply for 2013 Mitchell undergrad awards by March 25
Description:
Each year, the Mitchell award recognizes seven University of Texas undergraduates for superior scholarly or creative achievement. Faculty are encouraged to nominate talented juniors and seniors for the University Co-op George H. Mitchell Undergraduate Student Awards for Academic Excellence. Visit the link below. 



Faculty members should nominate students who have demonstrated superior scholarly or creative achievement through a notable paper or thesis, research project, creative or artistic endeavor, or academic work. To qualify for an award, nominees must be either a junior or senior currently enrolled at UT Austin or have received their undergraduate degree in December 2012. Submitted work should be finished or close to finished (e.g., a complete draft of a thesis or research paper). Previous Mitchell Award recipients are eligible only if the submitted work is a completely different project.

Summary: Participate in a video interview for Texas OnRamps
Description:
Interview participants are sought for a video project to be used in a high school rhetoric curriculum. Interview topics explore issues of gender, race, ethnicity and American identity as well as questions about critical thinking. 



Contact producer Mary Beth Chambers at marybeth@houndstoothstudio.com,including both mobile number and email address. Interviews conducted Monday, March 18, from 9 a.m.-5 p.m.



Additional questions can be addressed to Chambers at the email above or 512-699-6757, or interviewer Amelia Torres at amelia.torres@enspire.com or 512-745-7644.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), southwest corner outside Cactus Cafe

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in any amount up to $2,000. To learn more, attend an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu, or visit us online.

Summary: Texas men's tennis faces North Carolina
Description: The Texas men's tennis team takes on North Carolina. Support your Longhorns as they compete against the Tar Heels.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Oral Roberts
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Oral Roberts Golden Eagles. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Apply for fall & summer DHFS student staff positions
Description: The Division of Housing and Food Service is now accepting applications for summer and fall 2013 positions. Apply by March 26. Positions include: Summer Conference Assistant, Summer Clerical Assistant, Summer Resident Assistant, and Fall/Spring Clerical Assistant. An information session will be held on March 19 at 7 p.m. in the San Jacinto MPR.  Contact DHFSSTUDENTJOBS@austin.utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: Register for Strategic Leadership classes from PDC
Description:
Registration is open for Strategic Leadership courses from the university's Professional Development Center (PDC): "Strategic Leadership and Management" (April 16), "People Matter: Making the Case for HR" (May 21) and "Moving Forward - Transformation and Vision" (June 11). Take courses separately or together as a certificate program.



PDC is a department of the Division of Continuing and Innovative Education.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Attend a FAFSA info and completion session
Description: The Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) is the one application needed to apply for financial aid grants, work study and student loans for the 2013-2014 school year. Attend this session for help completing your FAFSA. Bring 2012 tax returns for yourself and your parent(s), or 2012 W-2s or 2011 tax returns. UT Austin's priority deadline is March 15.

Summary: Texas women's tennis plays Oklahoma
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Big 12 rival Oklahoma. Support the Longhorns as they face the Sooners.

Summary: Texas men's tennis plays Virginia
Description: Support Longhorn men's tennis as they face the Virginia Cavaliers.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Texas Tech
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor, the Texas Tech Red Raiders. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals.

Summary: Taiwanese musicians perform on campus during SXSW week
Description: The Taiwanese International Student Association hosts a performance by three Taiwanese bands visiting Austin for SXSW. Hear Wonfu, Peggy Hsu and Cosmos People in concert.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Texas Tech
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor, the Texas Tech Red Raiders. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Texas women's tennis takes on Oklahoma State
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor Oklahoma State. Support your Longhorns as they face the Cowboys.

Summary: Texas baseball plays final game against Texas Tech
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor, the Texas Tech Red Raiders, in the final game of a series. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals.

Summary: Yo Gabba Gabba! performs early show at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Yo Gabba Gabba! Live! takes the stage at Bass Concert Hall with a new show, "Get the Sillies Out." A second show takes place at 5 p.m.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Yo Gabba Gabba! performs at Bass Concert Hall
Description: Yo Gabba Gabba! Live! takes the stage at Bass Concert Hall with a new show, "Get the Sillies Out." An early show takes place at 2 p.m.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Eric Clapton performs with special guest The Wallflowers
Description: Rock 'n' roll legend Eric Clapton headlines, with special guest The Wallflowers. The concert in Austin is Clapton's only appearance in the area. Clapton is the only three-time inductee into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, has won 17 Grammy awards and placed second on Rolling Stone's list of the "100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time" last year.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Student Health Advisory Committee applications are open
Description: Applications to join the Student Health Advisory Committee (SHAC) are available online at the link below. Learn more about SHAC and apply for fall 2013. All applications are due by midnight, April 4.

Summary: United to Serve Week celebrates learning, civic engagement
Description: United to Serve is a system-wide initiative of the University of Texas to unite all of the campuses in service. Students, administrators, faculty and staff volunteer their time and talents for service projects. For a listing of the week's events, visit the link below.

Summary: Orange Jackets presents Week of Women
Description: Orange Jackets hosts Week of Women, a week-long celebration of womanhood centered around the theme "Inform, Empower, and Celebrate." This year's line-up of events includes films, monologues, panel discussions and more. Visit the link below for details.

Summary: Projects for Underserved Communities accepts applications
Description: Projects for Underserved Communities (PUC) matches engineering students with communities overseas that need the skills and resources UT engineers can provide. Social work students are also needed. Apply by 5 p.m., March 29. Find application and more information at the link below.

Summary: Diabetes, blood pressure, obesity study seeks participants
Description: Overweight individuals with type 2 diabetes and/or high blood pressure are sought for a research study investigating the impact of metabolic and cardiovascular health on cognition and brain function in adults 40-60 years old. For more information and to sign up, visit the link below, call 512-471-7926 or email neurolab.ut@gmail.com.

Summary: Cultural Forms anthropology talks look at surveillance
Description: The UT Department of Anthropology presents "Body Issues: Perverse Surveillance and the  Sexualized Sovereign," a talk by Randolph Lewis, associate professor in American studies; and "Gazing or Glancing?: Photography, Surveillance, and Socialist Colonialism," presented by Craig Campbell, assistant professor in anthropology.

Summary: Researcher says yes, it is possible to be smart and happy
Description: Bites of Wellness, a lunch-and-learn series, presents "If You're So Smart, Why Aren't You Happy?" with Dr. Raj Raghunathan, McCombs marketing professor, who discusses the three most important determinants of a happy and fulfilling life. Sign up on TXClass PN 288. For questions, email healthpoint.wellness@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: AT&T Education & Conference Center (ATT), The Carillon, Private Dining Room 1

Summary: United to Serve holds campus-wide open house
Description: Faculty, students and staff are invited to attend an open house at the Longhorn Center for Civic Engagement to learn about the programs and services the center offers to the UT Austin community. This event serves as the kickoff for United to Serve Week. For more information, visit the link below.

Summary: Orange Jackets Week of Women screens "Bridesmaids"
Description: Kick off Orange Jackets' annual Week of Women event with a screening of the popular film "Bridesmaids." Free t-shirts and other giveaways available. Screening is followed by a panel discussion with UT professors on women in the media.

Summary: Computer Science hosts Integrated BS/MS info session
Description: Learn about the five-year Integrated BS/MS Program in computer science. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Forty Acres Fest holds final organization info session
Description: This is the third and final mandatory information session for authorized student organizations interested in participating in Forty Acres Fest 2013, which takes place Saturday, April 6. Only one representative per organization is required to attend. Apply to participate at this link: http://deanofstudents.utexas.edu/sa/40acres/index.php. Contact Vicky Nguyen at faforganizations2013@gmail.com with questions or if you cannot send a representative.

Summary: Palestinian poet Remi Kanazi reads and discusses work
Description: The Palestine Solidarity Committee, in conjunction with the Society for Islamic Awareness and the International Socialist Organization, presents a performance by Palestinian poet Remi Kenazi. Kanazi is a poet, writer and activist based in New York City and author of "Poetic Injustice: Writings on Resistance and Palestine."

Summary: Film about 1936 Berlin Olympics screened
Description: "Berlin 36" tells the story of the Nazis' attempt to keep Jewish athletes out of the 1936 Olympics. When they sabotage a German Jewish high jumper and replace her with a woman who harbors her own secret, the pair become friends and symbolically challenge an empire.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA), Julius Glickman Conference Center 1.302B

Summary: Pivot (Community of Science) navigation class offered
Description:
Attend Pivot navigation sessions. Pivot brings together the right research opportunities, funding and people quickly and

easily - for faculty, staff

researchers and students. Register via TXCLASS at https://utdirect.utexas.edu/txclass/index.WBX, course ID: SP 802. Contact liza@austin.utexas.edu or 512-471-2877 with questions.

Summary: "Vagina Monologues" tickets are on sale
Description: "Vagina Monologues" tickets can be purchased for three upcoming shows, performed on March 21-23 at 7 p.m. at BUR 106. Purchase in person at the Gender and Sexuality Center or at the link below.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: McNair Scholars program accepting applications
Description: The McNair Scholars Program is accepting applications until April 19.
