The goal of this federally funded program is to increase the number of students in doctoral degree programs who are low-income and first-generation undergraduates or students who come from groups underrepresented in graduate education. Learn more at the website below.

Summary: Adults 50 and up who have played sports sought for study
Description:
Adults ages 50-80 who have played any type of sport at any level in their lifetime are sought for a study on how sport may be designed to help people age successfully and enhance quality of life. Contact Dave Walsh, Ph.D. student, at 210-386-3668 or at dwalsh@austin.utexas.edu.



This research has been approved by the Institutional Review Board.

Summary: Students for Clean Water hold pizza fund-raiser
Description: Help Students for Clean Water raise funds for clean water projects in Ethiopia by enjoying pizza and drinks in exchange for donations to our campaign. Eat so they can drink.

Summary: Kennedy's Vietnam policy examined in lecture
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Kennedy, Vietnam, and Audience Costs" with Marc Trachtenberg, Professor at the University of California, Los Angeles. Trachtenberg examines a variety of historical interpretations of President John F. Kennedy's Vietnam policy which in a discussion of audience costs theory.

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in any amount up to $2,000. To learn more, attend an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu, or visit us online.

Summary: Commercial morality in Japanese business ethics discussed
Description:
Janet Hunter, Saji professor of economic history at London School of Economics, discusses Western criticism of Japanese traders for their low "commercial morality" during 1870s-1930s. A 3 p.m. reception precedes the talk.



Analysis of the commercial morality issue, whose influence on Japanese-Western economic relations persisted into the postwar period, offers insights into the complex interaction between cultural difference and the transnational spread of ideas and business practices.

Summary: Budget and build credit as a college student
Description: Acclimate your saving and spending style to the college lifestyle. Learn how to create and use a daily budget, save money, maintain and grow a savings account and build credit.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment.

 

University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program. The next information session takes place Tuesday, March 26.

Summary: Ethical leadership is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
This training is designed to provide a comprehensive and interactive perspective on ethics and integrity-based leadership. Participants will reflect on personal values and how they influence ethical leadership and decision making. Participants will also be introduced to an approach for evaluating and making ethical decisions. 



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: "Absolutely Safe" screened, on topic of breast implants
Description: Attend a screening of the documentary "Absolutely Safe," which takes an open-minded, personal approach to the controversy over breast implant safety. A Q&A with filmmaker Carol Ciancutti-Leyva and Judy Norsigian, executive director, Our Bodies Ourselves, follows the screening.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Orange Jackets presents "Get Sexy, Get Consent" with VAV
Description: "Get Sexy. Get Consent" is a highly interactive one-hour program that examines how we negotiate sex and consent, boundaries and safety. Trained student-facilitators act out scenes, monologues and improv dialogues to engage audiences on questions such as What is consent? How do you know that someone else wants what you want? How do you communicate your boundaries?

Summary: Struggle for Justice in Palestine is lecture topic
Description: The Society for Islamic Awareness presents a talk by Anna Baltzer titled "Occupation and Apartheid: The Struggle for Justice in Palestine." Baltzer is a Jewish-American, a Columbia University graduate, former Fulbright scholar and an award-winning lecturer, author and activist for Palestinian human rights.

Summary: Film examines textbook censorship by state education board
Description: "The Revisionaries" is a brand new documentary on the battle between the Texas Freedom Network (TFN) and the Texas State Board of Education over textbook censorship and public school curriculum standards. TFN president Kathy Miller and documentary director Scott Thurman attend a Q&A after the screening. Free pizza served, with vegetarian and gluten-free options.

Summary: Operation Smile meets
Description: Operation Smile is a nonprofit organization that transforms lives across the globe by funding surgeries for children and young adults who are born with facial deformities, specifically cleft lip or cleft palate. Join us in our efforts to spread smiles. New members welcome. Food provided.

Summary: DHFS fall & summer student staff info session held
Description: The Division of Housing and Food Service holds an information session about student positions available for summer and fall 2013. Summer Conference Assistant, Summer Clerical Assistant, Summer Resident Assistant and Fall/Spring Clerical Assistant positions are available. Apply by March 26. Learn more at this session or at the link below. Contact DHFSSTUDENTJOBS@austin.utexas.edu with  questions.
Location: San Jacinto Residence Hall (SJR), multipurpose room

Summary: UT SoundBrain auditory study seeks participants
Description: The UT SoundBrain lab seeks monolingual American English speakers for an auditory study. Participants must have normal hearing and have no musical experience. Study takes approximately 2.5 hours. Contact utsoundbrain@gmail.com or call 512-471-8646 to make an appointment.

Summary: Sports analysis innovation challenge seeks participants
Description: Participate in an MBA program innovation challenge to improve an application that helps sports fans analyze the performance of their favorite team and players in new ways, providing a competitive advantage in your fantasy sports league. Rewards provided. Visit the link below for more information.

Summary: Idea to Product application deadline is March 26
Description: The I2P competition is an early-stage technology commercialization plan competition open to UT Austin students of all disciplines who are interested in technology-focused entrepreneurship. Entries should be unique and innovative, feasible to implement and address an identified market need. Apply by Tuesday, March 26. Visit the link below for details.

Summary: Arts Internship and Networking Fair announced
Description: Fine Arts Career Services hosts the spring 2013 Arts Internship and Networking Fair, featuring networking opportunities with numerous employers and internship information for summer and beyond. Past employers have included the Alley Theatre, SXSW, Austin Creative Alliance, Fisterra Studio, Austin Music Foundation and others.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall, 4th floor lobby

Summary: RecSports Job Fair announced
Description: Students seeking a part-time job for summer and/or fall can apply and interview for all types of positions at the RecSports Job Fair. Be ready for an interview by bringing a completed application. Forms are available for download at the link below or at Gregory Gym.

Summary: "UT Tiene Talento" auditions held; winners earn cash
Description: Cash prizes will be awarded for the winning acts in "UT Tiene Talento." UT Tiene Talento seeks students to participate in a showcase of Hispanic culture. Spanish or English acts welcome. Open auditions to be held through March 29. Email sigmadeltapizeta@gmail.com to schedule an audition time.

Summary: Dr. Eddie Chambers gives faculty book presentation
Description: Dr. Eddie Chambers presents and discusses his recently published book, "Things Done Change: The Cultural Politics of Recent Black Artists in Britain." Chambers is a professor at The University of Texas at Austin in the Department of Art and Art History. Dr. Cherise Smith, associate director of the John L. Warfield Center and professor of Art and Art History serves as discussant.

Summary: Scholar analyzes imperial ambitions of Nazi Germany
Description:
In a talk titled "The Ambitions of the SS in the East: Visualizing the Built Environment of Auschwitz," Professor Paul Jaskot analyzes the imperial ambitions of the Nazi SS as well as its ideological promotion of genocide as interrelated goals both revealed and concealed by the architecture of Auschwitz. 



Jaskot is professor of art history at DePaul University and director of the Summer Institute on the Holocaust and Jewish Civilization at Northwestern University.

Summary: Learn about volunteer opportunities at Knowledge & Noms
Description: Meet representatives from Teach for America, the Peace Corps, AmeriCorps and the UT Volunteer and Service Learning Center to hear about opportunities starting now or after graduation.
Location: The Gender and Sexuality Center, SAC 2.112

Summary: Roundtable examines legacies of Hugo Chávez
Description: LILAS and the Department of Government present a roundtable to discuss the impact of Hugo Chávez's administration on Venezuela and on the region. Speakers include Raul O. Fregoso Bailon, PhD candidate; Raul Madrid, associate professor of government; Jorge Mario Sanchez Egozcue, LLILAS Tinker visiting professor and professor of economics, Universidad de La Habana, Cuba; and Kurt Weyland, professor of government. For more details, contact Paloma Diaz at p.diaz@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: United to Serve Week announced
Description: United to Serve Week features daily events that culminate in a day of service, held Saturday, March 23, in the Dove Springs neighborhood. For information on the week's events or to register, visit the link below.

Summary: Get started with Google Books and Google Scholar
Description: Learn how to use two specialized Google searches - Google Books and Google Scholar - in conjunction with library resources for research and discovery.

Summary: Global Village 2013 seeks cultural organizations
Description: Participate in Global Village 2013, a campus-wide international culture fair hosted by AIESEC Austin, engaging over 40 student organizations, language departments and performance groups in the promotion of cultural awareness and tolerance. Sign up to be a country booth representative by Wednesday, March 20. Contact Teresa Chueng at globalvillageaustin@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Bilingualism in the foreign language classroom examined
Description: In a presentation titled "Bilingualism and Biculturalism in the Foreign Language Classroom," three Spanish heritage language teachers and researchers discuss classroom activities that ask students to question, defend and in some instances reassess, their assumptions about "what sounds right" in their language. The tasks specifically focus on Spanish vocabulary, culture and word order.

Summary: Dinshah Irani and Indo-Iranian culture are topic of talk
Description:
The Middle East History Lecture Series presents "Patron and Patriot: Dinshah Irani and the Revival of Indo-Iranian Culture," a lecture by Afshin Marashi, University of Oklahoma. 



Marashi examines the life and work of Dinshah Irani, a prominent Parsi scholar, lawyer and philanthropist who was a key intellectual intermediary between the Parsi community of Bombay and the intellectual community of Iranian nationalists during the 1920s and 1930s.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Lone Star Room 3.208

Summary: NASA Orion Program inside view presented
Description: Larry Price of Lockheed Martin Space Systems discusses NASA's new Orion spacecraft, which will serve as an exploration vehicle to carry space crews to space, provide emergency abort capability, sustain the crew during the space travel and provide safe reentry from deep-space return velocities.

Summary: Stocks, bonds and mutual funds are Bevonomics topic
Description: Find out what these stocks, bonds and mutual funds are, and how they work. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Learn to market yourself, products and ideas at workshop
Description: Delta Sigma Pi hosts "Become a SELLular Device," a workshop featuring David Trapp (St. Jude's sales rep), Ariel Skolnick (Dell sales rep), Professor Herb Miller and Professor Kristie Loescher. Learn to market your personal brand, ideas and products, efficiently and creatively. Food and drinks provided.

Summary: Texas Evening MBA info session held
Description: The Texas Evening MBA Program holds an information session for potential students. Learn about the program and meet admissions staff, current students and alumni.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), M2 level, 202

Summary: Israeli film about a legendary band is screened
Description: Borrowing from diverse genres, including samurai theater, spaghetti westerns and South American mysticism, "The Ballad of the Weeping Spring" follows the adventures of a son who pledges to reunite his father's legendary band to play one last concert before one of the band members dies.

Summary: Glimmer of Hope and Pratham Austin discuss their work
Description: Two Austin-based nonprofit organizations, A Glimmer of Hope and Pratham Austin, discuss the operations of their organizations and the issues they support. A Glimmer of Hope works toward ending the world's water crisis. Pratham Austin works to eradicate illiteracy in India. Doors open at 6:30 p.m.

Summary: TASA general meeting hosts guest speakers
Description: The Taiwanese American Students Association welcomes Dr. Yvonne Chang, director of the Taiwan Studies Program at UT Austin, and Hanna Huang, UT alumna, who speak about Taiwanese-American identity.

Summary: TPSM hosts Austin premiere of Jackie Robinson biopic
Description:
The Texas Program In Sports and Media (TPSM) hosts the Austin premiere of the Warner Bros. film "42," on the life of Jackie Robinson (played by Chadwick Boseman). A panel discussion follows, moderated by baseball historian and attorney Talmage Boston, and featuring actor Boseman, Sharon Robinson and Branch Rickey III. Contact christopher.hart@austin.utexas.edu for tickets.



Sharon Robinson is the daughter of the late Jackie Robinson and an educational consultant for Major League Baseball; Branch B. Rickey III is grandson of the late Branch Rickey and president of the Pacific Coast League.

Summary: Stalin film series screens "East-West"
Description: The Stalin Film Series presents "East-West," winner of a Golden Globe for Best Foreign Language Film in 1999. A naive Russian émigré and his family repatriate to the post-World War II Soviet Union only to discover, too late, the full truth about life under socialism. In French and Russian with English subtitles. Runs 120 min.

Summary: Weekly Feminist Action Project meets
Description: Join the Feminist Action Project for feminist discussion, zine making, anti-oppression workshops and more. Email feministactionproject@gmail.com or "like" us on Facebook for more information, or attend our Wednesday night meetings. Everyone interested in feminism is welcome.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC) 2.112, Gender and Sexuality Center

Summary: Interactive panel asks "Can Women Have It All?"
Description:
Join Orange Jackets and the Feminist Action Project for an interactive panel on "women having it all" and hear from professionals about the work/life balance. Part of Orange Jackets Week of Women:

https://www.facebook.com/events/296577977137331/?fref=ts.

Summary: Libby Kirkpatrick performs at the Cactus
Description: Libby Kirkpatrick is a powerful and refreshingly original singer-songwriter and acoustic guitarist who stuns audiences with her wide vocal range, serious command of dynamics, award-winning lyrics and soaring voice.

Summary: Real Role Models announces scholarship opportunity
Description: Real Role Models announces a scholarship to be awarded to a current UT student who demonstrates active engagement with the university and Austin community and embodies the spirit of mentorship. The award is presented at the "I Am Not a Bully" dinner on Wednesday, April 10. Apply at the link below. To learn more about Real Role Models Week, contact realrolemodels2011@gmail.com.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: César Chávez Identity Art Contest announced
Description:
Submit a piece of art that depicts how your identity reflects the values, history and principles of César Chávez or the Chicano movement. Submit artwork to the Student Events Center office (UNB 4.312) or the Multicultural Engagement Center (SAC 1.102) by 5 p.m. March 25. Submitted art will be displayed at the March 27 César Chávez activities. Learn more at link.



Winner receives a Kindle Fire HD.

Summary: Ongoing Infant Music Study seeks participants
Description: The Infant Music Lab seeks participants ages 6-24 months for a study on musical play. Participation involves playing with music toys with your child and answering some questions. Appointments (approx. 30 minutes) available days, evenings and weekends. Contact Carla at infantmusiclab@gmail.com or 512-475-7880. For more information about our research, click on "Research" at the link below.

Summary: Researchers seek subjects age 40-90 with osteoarthritis
Description:
The Kinesiology & Health Education's Cardiovascular Aging Research Laboratory seeks subjects ages 40-90 with diagnosed osteoarthritis (OA) to participate in a three-month study on the effects of stationary cycling or swimming on OA symptoms. Contact the lab at arthritisUT@gmail.com or 512-471-8594.  



Subjects will receive three months of supervised aerobic conditioning in UT facilities, pre- and post-training cardiovascular health assessments as well as $100 compensation upon trial completion.

Summary: United to Serve holds service reflection & info session
Description: Students are invited to enjoy cotton candy on Gregory Plaza and sign a reflection board describing the meaning of their service and volunteerism experiences at UT Austin. A Longhorn Center for Civic Engagement table will have information on organizations that help students learn how to bridge their service experiences with opportunities after graduation.

Summary: UT Health Science Center professor presents seminar
Description: Feng Liu, PhD, professor of pharmacology at The University of Texas Health Science Center at San Antonio, presents a seminar titled "Adiponectin Biosynthesis, Signaling, and Function."

Summary: Kinesiology & Health Education Job & Internship Fair held
Description:
Education Career Services hosts a Kinesiology and Health Education Job & Internship Fair geared toward students majoring in athletic training, exercise science, general kinesiology, health promotion and fitness, physical culture and sports, sport management and youth and community studies. Dress professionally and bring your resume.



This is a great opportunity to search for internships, network with various employers, familiarize yourself with the job market and search for employment opportunities.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Lunch with Landmarks celebrates new LeWitt pieces
Description: Landmarks celebrates the recent installation of two works by Sol LeWitt at the Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex & Dell Computer Science Hall. The concrete block structure "Circle with Towers" provides a gathering place for the community outside the Speedway entrance to the complex. "Wall Drawing #520" adds lush color to three walls in the atrium of the complex. Lunch With Landmarks provides a food truck and docent-led tours throughout this event.
Location: Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex & Dell Hall (GDC), Speedway entrance, south of 24th St

Summary: Master's in Engineering online information session held
Description: A live online information session discusses the engineering master's degree program geared toward the working professional offered through the Cockrell School of Engineering at The University of Texas at Austin. Programs offered are Engineering Management and Software Engineering; they meet one weekend (Friday/Saturday) a month for two years.

Summary: Greek art in "Through the Eyes of Texas" is talk topic
Description: Associate Professor Nassos Papalexandrou presents a gallery talk on Greek art in the Blanton exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections."

Summary: Advanced EndNote course offered
Description: This class covers advanced EndNote features such as modifying output styles, creating subject bibliographies, using connection files and more. Attendees should have taken "Introduction to EndNote," or be familiar with the basics of EndNote.

Summary: Staff Council holds monthly meeting
Description: The monthly meeting of the Staff Council is open to all staff and all are encouraged to attend. This month's guest is President Bill Powers; the start time is one half-hour earlier than usual.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: "Race or Color" category in Brazil's demographies examined
Description: Marcelo Paixão, Federal University of Rio de Janeiro, presents a lecture titled "The 'Race or Color' Category in Brazilian Demographic Databases: History, International Comparison, and Current State of the Art."
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: Computer Science hosts Game Development info session
Description: Learn more about the Game Development Certificate in Computer Science. Information session held for computer science students. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Texas women's tennis takes on Iowa State
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor Iowa State. Support your Longhorns as they face the Cyclones.

Summary: The Story of LingQ is recounted by system's creator
Description:
Learn about LingQ (pronounced "link") from creator Steve Kaufmann, a former forest products executive who says he "got in over his head" in a 10-year project to create the LingQ online language learning system. 



Kaufman describes his initial inspiration and ongoing challenges. Much like language learning itself, building an online learning community requires perseverance, commitment and a willingness to accept risk and uncertainty.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA) 3.102E, Glickman Conference Center

Summary: Make the most of your scholarship search
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships and learn writing tips to improve your application at this workshop.

Summary: Viewpoint Series presents Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The Viewpoint Series presents a lecture by Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck. Levine specializes in contemporary art, with a career in scholarship, teaching and criticism. Rodenbeck teaches 20th and 21st century European and American art at Sarah Lawrence College, with a special interest in technology and feminist theory.

Summary: Compliance & ethics are S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Compliance and ethics are the topics of a workshop offered for students employed by UT Austin. Compliance and ethics programs are a standard practice in business. Learn the importance of these programs in the public and private sectors. Presented by University Compliance Services.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. 



University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Landmarks hosts lecture on new Sol LeWitt artworks
Description:
Landmarks hosts a special lecture to celebrate the addition of two Sol LeWitt works to its campus collection. LeWitt is a pioneer of minimal and conceptual art. Veronica Roberts, director of research for the LeWitt Catalogue Raisonné and curator of the Blanton Museum of Art, presents the talk.



About the two new works: "Circle With Towers" provides a social gathering place at the Speedway entrance to the new Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex and Dell Computer Science Hall while "Wall Drawing #520" adds vivid color to three walls in the atrium of the complex.  in the ground floor auditorium of the complex.
Location: Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex & Dell Hall (GDC), ground floor auditorium

Summary: Blanton's Third Thursday is evening of art & activities
Description: Attend the Blanton's free evening of art and activities, including Beat the Rush Concert (5:30 p.m.), Art Gazes with Melinda Mayer (6 p.m.), Yoga in the Galleries (6:30 p.m.; passes available from 5:30) and a docent-led tour (7:30 p.m.).

Summary: UT Energy Symposium presents Student Research Showcase
Description:
This week, the UT Energy Symposium presents the Student Research Showcase, focusing on smart grid technology. Presenters are Josh Rhodes, Robert Fares and Steve Bourne.



Rhodes, Ph.D. candidate and member of the Webber Energy Group, presents "Data-Driven Results from the Pecan Street Smart Grid Demonstration Project." Mechanical engineering graduate student Robert Fares gives a talk titled "Towards a Distributed Grid: A Quantitative Assessment of Community Energy Storage for Islanding." Civil, architectural and environmental engineering Ph.D. student Steve Bourne presents "Thermal Storage and the Building Side of Smartgrid."

Summary: Third Thursday at CoFA presents money management session
Description: Learn how to manage your money with Dennis Hobbs of RBC Wealth Management. Attendees names will be entered into a drawing for two tickets to Circa on April 27. Free pizza provided, courtesy of Texas Performing Arts. RSVP to rsvp@texasperformingarts.org.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: University Investors Association holds general meeting
Description: The University Investors Association (UIA) holds its general meeting with a market update and social afterward. Mingle with members at Austin's Pizza following the meeting.

Summary: "Death and the Maidens" revisits 1968 massacre of Tlatelolco
Description: Among the hundreds of students and supporters murdered by the Mexican government on October 2, 1968, at Tlatelolco, one - Ana María Regina Teuscher Kruger, a 19-year old medical student and hostess for the impending Mexico City Olympics - captured the imagination of various artists. George Flaherty, assistant professor of Latin American and U.S. Latino Art, discusses her treatment in photography and literature.

Summary: Texas Graduate Christian Fellowship holds Bible study
Description: Join Texas Graduate Christian Fellowship for weekly dinner and Bible study. All graduate students are welcome.

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship discusses Christ's forgiveness
Description: Join the University Elohim Fellowship, a new Bible study organization, for a discussion titled "What Is Christ's Secret for the Forgiveness of Sins?" Email UEFellowship2012@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Synapse presents NeurOlympics
Description: NeurOlympics is a trivia game competition on the topic of neuroscience. Teams of four can sign up by emailing UTsynapse@gmail.com, or come cheer on your friends. Prizes awarded and food served to teams and attendees.

Summary: "5 Broken Cameras" documentary screened
Description: The Society for Islamic Awareness screens the Oscar-nominated documentary "5 Broken Cameras." An extraordinary and deeply personal film, "5 Broken Cameras" is first-hand account of nonviolent resistance in Bil'in, a West Bank village threatened by encroaching Israeli settlements. It was collaborated on by Israelis and Palestinians.

Summary: French comedy about relationships is screened
Description: "The DaySaw Your Heart" follows the story of Justine and her father Eli, who is expecting a child with his much-younger wife. In an attempt to become closer to his daughter, Eli begins to forge friendships with Justine's ex-boyfriends. But when Justine falls in love and fears her father will ruin it, the family teeters on the brink of destruction.

Summary: RTF presents "The Big Sleep" with Dr. Caroline Frick
Description:
Dr. Caroline Frick presents "Interpreting 'The Big Sleep': How Film Preservation Can Unlock Film Mysteries." 



Known and beloved as one of the most iconic film noirs of the 1940s, director Howard Hawks's movie continues to entertain audiences decades after its production. Frick, RTF assistant professor and film archivist, discusses why film history and preservation can help explain the movie's mysterious plot.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium

Summary: "The Vagina Monologues" performed
Description: "The Vagina Monologues" by Eve Ensler is performed on campus. Tickets are available in the Gender and Sexuality Center (SAC 2.112) or online at the link below. All proceeds benefit the Voices Against Violence Survivor Fund.

Summary: "Night of the Living Dead" screened
Description: Students for Clean Water presents its Fright Night Film Screening, featuring "Night of the Living Dead" (1968). Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Snacks sold outside before the show. All donations support clean water projects in Ethiopia.

Summary: TASA presents Culture Night
Description: The Taiwanese American Student Association holds Culture Night in collaboration with the Taiwanese International Student Association (TiSA), recreating Taiwan's famous night markets, with free food, games and raffle prizes. Enjoy Mapo tofu, green onion pancakes, shaved ice and more.

Summary: Author T.C. Boyle reads from his work
Description: The prolific author of over 20 fiction titles, T.C. Boyle recently lodged his archives with the university's Ransom Center. He will read from his work and answer audience questions.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Austin Classical Guitar Society presents Susan McDonald
Description: Texas-based touring and recording artist Susan McDonald makes her Cactus debut, sharing original music, including her multimedia work "The Aquarium: A Marine Micro-Ballet for Guitar and Sea Creatures." Intrigued? Music begins at 8 p.m. as members of the Community Guitarists program open the show with solo selections.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. Tour the Through the Eyes of Texas exhibit.

Summary: Chile's Teatrocinema presents "Sin Sangre"
Description: In this ArtesAméricas performance, Teatrocinema, Chile's inventive and original theater company creates an ingenious fusion of cinema and theater with their premier of  "Sin Sangre" (Without Blood), adapted from a novella by Alessandro Baricco with all the darkness of film noir and tension of a 1960s B-movie thriller. In Spanish with English supertitles.

Summary: Humanities Research Award Symposium announced
Description: The College of Liberal Arts' inaugural Humanities Research Award Symposium showcases the research of the 2009 Humanities Research Award recipients. The $15,000 award was established in 2009 by Dean Randy L. Diehl in response to a shortage of external grants for vital humanities research. A reception follows in the Texas Union Sinclair Suite.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: Metropolitan Museum of Art conservator presents talk
Description:
Sarah Scaturro, the conservator in charge of the conservation laboratory at The Costume Institute, Metropolitan Museum of Art, presents a talk titled "The Future of Textile Conservation and Museum Management."



Scaturro was formerly the textile conservator and assistant curator of fashion at the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum, Smithsonian Institution. She teaches fashion archiving in FIT's Fashion and Textiles Studies MA program and material culture studies in Parsons' Fashion Studies MA program. A member of the Board of Directors for the Textile Arts Center and the Costume Society of America, Scaturro is also an independent fashion curator and lectures and publishes internationally.

Summary: Conference addresses New World versus New (and Old) Europe
Description: "Identity Politics: The New World Versus New (and Old) Europe" is a conference exploring models of identity politics, with a focus on ethnicity, race and religion, in Europe as well as in the United States.

Summary: Registration open for summer semester Informal Classes
Description: Registration is now open for summer Informal Classes, featuring dozens of returning favorites, from Boxing to Chocolate 101, as well as brand-new classes like You Can Do Magic!, Intro to Castanets and Healing with the Mind. UT admission not required. Register now.

Summary: Original quilts by Terri Waddle on display
Description: Enjoy beautifully created quilts from artist Terri Waddle, on view Monday-Friday at Bass Concert Hall through May 2.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Dialogue in language learning is conference topic
Description: A conference titled "Dialogue in Multilingual, Multicompetent, and Multimodal Communities of Practice" focuses on questions such as "How can the study of dialogue advance the area of language learning?" and "What can interaction studies in various contexts of multilingualism and multimodalities contribute to our understanding of being multicompetent?" Learn more at the link below.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA) 1.302A Glickman Conference Center

Summary: Students sought for short study on consumer preference
Description: University students are sought for an online survey on consumer preference of socks. Filling out the survey takes no longer than 10 minutes. All survey participants will be thanked for their time. Visit the link below.

Summary: Horns Leading Horns peer leadership educators sought
Description: Horns Leading Horns peer leadership educators at the Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI) are motivated, qualified individuals who make it a priority to develop and continuously enhance their leadership skills. Learn about and apply for a leadership position at the link below.

Summary: LEAP mentor applications due
Description: Motivated, qualified individuals who work to develop and continuously enhance their leadership skills are well suited for student leadership positions within the university's Leadership and Ethics Institute (LEI). Apply to be a LEAP mentor today.

Summary: Register for one-day productivity course from PDC
Description:
Registration is open for FranklinCovey: The 5 Choices to Extraordinary Productivity, offered on April 10 from the university's Professional Development Center (PDC). Learn to align your daily and weekly tasks with your most important goals and move from being buried in emails, texts and unnecessary meetings to extraordinary productivity.



The PDC is a department of the Division of Continuing and Innovative Education (CIE).

Summary: World Water Day grill and rally announced
Description: Celebrate World Water Day and the importance of clean, safe water. Students for Clean Water will be grilling burgers and hot dogs all day, and accepting donations. All proceeds go to our campaign to build safe water projects in Ethiopia.

Summary: Artist talk presented by master printer Allan Edmunds
Description: African American master printer Allan Edmunds presents an artist talk. He is the founder, in 1972, of the Brandywine Print Workshop, which for the past forty years has produced lithographs from a plethora of local, national and international artists to generate dialogues about the relationship between art and social engagement.

Summary: Lunchtime concert presented in the Fine Arts Library
Description: A lunchtime concert by graduate and undergraduate performs and guests features chamber music for strings, including guitar. Works include J.S. Bach's 4th Suite for Solo Cello arranged for viola and Mozart's Divertimento for String Trio, K. 563.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 3.200

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Deborah Carr
Description: Deborah Carr, Department of Sociology at Rutgers University, gives a talk titled "We Don't Die Alone: The Role of Families in End-of-Life Planning and Bereavement Processes."

Summary: Gender symposium features talk by Dr. Nancy Stalker
Description: Dr. Nancy Stalker presents a talk titled "Blossoming Opportunities: Women and Ikebana in Postwar Japan." She examines growth and transformation among leading schools of ikebana, a discipline focused on the manipulation of flowers and plant material for decorative and artistic purposes, in response to emerging trends in art, market competition and women's changing lifestyles.

Summary: Panel discussion focuses on textile conservation
Description: Sarah Scaturro, the conservator in charge of the conservation laboratory at The Costume Institute, Metropolitan Museum of Art; Jill Morena, assistant curator of costumes and personal effects at the Harry Ransom Center; and Erin Muller, faculty member in the conservation program in Textiles and Apparel, participate in a panel discussion of textile conservation and museum management.

Summary: Texas women's tennis plays Miami
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on University of Miami. Support your Longhorns as they face the Hurricanes.

Summary: Janine Barchas presents "Jane Austen Between the Covers"
Description: Ready-bound books in sturdy no-nonsense cloth bindings first began to appear in the 1830s. With the advent of these so-called publishers' bindings, book covers became transformed into a marketing canvas of sorts. Janine Barchas traces the surprising history of the Austen cover - from Victorian schmaltz to Kindle-era nudity - while speculating about the range of marketing strategies and what they tell us about the shifting cultural opinion of Austen and her work.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Viewpoint seminar presents Cary Levine & Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The Viewpoint Series presents a seminar given by Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck. Levine specializes in contemporary art, with a career in scholarship, teaching and criticism. Rodenbeck teaches 20th and 21st century European and American art at Sarah Lawrence College, with a special interest in technology and feminist theory.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Alex Nagel
Description: Alex Nagel presents a lecture titled "Eastern Antiquities and Renaissance Europe." Nagel, professor of fine arts in the Institute of Fine Arts at New York University, points out that no term in this title was stable during the period around 1500. He argues that the formation of the conception of Europe required the settling down of the other two terms into their more restricted modern definitions.

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: Dr. Lisa Su speaks on life in semiconductor & tech world
Description: The Asian/Asian American Faculty & Staff Association announces the first event in their Distinguished Speaker Series. Dr. Lisa Su, senior vice president and general manager at Global Business Units, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), presents a talk titled "Life in Semiconductors and Technology: An Asian American Perspective." A reception follows the talk.
Location: Applied Computational and Engineering Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium, 2.302

Summary: Texas Rootstrikers meet
Description: Texas Rootstrikers is a nonpartisan network of online and grassroots activists fighting corruption in national and local politics whose goal is to reform the campaign financing system, demand transparency from UT about its funders and ask that the study of institutional corruption be included in the curriculum. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Turkic Spring Festival held
Description: Join the Turkic Cultures Student Association in celebrating Turkic cultures at the annual spring festival. Enjoy traditional Turkish and Kazakh music and dance, taste traditional foods and take pictures with the Sultans and Khans. Co-sponsored by Raindrop Turkish House.
Location: Main Mall (in front of the Tower)

Summary: Indian Cultural Association presents Antakshari
Description: Antakshari is a song competition with diverse rounds, giving contestants the chance to win $500 worth of prizes. Participants and audience members are welcome. Free food provided.

Summary: Palestinian music and dance performance presented
Description: Members of Layalina and the Austin Global Orchestra are joined by the UT Dabkah Dance group in a special evening of music and dance from the heart of Palestine.

Summary: Beyond Binaries Conference first keynote address held
Description:
The Graduate Committee for the Study of Religion proudly presents its first graduate conference in religious studies, "Beyond Binaries: Toward a Continuum Model of Religious Normativity." Dr. David Brakke's keynote is titled "Beyond Orthodoxy vs. Heresy - But Not Totally: Alternative Visions of Early Christianity." A reception follows the address.



Brakke is the Joe R. Engle Chair in the History of Christianity at the Ohio State University.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Drag Ball 2013 announced
Description: Queer People of Color and Allies (QPOCA) presents Drag Ball 2013, featuring RuPaul's Drag Race Season 3 Winner, Raja. Support your fellow student drag performers. Attendees encouraged to show up dressed in their best drag.

Summary: Chile's Teatrocinema presents "Sin Sangre"
Description: In this ArtesAméricas performance, Teatrocinema, Chile's inventive and original theater company creates an ingenious fusion of cinema and theater with their premier of  "Sin Sangre" (Without Blood), adapted from a novella by Alessandro Baricco with all the darkness of film noir and tension of a 1960s B-movie thriller. In Spanish with English supertitles.

Summary: Minorities In Education holds Mentor Saturday
Description: Minorities in Education (MIE) hosts a mentoring opportunity that guides young students to brighter career paths. We will work with students from Webb Middle School to provide them extra support to push through the difficulties of being underrepresented. Your participation can impact a child's life. Contact MIE at ut.mieducation@gmail.com.
Location: Webb Middle School, 601 East St. Johns Avenue

Summary: Volunteers sought for tree planting at pediatric center
Description: The Campus Environmental Center seeks volunteers for a tree planting event at the Dell Pediatric Research Center. Free breakfast and transportation provided. Meet at the Littlefield Fountain at 8:45 a.m. if you need a ride. Sign up to volunteer at the link below.
Location: Carpool meets at Littlefield Fountain; event @ Dell Pediatric Research Ctr, 1400 Barbara Jordan Bvd.

Summary: Electronic recycling drive held
Description: Recycle any electronic materials you no longer need. For a detailed list of all recyclable materials, visit the link below. Tax exemption forms are available upon request.

Summary: Beyond Binaries Religious Studies Conference slated
Description: The Graduate Committee for the Study of Religion proudly presents its first graduate conference in religious studies, "Beyond Binaries: Toward a Continuum Model of Religious Normativity." Find a full schedule of events and speakers at the link below.
Location: SAC Legislative Assembly Room (Sat.); Sanchez Building (SZB), Al Kiva Auditorium (Sun.)

Summary: Cycling in the African American Community holds trainings
Description: CAAC is a free, one-time learning experience for African American cyclists and noncyclists that includes a safety training session and an expert-guided 45-minute bike ride. Rides begin at Mellow Johnny's Bike Shop. Participants are encouraged to bring their own bike, but free rentals are also available. Register for a session at http://tinyurl.com/CAACstudy. Learn more at the link below.
Location: Mellow Johnny's Bike Shop, 400 Nueces Street

Summary: United to Serve holds service event in Dove Springs
Description: As a follow-up to Project 2013, the Longhorn Center for Civic Engagement holds a second day of service for all students. Register at www.utproject.org.

Summary: Longhorn Salsa presents Salsa Masquerade
Description: Longhorn Salsa presents a night of intrigue, glamour and dancing at the Salsa Masquerade. Wear your most fashionable mask and keep all the others guessing as you glide about the dance floor. Unmasking takes place at midnight. Event includes free salsa mini-lessons from 8-8:30 p.m. followed by dancing to salsa, bachata, merengue and more.

Summary: UT Red Cross Club holds annual mass CPR event
Description: Become CPR, AED and first-aid certified on campus. Put the power to save a life in your hands. Visit the link below to register.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday at UT's first student-run sustainable farm. A variety of tasks are available for all ages and skill levels. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Burpees for Boobies is breast cancer awareness fund-raiser
Description:
Help raise funds for breast cancer awareness resources in a competition involving workouts, awards, food, give-aways and more. All proceeds go to Passionately Pink for a Cure. Sign up at the link below, and visit the event on Facebook at 

https://www.facebook.com/events/426498310758909/.

Summary: Tridelta holds Courtyard Cookout to benefit hospital
Description: The Tridelt House holds a cookout to raise money for St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. All proceeds go to St. Jude's.

Summary: Blanton Museum screens "Le Mystere Picasso"
Description: Screened in conjunction with the exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas," "Le Mystere Picasso,"  by French director Henri-Georges Clouzot, depicts Picasso applying paint to glass panes in this intriguing document of the creative process. Running time is 78 minutes.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Texas men's tennis takes on Abilene Christian
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on Abilene Christian. Support the Longhorns as they face the Wildcats.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in this in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Beyond Binaries Conference presents second keynote address
Description:
The Graduate Committee for the Study of Religion presents a weekend-long conference, "Beyond Binaries: Toward a Continuum Model of Religious Normativity." The second keynote address of the conference is given by Dr. Kevin Trainor, and titled "The 'Missing' Cave of the Buddha's Midday Rest: Strategies of Authenticity at a Sri Lankan Pilgrimage Site." 



Trainor is Professor of Religion at the University of Vermont.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Texas men's tennis plays Rice
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on the Rice Owls. Support your Longhorns at free tennis matches.

Summary: Joe Ely plays the Cactus
Description: Texas legend Joe Ely returns to the Cactus with an acoustic show and a special guest, former Chicago-based songwriter Joe Pug. Join the Cactus for a night of hits, laughs and good times.

Summary: Texas Student Television presents 24Seven TV Marathon
Description: Texas Student Television goes live for the entire week of March 24 with "24Seven." View on antenna channel 29.1, dorm channel 15 or online via a live stream on our website. Live content also featured on cable channel 16 between 9-10 p.m. TSTV social media: @TexasStudentTV and www.facebook.com/texasstudenttelevision. Pitch your own show or contribute: 24Seven@texasstudenttv.com.

Summary: Texas women's tennis takes on West Virginia
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor West Virginia. Support your Longhorns as they face the Mountaineers.

Summary: Texas softball plays Baylor
Description: Texas softball hosts the Baylor Bears. A $8 web coupon includes one general admission ticket, hot dog and a 16 oz. drink. Coupons must be printed. Check www.bevosbargains.com for more special offers.

Summary: Sunday Math Circle looks at linear transformations
Description: The Sunday Math Circle presents "CTRL   Z: Linear Transformations and Their Inverses," led by Laura Fredrickson of the Mathematics Department. Sunday Math Circle is open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: Spanish-language poetry workshop taught at Blanton
Description: The Blanton Museum is proud to have inspired great poems by Texas writers. This spring, find your creativity in this Spanish-language workshop taught by acclaimed literary translator Liliana Valenzuela. Participants in this free workshop will learn forms and techniques for creating new poems about artworks in the museum.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Voices for Reproductive Justice holds general meeting
Description: Voices for Reproductive Justice (VRJ) holds a general meeting. In support of the reproductive justice movement, VRJ educates and advocates for the human right to make personal reproductive decisions. All are welcome.

Summary: Dafnis Prieto and the Sí o Sí Quartet perform
Description: Cuban-born drummer Dafnis Prieto and his Sí o Sí Quartet present an evening of Afro-Cuban jazz. Prieto's world rhythms exhibit a forceful yet flexible sense of groove derived from traditions of Afro-Caribbean hand percussion and polyrhythmic post-bop.

Summary: Take a student experience survey
Description: Students are invited to take the Student Experience in the Research University (SERU) survey, which will arrive soon via email. Information from the survey is used to improve the undergraduate experience on campus. Participants are eligible for prizes. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: Tower Awards nominations close March 29
Description: The Longhorn Center for Civic Engagement encourages you to nominate someone for a Tower Award today. The Tower Awards are presented annually to honor and highlight excellence in service among the students, faculty and staff at The University of Texas at Austin. Deadline is March 29. Visit the link below for more information.

Summary: Maddox Lab seeks subjects for paid genetics & learning study
Description: The Categorization and Decision Making Laboratory seeks participants for a study examining genetics and learning. Males and females, 25-35, with no history of psychological disorders are eligible. Participants can earn a total of $80 for completing all aspects of the study. Contact UTgenetics@gmail.com and mention "Genetics and Learning Study."

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Cohen New Works Festival showcases student talent
Description: The Cohen New Works Festival presented by the University Co-op is a week-long showcase of new work created by UT students held every other spring in various locations in and around the Winship Drama Building and the university campus. Learn more at the festival website, linked below.

Summary: UGS Summer Exploration Grant info session held
Description: The School of Undergraduate Studies (UGS) Summer Exploration Grant is designed for UGS students seeking to explore careers, majors or related interests over the summer of 2013. Grants can be requested in any amount up to $2,000. To learn more, attend an information session, email uhc@austin.utexas.edu, or visit us online.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series focuses on Google Flu Trends
Description: Professor Vanja Dukic of the University of Colorado at Boulder presents a talk titled "Tracking Epidemics with Google Flu Trends Data and a State-Space SEIR Model." Dukic looks at combing Google Flu Trends data with a sequential surveillance model to track the evolution of an epidemic process over time.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Eleonary Gilburd
Description: Dr. Eleonary Gilburd presents a workshop titled "The Tower of Babel: The 1957 Moscow Youth Festival." Gilburd's current work focuses on the 1950s and 1960s as a pivotal chapter in the history of Russia's westernization. She is assistant professor of history and Russian & Slavic studies at New York University. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Regenerating democracy in Brazil is topic of talk
Description: Dr. Brian Wampler presents a talk titled "Regenerating Democracy in Brazil: Popular Participation, Interlocking Institutions, and Social Justice," focusing on the city of Belo Horizonte, where five successive mayoral administrations were committed to democratic reform. Wampler  is professor of Political Science at Boise State University.

Summary: Mariah Wade presents "Ojo: The Eye on the Archive"
Description:
"Ojo - The Eye on the Archive" is a talk by Mariah D. Wade, associate professor of anthropology at The University of Texas at Austin.



The eye takes in (on) the archive - shapes, forms and filters. Textual archives lead the eye to follow the thought of the scribe, attentive to structure, penmanship, idiosyncrasies, margin notations, the ojo. What about archaeological archives of stone, clay, metal? How does one read them? What is the context of the material/textual culture?



An archaeologist and ethnohistorian, Wade's work is concentrated on the colonial and post-colonial periods in Texas, Northern Mexico and the Greater Southwest.

Summary: CMAS presents postdoctoral fellowship candidate talk
Description: Isabel Millán, a finalist for a Center for Mexican American Studies Carlos E. Castañeda Postdoctoral Fellowship in Mexican American Studies for the 2013-2014 academic year, presents "Niñas Raras, or the Odd Girls, in Transborder Children's Literature and Media." Millán is a doctoral candidate in the Department of American Culture at the University of Michigan.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Managing your student loans is workshop topic
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Climate change & U.S. water resources are lecture topic
Description: Guest lecturer Professor Dennis Lettenmaier, University of Washington, presents a talk titled "Climate Change and the Water Resources of the Western U.S."
Location: Jackson Geological Sciences Building (JGB), Barrow Conference Room 4.102

Summary: Special seminar on Guillaume Apollinaire announced
Description: In conjunction with the French Cultures Festival sponsored by the French Consulate of Houston, the Department of French & Italian welcomes Professor Emeritus Jean-Pierre Cauvin, showing highlights of the Ransom Center's Apollinaire holdings. A reception follows in the French & Italian Department lounge. RSVP to Michael Johnson at mjohnson@utexas.edu by March 24 to guarantee your place.

Summary: Krav Maga Class open to university community
Description: The Krav Maga Self Defense and Fighting System places emphasis on skills that work on the streets, for fitness and rapid results. Gain the confidence that comes with knowing you have the skills to protect yourself and family, while shedding pounds and getting into fighting shape. Open to faculty, staff and students.

Summary: Professionalism in the workplace is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: Get inside tips on creating and maintaining your professionalism. Workshop includes a discussion of communication with staff, faculty and peers, along with important tips on interview protocol. Presented by University Unions.

Summary: Practice yoga on Main Mall
Description: Stressed out about upcoming exams, or simply wanting a fun outdoor experience? Attend Art of Living UT's first campus-wide outdoor yoga event for a relaxing evening of yoga through the sunset and stars. No experience necessary. Bring a yoga mat (extras available) and dress comfortably.
Location: Main Mall in front of Tower

Summary: Queer, feminist burlesque dancers are topic of event
Description: Interested in the burlesque dancing scene? Wonder why someone who identifies as a feminist would be interested in burlesque dancing? Meet Cherry Jane Bom, a local burlesque dancer who has been a part of the drag/burlesque scenes both in Austin and New York.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Bitcoin & the regression theorem are Mises Circle topics
Description:
Is Bitcoin money? The Mises Circle thought they settled that at the last meeting on Bitcoin, but the debate rages on among Austrian scholars. In light of the regression theorem, Bitcoin's status and potential as money remains a hot topic. Join the Mises Circle and special guests for this discussion, or join us online via Google  Hangouts.



Reading for this meeting includes Konrad S. Graf's "Bitcoin, The Regression Theorem, and That Curious but Unthreatening Empirical World" and Patrik Korda's "Bitcoin Bubble 2.0".

Summary: Learn about Intellectual Entrepreneur internship
Description: The Intellectual Entrepreneurship Pre-Graduate School Internship is an opportunity for undergraduate students to work closely with a graduate student mentor and/or faculty member. Interns discover the unique aspects of graduate study such as conducting research, serving as teaching and research assistants and participating in seminars. Information is available at the link below.

Summary: Student organizations: Submit group photos to yearbook
Description: Space in the Cactus yearbook for student organization group photos is limited and going quickly. Students who take a photo with their organization receive a $30 discount on the yearbook if ordered at the photo shoot. Email kachelmeyer.jaclyn@gmail.com to schedule a time and for more information.

Summary: Honors Colloquium seeks student mentors
Description: The University Honors Center invites current and graduating students to apply for a student mentor position for the 32nd annual Honors Colloquium, July 17-20. Student mentors are a critical component interact with participants, serve as RAs and provide support for colloquium programs and activities. Apply by 5 p.m., March 29. Learn more below.

Summary: Spanish-speaking research assistants sought
Description: Spanish-fluent research assistants are needed for a research study on Mexican children who translate between English and Spanish for their parents. Students receive course credit for their work on the project. Contact aa.parenting02@gmail.com for more information and to schedule an interview.

Summary: Apply for Outstanding Student Awards
Description: Apply now for the Cactus yearbook's prestigious Outstanding Student Award. Applications are available at HSM 3.304 or online at the link below, and are due Friday, April 5, at noon in HSM 3.304. Application requirements are transcript, description of activities and optional personal statement.

Summary: Women sought for study on sexual health
Description: The Sexual Psychophysiology Lab at The University of Texas at Austin is recruiting women for a 90-minute study on women's sexual health. Participation includes viewing short erotic film clips in the lab while physical and psychological arousal are measured. All data collected are completely confidential. Participants must be 18 or over, and either heterosexual or lesbian (not bisexual). Contact us at 512-232-4805 or utsexualitylab@gmail.com.

Summary: Become an advanced Google super searcher
Description: Become a superior Google searcher. Learn how the Google search engine works and how to focus searches and get more relevant results, as well as the mechanics behind Google searches and advanced search tricks.

Summary: Mexican professor to discuss prisons in Latin America
Description: Professor Miguel Sarre from the Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México (ITAM) presents a talk entitled "Prisons in Latin America:  Building Up the Wall of Separation Between Justice and Revenge." Sarre is a professor of law and director of the Center for Public Law at ITAM in Mexico City as well as a member of the UN Subcommittee on Prevention of Torture and Other Cruel, Inhumane or Degrading Treatment or Punishment.

Summary: Music at the Blanton presents Bach's Missa Brevis
Description: Students and faculty from the Butler School of Music perform Bach's Missa Brevis in F (BWV 223) in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: CMAS presents community service plática
Description: A Center for Mexican American Studies community service plática features the work of Professor Luis Urrieta, Jr. (Curriculum and Instruction) and a group of graduate and undergraduate students at UT Austin. The focus is the development and establishment of the Mexican American Studies (MAS) Afterschool Program at Blazier Elementary in the Austin Independent School District.

Summary: Information session held for Health IT
Description: Graduating? Want an exciting career? Learn about Health Information Technology. The nine-week certificate program at The University of Texas has a 90 percent success rate in placing program graduates in jobs, with an average starting salary of $53,000. Apply now - the summer certificate program begins May 28.

Summary: Dr. John Mearsheimer discusses China's rise
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Can China Rise Peacefully?" with John Mearsheimer, professor at the University of Chicago. Refreshments provided. There is good reason to think China's rise might be the most important development in world politics during the 21st century. Is a powerful China likely to clash with the United States?



Mearsheimer is the R. Wendell Harrison Distinguished Service Professor of Political Science and the co-director of the Program on International Security Policy at the University of Chicago, where he has taught since 1982.

Summary: Chemical engineering graduate seminar announced
Description: A seminar titled "High Density Chemical and Biological Sensor Arrays" is presented by Dr. Nosang Myung, University of California, Riverside.

Summary: "Returning Souls" documentary accompanied by live violin
Description: The documentary film "Returning Souls" by Hu Tai-Li is presented with a performance by violinist Cho-Liang Lin of music by Shih-Hui Chen. Forty years ago, a typhoon destroyed the Amis ancestral house in Tafalong, Taiwan. Attempting to revitalize their traditions, the tribal villagers reclaimed the remains of the house where their ancestors resided. A 4:30 p.m. reception precedes the screening.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program.

Summary: Worker safety is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In this workshop, participants become familiar with basic worker safety concepts, learn situational awareness strategies and learn about the important legal protections afforded to employees and what to do in the event of a work injury. Presented by Human Resource Services - HealthPoint.

Summary: Money Talks presents angel investors talk
Description:
The Herb Kelleher Center and entrepreneur-in-residence Laura Kilcrease present Money Talks with three prominent angel investors from Texas, Kansas and Nebraska.



Jeff Harbach joined the Central Texas Angel Network in 2011 and brings over 10 years of entrepreneurial experience to this position. Bart Dillashaw is the president of the Nebraska Angels and an attourney at the law firm of Koley Jessen, P.C., L.L.O., in Omaha, where he represents companies in financing, mergers, acquisitions and corporate governance matters. Joel Wiggins is a founding organizer and executive manager of the Mid-America Angel Investments, L.L.C., started in March 2006.
Location: AT&T Education and Conference Center (ATT), Room 201

Summary: Zumba Gold class offered by Grupo Flor y Canto
Description: Zumba Gold is a low-impact, Latin-music-based fitness class. To register, email grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com. Students, faculty and staff of all ages and ability levels are welcome. We cannot accept individuals who have had injuries within the last two months. *No meeting on April 16.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Texas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Texas State Bobcats. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Texas Royals spirit group holds info session
Description: Meet the newest spirit group on campus. Founded in remembrance of Coach Darrell K Royal (DKR), Texas Royals seeks to enhance the college experience of its members by involvement in social, philanthropic, leadership and spirit activities. Email texasroyalsrecruitment@gmail.com for more information, or attend an information session.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), lobby

Summary: Oxfam UT screens "Food Inc."
Description: Attend a screening of "Food Inc." followed by a short discussion as part of Oxfam's Grow Campaign. Friends welcome. Free pizza provided, with a gluten-free option offered.

Summary: Classical Reinvention and Dance Action collaborate
Description: As part of the Cohen New Works Festival presented by the University Co-op, student organizations Dance Action and Classical Reinvention join forces for "Synthesis," an original work in which collaborating choreographers, dancers and musicians step beyond the boundaries of traditional theater to bring their invention into the Ransom Center. Seating is limited.

Summary: European Debt Crisis Forum slated
Description: The European Debt Crisis Forum presented by the Texas Economics Association brings together a panel of professors to discuss the economics and politics of the ongoing European debt crisis. Panelists are Dr. James Galbraith (LBJ School), Dr. Robert Duvic (McCombs School) and Dr. Terri Givens (LBJ School). RSVP at the link below.

Summary: Science Under the Stars presents "Life Among the Ants"
Description:
Dr. Mark W. Moffett, research associate at the National Museum of Natural History and author of "Adventures Among Ants," talks about the ways that modern humans are much more like ants than we are like chimpanzees. Arrive early for refreshments and activities for kids of all ages.



Science Under the Stars is a free, monthly public outreach lecture series founded and organized by graduate students in the Section of Integrative Biology. Our goals are to host fun, informal science outreach events for Austin citizens of all ages, and give scientists a venue to share their work with the general public.  Events are held outdoors except in the case of inclement weather.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Summary: Corporate involvement in UT is panel topic
Description: Attend a panel discussion of Smarter Systems for a Greater UT, a privatization plan commissioned by President Bill Powers that proposes corporatizing all nonacademic services at UT and would raise prices significantly for all on-campus services. Visit www.reclaimut.net to learn more. Panelists are Dr. Miguel Ferguson, School of Social Work; Anne Lewis, member, TSEU; and Michelle Uche, student.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: University Surplus Property auction announced
Description: The Surplus Property unit of Facilities Services hosts an auction of university property and equipment. Public viewing and registration are open March 26, from 7:30 a.m.-4 p.m. and on sale day at 7:30 a.m. More information is available at https://www.swicoauctions.com/onsite/. For additional information , contact Surplus Property supervisor Dewayne Digby at Dewayne.Digby@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: UT PTSD Treatment Study seeks participants
Description: The Laboratory for the Study of Anxiety Disorders, based at The University of Texas, is recruiting post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) sufferers for a clinical trial investigating the efficacy of a brief enhanced exposure treatment. All patient information will be kept confidential. Call 512-404-9118 if interested.

Summary: Learn Zotero to manage citations
Description: Learn how to use Zotero, a free, web-based tool, to collect, manage and cite your sources. This is an online class. At start time, go to the web address for the class, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher.

Summary: César Chávez parade and luncheon announced
Description: Join the Latino Leadership Council and the Student Events Center Mexican American Culture Committee to commemorate and celebrate the life and work of labor and civil rights leader César E. Chávez. Event begins at 10 a.m. with a parade in front of the Chávez statue, leading to the SAC. RSVP by March 25 to c.chavezluncheon@gmail.com.
Location: Cesar Chavez statue; Student Activity Center (SAC), ballroom

Summary: Inspire Women's Leadership Program holds open house
Description: Female students who will be sophomores in the fall semester of 2013 are invited to an information session on Inspire Women's Leadership, an interdisciplinary leadership program for young women sponsored by the Center for Women's and Gender Studies. Pizza served. Download an application here: https://adobeformscentral.com/?f=NCHeen27JqW44TPmRGVlYA. Application deadline is April 14.

Summary: Spring Into Giving assists students in need
Description:
Help fellow students in need with your participation in Spring Into Giving. Every dollar given by students will be met with a matching donation from alumni toward the Student Emergency Fund, which provides emergency financial assistance to students who are unable to meet essential expenses due to a temporary hardship. Learn more below. 



We're also on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/StudentsHookedOnTexas.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Tech Talk presents workshop on IT in the arts
Description: The Cohen New Works Festival presented by The University Co-op offers a Festival Plug-In Session Panel Discussion by Tech Talk, whose goal is to advocate the innovative use of technology in arts organizations. Reserve tickets at http://nwf.ticketleap.com/tech-talk/. Follow us on Twitter: #techtalk, or Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/events/322461424542880/.

Summary: Information session held for Health IT
Description: Graduating? Want an exciting career? Learn about Health Information Technology. The nine-week certificate program at The University of Texas has a 90 percent success rate in placing program graduates in jobs, with an average starting salary of $50,000. Apply now - the summer certificate program begins May 28.

Summary: Krav Maga class open to faculty, staff and students
Description: The Krav Maga Self Defense and Fighting System places heavy emphasis on skills that work on the streets, fitness and rapid results. If you are looking for the confidence that comes with knowing you have the skills to protect yourself and family, or a way to shed pounds and get into fighting shape, Krav Maga is the fastest, most effective and most enjoyable way to do it.

Summary: Amy Weisser presents CELA conference keynote lecture
Description: Amy S. Weisser presents the keynote address at the 2013 Council of Educators in Landscape Architecture (CELA) annual conference, hosted by the School of Architecture. Director of exhibition development for the National 9/11 Memorial and Museum, Weisser works to tell stories of loss, compassion, reckoning and recovery through monumental artifacts, intimate pieces of personal property, sounds and images.

Summary: Investing for Life is Bevonomics workshop
Description: Learn how to use investments to satisfy your financial goals.

Summary: Inclusive Leadership is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description:
This training is designed to help participants develop inclusive leadership skills and equip them to work with a diverse group of people. Concepts such as social  identities and inclusion will be introduced.



Presented by the Office of the Dean of Students - Leadership and Ethics Institute.

Summary: Improve your interview skills
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence introduces the 2013 ACE workshops, featuring this week's seminar, "Improving Your Interview Skills." Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Biology-based health seminar offered
Description: This seminar connects the magnificent field of biology with information on increasing your well-being. Learn about how your body works and steps you can take to improve your overall health.

Summary: International Gastronomy Society meets
Description: Love to cook? Love to eat good food? Attend the third general meeting of the International Gastronomy Society. Contact gastronomyinternational@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Travel Club Texas meets
Description: Travel Club Texas is a student club committed to providing opportunities for students and fellow travelers to share their past experiences, create new ones with each other and foster a love for traveling and world cultures. Attend this meeting to help plan a trip to Fredericksburg and more.

Summary: Author discusses race and the green economy
Description: Join author Dr. Alison Alkon for a Skype chat about her book "Black, White, and Green: Farmers Markets, Race and the Green Economy." An open discussion of the book and local food matters follows.
Location: The Carver Art Museum and Cultural Center, 1165 Angelina Street

Summary: Longhorn Wellness Club presents biologically based seminar
Description: Longhorn Wellness Club presents a biologically based seminar including a short yoga session and tips for healthy eating. Other topics include BPA in plastics, organics, antibiotics and hormones in meats, safety of canned foods/tuna, recognizing trans fats and what manufacturers' labels really mean.

Summary: New Music Ensemble performs
Description: The music of visiting composer Andrea Clearfield is the focus of this New Music Ensemble concert, along with the world premiere of UT student composer Ben Stonaker's 2012 Phosphenes I: Isolation, for chamber orchestra. The ensemble is conducted by Dan Welcher.

Summary: Nora Jane Struthers & The Party Line play the Cactus
Description: Nora Jane Struthers calls her music "classic Americana." The singer-songwriter's self-titled solo album was a revelation to roots music fans: overflowing with affecting, literate original compositions and featuring a complement of top Nashville players, it announced the debut of a major new talent.

Summary: Lumiere Bros. film screened, with experimental revisions
