Description: Mad Stork Cinema presents a screening devoted to the genesis of the film "Workers Leaving the Factory," by the Lumiere Brothers. The screening includes the original Lumiere piece, along with several other works - experimental revisions that tackle this moment of origin and honor, reinvent and explode the first motion picture ever made. Screenings in 16mm and digital video.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Israel-Palestine is topic of Cohen New Works Festival piece
Description: The Blanton's Rapoport Atrium serves at the site for multiple performances of "Handcuffs Are Not a Metaphor," a dance and video performance by UT graduate student Roni Chelben that explores the hierarchy of oppression in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. Part of the Cohen New Works Festival presented by the University Co-Op. Performance repeats at 2 p.m.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Rapoport Atrium

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these work in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Attend a research poster-making workshop
Description: Poster-making workshops are open to any undergraduate who is in the process of creating a research poster. Emphasis is on drafting and revising. Previous attendance at a poster design class recommended. RSVP to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Research poster design class offered
Description: Poster design classes are open to all undergraduates who are interested in creating a poster about their research. Learn about research poster content, design guidelines and timelines, and presentation tips. RSVP by email to uresearch@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Preserving Central Asian nomadic culture is talk topic
Description: "Recovering and Preserving the Richness of Central Asian Nomadic Culture: The Challenges for Public Memory" is a talk by Dr. Saule Sataye. Her presentation focuses on the preservation of Kazakhstan's nomadic heritage and why it is important.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Xin Wu
Description: "The Xiao-xiang Landscape and Chinese Literati's Subtle Art of Obliquity" is a talk by Xin Wu, assistant professor in the Department of Art and Art History, College of William and Mary.

Summary: Economics internal transfer session held
Description: The Department of Economics holds an internal transfer information session for prospective economics majors who wish to declare an economics major before registration starts. RSVP via the link below by 5 p.m. on Wednesday, March 27. Students who are unable to attend a session must wait until after registration declare. An additional session is offered on April 3.

Summary: Energy innovation investing is UT Energy Symposium topic
Description: Bob Metcalfe presents "Investing in Energy Innovation" at this week's meeting of the UT Energy Symposium. Metcalfe is professor of innovation and Murchison Fellow of Free Enterprise in the Cockrell School of Engineering at UT Austin. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Housing and community development panel convened
Description: Join UT Habitat for Humanity at a panel on community development in the Austin area. Interact with professionals from Austin Habitat for Humanity, the Austin Community Design and Development Center, the Food is Free Project and the UT Center for Sustainable Development, and learn about housing and the creation of community in Austin. Complimentary snacks provided.

Summary: Panel discusses careers in international relations
Description: Panelists with a wide variety of experiences in international relations discuss their careers, which include nonprofit work, higher education, international trade and global think tanks. UT's diplomat-in-residence and Peace Corps representative will also attend.

Summary: Panel discussion explores "Legacy of the Dirty Thirty"
Description:
A panel discussion explores a pivotal period in Texas politics in which a group of lawmakers, known as the Dirty Thirty, challenged the influence of special interests in the Legislature and the power of the House leadership.



In 1971, the Dirty Thirty called for an investigation of then Speaker of the House Gus Mutscher and other state officials named in a federal bribery-conspiracy case. This small band of reformers turned the federal case into a political issue, sparked a movement for more transparency in the activities of the Legislature and inspired Frances "Sissy" Farenthold's run for governor in 1972. More than 40 years later, the experiences of the Dirty Thirty still offer a lesson in the challenges of creating and sustaining political reform.

Summary: Elohim Fellowship discusses the Tree of Life
Description: The University Elohim Fellowship gathers to discuss the reality of the Tree of Life and how can we eat from it, looking for answers in the Bible. Email UEFellowship2012@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Life and work of Arnold Newman is topic of talk
Description:
Marianne Fulton, writer, teacher and former chief curator of the George Eastman House, discusses the work of photographer Arnold Newman in conjunction with the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass," which runs through May 12. Newman (1918-2006) created iconic portraits of some of the most influential innovators, celebrities and cultural figures of the twentieth century.



Fulton wrote the introduction for "Arnold Newman: At Work" (2013), published by the University of Texas Press and Ransom Center. She has worked in the field of photography as a curator, editor, archivist and writer for over 30 years.

Summary: Evan Smith speaks on the future of journalism
Description:
Evan Smith gives a lecture titled "The Evolution Will Be Digitized: The Future of the New News." Smith is editor-in-chief and CEO of The Texas Tribune, a nonprofit, nonpartisan digital news organization based in Austin. 



The Tribune's deep coverage of Texas politics and public policy can be found at its website, texastribune.org; in the pages of the New York Times; and in newspapers and on TV and radio stations across the state. Before co-founding the Tribune, Smith was editor-in-chief of Texas Monthly.

Summary: Native Hebrew speakers sought for linguistics study
Description: Researchers seek native Hebrew speakers to study accent perception. Contact Lauren Franklin (UTHebrewStudy@gmail.com) if interested in participating.

Summary: 2013 Africa Conference announced
Description: The theme of the 2013 Africa Conference is Social Movement, Political Expression and Religion. The goal of the conference is to generate an interdisciplinary dialogue about the historical and contemporary roles of Africa in fostering social, cultural and political change within the borders of its individual countries, throughout the continent and around the world. Learn more below.

Summary: Participants sought for language processing study
Description: The Department of Linguistics seeks native speakers of English ages 18 and over to participate in a study of language processing. A session lasts approximately one hour. Contact utlingpsych@gmail.com for more details.

Summary: Lecture examines legislation and abortion in Texas
Description: Daniel Grossman, M.D., Ibis Reproductive Health and University of California at San Francisco, presents a talk titled "The Impact of Recent Restrictions on Abortion Care in Texas."

Summary: Cancer prevention with dietary isothiocynates is talk topic
Description:
Shivendra Singh, Ph.D., presents a talk titled "Cancer Prevention with Dietary Isothiocyanates" as part of the ongoing speaker series in the Department of Nutritional Sciences.



Singh is a professor in the Department of Pharmacology and Chemical Biology at the University of Pittsburgh, Hillman Cancer Center. Singh's research focuses on preclinical and clinical development of novel agents, derived from dietary sources and traditional oriental and Indian medicinal plants, for the prevention of prostate and breast cancer in humans.

Summary: 2012-13 McCraw Lecture Series presents Juan Dominguez
Description: Juan Dominguez, Ph.D., assistant professor in the Department of Psychology at The University of Texas at Austin, presents "Brain and Hormone Influence on Natural and Artificial Reward."

Summary: Israel-Palestine is topic of Cohen New Works Festival piece
Description: The Blanton's Rapoport Atrium serves at the site for multiple performances of "Handcuffs Are Not a Metaphor," a dance and video performance by UT graduate student Roni Chelben that explores the hierarchy of oppression in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict. Part of the Cohen New Works Festival presented by the University Co-Op. Performance repeats at 2 p.m.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Rapoport Atrium

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: Food drive and pool party combine fun with a good cause
Description: Escape the heat and help Rotaract in collaboration with the Iranian Students Academic and Cultural Organization raise funds and collect donations to combat childhood hunger in Austin. Snacks, drinks and live music provided. Water, Coke and Sprite will be sold for $1. All proceeds, including donated cans of food, go to the Capital Area Food Bank.

Summary: FIGSO presents lecture by Professor Marcia Landy
Description:
Professor Marcia Landy discusses the uses of autobiography and biography as fabulation in contemporary Italian cinema in her talk, "The Biopic, Spectacle, and Counter History," which reconsiders the employment of invention and documentation in the formal and conceptual treatment of history. 



Landy is distinguished professor in English and film studies with a secondary appointment in the French and Italian Department at the University of Pittsburgh.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Texas Relays celebration and community jam session held
Description: The Central Texas Black Cultural and Health Festival presents the 2013 Texas Relays Parade and Community Jam Session. The parade begins at 6 p.m. at Huston-Tillotson University and ends at the George Washington Carver Museum, 1165 Angelina Street. A brief program and community jam session immediately follow, with musical performances by high school and middle school bands. Refreshments provided.
Location: Huston-Tillotson University and George Washington Carver Museum

Summary: Dance Across the Globe is human trafficking awareness event
Description: Join ACT (Against Cruel Trafficking) in celebrating the survivors of human trafficking at a dance benefit. All proceeds donated to agencies fighting modern-day slavery. Performers include Texas Ballroom, Nach Baliye, Longhorn Salsa and the Texas Chinese Dance Company. RSVP here. Pre-order tickets through events.actut@gmail.com.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: Workshop on portfolios for language & culture held
Description: This one-day workshop discusses the use of student-generated portfolios in both traditional and hybrid language and culture classes. Prompts provided include portfolios, sample student work and rubrics for assessing the final portfolios. Visit web link to register.

Summary: TeSPA DotA Showdown announced
Description: The Texas e-Sports Association (TeSPA) holds its first DotA 2 tournament, featuring a prize pool of at least $200 dollars, with one lucky person having the chance to win Lina's Fiery Soul of the Slayer. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday at UT's first student-run sustainable farm. A variety of tasks are available for all ages and skill levels. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these work in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Texas women's tennis takes on SMU
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on SMU.Support your Longhorns as they face the Mustangs at this free match.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these work in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: "News to History" exhibits photojournalism across 13 presidencies
Description:
The Dolph Briscoe Center for American History is proud to announce the exhibit "News to History: Photojournalism and the Presidency." The exhibit, which runs through Oct. 1, showcases iconic photographs from 13 presidential administrations over a period of 80 years - from Franklin D. Roosevelt to Barack Obama. 



The Briscoe Center is an organized research unit of The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Applications available for Peers for Pride
Description: Peers for Pride is a peer facilitation program offered throughout the school year for academic credit. Students write a monologue during the first semester and perform monologues and facilitate conversations on LGBTQA identities and issues during the second. Contact Shane Whalley, GSC coordinator at swhalley@austin.utexas.edu. Read the Peers for Pride blog here.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: "No one's asking for it" posters are on display
Description: "No one's asking for it," a campus-wide poster launch on the theme of violence against women is on display throughout April.

Summary: RSVP for Texas Shabbat 500
Description: Shabbat 500, coming April 12, is a Shabbat dinner planned by students, for students, with the aim of strengthening Jewish unity on campus while providing as many Jewish Longhorns as possible a meaningful Shabbat dinner experience. There are over 4,000 Jewish students at UT; we've set an attendance goal of 500. RSVP at the link below to join us.

Summary: Healthy vending machine survey seeks participants
Description: Do you purchase food or drinks from vending machines on campus? Would you like healthier options in the vending machines on campus? The Wellness Network Healthy Dining Workgroup wants your input. Complete a short survey at the link below.

Summary: Alpha Phi Omega holds blood drive
Description:
Alpha Phi Omega holds a blood drive at two locations on campus. The Central Texas Blood and Tissue Center mobile unit comes to Speedway Plaza 

Monday and Friday 10 a.m.-5 p.m., Tuesday-Thursday 10 a.m.-7 p.m. MD Anderson collects blood at McCombs Hall of Honors Monday, 10 a.m.-6 p.m., Tuesday-Thursday, 9a.m.-5 p.m.
Location: Speedway Plaza and McCombs Hall Of Honors (CBA)

Summary: Public Health Week Organization Fair held
Description: Health-focused student organizations, nonprofits, NGOs and businesses provide information on their organizations at this tabling event. Free t-shirts are available to be tie-dyed, decorated and customized during your visits to the various tables.

Summary: International Gastronomy Society holds crepe fund-raiser
Description: Enjoy a sweet and delicious crepe with fillings such as whipped cream, Nutella, fresh strawberries and bananas, all topped with powered sugar. Proceeds benefit International Gastronomy Society activities.

Summary: UT Engineering's Patron Saint Alec turns 105
Description: UT Engineering's Patron Saint Alexander Frederick Claire, better known as Alec, turns 105 years old. Celebrate at Alec's Birthday Party with free cake, meet Alec, win prizes and hear the Alec Building contest winners announced at 11:50 a.m. Friends of Alec is the Annual Giving Fund for the Cockrell School of Engineering; students are encouraged to become involved.

Summary: Inst. for Historical Studies hosts Sir Christopher Bayly
Description: "The Revolutionary Age in the Wider World, c. 1780-1850" is a talk by Dr. Sir Christopher Bayly, Vere Harmsworth professor of Imperial and Naval History and president, St. Catherine's College, Cambridge. He is also a trustee of the British Museum, and the recipient of the Wolfson History Prize for 2004. RSVP to cmeador@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Affect and infrastructure of the commons is lecture topic
Description:
The Department of Anthropology and the Humanities Institute present a talk by Lauren Berlant titled "The Commons: Affect and Infrastructure." Berlant is George M. Pullman professor of English, University of Chicago.



There's a romantic story about the common, a pastoral story of nature and human creativity; and an antipastoral one of rage, exploitation, theft, loss, mourning and radical resistance. At the same time there is ambivalence toward  being in common, as properties of relationality and relations of property and intimacy encounter each other frictionally. This segment of a longer work focuses on Waldo Emerson, Juliana Spahr and Liza Johnson's attempts to risk making and inhabiting the unbearable commons, addressing the sacrifices a nonuniversalist common might entail, including the priority of the human (the persistence of the inhuman, the aspiration to the impersonal, the recognition of activity in all things), on the other side of which is an optimism about aesthetics and, in particular, an ethics and politics of analogy.

Summary: Researcher says yes, it is possible to be smart and happy
Description: Bites of Wellness, a lunch-and-learn series, presents "If You're So Smart, Why Aren't You Happy?" with Dr. Raj Raghunathan, McCombs marketing professor, who discusses the three most important determinants of a happy and fulfilling life. Sign up on TXClass PN 288. For questions, email healthpoint.wellness@austin.utexas.edu.
Location: Pickle Research Center (PRC), Commons Cafe, Building 137

Summary: Postponed: Lyndon Gill discusses Audre Lorde
Description:
This event is postponed until April 22.



Lyndon Gill presents a Faculty Development Colloquium titled "Never Meant to Survive: Anti-Social Deaths & Our Lorde's Prayer." Through theoretical engagement the poetry and prose of black lesbian feminist poet and theorist Audre Lorde, this workshop is at once an invocation of the past and a vision for our collective future.

Summary: Richard Cobden's triumph of ideas is Mises Circle topic
Description:
Richard Cobden was a 19th-century British textile manufacturer and politician famous for his opposition to the British Corn Laws. Join the Mises Circle to discuss Tom Woods's prize-winning essay, "Cobden on Freedom, Peace, and Trade." Can't attend? Join us online via Google  Hangouts.



Find the essay here:  - read more about this event.... Find Cobden's essay "On the Repeal of the Corn Laws" here : http://mises.org/daily/536.

Summary: UT Symphony Orchestra performs "Rite of Spring," Wagner
Description: The UT Symphony Orchestra and Maestro Gerhardt Zimmermann present a centennial performance of Igor Stravinsky's indomitable masterpiece ballet, "The Rite of Spring." The concert then takes a turn for the dramatic, featuring music from Richard Wagner's monumental Ring Cycle with the Prelude to "Siegfried" and excerpts from "Gotterdammerung."

Summary: Art of Living UT offers free yoga classes
Description: Attend a free yoga session taught by a certified yoga instructor and hosted by the Art of Living UT. Bring a yoga mat. Subscribe to the Art of Living UT listserv for meeting reminders and change notifications, and view the website below for an updated meeting schedule, including times and locations of each session.

Summary: Landmarks Video presents Julia Kul's "Passport Reading"
Description: Landmarks Video presents "Passport Reading" by Polish-born artist Julia Kul.  The video underscores the instability and fallability of gender roles and nationalist values with the artist performing a set of commands that correspond to the letters and numbers found in her passport. On view throughout April.
Location: Art Building (ART), atrium, adjacent to Visual Arts Center galleries 23rd St. and San Jacinto

Summary: Social Media Journalism announces #keepaustinweird project
Description:
Help out your fellow Longhorns with a simple social media experiment. If you think Austin, Texas, is the greatest, weirdest city in the world, use your Twitter, Facebook and Instagram accounts to tell us why, using the hashtag #keepaustinweird. 

This research project is conducted by the Social Media Journalism spring 2013 class.

Summary: UT Austin Pride Week 2013 is coming April 15-19
Description: Queer Students Alliance will host the 2013 Pride Week celebration from April 15-19, promoting visibility and welcoming of the LGBTQ community on campus. Events include a kickoff celebration, free HIV testing, discussions and panels about being Queer in the professional world and socials including movie and game nights.

Summary: Register for the "Getting On Track" health symposium
Description: The 6th annual "Getting on Track" Health Symposium, held April 6, 9:30 a.m.-3 p.m., features networking opportunities with admissions officials and students who are currently pursuing health professions. Enter your name to win a full scholarship for any full prep course with Kaplan or The Princeton Review. You must be registered to enter the drawing. Contact ruth.ackah@gmail.com, or call 409-548-6002.

Summary: "A Conspectus of Wood Type" presented by David Shields
Description:
"Love Among the Ruins: A Conspectus of Wood Type" is a talk presented by David Shields. Throughout the 19th century, the proliferation of wood type played an integral role in the creation of American visual culture. Through a physical engagement of production processes, Shields charts the impact the tools and processes had on driving the derivation of styles throughout the 19th and early 20th centuries.



Shields is associate professor and the chair of the Department of Graphic Design at Virginia Commonwealth University in Richmond.

Summary: Nonprofit & Government Career Fair announced
Description:
The Nonprofit & Government Career Fair is open to all students and alumni of The University of Texas at Austin, as well as all residents of Central Texas interested in a nonprofit or public service career.



The UT Coalition for Careers in Public Service (CCPS) is a cooperative effort of the career services offices of the schools and colleges of UT Austin. The coalition's mission is to develop meaningful opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students to gain knowledge and skills in the not-for-profit, philanthropic and public sectors through the development and sponsorship of university-wide nonprofit career fairs.

Summary: Theatre for Dialogue presents "Get Sexy, Get Consent"
Description: "Get Sexy, Get Consent" is a highly interactive one-hour performance that examines how we negotiate sex, consent, boundaries and safety. Free lunch included.

Summary: CMAS plática explores state-sanctioned violence in Texas
Description: Monica Muñoz Martínez, CMAS Carlos E. Castañeda postdoctoral fellow in Mexican American studies for the 2012-2014 academic years, presents "Visual Legacies of State Sanctioned Violence in Texas, 1910-Present." The presentation addresses racial and gender violence in the twentieth century, particularly its impact on ethnic Mexican communities in South Texas.

Summary: International Food Challenge info session held
Description: The Food Lab announces the Barilla Center for Food and Nutrition's BCFN Yes! annual food startup competition. Students at The University of Texas at Austin and other Texas colleges and universities can begin competing now for the chance in November to participate in the finals in Italy. Learn more at this session.

Summary: Research + Pizza presents Professor Don Winget
Description: Research   Pizza presents Professor Don Winget, Department of Astronomy, giving a talk titled "Experimental Astronomy and Asteroseismology Research."

Summary: Revolution in military affairs discussed by Jaymie Durnan
Description: The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "The Revolution in Military Affairs: How Organizations, Operational Concepts and Technology Are Transforming the Way Militaries and Businesses Conduct Warfare," with Jaymie Durnan, senior adviser to the acting assistant secretary of defense for research & engineering. Refreshments provided.

Summary: Kazakh oral art is talk topic
Description: Dr. Gulnara Yeleukulova, associate professor at Kazakh-British Technical University, Almaty, presents "Kazakh Oral Art: The Treasure of a Nomadic People." Having survived devastating wars, colonization and collectivization, along with difficult natural conditions, the Kazakhs developed a rich tradition of oral art, and in return, the art itself became the spiritual foundation for survival.

Summary: Avoiding Plagiarism class offered online
Description:
Confused about what is and isn't plagiarism? This session covers mistakes that can lead to plagiarism, strategies for avoiding these mistakes and practical techniques for using sources correctly. At class start time, click the link below. Select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." Learn more at 

http://www.lib.utexas.edu/services/instruction/classes/index.html.

Summary: Ransom Center conservator gives talk on pastels
Description: The Harry Ransom Center presents a talk by conservator Thea Burns, "Pastel: Materials, Techniques, and Genres." Burns reviews selected works by professional and amateur artists of the 18th to 20th centuries who have used pastel for portraiture, natural science records, impressionist subjects, social commentary and landscape imagery.

Summary: Atmospheric nanoparticles are topic of ChE seminar
Description: "Atmospheric Nanoparticles, Air Quality and Climate Change" is a seminar given by Dr. Spyros Pandis, Carnegie Mellon University. Pandis explores a dramatic change to Earth's atmosphere brought on by human activity: the increase in the mass concentrations of sub-micrometer particles by one to sometimes two orders of magnitude over populated areas in the Northern Hemisphere.

Summary: Personality in workplace is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: In a workshop offered to student employees of UT Austin, unravel the mysteries behind your coworkers' - and classmates' - quirky behavior by exploring personality types, Carl Jung and the theories behind the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator. Become aware of your own personality type and the types of others, and explore how personality is expressed in the workplace.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Larissa Dryansky
Description: "A Thing Is a Hole in a Thing It Is Not: On Nothingness in American Art of the 1960s" is a talk by Larissa Dryansky, University of Paris - Sorbonne. In 1968, Carl Andre famously stated, "a thing is a hole in a thing it is not." Dryansky addresses the combined interest in "things" and emptiness in American art of the 1960s.

Summary: Texas softball plays McNeese State
Description: Texas softball hosts the McNeese State Cowboys in game one of a double header. Visit Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for ticket promotions and other offers.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program.

Summary: 10,000 Roses event seeks volunteers
Description: Volunteer with the White Rose Society for its annual 10,000 Roses event by dethorning roses. Special gloves provided, as well as volunteer hours for those who need them. The 10,000 Roses event remembers the 10,000 people who were killed every day at Auschwitz during the Holocaust.
Location: University Catholic Center, 21st St. and University Avenue

Summary: Dr. Lawrence Krauss presents "A Universe from Nothing"
Description: Renowned theoretical physicist and science popularizer Dr. Lawrence Krauss discusses his latest book, "A Universe from Nothing: Why There is Something Rather than Nothing," explaining how the staggeringly beautiful observations and predictions of modern physics suggest that not only CAN something arise from nothing, something WILL always arise from nothing. A Q&A and book signing follow the talk.

Summary: Texas Photography Club offers photo editing workshop
Description: The Texas Photography Club hosts a three-part series of open photo editing workshops covering a variety of digital editing techniques using Adobe Lightroom and Photoshop. Partcovers basic photo editing techniques.

Summary: Public health career & internship fair announced
Description: Attend a career tabling event with public health schools, NGOs, nonprofits and government organizations. Learn about internship opportunities and enjoy free food and raffle tickets (prizes given out during carnival). Attendees are encouraged to bring resumes.

Summary: Practica Plática screens "Ladrón que roba a ladrón"
Description: Practica Plática presents a screening of "Ladrón que roba a ladrón," a Spanish-language action/comedy with English subtitles.

Summary: Texas softball plays second game against McNeese State
Description: Texas softball hosts the McNeese State Cowboys in game two of a double header. Visit Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for ticket promotions and other offers.

Summary: Hook the Cure holds meeting
Description: Members of Hook the Cure come together under one common goal: to raise diabetes awareness. Refreshments served. All majors welcome.

Summary: Texas eSports Association (TeSPA) holds meeting
Description: The Texas eSports Association meets to discuss TeSPA's Dota 2 Tournament results, with an in-depth review of Hi-Rez Studio's SMITE and other exciting announcements.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Texas A&M-Corpus Christi
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Texas A&M-Corpus Christi Islanders. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Alderson Lecture and Hall of Honor ceremony announced
Description: Join the Department of Kinesiology and Health Education in welcoming Colonel Barbara Springer, speaking about Project HERO, a program focused on healing wounded, ill and injured service members and veterans. This event also celebrates our 2013 Hall of Honor inductee, Waneen Spirduso.

Summary: CLUTCH presents new music in final spring concert
Description: Collective Labors of the UT Composition Hub, CLUTCH, promotes new music by composers at The University of Texas at Austin. Hear premieres by Joelle Zigman, Jenna Wright, Joshua Shank, Ben Stonaker and Joel Love. Experience a concert of juxtaposing, interlocking, twisting parts written by living, breathing young composers.

Summary: Veteran disability claims assistance session offered
Description: Join the Student Veteran Services staff for free doughnuts and coffee while getting counseling about the VA's disability claims process. A counselor from the Texas Veteran Commission will be onsite to help you with this very important process. Start a new claim or get more information on continuing a pending claim.

Summary: 10,000 Roses commemorates lives lost in Holocaust
Description: The UT White Rose Society distributes 10,000 roses to students, professors, guests and random passers-by around campus as a remembrance of the 10,000 people who were killed every day at Auschwitz during the Holocaust. Campus community can pick up roses at Jester, the Belo Center, West Mall, Gregory Plaza and the Tower.

Summary: Apply to DemTex Leadership Team
Description: DemTex: Student-led Courses seeks applicants for the DemTex Leadership Team. Open positions are Financial Director, Recruiting Director, Communications Director and Webmaster. For more details, contact Joey Dominguez or Kevin Boening at utdemtex@gmail.com. Find the application at the link below.

Summary: Global Innovation Forum discusses U.S. immigration policy
Description: The Global Innovation Forum of the National Foreign Trade Council hosts a luncheon-discussion on policy issues surrounding the ability of the United States to attract and retain top global talent, particularly students, entrepreneurs, researchers and high-skilled workers. Students, faculty, entrepreneurs and business leaders to are encouraged to attend. RSVP below.
Location: AT&T Executive Education Center (ATT), Tejas Room

Summary: Shine a Light on Mental Health photo contest announced
Description: Visit the Texas System of Care Facebook page (http://bit.ly/14oHUvn)and submit a photo of yourself or your organization with a sign that says, "Shine a Light on Children's Mental Health," along with your name or the name or your organization. Contest voting ends April 30.

Summary: LeaderShape-Texas applications being accepted
Description: Apply now for LeaderShape-Texas (LS-T), open to all registered University of Texas at Austin undergraduate students. Session takes place May 18-23 at the Retreat at Balcones Springs in Marble Falls, TX. Transportation provided. LS-T is a six-day program of intensive, interactive and fun activities centered on becoming a leader with integrity. Application due at 11:59 p.m., Friday, April 5.

Summary: Spring 2013 Communication Job & Internship Fair announced
Description: Communication Career Services' spring 2013 Communication Job & Internship Fair features over 70 companies, with organizations from media, entertainment, retail, sales, management, advertising, public relations and Fortune 500 companies.
Location: DKR Stadium North End Zone, The Club (8th floor)

Summary: Center for Transportation Research holds annual symposium
Description: The Center for Transportation Research (CTR) of The University of Texas at Austin hosts its annual symposium, "Energy is the Key," with keynote addresses by Dr. Larry Lake of the Petroleum & Geosystems Engineering Department, and Dr. Ross Baldick of the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department. Additional speakers and a poster session round out the event.
Location: J.J. Pickle Research Campus (PRC), Commons Center, 10100 Burnet Road

Summary: Poetry on the Plaza presents Poetry of Sport
Description: The Harry Ransom Center presents the Poetry on the Plaza event "Poetry of Sport."

Summary: Black Panther women are topic of predoctoral fellow talk
Description: Black studies predoctoral fellow Ashley Farmer presents "Raising the Consciousness of the People: Panther Women's Construction of the 'Black Revolutionary,' in the Black Panther Party, 1966-1972."

Summary: Pelevin's Generation P and Pussy Riot explored in talk
Description: Keith Livers, professor in the Department of Slavic and Eurasian Studies, presents a talk titled "From Pelevin's Generation P to Pussy Riot: (Russian) Conspiracy Talk in the New Millennium."

Summary: Doctoral student presents CMAS graduate portfolio plática
Description:
Doctoral student Charles Lu presents a plática titled "STEM(ming) Up from Niños to Científicos," which focuses on the first-semester experience for Latino men in the STEM disciplines at a predominantly white institution using a science identity framework.



Lu is a doctoral candidate in the Department of Educational Administration with a Graduate Portfolio in Mexican American Studies. The chair of his dissertation committee is Victor B. Saenz, Assistant Professor in the Department of Educational Administration.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in the commercial real estate industry. Free pizza served. Register to attend at link below.

Summary: Ray Marshall discusses skill-based U.S. immigration policy
Description: Ray Marshall, former U.S. Secretary of Labor (1977-1981), speaks on the promise and prospects of a skill-based immigration policy for the United States. Marshall is the Audre and Bernard Rapoport Centennial Chair (emeritus) in Economics and Public Affairs, and founder of the Ray Marshall Center for the Study of Human Resources.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), LBJ School of Public Affairs, 3.124

Summary: Homeless & runaway youth interventions are talk topic
Description: Sanna J. Thompson, Ph.D., discusses her research on health behavior and outcomes for homeless and runaway youth.

Summary: G.F. Handel's audience is music seminar topic
Description: Music librarian Dr. David Hunter presents a seminar titled "In the Court of Public Opinion: Handel, Choice, and the Finite Audience," based on current research that explores who was in the audience for Handel performances and why they chose to be there. This is part of a weekly seminar arranged by the Association of Graduate Ethnomusicology and Musicology Students.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 4.104

Summary: Output workshop for Undergraduate Research Forum held
Description:
In preparation for the Undergraduate Research Forum, SURGe members and Office for Honors, Research and International Study (OHRIS) staff help students finalize posters, refine oral presentations and print their posters. Register to attend at the link below.



 - read more about this event...

Summary: Promotion and Tenure Panel held; all faculty welcome
Description: A Promotion and Tenure Panel provides candid and important information for faculty concerning promotion (including lecturers) and tenure.

Summary: Tarlton Talks welcomes Professor Thomas McGarity
Description: Professor Thomas McGarity discusses his research methods and his new book, "Freedom to Harm: The Lasting Legacy of the Laissez Faire Revival." The Tarlton Talks series offers an opportunity for students to meet faculty outside of the classroom and to learn about their research and scholarship.

Summary: Economics internal transfer session held
Description: The Department of Economics hosts an internal transfer information session for prospective majors who want to declare an economics major before registration starts. RSVP via the link below by 5 p.m. Tuesday, April 2. Students who are unable to attend a session must wait until after registration to declare.

Summary: Budget and build credit as a college student
Description: Acclimate your saving and spending style to the college lifestyle. Learn how to create and use a daily budget, save money, maintain and grow a savings account and build credit.

Summary: Lions Club holds food sale fund-raiser
Description: The Lions Club sells fried rice and drinks. Proceeds fund campaigns to raise awareness of and combat human trafficking.

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter. Learn what the Peace Corps can do for you and what you can do for humanity.

Summary: Speaker discusses realities of the music industry
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence's 2013 ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series welcomes Gary Powell, presenting "The Realities of the Music Industry." Powell's credits include scoring work, original songs and production as represented on numerous Disney storybook and song albums. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Get global at Public Health Week event
Description: Cultural and global health organizations present health highlights, information and issues in their respective countries via tabling or staged presentation. Free food served.

Summary: YesPlus course info session held
Description: Attend a free information session that includes stress-busting breathing and meditation, and learn more about the upcoming YesPlus course. Through breathing and meditation, as well as interactive activities, this course gives students the tools to relieve stress and have a better outlook on life.

Summary: Stress management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: A workshop on stress management for students employed by UT Austin introduces stress coping skills. Using cognitive techniques and guided relaxation, this interactive workshop helps participants learn to recognize the effects of stress affects and new ways to relax. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: VAV presents Take Back the Night
Description: Take Back the Night is a gender-inclusive event that illuminates the movement to end sexual violence, including a survivor speak-out open mic, free food and t-shirts.

Summary: Open mic returns to the Cactus Cafe
Description: Join the Cactus Cafe once a month to take your turn performing on its legendary stage. Sign-up is at 7 p.m.

Summary: Biz Stone speaks at Endowed Centennial Lectureship event
Description:
The Student Endowed Centennial Lectureship and the Distinguished Speakers Committee are proud to present Biz Stone, co-founder and creative director of Twitter. Stone presents a talk titled "Redefining Success" as part of the lectureship series. Doors open at 6:30 p.m. for students and at 6:45 for faculty and staff. Please have your UT IDs in hand.



Stone has been named Nerd of the Year by GQ, one of the Most Influential People in The World by TIME magazine, Entrepreneur of the Decade by Inc. Magazine, one of Vanity Fair's Top Ten Most Influential People of the Information Age, and was honored with the International Center for Journalists' first Innovation Award.

Summary: RTF presents "The Searchers," Q&A with author Glenn Frankel
Description: Charles Ramírez Berg talks to Glenn Frankel, author of "The Searchers: The Making of an American Legend," about the myths and truths behind one of Hollywood's most legendary films, John Ford's "The Searchers" (1956), starring John Wayne. A screening of the film follows.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium

Summary: Save Our Community Coalition hosts forum on UT outsourcing
Description: On January 29, President Bill Powers presented "Smarter Systems for a Greater UT," a plan to increase efficiency at UT, including outsourcing of facility, housekeeping and food service workers on campus. Join the UT Save Our Community Coalition at a forum discussing the implications of outsourcing for campus workers.

Summary: UT Libraries hold spring plant sale
Description: Purchase plants grown by UT Libraries staff. All sale proceeds will be donated to Meals on Wheels and More. Cash only.

Summary: Violence at the Urban Margins workshop announced
Description: This workshop features the research of scholars from sociology and anthropology whose ethnographic work offers significant insights into the complex ways in which interpersonal violence is shaping the lives of those living at the urban margins in contemporary North, Central and South America.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 2nd floor conference room

Summary: American Studies Graduate Conference slated
Description: The 2013 American Studies Graduate Conference centers on the theme "Reimagining the American Dream." The campus community is invited to attend as conference participants and presenters explore and complicate the narrative of the American Dream across time, space and disciplines.

Summary: Advise TX Corps applications now available
Description: Advise TX seeks recent UT graduates (Dec. 2012, May 2013) to serve as college advisers in low-income high schools in Austin, San Antonio, Corpus Christi, El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley. Advisers assist with college applications and admissions, financial aid and scholarship applications. Apply online at the UT Jobs website linked below. Learn more at http://advisetx.org. Deadline is April 19.

Summary: Design Futures in PID student summit registration open
Description: The UT Center for Sustainable Development announces the launch of the Design Futures Public Interest Design (PID) Student Leadership Forum, taking place at the School of Architecture from May 28-June 1. Registration is now open for the event and seats are limited. Contact the CSD at csd@austin.utexas.edu for scholarship application, due Friday, April 19.
Location: School of Architecture, West Mall Office Building (WMB), 4.122

Summary: Volunteers over age 50 sought for website research
Description: Volunteers over age 50 with basic computer skills are sought for research on usability testing of health-related websites. Contact Cara Schlegel, cara.schlegel@utexas.edu, with questions.
Location: UT Administration Building (UTA), IX Lab 5.510 and 5.516

Summary: Mobile web version usability study seeks participants
Description: Participants are sought for mobile web version usability study. Study duration is approximately 18 minutes. Participants must use their own smart phone with an unlimited data plan, have no prior experience with DriveTexas.org and be fluent in English. Experience with GPS navigation mandatory. Appointment required. Call 512-486-5800 or 925-681-8901.
Location: School of Information IX Lab, 1616 Guadalupe

Summary: RecSports Youth Camps registration announced
Description:
RecSports has opened registration for its 2013 summer youth camps program. These week-long camps are open to the community and consist of soccer, lacrosse and ultimate disc. Camps are held in June at Whitaker Fields, 51st and Guadalupe streets. Players of all abilities and all skill levels are welcome. Call 512-471-3116 with questions, Monday-Friday, 8 a.m.-5 p.m. Find complete details and register online at the link below.



Soccer camp for boys and girls, ages 5-10, runs June 10-14 and June 24-28. Lacrosse camp for ages 8-17 runs June 10-14 and June 17-21 (boys), and June 24-28 (girls). Ultimate disc camp for boys and girls ages 8-17 runs June 17-21.

Summary: CMCT hosts speaker from U. of Florida College of Medicine
Description: Michael Kladde, Ph.D., presents a seminar titled "Epigenetic Heterogeneity: Identifying Drug-Resistant Subpopulations of Tumor Cells by Single-Molecule Footprinting." Kladde is associate professor of biochemistry and molecular biology at the University of Florida Shands Cancer Center, University of Florida College of Medicine.

Summary: "Through the Eyes of Texas" is gallery talk topic
Description: Blanton curator of modern and contemporary art Veronica Roberts leads a gallery talk on the Blanton exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections."

Summary: Katrin Sieg presents "Ethnic Drag Reloaded"
Description: Dr. Katrin Sieg presents a talk titled "Ethnic Drag Reloaded" as part of the 2012-2013 University of Texas German Studies Lecture Series: Immigration/Migration/Multiculturalism/Multilingualism.

Summary: "Latinos Beyond Reel": Film challenges media stereotypes
Description: The Latino Media Studies program screens "Latinos Beyond Reel: Challenging a Media Stereotype." The film will be introduced by Dr. Joseph D. Straubhaar, the Amon G. Carter centennial professor in communication, and followed by a Q&A with UT Radio-Television-Film professors Charles Ramírez Berg and Mary C. Beltran, who served as consultants on the film.

Summary: Nobel laureate Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn delivers lecture
Description:
Nobel laureate Dr. Elizabeth Blackburn delivers the 14th annual Walter J. Burdette Distinguished Lecture, titled 

"The Implications of Telomere Maintenance in Aging-related Processes." The lecture can be viewed via live webstream at the link below.

Summary: Scholar discusses Muslims in early modern France & Britain
Description:
Dr. Jocelyne Dakhlia, visiting faculty from the École des Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales in Paris, presents a talk titled "Invisible Strangers: Muslims in Early Modern France and Britain, 1500-1800."

 

The contribution made by Muslims to the development of Western Europe is much greater than previously thought. This talk will examine a recent body of collaborative research that brings this history of Muslims in Europe out of the shadows.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: Polyhedral Geometries are ChE graduate seminar topic
Description:
The McKetta Department of Chemical Engineering Graduate Seminar Series presents "Polyhedral Geometries in the Living World," a talk by Dr. Monica Olvera de la Cruz, Northwestern University.



Platonic and Archimedean solids have beguiled scientists, artists and mathematicians for millennia. In recent times polyhedral shapes have been identified at the microscopic level in crystalline shells such as fullerenes, viral capsids and protein-based bacterial organelles. The most frequently found polyhedron in homogeneous crystalline shells is the icosahedron. Olvera de la Cruz and colleagues demonstrate that other geometries arise spontaneously in shells formed by more than one component.

Summary: Joseph Turow presents McGovern Lecture
Description: Joseph Turow, Robert Lewis Shayon professor of communication at the University of Pennsylvania's Annenberg School for Communication, presents the 2013 McGovern Lecture, titled "Primetime Doctors: Why Should You Care?"

Summary: Viewpoint Series presents Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The Viewpoint Series presents a lecture by Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck. Levine specializes in contemporary art, with a career in scholarship, teaching and criticism. Rodenbeck teaches 20th and 21st century European and American art at Sarah Lawrence College, with a special interest in technology and feminist theory.

Summary: Yoga & Wellness Workshop announced
Description: Join Longhorn Wellness Club for a yoga workshop that also features mind and body techniques to relieve stress.

Summary: Hispanic Women's Network of Texas holds info meeting
Description: The Hispanic Women's Network of Texas is a new, professional student organization created to promote the advancement of Hispanic women in higher education through professional and personal development. Learn more at this meeting. Leadership positions are available and all majors are welcome.

Summary: Public Health Week Carnival announced
Description: Enjoy free games, food, prizes, activities and fun at the Public Health Week Carnival.

Summary: "Chevy vs. Cadillac": Talk examines the future of UT-Austin
Description:
Two years ago, UT System regent Gene Powell ignited a firestorm when he suggested that the state's public universities should turn their attention from being world-class research institutions ("Cadillacs") and focus instead on offering affordable four-year degrees, something like the old Chevrolet Bel Air. The continuing controversy involving research and undergraduate education at major public research universities is the subject of this panel discussion.



Panelists are Senior Vice Provost David Laude, Professor of Philosophy and former Dean of the School of Undergraduate Studies Paul Woodruff, Natural Sciences Associate Dean Sacha Kopp and former UT-Austin student Guarav Sanghavi, co-developer of the online learning tool Hoot.me. University Fellow and biology major Maria Fabiola Rodriguez moderates.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Talk addresses renewables and efficiency in the energy mix
Description: Jim Davis, president of Chevron Energy Solutions, presents this week's UT Energy Symposium talk, titled "Integrating Renewables and Efficiency in the Energy Mix at Chevron." Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Advances in self-diagnosis are topic of lecture
Description: Dr. Andrew Ellington, professor of biochemistry, presents "Diagnosing Ourselves: Take Two Assays and Don't Call Me in the Morning," a talk on exciting advances in low-cost, personalized diagnostics and the promise of creating virtual clinical trials through social networks to improve healthcare on a global scale. Pre-lecture fair begins at 5:45 p.m. Lecture begins at 7, followed by a Q&A.

Summary: Survey research & questionnaire design seminar offered
Description: Back by popular demand, the Office of Survey Research offers a two-hour seminar on basic survey research and questionnaire design concepts for students who are new to the process of conducting a survey research project or have limited experience designing surveys or drafting questionnaires. Visit the TXshop store at the link below and click on "OSR Seminar Series."

Summary: The life of Michael Vick is keynote topic
Description: As part of the Department of American Studies Graduate Conference, "Reimagining the American Dream," Dr. Claire Jean Kim (UC-Irvine) delivers the keynote address, "The Wonderful, Horrible Life of Michael Vick."

Summary: Dept. of Computer Science hosts Sandia National Labs
Description: The Department of Computer Science hosts Sandia National Labs, with a presentation on the benefits of attending graduate school. Open to current UT CS students. RSVP to under-info@cs.utexas.edu. Pizza will be served.

Summary: Stress Management is S.E.E.D. workshop topic
Description: A workshop on stress management for students employed by UT Austin introduces stress coping skills. Using cognitive techniques and guided relaxation, this interactive workshop helps participants learn to recognize the effects of stress affects and new ways to relax. Presented by the UT Counseling and Mental Health Center.

Summary: International Student Energy Association holds meeting
Description: International students who plan to be in the market for a job or an internship are invited to a meeting hosted by the International Student Energy Association with a representative from Schlumberger on the hiring of international students and what companies are looking for.

Summary: Vigil honors Shi'a Muslims killed in Pakistan
Description: Muslims from all around Austin gather for a solidarity vigil to denounce the recent surge of violence targeting communities in Pakistan. This gathering strives to uphold the Islamic ideals of unity, peace and justice, and features presentations by several community and student leaders.

Summary: E3W presents Sequels Symposium keynote speeches
Description: E3W (Ethnic & Third World Literatures) announces the 12th annual Sequels Symposium, "Literary Indictments: Bodies on Trial, in Prison, and Out of Bounds." Sequels is an annual graduate student conference featuring recent work of UT-Austin alumni and the research of current graduate students. English alumni Peter Caster and Ellen Crowell are this year's keynote speakers. Learn more below.

Summary: Communism & political Islam examined in presentation
Description:
A presentation titled "79.89.09. Slavs and Tatars" looks at two moments - the Iranian Revolution of 1979 and Poland's Solidarnosc movement in the 1980s - as bookends to the two major geopolitical narratives of the 20th and 21st centuries, respectively - communism and political Islam. 



Slavs and Tatars is a faction of polemics and intimacies devoted to an area east of the former Berlin Wall and west of the Great Wall of China known as Eurasia.

Summary: ¡A Viva Voz! presents an evening with Lalo Alcaraz
Description: The 11th annual ¡A Viva Voz! celebration of U.S. Latin@ culture presents an evening with Lalo Alcaraz, cartoonist, artist and writer. The event includes an exhibit of Alcaraz's unique and thought-provoking artwork, with comments by UT art professor George Flaherty. Light refreshments provided.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection

Summary: "Stuff UT Freshmen Say" talent show announced
Description: The Black Student Alliance hosts the funniest campus talent show you will ever attend. If you are interested in performing, email David McDonald at davidmcdonald@utexas.edu. First place winner earns a $100 prize at this don't miss event.

Summary: Polaris puts spotlight on modern-day slavery
Description: Polaris is an evening of discussion about current efforts to combat modern-day slavery. Learn about the resources and people in our city who have joined the fight against human trafficking in Austin and beyond. A 20-minute documentary by Trade In Hope will be screened. Learn how you can join in anti-human trafficking efforts.

Summary: Women in Foreign Affairs welcomes founder of SEN magazine
Description: Women in Foreign Affairs welcomes Senay Ozdemir, founder of SEN magazine, a glossy monthly magazine for Mediterranean women in the Netherlands founded in March 2004 and named best new magazine by the Dutch daily de Volkskrant. Ozdemir shares her experiences in business. A networking reception follows.

Summary: Longhorn Startup Seminar features Gary Hoover
Description: Entrepreneurial lessons with Gary Hoover are presented at this Longhorn Startup Seminar.

Summary: Texas softball takes on Texas Southern
Description: Texas Softball hosts the Texas Southern Tigers. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and special activities that will take place at the game.

Summary: Conference examines role of law in closing achievement gap
Description:
Aimed at education reformers, lawyers, educators, policy makers, scholars and students, this conference - The Role of Law in Closing the Educational Achievement Gap - explores ongoing law-related efforts to close the achievement gap as well as possible future initiatives. Register and learn more at the website below.



Co-presented by the William Wayne Justice Center for Public Interest Law and the Texas Journal on Civil Liberties & Civil Rights.

Summary: E3W Sequels Symposium presents panels & roundtable
Description: Ethnic & Third World Literatures (E3W) announces its 12th annual Sequels Symposium, "Literary Indictments: Bodies on Trial, in Prison, and Out of Bounds," a graduate student conference  centering around the recent work of UT Austin alumni and showcasing the research of current graduate students. For a full schedule of panels and other events, visit the link below.

Summary: German Immersion Weekend/Deutsches Wochenende announced
Description: Wilkommen! German Immersion Weekend invites any and all levels of German speakers to participate in a wide variety of German activities at beautiful McKinney Falls. Includes food, games, a scavenger hunt, swimming (weather permitting) and lots of German speaking with your peers. Carpool available. Bring a camping mat. Learn more and sign up at link below.
Location: McKinney Falls State Park, Austin, TX

Summary: Kayak for a Cause benefits GlobeMed partner clinic
Description: Enjoy time kayaking on Lady Bird Lake while helping GlobeMed at UT Austin raise money for its partner clinic in Guarjila, El Salvador. Tickets can be purchased online at link below, or on West Mall, and are redeemable from April 8-14. Fifty percent of proceeds from sales benefit the clinic. Visit globemedut.org for more information.
Location: Live Love Paddle at Ladybird Lake

Summary: Apply to CMHC's Student Advisory Committee
Description: The Counseling and Mental Health Center (CMHC) Student Advisory Committee provides a forum for direct input from UT student stakeholders to help CMHC better meet the mental health needs of UT students.  Committee members attend meetings the first Tuesday of every month in the fall and spring semesters, from 3:30-5 p.m. Members are strongly encouraged to volunteer at CMHC-sponsored campus events throughout the year. Learn more at the link below.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Jim Hobert
Description: The SSC Seminar Series is proud to present Professor James Hobert, University of Florida, with a seminar titled "Convergence Analysis of the Gibbs Sampler for Bayesian General Linear Mixed Models with Improper Priors." This talk introduces a convergence rate analysis of Gibbs samplers associated with using the popular default prior.

Summary: Annual Yoruba Day Celebration announced
Description: Join the Black Studies Department and the John L. Warfield Center for the eighth annual Yoruba Day Celebration and festivities. Showcases include a special keynote speaker, music, food, performances and much more.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: Population Research Center series presents Steven Austad
Description: Steven Austad, Department of Cellular and Structural Biology at UT San Antonio Health Sciences, gives a talk titled "The Future of Human Health and Longevity."

Summary: Pharmacists' role in new healthcare system discussed
Description: Dr. Terry McInnis is considered an expert on pharmacy's future.  She presents "Pharmacists' Role in a Transformed Healthcare System." Presentation available via a webcast at link below.

Summary: Race and indigeneity in Hawai'i discussed by scholar
Description: Judy Rohrer presents a talk titled "Staking Claim: Race and Indigeneity in Hawai'i." She is author of the book "Haoles in Hawai'i." This event is a component of the Shared Histories: Native American/Indigenous Studies Speaker Series.

Summary: Paul Soileau & PJ Rava discuss their collaboration
Description: The Performance as Public Practice program welcomes performance artist Paul Soileau - aka Rebecca Havemeyer, Austin's favorite drag queen, and the edgy and raw Christeene Vale - and award-winning cinematographer and documentary filmmaker PJ Raval, assistant professor, RTF. Soileau and Raval discuss Soileau's personas as well as their collaboration. For mature audiences.

Summary: Outsourcing at UT is conflict resolution event topic
Description: Make your voice heard in a discussion on the possible effects on students and workers if UT decides to follow through with plans to outsource nonacademic services. A report summarizing the results of this meeting will be submitted to the UT administration.

Summary: Sir Christopher Bayly discusses colonial India & Australia
Description: Sir Christopher Bayly discusses the colonial experience of India and Australia. In the aftermath of European settlement and metropolitan policies, the themes include race, gender, colonial violence, "governmentality" and political representation.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: Viewpoint seminar features Cary Levine & Judith Rodenbeck
Description: The Viewpoint Series presents a seminar given by Cary Levine and Judith Rodenbeck. Levine specializes in contemporary art, with a career in scholarship, teaching and criticism. Rodenbeck teaches 20th and 21st century European and American art at Sarah Lawrence College, with a special interest in technology and feminist theory.

Summary: Middle East Working Group welcomes Dr. Jocelyne Dakhlia
Description:
The Middle East Working Group announces a graduate student workshop with visiting professor and social historian Jocelyne Dakhlia. The workshop is an informal, interdisciplinary follow-up to Dakhlia's public lecture, "Invisible Strangers: Muslims in Early Modern France and Britain, 1500-1800," presented Thursday, April 4.



Dakhlia's recent work concerns Muslim immigration to Europe and its contemporary implications. She is visiting from École des Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales as part of an exchange program.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters holds open house
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters, the university branch of an international public speaking organization, hosts an open house for guests from all departments and majors. Enjoy an evening of networking and skill-building including a talk by two experienced speakers. A practice session follows. Free food and drinks served.

Summary: Texas women's tennis plays Florida International
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Florida International. Support your Longhorns as they face the Panthers.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Oklahoma
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 rival the Oklahoma Sooners. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Korean Culture Night competition announced
Description: Korean Culture Night is a competition-based show with cash prizes in which the audience's vote determines the winners. Bring your friends for great performances and vote for your favorite act. Free Korean food served.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: LAIC Spring Pow Wow announced
Description:
The Longhorn American Indian Council announces its Spring Pow Wow. An annual event, this year's Pow Wow is noncompetitive and features prominent dancers and singers from Austin's Great Promise of American Indians, including fancy dancers, grass dancers and women's fancy shawl. 



Special thanks to the Student Event Co-Sponsorship Committee and Student Government as well as the Multicultural Engagement Center and the Division of Diversity and Community Engagement for their support.

Summary: Volleyball National Championship celebration held
Description: Texas volleyball celebrates its 2012 national championship victory with fans during an exhibition match against NCAA regional semifinalist Wichita State. The match begins at noon. From 11:15-11:45 a.m., fans may take photos with head coach Jerritt Elliott and the national championship trophy. Prior to the match, a 30-minute documentary,"Point Texas: 2012 National Champions," will be shown on the video board.

Summary: Concert Crawl of Austin's Cultural Campus presented
Description: Butler School of Music students perform short, informal chamber music concerts in five museums from Austin's Cultural Campus. Each mini-concert features masterworks specifically chosen to respond to the art exhibited at the museums. Concerts run continuously from 1-4 p.m. at the Blanton Museum of Art, Harry Ransom Center, Texas Memorial Museum, Visual Arts Center and the LBJ Presidential Library.

Summary: Blanton Museum screens "Portrait of Wally"
Description: How does the law respond to art ownership disputes? This documentary traces the legal history of a famous Egon Schiele painting - seized by the Nazis in 1939 - and the subsequent quest for its return. Director Andrew Shea, associate professor in the UT Department of Radio-Television-Film, discusses the film. Running time, 90 minutes.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Forty Acres Fest 2013 announced
Description: Celebrate the 21st annual Forty Acres Fest, with music, games, prizes and lots of free booths hosted by our wonderful student organizations. Featured artists include Akina Adderley & the Vintage Playboys, Blue Bear, Jonathas, The Followthrough, Ben Baxter Band and a new festival favorite, Suite 7009. Student acts featured throughout the day. Chiddy Bang takes the stage at 7 p.m.
Location: Main Mall in front of Tower

Summary: Texas women's tennis battles Texas Tech
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor Texas Tech. Support your Longhorns as they face the Red Raiders.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Oklahoma
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 rival the Oklahoma Sooners. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Tailgate recycling for baseball seeks volunteers
Description: The Campus Environmental Center seeks volunteers for tailgate recycling at three spring baseball games. Volunteers assist attendees with recycling, and patrol the stands during the 5th and 7th innings. Volunteering can help you win for your organization, and get into the game for free.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Texas softball plays Western Kentucky
Description: Texas softball hosts the Western Kentucky Hilltoppers. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities that will take place.

Summary: Spain is topic of Study Abroad Country Corner
Description: The UT Study Abroad Office hosts a Country Corner information session on Spain. Peer advisers who have been to Spain talk about programs and their experiences abroad. Email studyabroadoffice@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-6490 for more information.
Location: Study Abroad Office, 2222 Rio Grande, MPR

Summary: Meryl Tankard's "The Oracle" performed
Description: Paul White performs a sensual, intense piece by celebrated choreographer Meryl Tankard that explores the conflicting forces of nature and man, masculinity and femininity, violence and nurturing, strength and vulnerability. Set to Stravinsky's seminal composition for the infamous 1913 ballet "The Rite of Spring," which caused riots at its Paris premiere and is celebrating is centennial in 2013.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: QPOCA presents Queer Prom: MasQUEERade 2013
Description: Also known as the "Second Chance Prom," this year's QPOCA prom theme is MasQUEERade. Refreshments and snacks provided, as well as a mask-making station, live DJ and photo booth.

Summary: Central Texas Friendship Walk funds Best Buddies projects
Description: Join Best Buddies to raise funds for inclusion, friendship and leadership opportunities for intellectually and developmentally disabled individuals. Register or join a team to participate in the Friendship Walk today.

Summary: Texas softball takes on Western Kentucky
Description: Texas softball hosts the Western Kentucky Hilltoppers. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities that will take place.

Summary: Texas women's tennis takes on Boston University
Description: Texas women's tennis takes on Boston University. Support your Longhorns as they face the BU Terriers.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Oklahoma
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 rival the Oklahoma Sooners. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Dawn Upshaw, soprano, performs
Description: Dawn Upshaw, soprano, performs with Stephen Prutsman, piano. Upshaw is a worldwide celebrity on both opera and concert stages, with a diverse repertoire that ranges from classic works of Bach to the freshest sounds of today.

Summary: 40 Days 'Til Graduation launched
Description: The launch for the 40 Days 'Til Graduation program launches with a kick-off event for graduating seniors in anticipation of their graduation day. The countdown display board begins at West Mall and moves across campus to remind students of the countdown. Look for display boards in Gregory Gym, Flawn,  Student Activity Center and the Student Services Building in order to win prizes.

Summary: Be a peer educator with Voices Against Violence, for credit
Description: Join the Voices Against Violence Theatre for Dialogue program and get upper-division credit for your time. Create and perform interactive scenarios about relationships, red flags, boundaries and consent. No experience necessary. Apply by April 22. Applications available at link below. Hear what students have to say about this class here.

Summary: Rhythmic grouping study seeks volunteers
Description: Volunteers are needed for a 45-50-minute experiment studying how native speakers of English group rhythmic speech sequences. Compensation is $10. If interested, contact Niamh Kelly or Megan Crowhurst at UTrhythmstudy@gmail.com to discuss eligibility and schedule.

Summary: Anti-Bullying Week presented by Real Role Models
Description: The Real Role Models host UT's very first Anti-Bullying Week. Events include Anti-Bully Pledge Day, Anti-Bully Dinner (free catering & spoken word) and Bully Free Festival (with free food, live music, games, prizes and more). For more information or to volunteer, visit the link below or https://www.facebook.com/home.php#!/events/118369541686200/.

Summary: Celebrate National Student Employee Appreciation Week
Description: National Student Employee Appreciation Week 2013 is the campus-wide celebration of contributions made by student employees to the university. Check the Celebrating Student Employees website linked below for information and tools for recognizing student employees in your school or college throughout the week.

Summary: Waller Creek Cleanup seeks volunteers
Description: Environmental Health and Safety and the Texas Natural Science Center host the biannual Waller Creek Cleanup on Saturday, April 13, to restore the urban watershed that runs from north Austin through the university campus into Lady Bird Lake. Register and download waiver at link below and bring it to event, which meets at Mustang statue at 8:45 a.m.

Summary: Register for Richie's Spirit basketball tournament
Description: Richie's Spirit Foundation promotes organ donation to people of all ages through innovative programming and meaningful grants. Participate in a basketball tournament benefiting the foundation on Sunday, April 14. Register now, and learn more, at the link below. "You only live once, why miss the opportunity?" - Richie Herskowitz

Summary: Lions Club Volleyball Tournament sign-up announced
Description: Sign up now for the Lions Club Volleyball Tournament, held from 3-10 p.m. on Friday, April 19. All proceeds go toward campaigns to fight human trafficking. To sign up or ask questions, contact Estel Yoo at 915-799-9500 or estel.k.yoo@utexas.edu or visit http://goo.gl/nqkAz. Individuals and teams with under 6 players, sign up at http://goo.gl/WzLVU.

Summary: Sign up for Longhorn Run
Description: The 2013 Longhorn Run takes place from 8 a.m.-noon on Saturday, April 13. All Longhorns are encouraged to participate, and the wider community is also welcome. Register and find out more at the link below. Email thelonghornrun@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Applied Movement Science degree program accepts applicants
Description: The Applied Movement Science Program in the Department of Kinesiology and Health Education, College of Education, is accepting internal transfer applications from students currently enrolled at UT Austin.  Visit the link below for more information, or contact Tere Ramirez at t.ramirez@austin.utexas.edu.  Advising available starting April 8.

Summary: Introduction to EndNote offered
Description: Bibliographies made easy: This online introductory class covers tricks for using EndNote with library databases, such as Web of Science, and with indexes and the library catalog. At class start time, go to the web address for the class, select "Enter as a Guest," type your name and click "Enter Room." You will need headphones or speakers and Flash 9 or higher.

Summary: Sorcery among the ancient Maya is talk topic
Description:
Professor David Stuart presents "The Ways of Witchcraft: Sorcery as Political Ideology Among the Ancient Maya." The talk offers an innovative look at the political culture of the ancient Maya, focusing on the roles of sorcery and witchcraft in the ideology of statecraft during the so-called Late Classic period (ca. 600-850 CE).



Stuart is the Linda and David Schele professor of Mesoamerican art and writing, University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Human Rights Symposium student panel held
Description: The UT White Rose Society's annual Human Rights Symposium hosts a student panel with representatives from various NGOs to discuss pressing human rights issues.

Summary: Forecasting of floods, droughts & extreme events discussed
Description: Guest lecturer Soroosh Sorooshian, University of California - Irvine, presents"Current State of Hydrologic Modeling and Challenges in Forecasting Floods and Predicting Droughts and Extreme Events."
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Charles Moyer discusses Inter-American Human Rights System
Description: Charles Moyer of the Inter-American Institute of Human Rights presents a talk titled "The Inter-American System of Human Rights: From an Auspicious Beginning to an Uncertain Future." Professor Ariel Dulitzky serves as respondent. Light refreshments served.

Summary: Stocks, bonds and mutual funds are Bevonomics topic
Description: Find out what stocks, bonds and mutual funds are, and how they work. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Panel discusses careers in public health
Description: Public health is a diverse and fast-growing field. Learn more about careers in this exciting sector from current professionals in areas including epidemiology, emergency preparedness and global health.

Summary: Latino-Jewish Passover seder held
Description: Attend the second annual Latino-Jewish Seder. This seder, the ritual dinner associated with the holiday of Passover, is an opportunity to share modern stories of exodus and raise awareness of current humanitarian crises affecting people across Latin America. We will hear stories from individuals who have sought political asylum in the U.S. through the organization Mexicanos en Exilio.
Location: Texas Hillel, 2105 San Antonio Street, corner of 21st and San Antonio

Summary: Caribbean Students Association holds general meeting
Description: The Caribbean Students Association holds general meetings every other Monday. Join us in celebrating all aspects of Caribbean culture. Meetings feature free Caribbean food, and a chance to meet other Caribbean students and become involved in our vibrant organization.
