Summary: Bitcoin is Mises Circle topic
Description: The Mises Circle discusses the economics and technology of the crypto-currency Bitcoin. If you cannot make it in person, join us online via Google  Hangouts.

Summary: Multicultural Engagement Center seeks student assistants
Description: The Multicultural Engagement Center (MEC) seeks applicants for fall employment. Work on campus 10-12 hours a week and help with projects and light office duties. Deadline to apply is Friday, April 12. Stop by the MEC office or email sreddick@austin.utexas.edu for an application.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: Human Rights Symposium hosted by White Rose Society
Description: The White Rose Society hosts a panel discussion on human rights issues with Professors Jeremi Suri and Joshua Busby.

Summary: Obama's Middle East Policy in second term discussed
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Obama's Second Chance: Middle East Policy in the President's Second Term," with Robert Satloff, executive director of The Washington Institute. Refreshments provided.



An expert on Arab and Islamic politics as well as U.S. Middle East policy, Satloff has served since 1993 as executive director of The Washington Institute. In that capacity, he oversees all Institute operations and leads the organization's unparalleled team of Middle East scholars, experts and policy practitioners. He also holds the Institute's Howard P. Berkowitz Chair in U.S. Middle East Policy.

Summary: Dan Balz presents Hearst Fellows Award Lecture
Description: Dan Balz, chief correspondent at The Washington Post, presents the William Randolph Hearst Fellows Award Lecture. His speech is titled "Red and Blue America: Politics and Journalism in a Divided Country." A 5 p.m. reception follows the lecture.

Summary: Author Mikhail Shishkin speaks about contemporary Russia
Description: Award-winning Russian author Mikhail Shishkin discusses language and politics in Russia. Shishkin outraged the Russian government recently when he refused to participate in a delegation to the prestigious BookExpo America 2013 in New York, citing Russia as "a country where power has been seized by a corrupt, criminal regime, where the state is a pyramid of thieves." His latest novel, "Maidenhair," was recently translated into English.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: Entrepreneurship Live presents Susan Strausberg
Description: Guest speaker Susan Strausberg discusses her years as a successful entrepreneur. A reception with hors d'oeuvres follows her talk.
Location: AT&T Education and Conference Center (ATT), Room 201

Summary: South Asian American Digital Archive holds event
Description: Attend a lecture and reception on the South Asian American Digital Archive (SAADA), an independent nonprofit working to document, preserve and provide access to South Asian American history through a digital-only archive. SAADA co-founder and executive director Samip Mallick discusses the archive and its role in society.

Summary: Jesus in the Quran is topic of talk
Description: The Islamic Dialogue Student Association presents a talk titled "Jesus in the Quran," by Okan Dogan. What does the Quran say about the life and miracles of Jesus? What do Muslims believe about him and his mother, Mary? Refreshments served.

Summary: Learn about HDO executive master's degree
Description:
The Human Dimensions of Organizations (HDO) master of arts degree application is available for the HDO's first class, to commence in fall 2013. Attend an information session to meet the director and select faculty. RSVP at link below.



HDO provides training in identifying and solving organizational problems. This professional graduate degree is designed specifically for local, national and international leaders in the business and nonprofit sectors. Courses emphasize the real-world applications of the humanities, social sciences and behavioral sciences.
Location: Flawn Academic Center (FAC) 18, Liberal Arts Career Services Suite

Summary: Tailgate recycling for baseball seeks volunteers
Description: The Campus Environmental Center seeks volunteers for tailgate recycling at three spring baseball games. Volunteers assist attendees with recycling, and patrol the stands during the 5th and 7th innings. Volunteering can help you win for your organization, and get into the game for free.

Summary: Study Abroad holds France Planning Scholarships session
Description: Students who won a Planning Scholarship through the Study Abroad Office or who are interested in studying abroad in France are invited to an information session about life, culture and academics in France that includes details on the different study abroad programs in the country.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Texas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Texas State Bobcats. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Kate Henderson, COO of University Medical Center, speaks
Description: Last November, Travis County voters approved Proposition 1, funding local health-care initiatives, including the new UT Austin medical school and a teaching hospital that will replace University Medical Center (UMC) Brackenridge. Kate Henderson, chief operating officer of UMC Brackenridge, looks ahead to how local health care will change for the better.

Summary: VAC presents "Double Exposure: Reflections in Film"
Description: In conjunction with their Vaulted Gallery exhibition "Diffuse Reflection Lab," Lead Pencil Studio and the Visual Arts Center present an evening of selected cinematic vignettes by a diverse group of directors and cinematographers, all of whom employ reflections in their work to stunning visual effect.

Summary: UT Percussion Ensemble performs
Description: The UT Percussion Ensemble presents a rare performance of Steve Reich's "Music for 18 Musicians," featuring guest artists Tim Laughlin, Brian Heim, Charlie Magnone, Josh Straub, Dana Zenobi, Rebekah Smeltzer, Page Stephens, Steph Pollock, Alex Ford, Nick Galuban, Rachell Wong and Liz Lee.

Summary: Abbie Conant presents "Music for the End of Time"
Description: "Music for the End of Time" is a 52-minute work based on the Book of Revelation for trombone, surround-sound and video by William Osborne.
Location: Butler School of Music (MRH), Recital Studio 2.608

Summary: "Million Dollar Quartet" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description: Tony Award-winning Broadway musical "Million Dollar Quartet" is inspired by the true story of the famed recording session that brought together rock 'n' roll icons Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins for the first and only time.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Privatization protest announced
Description:
On January 29, University of Texas President Bill Powers announced "Smarter Systems for a Greater UT," a privatization plan proposed by 13 consultants who were paid $960,000 to come up with ideas to make UT "more efficient." The plan proposes outsourcing all nonacademic services and will raise prices significantly for on-campus services. Join students and members of the Texas State Employees Union at a protest to take a stand against this plan.



The Powers plan directly affects women and minority workers on campus, as well as the students who struggle to afford the rising cost of UT.

Summary: State Employees' Union Rally and Lobby Day announced
Description: State workers and union members from across Texas come to Austin for a march and rally to defend public workers and public services. Everything is at stake: our jobs, our pensions, our health care, our pay and the services we provide. TSEU is calling for a massive show of strength with a march to the Capitol, a rally on the south steps and visits to legislators.

Summary: Apply to participate in Honors Day poster presentation
Description: Liberal arts undergraduate researchers who wish to publicize their work can apply to participate in the Liberal Arts poster presentation. Approved applicants will have their posters professionally printed, courtesy of the college, and present their poster at the Honors Day reception on Saturday, April 13. Call at 232-5749 for more information.

Summary: SoundBrain Lab seeks monolingual subjects for study
Description: The SoundBrain Lab seeks healthy participants ages 18-40 with normal hearing and no second language experience before the age of 12 for a behavioral study of auditory training optimization.

Summary: Spring 2013 Career & Internship Fair announced
Description: Attend the Spring 2013 Career & Internship Fair to help launch your career or find an internship. Attire is business dress to business casual. Bring several copies of your resume.

Summary: Take a break at StressFest 2013
Description: Get rid of stress before the end of the semester. StressFest features free chair massages, live music, pet therapy dogs, a photo booth, fitness/wellness class demonstrations, tropical slushies, a relaxation deck, biofeedback, acupuncture and much more.

Summary: CMAS presents faculty research talk
Description:
The Center for Mexican American Studies (CMAS) hosts a Faculty Research Plática with Deborah Paredez, titled "Blue and Full of Stars." Paredez is associate professor in the Department of English. This talk focuses on her poetry manuscript, which engages issues of gender and memory through an account of a Mexican-American woman who is suffering from Alzheimer's disease.



CMAS Faculty Research Pláticas are presented by faculty affiliates of the Center who were awarded a CMAS Faculty Research Fellowship during the previous academic year.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Learn to manage citations with Zotero
Description: Learn how to use Zotero, a free, web-based tool, to collect, manage and cite your sources. The session introduces the basics of Zotero and moves into more advanced concepts to be selected by attendees.

Summary: Race, history & the present addressed in two talks
Description:
Dr. Simone Browne and Dr. Ben Carrington, both of the Department of Sociology, present talks on the theme of race. Contact event coordinators Amina Zarrugh (amina.zarrugh@utexas.edu) or Christine Wheatley (christine.wheatley@utexas.edu) to receive advance copies of the papers.



Browne's talk is titled "Walking While Black: Notes on Surveillance Studies," a look at The Book of Negroes and modern surveillance. Carrington's talk is "Summer Flames, Summer Games," examining how sport both reinforces and challenges dominant ideologies around class, race, gender and nation.

Summary: Asian Studies undergrad honors info session held
Description: Faculty honors adviser Dr. Heather Hindman holds an information session to answer questions about applying for departmental honors this April. The Asian Studies Honors program gives students an opportunity to work closely with faculty and to write an independent research paper. Light refreshments served.

Summary: Make the most of your scholarship search
Description: Find out how best to search for scholarships, and learn writing tips to improve your application.

Summary: Country Corners features Western Europe, Scandinavia
Description: Learn about Study Abroad programs in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Greece, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK at this edition of Country Corners.

Summary: Whole systems seminar announced
Description: Whole systems takes health to another level, focusing on the entire body as opposed to a single area. Learn how to keep your entire body in harmony.

Summary: Lions Club holds food sale fund-raiser
Description: The Lions Club sells fried rice and drinks. Proceeds fund campaigns to raise awareness of and combat human trafficking.

Summary: Teach English abroad info session held
Description: Learn about opportunities to teach English abroad from ESL faculty who have taught in foreign countries and through Cambridge's ESL Certificate program.

Summary: Sleep and Stress Seminar announced
Description: The Longhorn Wellness Club holds a Sleep and Stress Seminar. Do you have trouble sleeping due to stress? Learn of remedies that can help you sleep. Systemic muscle relaxation, yoga and other stress-relief techniques will be taught.

Summary: Compliance & Ethics is S.E.E.D. student workshop topic
Description: Compliance and ethics are the topics of a workshop offered for students employed by UT Austin. Compliance and ethics programs are a standard practice in business. Learn the importance of these programs in the public and private sectors and how they got started. Presented by University Compliance Services.

Summary: FDR's "Fourth Policeman" is topic of scholar's talk
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law and the William P. Clements Jr. Center on History, Strategy and Statecraft jointly invite you to "The Fourth Policeman: FDR's Vision for China's Global Role," with Erez Manela, professor at Harvard University. Refreshments provided.



It is well known that U.S. president Franklin Roosevelt envisioned a postwar order based on four great powers, the so-called "four policemen": the United States, the Soviet Union, Great Britain and China. But why did Roosevelt insist on including China among the four policemen when China had long been considered a minor power and when his other wartime allies, Churchill and Stalin, both strongly opposed the idea? This talk explores this question and shows how it shed light on U.S. global strategy in the 1940s and since.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), LBJ School of Public Affairs, 3.124

Summary: Difficult Dialogue panel discusses Prop. 8 and DOMA
Description: The Liberal Arts Council presents: Difficult Dialogue - A Panel on Proposition 8 and the Defense of Marriage Act. Panelists from different departments in the Liberal Arts College discuss the implications of the two current gay marriage cases being argued before the Supreme Court, taking audience questions live and via Twitter. A short reception follows.

Summary: Over-Consumerism & the U.S. housing crisis is talk topic
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence ACE/Distinguished Speaker Series welcomes Professor Mechele Dickerson, presenting "Over-Consumerism and the U.S. Housing Crisis." Dickerson is a nationally recognized consumer law and bankruptcy scholar whose current research focuses on the U.S. housing crisis and consumer over-indebtedness. Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Art of Living holds "stress-buster" breathing sessions
Description: Art of Living UT offers weekly "stress-buster" sessions to teach stress management through simple breathing techniques and meditation. This session is led by an experienced Art of Living guest speaker.

Summary: Human Rights Symposium presents keynote speaker
Description: The White Rose Society hosts a keynote address by Anna Yáñez-Correa, executive director of the Texas Criminal Justice Coalition.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA), Conference Room

Summary: Hindu YUVA meets
Description: Join Hindu YUVA for weekly activities, including yoga, games, discussions and physical exercise.

Summary: Dr. Gloria Gonzalez-Lopez discusses masculinities, violence
Description: Join students and off-campus community partners as Voices Against Violence welcomes Dr. Gloria Gonzalez-Lopez to discusses masculinities and antiviolence. Free food served.

Summary: Engineering masters degree info session held
Description: The Engineering Masters Degree Program hosts an information session about the Engineering Management and Software Engineering programs at The University of Texas at Austin. Alumni and current students will be present to answer your questions, following a brief program overview.
Location: J. J. Pickle Research Campus (PRC), Stadium Room 1.130

Summary: URES Real Estate Debt Industry Update presented
Description: Get an update on the current state of the real estate industry and learn about the debt side of commercial real estate financing with top executives from Prudential Mortgage Capital Company.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: College Republicans debate University Democrats
Description: Representatives from College Republicans and University Democrats face off at the CR/Udems Debate. Join us for a night of constructive debate between two of the oldest political groups on campus. The moderator will field questions from the audience for both teams. Follow us on @texascr and @Udems #UTDebate.

Summary: Intific representative speaks at EGaDS general meeting
Description: A representative from Intific speaks at the upcoming EGaDS meeting. Intific builds and delivers effective software that is technologically aggressive. This presentation will look at what's next in the areas of immersive technologies, game-based training and education, and neuroscience, such as mind-controlled games. Free pizza and soft drinks served.

Summary: BON JOVI "Because We Can - The Tour"
Description: Blazing a trail across the globe, all-American rock band Bon Jovi brings their "Because We Can - The Tour" to the Frank Erwin Center for a one-night-only performance.

Summary: Mary Gauthier performs at the Cactus
Description: Mary Gauthier writes songs that have a way of burrowing into that hole so many of us carry inside our souls, and emerging with universal truths that show we aren't so alone after all. Hear Gauthier on the intimate Cactus stage.

Summary: Avant-Garde Film Night presents "4 x Nathaniel Dorsky"
Description: Attend a screening of four silent films by director Nathaniel Dorsky: "Compline" (18.5 min., 16mm, 2009); "Pastourelle" (16.5 min., 16mm, 2010); "August and After" (18.5 min., 16mm, 2012); and "April" (26 min., 16mm, 2012).

Summary: Learn to use maps with your research
Description: Learn how to incorporate maps into your research without having to learn GIS.

Summary: Asian art in "Through the Eyes of Texas" is talk topic
Description: Asian art scholar Hao Sheng leads a gallery talk on the Blanton exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections."

Summary: Hidden Biases of Good People presented by Mahzarin Banaji
Description: Professor Mahzarin R. Banaji, the foremost leader on the science behind unconscious thinking and feeling as they unfold in social context, leads a discussion on the research behind her new book, "Blindspot: Hidden Biases of Good People." Banaji demonstrates how subtle biases influence how we perceive our clients and witnesses, interact with other attorneys and judges and attempt to persuade juries. For more information, contact Melissa Galusky at mgalusky@law.utexas.edu or 512-232-1911.
Location: The Four Seasons Hotel, 98 San Jacinto Boulevard

Summary: SweCxn database of Swedish constructions presented
Description: "SweCxn - a Swedish Constructicon" is presented by Benjamin Lyngfelt, Department of Swedish, University of Gothenburg. The Swedish Constructicon (SweCxn) is a database of Swedish constructions based on principles of construction grammar and developed as an addition to the Swedish FrameNet.

Summary: Renowned historian Ayesha Jalal launches new book at UT
Description: Renowned historian Ayesha Jalal leads a seminar at the university's Hindi Urdu Flagship to launch her new book "The Pity of Partition: Manto's Life, Times, and Work Across the India-Pakistan Divide." The book focuses on Saadat Hasan Manto (1912-1955), a master of 20th-century Urdu literature whose fiction serves as a lens through which the tragedy of partition is brought sharply into focus.

Summary: Managing your student loans is workshop topic
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Nuclear scientist to speak on unlocking energy innovation
Description: Richard Lester, head of the Department of Nuclear Science and Engineering at MIT, gives a talk titled "Unlocking Energy Innovation" at this week's meeting of the UT Energy Symposium. Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Healthcare reform panel addresses future business leaders
Description: Understanding Healthcare Reform: Preparation for Business Leaders is a panel discussion providing essential information on the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. Learn how healthcare reform might affect you and your large or small business after graduation. Discuss what new products and services entrepreneurs might bring to market.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 103

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Coco Fusco
Description: New York-based interdisciplinary artist Coco Fusco presents an artist talk on her most recent work. Fusco is also a writer and the director of Intermedia Initiatives at Parsons School for Design. Her work combines electronic media and performance in a variety of formats.

Summary: Student Ambassador info session announced
Description: The Office of Admissions seeks to hire student ambassadors/tour guides to start in the summer or fall. You must attend one information session to be eligible. Additional sessions are held April 14 at 2:30 p.m. in Walter Webb Hall (WWH), and April 16 and 17 at 5:30 p.m. in JHH.
Location: John Hargis Hall (JHH), Undergraduate Admissions Center

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in the commercial real estate industry. Register to attend at link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.20

Summary: U.S. Department of State info session announced
Description: This information session introduces attendees to employment opportunities at the U.S. Department of State as well as internships and fellowships. Diplomat-in-Residence Julie Connor and U.S. Department of State officer Anjoly Ibrahim will be the briefers. Working for the U.S. Department of State requires U.S. citizenship. The Department is an equal opportunity employer.

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship discusses Jesus' New Covenant
Description: What did Jesus preach 2,000 years ago? According to the Bible, He preached the gospel, the New Covenant. Explore the meaning of the covenant at this Bible study. Email UEFellowship2012@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: "Making Trouble": Film looks at female Jewish comedians
Description: Attend a screening of "Making Trouble," a documentary film about female Jewish comedians. Light snacks provided.

Summary: Larry Towell presents an evening of photography & music
Description:
Magnum photographer, poet and folk musician Larry Towell presents an evening of photography and music, with accompaniment by harmonica virtuoso Mike Stevens. This multimedia performance incorporates still images, video, poetry and song.



Towell is the author of 12 books, and his exhibitions have toured North America and Europe. Stevens is best known for his groundbreaking work in bluegrass music and is a member of The Grand Ole Opry. 



The Magnum Photos archive resides at the Ransom Center.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BEL), auditorium

Summary: Poet Linda Gregg reads from her work
Description: Visiting professor of poetry Linda Gregg gives a reading of her work. She is hailed as one of America's finest lyric poets, and her eight books include "In the Middle Distance," "Things & Flesh" and "The Sacraments of Desire."
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Austin Classical Guitar Society presents Global Cactus
Description: Croatian guitarist and UT doctoral student Paulina Puljek makes her Cactus Cafe debut (9 p.m.), preceded by award-winning Chilean virtuoso Nicolas Emilfork with flutist Natalie Zeldin (8 p.m.).

Summary: Science under the Stars presents "Electric Life"
Description: Science Under the Stars presents UT graduate student Ben Liebskind, "Electric Life." It has long been known that animal tissues can generate electricity. Every organism on the planet, even bacteria, uses electricity in one way or another. Liebeskind explores some of the lesser-known uses of electricity in strange and wonderful organisms, and complex electrical signaling in animal brains. Arrive early for refreshments and fun activities for kids of all ages.
Location: Brackenridge Field Laboratory (BFL), 2907 Lake Austin Boulevard

Summary: History Honors symposium slated
Description: History Honors thesis writers present their research for questions and discussion. Snacks will be provided and all are welcome. For more information about this event, call 512-475-7235.

Summary: SALSA XXI symposium presents "Language Variation & Change"
Description: The two-day 21st annual SALSA symposium is titled "Language Variation and Change." Keynote speakers are Sergio Romero (UT), Spike Gildea (U. of Oregon), Jacob Eisenstein (Georgia Tech), Jacqueline Toribio and Barbara Bullock (UT) and special guest Samy Alim (Stanford). Talks discuss typological, anthropological, computational and sociolinguistic approaches to the symposium theme.

Summary: Participants ages 18-35 sought for exercise study
Description: Participants ages 18-35 are sought for an ongoing exercise study of recreationally active individuals. Potential participants must be currently engaged in at least 200 minutes of strenuous exercise per week (defined by rapid heartbeat, exercise on the verge of being uncomfortable, etc.). Contact rictstudy@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Register for Lavender Graduation
Description:
Lavender Graduation, which takes place Wednesday, May 15, is a special graduation ceremony that honors the achievements of graduating lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer and ally students on campus. RSVP to the Facebook event by May 10 to attend, and register at the URL provided below by May 1 to participate. Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/143470422482143/.

 

Lavender Graduation is co-hosted by the Gender and Sexuality Center and the UT Queer Students Alliance (QSA). The goal is to provide a venue to demonstrate the success of our community members in a personal, entertaining and celebratory way. The Lavender Graduation Ceremony includes: exhilarating speeches from UT faculty, administrators, students and alumni; the chance to cross the lavender stage to celebrate your success and to receive a Lavender Graduation certificate as well as a rainbow tassel; and music, cake and food to share with friends, family and well-wishers.

Summary: Osteoarthritis study subjects (ages 40-90) can earn $100
Description:
The Kinesiology & Health Education Department's Cardiovascular Aging Research Laboratory seeks subjects ages 40-90 with diagnosed osteoarthritis (OA) to participate in a 12-week  study on the effects of stationary cycling or swimming on OA symptom management. Contact the lab at arthritisUT@gmail.com or 512-471-8594.



Subjects receive three months of supervised aerobic conditioning in UT facilities, pre- and post-training cardiovascular health assessments, body composition assessments, as well as $100 compensation upon trial completion.

Summary: IRB office hours held
Description: This session provides researchers (students, faculty and other university community members) with the opportunity to ask questions about draft research protocols, Institutional Review Board (IRB) application documents and ethical concerns about social/behavioral research with human participants. Bring your study documents (hard copies preferred) and receive immediate feedback and answers to IRB-related questions.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Richard Hahn, U. of Chicago
Description: The Division of Statistics and Scientific Computation is proud to host University of Chicago professor Richard Hahn, with a talk titled "DSS: Decoupled Shrinkage and Selection in Linear Models."

Summary: Undergraduate Research Forum held
Description: Every spring, the College of Natural Science celebrates its student-scientists at this one-day event, where more than 200 students present research posters. The best and most innovative posters and presentations are recognized with awards judged and sponsored by the university, faculty, alumni and industry.

Summary: Psychfest features presentations, keynote
Description: The Psychology Department hosts an afternoon of presentations by Clinical Area doctoral students and a keynote lecture by guest speaker Professor Matt McGue of the University of Minnesota at 3:30 p.m. McGue's talk is titled "Adolescent Substance Use and Abuse: A Developmental Behavioral Genetic Perspective." Doctoral student presentations begin at 1 p.m. (talk titles available at the link below). A reception follows.

Summary: Performing Blackness Series symposium held
Description: Theatre & Dance's Performance as Public Practice program and the Warfield Center's Performing Blackness Series co-host a discussion of Charles O. Anderson/Dance Theatre X's "TAR," examining Black dance, producing Black art and the role of art in generating social change. Dr. Thomas Frantz, professor, Duke University, is the keynote speaker. Held in conjunction with two public performances of Dance Theatre X's "TAR," on April 12 and 13 at 8 p.m. in the Oscar G. Brockett Theatre.

Summary: Philip Waller discusses "Writers, Readers, & Reputations"
Description:
Author Philip Waller discusses the origin of his book "Writers, Readers, and Reputations: Literary Life in Britain 1870-1918," which presents a panoramic view of literary life in Britain over half a century before the First World War, revealing the authors' relations with the reading public and tracing how reputations were made and unmade.



Waller is a past editor of the English Historical Review and a fellow of Merton College, Oxford as well as the author of numerous other books.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: Learning & Memory conference hosts Edvard & May-Britt Moser
Description:
Drs. Edvard Moser and May-Britt Moser deliver back-to-back keynote presentations for the UT Austin conference on Learning and Memory. The Mosers are co-directors of the Kavlie Institute for Systems Neuroscience at the Norwegian University of Science and Technology. Their research has provided seminal insights into how spatial location and spatial memory are computed and represented in the brain.  



Dr. May-Britt Moser delivers a presentation titled "The Entorhinal-Hippocampal Space Map" at 3 p.m., and Dr. Edvard Moser presents "Functional Organization of the Grid-Cell System" at 4 p.m.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), amphitheater 204

Summary: Musicology/Ethnomusicology holds Colloquium Series lecture
Description: Guest lecturer Professor Daniel Neuman, UCLA, presents "Hindustani Music History Making," a talk on the general challenges of writing Hindustani music history and his the examination of five generations of musicians in the family of his teacher, Ustad Sabri Khan.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters Meeting
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Closing reception for student exhibitions held
Description: Join the Department of Art and Art History for a reception celebrating the Senior Art, Senior Design and Masters of Fine Arts Design exhibitions at the Visual Arts Center.

Summary: X'ene Sky Taylor presents junior piano recital
Description: Join junior X'ene Sky for a piano recital, with music ranging from Henry Cowell to a fiery Beethoven sonata. Reception to follow.

Summary: Distinguished photographers discuss portraiture
Description: Three distinguished photographers shows slides of their work and discuss the technical, aesthetic and ethical issues a photographer must consider when photographing people, whether in Afghanistan or in one's own backyard. Panelists are Louie Palu, Larry Towell and and Sarah Wilson. Reception begins at 6 p.m., with slide presentations and discussion starting at 7 p.m.

Summary: Texas softball plays Iowa State
Description: Texas softball hosts the Iowa State Cyclones. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities.

Summary: Chamber Singers perform
Description: The UT Chamber Singers perform a spring concert.

Summary: Performing Blackness Series presents TAR
Description: The Warfield Center's Performing Blackness Series presents "TAR," Charles O. Anderson and Dance Theatre X, with a special appearance by Ursula Rucker. TAR rewrites the Uncle Remus tales - retelling and redefining the African American trickster tradition embodied by the tar baby metaphor. Pre-performance event begins at 7 p.m.; post-performance commentary by Brenda Dixon-Gottschild.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Wildflower Center holds Spring Plant Sale & Gardening Fest
Description: The Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center's Spring Plant Sale & Gardening Festival provides the best selection of hardy Central Texas plants, shrubs and trees, with butterfly gardening as a special emphasis this year. Take a guided hike with the designer of our butterfly garden Saturday at 2 p.m. and Sunday at 1 p.m. Book signings take place both afternoons at The Store from 1-4 p.m.
Location: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center, 4801 La Crosse Avenue

Summary: West Campus Clean-Up announced
Description: Sick of how dirty West Campus is? Help the Campus Environmental Center with a clean-up and make West Campus a little more sustainable. Contact recycling@utenvironment.org for more information or sign up here at the link below.
Location: Meets 8:45 a.m. at Barbara Jordan statue near UNB

Summary: SALSA "Language Variation & Change" symposium continues
Description: The two-day 21st annual SALSA symposium, "Language Variation and Change," continues. Speakers include Sergio Romero (UT), Spike Gildea (U. of Oregon), Jacob Eisenstein (Georgia Tech), Jacqueline Toribio and Barbara Bullock (UT) and special guest Samy Alim (Stanford). Talks discuss typological, anthropological, computational and sociolinguistic approaches to the symposium theme.

Summary: The Ladies of Umoja present annual Black Women's Symposium
Description:
The Black Women's Symposium helps establish a confidence-building environment and supports the success of attendees after graduation. Workshops and presentations discuss mental and physical health, dressing for success, financial stability and more. This year's keynote is given by Mrs. Joie Rasberry. Free breakfast and lunch served. Learn more at https://www.facebook.com/events/508005985924637/.



Workshop presenters include Ms. Brenda Burt, Mrs. Thais Moore, Dr. Kevin O. Cokley and Dr. Kesha Bentley-Edwards.

Summary: Saturday Morning Math Group discusses coding & the brain
Description: The Saturday Morning Math Group presents "Information, Bits, Coding and the Brain," a talk led by Dr. Jonathan Pillow of the UT Center for Perceptual Systems. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Bagels, snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday at UT's first student-run sustainable farm. This weekend is the farm's ground-breaking event. All ages and skill levels invited. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Amnesty International state conference slated
Description: The Amnesty International chapter at UT hosts the Amnesty Conference for the State of Texas. Attendees have the opportunity to network with activists from around the state, learn new activism skills and hear from experts working in human rights fields.

Summary: Texas 4000 Hope Day promotes cancer awareness
Description: Join Texas 4000 for its second annual Hope Day festival, featuring free games, live music and interactive booths. Texas 4000 is dedicated to spreading hope, knowledge and charity in the fight against cancer. Hope Day shares the pillar of our mission with the local cancer community. Learn more about our organization, or sign up for a ride, at http://www.texas4000.org.

Summary: Blanton presents Reiko Tomii on modernism & Japanese art
Description: Art historian Reiko Tomii presents a lecture on modernism and Japanese art in conjunction with the exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas." This event is co-presented with the UT Department of Art History.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: Honors Day celebrates academic achievement
Description:
The 65th annual Honors Day program celebrates students who have achieved academic excellence by honoring them as College Scholars and Distinguished College Scholars. Steven Dietz delivers the keynote address.



The Honors Day Convocation includes ceremonial elements such as an academic procession, orange-and-white honors cords worn by students, heraldic banners, inspirational messages and celebratory music.



Keynote speaker Dietz is Fellow to the Theater for Youth Chair and Professor of Playwriting and Directing in the Department of Theatre and Dance in the College of Fine Arts at The University of Texas at Austin, and is a resident faculty member of the Michener Center for Writers.

Summary: "Million Dollar Quartet" matinee performed
Description: Tony Award-winning Broadway musical "Million Dollar Quartet" is inspired by the true story of the famed recording session that brought together rock 'n' roll icons Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins for the first and only time.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: The challenges of pre-med are topic of workshop
Description: Chinyere Ugwuzor, a senior and member of INSPIRE Women's Leadership, discusses her experience as a pre-med student and reflects on what she would have done differently. The workshop includes a brief interactive presentation with a question/answer session on the med school application process, interview tips, the MCAT and more.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Anchor Slam is 3-on-3 charity basketball competition
Description: Sign up to play in Anchor Slam, a 3-on-3 basketball tournament benefiting the Delta Gamma (DG) Foundation and the Texas School for the Blind and Visually Impaired. Price includes t-shirts, pizza and the chance to win prizes. Check out the Facebook event or ask to a DG or Wrangler for more information.

Summary: Texas softball takes on Iowa State
Description: Texas softball hosts the Iowa State Cyclones. Wear pink to support breast cancer awareness as part of UT Athletics Horns for Hope initiative. Pink at the Plate ticket is $4, general admission. Enter PINKSB13 on the promo code page of TexasSports.com or call 512-232-3865 by Friday. Visit the Bevo's Bargains section of TexasSports.com to learn of additional promotions and activities.

Summary: Turkish Film Series screens "Once Upon a Time in Anatolia"
Description: Attend a screening of "Bir Zamanlar Anadolu'da" (Once Upon a Time in Anatolia, 2011, 150 minutes), directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan. In the dead of night, a group of men - including a police commissioner, a prosecutor, a doctor and a murder suspect - drive through the tenebrous Anatolian countryside in search of a corpse, the victim of a brutal murder. During the drive, further mysteries unfold. In Turkish with English subtitles.

Summary: Texas Revue 2013 presented
Description: Texas Revue is the largest and most diverse student-run talent show held on campus, showcasing a variety of diverse and talented acts including dancing, music and skits performed by student organizations and individuals.

Summary: Maria Schneider performs with UT Jazz Orchestra
Description: Grammy-winning arranger, composer and big band leader Maria Schneider joins The University of Texas Jazz Orchestra as part of the Butler School of Music's annual Longhorn Jazz Festival. Directed by Professor Jeff Hellmer, the UT Jazz Orchestra is the Butler School's premiere jazz ensemble.

Summary: Nominate for Liberal Arts Council Faculty Endowment Award
Description: The nomination process is open for the Liberal Arts Council (LAC) Faculty Endowment Award. Recipients are professors who demonstrate outstanding teaching ability and a commitment to their students and the College of Liberal Arts. Students can nominate a tenure or tenure-track professor at the link below by Tuesday, April 16 at 5 p.m. Direct questions to morgan@morgancaridi.com.

Summary: Backpacks for Brazil seeks donations
Description: Send much-needed backpacks to elementary school students in Brazil with a UT student volunteer. Gently used backpacks or new backpacks are needed. Visit the Facebook page below to find out more, and spread the word.

Summary: Senior Thesis Symposium held
Description: Seniors in the Plan II Honors Program give a series of oral presentations on their original thesis research. Senior Thesis Symposium sessions cover a wide range of interdisciplinary topics, including literature, science, history, creative writing, music, health care, engineering, philosophy, business and politics. For more information about this event, call at 512-471-1442.
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA), ground floor

Summary: Arnold Newman-inspired cooking class offered
Description:
Celebrate the exhibition "Arnold Newman: Masterclass" with the Ransom Center and Central Market Cooking School. Inspired by Newman's portraits, Chef Louis Ortiz has created a menu drawn from some of the fine dining establishments of the 1950s and 1960s and the luminaries who frequented them. Pre-payment and registration required; visit link below. Members, call 512-232-3669 for the discount code. Early registration recommended due to limited class size.



Representatives from the Ransom Center will be on hand to discuss the exhibition as attendees enjoy this cooking class and demonstration. Menu includes Russian Tea Room Salad; Romanoff's Crab-Stuffed Tomato; Louie's Poached Egg Tribute to Salvador Dali; Russian Tea Room Beef Stroganoff; and Strawberries Romanoff.
Location: Central Market Cooking School, 4001 North Lamar Blvd.

Summary: "Million Dollar Quartet" matinee performed
Description: Tony Award-winning Broadway musical "Million Dollar Quartet" is inspired by the true story of the famed recording session that brought together rock 'n' roll icons Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins for the first and only time.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas softball plays Iowa State
Description: Texas softball hosts the Iowa State Cyclones. Longhorns Kids Club Party is a postgame party for club members. Visit http://www.longhornskidsclub.com to join today. See Bevo's Bargains at TexasSports.com for additional ticket offers and activities.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in this in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Untitled Stories looks at Black-Latino relations
Description: This performance piece tackles relationships between the Black and Latino communities. Through poetry, song and cups (ever seen "Pitch Perfect"?) five artists raise questions about tensions, relationships and history of interactions in an unforgettable performance. A short discussion follows.

Summary: "Million Dollar Quartet" comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description: Tony Award-winning Broadway musical "Million Dollar Quartet" is inspired by the true story of the famed recording session that brought together rock 'n' roll icons Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins for the first and only time.
Location: BPerforming Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Selected drawings from Foundations classes exhibited
Description: Selected drawings from students enrolled in Foundations drawing classes take place this week. Call 512-673-6739 for more information.

Summary: Register for University Extension evening and online classes
Description:
Registration is open for University Extension's summer and fall 2013 evening and online cohort classes.



Registration is always open for a wide range of University Extension (UEX) self-paced online courses. UEX offers more than 50 self-paced online courses that are independent study, allowing up to five months to complete coursework. Register and start self-paced online courses at any time.



UEX courses are drawn from the university's course inventory. UT admission is not required.

Summary: Design VI exhibit announced
Description: Design VI is a comprehensive studio in which students conceptualize the development of a building while considering structural, mechanical, electrical and site integration needs. The exhibit reflects work on the design and development of a new rowing center on Lady Bird Lake in downtown Austin. Call 512-471-0109 for more information.

Summary: Conference on Shifting Conflict Patterns in Africa slated
Description:
Food and water stress, migration and urbanization, and rapid political shifts are reshaping the sociopolitical landscape in Africa, triggering potential conflict and cooperation in response to these changes. This two-day conference examines the drivers of changing conflict patterns in Africa, bringing together policymakers, practitioners, military personnel and scholars.



Co-sponsored by the U.S. Africa Command, the Africa Center for Strategic Studies at the National Defense University and the Army War College Fellowship at UT-Austin.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Participate in Online Nutrition (FEED) study
Description: Mothers and their adolescent children ages 11-14 are invited to participate in a study examining the effect of the home environment on eating behavior and physical activity. Study involves answering two online questionnaires. Participants receive $10 compensation. Email feedstudy@gmail.com and complete the short survey provided in the link below.

Summary: Apply for Rapoport Ctr Working Paper Editorial Committee
Description: The Bernard and Audre Rapoport Center for Human Rights & Justice is accepting applications from UT law and graduate students to become members of the editorial committee for the Rapoport Center Human Rights Working Paper Series. Applications are due by Friday, May 10.
Location: School of Law, Rapoport Center for Human Rights & Justice

Summary: Operation Smile holds silent auction
Description: Operation Smile holds a silent auction with all proceeds funding surgeries for children with cleft lip/palate. Bid on items from: Uchi, Fogo de Chão, AT&T Conference Center, Omni Hotel, Trace, The Melting Pot and much more.

Summary: Game Development info session invites Fine Arts students
Description:
Learn about how Fine Arts students can participate in the Game Development Program, including the Capstone: 2D Games course offered in

the fall. This session is for Fine Arts students from all

three departments.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: Mobility & rootedness in indigenous India is talk topic
Description: Kaushik Ghosh, assistant professor of Anthropology, University of Texas at Austin, presents "The Shimmering Landscape: Mobility and Rootedness in Indigenous India."

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Melissa Byrnes
Description:
Professor Melissa K. Byrnes presents a talk titled "Migration and Municipal Foreign Policy: North Africans in the Suburbs of Paris and Lyon." Byrnes is assistant professor of history at Southwestern University. To RSVP and receive a copy of the pre-circulated paper, email Courtney Meador  by 9 a.m., Friday, April 12.



Burns' research focuses on immigration from North Africa to France in the 20th century. In 2009-2010, she was awarded an ACLS Mellon Doctoral Recipients Fellowship to conduct research in France and work on a book manuscript. She earned an M.A. in history, an M.S. in foreign service and a Ph.D. in history from Georgetown University.

Summary: Environmental Science poster session held
Description: Students in the Environmental Science degree program present their senior research projects and posters to the public. Visit the link below for a full list of topics.

Summary: Game Development Capstone info session held
Description: Learn more about the Game Development certificate in Computer Science and the Capstone: 2D Games course offered in the fall. This session is targeted toward computer science students, though students from other majors are welcome to attend.
Location: Bill & Melinda Gates Computer Science Complex & Dell Computer Science Hall (GDC), 2.104

Summary: University Fellows capstone research talks presented
Description: Students present brief talks on their capstone thesis research for the University Fellows program. Topics range from sustainable agricultural practices and advances in Parkinson's disease research to poverty interventions and the nature of consciousness. For more information, call 512-232-5721.

Summary: CWGS presents New Faculty Colloquium with Kelly McDonough
Description: Kelly McDonough discusses Diego Rivera's "Flower Vendor" (1926) (model: Doña Luz Jiménez), part of the collection of the Honolulu Museum of Art. McDonough is the author of "The Flower Vendor Was Also a Writer: Nahua Intellectualism and the Case of Doña Luz Jiménez." As one of Diego Rivera's favorite models, Jiménez's image has circulated worldwide, yet her early-twentieth-century writings have been overlooked.

Summary: Scholar discusses development of Swedish in America
Description: Benjamin Lyngfelt, University of Gothenburg, presents a talk titled "Swedish in America, Past and Present." Based on linguistic research, Lyngfelt sheds light on how Swedish in the United States today differs from the varieties spoken 50 years ago.

Summary: Country Corners info session features Africa
Description: Learn more about Study Abroad programs in Africa. Listen to advice from peer advisers from the UT Study Abroad Office who have first-hand experience, and get ready to pack your bags for the trip of a lifetime.

Summary: Government honors thesis research presented
Description: Presentations of honors thesis research conducted by Department of Government undergraduates takes place in this session, and one on Tuesday, April 16. For more information about this event, call 720-470-9381.

Summary: Investing for Life is Bevonomics workshop
Description: Learn how to use investments to satisfy your financial goals. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: Panel discusses value of research in the working world
Description: A panel of employers and professors from diverse disciplines discusses the value of undergraduate research experience. Students of all majors are encouraged to attend. An opportunity to network follows the panel discussion. Call 512-471-8294 for more information.

Summary: Asian American Heritage Week announced
Description:
Asian American Heritage Week, hosted by the Asian Desi Pacific Islander American Collective (APAC), is a week-long cultural celebration. Events include Monday 6 p.m. Taste of Asia at Gregory Plaza, Tuesday 7 p.m. Gigglepants at BUR 106, Wednesday 6 p.m. RAISE awards at SAC ballroom, 

Thursday 6 p.m. Alumni Panel and Friday, from 2 p.m., bubble tea and movies at SAC 1.102. See link for details.

Summary: Undergraduate research opportunities at McCombs presented
Description: Learn about different research opportunities available to undergraduates at the McCombs School of Business and share in the research experiences of your peers. Call 512-471-5899 to learn more.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.202

Summary: Theatre for Dialogue & Laura Dannenmaier discuss assault
Description: Attend a discussion and performance on how to support survivors of assault and speak out against rape culture. Free food served.

Summary: Official class ring ceremonies held
Description: One of UT's finest traditions, the ring ceremony is a special way to commemorate your achievements at UT. Ceremonies take place over a three-day period, scheduled alphabetically by last name. Learn more at the link below. Students who are unable attend the ring ceremony can pick up their rings from the Alumni Center from 9 a.m.-4 p.m., starting Thursday, April 18.

Summary: Plant Biology Society presents movie night
Description: The Plant Biology Society hosts a screening of "The Day of the Triffids." Meet at 6 p.m. in front of UTC to walk to Tapioca House for a pre-movie treat.

Summary: France Planning Scholarships info session held
Description: Students who won a Planning Scholarship through the Study Abroad Office or who are interested in studying abroad in France are invited to attend this session. Learn about life, culture and academics in La France, with details about the different study abroad programs offered for the country.

Summary: Riki Ott speaks on energy and democracy
Description:
Riki Ott - a marine toxicologist, author and former commercial fisher - discusses America's energy future, the devastating costs of our fossil-fuel dependency and what ordinary people are doing to create more self-reliant and democratic communities. Ott has written two books on the Exxon Valdez oil spill and was featured in the award-winning documentary film "Black Wave: The Legacy of the Exxon Valdez."



Ott has worked on these issues since she was one of the first people on the scene during the Exxon Valdez oil spill, when millions of gallons of crude oil spilled into Prince William Sound, Alaska. She is the author of "Sound Truth and Corporate Myth$: The Legacy of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill" and "Not One Drop: Promises, Betrayal, and Courage in the Wake of the Exxon Valdez Oil Spill."

Summary: "Man, Economy and Sport" is Mises Circle topic
Description: Are sports just another government institution? From antitrust laws in the NFL to intellectual property laws protecting the Longhorn logo, government entangles itself in the affairs of sports in every way it can, all with economic consequences. Join the Mises Circle to discuss this topic with columnist Skip Oliva, author of the Man, Economy & Sport blog.

Summary: Afren Design Competition announced
Description: Afren and the UT Grand Challenge Scholars Program host the Afren Design Contest for Developing Communities with a $5,000 prize for the winning teams. Apply by April 20 by submitting a research poster or a video of your idea for a sustainable system or product for either developing domestic (U.S.) or international communities. Learn details at the link below.

Summary: Research study on C code debugging seeks participants
Description: The Advanced Research in Software Engineering lab seeks participants for a study on how people debug C code. Basic C understanding needed. Study lasts approximately four hours. Participants will be entered into a drawing. Fill out the form at the link below. Study ends May 1.

Summary: RecSports Poker Walk registration open
Description: Registration is now open for the RecSports Poker Walk, to be held on Wednesday, May 8, beginning at 11:30 a.m. at the South Mall near Parlin Hall (PAR). This annual event celebrates National Employee Health and Fitness Day and is free to all current and retired UT faculty and staff. Participants walk a one-mile course, gathering poker chips along the way. Prizes awarded. Register online now. Sign up solo or with a team. Wear a costume to enter the Best Costume contest.

Summary: Pharmacy Research Excellence Day celebrated
Description:
Systematic inquiry takes center stage as the College of Pharmacy observes its ninth annual Celebrating Pharmacy Research Excellence Day. All events scheduled in conjunction with the day are free and open to the public. Presentations will be open to a global audience via a live-chat function on the web. Learn more at the link below.



The event showcases the research contributions of the college's professional degree students, graduate students and post-doctoral residents and fellows. One student from each of the three research categories, will be cited for excellence and will be invited to make brief oral summaries of his/her work.



Research initiatives by all participating students will be featured at an afternoon poster showcase in the SAC Ballroom. Food and beverages served. For more information about this event, call 512-471-4501.

Summary: Dr. Michael Webber discusses how business looks at energy
Description: In a talk titled "Changing the Way Business Thinks About Energy," Dr. Michael Webber gives a surprising look into the future of energy with an entertaining and big-picture overview of global energy trends mixed in with humorous anecdotes, historical snippets and a focus on the business opportunities that are emerging amid shifting philosophies in the business sector.

Summary: Urban resilience & climate challenges in Africa discussed
Description:
Students in Dr. Robert Wilson's Policy Research Project course at the LBJ School of Public Affairs present findings from field research on the capacity of local governments in Africa to respond to the impacts of climate change. 



Students traveled to select African cities - including Accra, Ghana; Alexandria, Egypt; Cape Town, South Africa; Casablanca, Morocco; Dakar, Senegal; Dar es Salaam, Tanzania; Kampala, Uganda; Luanda, Angola; and Maputo, Mozambique - to conduct field research in order to identify the factors that explain the variation in capacity across different types of disaster reduction and mitigation systems and across metropolitan areas.

Summary: Binge drinking research showcased
Description: Students in the Department of Advertising and Public Relations Research Club showcase their commitment to research and share their experiences about research done on binge drinking in a presentation for students and faculty members. Call 281-513-5820 for more information.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), first floor lobby

Summary: D.T. Max discusses researching David Foster Wallace
Description: D.T. Max, a staff writer for the New Yorker magazine, discusses his research in the David Foster Wallace archive at the Harry Ransom Center. The research Max conducted at the HRC was essential to completing his new book, a biography of Wallace titled "Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story: A Life of David Foster Wallace." Call 512-471-5692 for more information.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Mosley Room (3rd floor)

Summary: Bridging Disciplines poster session announced
Description: Attend a poster session presented by students in the Bridging Disciplines Programs. Students showcase work they have done through internship and research Connecting Experiences.

Summary: Ally Toolkit open training held
Description: Attend an open information session on how to ally yourself with the LGBTQ community.

Summary: Final Advise TX College Advising Corps info session held
Description: Advise TX seeks recent UT graduates (Dec. 2012, May 2013) to serve as college advisers in low-income high schools in Austin, San Antonio, Corpus Christi, El Paso and the Rio Grande Valley. Advisers help high school students realize their dream of attending college by assisting with college admissions, financial aid and scholarship applications. Learn more at this meeting.

Summary: Research in Motion hosted by Liberal Arts Council
Description: Undergraduate students in the College of Liberal Arts present their research at the annual Research in Motion event, hosted by the Liberal Arts Council. Food served.

Summary: Engineering honors thesis pizza & info session held
Description: Attend a pizza and information session about the engineering honors thesis. Learn about the process and procedures involved, and hear from current and former students who have completed a thesis, followed by a Q&A. For more information, call 512-232-9446.

Summary: School of Undergraduate Studies presents Magellan Circle
Description: The Magellan Circles give UGS students the chance to meet professionals and gain insight about their fields of interest. At this circle, meet venture capitalist Dr. Philip Sanger, who worked as a pulmonary and critical care specialist for over 25 years and supports healthcare entrepreneurs. RSVP required; visit the link below.

Summary: Daniel Marcos Gomez, saxophonist, presents doctoral recital
Description: Daniel Marcos Gomez performs his final recital at The University of Texas, presenting works on saxophone by Giacinto Scelsi, David Diamond, Jules Demersseman and Johannes Brahms. Music from the West, and some inspired from the East, featuring collaborative pianist Michael Bunchman.

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major who have an interest in pursuing a career in the commercial real estate industry. Register to attend at link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.20

Summary: Country Corners features Western Europe, Scandinavia
Description: Learn about Study Abroad programs in Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Ireland, Italy, Greece, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Sweden, Switzerland and the UK at this edition of Country Corners.

Summary: Latino-Jewish panel slated
Description: The Latino-Jewish Student Coalition hosts a panel on the importance of creating a relationship between the Latino and Jewish communities. Panelists include Dr. Amelia Weinreb, anthropology and Jewish studies; Eli Levine, managing director of Hasbara Fellowships; Mack Hernandez, local attorney; and Elizabeth Anderson, UT student. Pizza and snacks served.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: Forgotten victims of America's drones are theme of rally
Description: Amnesty International hosts an event to raise awareness about American drone strikes abroad. Hear speakers discuss the human rights violations of drone victims, listen to slam poetry and learn about the human costs of war.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on UT Pan-American
Description: Texas baseball hosts UT Pan-American. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Visual Arts Center presents "Screening Room" episode
Description: "Screening Room," a 1970s television series that aired in Boston, invited independent filmmakers to screen and discuss their work on a commercial affiliate station. This episode features Robert Breer, an animator known for his films exploring shape, color, perspective and motion.

Summary: Anna's Yoga Workshop provides stress relief
Description: Stressed or feeling down? Need a relaxer? Reach a new level of harmony and fitness yourself through yoga. Workshops are open to participants of any skill level.

Summary: Honors thesis symposium held
Description: Students in the Honors Thesis Program in Government present their theses in two consecutive sessions, and take questions from professors and peers. For more information, please call 512-232-7246.

Summary: UT Early Music Ensemble, "Austinato," performs
Description: The UT Early Music Ensemble, "Austinato," presents "Of Gods and Men: From the 'Divine' Corelli to the 'Almighty Jupiter'." Listen to music featuring the divine beauty of love and jealousy, a prayer to Jupiter and the celebrated violin sonatas by Arcangelo Corelli, "il divino" in a concert featuring works by A. Scarlatti, G.F. Handel, N. Porpora, T. Albinoni and A. Corelli.

Summary: New Yorker writer D.T. Max discusses David Foster Wallace
Description: Though only 46 when he died, David Foster Wallace left an enormous legacy of literature, including novels, short stories and nonfiction. Writer D.T. Max discusses his fascinating new biography on Wallace, "Every Love Story Is a Ghost Story: A Life of David Foster Wallace," much of it researched in the Wallace archives housed at UT's Ransom Center.

Summary: Alison Balsom, trumpet, performs with Scottish Ensemble
Description: Virtuoso trumpeter Alison Balsom joins the versatile and ambitious chamber music outfit, The Scottish Ensemble, for an elegant evening of classical bliss.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Shawn Mullins plays two shows at the Cactus
Description: Shawn Mullins displays a newfound level of musical and lyrical ambition in new material on "Light You Up," released last October. This captivating new song cycle is among the music featured in two nights of Cactus shows.

Summary: Learn about the Texas State Employees Union
Description: The Texas State Employees Union visits campus with an information and sign-up table. The union seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions of all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at UT Austin. The union advocates across-the-board flat-amount pay raises and opposes all attempts to remove long-standing protections against arbitrary cuts in benefits.

Summary: TEDMED Live comes to The University of Texas at Austin
Description: TEDMED is where the world's most creative minds meet to discuss healthcare's most innovative science. Speakers include global leaders from science, research, technology, academia, business, government and the arts.

Summary: Longhorn Research Bazaar announced
Description: The Longhorn Research Bazaar is a festive event where colleges, departments, research units, programs and student organizations from across campus provide information for students about their undergraduate research activities and opportunities. Refreshments and free t-shirts provided. For more information about this event, call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Centennial pharmacy fellow discusses the promise of viruses
Description: Dr. Maria Croyle, Ph.D., the Alan W. Hamm centennial fellow in pharmacy, presents "Viruses: Smart Biologicals of the Twenty-First Century, How They Can Obliterate Dangerous Pathogens and Help Us Understand Physiological Processes."
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Libraries Fair 2013 takes place during Research Week
Description:
Ten campus library branches converge to provide a one-stop opportunity for students to drop by and learn about resources and services available to them across campus. Staff from the branch libraries, and from UT Libraries service divisions will be on hand to answer questions and raise awareness of library resources. Booths will feature contests, prizes and treats.



For the first time, the Libraries are joined by campus partners, including the Harry Ransom Center, the Dolph Briscoe Center for American History and the H.J. Lutcher Stark Center for Physical Culture and Sports, as well as by typewriter poet Jena Kirkpatrick, promoting the April 19 screening of "The Typewriter (in the 21st Century)" at the Fine Arts Library.

Summary: Student presents CMAS graduate portfolio plática
Description:
In this portfolio plática, Milagros Lopez discusses Project MALES research on the Latino male gender gap in post-secondary education, which has led to the establishment of a statewide initiative for male student success.



Lopez is a second-year Master of Education degree student in the Department of Educational Administration with a Graduate Portfolio in Mexican American Studies. Her project supervisor is Victor B. Saenz, assistant professor in the Department of Educational Administration.

Summary: Drug-development crisis is pharmacy research talk topic
Description: Dr. Leslie Z. Benet, professor of biopharmaceutical sciences and pharmaceutical chemistry, University of California, San Francisco, presents "Will the New Solutions for the Drug Development Crisis Be Any More Effective Than the Combinatorial Chemistry Failure?"

Summary: Explore world-changing research conducted at Pickle campus
Description: Undergraduate students discuss their role in groundbreaking research with UT Pickle Research Campus groups. View their work at the TACC/ACES Visualization Lab, which houses one of the world's highest resolution tiled displays; and learn about future research opportunities in multiple fields on the PRC campus. For more information about this event, call 512-475-9411.

Summary: UT Austin "Assessment Dialogue" held
Description: Assessment is a hot topic in higher education. Faculty members, staff and students are invited to participate in the UT Austin "Assessment Dialogue" to highlight the value and range of assessment knowledge and activities across campus and share innovations. View schedule at link below.

Summary: Celebrating Pharmacy Research Excellence posters presented
Description: Celebrating Pharmacy Research Excellence presents academic posters featuring research activities of students in the pharmacy professional degree program, the graduate program and the residency/postgraduate program.

Summary: Undergraduate Art History Research Symposium held
Description: The Department of Art and Art History presents the first ever Undergraduate Art History Research Symposium, featuring papers by art history majors currently writing a senior thesis or engaged in advanced research on an art historical topic. This event is part of Undergraduate Research Week 2013.

Summary: Tongue twisters are strategy to teach Yoruba
Description: The Language Matters Series presents a talk by Fehintola Mosadomi, "Tongue Twisters: An Effective Strategy for Teaching Yoruba with an Open Access Text."

Summary: Asian studies honors theses presented
Description: Honors students in Asian Studies give brief presentations on their thesis projects followed by a Q&A.

Summary: Women's & Gender Studies holds pizza & open house event
Description: As part of Research Week, join the Center for Women's and Gender Studies (WGS) to socialize and meet students who are currently working on a thesis in WGS or other research. RSVP by noon on April 15 at http://bit.ly/wgspizza. Call 512-475-7858 for more information.

Summary: Capitalizing on employee benefits is Bevonomics topic
Description: Learn about 401(k) plans and other benefits your future employer may offer. Funded in part by a grant from the Investor Protection Trust, www.investorprotection.org.

Summary: What's the (B)? Open training on bisexuality held
Description: An open training is offered on the nuances, realities and myths of bisexuality.

Summary: Social justice & ecological sustainability is talk topic
Description:
Dr. Robert Jensen, professor of journalism in the College of Communication, presents a talk titled "Social Justice and Ecological Sustainability." Presented by the Leadership Series, a series of workshops designed to develop both individual student leaders as well as provide resources for growth and change for student organizations.

 

For more information about this event, call 512-232-2831.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Governors' Room 3.116

Summary: Graduate school preparation is panel topic
Description: The Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence presents a seminar titled "Graduate School Preparation & Panel Discussion." Contact Charles Lu at charleslu2002@gmail.com with questions.

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter.

Summary: Texas men's tennis plays Baylor
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor Baylor. Support your Longhorns as they face the Bears.

Summary: "Research Stories" presented at School of Social Work
Description: The School of Social Work and the Social Work Council jointly "Research Stories", a panel presentation by invited faculty and students who share stories of how they became involved in their current research. Refreshments provided. For more information, call 512-471-2364.

Summary: Health at Every Size movement is speaker's topic
Description: Guest speaker Ragen Chastain is the author of the popular blog, danceswithfat.wordpress.com, which promotes the Health at Every Size movement and challenges the thin ideal. Chastain presents a talk on the movement is part of the Love Your Body Campaign to promote positive body image. If you need accommodations for this event, please contact Traci at t.toone@uhs.utexas.edu.

Summary: Trans-Pacific China and the Cold War conference slated
Description: A conference titled "Trans-Pacific China and the Cold War" is to be convened by Dr. Madeline Y. Hsu, associate professor of history and director of the Center for Asian Studies, UT Austin, and Dr. Poshek Fu, professor of history, University of Illinois at Urbana-Champagne. This conference is part of the multidisciplinary 'Reinventing Diplomacy' program.

Summary: Healthy adults over 60 sought for sleep & memory study
Description:
The Learning and Memory Lab seeks participants ages 60-80 who are in good general health to participate in an MRI study of sleep and memory. The study consists of two sessions and the continuous wearing of a small wristwatch device that measures your sleep/wake activity for 10 days. Contact us at UTagingstudy@gmail.com or 512-232-7830.



The first session (one hour) includes questionnaires and behavioral tasks. The second session (two hours) includes functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Your participation could help further our understanding of how age-related changes in sleep affect memory performance.

Summary: Handmade Jewelry Trunk Show comes to Blanton's Museum Shop
Description: Looking for the perfect Mother's Day or Graduation gift? Don't miss the Museum Shop's annual Handmade Jewelry Trunk Show.

Summary: UCAR president Tom Bogdan gives talk
Description: The Center for Integrated Earth System Science presents a conversation with University Corporation for Atmospheric Research (UCAR) president Tom Bogdan.

Summary: Lab of Image & Video Engineering seeks study participants
Description: The Laboratory of Image and Video Engineering seeks participants for a study on the viewing experience of users when videos are watched on handheld devices. Participants earn $20 for their participation. Sign up at ENS 430 for three slots. Call 512-949-9169 with questions or scheduling problems.

Summary: Get tips on publishing research and writing abstracts
Description: At this seminar, undergraduates learn strategies for writing abstracts and hear about an opportunity to get their work published through the Undergraduate Awards. For more information, call 512-475-8143.

Summary: IE Citizen Scholars Research Contest announced
Description: Intellectual Entrepreneurship hosts the second annual Citizen Scholars Research Contest for all current and former IE undergraduate interns. Prizes will be given to the 1st, 2nd and 3rd places in each category. An overall grand winner will be chosen as well.

Summary: Future of the newspaper industry discussed in talk
Description: Professor Amy Reynolds, Louisiana State University, presents "The Digital Push and the Future of the Newspaper Industry" at an informal brown-bag seminar.

Summary: UT Staff Toastmasters holds open house
Description: University staff members are invited to attend this week's Toastmasters meeting. Founded in 1924, Toastmasters International helps people become more competent and comfortable speaking in front of an audience. Membership is limited to current and retired University of Texas staff.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Legislative Assembly Room 2.302

Summary: Pre-Columbian Art in "Through the Eyes of Texas" explored
Description: Associate Professor of Art Julia Guernsey leads a gallery talk on pre-Columbian art in the exhibition "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections."

Summary: Border delegation report-back held
Description:
On January 18-20, Austin Tan Cerca de la Frontera (ATCF, Austin So Close to the Border) organized a delegation to visit workers and activists in Ciudad Acuña, Mexico. Hear from delegation members about the lives and struggles of these workers, and see photos from their recent trip.



ATCF seeks to address conditions of social and economic injustice along the Texas/Mexico border particularly as they affect women and communities of color, and to find community-driven alternatives through transnational solidarity and fair trade. We believe that our environment, our communities and human dignity are sacred and must be respected in the movement for social justice.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: IPSF Blood Drive held
Description: The UT Academy of Student Pharmacists sponsors a blood drive in Speedway Plaza. Donate and save a life.

Summary: Volunteer with the Women's Leadership Institute
Description: Learn how you can volunteer for an exciting summer institute at an information session. New Leadership Texas (NEWLT) is a nonpartisan intensive residential program that educates college women about politics and policy-making and inspires them to get involved in the political process.

Summary: Staff Council holds monthly meeting
Description: The monthly meeting of the Staff Council is open to all staff and all are encouraged to attend.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Filmmaker screens excerpts from work on Mexican violence
Description: Documentary filmmaker Charlie Minn discusses the drug-related violence that has tragically murdered over 100,000 people in Mexico since 2006, when former president Felipe Calderon declared war on the drug cartels. The talk includes video clips from Minn's trilogy about the drug-related violence in Ciudad Juarez, Mexico.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Rachel Weiss
Description: Rachel Weiss discusses "Lupe at the Mic."
