At a 2009 performance in Havana, Tania Bruguera installed a microphone on the patio of the Wifredo Lam Center and invited people to speak, unfiltered, for a minute each. Among those who took her up on her offer was famed dissident blogger Yoani Sanchez, making the piece an instant scandal. Weiss is professor of Arts Administration and Policy at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

Summary: Power Up Research presents keynote by President Powers
Description: President Bill Powers gives a keynote speech on the importance and benefits of undergraduate research. Event includes a panel of award-winning faculty researchers who have worked with undergraduates, and a Q/A. Call 832-330-4889 to learn more.

Summary: Blanton's Third Thursday is evening of art & activities
Description: Attend the Blanton's free evening of art and activities, featuring music by Graham Reynolds (5:30 p.m.), Art Gazes with Paul Bolin (6 p.m., a gallery talk featuring slow, contemplative conversations about art in the collection); Yoga in the Galleries (6:30 p.m. passes given out at 5:30); Art Glimpses (7 p.m., a fast-paced tour of current exhibit); docent-led tour (7:30 p.m.).

Summary: Women Leading Locally features city and county officials
Description: Women Leading Locally is a discussion with City of Austin and Travis County elected officials featuring County Constable, Precinct 4, Maria Canchola; Mayor Pro Tem Sheryl Cole; and County Commissioner, Precinct 2, Sarah Eckhardt. Come to learn about what these outstanding panelists do and why they do it. Event includes dinner.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), LBJ School of Public Affairs, 3.124

Summary: Energy Open House and Networking event held
Description: The Energy Institute invites students and faculty to a networking event on the latest news in energy research and teaching on campus. Pizza served.

Summary: String chamber music concert presented
Description: Attend a concert featuring a variety of classical music for string instruments. Students work in small ensembles, with faculty guidance, for this culminating concert of the semester. For more information about this event, call 512-471-5496.

Summary: "Growing Seeds of Peace" book signing, photo exhibit held
Description: Dr. Martha Ann Kirk discusses her recent book, "Growing Seeds of Peace," containing stories and images from Southeastern Turkey, where the Gulen Institute has worked at rebuilding and educating in an area where more than 40,000 were killed, thousands were wounded and millions fled from their homes since the mid-1980s.

Summary: Meet and greet local jewelry designers at Museum Shop
Description: Join the Blanton Museum Shop for a meet and greet with local jewelers Adaptive Reuse, M Squared Jewelry by Mae Mae Stiles, Son of Sailor and Tasty Jewelry. Shop for unique, handcrafted jewelry as you chat with the designers. Refreshments served. This special event is part of the Blanton Museum Shop's Handmade Jewelry Trunk Show.

Summary: University Elohim Fellowship discusses God's true church
Description: What Is the Sign of God's True Church? Two thousand years ago Jesus preached one gospel and established one church. Today, however, many different churches claim that they are the church that Christ established. Then how can we know which church is God's true church? Join us to learn through the Bible "What Is the Sign of God's True Church?" Email UEFellowship2012@gmail.com for more information.

Summary: Formula Society of Automotive Engineers presents lecture
Description: The Formula Society of Automobile Engineers presents an exciting engineering lecture from one of Red Bull's own MotoGP engineers: 1000cc's. 200mph. 1 racer. Learn how the fastest sport on two wheels is engineered.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), amphitheater 204

Summary: Lecture looks at Commentary magazine in the 1960s
Description:
Author Morris Dickstein presents the lecture "America's Best Magazine?: Commentary in the 1960s." The Commentary archive resides at the Ransom Center and includes correspondence with Norman Mailer, Bernard Malamud, James Baldwin and Elie Wiesel.



Founded in 1945 as a monthly journal of general interest from within the Jewish community, Commentary went through a dramatic shift in 1960 under its new editor, Norman Podhoretz, who applied more rigorous critical standards and made greater use of strong-minded New York intellectuals such as Irving Howe, Alfred Kazin and Mailer. The magazine responded to all the major controversies of the decade, from the Eichmann trial and the civil rights movement to the Vietnam War and the Columbia student uprising. 



Dickstein is Distinguished Professor of English and Theatre at the CUNY Graduate Center. 



View a live webcast of this program at www.hrc.utexas.edu/webcast.



The Albert and Ethel Herzstein Charitable Foundation made a generous donation to support this program and the cataloging of the Commentary magazine archive.

Summary: RTF Community Screening presents "A Shock to the System"
Description: Mid-Life Crisis Goes to the Movies: How do we respond when our lives don't turn out as we had planned? In the darkly comic "Shock to the System" (1990), the irrepressible Michael Caine plays a mid-level advertising exec who is jolted into taking stock of his life when his long-anticipated promotion goes to someone else. Associate professor and screenwriting area head Richard Lewis discusses this and other cinematic midlife crises.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), auditorium

Summary: Theatre for Dialogue presents "Get Sexy, Get Consent"
Description: This interactive theater performance is co-sponsored by the Queer Students Alliance as part of Pride Week. Cupcakes provided.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Chicano Culture Room 4.206

Summary: Uneasy Money: Panel discusses payday and auto-title loans
Description: "Uneasy Money: Reforming Texas' Payday and Auto-Title Loan Industry" is a panel discussion on efforts to break the cycle of debt. Panelists include state Rep. Mike Villarreal; Chad Chaddick, pastor of Northeast Baptist Church; Ann Baddour of Texas Appleseed; and Rob Norcross (tentative) of the Consumer Service Alliance.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH) 3.122, LBJ School of Public Affairs

Summary: "Meter-morphosis" is Collegium Musicum's spring concert
Description: Collegium Musicum, directed by Matt Jackfert and assistant director Phillip Bernard, presents two performances of its spring concert of a cappella works from all over the world. Thursday's concert takes place at the Congregational Church and Friday's at St. Mark's Lutheran (see addresses below).
Location: Congregational Church of Austin (23rd & San Antonio) St.; St. Martin's Lutheran (W. 15th & Nueces)

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: "Dream of Perfect Sleep" is play by Kevin Kautzman
Description: When the grown children of an elderly and ailing couple return to a home decorated for the holidays - and it's not the holidays - the family must make a hard decision about what it means to exit this world with grace. Playwright Kevin Kautzman is pursuing his MFA at the Michener Center.

Summary: Tejas Coffee features The Ransom Notes
Description: UT's premier a capella group, The Ransom Notes, performs at The Tejas Club's weekly Coffee Social. Enjoy an informal gathering with your peers and this very talented group. Refreshments provided.

Summary: "Energy at the Movies" presented by Dr. Michael Webber
Description:
From the gushing geysers of "Giant" to the plutonium-powered time machine of "Back to the Future," Hollywood has entertained us with unforgettable, often iconic images of energy. In this broadcast, energy expert and Cockrell School of Engineering professor Dr. Michael E. Webber explores 70 years of energy on the big screen. Visit http://www.klru.org/schedule/program/19633.



"Energy at the Movies" is presented with additional support from the American Clean Skies Foundation and AMD. It was taped before a live audience in the historic Austin City Limits Studio 6A at KLRU TV, Austin PBS.

Summary: CMAS hosts spring 2013 symposium
Description: The Center for Mexican American Studies is proud to announce a public symposium, "The Mexican American Archival Enterprise at the Benson Latin American Collection: An Historical Appraisal," examining the contributions of the Mexican American and Latin@ resources found in the Nettie Lee Benson Latin American Collection.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection, 2nd floor conf. room

Summary: Undergraduate science research info session held
Description: Representatives of the Office of Undergraduate Research answer questions and discuss strategies for getting involved in research at UT Austin. Although this session focuses on science, material presented at the general and science sessions is similar in nature, so you only need attend one session. Sign up at the link below. Call 512-471-5949 for more information.

Summary: Texas Ballroom presents The Austin Open
Description: The Austin Open is a dance competition where dancers from around the state come to compete to be the best in their respective dance category. Dances include ballroom styles such as waltz, tango and foxtrot, and social dances such as salsa, two-step, and East Coast swing, to name a few. Spectators enter for free.

Summary: Register for Survival Spanish course
Description:
Registration is now open for Survival Spanish for Travelers, taught from May 20-21 by the university's Professional Development Center (PDC). This intensive two-day course provides a quick yet thorough program for travelers, students and businesspeople who need to master key Spanish speaking skills - fast. 



The program stresses key vocabulary and phrases used in everyday conversations, with pronunciation exercises to ensure your accuracy. Acquire a solid foundation of phrases and terms that will have you speaking basic Spanish in no time.

Summary: Students compete to shape ideas into products
Description: The Idea to Product's UT Competition is an early-stage technology commercialization plan competition hosted by the Idea to Product Program in the Cockrell School of Engineering in which students create links between emerging technologies and market needs required to support later stages of commercialization.
Location: Applied Engineering and Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Handmade Jewelry Trunk Show comes to Blanton's Museum Shop
Description: Looking for the perfect Mother's Day or Graduation gift? Don't miss the Museum Shop's annual Handmade Jewelry Trunk Show.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Dave Stephens, McGill U.
Description: The Division of Statistics and Scientific Computation presents Professor Dave Stephens of McGill University, with a talk titled "Bayesian Approaches to Causal Inference: A Lack of Success Story."

Summary: Undergraduate Poster Exhibition Competition announced
Description: The Student Engineering Council (SEC) Poster Exhibition Committee proudly presents the 2013 Undergraduate Poster Exhibition. All students, faculty and staff are encouraged to support talented undergrads as they present their research to a panel of judges. Email poster@sec.engr.utexas.edu with questions.

Summary: Classroom cheating is workshop topic
Description: The Center for Teaching and Learning hosts a workshop for faculty on cheating. Do you know what are the most common forms of cheating at UT? Would you like to learn how to reduce the likelihood of cheating or how to solve a recurring cheating problem? This interactive, group-facilitated discussion invites participants to share challenges and compare notes with colleagues.

Summary: MEC Cinema presents Oscar-winning short "Inocente"
Description: MEC Cinema of the Multicultural Engagement Center presents a screening of the Oscar-winning short "Inocente." Screening to be followed by a discussion about the film, education and immigration as a human rights concern.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: Undergraduate general research info session held
Description: Representatives of the Office of Undergraduate Research answer questions and talk about strategies for getting involved in research at UT Austin. Material presented at the general and science sessions is similar in nature, so you only need attend one session. Visit the link below to sign up. For more information, call 512-471-5949.

Summary: Population Research Center presents Cynthia Osborne
Description: Cynthia Osborne, LBJ School, gives a talk titled "Family Instability, Multipartner Fertility, and Behavior in Middle Childhood."

Summary: Gender Symposium looks at 1968 hunger documentary
Description:
Based on her work in progress "The Discovery of Hunger in America: The Politics of Race, Poverty, and Malnutrition After the Fall of Jim Crow," Professor Laurie Green presents and discusses the prize-winning CBS television documentary "Hunger in America," directed by Martin Carr and Peter Davis, which is screened at this event.



First aired in the globally tumultuous month of May 1968, the broadcast drew more attention and provoked more controversy than had any television documentary to date. Reactions included college students deciding to volunteer in the antipoverty movement, viewers sending money and food to mothers and children interviewed in the program, and congressmen denouncing the film and initiating investigations by FBI officials and the Federal Communications Commission into its veracity.

Summary: Britain's refugee camps are scholar's topic
Description: In the decades after the Second World War, the British created resettlement camps for Poles and Hungarians in the 1950s, Ugandan Asians in the 1970s and Vietnamese refugees in the 1980s. Jordanna Bailkin, professor of European history at the University of Washington, discusses what these camps reveal about Britain in the latter half of the 20th century.
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Gender & violence in historical Greece & India compared
Description:
Dr. Florence Pasche Guignard presents "Gender and Violence in Religious Contexts: Differential Comparisons of Ancient Greece and Early Modern India." A 3 p.m. reception precedes talk.



Guignard presents an analysis of selected examples from literary sources of Ancient Greece (Aeschylus, Euripides, Plutarchus) and from a devotional and hagiographic tradition of early modern Northern India (poetry attributed to Mirabai) through differential comparison, highlighting the diversity of scenarios featuring violence against female figures in a religious context.

Summary: Texas softball plays Oklahoma
Description: Texas softball hosts Big 12 Conference rival Oklahoma Sooners. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities that will be taking place.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meet
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: "The Typewriter (in the 21st Century)" screened
Description:
The Fine Arts Library premieres "The Typewriter in the 21st Century," a documentary about a machine and the people who use, love and repair it. 



Filmmakers Christopher Lockett and Gary Nicholson interview authors, collectors, journalists, professors, bloggers, students, artists, inventors and repairmen (and women) who meet up for 'Type-In' gatherings to both celebrate and use their decidedly low-tech typewriters in a plugged-in world.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Fine Arts Library 3.200

Summary: Helping Hornz presents "The Lion King"
Description: Helping Hornz presents a performance of "The Lion King" featuring the children on Ridgetop Elementary School. An established student service organization at UT since 2010, Helping Hornz has a mentoring partnership with Ridgetop, a local AISD school where about 30 of our members mentor children on a regular basis. In addition to Friday and Saturday evening shows, there is a Sunday matinee at 12 noon.
Location: Ridgetop Elementary School, Caswell Ave Austin, TX 78751

Summary: Texas baseball plays West Virginia
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor, the West Virginia Mountaineers. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: "Untitled" is exhibit and sale of student art
Description: "Untitled" is a one-night exhibit and sale of student artwork. Enjoy a night of art, featuring a DJ, photo booth and more.

Summary: Japanese Association host Golden Week Festival
Description: The Japanese Association holds its annual Golden Week Festival. Enjoy performances, games and great Japanese food with friends and family.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents "Roots and Wings"
Description: UT's award-winning ensemble Dance Repertory Theatre takes flight with "Roots and Wings," a showcase of exciting new dance works and re-staged masterpieces by nationally and internationally acclaimed guest artists and faculty. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "70 Secrets of Marmalade Kittens" presented by UTNT
Description: In this play by Gabrielle Reisman, Quinn wrestles with abandoning her husband, her young children and their lonely life on an Iowa hog confinement farm. Ten years later, her now-grown children must choose between selling off their father's business and tracking down the ghosts of their mother's desires. UTNT (UT New Theatre) presents newly developed work of emerging playwrights.

Summary: Cheryl Wheeler plays the Cactus
Description: Singer-songwriter Cheryl Wheeler has to be seen to be appreciated. Her performances include many unrecorded songs, and her humor delights audiences.

Summary: UT Sailing Club announces Saturday Sail
Description: Join the UT Sailing Club (UTSC) for a Saturday sail on Lake Travis. UTSC is a no-experience-necessary recreational sailing club with a variety of boats ranging from sunfish and lasers to a J/24. Meet to carpool. Bring multiple layers, water, lunch and sunscreen.
Location: Carpool meets at 27th St. & Wichita surface parking lot

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday at UT's first student-run sustainable farm.  All ages and skill levels invited. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Cochlear Implant Kids Day announced
Description: On Cochlear Implant Kids Day, children with cochlear implants and their families are invited to campus for a day of fun activities. This event offers an opportunity for the kids to meet peers with cochlear implants as well as a chance for families to connect and build support. RSVP to ut.cikd@gmail.com.

Summary: "A Perfect Robot": UTNT presents free reading of play
Description: "A Perfect Robot" is a play about robots and octopi, consciousness and programming, passwords and ghosts by Michener fellow Sarah Saltwick. It will be read onstage, with tickets distributed beginning at 10 a.m. at the LAB box office.

Summary: Free Minds tours "Arnold Newman: Masterclass"
Description:
Join the Free Minds Project for a special tour and discussion of the Harry Ransom Center's new exhibit, "Arnold Newman:  Masterclass," led by arts educator Margaret Burke. RSVP at 512-232-6093 or freeminds@ausin.utexas.edu.



Post-World War II, Newman was formulating a new approach to portraiture, capturing iconic subjects like Pablo Picasso, Marilyn Monroe and Mickey Mantle in their own environments. Through this trademark style, Newman created works of lasting cultural resonance.

Summary: EGaDS and TeSPA hold Play Away Game Day
Description: The Electronic Game Developers Society teams up with Texas eSports Association to hold their first joint console and board game event. Games such as Munchkin, Street Fighter, Settlers of Catan and many more will be available.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents "Roots and Wings" matinee
Description: UT's award-winning ensemble Dance Repertory Theatre takes flight with "Roots and Wings," a showcase of exciting new dance works and re-staged masterpieces by nationally and internationally acclaimed guest artists and faculty. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "70 Secrets of Marmalade Kittens" presented by UTNT
Description: In this play by Gabrielle Reisman, Quinn wrestles with abandoning her husband, her young children and their lonely life on an Iowa hog confinement farm. Ten years later, her now-grown children must choose between selling off their father's business and tracking down the ghosts of their mother's desires. UTNT (UT New Theatre) presents newly developed work of emerging playwrights.

Summary: Texas baseball plays West Virginia
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor the West Virginia Mountaineers. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Jump Cut Film Festival announced
Description: The 14th annual Jump Cut Film Festival features short student films and distinguished guest panelists from the film industry. A filmmakers' mixer takes place following the screening at the Texas Chilli Parlor, 1409 Lavaca Street. Learn more at the link below.
Location: Alamo Drafthouse The Ritz, 320 E. 6th St.

Summary: A Prairie Home Companion comes to Bass Concert Hall
Description: Attend a live National Public Radio broadcast of A Prairie Home Companion created and hosted by Garrison Keillor. America's beloved live radio variety show broadcast from the Fitzgerald Theater in Saint Paul, Minnesota, frequently goes on tour. Airing locally on KUT 90.5 from 5-7 p.m. Saturdays, the show is known for its musical guests, especially folk and traditional musicians, tongue-in-cheek radio drama and Keillor's storytelling segment, "News from Lake Wobegon."
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Texas softball takes on Oklahoma
Description: Texas softball hosts Big 12 Conference rival the Oklahoma Sooners. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities that will be taking place.

Summary: Middle Eastern Ensemble performs
Description: The Middle Eastern Ensemble performs. Call 512-471-5496 for more information.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents "Roots and Wings"
Description: UT's award-winning ensemble Dance Repertory Theatre takes flight with "Roots and Wings," a showcase of exciting new dance works and re-staged masterpieces by nationally and internationally acclaimed guest artists and faculty. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "The Kingdom": Play examines priest's loss of faith
Description: In this play by Andrew Hinderaker, a Catholic priest of 22 years has stopped taking confession. He has stopped delivering mass. Hiding out in the basement of his church, he seeks to perform miracles of his own making. What becomes of a priest who has lost his faith in us all? "The Kingdom" is performed as part of a series of new plays this spring.

Summary: Kinsolving Garden Work Day held
Description: Students, faculty and staff are invited to the Kinsolving Garden to get their hands dirty and learn the basics of gardening. The Kinsolving Garden is located on the dining hall patio. This is a come-and-go event.

Summary: Sunday Math Circle explores roots and symmetry
Description: The Sunday Math Circle presents "Roots and Symmetries," a talk led by Hendrik Orem of UT Austin. The talk is open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: Texas baseball plays West Virginia
Description: Texas baseball hosts BIG 12 competitor the West Virginia Mountaineers. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Texas men's tennis plays Texas Tech
Description: Texas men's tennis takes on Big 12 competitor Texas Tech. Support your Longhorns as they face the Red Raiders.

Summary: Dance Repertory Theatre presents "Roots and Wings" matinee
Description: UT's award-winning ensemble Dance Repertory Theatre takes flight with "Roots and Wings," a showcase of exciting new dance works and re-staged masterpieces by nationally and internationally acclaimed guest artists and faculty. Subscription Series packages are now on sale for 20 percent savings and the best seats.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), B. Iden Payne Theatre

Summary: "Dream of Perfect Sleep" is play by Kevin Kautzman
Description: When the grown children of an elderly and ailing couple return to a home decorated for the holidays - and it's not the holidays - the family must make a hard decision about what it means to exit this world with grace. Playwright Kevin Kautzman is pursuing his MFA at the Michener Center.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Texas softball faces Oklahoma
Description: Texas softball hosts Big 12 Conference rival the Oklahoma Sooners. See Bevo's Bargains at texassports.com for additional ticket offers and activities that will be taking place.

Summary: Combined UT Men's & Women's Chorus presents spring concert
Description: The UT Men and Women's Chorus presents a spring concert program of Brahms and Beethoven, spirituals and traditional American music. The UT Women's Chorus performs under the direction of Steven Brennfleck; the UT Men's Chorus is under the direction of Chris Larsen.

Summary: "The Kingdom": Play examines priest's loss of faith
Description: In this play by Andrew Hinderaker, a Catholic priest of 22 years has stopped taking confession. He has stopped delivering mass. Hiding out in the basement of his church, he seeks to perform miracles of his own making. What becomes of a priest who has lost his faith in us all? "The Kingdom" is performed as part of a series of new plays this spring.

Summary: Sign up for Hunger & Homelessness Outreach volunteerathon
Description: Join Hunger and Homelessness Outreach (H2O) on Saturday, April 27, 8:30 a.m.-noon, for a day of volunteering with three agencies around the Austin area that work hard to help ease the burden of hunger and homelessness. Locations are Micah 6 food bank, UUMC Open Door hot lunch program or Posada Esperanza transitional housing program. Learn more and sign up at the link below.
Location: Sign up online; event meets at Littlefield Fountain at 8:30 a.m.

Summary: HRSAC Human Rights Fair  held
Description: Human rights student groups on campus collaborate to host the Human Rights Student Advisory Council (HRSAC) Human Rights Fair, promoting the common cause of human rights awareness and advocacy. The event will feature booths for each student organization present with activities. Free pizza and drinks provided.

Summary: Earth Day Carnival celebrates sustainability
Description: At the Earth Day Carnival, student organizations and UT departments celebrate sustainability with games, prizes and lots of fun. Free food, face painting, a photo booth and educational games are all part of the event. Fill out a form here if you would like to volunteer: https://docs.google.com/a/utenvironment.org/spreadsheet/viewform?formkey=dHBHS0FIcUVSTUpPMU9Eam1kdFdyZnc6MQ.

Summary: RTF Game Development Program info session held
Description: Learn about how RTF students can participate in the Game Development Program, including the Capstone: 2D Games course offered in the fall. Learning game development will help students work in almost any interactive media company, including game studios, social media companies and mobile app developers.

Summary: CWGS presents colloquium on Audre Lorde with Lyndon Gill
Description: Lyndon Gill presents a Faculty Development Colloquium titled "Never Meant to Survive: Anti-Social Deaths & Our Lorde's Prayer." Through theoretical engagement with the poetry and prose of black lesbian feminist poet and theorist Audre Lorde, this workshop is at once an invocation of the past and a vision for our collective future.

Summary: Lecture on autism presented by Dr. Olive Healy
Description:
The Meadows Center for Preventing Educational Risk hosts the 2013 Mollie Villeret Davis Distinguished Lecture Series, featuring a lecture by Dr. Olive Healy titled "Child and Family Research Outcomes at the Irish Centre for Autism and Neurodevelopmental Research." A reception follows. RSVP "Autism" to rsvp@meadowscenter.org.



Healy is director of research, Iris Centre for Autism and Neurodevelopment Research. Worth 2.3 BCBA continuing education credits.

Summary: Student discussion with Dr. Paul Farmer held
Description:
The Humanities Institute hosts an open discussion focused on medicine and social justice with Dr. Paul Farmer, co-founder of the global health advocacy group Partners in Health and chair of the Department of Global Health and Social Medicine at Harvard Medical School. Seating is available on a first-come, first-served basis.



Farmer's research focuses on the role of social inequality in determining disease distribution and treatment outcomes. His work promotes the creation of community-based treatment initiatives for infectious diseases in resource-poor settings.

Summary: "Children in a World of Gangs" presented by Donna De Cesare
Description: Photojournalist and professor Donna De Cesare documents a history of repression, violence and trauma in Central America, in which gangs are as much a symptom as a cause of violence, trapped as they are by social neglect.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection 2nd floor conference room

Summary: Twenty-first-century permafrost thaw is topic of talk
Description: Dave Lawrence of the NCAR Earth System Laboratory presents "Projections and Implications of 21st Century Permafrost Thaw."

Summary: Demons and evil angels in early Judaism discussed
Description:
Carol A. Newsom, Emory University, presents a lecture titled "Demons and Evil Angels in Early Judaism." Although classical Israelite religion has very little to say about demons and other evil forces, popular religion took it for granted that evil demons existed, haunting desert ruins and sometimes preying on people. Although rabbinic Judaism largely rejected it, this worldview strongly shaped Christian religious beliefs. 



Newsom is Charles Howard Candler professor of Old Testament at Emory University's Candler School of Theology. She has written seven books and scores of articles, book chapters, translations, encyclopedia articles and reviews. She recently served as president of the Society of Biblical Literature and is a senior fellow at Emory University's Center for the Study of Law and Religion.

Summary: Study Abroad Country Corner topic is Spain
Description: The UT Study Abroad Office hosts a Country Corner information session on Spain. Peer advisers who have been to Spain talk about programs and their experiences abroad. Email studyabroadoffice@austin.utexas.edu or call 512-471-6490 for more information.
Location: Study Abroad Office, 2222 Rio Grande, multi-purpose room, along 23rd St.

Summary: Science Study Break presents talk on "Star Trek"
Description: Want to be a rocket scientist? Science Study Break examines the science and technology of "Star Trek" with Dr. Glenn Lightsey of Aerospace Engineering and Engineering Mechanics, featuring scenes from the popular TV shows and movies, and a discussion of where today's actual research is boldly going. Free pizza served.

Summary: Caribbean Students Association meets
Description: The Caribbean Students Association holds general meetings every Monday. Join us in celebrating all aspects of Caribbean culture. Meetings feature free Caribbean food, and a chance to meet other Caribbean students and become involved in our vibrant organization.

Summary: "Heaven's Rain" screened for Crime Victim Rights Week
Description: Attend a screening of "Heaven's Rain," based on the true story of crime survivors Brooks and Leslie Douglass. Mr. Douglass will be part of a discussion after the movie.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: "Man, Economy and Sport" is Mises Circle topic
Description: Are sports just another government institution? From antitrust laws in the NFL to intellectual property laws protecting the Longhorn logo, government entangles itself in the affairs of sports in every way it can, all with economic consequences. Join the Mises Circle to discuss this topic with columnist Skip Oliva, author of the Man, Economy & Sport blog.

Summary: Elite cycling is topic of McGarr Symposium
Description:
As the professional cycling community continues to come to grips with doping confessions that have rocked the sport, the College of Communication's Texas Program in Sports and Media (TPSM) hosts its 2013 McGarr Symposium on Sports and Society, titled "The Real Price of Winning at All Costs: A Discussion About Elite Cycling." A panel of cyclists and other experts addresses the importance of fair play, the urgency of anti-doping measures and the rooting out of a culture of corruption in sport.  



The event features Greg LeMond, three-time Tour de France champion; Greg's wife, Kathy; Betsy Andreu, wife of professional cyclist Frankie Andreu; Bill Bock, general counsel to the U.S. Anti-Doping Agency; and Reed Albergotti, white collar crimes reporter for The Wall Street Journal. Michael Cramer, TPSM director, serves as moderator. The educational discussion will take a closer look at what happens when a culture of cheating and corruption takes over a sport. The panelists will discuss the physical, emotional and ethical costs that elite cyclists have had to face in the recent history of the sport.
Location: Belo Center for New Media (BMC), second-floor auditorium, 300 W. Dean Keeton St.

Summary: Talk on Haiti touches on health care, human rights
Description:
The Humanities Institute presents a lecture by Dr. Paul Farmer, C.L. and Henriette Cline Visiting Professor in the Humanities, titled "Haiti After the Earthquake: Healthcare as a Human Right." Farmer is co-founder of the global health advocacy group, Partners in Health and chair of the Department of Global Health and Social Medicine at Harvard Medical School. A reception and book signing follow the lecture.



Seating is on a first come, first served basis.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), grand ballroom

Summary: Tony Kushner talks with Evan Smith
Description: Texas Performing Arts presents a conversation with Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter Tony Kushner. Kushner is best known for his two-part epic, "Angels in America: A Gay Fantasia on National Themes," and known for tackling difficult subjects in contemporary history. He will talk with Evan Smith, CEO and editor-in-chief of The Texas Tribune.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Longhorn Salsa presents Bachata Special
Description: Longhorn Salsa presents a special bachata lesson and dance session with local Latin instructor extraordinaire Favian Bustos. Learn this sensual Dominican dance, get some exercise, make new friends and have fun.

Summary: Graduate student presents CMAS graduate portfolio plática
Description:
Doctoral student Lucy Guevara Velez presents a plática titled "Constructing Latino Cultural Citizenship in the GED Classroom: Mexican Immigrant Students Claim Their Right to an Education."



Velez is a doctoral candidate in the Department of Curriculum and Instruction with a Graduate Portfolio in Mexican American Studies. The chair of her dissertation committee is Angela Valenzuela, professor in the Department of Curriculum and Instruction and the Department of Educational Administration.

Summary: Scholar discusses origins of the American way of war
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "Conquered into Liberty: The Deep Origins of the American Way of War" with Eliot Cohen, professor of strategic studies at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS), Johns Hopkins University. Refreshments provided.



Why do Americans wage war the way they do? Some point to the Civil War and World War II as the seminal events in our military history; others see the frontier contest between Native Americans and settlers as the crucible of the American approach to war.  Professor Cohen offers another interpretation: that it emerged over a protracted struggle, both conventional and irregular, with the European masters of Canada, over a period of nearly two centuries, and that its focal point was the Great Warpath route between Albany and Montreal.



Cohen is the Robert E. Osgood Professor of Strategic Studies at the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies (SAIS) of the Johns Hopkins University and founding director of the Philip Merrill Center for Strategic Studies.

Summary: MEC Cinema presents "Soul Food Junkies"
Description:
Co-founders of Food for Black Thought Naya Jones and Kevin Thomas host this installment of MEC Cinema and facilitate a discussion following the screening of "Soul Food Junkies," a documentary that looks at the effects of "soul food" on African Americans and others.



Inspired by his own family's complex relationship with "soul food" - fried chicken, ribs, macaroni and cheese, peach cobbler and the whole panoply of down-home foods made with grease, sugar and love - acclaimed filmmaker Byron Hurt asks whether this diet is nurturing or destroying the African American community. With humor and heart, Hurt questions the effects of "soul food" on the health of not only African Americans, but all who guiltily consume this most comforting of American comfort foods.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Multicultural Engagement Center 1.102

Summary: Economics Honors Symposium announced
Description: The Economics Honors Symposium features brief presentations of student research projects followed by discussion by a peer discussant and Q&A. Come and go for any presentation; see the full schedule here: http://blogs.utexas.edu/ecoadvising/files/2012/05/Econ-Honors-Symposium-Spring-20131.pdf.

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description: Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: International Relations Benefit Sale announced
Description: The International Relations Special Committee (IRSC) of the Lions Club hosts a three-day food sale featuring cuisine from Africa, Latin America, the Middle East and Asia. Proceeds go to a Filipino child sponsored by the committee and to IRSC's pen-pal program with Kenya.

Summary: Money Talks & Entrepreneurship Live present Laura Kilcrease
Description:
Entrepreneur-in-residence Laura Kilcrease is interviewed by Dr. John Sibley Butler. This exciting interview allows the audience to view the entire entrepreneurial process and how wealth is created. A reception follows.



Kilcrease has grown companies on a national and global scale, been on boards of directors for startups, funded companies with her Venture Firm and harvested companies for shareholder value. She is founder of Triton Venture Partners, L.P., an Austin, Texas-based venture capital fund specializing in high technology spin-off companies and other promising startups.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT) 201

Summary: Undergrad Real Estate Program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session to learn about the Undergraduate Real Estate Certificate Program (Texas URE), open to students from any major interested in pursuing a career in the commercial real estate industry. Register to attend at link below.
Location: McCombs School of Business (CBA), Legacy Events Room 3.20

Summary: Lions Club holds general meeting
Description: Looking for community service and social opportunities? Attend a meeting of the world's largest service organization to learn how you can get involved in meaningful community service projects and exciting socials with other members.

Summary: International Coffee Hour hosted by Study Abroad
Description: Join the Study Abroad Office at this event for mingling and free coffee with international students and study abroad students. All are welcome.
Location: 713 West 23rd (multipurpose room next to Abel's Copies)

Summary: Practica Plática holds last meeting of the semester
Description: Join Practica Plática for its last meeting of the semester, an informal two-hour Spanish conversation session. Food and music provided. Participants with all levels of fluency welcome.

Summary: Fandango is Latin-dance-based fitness party
Description: Participate in a fun, Zumba-themed event. Dance to merengue, salsa, reggaeton and other Latin beats while getting a great workout at the same time. Prizes provided. Zumba is Latin-based fitness experience. Athletic shoes required. For more information, email grupoflorycanto@yahoo.com.

Summary: Body-based seminar hosted by Longhorn Wellness Club
Description: Learn more about your body and how it works so that you can apply this knowledge to improving your health and everyday life.

Summary: "Perfect Storms" screened, with follow-up discussion
Description: Robert Dulls, senior research fellow in the Environmental Science Institute at The University of Texas at Austin, presents and discusses the documentary "Perfect Storms," which features his theory on the "AD 536 Event," a period of extreme climate change that led to global crop failures, famine and potentially the first mass outbreak of bubonic plague in the Mediterranean.

Summary: Bodyworks Seminar presented
Description: The last Longhorn Wellness Club seminar of the semester is the Bodyworks Seminar, demonstrating self-massage and breathing relaxation (breath work) techniques.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Houston
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Houston Cougars. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Oxfam Hunger Banquet held
Description:
Share a free meal and join the interactive and powerful discussion that is an Oxfam Hunger Banquet. Unique and memorable, this event 

allows organizers and participants alike to experience firsthand how our decisions affect others in the world.

Summary: Careers in LGBTQ advocacy discussed at meeting
Description: Join a discussion with local community members working in LGBTQ advocacy for tips on how to break into the field.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender & Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Why Bother? topic is Austin after 10-1
Description:
"Why Bother? Austin After 10-1" takes an in-depth look at how the change to the Austin City Council's governing structure will impact voters. Austin community experts, neighborhood representatives and the public participate.



Experts and community members from across the city meet to discuss issues that are most important to them, and how 10 separate districts will reconcile their differences once the new council is elected.
Location: Jones Communications Building B (CMB), Studio 6A, KLRU

Summary: Rush Clockwork Angels Tour comes to Erwin Center
Description: The highly acclaimed Rush Clockwork Angels Tour returns to North America for a performance at the Frank Erwin Center.

Summary: "Rhapsody in Blue" performed by University Orchestra
Description: In its final concert of the season, UT University Orchestra welcomes pianist Charlie Magnone for a performance of George Gershwin's iconic "Rhapsody in Blue." The program also includes an arrangement of Claude Debussy's "The Sunken Cathedral," Jean Sibelius's "King Christian II Suite" and the premiere of "Lux," by UT composer Joel Love.

Summary: "I'm Positive": HIV/AIDS documentary screened
Description: In honor of Get Yourself Tested Month, Voices for Reproductive Justice hosts a screening of "I'm Positive," a 60-minute documentary on the lives of three HIV-positive young people that premiered on MTV for World AIDS Day 2012. A dialogue on HIV services and prevention follows. Light bites and refreshments provided.

Summary: "Y.E.R.T. (Your Environmental Road Trip)" screened
Description: Three friends. Fifty states. One wild year. Called to action by a planet in peril, three friends hit the road - traveling America with hope, humor and all of their garbage for the year - to explore the good, the bad and the weird across every state. Free popcorn, treats and giveaways included. Watch a trailer here.
Location: Fire Place Lounge in Jester West

Summary: Pancakes for Parkinson's feeds for a good cause
Description: Texas Round Table sponsors a day of pancakes, door prizes and special Guest Flippers. Who knows? See if your favorite professor, athlete or administrator is one of them. Proceeds help fund Parkinson's disease research and a search for a cure.

Summary: VAV and SafePlace host Denim Day
Description: Support Austin's SafePlace by wearing denim to make a statement against victim blaming. More information and a free sticker are available at the Powerhouse in Student Services Building (SSB) G1.400H.

Summary: Learn about Texas State Employees Union
Description: The Texas State Employees Union sets up an information and sign-up table on campus. The union seeks to improve salaries, benefits and working conditions of all state workers, including faculty, staff and student employees at UT Austin. The union also advocates across-the-board flat-amount pay raises and opposes all attempts to remove long-standing protections against arbitrary cuts in benefits.

Summary: Longhorn Lights Out commemorates Earth Month
Description:
UT Facilities Services launches Longhorn Lights Out on April 24 as part of the university's Earth Month commemoration. The department is asking the campus community to turn off any lights that can be easily controlled on campus (without negative impact on safety and research), from noon to 1 p.m. 



Learn more: energysteward@austin.utexas.edu;  - read more about this event...;  - read more about this event... (#LonghornLightsOut).

Summary: CMAS presents student research plática
Description:
Three students, one in the Honors Program in Mexican American Studies and two in the Master of Arts degree program in Mexican American Studies, present from their respective research projects.



ToniAnn Treviño discusses "Narco Cinema" as an emerging film genre, specifically the portrayals of traditional and queer Narco families.



Ismael Cuevas discusses Latino Critical Race Theory to further understand the incorporation of undocumented students into the American mainstream.



Jaime Puente discusses the history of the Juarez-Lincoln University and its role as the knowledge producing arm of the Chicana/o Movement in Texas.

Summary: The role of the state in prison privatization discussed
Description:
The Edward A. Clark Center for Australian & New Zealand Studies launches its Fulbright Distinguished Speakers Series with a talk by Malcolm Feeley, whose research compares the Australian and American experiences with privatization of prisons. Australia leads the world in the proportion on inmates held in private prisons.



Feeley is the Claire Sanders Clements Dean's Chair Professor of Law at Berkeley Law School. Feeley's spent six months in Australia in 2012 as Fulbright Flinders University Distinguished Chair in American Political Science. Whereas privatization is taken for granted by both conservatives and liberals in Australia, in the U.S., it remains a highly controversial project. Feeley examines differences in public reactions to prison privatization, differences in the quality of services and programming in public versus private prisons and differences in the ways in which corrections officials approach privatization in the two countries.

Summary: Organizing and Synthesizing Sources is library course
Description: You've done your research, found your sources and are ready to write your paper. Feeling overwhelmed? This class covers tips, tricks and tools to help you organize, manage and use your sources effectively.

Summary: Managing your student loans is talk topic
Description: Review the repayment options available for federal, state and private loans. In addition, learn about consolidation, deferment options and loan forgiveness programs.

Summary: Grand Challenge Scholars Program info session held
Description: The Grand Challenge Scholars Program (GCSP) holds an information session to discuss the upcoming early application. The key components of GCSP include facing the 21st century's engineering grand challenges with entrepreneurship and service-learning, and understanding global dimensions through research and interdisciplinary curriculum. All majors are welcome.

Summary: Civil rights documentary screened at Sweatt Symposium
Description: The 2013 Heman Sweatt Symposium on Civil Rights includes a screening of "The Powerbroker: Whitney Young's Fight for Civil Rights," and a talkback with documentary producer Bonnie Boswell. The film chronicles the public and private trials of a man navigating a divided society in an explosive time. A reception precedes the screening.

Summary: Believe in Zero Fair hosted by UNICEF
Description: Students are invited to learn about global issues and the shared humanitarian efforts of UNICEF and other student organizations on campus. The Believe in Zero Fair features free food, games and other fun activities.

Summary: VAV Theatre for Dialogue presents final ensemble piece
Description: Voices Against Violence (VAV) presents a celebratory interactive performance from this year's Theatre for Dialogue class. If you need assistance or accommodations for this event, contact Erin Burrows at eburrows@austin.utexas.edu three business days prior to the event.

Summary: University of Texas Mariachi Ensemble holds auditions
Description: The University of Texas Mariachi Ensemble, Mariachi Paredes de Tejastitlán, holds spring mariachi auditions for current and prospective students. Bring instruments - guitar, vihuela, guitarrón, harp, violin, trumpet - and your voice. Students must show instrumental and sight-reading proficiency and be prepared to perform a musical selection of their choice. Instruments provided if needed.

Summary: Toying with the Truth: David Levinthal discusses his work
Description: Photographer David Levinthal presents "Toying with the Truth," a discussion of his work with examples from the past 40 years. Levinthal finds toys and other objects that he uses in his artwork to be reflections of both the period and the culture that they come from. He incorporates the objects of the social landscape - from Barbie to toy soldiers - into his work. Doors open at 6:30 p.m.

Summary: Climate change in Texas is panel topic
Description:
The Campus Environmental Center presents "Climate Change in Texas: Risks and Opportunities," a panel discussion moderated by former Austin mayor Will Wynn. Panelists include Dr. Kerry Cook, Jackson School of Geosciences, Dr. Ramón Alvarez, Environmental Defense Fund, and Zach Baumer, City of Austin Climate Program Manager. 



The discussion will touch on issues of sustainability economics, city planning, climate change modeling and environmental policy.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: "70 Secrets of Marmalade Kittens" presented by UTNT
Description: In this play by Gabrielle Reisman, Quinn wrestles with abandoning her husband, her young children and their lonely life on an Iowa hog confinement farm. Ten years later, her now-grown children must choose between selling off their father's business and tracking down the ghosts of their mother's desires. UTNT (UT New Theatre) presents newly developed work of emerging playwrights.

Summary: Mad Stork Avant Garde Film Night screens Mark LaPore films
Description: Mad Stork presents 3 X LaPore, a screening of five short films. Scheduled to be screened are "Netezza Urbana: N.U." (Michelangelo Antonioni, 9 min., 1948); "Crossroad" (Phil Solomon with Mark LaPore, 5 min., 2005); "The Sleepers" (LaPore, 16 min., 1989), "A Depression in the Bay of Bengal" (LaPore, 28 min. 1996) and "The Glass System" (LaPore, 20 min., 2000).

Summary: Volunteers sought for the Global Venture Labs competition
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs solicits volunteers for the upcoming Global Venture Labs Investment Competition (VLIC), coming May 2-4. To volunteer, sign up at the link below by April 29. If you are interested in attending but cannot volunteer, RSVP at http://bit.ly/GVLIC2013a.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: 13th Annual Symposium in Dispute Resolution slated
Description:
The annual Dispute Resolution Symposium is a showcase for law student presentations and one professional panel on topics relevant to the field of dispute resolution. The title of this year's panel, at 10:30 a.m., is "How to Keep Disputes from Derailing Long-Term Contracts."



The panel presentation will provide insights into dispute resolution boards (DRBs), a mechanism used to efficiently manage disputes that arise in long-term contracts. The esteemed panel includes Bill Hinton with the DRB Foundation and Jeri Arbuckle with DART and will be moderated by Jeff Jury and Steve Nelson, experienced ADR practitioners.
Location: UT School of Law, Connally Center for Justice (CCJ), Eidman Courtroom 2.306

Summary: Courtyard Gallery features Thuy-Van Vu's "Works on Paper"
Description:
The Courtyard Gallery features the artwork of faculty and alumni of the Department of Art and Art History in the College of Fine Arts. This exhibit features the art of Thuy-Van Vu.



A native of Phoenix, Arizona, Vu received her BFA in painting from the Rhode Island School of Design in 1998 and her MFA in Studio Art from the University of Texas in Austin in 2006, where she was a recipient of the David Bruton Jr. Graduate Fellowship. Vu's work has been exhibited in the U.S. and abroad.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Courtyard Gallery

Summary: LGBT families are topic of talk with Stephen Russell
Description: Knowledge & Noms presents a talk on LGBT families by Stephen Russell, director of the Frances McClelland Institute for Children, Youth and Families at the University of Arizona. Free pizza served.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Gender and Sexuality Center 2.112

Summary: Engineering master's degree info session held online
Description: Attend a live-online information session about the engineering master's degree program geared toward the working professional and offered through the Cockrell School of Engineering at The University of Texas at Austin. Programs include Engineering Management and Software Engineering, and meet one weekend (Friday and Saturday) a month for two years.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these work in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Beyond the Clicker talk presented
Description: Clickers are increasingly common in classrooms, however many instructors find them  limiting. A talk titled "Beyond the Clicker: Productive Confusion and Collaboration" introduces "learning catalytics," a tool that addresses these limitations. Questions? Contact anne.braseby@austin.utexas.edu.

Summary: Landmarks Walk & Talk public tour highlights campus art
Description:
Join Landmarks docents for an insightful and conversational walking tour of Landmarks public art projects throughout the main campus. This tour builds awareness and appreciation of modern and contemporary art and features new works by Sol LeWitt. Meets in the Bass Concert Hall Lobby

Contact Landmarks Education Coordinator Taylor Browning taylor.browning@austin.utexas.edu to learn more.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall lobby

Summary: Creating change for LGBT youth is topic of talk
Description: Stephen T. Russell, director of the Frances McClelland Institute for Children, Youth and Families at the University of Arizona, presents a talk titled "'It Gets Better?' Creating Change for LGBT Youth." The talk includes a review and critique of research on bullying and school policies, with a focus on the emergence of promising school strategies for promoting the well-being of all students.

Summary: Art History Lecture Series presents Mildred Howard
Description: Artist Mildred Howard presents a talk titled "The Golden State meets the Lone Star State: Art in the Public Realm."

Summary: UEX walk-in advising session held
Description:
Dr. Mike Raney, the University Extension's academic adviser, holds a two-hour session to meet with students. Email Raney at mike.raney@austin.utexas.edu with questions or to schedule an appointment. 



University Extension provides flexible course options and formats to individuals seeking to earn credit at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Studies of the changing cryosphere discussed by scientist
Description: Dr. Dorothy Hall from the Cryospheric Sciences Laboratory at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center presents a talk titled "Satellite Snow and Ice Products for Studies of the Changing Cryosphere."
Location: Jackson Geological Sciences Building (JGB), Barrow Conference Room 4.102

Summary: SBS Postdoc Association holds Business of Science Seminar
Description:
The School of Biological Sciences Postdoctoral Association announces its next seminar in the Business of Science series, featuring a talk by Thomas Kodadek titled "The Ups & Downs of Moving 'Disruptive' Diagnostic and Therapeutic Technology From the Lab to the 'Real World.'" A networking reception in the third floor lounge follows the seminar.



Kodadek is vice chair, Department of Chemistry, Scripps Institute, Florida Scientific Advisory Board, Opko Health Inc.

Summary: Opening reception held for Thuy-Van Vu, "Works on Paper"
Description:
Join Art Department alumna Thuy-Van Vu for the opening reception for her exhibition "Works on Paper," on view April 25 through Sept. 27.



Thuy-Van Vu was born in Phoenix, Arizona, and received her BFA in painting from the Rhode Island School of Design in 1998 and her MFA in Studio Art from the University of Texas in Austin in 2006, where she was a recipient of the David Bruton Jr. Graduate Fellowship. Her work has been exhibited in the U.S. and abroad.



The Courtyard Gallery features the artwork of faculty and alumni of the Department of Art and Art History in the College of Fine Arts.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), Courtyard Gallery

Summary: Plan II Honors holds CLA open house
Description: Plan II has moved into a beautiful space in the brand-new College of Liberal Arts building (CLA), and we are most eager to show it off. Plan II alumni and families are invited to an open house to celebrate our new home, followed by a reception at the nearby Alumni Center, which precedes the 2013 Glickman Lecture (see separate listings).

Summary: Longhorn Startup Lab Demo Day held
Description: Longhorn Startup Lab Demo Day showcases the 10 undergraduate startups from our spring 2013 class. Undergraduate students from many different departments experienced entrepreneurship firsthand, starting companies and being assisted with a semester-long program of startup acceleration with speakers, mentors and supervised project work. Each company gives a six-minute pitch at this event.
Location: LBJ Library & Museum, Lady Bird Johnson Auditorium

Summary: Scientist discusses renewable electricity markets
Description: Ryan Wiser, staff scientist and deputy groupleader in the Electricity Markets and Policy Group at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory, is the guest speaker at this week's UT Energy Symposium. Wiser's talk is titled "United States Renewable Electricity Futures: Are High Penetrations Possible?" Cookies served at 5 p.m.

Summary: Donna De Cesare book & exhibit looks at children and gangs
Description: Award-winning photojournalist Donna De Cesare exhibits her photographs of gang members and their families that have been collected in the volume "Unsettled: Children in a World of Gangs." Through her work, De Cesare uncovers the effects of decades of war and gang violence on the lives of youths in Central America and in refugee communities in the United States.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection, 2nd floor

Summary: Plan II alumni reception precedes Glickman Lecture
Description: Plan II Honors alumni are invited to a reception with light snacks and drinks preceding the 2013 Glickman Lecture, to be delivered by writer and scholar Louis Menand.

Summary: Cooperation Texas & Food for Black Thought hold workshop
Description:
A workshop and potluck with Cooperation Texas and Food for Black Thought explores the past and present state of the racial wealth divide in the U.S. and Texas, and how worker-owned cooperatives can serve as the basis of a more just and sustainable economy.



This workshop may especially appeal to you if:

* You're ready to talk fresh ways to address food issues

* You're inspired to create a food cooperative

* You have a food cooperative group in the works

* You want facts and action

Summary: Listen to Autism panel and silent auction held
Description: Autism Speaksmarks Autism Awareness Month with a Listen to Autism Panel of professionals from the field, researchers and local service providers. A silent auction benefits the national Autism Speaks charity. Refreshments served.

Summary: Louis Menand delivers 2013 Glickman Lecture
Description: Pulitzer Prize-winning author Louis Menand delivers the 2013 Glickman Lecture, "The Condition of the Humanitites." Menand is professor of English and American Literature and Language at Harvard University, and a writer for The New Yorker. His work engages the worlds of both academia and popular high culture. Menand's most recent book is "The Marketplace of Ideas: Reform and Resistance in the American University."

Summary: Asian Culture Showcase presented by aKDPhi and ACC
Description: The Eta Chapter of alpha Kappa Delta Phi and the Asian American Culture Committee present their first ever Asian Culture Showcase. Learn about the rich Asian heritage and culture and enjoy a cultural fashion show and performances by RDC, Texas Wushu and other artists. Prizes given all night to those who answer trivia questions correctly.

Summary: Worlds Unite celebrates campus diversity with festival
Description: UT's Kappa Phi Lambda Sorority hosts its third annual Worlds Unite. Join us for a night of food, performances, games and prizes that celebrates diversity and promotes cultural integration.

Summary: The crisis in the UT system is forum topic
Description:
The International Socialist Organization and guest speaker Professor Snehal Shingavi,  Center for Asian American Studies, discuss President Bill Powers' proposal to privatize all nonacademic jobs, as well as a Regents proposal that favors the privatizing of academic jobs.



The Powers plan would essentially force staff in food services, janitors, parking and other departments to work for lower wages than they do now, or to leave. The UT Regents proposal would gut tenure-track programs and implement many free-market solutions that do not belong in higher education.

Summary: "The Kingdom": Play examines priest's loss of faith
Description: In this play by Andrew Hinderaker, a Catholic priest of 22 years has stopped taking confession. He has stopped delivering mass. Hiding out in the basement of his church, he seeks to perform miracles of his own making. What becomes of a priest who has lost his faith in us all? "The Kingdom" is performed as part of a series of new plays this spring.

Summary: Project Come Together carnival welcomes schoolchildren
Description: Delta Epsilon Psi Fraternity hosts the 14th annual Project Come Together in conjunction with the Neighborhood Longhorns Program, a carnival day for elementary school students that rewards academic achievement and encourages kids to pursue higher education. Organizations wishing to host a booth or field game should email servicechair@depsifounding.org.

Summary: SSC Seminar Series presents Professor Sayan Mukherjee
Description:
The Division of Statistics and Scientific Computation welcomes Duke University professor Sayan Mukherjee, who presents a talk titled "Modeling Quantitative Phenotypes."



In this talk Mukherjee considers two problems in modeling quantitative phenotypes. The first is estimating the genetic covariance matrix (G-matrix) of high-dimensional traits. The second involves measuring distances between bones (2-dimension surfaces embedding in 3-dimensions).

Summary: Austin Summit on LGBT Families presents keynote speaker
Description:
The Austin Summit on LGBT Families presents a keynote address by Gary Gates, The Williams Institute, University of California, Los Angeles, titled "LGBT Parenting Research: Science in the Public Square." Contact Julie Kniseley at jkniseley@austin.utexas.edu for more information.



Gary Gates is the Williams Distinguished Scholar at the Charles R. Williams Institute on Sexual Orientation and Gender Identity Law and Public Policy at UCLA. He will present some of his new research on LGBT parents and families and consider some of the challenges of conducting good research on a topic of considerable public interest and debate.

Summary: Sugar, obesity and metabolic risk are topic of talk
Description:
Michael Goran, Ph.D., a leading researcher in the field of childhood obesity, presents a talk titled "The Sugar 'Maize': Sugar, High Fructose Corn Syrup, Obesity and Metabolic Risk: From Genes to Policy" as part of the ongoing speaker series in the Department of Nutritional Sciences.



Goran is a professor of preventative medicine, physiology, biophysics at the University of Southern California. His research explores how the body regulates where excess fat is deposited, how increased body fat affects health and how fat is regulated during growth and development across segments of the population. He is particularly interested in ethnic disparities in obesity and obesity-related diseases.

Summary: McCraw Lecture presented by Bob Heere
Description: "This is Our Team: Community Development In and Through Sport" is presented by Bob Heere, Ph.D., assistant professor, Department of Kinesiology and Health Education.

Summary: Social support in close relationships is topic of talk
Description: Shelly Gable, professor at the University of California, Santa Barbara, presents a talk titled "Being There When Things Go Right Builds Resources for When Things Go Wrong." Gable's research focuses on appetitive and aversive motivation in social interaction and close relationships, and also examines the positive aspects of close relationships and their role in physical and emotional health.

Summary: Fulbright U.S. Student Program holds info session
Description: Attend an information session for prospective applicants to the Fulbright U.S. Student Program, presented by an alumni ambassador from the Institute of International Education.

Summary: Geoffrey Wheatcroft discusses Margaret Thatcher
Description:
Lady Margaret Thatcher's funeral brought together bitter enemies who had not spoken to each other in years to pay tribute to the longest-serving British prime minister of the twentieth century and the only woman to have held the office. Journalist and historian Geoffrey Wheatcroft examines the complex legacy of this polarizing leader.



Wheatcroft studied modern history at New College, Oxford, and joined the Spectator in 1975. He writes regularly for the Spectator, the New York Times and the Wall Street Journal. His books include "The Randlords," "The Controversy of Zion" and "The Strange Death of Tory England."
Location: Harry Ransom Center (HRC), Tom Lea Rooms 3.206

Summary: Department of French & Italian presents Tavola Italiana
Description: The Department of French and Italian presents Tavola Italiana at the Cactus Cafe, a weekly meeting for informal conversation in Italian on Italian culture.

Summary: UT Sciences Toastmasters meets
Description: UT Sciences Toastmasters is a friendly, laid-back group whose members work to improve their speaking, speech-making and general communication skills for success in academic careers and future endeavors. Students from all majors and departments are welcome.

Summary: Texas baseball meets Baylor
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor, the Baylor Bears.

Summary: Nautanki performance is North Indian musical folk theater
Description: The South Asia Institute presents a Nautanki performance, "Indal Haran" (The Abduction of Indal) by Dr. Devendra Sharma's Swang and Nautanki Mandali. Nautanki is one of the most popular operatic performance traditions of northern India, bringing together singing, drumming, dancing and storytelling in a highly entertaining format.
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Texas Union Theatre 2.228

Summary: "Don Giovanni" presented by Butler Opera Center
Description: The Butler Opera Center presents a 21st-century adaptation of Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's two-act opera, "Don Giovanni." Discounted parking ($6) is only available online until 10 p.m. of the day prior to an event. More parking information is at http://www.clickandpark.com/faq.shtml.

Summary: "Dream of Perfect Sleep" is play by Kevin Kautzman
Description: When the grown children of an elderly and ailing couple return to a home decorated for the holidays - and it's not the holidays - the family must make a hard decision about what it means to exit this world with grace. Playwright Kevin Kautzman is pursuing his MFA at the Michener Center.

Summary: Spanish & Portuguese hosts Poetry Declamation Contest
Description: The 39th annual Poetry Declamation Contest, hosted by the Department of Spanish and Portuguese, invites K-12 students in the greater Austin area to participate in a friendly academic competition, reciting Spanish-language poetry by authors of diverse nationalities. An awards ceremony, breakfast and refreshments included.

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in a UT Micro Farm workday at UT's first student-run sustainable farm. This weekend we'll be preparing our soil for planting. All ages and skill levels invited. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Blanton Fifty Fest celebrates museum's birthday
Description: Celebrate the Blanton's 50th birthday at Fifty Fest, a free, 12-hour party lasting from noon to midnight on April 27. Visitors of all ages can enjoy live music, art-making activities and exhibition tours, plus performances by T Bird and the Breaks, Brownout, Minor Mishap Marching Band and others.

Summary: "Austinites for Bostonites" track marathon announced
Description: Austinites for Bostonites is a 24-hour track event to show support for Boston and raise money for the Boston-area Red Cross. Participants sign up for a specific time to run or walk laps between 6 p.m. Saturday, April 27 and 6 p.m. Sunday, April 28. Drop-ins also welcome. The aim is to have at least one person on the track at all times. Comments invited on the Facebook events page listed below.
Location: Caven Lacrosse and Sports Center at Clark Field

Summary: Saturday Morning Math Group presents "How to Solve It"
Description: The Saturday Morning Math Group presents "How to Solve It," a discussion and problem-solving session led by Dr. Dan Freed of the UT Department of Mathematics. Open to all ages and especially geared toward high school and middle school-aged students. Bagels, snacks and beverages provided.

Summary: "A Perfect Robot": UTNT presents free reading of play
Description: "A Perfect Robot" is a play about robots and octopi, consciousness and programming, passwords and ghosts by Michener fellow Sarah Saltwick. It will be read onstage, with tickets distributed beginning at 10 a.m. at the LAB box office.

Summary: "Dream of Perfect Sleep" is play by Kevin Kautzman
Description: When the grown children of an elderly and ailing couple return to a home decorated for the holidays - and it's not the holidays - the family must make a hard decision about what it means to exit this world with grace. Playwright Kevin Kautzman is pursuing his MFA at the Michener Center.

Summary: Jessen Series presents Delaine Leonard Fedson & friends
Description: Delaine Leonard Fedson, harp, performs. The first half of the concert is a short solo harp recital dedicated to the memory of former University of Texas harp professor Gayle Horn Barrington, followed by a collaborative performance of works by Vierne, Andrès and DeFalla with soprano Kathryn Findlen and harpist Jacquelyn Venter.

Summary: Top Rank Texas Boxing Tour comes to Erwin Center
Description: Top Rank Texas Boxing Tour includes six Texas boxers and Olympian Jose Ramirez on the undercard, with the main event featuring a lightweight battle between NABF lightweight champion and no. 4 world-rated contender Raymundo Beltran of Los Mochis, Sonora, Mexico, and Alejandro Rodriguez of Guadalajara, Mexico.

Summary: C!rca contemporary circus performs
Description: C!rca, directed by Yaron Lifschitz, is a bold new vision of contemporary circus in which acrobatics and movement meld into a seamless whole, fundamentally redefining the nature of circus as spectacle.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: "70 Secrets of Marmalade Kittens" presented by UTNT
Description: In this play by Gabrielle Reisman, Quinn wrestles with abandoning her husband, her young children and their lonely life on an Iowa hog confinement farm. Ten years later, her now-grown children must choose between selling off their father's business and tracking down the ghosts of their mother's desires. UTNT (UT New Theatre) presents newly developed work of emerging playwrights.

Summary: Enhanced reading of "The Kingdom" presented
Description: In this play by Andrew Hinderaker, a Catholic priest of 22 years has stopped taking confession. He has stopped delivering mass. Hiding out in the basement of his church, he seeks to perform miracles of his own making. What becomes of a priest who has lost his faith in us all? "The Kingdom" is performed as part of a series of new plays this spring.

Summary: Integrated pest management class held at Community Garden
Description: Be an environmental steward while growing your own food in a sustainable way. Integrated pest management is a system of pest control that minimizes chemical use. Learn to identify common garden pests and organic remedy solutions. Class is led by Elizabeth McVeety, Garden Center coordinator for Austin's Zilker Botanical Garden.

Summary: NGO fosters rural livelihood development in India
Description: Learn about Samaj Parivartan Samudaya (SPS), a nongovernmental organization (NGO) in Karnataka, India, and a partner organization of the Association for India's Development, which fosters rural livelihood development and protection of natural resources through capacity-building programs for women, farmers and tribal peoples. SPS has been instrumental in empowering communities to take ownership of their local resources.

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: "PORTFOLIO" opening reception held
Description: Come see how imagination manifests itself on stage and film. Join Theatre and Dance artists at the opening reception of PORTFOLIO: The Future of Performance Design & Technology. This annual exhibition celebrates the work of emerging artists in costume design, lighting design, scenery, media and technology.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: "PORTFOLIO" celebrates performance design & technology
Description: The University of Texas at Austin Department of Theatre and Dance presents "PORTFOLIO 2013," an exciting exhibition celebrating the work of emerging artists in costume design, lighting design, scenery, media and technology. Come see how imagination manifests itself on stage and film. Closed May 3. Hours on May 4 are 10 a.m.-5 p.m.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Traversing the Boundaries of Resistance symposium held
Description: Activists Edson Cardoso (Brazil) and Haile Gerima (Ethiopia/U.S.) attend a screening of "Beyond the Mirror" (dir. Ana Flauzina) at the "Traversing the Boundaries of Resistance" symposium. The film features a dialogue between Cardoso and Gerima. Following is a formal presentation by Cardoso and a screening and discussion of Gerima's most recent movie "Teza."
Location: College of Liberal Arts Building (CLA), Julius Glickman Conference Center 1.302B

Summary: The Iraq Legacy: Talk hosted by Strauss Center
Description:
The Robert S. Strauss Center for International Security and Law presents "The Iraq Legacy: Learning the Right Lessons" with Emma Sky, senior fellow at Yale University's Jackson Institute. Refreshments provided.



Sky offers a pointed critique of U.S. policy over the last decade, arguing that valuable lessons can be learned from the Iraq's "American era" now that U.S. forces have withdrawn. She examines these lessons learned and urges U.S. policymakers to set realistic goals for future intervention.

Summary: Iran and the Arab world to be talk topic
Description:
Dr. Hamid Dabashi, professor of Iranian studies and comparative literature at Columbia University, presents a talk titled "Iran and the Arab World: Connecting the Dots."
