Since the summer of 2009 in Iran, and the spring of 2011 in the Arab world, a succession of historic events have radically altered the geopolitics of the region. 

How are the rise of the Green Movement in Iran and the revolutionary momentum code-named the Arab Spring connected, and what can we learn from the structural link between these two transformative events in the Arab and Muslim world?

Summary: Lisa Thompson presents CWGS New Faculty Colloquium
Description: Lisa B. Thompson, associate professor in the Department of African and African Diaspora Studies, presents "The Rage of a Privileged Class: Angst, Anger and Alienation in Contemporary African American Theatre."

Summary: The Fight to Save Juárez is talk by Ricardo Ainslie
Description: Dr. Ricardo Ainslie of the Department of Educational Psychology discusses Ciudad Juárez, ground zero for the drug war that is raging across Mexico and has claimed close to 60,000 lives since 2007. Whatever happens in Juárez, Ainslie argues, will have lasting repercussions for both Mexico and the United States.

Summary: Development of hydrological models discussed by professor
Description: Dr. Jay Famiglietti, director, UC Center for Hydrologic Modeling at the University of California - Irvine, presents his research on water needs and current trends in a talk titled "Strategies for the Development of Hydrological Models."

Summary: CMAS hosts Américo Paredes Distinguished Lecture
Description: The Center for Mexican American Studies (CMAS) is pleased to welcome Abel Valenzuela, Jr., Chair of the UCLA César E. Chávez Department for Chicana/o Studies at the University of California, Los Angeles, to give the 2013 Américo Paredes Distinguished Lecture, titled "Chicano Studies, Hispanic Studies, Latino Studies (?): Naming and the Future of Chicano Studies."
Location: Texas Union Building (UNB), Santa Rita Suite 3.502

Summary: "Last Call at the Oasis" environmental film screened
Description: How might climate change and population growth affect the way your water is replenished? Jay Famiglietti explores this question in "Last Call at the Oasis," a film by the producers of "An Inconvenient Truth." A Q&A follows the screening.

Summary: "The Candlemakers' Petition" is Mises Circle topic
Description:
The Mises Circle closes out the semester with a throwback reading from the great French economist Frédéric Bastiat. "The Candlemakers' Petition," from his seminal 1845 work, "Economic Sophisms," is a satirical essay written from the perspective of candlemakers hoping to convince the French parliament to block out the sun so as to prevent unfair competition. Read the essay here.



While over a century-and-a-half old, this essay still comically illuminates the follies of many economic policies being peddled today, as well as general misconceptions of economic law at large.

Summary: Ramin Karimloo presents "Broadway to Bluegrass"
Description: West End and Broadway singing sensation Ramin Karimloo brings his "Broadway to Bluegrass" Concert to The University of Texas. Don't miss this incredible opportunity to hear London's brightest star sing.

Summary: Symphony Orchestra performs with Rachell Wong, violin
Description: The UT Symphony Orchestra performs with guest violinist Rachell Wong, two-time Butler School String Concerto Competition winner, performing Shostakovich's Violin Concerto, op. 77. Guest conductor Tim Laughlin leads UTSO with Mendelssohn's picturesque "Hebrides Overture" and Maestro Zimmermann takes the podium for Dvorak's lively "Czech Suite."

Summary: 20th annual HUB/SB Vendor Fair announced
Description: The University of Texas at Austin and UT System Administration sponsor the 20th Annual HUB Vendor Fair. The one day exhibit is designed to give historically underutilized business (HUB) owners an opportunity to market their products and/or services to the many departmental purchasing representatives on campus, as well as to the many other State of Texas agencies located in the capitol city.

Summary: S.A.F.E. Street Carnival benefits SafePlace
Description: The sisters of Sigma Phi Omega host the S.A.F.E. Street Carnival to raise funds and awareness for victims of domestic violence. Join us for fun games and free food and drinks. Raffle prizes include gift cards to local eateries and more. Donuts and a dunking booth round out the event.

Summary: Music at the Blanton: Bach Cantata performed
Description: Students and faculty from the Butler School of Music perform Bach's "Freue dich, erloste Schar" BWV 30 in the Blanton's Rapoport Atrium.

Summary: "Rethinking Power" conference video archive launched
Description:
The Center for Women's & Gender Studies (CWGS) and the University of Texas Libraries Human Rights Documentation Initiative (HRDI) announce the launch of the online video archive for the 2012 conference "Rethinking Power & Resistance: Gender and Human Rights from Texas to the Transnational Americas." Attendees and panelists will discuss gender justice.



Gender justice panelists are Dr. Matt Richardson, associate professor of English and African and African Diaspora studies and CWGS affiliate; Dr. Christen Smith, assistant professor of anthropology and African and African Diaspora studies; and Rose Pulliam, MSW, co-director of allgo, a statewide queer people of color organization.
Location: Sid Richardson Hall (SRH), Benson Latin American Collection, 2nd floor conference room

Summary: UT Energy Symposium presents "Energy with the CEO"
Description: This semester's installment of the UT Energy Symposium's "Energy with the CEO" series brings Randy Foutch, chairman and CEO of Laredo Petroleum, to campus to speak on energy innovation and entrepreneurship.

Summary: Surviving Finals 101 presented
Description: Preparing for finals for the first time? Feel like your old study techniques could use a tune up? Get tips and strategies on how to manage your time, study strategically and stay healthy as you reach the academic finish line.

Summary: UT Lions Club holds general meeting
Description: Looking for community service and social opportunities? Attend the Lions Club's general meeting to learn how you can get involved in meaningful community service projects and exciting socials with other members.

Summary: Texas baseball plays Prairie View A&M
Description: Texas baseball hosts the Prairie View A&M Panthers. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: VAC presents Two Ships Passing with Kyle Schlesinger
Description:
The Visual Arts Center, in collaboration with the art publication "Pastelegram," presents the spring 2013 edition of Two Ships Passing focused on the topic of pacing and featuring invitee Kyle Schlesinger and his guest, Austin writer Cindy St. John. Two Ships Passing explores pertinent topics within the creative community through conversation.



Central to magazine work - online or in print - is the consideration of the pacing of images, texts and ideas. Structuring how information unfolds over time concerns many of those working in temporal media such as magazines, films or written narratives.



In each edition of this conversation series, one speaker is invited and prompted to request the company of a committed colleague, mentor or perhaps even a new acquaintance, creating a unique pairing for a dialogue. This remarkable event aims to establish a reactive space where ideas will be exchanged and unexpected conclusions reached.

Summary: Soaring Eagle Talent Show benefits Boys & Girls Clubs
Description: The señoritas of the Elite Eta Chapter of Sigma Lambda Alpha Sorority, Inc. announce the Soaring Eagle Talent Show. Watch and support performers as they showcase their talents for a noble cause. All event proceeds will be donated to the South Austin Boys & Girls Club of America. Register to perform by April 27 at 5 p.m. Visit link below for more information.

Summary: Harry Ransom Lecture: Kevin Powers
Description:
In partnership with the Austin Public Library Friends Foundation's Mayor's Book Club, the University Co-op and the Harry Ransom Center present Kevin Powers, author of the critically acclaimed war novel "The Yellow Birds," in conversation with Michener Center director Jim Magnuson. A book signing follows. Doors open 6:30 p.m., 6:20 for members.



Powers joined the army at the age of 17, later serving a year as a machine gunner in Mosul and Tal Afar, Iraq, in 2004 and 2005. After his honorable discharge, he enrolled in Virginia Commonwealth University, where he graduated in 2008 with a B.A. in English. He holds an M.F.A. from The University of Texas at Austin, where he was a Michener Fellow in Poetry. This is his first novel.



Doors open at 6:20 p.m. for members and at 6:30 p.m. for the general public. Members must present their membership cards for priority entry; one seat per membership card. Members arriving after 6:30 p.m. will join the general queue.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), amphitheater

Summary: Bike to UT Day free breakfasts served
Description: Celebrate Bike to UT Day with breakfast served at guard kiosks on campus. Ride your bike to campus and enjoy a light breakfast and a chance to win prizes. Participating kiosks include San Jacinto at 20th St., 24th St. at Whitis, San Jacinto at 24th St., 23rd St. & Trinity, 21st St. just east of University Ave., east entrance to Pickle Research Campus off Burnet Road.

Summary: Peace & Justice Series focuses on city's segregated past
Description: The John Warfield Center's Peace and Justice Series presents "East Avenue: Racial Segregation in Austin, Past and Present," a forum featuring those who recall the not-so-distant past of racial segregation in Austin. The event unveils footage from a documentary project that captures stories from Austin during the Jim Crow period, exploring the ways in which that legacy continues today.

Summary: Bike to UT Day Party on the Plaza announced
Description: Enjoy food, drink, giveaways and celebrate cycling to campus at this party on Bike to UT Day.

Summary: Family-focused cancer care is lecture topic
Description: The School of Social Work presents a State of the Science talk titled "Family-Focused Cancer Care: When a Parent Has Cancer," given by Dr. Frances Marcus Lewis, professor in the Department of Family and Child Nursing, University of Washington. CEUs provided. RSVP to ffarya@gmail.com.
Location: School of Social Work (SSW), Utopia Theatre

Summary: Peace Corps coffee talk held
Description: Attend an informational coffee talk on the Peace Corps. Talks are held on the first and third Wednesdays of every month and feature former Peace Corps volunteers and the UT recruiter. Learn about what the Peace Corps can do for you and what you can do for humanity.

Summary: Sweatt Symposium explores future of black life in Austin
Description: The Sweatt Symposium brings together community leaders and City of Austin officials for a discussion on the future of black life in Austin and issues facing the African American community. Panelists include Joyce James, associate deputy commissioner, Health and Human Services; Shannon Jones III, deputy director, Travis County Health & Human Services; and Margo Frasier, police monitor, APD.

Summary: Tower Awards presented today
Description: The Tower Awards are presented annually to honor excellence in volunteerism among the students, faculty and staff at The University of Texas at Austin. This year's awards recognize students from various centers: Gender and Sexuality Center, Longhorn Center for Academic Excellence, Longhorn Center for Civic Engagement, Multicultural Engagement Center and Services for Students with Disabilities.

Summary: WIP holds Zumba fitness fund-raiser
Description: Women in Psychology (WIP) hosts a Zumba fitness fund-raiser with instructor Abi Guerra from TeXercise. All proceeds benefit GirlStart, a nonprofit organization that educates and empowers young girls in math, technology and science. Prizes given to raffle winners.

Summary: Talk examines European sport, nationalism & identity
Description: In celebration of Europe Day, Dr. Ben Carrington gives a talk titled "Reflections on European Culture: Sport, Nationalism and Identity."

Summary: Global Venture Labs Investment Competition held
Description: The Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs hosts the 2013 Global Venture Labs Investment Competition, running May 2-4, in which 40 teams of student entrepreneurs from around the world pitch their "investor-ready" ideas to entrepreneurs, investors and industry experts.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in this in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: University Extension webinar explores global health issues
Description:
University Extension (UEX) hosts a free webinar with Dr. Jane Champion of the School of Nursing to introduce the online course N 309 - Global Health, offered online during the summer 2013 semester, providing a special opportunity for students all over the world to earn credit while exploring current global health issues. Course instructor Champion gives a brief introduction to some of the topics that will be covered in depth this summer.



Champion, PhD, DNP, MSN, MA, FNP, AH-PMH-CNS, FAAN, is a faculty member in the School of Nursing at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Fifteen startups pitch on May 2 during Venture Expo
Description: Sixteen "investor-ready" startups from The University of Texas at Austin and Central Texas pitch their business ideas to a packed house. Come see what UT entrepreneurship is all about while rubbing elbows with entrepreneurs and investors. Companies include current members of the Jon Brumley Texas Venture Labs Accelerator, as well as ATI companies and Texas Venture Labs alumni.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT)

Summary: Performing Blackness presents RGB Batey y Macorix
Description: Areytos Performance Works (Sita Frederick, artistic director) performs RGB: Batey Y Macorix, a piece that remixes the Dominican dance and music traditions Gaga and Guloya and reflects on the politics of black identity, border zones and "otherness" within the New York Dominican community and beyond. Guest artist Nelly Rosario, a fiction writer, discusses the work.
Location: Student Activity Center (SAC), Black Box Theater 2.304

Summary: Population Research Center presents Jacquelynne Eccles
Description: Jacquelynne Eccles, School of Education & Department of Psychology at the University of Michigan, gives a talk titled "How Should We Think About Developmental Contexts?"

Summary: Mindful restaurant eating is topic of Nursing School talk
Description: Dr. Gayle Timmerman, PhD, RN, CSN, presents lessons learned and outcomes of her widely disseminated pilot study on mindful restaurant eating. Are you interested in eating out without gaining weight? This intervention addresses the issue of weight gain prevention. A mindful eating exercise is included. Timmerman is associate professor and associate dean for Academic Relations, UT School of Nursing.

Summary: Victor Mendez gives Distinguished Lecture in Transportation
Description:
The Center for Transportation Research (CTR) is proud to announce the Texas Distinguished Lecture Series in Transportation, presenting the latest thinking and challenges in the field of transportation. Victor Mendez, FHWA administrator, gives the inaugural lecture, "Pursuing Innovation in Transportation."

A reception follows.

Summary: MFA Actor Showcase held
Description: The M.F.A. in Acting graduating class of 2013 displays its talents in this Austin showcase. Seating is limited.

Summary: Reception held for MFA studio art exhibition
Description: Join the Department of Art and Art History for a reception celebrating the 2013 MFA studio art exhibition.

Summary: Texas baseball takes on Kansas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor the Kansas State Wildcats. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Chris Tucker brings stand-up show to Bass Concert Hall
Description: Actor and comedian Chris Tucker's trademark style, incomparable delivery, impeccable comedic timing and signature voice make him one of today's premiere entertainers.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: MFA graduation reading hosted by Michener Center
Description: Spring graduates of the Masters of Fine Arts in Writing of the Michener Center for Writers read from their work. Hear Jeffrey Bruemmer, Chanel Clarke, Kevin Kautzman, Brad Kelly, Monica Macansantos, Greg Marshall, Mary Miller, Matthew Moore, Chad Nichols, Sarah Saltwick, Bradley Harrison Smith and Claire Sylvester Smith.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Texas Ballroom & Texas 4000 host Dancing with the Stars UT
Description: UT stars pair up with dance instructors to compete in the UT edition of Dancing with the Stars. All proceeds donated toward Texas 4000's goal of $600,000 for cancer research. Raffle tickets sold at $1 each. Prizes include four weeks of dancing for a couple and one month of unlimited tango classes.

Summary: UT Micro Farm workday announced
Description: Participate in planting the first crops at the UT Micro Farm, UT's first student-run sustainable farm. All ages and skill levels invited. Tools and supplies provided, but additional construction tools welcome. Closed-toed shoes required; don't forget water and work gloves. Contact microfarm@utenvironment.org with questions.

Summary: Fifth Language Creation Conference (LCC5) slated
Description: The fifth Language Creation Conference comes to Austin, hosted by the Language Creation Society at The University of Texas at Austin, a chapter of the national Language Creation Society. Join us for a weekend of interesting and engaging presentations from linguists and conlangers from all over.

Summary: "PORTFOLIO" celebrates performance design & technology
Description: The University of Texas at Austin Department of Theatre and Dance presents "PORTFOLIO 2013," an exciting exhibition celebrating the work of emerging artists in costume design, lighting design, scenery, media and technology. Come see how imagination manifests itself on stage and film.
Location: Winship Drama Building (WIN), Oscar G. Brockett Theatre

Summary: Texas baseball plays Kansas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor the Kansas State Wildcats. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in this in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Texas baseball competes against Kansas State
Description: Texas baseball hosts Big 12 competitor the Kansas State Wildcats in game three of a series. Visit bevosbargains.com for special ticket deals for this event.

Summary: Music at the Blanton: Jazz trio celebrates expressionism
Description: Pianist Jeff Helmer leads a faculty trio from the UT Butler School of Music through improvisations inspired by the expressionist era in art and music.

Summary: Blanton holds Restoration and Revelation tour
Description: Masterful artistry, precise science and careful research come together in this in-depth, focused look at how museums care for and protect centuries-old works of art.

Summary: Employee Engagement talk asks why good people do bad things
Description: Do you ever wonder "What were they thinking?" when you hear about scandal and dishonesty?  This fascinating session looks at why people sometimes slip into unethical situations. By learning how this can happen, participants increase their awareness of the ethical implications of our behavior in everyday life.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Institute for Historical Studies presents Denise Spellberg
Description: "U.S. Treaties, Their Problematic Translations, and U.S. Diplomatic Relations with North Africa" is a talk by Dr. Denise A. Spellberg, associate professor of history and Middle Eastern studies at The University of Texas at Austin.

Summary: Natural products explored as probes of the pain pathway
Description:
The Lorene Morrow Kelley Distinguished Lecture Series welcomes David Julius, Ph.D., delivering his talk, "From Peppers to Pit Vipers: Natural Products as Probes of the Pain Pathway."



Julius is chair of the Department of Physiology at the University of California, San Francisco. His research focuses on the molecular biology of sensory transduction and neurotransmitter action in the mammalian nervous system. His goal is to understand the molecular basis of somatosensation - the process whereby we experience touch and temperature - with an emphasis on identifying molecules that detect noxious (pain-producing) stimuli. He is also interested in understanding how somatosensation is altered in response to tissue or nerve injury.



The Lorene Morrow Kelley Lectureship was established with gifts by Lorene Kelley Morrow to honor her sister, Marie Betzner Morrow, who at the time of her death in 1971 was an associate professor of microbiology at The University of Texas at Austin.
Location: Applied Computational Engineering & Sciences Building (ACE), Avaya Auditorium 2.302

Summary: Nonprofit expert explores trends reshaping social sector
Description: The RGK Center hosts a public lecture by David La Piana, an expert in nonprofit management and governance. In "Convergence: How Five Trends Will Reshape the Social Sector," La Piana explains how the nonprofit sector is being transformed by a broad range of trends, and explores the impact they will have on the future of the social sector.
Location: Blanton Museum of Art, Edgar A. Smith Building (EAS), auditorium

Summary: PCL Spring Bake Sale held
Description: No time to cook or bake? Support Caritas of Austin by stopping by for a delicious treat donated by the UT Libraries staff.

Summary: Water, Technology and Policy course offered
Description: The Water Technology and Policy course gives students an overview of water and its role in society. The program includes an introduction to quantitative concepts in water; differences among treatment methods and technologies; infrastructure; and societal aspects both domestic and international. Emphasis is also given to the role of water in Texas.
Location: IC2 Institute, 2815 San Gabriel Street, and online

Summary: Fine Arts Career Services presents Grades to Green
Description: Graduating this semester? FACS announces its semiannual Grades to Green workshop, addressing how academic success can help you in your career. Strengthen your business etiquette, sharpen your networking skills and improve your resume. Lunch provided. Register at the link below. Contact FACS at 512-232-7333 or facs@austin.utexas.edu with questions.
Location: Doty Fine Arts Building (DFA), Co-Op Student Lounge 1.101

Summary: ReaSports hosts Splash Bash Study Break
Description: UT students are invited to take a break from the books at the beautiful Gregory Gym Aquatic Complex. Relax by the pool with DJ music, food and snack bags, a chair massage, group meditation classes, a water Zumba exercise class and more. Bring your swimsuit. All events free.

Summary: Roadmap for careers in the 21st century is forum topic
Description: "Surviving the 21st Century as a Thought Worker" is the title of a presentation by Jennifer Bullard, chair of the Austin Chapter of the International Game Developers Association. The video game industry is one of the most rapidly changing and innovating industries in technology. Bullard discusses the skills necessary to survive and thrive in a 21st-century career.
Location: AT&T Executive Education and Conference Center (ATT), amphitheater

Summary: "Priscilla Queen of the Desert" comes to campus stage
Description: This outrageously fun show tells the uplifting story of a trio of friends on the road trip of a lifetime who hop aboard a battered old bus searching for love and friendship in the middle of the Australian outback and end up finding more than they could ever have dreamed of. Recommended for ages 13 and up due to mature language and situations.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: The Cyprus Bank Deposit Confiscation-Is Your Money Safe Anywhere?
Description: Finance professor Lew Spellman presents "The Cyprus Bank Deposit Confiscation: Is Your Money Safe Anywhere?" - a talk on the impact of the Cypriot bank crisis, U.S. government debt, private wealth, global wealth reallocation, government bond purchasing and sovereign debt. Presented as part of the Texas Enterprise Speaker Series.

Summary: Works on paper in "Through the Eyes of Texas" explored
Description: Works on paper in "Through the Eyes of Texas: Masterworks from Alumni Collections" are discussed by Francesca Consagra, the Blanton's senior curator of prints and drawings and European paintings, and curatorial associate Catherine Zinser.

Summary: "Priscilla Queen of the Desert" matinee performed
Description: This outrageously fun show tells the uplifting story of a trio of friends on the road trip of a lifetime who hop aboard a battered old bus searching for love and friendship in the middle of the Australian outback and end up finding more than they could ever have dreamed of. Recommended for ages 13 and up due to mature language and situations.
Location: Performing Arts Center (PAC), Bass Concert Hall

Summary: Tour "Through the Eyes of Texas" at Blanton Museum
Description: To celebrate the Blanton's 50th anniversary, University of Texas at Austin alumni have loaned the museum over 100 extraordinary objects spanning centuries, cultures and artistic periods. View these works in the "Through the Eyes of Texas" exhibit.

Summary: Blanton's "Persuasion" tour explores messages in art
Description: A picture is worth a thousand words, the adage goes. From the church-sponsored art of the 17th century to contemporary artists reflecting on war, poverty and politics, artists have long sought to persuade the masses. Tour the Blanton Museum of Art's permanent collection and examine how artists have communicated messages and meaning from the beginning of time.

Summary: Tour Blanton's "Changing American Landscape" exhibit
Description: The wide-open spaces of the American West have beckoned artists since the 19th century. Trace the development of landscape painting from its roots in Europe to its culmination in the 21st century during this tour that features the C.R. Smith Collection of Western Art.

Summary: Symbol and allegory in art explored in Blanton tour
Description: Have you ever wondered what artists had in mind when they created an artwork? How did audiences recognize messages encoded into works of art? This illuminating glimpse into the hidden language of the artists will take you through the Europe of centuries past.

Summary: Lifelike: Exhibit explores realism in contemporary art
Description: Explore how contemporary artists address realism in this playful, eclectic exhibition organized by the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. Works by Vija Celmins, Chuck Close, Gerhard Richter and Ai Weiwei are among the 80 objects and installations in this thought-provoking exhibition.
